title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: It was released on April 8, 2012, by Interscope Records as the third single from the record.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: Produced by Emile Haynie, the song was written by Del Rey, Haynie, and Dan Heath.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: It is a downtempo ballad with hip hop influences.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: A controversial performance of the song on "SNL" placed Del Rey under scrutiny and polarized opinion.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: Charting across Europe and Asia, "Blue Jeans" reached the top 10 in Belgium, Poland, and Israel.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: Two music videos were created for the song.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: The first was self-produced.

title: Blue Jeans (Lana Del Rey song)
text: The second was shot and directed by Yoann Lemoine, featuring film noir elements and crocodiles.

title: Nusretiye Clock Tower
text: Nusretiye Clock Tower, aka Tophane Clock Tower, is a clock tower situated in Tophane, a neighborhood in Beyoğlu district of Istanbul, Turkey next to Nusretiye Mosque and Tophane Kiosk at the European waterfront of Bosphorus.

title: Nusretiye Clock Tower
text: It was ordered by the Ottoman sultan Abdülmecid I (1823-1861), designed by architect Garabet Amira Balyan and completed in 1848.

title: Tashkopryu Mosque
text: Tashkyopryu Mosque (Bulgarian: Ташкьопрю джамия "Tashkyopryu Dzhamiya", Turkish: "Taşköprü Camii") is a mosque in Plovdiv, Bulgaria , built by Ottoman Turks in 16th century during their 500-year rule in today's Bulgaria.

title: Tashkopryu Mosque
text: It is currently the third mosque in Plovdiv which is in good condition after Dzhumaya Mosque and Imaret Mosque.

title: Tashkopryu Mosque
text: It is currently inactive despite efforts and demands, mainly by Turks of Bulgaria, to give active status for it.

title: Kumanovo Clock Tower
text: Kumanovo Clock Tower (Macedonian: Саат Кула Куманово ) was a clock tower in Kumanovo, Ottoman Empire (today Republic of Macedonia).

title: Kumanovo Clock Tower
text: The tower is believed to have existed since the second half of the 18th century but there are now known historical facts.

title: Kumanovo Clock Tower
text: It was near Eski Mosque in the former Orta Bunar Neighborhood (Macedonian: Орта Бунар Маало ).

title: Kumanovo Clock Tower
text: It was demolished after the Second World War.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: On 22 June 1954 The foundation stone of this great mosque was laid in a religious customs.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: That day fell on the birth day of Ali al-Ridha, eighth Imam of shia.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: The construction of it was ended in 1961.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: Azam mosque had been built basis on the Islamic architecture.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: This mosque made of four prayer halls and three towering balconies.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: The diameter of the large dome of the mosque is 30 metres and its height above the roof of the mosque is 15 metres and 35 metres from the basement of the mosque.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: The minarets of the mosque has 25 metres length above the roof of the mosque and 45 metres from the basement of the mosque.

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: The upper part of the minarets is 5 metres .

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: It has special section and used to call to prayers (A'zaan).

title: Azam mosque of Qom
text: A towering clock tower with a big clock is located in the north of the mosque and this tower can be seen from all the four sides of the mosque.

title: Galle Clock Tower
text: The Galle Clock Tower (or Anthonisz Memorial Clock Tower) is located within the Galle Fort in Galle, Sri Lanka.

title: Galle Clock Tower
text: The Clock Tower is a popular landmark and overlooks the central Moon Bastion, on the site of the former guard room.

title: Galle Clock Tower
text: The Clock Tower was constructed in 1883, paid for through public subscriptions by the people of Galle, in recognition of Dr. P. D. Anthonisz.

title: Galle Clock Tower
text: The clock itself was the sole gift of a grateful patient, Mudaliyar Samson de Abrew Rajapakse.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: Hysen Pasha Mosque (Albanian: "Xhamia e Hysen Pashës" ) or Clock Mosque "(Xhamia e Sahatit)" is a Cultural Monument of Albania, located in Berat.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: It was built in 1670 by Hussein Pasha.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: It is named Clock Mosque because in 1870 the Ottomans built a clock tower next to it.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: The clock tower was destroyed during the Communist dictatorship in 1967.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: The mosque also got destroyed with the minaret being the only part left over.

title: Hysen Pasha Mosque
text: After the end of Communism the mosque got renovated.

title: Clock Tower, Brighton
text: The Clock Tower (sometimes called the Jubilee Clock Tower) is a free-standing clock tower in the centre of Brighton, part of the English city of Brighton and Hove.

title: Clock Tower, Brighton
text: Built in 1888 in commemoration of Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee, the distinctive structure included innovative structural features and became a landmark in the popular and fashionable seaside resort.

title: Clock Tower, Brighton
text: The city's residents "retain a nostalgic affection" for it, even though opinion is sharply divided as to the tower's architectural merit.

title: Clock Tower, Brighton
text: English Heritage has listed the clock tower at Grade II for its architectural and historical importance.

title: Birgu Clock Tower
text: The Birgu Clock Tower (Maltese: "It-Torri tal-Arloġġ tal-Birgu" ), also called the "Vittoriosa Clock Tower" and originally the Civic Clock Tower, was a clock tower in Birgu, Malta.

title: Birgu Clock Tower
text: It was located in Victory Square, the city's main square, and it was a prominent landmark in Birgu and the rest of the Three Cities.

title: Birgu Clock Tower
text: The tower was probably built in the Middle Ages, although some sources state that it was constructed in 1549.

title: Birgu Clock Tower
text: It served as a watchtower since it had views over the Grand Harbour and the surrounding countryside, and it saw use during the Great Siege of Malta in 1565.

title: Birgu Clock Tower
text: A clock was installed in the tower in the 17th century.

title: Eski Imaret Mosque
text: Eski Imaret Mosque (Turkish: "Eski Imaret Camii" ) is a former Eastern Orthodox church converted into a mosque by the Ottomans.

title: Eski Imaret Mosque
text: The church has traditionally been identified with that belonging to the Monastery of Christ Pantepoptes (Greek: Μονή του Χριστού Παντεπόπτη ), meaning "Christ the all-seeing".

title: Eski Imaret Mosque
text: It is the only documented 11th-century church in Istanbul which survives intact, and represents a key monument of middle Byzantine architecture.

title: Eski Imaret Mosque
text: Despite that, the building remains one among the least studied of the city.

title: Clock Tower of Murshidabad
text: The Clock Tower of Murshidabad (locally known just as "Clock Tower" or "Ghari Ghar", also known as "Big Ben of Murshidabad") is a clock tower in the Nizamat Fort Campus in West Bengal, India.

title: Clock Tower of Murshidabad
text: The clock tower stands in the garden space between the Nizamat Imambara and the Hazarduari Palace; to its east, hardly a few feet away, is the old Madina Mosque and the Bacchawali Tope.

title: Grand Ole Opry
text: The Grand Ole Opry is a weekly country-music stage concert in Nashville, Tennessee, which was founded on November 28, 1925, by George D. Hay as a one-hour radio "barn dance" on WSM.

title: Grand Ole Opry
text: Currently owned and operated by Opry Entertainment (a division of Ryman Hospitality Properties, Inc.), it is the longest-running radio broadcast in US history, albeit not the longest-running one on a radio network.

title: Grand Ole Opry
text: Dedicated to honoring country music and its history, the Opry showcases a mix of famous singers and contemporary chart-toppers performing country, bluegrass, Americana, folk, gospel, and comedic performances and skits.

title: Grand Ole Opry
text: It attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors from around the world and millions of radio and Internet listeners.

title: John England & the Western Swingers
text: John England & the Western Swingers is a six piece Nashville, Tennessee band that plays Western swing.

title: John England & the Western Swingers
text: The group has played at Nashville's Robert's Western World every Monday since July 2001.

title: John England & the Western Swingers
text: The Swingers have also performed at New York's Lincoln Center, the Grand Ole Opry, the Legends of Western Swing Festival, the Ernest Tubb Record Shop's "Midnight Jamboree", and has been profiled by Downbeat magazine, the Nashville Tennessean, and other print media.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Bradley Gaskin (born in Gadsden, Alabama) is an American country music singer-songwriter.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: He signed with Columbia Nashville in 2011 and has released his debut single, "Mr. Bartender" after being discovered through a talent contest sponsored by John Rich.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: At the time, Gaskin had been working for his father hanging sheetrock.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: The song entered the Hot Country Songs charts at number 51 on the chart dated for the week ending April 2, 2011.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: He made his Grand Ole Opry debut on August 20th, 2011.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: After a corporate restructuring, Gaskin moved to Columbia Records to release his second single, "Diamonds Make Babies".

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: On June 4, 2012, it was announced that Sony Nashville was retiring the BNA label and moving its roster to Columbia Nashville.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Gaskin was dropped from the label following this move.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Gaskin spent much of 2012 touring with Big & Rich, typically performing "Mr. Bartender" as well as a cover of Keith Whitley's "Don't Close Your Eyes".

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Gaskin had plans for releasing a version of the Keith Whitley song prior to the problems that arose with his label.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Gaskin wrote a Tate Stevens "Power of a Love Song" in 2013.

title: Bradley Gaskin
text: Bradley performed "Don't Close Your Eyes" during a Grand Ole Opry performance on October 30, 2015.

title: Infinity Cat Recordings
text: Infinity Cat Recordings is an independent record label founded in 2002 and based in Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Infinity Cat Recordings
text: The label has released recordings from artists including JEFF the Brotherhood, Diarrhea Planet, Be Your Own Pet, Ed Schrader's Music Beat, and Daddy Issues.

title: Infinity Cat Recordings
text: In 2011, the label was highlighted by British publication The Guardian, which wrote "forget the Grand Ole Opry; there are more thrilling new bands in East Nashville than anywhere else on earth  so many of their records have been released on the same label, Infinity Cat."

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Nashville Terminal Subdivision is a railroad line owned by CSX Transportation in the U.S. State of Tennessee.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Subdivision is broken up into 5 sections all in Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The northern part of the Terminal is in Madison, Tennessee at milepost 000/0BA 174 on the southern end of the Ex-L&N Mainline Subdivision at Monfort.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Disptach for the Mainline Sub is known as "LD" which is part of the Cincinnati Division.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From here in Madison begins the double track that stays for another 22 miles south to Brentwood, Tennessee.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At milepost 000/0BA/00H 176.6, the famous Johnny Cash "Amqui" location where the Ex-L&N Evansville, Indiana line, the Henderson Subdivision meets with the Terminal.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Dispatch for the Henderson Sub is known as "SA" and operates on AAR58.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: There are two crossings near each other, Williams Ave and Nesbitt Lane at Amqui.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From here the Terminal goes south about 2 miles to the Nashville National Cemetery to the first major location, known as Ekin, 000179, where there is a cross over track from number 1 to number 2 track (left to right track).

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: There is also the first EDD (Defect Detector) at 000179.1.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Few more miles southward, the next major location appears.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At 000181.0, Maplewood is a major location for the Terminal.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From here the regular Terminal goes south to swap crews at Kayne Ave, and the right side, Radnor Cutoff, detours the city and gives yard departures and arrivals direct access to and from Radnor yard to cities like Louisville and Chicago.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Cutoff runs from Maplewood to Shelby Park double track.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From Shebly the track converges into one to pass the historic Shelby bridge, then it opens back to double track.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From there, the cutoff hits the Intermediates at 0BA187.0 known as Chicken Pike.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Radnor Cutoff carries the L&N mainline classification of "0BA" but meets the main at the same milepost from the Terminal.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At Chicken Pike, trains are staged to await arrival to Radnor yard.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Once they get clearance, speed is decreased to 15, and at 0BA188.1 the EDD (Defect Detector) sounds for departures and arrivals.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This location is known as North Radnor.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The right track diverging from the #2 is known as A-1, it is for departure trains to Chattanooga and Atlanta.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The left track which goes west from the #1 is known as A-2, and serves as a departure track to Memphis, and if the cutoff is out of service, all northbound departures.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The interesting piece of Maplewood is the crossovers that are there to move trains from the Cutoff to the Main.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Both lines remain double track for a while.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The main runs south for 2 more miles until the Intermediate signals at 000183.0.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Commonly trains will stop before Delmas Ave when Kayne Ave is at capacity and await dispatch permission before moving south.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From here, the main continues south until the CR Cumberland River Swingbridge, where the main converges into a single track shortly to cross the bridge.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At this point, trains had been running at track speed of around 40.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From the drawbridge into town, speed is reduced to around 10.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: After the bridge is passed, the main returns to double track in downtown.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: On the #1 track about a half a mile south, another connecting track is present.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This is the Wye track that connects the main with the Bruceton side, while rarely used for mainline trains, locals and river jobs use it.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The location is known as 8th Avenue or 8th Avenue Wye.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The main then runs down to Kayne Ave, the central hotbed of all Nashville thru traffic.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Memphis, Tennessee Ex-L&N Bruceton Subdivision meets with the Terminal.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Bruceton Sub begins at Church Street at 00N0.0.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The line then runs single track until 00N0.7 "11th Avenue" where it turns into double track and also meets the aforementioned, Wye track.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Bruceton line then goes southwest a while to the next signals, at "Shops".

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Now speed has been increased.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The line is still double track until "Sellars", where speed is increased to 40 and jurisdiction transferred to the SD Dispatcher.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: For a short time, 4 main tracks are present and an additional fifth track for switchers and yard movements.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The tracks from left to right in Kayne Ave are as follows: 100, 99, 98, 12, 3.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Kayne Ave yard is also here in this area, which houses some frieght and some switcher engines.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The tracks to the old shed are covered and removed.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Union Station is not an active station, but a historic hotel.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Crew change usually occurs at the "walkway" which is under the Demombreun St bridge by the Kayne Ave Tower.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This is also where the Ex-NC&StL Chattanooga Subdivision begins.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Then tracks run south to Fogg St/South End where things get complicated.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At milepost 000/0BA/00J187 the 98 track merges into the 12 track, making for 3 tracks now.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: There is a crossover from 99 to 12, also a crossover from 12 to 3.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: About 2/10ths of a mile down the 99 merges into the 12 track reducing the tracks back to the regular double.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: About 4/10ths of a mile down the line from Fogg St, 000187.4, Oak St, is a crossover track from #2 to #1 (the track names are no longer 3 and 12, but are back to regular names).

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: When trains use this crossover northbound, such as Memphis bound trains from the A-2 line, they refer to it as "Long Lead".

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: And now, the Terminal splits into two parts.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The right side turns into a single track shortly, and will become the Chattanooga Subdivision, and the left side runs south to Brentwood.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The right track runs single shortly until double track for a while.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This begins part of the Chattanooga Sub or J-Line.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The #2 meets with the A-2 connection track at 00J2.2 known as A-2.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Speed is now increased to 40.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Commonly northbounds will stage at 4th Ave on the #1 to await clearance.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Now about a mile down the #1 meets the A-1 connection line.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At 00J3.6 known as A-1.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Further down the double track ends at Glencliff (00J4.9).

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Now it runs single for three miles until it hits Danley, which has the D Line connection track, which is an arrival track for incoming Radnor trains from the J Line.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At Danley, the Terminal ends but the same dispatcher handles traffic, "SC".

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At Oak Street, our main terminal line goes south two miles to 000189.0 known as Criaghead or Vine Hill.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: There is a crossover here from #1 to #2 track.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: And there is also a connection/delivery track to the Nashville and Eastern Railroad which connects the Tennessee Central Railroad Museum to a major railroad.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Trains sometimes stop on the #2 before Craighead if they are waiting to enter Radnor yard.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Sometimes trains wait on the #1 at the Berry Road crossing if they await arrival to Kayne Ave. At this point, speed has been increased to 30 from 10.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Moving south, the line hits Radnor Yard at 000192.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The #2 track meets the E-Line arrival track which most Memphis trains and locals use.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The B-Line which meets the #1 track is used for departures out of the C yard and local jobs.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: At Mayton, 000192.3, the B line meets the #1 track, and there is a crossover track from #2 to #1.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Speed is now at 40.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: 2 miles south, at 000194.0, South Radnor, the next intersection is present.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This is where the Radnor A yard meets the main.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: There is a single departure/arrival track that meets the #2 track along with a crossover from #1 to #2 track.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Commonly, the #2 track south of the signals is used to halt trains.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: This location is known as TVA, because of the power station that is adjacent.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: From here the Terminal runs about 2.5 miles south until we hit the southern tip.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The tracks converge onto one single main, at 000/0BA196.6 known as Brentwood.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: Speed is increased to 50 and jurisdiction to the S.E. dispatcher.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The right track is the main, S&NA North, while the left track is the Nashville Subdivision which runs to Columbia and exchanges freight with the TSRR.

title: Nashville Terminal Subdivision
text: The Nashville Terminal Subdivision is one of the busiest locations on the CSX network, and one of the most important.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys were an American bluegrass act widely considered to be among the first to cultivate the duo harmony vocal technique widely used in modern bluegrass music today.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: Charlie Bailey (February 11, 1916 in Happy Valley, Tennessee, near Rogersville – March 12, 2004 in Bear, Delaware) began his musical career in 1936.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: His brother, Danny Bailey (December 1, 1919, Happy Valley, Tennessee – March 22, 2004, Knoxville, Tennessee), teamed up with him in 1940, and the brothers began making frequent appearances on Tennessee radio stations in the Knoxville area.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: Danny formed the Happy Valley Boys after Charlie joined the military in 1941.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: In 1944 the Happy Valley Boys relocated to Nashville, where they became members of the Grand Ole Opry, and also made regular appearances on WSM radio in Nashville.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: At that time, Danny was the youngest person to ever perform on the Grand Ole Opry.

title: The Bailey Brothers and the Happy Valley Boys
text: When Charlie returned from his military service in 1946 the brothers were reunited as a duo but only stayed in Nashville briefly before returning to radio work in Knoxville.

title: Music City Queen
text: Music City Queen was a replica showboat formerly operating for entertainment purposes on the Cumberland River in the southern United States.

title: Music City Queen
text: It was the smaller of two stern-wheel paddle steamers based at Opry Mills in Nashville, Tennessee; the other is the "General Jackson".

title: Ryman Auditorium
text: Ryman Auditorium (formerly Grand Ole Opry House and Union Gospel Tabernacle) is a 2,362-seat live performance venue, located at 116 5th Avenue North, in Nashville, Tennessee and is best known as the home of the "Grand Ole Opry" from 1943 to 1974.

title: Ryman Auditorium
text: It is owned and operated by Ryman Hospitality Properties, Inc.

title: Opry Mills
text: Opry Mills is a super-regional shopping mall owned by Simon Property Group, formerly by its initial owners Mills Corporation and Gaylord Entertainment.

title: Opry Mills
text: It opened in Nashville, Tennessee in 2000 on the former site of the Opryland USA theme park.

title: Keith Bilbrey
text: Keith Bilbrey (born August 14, 1952) is an American country music disc jockey and television host in Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Keith Bilbrey
text: He served as a disc jockey at Nashville's WSM, as an announcer on the Grand Ole Opry, and as the host of TNN’s Grand Ole Opry Live.

title: 2011 Inner Mongolia unrest
text: On the night of May 10, 2011 an ethnic Mongol herdsman was killed by a coal truck driver near Xilinhot, Inner Mongolia, China.

title: 2011 Inner Mongolia unrest
text: The incident, alongside grievances over mining development in the region and the perceived erosion of traditional lifestyle of indigenous peoples, led to a series of Mongol protests across Inner Mongolia.

title: 2011 Inner Mongolia unrest
text: Some 2000 students participated in protests at Communist Party headquarters of the West Ujimqin Banner, followed by demonstrations by secondary school students in the Xilinhot area.

title: 2011 Inner Mongolia unrest
text: Select secondary schools and universities with large ethnic Mongol populations were reportedly under "lockdown".

title: 2011 Inner Mongolia unrest
text: The Inner Mongolia government under Hu Chunhua tightened security in Inner Mongolian cities, including dispatching People's Armed Police troops to central Hohhot.

title: Inner Mongolia Normal University
text: Inner Mongolia Normal University (, Mongolian: ) is a university in Inner Mongolia, People's Republic of China under the authority of the Autonomous Region government.

title: Inner Mongolia Normal University
text: It is located in Hohhot, the capital city of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

title: Inner Mongolia Agricultural University
text: Inner Mongolia Agricultural University (IMAU, , Mongolian: ) is a university in Hohhot, Inner Mongolia, China under the authority of the Autonomous Region government.

title: Inner Mongolia Agricultural University
text: It is located in Hohhot, the capital city of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

title: Inner Mongolia Agricultural University
text: It was established in 1952.

title: G5511 Jining–Arun Expressway
text: The Jining–Arun Expressway (), commonly referred to as the "Ji'a Expressway" () is a planned expressway that will connect Arun Banner, Hulunbuir, Inner Mongolia, China, and Jining District, Ulanqab, Inner Mongolia.

title: G5511 Jining–Arun Expressway
text: The expressway is a spur of G55 Erenhot–Guangzhou Expressway and will be completely in Inner Mongolia.

title: G5511 Jining–Arun Expressway
text: The expressway is currently in the planning stages.

title: Inner Mongolia First Machinery Group Corporation
text: Inner Mongolia First Machinery Group Corporation (内蒙古第一机械集团有限公司, abbrev.

title: Inner Mongolia First Machinery Group Corporation
text: 一机), previously First Inner Mongolia Machinery Factory, is a military manufacturing company in China.

title: Inner Mongolia First Machinery Group Corporation
text: It is a facility in Inner Mongolia and supplier of various military equipment to the PLA Army.

title: Inner Mongolia First Machinery Group Corporation
text: It has also been known as Factory 617 (六一七厂) and the Baotou Tank Plant.

title: Inner Mongolia University of Technology
text: Inner Mongolia University of Technology (IMUT)() is a university in Inner Mongolia, People's Republic of China, under the authority of the Autonomous Region government.

title: Inner Mongolia University of Technology
text: It was founded in 1951 and was originally known as the Suiyuan Higher Technical School (绥远省高级工业学校) and then after 1958 the Inner Mongolia Polytechnic Institute (内蒙古工学院) before changing to its current name in 1993.

title: Inner Mongolia University of Technology
text: It is located in north part of Hohhot, the capital city of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

title: Bu Xiaolin
text: Bu Xiaolin (; born August 1958) is a Chinese politician of Mongol descent.

title: Bu Xiaolin
text: She has served as Chairwoman (governor) of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region since March 2016.

title: Bu Xiaolin
text: She is the daughter of Buhe, a former chairman of Inner Mongolia, and the granddaughter of Ulanhu, the founding chairman of Inner Mongolia and a vice-president of China.

title: Ejin–Hami Railway
text: Ejin–Hami Railway or Eha Railway (), is a railway in western China between Ejin Banner in Alxa League of western Inner Mongolia and the city of Hami in the eastern part of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region.

title: Ejin–Hami Railway
text: The line runs 644 km through the deserts near the Mongolian border.

title: Ejin–Hami Railway
text: Apart from Inner Mongolia and Xinjiang, the line also crosses the Subei Mongol Autonomous County, the sliver of Gansu Province that extends to the Mongolian border.

title: Ejin–Hami Railway
text: Construction began on June 30, 2014 and was slated to take three years, but the line opened only 17 months later on December 1, 2015.

title: Ejin–Hami Railway
text: The opening of this rail line shortened the distance by rail from Hohhot, Inner Mongolia's capital, to destinations in Xinjiang and Kazakhstan by over 800 km.

title: Inner Mongolia Medical University
text: Inner Mongolia Medical University (内蒙古医科大学) is a university in Inner Mongolia, China under the authority of the Autonomous Region government.

title: Inner Mongolia Medical University
text: It is located in Hohhot, the capital city of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

title: Inner Mongolia Medical University
text: It was renamed from Inner Mongolia Medical College in 2012.

title: Zhukaigou culture
text: The Zhukaigou culture was a late Neolithic and early Bronze Age culture centered in the Ordos Plateau of Inner Mongolia, China.

title: Zhukaigou culture
text: The type site at Zhukaigou was discovered in Ejin Horo Banner, Inner Mongolia, and excavated from 1977 to 1984.

title: Zhukaigou culture
text: Zhukaigou culture is a reputed progenitor of the Ordos bronze culture and accordingly a first "Northern Zone" culture, extending to northern and central Inner Mongolia, northern Shaanxi, and northern Shanxi, with the Ordos region at its center.

title: Zhukaigou culture
text: Transition to metalworking is dated to around the end of the third millennium BCE, at the same time was attained a higher level in the ceramic.

title: Zhukaigou culture
text: Zhukaigou culture lasted to ca. 1500 BCE.

title: Chris Marker
text: Chris Marker (] ; 29 July 1921 – 29 July 2012) was a French writer, photographer, documentary film director, multimedia artist and film essayist.

title: Chris Marker
text: His best known films are "La Jetée" (1962), "Le Joli Mai" (1963), "A Grin Without a Cat" (1977) and "Sans Soleil" (1983).

title: Chris Marker
text: Marker is often associated with the Left Bank Cinema movement that occurred in the late 1950s and included such other filmmakers as Alain Resnais, Agnès Varda, Henri Colpi and Armand Gatti.

title: Last Year at Marienbad
text: L'Année dernière à Marienbad (released in the US as Last Year at Marienbad and in the UK as Last Year in Marienbad) is a 1961 French-Italian film directed by Alain Resnais from a screenplay by Alain Robbe-Grillet.

title: Alain Resnais
text: Alain Resnais (] ; 3 June 19221 March 2014) was a French film director and screenwriter whose career extended over more than six decades.

title: Alain Resnais
text: After training as a film editor in the mid-1940s, he went on to direct a number of short films which included "Night and Fog" (1955), an influential documentary about the Nazi concentration camps.

title: Giovanni Fusco
text: Giovanni Fusco (10 October 1906, Sant'Agata dei Goti, Benevento – 31 May 1968, Rome) was an Italian composer, pianist and conductor, who has written numerous film scores since 1936, including those of Alain Resnais's "Hiroshima mon amour" (1959) and "La guerre est finie" (1966), as well as of most of the 1948-1964 films directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, from "N.U." ("Nettezza Urbana") to "Il deserto rosso", except for "La notte" (soundtrack by Giorgio Gaslini) and some of his early short films.

title: Giovanni Fusco
text: Two of his soundtracks, those of Antonioni's "Cronaca di un amore" and "L'avventura", won Silver Ribbon for the best film score from Italian National Syndicate of Film Journalists in 1951 and 1961, respectively.

title: Muriel (film)
text: Muriel (French: Muriel ou le Temps d'un retour , literally "Muriel, or the Time of a Return") is a 1963 French film directed by Alain Resnais.

title: Muriel (film)
text: It was Resnais's third feature film, following "Hiroshima mon amour" (1959) and "L'Année dernière à Marienbad" (1961), and in common with those films it explores the challenge of integrating a remembered or imagined past with the life of the present.

title: Muriel (film)
text: It also makes oblique reference to the controversial subject of the Algerian War, which had recently been brought to an end.

title: Muriel (film)
text: "Muriel" was Resnais's second collaboration with Jean Cayrol, who had also written the screenplay of "Nuit et brouillard" ("Night and Fog") (1955).

title: Life of Riley (2014 film)
text: Life of Riley (French: Aimer, boire et chanter ) is a 2014 French comedy-drama film directed by Alain Resnais in his final feature film before his death.

title: Life of Riley (2014 film)
text: Adapted from the play "Life of Riley" by Alan Ayckbourn, the film had its premiere in the competition section of the 64th Berlin International Film Festival, just three weeks before Resnais died, where it won the Alfred Bauer Prize.

title: Hiroshima mon amour
text: Hiroshima mon amour (] , "Hiroshima My Love"; Japanese: 二十四時間の情事 "Nijūyojikan'nojōji", "Twenty-four-hour affair") is a 1959 drama film directed by French film director Alain Resnais, with a screenplay by Marguerite Duras.

title: Hiroshima mon amour
text: It is the documentation of an intensely personal conversation between a French-Japanese couple about memory and forgetfulness.

title: Hiroshima mon amour
text: It was a major catalyst for the Left Bank Cinema, making highly innovative use of miniature flashbacks to create a uniquely nonlinear storyline.

title: The War Is Over (film)
text: The War is Over (French: La Guerre est Finie -1966) is a French drama film about a leftist in Franco's Spain, directed by Alain Resnais and starring Yves Montand, Ingrid Thulin, and Geneviève Bujold.

title: The War Is Over (film)
text: Joseph Losey directed a sequel, "Roads to the South" (French: "Les Routes du Sud" -1978).

title: Isle of Flowers
text: Isle of Flowers (Portuguese: Ilha das Flores ) is a 1989 Brazilian short film by Jorge Furtado.

title: Isle of Flowers
text: It tracks the path of a tomato from garden to dump with the help of a monotone voiceover and a collection of bizarre images.

title: Isle of Flowers
text: While a very humorous film, the message it delivers about how human beings treat each other is anything but such.

title: Isle of Flowers
text: The director himself has stated that the film was inspired by the works of Kurt Vonnegut and Alain Resnais, among others.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: Julián Hernández (born 1972 in Mexico City, Mexico as Julián Hernández Pérez) is a Mexican multi-awarded filmmaker.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: He won twice the Teddy Award at Berlin Film Festival with his movies" Thousand Clouds of Peace Fence the Sky, Love, Your Being Love Will Never End " (2003), and "Raging Sun, Raging Sky ("2009).

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: He studied at the Centro Universitario de Estudios Cinematográficos (CUEC), from where he was expelled due to his gay-themed films during a homophobic administration, and was not mentioned as a serious director until he started winning international recognition.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: He has credited his use of cinematographic language to influences from filmmakers such as Michelangelo Antonioni, Leonardo Favio, Robert Bresson, and Alain Resnais.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: Hernández has directed more than 20 awarded short films (both documentaries and fictional), and became a gay-cinema icon for his feature films, including Broken Sky.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: Along with producer and director , he founded Cooperativa Cinematográfica Morelos.

title: Julián Hernández (filmmaker)
text: which later became the prestigious production company , producing 29 films over two decades.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Eastern Hills Mall is a shopping mall located at the western border of the Town of Clarence in Erie County, New York, United States.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: It lies on Transit Road (New York State Route 78, a 73.49-mile state highway), which in the vicinity of the mall, divides Clarence, New York from the town of Amherst, New York east of (Buffalo, New York).

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: The mall is north of the junction of NY-78 with NY-5, and Main Street.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: The name "Eastern Hills" refers to the very low hills that contribute to a slightly higher elevation than the bordering areas along the Onondaga Escarpment.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Eastern Hills Mall is part of a long commercial strip on Transit Road.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: It consists of two long wings running north and south and one short wing running east and west, which connects the north-south wings in a "double L-shaped" formation.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: A major department store is at the end of each wing.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: A food court is located adjacent to the end of the long south wing.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: A three-screen movie theater showing mainly independent films is also located in the mall, as well as a small New York State Department of Motor Vehicles office.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Surrounding the mall is a large, but generally unkept, parking lot.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: The ratio of the mall is so large, it provides the highest parking ratio of any Buffalo area mall.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Much of the parking lot space is leased to area car dealerships to store overstock vehicles due to the low volume of shoppers at the mall.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Eastern Hills Mall is currently at approximately 70% occupancy, with many vacant stores throughout the mall and popular anchor store Dave & Busters shuttering its doors in 2015 to move to the nearby Walden Galleria.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Eastern Hills is considered by many area residents to be a "dead mall" and is listed on the website Deadmalls.com.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: Most major and nationally recognized retailers have left and been replaced by independently owned "mom-and-pop" type stores, selling crafts and homemade goods.

title: Eastern Hills Mall
text: It is common for retailers to open and close within their first few months, unable to turn a profit due to the low volume of shoppers that still visit Eastern Hills Mall.

title: Citadel Mall
text: Citadel Mall, one of the largest shopping malls in the state, is a regional 1138527 sqft shopping mall located in Charleston, South Carolina, United States.

title: Citadel Mall
text: It opened on July 29, 1981 and is located at the intersection of Sam Rittenberg Boulevard (SC Hwy.

title: Citadel Mall
text: The mall features more than 100 stores, including six anchor stores: the area's largest Belk and Dillard's department stores, Dick's Sporting Goods, Sears and the region's first Target that was recently remodeled to include a new "Fresh Grocery" section.

title: Citadel Mall
text: On September 1, 2013 the mall went into foreclosure after then owner CBL & Associates Properties defaulted on mortgage payments and it was purchased at auction by the lender in January 2014.

title: Citadel Mall
text: After the auction, the mall was placed under the ownership of a holding company formed by the lender, 2070 Sam Rittenberg Boulevard Holdings LLC and as of January 2017 was under contract to be sold to an undisclosed buyer.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: Halloween Adventure Stores (also known as Masquerade, LLC) is a retail store chain specializing in Halloween-related merchandise, they are one of the world's largest costuming companies and arguably the largest chain store specializing in Halloween in the United States.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: The company was founded in 1981 by brothers Bruce and Darron Goldman in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and has locations in Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Florida, and California.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: In 2006 there were over 120 "seasonal stores", using temporary locations in shopping malls that were vacated for seasonal short-term rentals.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: Halloween Adventure sells a variety of costumes, masks, makeup, props, hats and other accessories for adults and children.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: They also sell online as they found costumers would brouse in-store then search online for the best pricing.

title: Halloween Adventure
text: Its main competition for this group is Halloween Thrills.

title: Spirit Halloween
text: Spirit Halloween LLC is a seasonal retailer that supplies Halloween decorations, costumes and accessories.

title: Spirit Halloween
text: It was founded in 1983 and is based in Egg Harbor Township, New Jersey.

title: Spirit Halloween
text: In 1999, the store had 60 seasonal locations and was purchased by Spencer Gifts.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: Rolling Acres Mall was a retail mall located in the Rolling Acres area of Akron, Ohio, United States.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: Built in 1975 and expanded several times in its history, it once comprised more than 140 stores, including five anchor stores, a movie theater and a food court.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: The mall closed on October 31, 2008, leaving only two of its anchor stores in operation, Sears and JCPenney.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: In January 2011, Sears announced their store would close: the Sears store closed in April 2011, while JCPenney converted remaining outlets to "JC's 5 Star Outlet" stores.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: In 2013, JCPenney announced that it would close all remaining "JC's Five Star Outlet" stores, including the store at Rolling Acres.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: The store shut its doors on December 31, 2013, leaving the mall vacant of retail stores.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: The mall currently houses Storage of America and Pinnacle Recycling.

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: One of the mall's dilapidated entrances appears as the cover art to The Black Keys' single "Gold on the Ceiling".

title: Rolling Acres Mall
text: The mall has been nicknamed "Rotting Acres Mall" during its years of abandonment, in reference to the large amount of black mold growing throughout the mall, and the deterioration of the mall since it closed down.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: The Crossings at Northwest, formerly Northwest Plaza, was a shopping mall located in St. Ann, a suburb of St. Louis, Missouri, United States.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: The mall comprised nearly 1770000 sqft of gross leasable area, making it the 27th largest mall in the United States according to the International Council of Shopping Centers prior to its closure.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: With a total of 1900000 sqft of enclosed space, it was the largest enclosed mall in the state of Missouri.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: The mall featured nine anchor stores and more than 210 stores at its peak.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: It is currently owned by St. Ann Shopping Center, LLC.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: The current plans for the mall include a total demolition, and rebuilding into a lifestyle center.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: At the end of 2010, it became the second St Louis area mall to permanently close since 2006.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: The first was St. Louis Centre.

title: The Crossings at Northwest
text: Redevelopment of the site begun, including massive demolition and reconstruction, as well as the name change from Northwest Plaza to The Crossings at Northwest.

title: FedMart
text: FedMart was a chain of discount department stores started by Sol Price, who later founded Price Club.

title: FedMart
text: His first location in San Diego, California was in a converted airport hangar.

title: FedMart
text: It was originally a discount department store open to government employees, who paid a membership fee of $2 per family.

title: FedMart
text: FedMart's first year was highly successful.

title: FedMart
text: Over the next 20 years Fedmart grew to include 45 stores in a chain that generated more than $300 million in annual sales.

title: FedMart
text: The business expanded to several states in the Southwest United States.

title: FedMart
text: Many stores were previous White Front or Two Guys locations.

title: FedMart
text: Price later sold two-thirds of the chain to Hugo Mann, a German retail chain, in 1975 and was forced out of his leadership position the following year.

title: FedMart
text: FedMart went out of business in 1982.

title: Walt Whitman Shops
text: Walt Whitman Shops (formerly known as Walt Whitman Mall) is a luxury shopping mall located in Huntington Station, New York on Walt Whitman Road (Route 110) and New York Avenue.

title: Walt Whitman Shops
text: It has many stores including main anchors Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor, Macy's and Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Walt Whitman Shops
text: The mall is owned and managed by Melvin Simon and Associates, one of the largest developers of shopping malls in the United States and owner of Long Island's largest mall, Roosevelt Field in Garden City.

title: Walt Whitman Shops
text: Suffolk County Transit, Nassau Inter-County Express and Huntington Area Rapid Transit all have bus routes that service the mall.

title: Spencer Gifts
text: Spencer Gifts LLC, doing business as Spencer's, is a North American mall retailer with over 600 stores in the United States and Canada.

title: Spencer Gifts
text: Their stores specialize in novelty and gag gifts, and also sell clothing, band merchandise, sex toys, room decor, collectible figures, fashion and body jewelry, and fantasy and horror items.

title: Spencer Gifts
text: The company also owns and operates a seasonal retailer, Spirit Halloween.

title: Warehouse store
text: A warehouse store or warehouse supermarket is a food and grocery retailer that operates stores geared toward offering deeper discounted prices than a traditional supermarket.

title: Warehouse store
text: These stores offer a no-frills experience and warehouse shelving stocked well with merchandise intended to move at higher volumes.

title: Warehouse store
text: Unlike warehouse clubs, warehouse stores do not require a membership or membership fees. Warehouse stores also offer a selection of merchandise sold in bulk, Typically warehouse stores are laid out in a logical format which leads people a certain way around the store to the checkout.

title: Warehouse store
text: As one enters the store they are directed down an aisle of discounted special buys when entering the store.

title: Warehouse store
text: From there the layout typically then leads to the fresh Produce followed by the Deli at the back of the store.

title: Warehouse store
text: Also included bakery and other departments similar to other supermarkets.

title: Warehouse store
text: Another typical feature of these stores is that the customer bags their own groceries which also helps to reduce the overall cost.

title: Warehouse store
text: Many warehouse stores are operated by traditional grocery chains both as a way to attract lower income, value conscious consumers and to maximize their buying power in order to lower costs at their mainstream stores.

title: Warehouse store
text: Notable examples of corporations who operate warehouse stores include United States chains Kroger and Albertsons LLC and the smaller Sacramento-based Nugget Market.

title: Warehouse store
text: However, WinCo Foods is an exception as it is a warehouse chain of its own and not part of a larger chain of traditional supermarkets like A&P, Safeway, Kroger, or Supervalu.

title: Bard College Berlin
text: Bard College Berlin (formerly known as ECLA or European College of Liberal Arts) is a private, non-profit institution of higher education in Berlin, Germany.

title: Bard College Berlin
text: It was founded as a non-profit association in 1999.

title: Bard College Berlin
text: The college is, according to Martha Nussbaum, one of the educational institutions in Europe that makes the liberal arts idea into reality.

title: Bard College Berlin
text: Students and faculty come from all over the world and the language of instruction is English.

title: Bard College Berlin
text: Qualifying students earn both an American B.A. and a German B.A.

title: Macalester College
text: Macalester College ( ) is a private, coeducational liberal arts college located in Saint Paul, Minnesota, US.

title: Macalester College
text: It was founded in 1874 as a Presbyterian-affiliated but nonsectarian college.

title: Macalester College
text: Its first class entered September 15, 1885.

title: Macalester College
text: Macalester is exclusively an undergraduate four-year institution and enrolled 1,978 students in the fall of 2013 from 50 U.S. states and 90 countries.

title: Macalester College
text: In 2015, "U.S. News & World Report" ranked Macalester as tied for the 23rd best liberal arts college in the United States, 6th for undergraduate teaching at a national liberal arts college, and 19th for best value at a national liberal arts college.

title: James Fieser
text: James Fieser is professor of philosophy at the University of Tennessee at Martin.

title: James Fieser
text: He received his B.A. from Berea College, and his M.A. and Ph.D. in philosophy from Purdue University.

title: James Fieser
text: He is founder and general editor of the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

title: James Fieser
text: He is author, coauthor or editor of more than ten text books.

title: Work college
text: Work colleges are distinctive liberal arts colleges in the United States that promote the purposeful integration of work, learning, and service.

title: Work college
text: At a work college all students work regardless of their academic program or their financial need.

title: Work college
text: A work college is a public or private non-profit, four-year degree-granting institution of higher learning where student work is an integrated, essential and federally required core component of the educational work-learning-service program.

title: Work college
text: Unlike Federal Work Study, which is solely need-based, work colleges do not differentiate between those that can afford to pay for their education from those that must work to cover their educational costs.

title: Work college
text: At work colleges, students are regularly evaluated and assessed on their work performance and can be dismissed from the institution for non-performance in the work program.

title: Work college
text: Students do not have the ability to "buy" their way out of the work requirement.

title: Work college
text: Students perform essential institutional functions in every area imaginable on their campuses and gain a strong sense of ownership and responsibility for their campus community.

title: Work college
text: Student labor enables work colleges to be far more operationally efficient and administratively lean (compared to more traditional colleges).

title: Work college
text: This, in turn, contributes to lower operational costs which results in lower – and more affordable – tuition.

title: List of liberal arts colleges
text: Liberal arts colleges are primarily colleges or universities with an emphasis upon undergraduate study in the liberal arts.

title: List of liberal arts colleges
text: The "Encyclopædia Britannica Concise" offers the following definition of the liberal arts as a, "college or university curriculum aimed at imparting general knowledge and developing general intellectual capacities, in contrast to a professional, vocational, or technical curriculum."

title: List of liberal arts colleges
text: Although the genesis for what is known today as the liberal arts college began in Europe, the term is commonly associated with the United States.

title: List of liberal arts colleges
text: Liberal arts colleges are found in countries all over the world as well.

title: List of liberal arts colleges
text: See the list (link) of international members of the Association of American Colleges and Universities for other institutions offering liberal arts education programs.

title: Liberal arts college
text: A liberal arts college is a college with an emphasis on undergraduate study in the liberal arts and sciences.

title: Liberal arts college
text: A liberal arts college aims to impart a broad general knowledge and develop general intellectual capacities, in contrast to a professional, vocational, or technical curriculum.

title: Liberal arts college
text: Students in a liberal arts college generally major in a particular discipline while receiving exposure to a wide range of academic subjects, including sciences as well as the traditional humanities subjects taught as liberal arts.

title: Liberal arts college
text: Although it draws on European antecedents, the liberal arts college is strongly associated with American higher education, and most liberal arts colleges around the world draw explicitly on the American model.

title: Berea College
text: Berea College is a liberal arts work college in the city of Berea, in the U.S. state of Kentucky.

title: Berea College
text: It is located in Madison County, approximately 35 miles south of Lexington.

title: Berea College
text: Founded in 1855, Berea College is distinctive among post-secondary institutions for providing free education to students and for having been the first college in the Southern United States to be coeducational and racially integrated.

title: Berea College
text: Berea College charges no tuition; every admitted student is provided the equivalent of a four-year, full-tuition scholarship (currently worth $97,200; $24,300 per year).

title: Alice Lloyd College
text: Alice Lloyd College is a four-year boarding school-style liberal arts work college in Pippa Passes, Kentucky, United States.

title: Alice Lloyd College
text: It was co-founded by the journalist Alice Spencer Geddes Lloyd, a native of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and June Buchanan, a native of New York City, in 1923, at first under the name of Caney Junior College, as an institution to educate leaders for Appalachia locally.

title: Alice Lloyd College
text: It became a four-year, bachelor's degree-granting institution in the early 1980s.

title: Alice Lloyd College
text: Alice Lloyd College is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS).

title: Altruism (ethics)
text: Altruism (also called the ethic of altruism, moralistic altruism, and ethical altruism) is an ethical doctrine that holds that the moral value of an individual's actions depend solely on the impact on other individuals, regardless of the consequences on the individual itself.

title: Altruism (ethics)
text: James Fieser states the altruist dictum as: "An action is morally right if the consequences of that action are more favorable than unfavorable to everyone except the agent."

title: Altruism (ethics)
text: Auguste Comte's version of altruism calls for living for the sake of others.

title: Altruism (ethics)
text: One who holds to either of these ethics is known as an "altruist."

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: Nancy K. Pearson is an American poet.

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: She is the author of "The Whole by Contemplation of a Single Bone" Fordham University Press, forthcoming 2016 and "Two Minutes of Light" Perugia Press, 2008.

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: Her poems have been published in many literary journals and magazines including Alaska Quarterly, Gulf Coast, The Iowa Review, Black Warrior Review, Indiana Review, Provincetown Arts Magazine, and others.

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: Her honors include winning the 2015 Poets Out Loud Prize, The 2015 Inprint Donald Barthelme Prize in Poetry and The 2014 Inprint Marion Barthelme Prize in Nonfiction, the Perugia Press Prize, the 2009 L. L. Winship/PEN New England Award, The Massachusetts Book Awards "Must Read Book of 2009" and two seven-month fellowships at the Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown.

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: Pearson grew up in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and received her B.A. from University of Virginia and her M.F.A. in Poetry from George Mason University and her MFA in Nonfiction from the University of Houston, where she taught literarture and writing.

title: Nancy K. Pearson
text: She is faculty at 24 Pearl Street & has taught at The Fine Arts Work Center's Summer Program.

title: Don't Fence Me In (film)
text: Don't Fence Me In is a 1945 American western film directed by John English and starring Roy Rogers, George "Gabby" Hayes and Dale Evans.

title: Don't Fence Me In (film)
text: The film was part of the long-running series of Roy Rogers films produced by the Hollywood studio Republic Pictures.

title: Apache Rose
text: Apache Rose is a 1947 American Trucolor Western film directed by William Witney and starring Roy Rogers.

title: Apache Rose
text: It was the first Roy Rogers Western shot in the process though most copies on DVD are in monochrome.

title: Song of Arizona
text: Song of Arizona is a 1946 American Western film directed by Frank McDonald and starring Roy Rogers.

title: Along the Navajo Trail (film)
text: Along the Navajo Trail is a 1945 American western film directed by Frank McDonald and starring Roy Rogers, George 'Gabby' Hayes and Dale Evans.

title: Along the Navajo Trail (film)
text: The film's story was based on a William Colt MacDonald novel.

title: Along the Navajo Trail (film)
text: The film marked the debut of the Cuban actress Estelita Rodriguez, who Republic Pictures then began to build up into a star.

title: Along the Navajo Trail (film)
text: Its title song is "Along the Navajo Trail", an instrumental version of which appears with the opening credits, with a brief vocal version during the last twenty seconds of the film.

title: Along the Navajo Trail (film)
text: The first few bars of the song are used as background music in several chase scenes.

title: Rainbow Over Texas
text: Rainbow Over Texas is a film from 1946 in which Roy Rogers plays himself as a famous cowboy-singer returning to Texas.

title: Rainbow Over Texas
text: Directed by Frank McDonald from a story by Max Brand, it co-stars George "Gabby" Hayes and Dale Evans.

title: Sons of the Pioneers (film)
text: Sons of the Pioneers is a 1942 American Western film directed by Joseph Kane and starring Roy Rogers, George 'Gabby' Hayes and Bob Nolan.

title: Sons of the Pioneers (film)
text: The film was part of the long-running series of Roy Rogers films produced by the Hollywood studio Republic Pictures.

title: Lights of Old Santa Fe
text: Lights of Old Santa Fe is a 1944 American Western Musical film directed by Frank McDonald with a screenplay by Gordon Kahn and Bob Williams.

title: Lights of Old Santa Fe
text: The film stars Roy Rogers and Dale Evans in a story about a rodeo owner and her struggle to make her show a success.

title: Lights of Old Santa Fe
text: When her rodeo is sabotaged by a rival showman, Rogers brings the perpetrator to justice.

title: San Fernando Valley (film)
text: San Fernando Valley is a 1944 American western film directed by John English and starring Roy Rogers, Dale Evans and Jean Porter.

title: San Fernando Valley (film)
text: The film was part of the long-running series of Roy Rogers films produced by Republic Pictures.

title: Frank McDonald (director)
text: Frank McDonald (November 9, 1899 Baltimore, Maryland – March 8, 1980 Oxnard, California) was an American film and television director, active from 1935 to 1966.

title: Frank McDonald (director)
text: He directed more than 100 films, including many Westerns starring Gene Autry and Roy Rogers, and numerous TV show episodes.

title: Frank McDonald (director)
text: He is interred at Conejo Mountain Memorial Park in Camarillo, California.

title: My Pal Trigger
text: My Pal Trigger is a 1946 American Western musical film directed by Frank McDonald.

title: My Pal Trigger
text: The screenplay by Jack Townley and John K. Butler was based upon a story by Paul Gangelin.

title: My Pal Trigger
text: The film stars Roy Rogers, Dale Evans, George “Gabby” Hayes, Jack Holt, and Trigger in a story about the origin of Rogers's mount, and their deep and faithful bond.

title: My Pal Trigger
text: The film features several musical numbers for Rogers, Evans, and Bob Nolan and the Sons of the Pioneers.

title: Irakli Bagrationi (born 1981)
text: Irakli Davitis Dze Bagrationi (Georgian: ირაკლი დავითის ძე ბაგრატიონი ) (born 1981) is a Georgian scion of the royal Bagrationi dynasty of Imereti, one of the two surviving direct male-line descendants of the kings of Imereti.

title: Cadet branch
text: In history and heraldry, a cadet branch consists of the male-line descendants of a monarch or patriarch's younger sons (cadets).

title: Cadet branch
text: In the ruling dynasties and noble families of much of Europe and Asia, the family's major assets—realm, titles, fiefs, property and income—have historically been passed from a father to his firstborn son in what is known as primogeniture; younger sons—cadets—inherited less wealth and authority to pass to future generations of descendants.

title: Line of succession to the former Egyptian throne
text: Under the Muhammad Ali dynasty, the line of succession to the former Egyptian throne was subject to a number of changes during its history.

title: Line of succession to the former Egyptian throne
text: From its founding in 1805 until 1866, the dynasty followed the imperial Ottoman practice of agnatic seniority, whereby the eldest male in any generation would succeed to the throne.

title: Line of succession to the former Egyptian throne
text: In 1866, however, the then Khedive of Egypt Isma'il Pasha obtained a "firman" from the Ottoman Emperor which restricted the succession to the male-line descendants of Isma'il Pasha.

title: Line of succession to the former Egyptian throne
text: The resulting succession remained in force until the abolition of the Egyptian monarchy in 1953, following the 1952 Egyptian Revolution.

title: Batonishvili
text: Batonishvili (Georgian: ბატონიშვილი ) (literally "a child of batoni (lord or sovereign)" in Georgian) is a title for royal princes and princesses who descend from the kings of Georgia from the Bagrationi dynasty and is suffixed to the names e.g. Alexandre Batonishvili, Ioane Batonishvili, Nino Batonishvili etc.

title: Batonishvili
text: The title was eventually borne not only by the children of the reigning king ("mepe"), but by all male-line descendants of past kings.

title: Batonishvili
text: The customary attribute or form of address for a Batonishvili was "უგანათლებულესი" ("uganatlebulesi") ("Most Brilliant" or "Most High").

title: Duke of Leuchtenberg
text: Duke of Leuchtenberg was a title created twice by the monarchs of Bavaria for their relatives.

title: Duke of Leuchtenberg
text: The first creation was awarded by Maximilian I, Elector of Bavaria to his son Maximilian Philipp Hieronymus, upon whose death without children the lands passed back to his nephew Elector Maximilian II.

title: Duke of Leuchtenberg
text: It was re-created by Maximilian I Joseph, King of Bavaria on 14 November 1817 and awarded to his son-in-law Eugène de Beauharnais.

title: Duke of Leuchtenberg
text: Eugène was the adopted stepson of the deposed Emperor Napoleon I of France, and Eugène had been his heir in Frankfurt and briefly in Italy.

title: Duke of Leuchtenberg
text: King Maximilian Joseph compensated his son-in-law after he lost his other titles and named him heir to the kingdom after the male-line descendants of the royal house and next in precedence after the Royal Family.

title: Zulu royal family
text: The Zulu royal family consists of the reigning monarch of the Zulus of South Africa, King Goodwill Zwelithini kaBhekuzulu, his consorts, legitimate descendants, near relatives and male-line descendants of his great-grandfather, King Mpande who, as a half-brother of the Zulu "Pater Patriae", King Shaka, reigned from 1840 to 1872.

title: Zulu royal family
text: Shaka's policies and conquests transformed a small clan into one of South Africa's most influential pre-colonial realms, extending over much of what is now KwaZulu-Natal.

title: List of members of the House of Windsor
text: The House of Windsor, the royal house of the Commonwealth realms, includes the male-line descendants of Queen Victoria who are subjects of the Crown (1917 Order-in-Council) and the male-line descendants of Elizabeth II (1952 Order-in-Council).

title: List of members of the House of Windsor
text: According to these two Orders-in-Council, male-line female descendants lose the name Windsor upon marriage.

title: Mountbatten-Windsor
text: Mountbatten-Windsor is the personal surname used by the male-line descendants of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.

title: Mountbatten-Windsor
text: Under a declaration made in Privy Council in 1960, the name "Mountbatten-Windsor" applies to male-line descendants of the Queen without royal styles and titles.

title: Mountbatten-Windsor
text: Individuals with royal styles do not usually use a surname, but some descendants of the Queen with royal styles have used "Mountbatten-Windsor" when a surname was required.

title: House of Capet
text: The House of Capet or the Direct Capetians (French: "Les Capétiens directs, la Maison capétienne" ), also called the House of France ("la maison de France"), or simply the Capets, ruled the Kingdom of France from 987 to 1328.

title: House of Capet
text: It was the most senior line of the Capetian dynasty – itself a derivative dynasty from the Robertians.

title: House of Capet
text: Historians in the 19th century came to apply the name "Capetian" to both the ruling house of France and to the wider-spread male-line descendants of Hugh Capet.

title: House of Capet
text: It was not a contemporary practice (see House of France).

title: House of Capet
text: They were sometimes called "the third race of kings", the Merovingians being the first, and the Carolingians being the second.

title: House of Capet
text: The name is derived from the nickname of Hugh, the first Capetian King, who was known as "Hugh Capet".

title: Capetian dynasty
text: The Capetian dynasty , also known as the House of France, is a dynasty of Frankish origin, founded by Hugh Capet.

title: Capetian dynasty
text: It is among the largest and oldest royal houses in Europe and the world, and consisting of Hugh Capet's male-line descendants.

title: Capetian dynasty
text: The senior line ruled in France as the House of Capet from the election of Hugh Capet in 987 until the death of Charles IV in 1328.

title: Capetian dynasty
text: They were succeeded by cadet branches, the Houses of Valois and Bourbon, which ruled until the French Revolution.

title: The Day the Universe Changed
text: The Day the Universe Changed: A Personal View by James Burke is a British documentary television series written and presented by science historian James Burke, originally broadcast on BBC1 from 19 March until 21 May 1985 by the BBC.

title: The Day the Universe Changed
text: The series' primary focus is on the effect of advances in science and technology on western society in its philosophical aspects.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections is a documentary series originally broadcast on the National Geographic Channel, and later on BBC2.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: It is presented by Richard Hammond, and looks at how engineers and designers use historic inventions and clues from the natural world in ingenious ways to develop new buildings and machines.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The show's format is very similar to that of James Burke's 1978 documentary series, "Connections".

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The first series premièred on 8 September 2008, on National Geographic, and on 1 March 2010, on BBC2.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The first series contained four episodes.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The second series premièred on 7 September 2009, on National Geographic, and on 8 May 2010, on BBC2.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The second series contained six episodes.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The third series premièred on 8 May 2011, on BBC2 and contained six episodes.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: The BBC2 broadcasts of the first two series have a slightly shorter running time and contain less information than the original National Geographic broadcasts, with on average one minute of footage cut from every episode.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: None of the three series of the programme are available to purchase on DVD in the UK, however, all three can be watched on demand for subscribers of National Geographic on Sky, Virgin Media and BT Vision.

title: Richard Hammond's Engineering Connections
text: In Australia, all three series are available on DVD, either separately or as a box-set.

title: Connections (TV series)
text: Connections is a 10-episode documentary television series and 1978 book ("Connections", based on the series) created, written, and presented by science historian James Burke.

title: Connections (TV series)
text: The series was produced and directed by Mick Jackson of the BBC Science and Features Department and first aired in 1978 (UK) and 1979 (USA).

title: Connections (TV series)
text: It took an interdisciplinary approach to the history of science and invention, and demonstrated how various discoveries, scientific achievements, and historical world events were built from one another successively in an interconnected way to bring about particular aspects of modern technology.

title: Connections (TV series)
text: The series was noted for Burke's crisp and enthusiastic presentation (and dry humour), historical re-enactments, and intricate working models.

title: Sci Fi Science: Physics of the Impossible
text: Sci Fi Science: Physics of the Impossible (also called Science of the Impossible) is an American documentary television series on Science which first aired in the United States on December 1, 2009.

title: Sci Fi Science: Physics of the Impossible
text: The series is hosted by theoretical physicist Michio Kaku and is based on his book "Physics of the Impossible".

title: Sci Fi Science: Physics of the Impossible
text: In each episode, Dr. Kaku addresses a technological concept from science fiction and designs his own theoretical version of the technology using currently-known science.

title: Sci Fi Science: Physics of the Impossible
text: He also visits scientists developing technology related to the episode's concept.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: National Geographic Explorer (or simply Explorer) is an American documentary television series that originally premiered on Nickelodeon on April 7, 1985, after having been produced as a less costly and intensive alternative to PBS's "National Geographic Specials" by Pittsburgh station WQED.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: The first episode ("Herculaneum: Voices from the Past") was produced by WQED and featured long-time "Explorer" camerman Mark Knobil, who is the few staff members with the franchise during all 24 seasons.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: The program is the longest-running documentary television series on cable television.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: Presented every Sunday from 5:00 pm to 8:00 pm, the original series was three hours in length, containing five to ten short films.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: Although the National Geographic Society had been producing specials for television for 20 years prior to "Explorer", the premiere of the series required an increase in production from 4 hours of programming a year to 156 hours.

title: National Geographic Explorer
text: Tim Cowling and Tim Kelly were the executive producers for the series during this transition.

title: Freaky Eaters (TLC series)
text: Freaky Eaters is an American documentary television series based on the BBC series of the same name that aired on TLC.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: Ripley's Believe It or Not!

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: is the name of several documentary television series based on the newspaper feature.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: The first series aired on NBC from 1949 to 1950, and was hosted by Robert L. Ripley until his death, after which several substitute hosts filled in.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: The series was revived for ABC in the 1980s, and was hosted primarily by Jack Palance.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: Another revival debuted on TBS in 2000, and aired until 2003, with Dean Cain as host.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: A Filipino version, hosted by Chris Tiu, debuted in 2008.

title: Ripley's Believe It or Not! (TV series)
text: An animated series based on the "Ripley's" franchise was also created.

title: James Burke (science historian)
text: James Burke (born 22 December 1936) is a British broadcaster, science historian, author, and television producer, who is known, among other things, for his documentary television series "Connections" (1978), and for its more philosophically oriented companion series, "The Day the Universe Changed" (1985), which is about the history of science and technology.

title: James Burke (science historian)
text: "The Washington Post" called him "one of the most intriguing minds in the Western world".

title: Aaron Faulls
text: Aaron Faulls (born February 6, 1975), is an American television personality, filmmaker, musician and marine conservationist.

title: Aaron Faulls
text: He is best known for his role as the original host of the television series Into The Drink, a Travel documentary-style series based around Faulls's background as an underwater filmmaker and journalist.

title: Aaron Faulls
text: He is also known for his appearances on "Gangland", a documentary television series on the History Channel.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey is a 2014 American science documentary television series.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: The show is a follow-up to the 1980 television series "", which was presented by Carl Sagan on the Public Broadcasting Service and is considered a milestone for scientific documentaries.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: This series was developed to bring back the foundation of science to network television at the height of other scientific-based television series and films.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: The show is presented by astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson, who, as a young high school student, was inspired by Sagan.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: Among the executive producers are Seth MacFarlane, whose financial investment was instrumental in bringing the show to broadcast television, and Ann Druyan, a co-author and co-creator of the original television series and Sagan's wife.

title: Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
text: The show is produced by Brannon Braga, and Alan Silvestri composed the backing score.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: Jeonju Hanok Village is a village in the city of Jeonju, South Korea, and overlaps with the Pungnam-dong and Gyo-dong neighborhoods.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: The village contains over 800 Korean traditional houses called 'Hanok'.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: The village is famous among Koreans and tourists because of its traditional buildings that strongly contrast with the modern city around it.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: The village was designated as an International Slow City in 2010 in recognition of its relaxed pace of life where traditional culture and nature blend harmoniously.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: The number of visitors to Jeonju Hanok Village has increased sharply since the 2000s.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: The visitor numbers more than doubled from 2007 to 2014, from 3.17 million to 7.89 million.

title: Jeonju Hanok Village
text: Excluding Seoul, Jeonju is ranked third among major tourist cities throughout South Korea, behind Jeju and Busan.

title: Asante Traditional Buildings
text: Asante Traditional Buildings is a World Heritage Site in Ghana, which is a collection of 13 traditionally built buildings from the time of the Ashanti Empire in the area.

title: Open-air museums in Slovakia
text: Slovakia has around 14 open-air museums, or skanzens, showcasing the country's folk traditions, architecture, and economic history.

title: Open-air museums in Slovakia
text: The museums include examples of traditional buildings and furnishings, and many offer demonstrations of traditional handicrafts.

title: Open-air museums in Slovakia
text: The largest open-air museum is the Slovak Village Open Air Museum in Martin.

title: Ballenberg
text: Ballenberg is an open-air museum in Switzerland that displays traditional buildings and architecture from all over the country.

title: Ballenberg
text: Located near Brienz in the municipality of Hofstetten bei Brienz, Canton of Bern, Ballenberg has over 100 original buildings that have been transported from their original sites.

title: Cultural Property (Japan)
