text: A Cultural Property (文化財 , bunkazai ) is administered by the Japanese government's Agency for Cultural Affairs, and includes tangible properties (structures and works of art or craft); intangible properties (performing arts and craft techniques); folk properties both tangible and intangible; monuments historic, scenic and natural; cultural landscapes; and groups of traditional buildings.

title: Cultural Property (Japan)
text: Buried properties and conservation techniques are also protected.

title: Cultural Property (Japan)
text: Together these cultural properties are to be preserved and utilized as the heritage of the Japanese people.

title: Groups of Traditional Buildings
text: Groups of Traditional Buildings (伝統的建造物群 , Dentōteki Kenzōbutsu-gun ) is a Japanese category of historic preservation introduced by a 1975 amendment of the law which mandates the protection of groups of traditional buildings which, together with their environment, form a beautiful scene.

title: Groups of Traditional Buildings
text: They can be post towns, castle towns, mining towns, merchant quarters, ports, farming or fishing villages, etc.

title: Groups of Traditional Buildings
text: The Japanese government's Agency for Cultural Affairs recognizes and protects the country's cultural properties under the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties.

title: Hachimanyama Ropeway
text: The Hachimanyama Ropeway (八幡山ロープウェー , Hachiman'yama Rōpuwē ) is Japanese aerial lift line in Ōmihachiman, Shiga, operated by Ohmi Railway.

title: Hachimanyama Ropeway
text: Opened in 1962, the line climbs Mount Hachiman, where there was Hachiman Castle built by Toyotomi Hidetsugu.

title: Hachimanyama Ropeway
text: The observatory has a view of Lake Biwa, as well as the city of Ōmihachiman, known for its traditional buildings lasting from Edo period.

title: Museumsdorf Niedersulz
text: Museumsdorf Niedersulz is an open-air museum in Austria that displays traditional buildings and architecture from the Weinviertel.

title: Museumsdorf Niedersulz
text: It is located in the village of Sulz im Weinviertel, about 45 km north of Vienna in the province of Lower Austria.

title: Museumsdorf Niedersulz
text: The Museumsdorf Niedersulz has over 80 original buildings and structures that have been transported from their original sites.

title: Imanishi family's House
text: The Imanishi Family Residence (今西家住宅 , Imanishi-ke jūtaku ) is one of a Group of Traditional Buildings in Imai-cho, Kashihara, Nara Prefecture Japan.

title: Imanishi family's House
text: It dates to 1650 and has been designated an Important Cultural Property.

title: Omodos
text: Omodos () is a village in the Troödos Mountains of Cyprus.

title: Omodos
text: It is also located in the Limassol District of Cyprus and is 80 kilometers from the city of Nicosia.

title: Omodos
text: The village produces a lot of wine and holds a wine festival every August.

title: Omodos
text: You can visit a 17th-century stone-built monastery via a cobblestone path and sample local wine for free at many outlets.

title: Omodos
text: You will also find a good mix of restaurants including traditional tavernas and a few modern bars housed in traditional buildings.

title: The Magic Christian (novel)
text: The Magic Christian is a 1959 comic novel by American author Terry Southern (1924–1995) about an odd billionaire who spends most of his time playing elaborate practical jokes on people.

title: The Magic Christian (novel)
text: It is known for bringing Southern to the attention of filmmaker Stanley Kubrick, who had received a copy as a gift from Peter Sellers, and subsequently hired him as co-writer for "Dr. Strangelove" (1964) when Kubrick decided to make that film a black comedy/satire, rather than a straightforward thriller.

title: The Magic Christian (novel)
text: In 1969, "The Magic Christian" was made into a film starring Peter Sellers and Ringo Starr; the story was much altered and relocated from New York City to London.

title: Jaroslav Hašek
text: Jaroslav Hašek (] ; April 30, 1883 – January 3, 1923) was a Czech writer, humorist, satirist, journalist, bohemian and anarchist.

title: Jaroslav Hašek
text: He is best known for his novel "The Good Soldier Švejk", an unfinished collection of farcical incidents about a soldier in World War I and a satire on the ineptitude of authority figures.

title: Jaroslav Hašek
text: The novel has been translated into about 60 languages, making it the most translated novel in Czech literature.

title: Jaroslav Hašek
text: He is also known as the Obscure Czech Writer.

title: José María Gironella
text: José María Gironella Pous (31 December 1917 in Darnius – 3 January 2003 in Arenys de Mar) was a Spanish author best known for his fictional work "The Cypresses Believe in God" ("Los cipreses creen en Dios"), which was published in Spain in 1953 and translated into English by Harriet de Onís in 1955.

title: José María Gironella
text: The book is a novel in two parts, and is the first novel of four, written from a Roman Catholic viewpoint, by its Catholic author, who had been educated in a seminary — but whose approach is notable for its even-handedness and fair assessment of the many nuances and subtleties among all factions on the eve of war.

title: José María Gironella
text: The story is set in Girona, a city in eastern Catalonia, and follows the life of a family, from 1931 until the Spanish Civil War breaks out in 1936.

title: José María Gironella
text: The protagonist is the son of an atheist from Madrid, who is married to a devout Basque woman, and has a younger brother and sister also caught up in the conflict.

title: José María Gironella
text: In a sequel to "Cypresses", "One Million Dead" ("Un millón de muertos"), translated by Joan MacLean, Gironella follows the Alvear family through the war.

title: José María Gironella
text: The next novel is "Peace after War", published in English in 1969, and was also translated by MacLean.

title: José María Gironella
text: The fourth novel, Los hombres lloran solos (Men cry alone), has not been translated and published in English.

title: Stanisław Lem
text: Stanisław Herman Lem (] ; 12 or 13 September 1921 – 27 March 2006) was a Polish writer of science fiction, philosophy, and satire, and a trained physician.

title: Stanisław Lem
text: Lem's books have been translated into forty-one languages and have sold over forty-five million copies.

title: Stanisław Lem
text: From the 1950s to 2000s, he published many books, both science fiction and philosophical/futurological.

title: Stanisław Lem
text: He is best known as the author of the 1961 novel "Solaris", which has been made into a feature film three times.

title: Stanisław Lem
text: In 1976, Theodore Sturgeon wrote that Lem was the most widely read science fiction writer in the world.

title: Joanna Russ
text: Joanna Russ (February 22, 1937 – April 29, 2011) was an American writer, academic and radical feminist.

title: Joanna Russ
text: She is the author of a number of works of science fiction, fantasy and feminist literary criticism such as "How to Suppress Women's Writing", as well as a contemporary novel, "On Strike Against God", and one children's book, "Kittatinny".

title: Joanna Russ
text: She is best known for "The Female Man", a novel combining utopian fiction and satire, and the story "When It Changed".

title: Simon R. Taylor
text: Lord Simon R. Taylor (born 14 December 1988) is a Scottish author, editor, play right and critic.

title: Simon R. Taylor
text: He is best known for his fantasy novel "Fairydust", and his long-running spy satire "Monday: Impossible".

title: Little Big Man (novel)
text: Little Big Man is a 1964 novel by American author Thomas Berger.

title: Little Big Man (novel)
text: Often described as a satire or parody of the western genre, the book is a modern example of picaresque fiction.

title: Little Big Man (novel)
text: Berger made use of a large volume of overlooked first-person primary materials, such as diaries, letters, and memoirs, to fashion a wide-ranging and entertaining tale that comments on alienation, identity, and perceptions of reality.

title: Little Big Man (novel)
text: Easily Berger's best known work, "Little Big Man" was made into a popular film by Arthur Penn.

title: Little Big Man (novel)
text: It has been called "Berger's response to the great American myth of the frontier, representing as it does most of the central traditions of American literature."

title: Hugh Gallagher (humorist)
text: Hugh Gallagher is an author and musician from New York City.

title: Hugh Gallagher (humorist)
text: He is best known for his satire, including his band Von Von Von, his award-winning satire on the college application essay, "3A Essay", and the novel "Teeth".

title: Claudia Durst Johnson
text: Claudia Durst Johnson is a literary scholar best known for her work on the novel "To Kill a Mockingbird", introducing the idea of the novel's gothicism and gothic satire.

title: Claudia Durst Johnson
text: In the process of her research she befriended the author, Harper Lee.

title: Claudia Durst Johnson
text: When the city of Chicago organized a One City One Book program in 2001 based on "To Kill a Mockingbird", Lee was unavailable to speak, so Johnson was invited to Chicago to present the book to the city.

title: Satyricon
text: The Satyricon, or Satyricon "liber" ("The Book of Satyrlike Adventures"), is a Latin work of fiction believed to have been written by Gaius Petronius, though the manuscript tradition identifies the author as a certain Titus Petronius.

title: Satyricon
text: The Satyricon is an example of Menippean satire, which is very different from the formal verse satire of Juvenal or Horace.

title: Satyricon
text: The work contains a mixture of prose and verse (commonly known as "prosimetrum"); serious and comic elements; and erotic and decadent passages.

title: Satyricon
text: As with the "Metamorphoses" (also called "The Golden Ass") of Apuleius, classical scholars often describe it as a "Roman novel", without necessarily implying continuity with the modern literary form.

title: Sindhi folk tales
text: Sindhi folktales ( لوڪ ڪهاڻيون) play an important part in the culture of the Sindhi people of southern Pakistan.

title: Sindhi folk tales
text: Pakistan's Sindh province abounds in fairy-tales and folktales that form its folklore.

title: Sindhi folk tales
text: Some of these folktales(قصا) are particularly important for the development of higher literature in Sindhi, since they were to form the core of mystical tales of Sindh immortalized by Shah Abdul latif Bhittai, and are generally known as Heroines of Shah (شاه جون سورميون).

title: The Greek Princess and the Young Gardener
text: The Greek Princess and the Young Gardener is an Irish fairy tale collected by Patrick Kennedy in "Fireside Stories of Ireland".

title: The Greek Princess and the Young Gardener
text: Joseph Jacobs included it in "More Celtic Fairy Tales".

title: Brian Kennedy (singer)
text: Brian Edward Patrick Kennedy (born 12 October 1966, Belfast, Northern Ireland) is an Irish singer-songwriter and author, who is known for his ballads, and has represented Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2006.

title: Brian Kennedy (singer)
text: He is the younger brother of the late musician Bap Kennedy.

title: Jack and His Comrades
text: Jack and his Comrades is a short Irish fairy tale describing the title character's story of success with the help of his animal helpers, collected by folklorist Patrick Kennedy from a resident of County Wexford, Ireland, and published in "Legendary Fictions of the Irish Celts" (1866).

title: Jack and His Comrades
text: It was later reprinted, revised but only slightly, by Joseph Jacobs in his Celtic fairy tale compilation.

title: Patrick Kennedy (folklorist)
text: Patrick Kennedy (early 1801 – 29 March 1873) was a folklorist from Co.

title: Patrick Kennedy (folklorist)
text: Wexford, Ireland.

title: Patrick Kennedy (folklorist)
text: A bookseller by trade, he is known for his collections of Irish (Leinster) folktales.

title: Patrick Kennedy (folklorist)
text: The tales are told in rusticated English of the Irish peasantry who had established roots in The Pale, the anglicized part of Ireland.

title: Patrick Kennedy (folklorist)
text: He is "widely credited with preserving irish idioms in the turn of phrase, sentence structure, Irish words".

title: Seumas MacManus
text: Seumas MacManus (31 December 1867 – 23 October 1960) was an Irish author, dramatist, and poet known for his ability to reinterpret Irish folktales for modern audiences.

title: Irish Fairy Tales
text: Irish Fairy Tales is a retelling of ten Irish folktales by the Irish author James Stephens.

title: Irish Fairy Tales
text: The English illustrator Arthur Rackham provided interior artwork, including numerous black and white illustrations and sixteen color plates.

title: Irish Fairy Tales
text: The stories are set in a wooded, Medieval Ireland filled with larger-than-life hunters, warriors, kings, and fairies.

title: Irish Fairy Tales
text: Many stories concern the Fianna and their captain, Fionn mac Uail, from the Fenian Cycle of Irish mythology.

title: Patrick Kennedy (1823–1858)
text: Patrick Kennedy (February 16, 1823 – November 22, 1858) was an Irish farmer, businessman, and politician who moved to East Boston, Massachusetts from County Wexford, Ireland.

title: Patrick Kennedy (1823–1858)
text: He was born in New Ross, Ireland.

title: Patrick Kennedy (1823–1858)
text: He was the father of businessman/politician P. J. Kennedy, paternal grandfather of businessman/politician Joseph P. Kennedy Sr., and patrilineal great-grandfather of World War II casualty Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., President John F. Kennedy, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and longtime Senator Ted Kennedy.

title: The Brown Bear of Norway
text: The Brown Bear of Norway is an Irish fairy tale collected by Patrick Kennedy which appeared in his "Legendary Fictions of the Irish Celts" (1866).

title: The Brown Bear of Norway
text: It was later included by Andrew Lang in his anthology "The Lilac Fairy Book" (1910), though Lang misattributed his source as "West Highland Tales" (cf. The Brown Bear of the Green Glen).

title: Amy Corzine
text: Amy Corzine is an American fiction and non-fiction writer and poet.

title: Amy Corzine
text: Her first book was a Cadogan travel guide to Ireland for families in which she included stories she wrote based on Irish folktales.

title: Amy Corzine
text: After that, Watkins Publishing commissioned her for 'The Secret Life of the Universe: The Quest for the Soul of Science'.

title: Amy Corzine
text: Then Classical Comics asked her to adapt Charlotte Brontë's 'Jane Eyre' into graphic novel form.

title: Sport & Leisure Swifts F.C.
text: Sport & Leisure Swifts Football Club is an intermediate, Northern Irish football club playing in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Sport & Leisure Swifts F.C.
text: The club hails from Belfast and plays their home games at Glen Road Heights which is in the west of the city.

title: Sport & Leisure Swifts F.C.
text: It was founded in 1978 and played in the County Down Premier League and the Dunmurry League, before joining the Northern Amateur League in 1990.

title: Armagh City F.C.
text: Armagh City Football Club is an intermediate, Northern Irish football club playing in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Northern Ireland Intermediate League
text: The Northern Ireland Intermediate League is an amateur intermediate league based in the north-west region of Northern Ireland.

title: Northern Ireland Intermediate League
text: As one of the leagues in the 4th tier of Northern Irish football, the league champions can be promoted to the NIFL Premier Intermediate League, providing they meet the admittance requirements.

title: NIFL Premier Intermediate League
text: The NIFL Premier Intermediate League is the third division of the Northern Ireland Football League, the national association football league in Northern Ireland, and the highest intermediate division in Northern Ireland, occupying level three in the Northern Ireland football league system – below.

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: Portstewart Football Club is an intermediate, Northern Irish football club from Portstewart, County Londonderry.

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: The club was founded in 1968 and currently plays in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: The club's main colours are sky blue and navy.

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: Portstewart are nicknamed "The Seahawks".

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: The club's home ground, Mullaghacall, was officially opened in 1997 by Harry Gregg MBE.

title: Portstewart F.C.
text: Portstewart Reserves play in the Coleraine and District Morning League.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: Newington Y.C. Football Club (also known as Newington Youth Club, Newington Y.C., Newington F.C. or simply Newington) is an intermediate-level Northern Irish football club playing in NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: The club originates in the Newington area of Belfast, although owing to the lack of facilities for junior and intermediate clubs in north Belfast they have played home matches at Muckamore Park in Antrim, Brantwood FC on Skegoneill Avenue, Richardson Park in Dunmurry and The Cliff in Larne.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: In 2008, the club became involved in a partnership with IFA Premiership club Crusaders, with a view to securing funding for a new, shared ground in north Belfast.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: As part of the arrangement, Newington used Crusaders’ current ground Seaview for home matches in 2008–09, marking a return to home matches in the club's native north Belfast.

title: Newington Youth F.C.
text: For the 2013–14 season, the club's first season in NIFL Championship 2, Seaview will be the home venue once again.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: Lisburn Distillery Football Club is a Northern Irish, intermediate football club who are based in Ballyskeagh, County Down and play in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: The club, founded in 1880, originated in west Belfast, where it was based at Grosvenor Park at Distillery Street off the Grosvenor Road until 1971.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: After sharing Skegoneill Avenue (Brantwood) and Seaview (Crusaders) for some years the club moved in 1980 to a permanent new home at New Grosvenor Stadium, Ballyskeagh, County Antrim, on the southern outskirts of Belfast.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: The club was known as Distillery until 1999, when it changed its name to 'Lisburn Distillery' in an attempt to associate itself more closely with its adopted borough (now city) of Lisburn.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: The club colour is white.

title: Lisburn Distillery F.C.
text: The club, a founder member of the Irish League in 1890, was relegated in May 2013.

title: Northern Ireland Football League
text: The Northern Ireland Football League (commonly abbreviated to NIFL), also known as the Irish League, is the national football league of Northern Ireland.

title: Northern Ireland Football League
text: It was formed in 2013 to assume independent collective management of the top three levels of the Northern Ireland football league system; namely the Premiership, Championship and NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Queen's University Belfast A.F.C.
text: Queen's University Association Football Club is an intermediate, Northern Irish football club playing in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Queen's University Belfast A.F.C.
text: The club, founded in 1910, a founder member of the Irish League B Division, is affiliated to Queen's University Belfast, and plays home matches at the newly built Arena at the Queen's University sports grounds, Upper Malone, Belfast - also known as "the Dub".

title: Donegal Celtic F.C.
text: Donegal Celtic Football Club is an intermediate football club based in Belfast, Northern Ireland who currently play in the NIFL Premier Intermediate League.

title: Donegal Celtic F.C.
text: The club, founded in 1970, plays its home matches at Donegal Celtic Park.

title: Donegal Celtic F.C.
text: Club colours are green and white in Celtic-style hoops.

title: Romeo and Juliet (1954 film)
text: Romeo and Juliet is a 1954 film adaptation of William Shakespeare's play of the same name.

title: Romeo and Juliet (1954 film)
text: It was directed by Renato Castellani and stars Laurence Harvey as Romeo, Susan Shentall as Juliet, Flora Robson as the Nurse, Mervyn Johns as Friar Laurence, Bill Travers as Benvolio, Sebastian Cabot as Lord Capulet, Ubaldo Zollo as Mercutio, Enzo Fiermonte as Tybalt and John Gielgud as the Chorus.

title: Romeo
text: Romeo Montague (Italian: "Romeo Montecchi" ) is the protagonist of William Shakespeare's tragedy "Romeo and Juliet".

title: Romeo
text: The son of Montague and his wife, he secretly loves and marries Juliet, a member of the rival House of Capulet.

title: Romeo
text: Forced into exile after slaying Juliet's cousin, Tybalt, in a duel, Romeo commits suicide upon hearing falsely of Juliet's death.

title: Rory Williams
text: Rory Williams is a fictional character portrayed by Arthur Darvill in the long-running British science fiction television series "Doctor Who".

title: Rory Williams
text: Having been introduced at the start of the 5th series, Rory joins the Eleventh Doctor (Matt Smith) as a companion in the middle of Series 5.

title: Rory Williams
text: As Amy Pond's fiancé, Rory is initially insecure because he believes Amy secretly loves the Doctor more.

title: Rory Williams
text: Later, however, he proves to be a hero in his own right and he and Amy marry.

title: Rory Williams
text: The couple conceive a daughter aboard the Doctor's time machine, the TARDIS, while in the time vortex, but their baby is kidnapped at birth.

title: Rory Williams
text: In "A Good Man Goes to War", Rory and Amy discover their time-traveler friend River Song is actually their daughter Melody Pond.

title: Rory Williams
text: The Doctor and River marry in "The Wedding of River Song", and Rory becomes the Doctor's father-in-law.

title: Benvolio
text: Benvolio is a fictional character in Shakespeare's drama "Romeo and Juliet".

title: Benvolio
text: He is Montague's nephew and Romeo's cousin.

title: Benvolio
text: Benvolio serves as an unsuccessful peacemaker in the play, attempting to prevent violence between the Capulet and Montague families.

title: Macbeth
text: Macbeth ( ; full title The Tragedy of Macbeth) is a tragedy by William Shakespeare; it is thought to have been first performed in 1606.

title: Macbeth
text: It dramatises the damaging physical and psychological effects of political ambition on those who seek power for its own sake.

title: Macbeth
text: Of all the plays that Shakespeare wrote during the reign of James I, who was patron of Shakespeare's acting company, "Macbeth" most clearly reflects the playwright's relationship with his sovereign.

title: Macbeth
text: It was first published in the Folio of 1623, possibly from a prompt book, and is Shakespeare's shortest tragedy.

title: Juliet
text: Juliet Capulet (Italian: "Giulietta Capuleti" ) is the female protagonist in William Shakespeare's romantic tragedy "Romeo and Juliet".

title: Juliet
text: Juliet is the only daughter of the patriarch of the House of Capulet and falls in love with Romeo, a member of the House of Montague (with which the Capulets have a blood feud).

title: Juliet
text: The story has a long history that precedes Shakespeare himself.

title: Prince Hamlet
text: Prince Hamlet is the title character and protagonist of William Shakespeare's tragedy "Hamlet".

title: Prince Hamlet
text: He is the Prince of Denmark, nephew to the usurping Claudius, and son of King Hamlet, the previous King of Denmark.

title: Prince Hamlet
text: At the beginning of the play, he struggles with whether, and how, to avenge the murder of his father, and struggles with his own sanity along the way.

title: Prince Hamlet
text: By the end of the tragedy, Hamlet has caused the deaths of Polonius, Laertes, Claudius, and two acquaintances of his from the University of Wittenberg Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

title: Prince Hamlet
text: He is also indirectly involved in the deaths of his love Ophelia (drowning) and of his mother Gertrude (poisoned by Claudius by mistake).

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: Shakespearean tragedy is the designation given to most tragedies written by playwright William Shakespeare.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: Many of his history plays share the qualifiers of a Shakespearean tragedy, but because they are based on real figures throughout the History of England, they were classified as "histories" in the First Folio.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: The Roman tragedies—"Julius Caesar", "Antony and Cleopatra" and "Coriolanus"—are also based on historical figures, but because their source stories were foreign and ancient they are almost always classified as tragedies rather than histories.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: Shakespeare's romances (tragicomic plays) were written late in his career and published originally as either tragedy or comedy.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: They share some elements of tragedy featuring a high status central character but end happily like Shakespearean comedies.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: Several hundred years after Shakespeare's death, scholar F.S. Boas also coined a fifth category, the "problem play," for plays that don't fit neatly into a single classification because of their subject matter, setting, or ending.

title: Shakespearean tragedy
text: The classifications of certain Shakespeare plays are still debated among scholars.

title: Anna Devane
text: Anna Devane is a fictional character from the original ABC Daytime soap opera, "General Hospital", played by Finola Hughes.

title: Anna Devane
text: Hughes also appeared as Anna on "All My Children", and the "General Hospital" prime time, spin-off series, "".

title: Anna Devane
text: The character first appeared on the April 10, 1985 episode of "General Hospital" as a fence.

title: Anna Devane
text: The character was created and introduced by executive producer, Gloria Monty, and co-head writers, Pat Falken Smith and Norma Monty.

title: Anna Devane
text: Upon her introduction, Anna is revealed to be the super spy ex-wife of Robert Scorpio and romantic rival to his current wife, Holly Sutton.

title: Anna Devane
text: Anna remained a prominent character in the series until 1992 due to her romantic pairings with Robert and former mobster, Duke Lavery.

title: Anna Devane
text: The storyline in which Duke tries to evade his criminal past with the Jerome family, allows for Duke and Anna to become one of the show's supercouples, along with Robert and Anna.

title: Anna Devane
text: However, the storyline ends in tragedy when Duke dies in Anna's arms.

title: Anna Devane
text: Robert and Anna eventually reunite to raise their daughter, Robin, and eventually remarry; the happiness is short lived and the duo are killed off in 1992 along with their rival, Cesar Faison.

title: Revenge tragedy
text: Revenge tragedy (less commonly referred to as revenge drama, revenge play, or tragedy of blood) defines a genre of plays made popular in early modern England.

title: Revenge tragedy
text: Ashley H. Thorndike formally established this genre in his seminal 1902 article "The Relations of Hamlet to Contemporary Revenge Plays," which characterizes revenge tragedy "as a tragedy whose leading motive is revenge and whose main action deals with the progress of this revenge, leading to the death of the murderers and often the death of the avenger himself."

title: Revenge tragedy
text: Thomas Kyd's "The Spanish Tragedy" (c.1580s) is often considered the inaugural revenge tragedy on the early modern stage.

title: Revenge tragedy
text: However, more recent research extends early modern revenge tragedy to the 1560s with poet and classicist Jasper Heywood's translations of Seneca at Oxford University, including "Troas" (1559), "Thyestes" (1560), and "Hercules Furens" (1561).

title: Revenge tragedy
text: Additionally, Thomases Norton and Sackville's play "Gorbuduc" (1561) is considered an early revenge tragedy (almost twenty years prior to "The Spanish Tragedy").

title: Revenge tragedy
text: Other well-known revenge tragedies include William Shakespeare's "Hamlet" (c.1599-1602) and "Titus Andronicus" (c.1588-1593) and Thomas Middleton's "The Revenger's Tragedy" (c.1606).

title: Nancy Spungen
text: Nancy Laura Spungen (February 27, 1958 – October 12, 1978) was the American girlfriend of Sex Pistols bassist Sid Vicious and a figure of the 1970s punk rock scene.

title: Nancy Spungen
text: Spungen's life and death have been the subject of controversy among music historians and fans of the Sex Pistols.

title: Live at Winterland 1978 (Avengers album)
text: Live at Winterland 1978 is a live album by the Avengers.

title: Live at Winterland 1978 (Avengers album)
text: It was released through online music stores on February 16, 2010.

title: Live at Winterland 1978 (Avengers album)
text: The album features a recording of their set on January 14, 1978 at the Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco, CA, when they opened for the Sex Pistols on what would become the Sex Pistols final show, before reuniting years later.

title: Live at Winterland 1978 (Avengers album)
text: The Sex Pistols' set has been released on an album of the same name.

title: Live at Winterland 1978 (Avengers album)
text: Songs from this album were previously released on a couple 7" bootlegs titled "Penelope" and "Summer of Hate".

title: The Flowers of Romance (band)
text: The Flowers of Romance were an early punk band, formed in mid-1976 by Jo Faull and Sarah Hall.

title: The Flowers of Romance (band)
text: The band never played live or released any recordings, and, like London SS and Masters of the Backside, are more famed for the number of band members that later became well known, including: Sid Vicious of the Sex Pistols, Keith Levene (an early member of The Clash and later of Public Image Ltd) and Palmolive and Viv Albertine, who went on to play in The Slits.

title: The Flowers of Romance (band)
text: Despite never playing live, they were interviewed by a fanzine named "SKUM", in which Sid Vicious proclaimed "I'll just be the yob that I am now".

title: Revolution in the Classroom
text: "Revolution in the Classroom" was a single released by the Ex Pistols; despite its packaging, the record has nothing to do with the Sex Pistols.

title: Revolution in the Classroom
text: The single was released in 1989 on the STP Records label, pressed on various colours of vinyl.

title: Revolution in the Classroom
text: The song, along with its B-side "Schools Are Prisons", were both included on the Ex-Pistols album, "Deny".

title: Revolution in the Classroom
text: They also appear disguised as genuine Sex Pistols recordings on two Sex Pistols retrospective albums by former producer Dave Goodman, "Pirates of Destiny" (I Swirled Records, 1989) and "We Have Cum For Your Children" (Skyclad Records, 1988).

title: Revolution in the Classroom
text: Under the title "Revolution" the song appears on a German Sex Pistols compilation "Anarchy in the USA" from 1992 released on MBC records.

title: Ex Pistols
text: The Ex Pistols were a scam act introduced in 1979 by one-time Sex Pistols producer Dave Goodman after his services were substituted for those of professional producers.

title: Ex Pistols
text: The Ex Pistols existed as a sound-alike band meant to mislead fans due to the similar music, name, and artwork, that led people to believe their songs were actually new or lost Sex Pistols recordings.

title: Glen Matlock
text: Glen Matlock (born 27 August 1956) is an English musician best known for being the bass guitarist in the original line-up of the punk rock band the Sex Pistols.

title: Glen Matlock
text: He is sometimes credited as a co-author on 10 of the 12 songs on "Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the Sex Pistols", although he had left the band by the time the record was released and the bass was played by Steve Jones.

title: Glen Matlock
text: He also continues to make his own records and tour with various bands, including the Sex Pistols.

title: Bodies (Sex Pistols song)
text: "Bodies" is a Sex Pistols song about the shock of abortion from the 1977 album "Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the Sex Pistols".

title: Bodies (Sex Pistols song)
text: The lyrics contain very graphic imagery about a terminated fetus and feature a great deal of profanity for the time: the third and final verse begins with a couplet in which the word "fuck" is repeated five times in rapid succession.

title: Bodies (Sex Pistols song)
text: Along with the later "Belsen Was a Gas," it is probably the most graphic and controversial Sex Pistols song in both its subject matter and style.

title: Bodies (Sex Pistols song)
text: Musically, it is also the fastest and heaviest song in the Sex Pistols canon — characterized by thudding drums, droning buzzsaw guitar, and shouted vocals.

title: Bodies (Sex Pistols song)
text: As such, it can be considered a significant antecedent to the genres of hardcore, thrash, and speed metal that was to emerge in the 1980s.

title: The Swindle Continues
text: The Swindle Continues is the first album released by the Ex Pistols in 1988.

title: The Swindle Continues
text: It consists of half Sex Pistols and half Ex Pistols material, and is the only Ex Pistols release that doesn't disguise itself as material completely by the Sex Pistols.

title: The Idols with Sid Vicious
text: The Idols with Sid Vicious is a concert album of former Sex Pistols bassist Sid Vicious performing with The Idols; though recorded in September 1978, it wasn't released until 1993.

title: The Idols with Sid Vicious
text: Steve Dior provided a recording of this performance to the New Rose record label.

title: The Idols with Sid Vicious
text: It was originally released by the Fan Club division of New Rose.

title: The Idols with Sid Vicious
text: It was also released in Japan by Teichiku Records, under license from New Rose.

title: Sham Pistols
text: The Sham Pistols were a short-lived punk rock supergroup composed of guitarist Steve Jones and drummer Paul Cook of the Sex Pistols with vocalist Jimmy Pursey and bass player Dave Tregunna of Sham 69.

title: Sham Pistols
text: Although now referred to as The Sham Pistols no name had been decided upon at the time.

title: Sham Pistols
text: There was the possibility that they may have been called The Sex Pistols.

title: Docking (animal)
text: Docking is the intentional removal of part of an animal's tail or, sometimes, ears.

title: Docking (animal)
text: The term cropping is more commonly used in reference to the cropping of ears, while "docking" more commonly—but not exclusively—refers to the tail.

title: Docking (animal)
text: The term tailing is also commonly used.

title: Docking (animal)
text: The term arises because the living flesh of the tail, from which the animal's tail hairs grow, commonly is known as the dock.

title: STOLport
text: A STOLport or STOLPORT was an airport designed with STOL (Short Take-Off and Landing) operations in mind, usually for an aircraft class of its weight and size.

title: STOLport
text: The term STOLport did not appear to be in common usage as of 2008 although was commonly used by pilots flying into Biggin Hill during 1986/87 when the London City airport was opened restricting approaches and ceilings to the north of Biggin.

title: STOLport
text: A STOLport normally had a short single runway, in general shorter than 5000 ft .

title: STOLport
text: STOLports only accepted certain types of aircraft, often only smaller propeller aircraft, often with limits on the amount of fuel that can be taken.

title: STOLport
text: In the United States, short runway facilities are simply known as airports and the term STOLport has not been commonly used since the early 1970s.

title: Trickle valve
text: Trickle valves, also known as vacuum valves, are commonly used in industrial dust collection applications to maintain an airlock seal on a dust collector hopper while allowing bulk solid material to be automatically discharged.

title: Trickle valve
text: These valves are typically a less expensive alternative to more commonly used rotary airlocks.

title: Trickle valve
text: Unlike rotary airlock valves which are driven by either an electric motor or a gas or air-powered motor, trickle valves require no external power source and are therefore well-suited for use in mechanical trenchers, where a dust-free environment in the pinnacle truss and axle bore is required for smooth operation.

title: Trickle valve
text: Trickle values were originally developed for this purpose.

title: Belling-Lee connector
text: The Belling-Lee connector or IEC 61169-2 radio-frequency coaxial connector of type 9,52, known colloquially in countries where it is used as a TV antenna connector as a PAL antenna connector, IEC antenna connector, or simply as a TV aerial plug, is commonly used in Europe and Australia to connect coaxial cables with each other and with terrestrial VHF/UHF roof antennas, antenna signal amplifiers, CATV distribution equipment, TV sets, and FM and DAB radio receivers.

title: Belling-Lee connector
text: It is one of the oldest coaxial connectors still commonly used in consumer devices.

title: Pox (drink)
text: "Pox" is a liquor commonly used for ceremonial purposes among the Mayans of Mexico and Central America.

title: Pox (drink)
text: "Pox" is a liquor made of corn, sugar cane and wheat, very important in mayan culture for its ceremonial uses and is also known as aguardiente.

title: Pox (drink)
text: Besides its religious significance it is also a somewhat popular alcoholic drink in the Chiapas region of Southern Mexico.

title: Pox (drink)
text: The word "pox" in Tzotzil means "medicine, cane liquor, cure."

title: Pox (drink)
text: Pox was commonly used in religious ceremonies and festivals in San Juan Chamula, Chiapas, but increasingly soda has been substituted for it.

title: Yogurt
text: Yogurt, yoghurt, or yoghourt ( or ; from Turkish: "yoğurt" ; other spellings listed below) is a food produced by bacterial fermentation of milk.

title: Yogurt
text: The bacteria used to make yogurt are known as "yogurt cultures".

title: Yogurt
text: Fermentation of lactose by these bacteria produces lactic acid, which acts on milk protein to give yogurt its texture and characteristic tart flavor.

title: Yogurt
text: Cow's milk is commonly available worldwide, and, as such, is the milk most commonly used to make yogurt.

title: Yogurt
text: Milk from water buffalo, goats, ewes, mares, camels, and yaks is also used to produce yogurt where available locally.

title: Yogurt
text: Milk used may be homogenized or not (milk distributed in many parts of the world is homogenized); both types may be used, with substantially different results.

title: Tensile testing
text: Tensile testing, also known as tension testing, is a fundamental materials science test in which a sample is subjected to a controlled tension until failure.

title: Tensile testing
text: The results from the test are commonly used to select a material for an application, for quality control, and to predict how a material will react under normal forces. Properties that are directly measured via a tensile test are ultimate tensile strength, maximum elongation and reduction in area.

title: Tensile testing
text: From these measurements the following properties can also be determined: Young's modulus, Poisson's ratio, yield strength, and strain-hardening characteristics.

title: Tensile testing
text: Uniaxial tensile testing is the most commonly used for obtaining the mechanical characteristics of isotropic materials.

title: Tensile testing
text: For anisotropic materials, such as composite materials and textiles, biaxial tensile testing is required.

title: Metandienone
text: Metandienone (INN) (brand names Averbol, Dianabol, Danabol, Metanabol, Naposim, Vetanabol), or methandienone (BAN), also commonly known as methandrostenolone, is a synthetic, orally active anabolic-androgenic steroid (AAS) and a 17α-methylated derivative of testosterone which was formerly used medically but has since been discontinued in most countries.

title: Metandienone
text: It has also seen non-medical use as a performance-enhancing drug.

title: Homeschooling
text: Homeschooling, also known as home education, is the education of children inside the home.

title: Homeschooling
text: Home education is usually conducted by a parent or tutor.

title: Homeschooling
text: Many families use less formal ways of educating.

title: Homeschooling
text: "Homeschooling" is the term commonly used in North America, whereas "home education" is commonly used in the United Kingdom, Europe, and in many Commonwealth countries.

title: Methyltestosterone
text: Methyltestosterone (brand names Agovirin, Android, Metandren, Oreton, Testred, Virilon, others) is a synthetic, orally active anabolic-androgenic steroid (AAS) which is used in the treatment of androgen deficiency in males and for a number of other indications.

title: Methyltestosterone
text: It is also used illicitly for physique- or performance-enhancing purposes by athletes and bodybuilders.

title: Methyltestosterone
text: The drug was synthesized in 1935 shortly following the discovery of testosterone, and was one of the first synthetic AAS to be developed.

title: Methyltestosterone
text: Although it is not as commonly used as other AAS for various reasons, methyltestosterone continues to be used medically even today.

title: George Hammond (Stargate)
text: Lieutenant General George S. Hammond, USAF (Ret.)

title: George Hammond (Stargate)
text: is a fictional character in the "Stargate franchise".

title: George Hammond (Stargate)
text: Played by American actor Don S. Davis, General Hammond serves as the commander of Stargate Command (SGC) in the first seven seasons of the television series "Stargate SG-1".

title: George Hammond (Stargate)
text: He is relieved of command in the series' season 7 finale "Lost City", but becomes head of the new Homeworld Security department at the beginning of season 8.

title: George Hammond (Stargate)
text: Hammond's off-screen retirement is confirmed in "SG-1"' s season 10, and the character's death is mentioned in the series finale of "SG-1"' s spin-off series "Stargate Atlantis", "Enemy at the Gate".

title: Stargate SG-1
text: Stargate SG-1 (often abbreviated as SG-1) is an adventure and military science fiction television series and part of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Stargate" franchise.

title: Stargate SG-1
text: The show, created by Brad Wright and Jonathan Glassner, is based on the 1994 science fiction film "Stargate" by Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich.

title: Stargate SG-1
text: The television series was filmed in and around the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

title: Stargate SG-1
text: The series premiered on Showtime on July 27, 1997 and moved to the Sci Fi Channel on June 7, 2002; the final episode first aired on Sky1 on March 13, 2007.

title: Stargate SG-1
text: With 214 episodes over ten seasons, "Stargate SG-1" had surpassed "The X-Files" as the longest-running North American science fiction television series, until it was surpassed by the series "Smallville" in 2011.

title: Vala Mal Doran
text: Vala Mal Doran is a fictional character in the American military science fiction television series "Stargate SG-1", a science fiction show about a military team exploring the galaxy via a network of alien transportation devices.

title: Vala Mal Doran
text: Played by former "Farscape" actress Claudia Black, Vala was created by Damian Kindler and Robert C. Cooper as a guest character for the season 8 episode "Prometheus Unbound" (2004).

title: Vala Mal Doran
text: Because of the on-screen chemistry between Black's Vala and Michael Shanks' character Daniel Jackson, and the character's popularity with the producers and the audience, Claudia Black became a recurring guest star in season 9 (2005–2006) and joined the main cast in season 10 (2006–2007).

title: Don S. Davis
text: Don Sinclair Davis, PhD (August 4, 1942 – June 29, 2008) was an American character actor best-known for playing General Hammond in the television series "Stargate SG-1" (1997–2007), and earlier for playing Major Garland Briggs on the television series "Twin Peaks" (1990–1991).

title: Don S. Davis
text: He was also a theater professor, painter, and United States Army captain.

title: Stargate: Continuum
text: Stargate: Continuum is a 2008 Canadian-American military science fiction direct-to-video film in the "Stargate" franchise.

title: Stargate: Continuum
text: It is the second sequel to television series "Stargate SG-1" following "".

title: Stargate: Continuum
text: It is directed by Martin Wood, director and producer of many episodes of "Stargate SG-1" and "Stargate Atlantis", written by "SG-1" and "Atlantis" creator Brad Wright, and produced by Wright and "Ark of Truth" director Robert C. Cooper.

title: Lost City (Stargate SG-1)
text: "Lost City" is the two-part finale to the seventh season of the science fiction television show "Stargate SG-1".

title: Lost City (Stargate SG-1)
text: It was originally intended to be a second "Stargate" film, and was then to be the show's absolute finale, and finally ended up being the seventh season finale after the series was renewed.

title: Lost City (Stargate SG-1)
text: "Lost City" served as an introduction to "Stargate Atlantis" and the events portrayed were followed up in the "Atlantis" premiere "Rising" as well as in "SG-1"<nowiki>'</nowiki>s own "New Order".

title: Lost City (Stargate SG-1)
text: "Lost City" also featured special guest star Chief of Staff of the Air Force John P. Jumper as himself.

title: Lost City (Stargate SG-1)
text: This episode was nominated for an Emmy Award in the category Outstanding Special Visual Effects for a Series and for a Gemini Award in the category Best Visual Effects.

title: Samantha Carter
text: Samantha "Sam" Carter, USAF is a fictional character in the Canadian–American military science fiction "Stargate" franchise.

title: Samantha Carter
text: Played by Amanda Tapping, she appears in all three shows in the franchise: "Stargate SG-1", "Stargate Atlantis", and "Stargate Universe".

title: Samantha Carter
text: She was a main character in all ten seasons of "Stargate SG-1" (1997–2007).

title: Samantha Carter
text: Following a recurring role in "Stargate Atlantis" for three seasons (2004–07), Carter became a main character in Season 4 of "Atlantis" (2007–08), and also appeared in the 2008 direct-to-DVD "SG-1" films "" and "".

title: Samantha Carter
text: Amanda Tapping accepted a starring role in "Sanctuary" and appears in only the first and last episodes in Season 5 of "Atlantis" (2008–09).

title: Samantha Carter
text: Carter also appears in two episodes of Season 1 of "Stargate Universe."

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: Season eight of "Stargate SG-1", an American-Canadian military science fiction television series, began airing on July 9, 2004 on the Sci Fi channel.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: The eighth season concluded on February 22, 2005, after 20 episodes on British Sky One, which overtook the Sci Fi Channel in mid-season.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: This was the first season of the show to have 20 episodes instead of 22, as well as the first to air concurrently with "Stargate SG-1" spinoff series "Stargate Atlantis" (the first season thereof).

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: The series was originally developed by Brad Wright and Jonathan Glassner, while Brad Wright and Robert C. Cooper served as executive producers.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: Season eight regular cast members include Richard Dean Anderson, Amanda Tapping, Christopher Judge, and Michael Shanks.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: The eighth season begins with the SG-1 team trying to revive Colonel Jack O'Neill (Richard Dean Anderson) after the events of the seventh season.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: At the end of the two-episode season opener, Colonel O'Neill is promoted to General and assumes command of Stargate Command (SGC), while Major Samantha Carter (Amanda Tapping) is promoted to Lieutenant Colonel and assumes command of SG-1.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 8)
text: The season arc centers on the growing threat and seemingly final defeat of the Goa'uld and the Replicators, races who were introduced in the first and third season of the show, respectively.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 1)
text: The first season of the military science fiction television series "Stargate SG-1" commenced airing on the Showtime channel in the United States on July 27, 1997, concluded on the same channel on March 6, 1998, and contained 22 episodes.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 1)
text: The show itself is a spin off from the 1994 hit movie, "Stargate" written by Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 1)
text: Stargate SG-1 re-introduced supporting characters from the film universe, such as Jonathan "Jack" O'Neill and Daniel Jackson and included new characters such as Teal'c, George Hammond and Samantha "Sam" Carter.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 1)
text: The first season was about a military-science expedition team discovering how to use the ancient device, named the Stargate, to explore the galaxy.

title: Stargate SG-1 (season 1)
text: However, they encountered a powerful enemy in the film named the Goa'uld, which is bent on destroying Earth and all that oppose them.

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: The two-part episode "Redemption" is the Season 6 premiere of the science fiction television series "Stargate SG-1".

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: Airing on June 7 and June 14, 2002, it was the first all-new "SG-1" episode to be broadcast by SCI FI, the new home of "SG-1" after the series' move from Showtime.

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: The episode was written by producer Robert C. Cooper, and directed by Martin Wood.

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: "Redemption" is the first episode where actor Corin Nemec had main cast status, his character Jonas Quinn replacing Daniel Jackson (played by Michael Shanks) who died at the end of season 5.

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: The episode also marks the second appearance of David Hewlett's character Rodney McKay, who later became a main character on "Stargate Atlantis".

title: Redemption (Stargate SG-1)
text: "Redemption Part 2" was nominated for a Gemini Award in the category "Best Visual Effects".

title: Heaven Bound (I'm Ready)
text: "Heaven Bound (I'm Ready)" is a song written by Dennis Linde and originally recorded by the American country music group The Oak Ridge Boys on their 1991 album "Unstoppable".

title: Heaven Bound (I'm Ready)
text: It was released in August 1995 by American country music group Shenandoah as the third single from the album "In the Vicinity of the Heart".

title: Heaven Bound (I'm Ready)
text: Their version of the song reached number 24 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

title: Sixwire
text: Sixwire is an American country music group from Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Sixwire
text: The group is composed of Andy Childs (guitar, piano, lead vocals), Robb Houston (guitar, vocals), John Howard (bass guitar), Steve Mandile (guitar, vocals), and Chuck Tilley (drums, percussion).

title: Sixwire
text: The band's name references the six strings on a guitar.

title: Sixwire
text: Sixwire recorded one album for Warner Bros.

title: Sixwire
text: Records in 2002, and charted two singles on the "Billboard" country charts, including the No. 30 "Look at Me Now".

title: Sixwire
text: Five years later, they placed second on the talent show "The Next Great American Band", and served as the house band on "Can You Duet", another talent show.

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: "Baby Girl" is the debut single co-written and recorded by American country music group Sugarland.

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: Originally released in 2003 as part of "Premium Quality Tunes", it was re-released in July 2004 as the first single from the album "Twice the Speed of Life".

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: The single reached a peak position of number 2 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now Hot Country Songs) charts in April 2005.

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: The song spent a total of 46 weeks on the country music charts; setting a new record for the longest chart run since the inception of Nielsen SoundScan digital chart tabulation in 1990.

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: In addition, "Baby Girl" became the highest-peaking debut single for a country music group in 14 years.

title: Baby Girl (Sugarland song)
text: It was written by group members Jennifer Nettles, Kristian Bush, and Kristen Hall, along with Troy Bieser.

title: Hometown News
text: Hometown News was an American country music duo composed of singer-songwriters Ron Kingery and Scott Whitehead.

title: Hometown News
text: Both musicians alternate as lead and background vocalists, in addition to playing guitar, while Kingery also plays the mandolin.

title: Hometown News
text: Hometown News has recorded two independently released albums, in addition to charting two singles on the "Billboard" country music charts.

title: Hometown News
text: Their highest-peaking single and only Top 40 hit, "Minivan", reached No. 37 in 2002.

title: The Bama Band
text: The Bama Band is an American country music group composed of Lamar Morris (vocals, guitar), Wayne "Animal" Turner (guitar), Clifford E. "Cowboy" Eddie Long (steel guitar), Jerry McKinney (saxophone), Vernon Derrick (fiddle), Ray Barrickman (bass), Billy Earheart (keyboards) and William Claude Marshall (drums).

title: The Bama Band
text: For more than twenty years, The Bama Band were the backing band for Hank Williams, Jr. The Bama Band was nominated twice for Band of the Year by the Academy of Country Music.

title: The Bama Band
text: They also found success on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles chart in the 1980s with singles like "Dallas," "Tijuana Sunrise" and "What Used to Be Crazy."

title: The Bama Band
text: An eponymous album released on Compleat Records in 1985 charted on the "Billboard" Top Country Albums chart.

title: Hanna–McEuen
text: Hanna–McEuen was an American country music duo comprising first cousins Jaime Hanna and Jonathan McEuen.

title: Hanna–McEuen
text: Both members of the duo sang, in addition to playing guitar and mandolin; Hanna also played harmonica, while McEuen also played banjo.

title: Hanna–McEuen
text: Their fathers, Jeff Hanna and John McEuen, co-founded the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, a country music band which had success in the 1970s and 1980s.

title: Hanna–McEuen
text: In addition, Hanna was formerly an occasional supporting musician for the Tex-Mex/americana band The Mavericks.

title: Candy Coburn
text: Candy Coburn is an American national performing country music artist who has shared the stage with many notable artists, including Brooks and Dunn, Kellie Pickler, Montgomery Gentry, Blake Shelton, Miranda Lambert, Gary Allan, Josh Turner, Lady Antebellum and others.

title: Candy Coburn
text: Scheduled to release her third album in 2010, Candy's most notable contribution to music so far has been her song, "Pink Warrior."

title: Carolina Rain
text: Carolina Rain was an American country music group composed of Jeremy Baxter (tenor vocals, mandolin), Rhean Boyer (lead vocals, guitar), and Marvin Evatt (baritone vocals, guitar, banjo).

title: Carolina Rain
text: Founded in 2003, the band was signed in 2004 as the first act on Equity Music Group, an independent record label owned by country music artist Clint Black.

title: Carolina Rain
text: Carolina Rain has released one studio album (2006's "Weather the Storm") and has charted five singles on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Songs charts.

title: Carolina Rain
text: A second album, "American Radio", was slated for an early 2009 release, but was never issued due to the closure of Equity.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Highspeed Hayride is an American country music band established in 2002 in Goliad, Texas.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: The band consists of Eugene Moreno III on lead vocals and rhythm guitars, Shelby David Stockton, Jr. on bass guitar and harmony vocals, Matthew Groll on drums and Bo Carter on lead guitar and harmony vocals.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Highspeed Hayride has released three independent albums including "Lights of Town" (2004), "Thought You Should Know" (2006) and the self-titled album "Highspeed Hayride" (2008).

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Highspeed Hayride has shared the stage with many of their childhood heroes as well as their Texas Country comrads.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Some artists the band has shared the stage with include: The Bellamy Brothers, Little Texas, John Conlee, Earl Thomas Conlee, David Allan Coe, Robert Earl Keen, Shooter Jennings, George Strait, Kevin Fowler, Pat Green, Randy Rogers, and many more.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Highspeed Hayride played their farewell show in May 2010.

title: Highspeed Hayride
text: Some members of the band continue to play on...

title: Snapback (song)
text: "Snapback" is a song by American country music group Old Dominion.

title: Snapback (song)
text: It was released on January 11, 2016 as the second single from their debut studio album, "Meat and Candy" (2015).

title: Snapback (song)
text: "Snapback" peaked at #2 and #4 on the "Billboard" Country Airplay and Hot Country Songs charts, and was the #2 Country Airplay record of 2016.

title: Snapback (song)
text: It also reached the top 50 on the Hot 100.

title: Snapback (song)
text: The song was certified Gold by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), and has sold 413,570 copies in the United States as of July 2016.

title: Snapback (song)
text: It received similar chart success in Canada, giving the band their second #1 hit on the Canada Country chart and reaching #68 on the Canadian Hot 100.

title: Snapback (song)
text: It also garnered a Platinum certification from Music Canada, denoting sales of 80,000 units in that country.

title: Snapback (song)
text: The accompanying music video for the song was directed by Steve Condon and features the band in Los Angeles performing at a skate park and a house party.

title: Religion in Ghana
text: Christianity is the largest religion in Ghana, with approximately 71.2% of the country's population being members of various Christian denominations as of 2010 census.

title: Religion in Ghana
text: The religious composition of Ghana in the first postindependence population census of 1960 was 25 percent Muslim, 23 percent traditionalist, 41 percent Christian, and the rest (about 9 percent) other.

title: Religion in Ghana
text: A breakdown of the 1960 population according to Christian sects showed that 25 percent were Protestant (non-Pentecostal); 13 percent, Roman Catholic; 2 percent, Protestant (Pentecostal); and 1 percent, Independent African Churches.

title: Religion in Ghana
text: The 1970 population census did not present figures on the religious composition of the nation.

title: National Archives of Namibia
text: The National Archives of Namibia is the national archives of Namibia, located in Windhoek and it was established in 1939.

title: National Archives of Namibia
text: It holds 5600 maps, 61000 photographs, 2000 audio cassettes, 450 films and a complete collection of all local newspapers from 1897 to 1962.

title: National Archives of Namibia
text: It shares a building with the National Library of Namibia.

title: National Archives and Library of Ethiopia
text: The National Archives and Library of Ethiopia, located in Addis Ababa, is the national library and archives of the country.

title: National Archives and Library of Ethiopia
text: The library was inaugurated in 1944 by Emperor Haile Selassie and began service with books donated by the emperor.

title: National Archives of Bangladesh
text: The National Archives of Bangladesh (NAB) are based in Dhaka and contain 225,000 volumes of documents in addition to books, microfilm rolls and newspaper clippings.

title: National Archives of Bangladesh
text: The archives were founded in 1973 by the government of Bangladesh and are administered by the Directorate of National Archives and Libraries.

title: National Archives of Bangladesh
text: Located in a rented building near the campus of Dhaka University until 1985, the collections are now housed in a purpose-built part of the National Library of Bangladesh complex in Sher-e-Bangla Nagar.

title: Bibliothèque et Archives nationales du Québec
text: Bibliothèque et Archives nationales du Québec (BAnQ, unofficially translated as National Library and Archives of Québec) is a Québec governmental organization who manages the legal deposit and national archives systems of the province as well as its national library, which is located in the Grande Bibliothèque in Montreal.

title: Bibliothèque et Archives nationales du Québec
text: It is born out of a merger between the Bibliothèque nationale du Québec (BNQ) and the Archives nationales du Québec, in 2006.

title: Bibliothèque et Archives nationales du Québec
text: The Bibliothèque nationale du Québec had previously merged with the Grande bibliothèque du Québec in 2002.

title: National Archives of Zambia
text: The National Archives of Zambia preserves the archives of the Republic of Zambia and maintains its legal deposit library.

title: National Archives of Zambia
text: The library holds 70,000 volumes.

title: National Archives of Zambia
text: Its headquarters is located in Ridgeway in the city of Lusaka.

title: National Archives of Mauritania
text: The Archives Nationales de Mauritanie (National Archives of Mauritania) is the national archives of Mauritania.

title: National Archives of Mauritania
text: It was founded in 1955 and hold 3,000 volumes.

title: National Archives of Mauritania
text: As of 2007 it was located on Avenue de l'Indépendance.

title: National Archives of Mauritania
text: Directors have included Mohamed Ould Gaouad (circa 1974), Izidh Bih Ould Sidi Mohamed (circa 2007), and Mohamed Moctar Ould Sidi Mohamed (circa 2017).

title: Gaboš
text: Gaboš (Serbian Cyrillic: ) is a village in Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia.

title: Gaboš
text: There are 613 inhabitants, the majority of the population which are Serbs, who make up 95% of the population according to the 2001 population census.

title: List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia
text: This is a list of ethnic groups in Ethiopia that are officially recognized by the government.

title: List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia
text: It is a list taken from the 2007 Ethiopian National Census: Population size and percentage of Ethiopia's total population according to the 1994 and 2007 censuses follows each entry.

title: Addis Ababa
text: Addis Ababa (Amharic: አዲስ አበባ "Addis Abäba " ] , "new flower"; Oromo: "Finfinne" , ] "Natural Spring(s)") or Addis Abeba (the spelling used by the official Ethiopian Mapping Authority), is the capital and largest city of Ethiopia.

title: Addis Ababa
text: It has a population of 3,384,569 according to the 2007 population census, with annual growth rate of 3.8%.

title: Addis Ababa
text: This number has been increased from the originally published 2,738,248 figure and appears to be still largely underestimated.

title: Night Ferry (composition)
text: Night Ferry is an orchestral composition in one movement by the British-born composer Anna Clyne.

title: Night Ferry (composition)
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for which Clyne was then composer-in-residence.

title: Night Ferry (composition)
text: It was first performed February 9, 2012 at Symphony Center, Chicago by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under conductor Riccardo Muti.

title: Symphony No. 5 (Rouse)
text: The Symphony No. 5 is a symphony for orchestra by the American composer Christopher Rouse.

title: Symphony No. 5 (Rouse)
text: The work was jointly commissioned by the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, the Nashville Symphony, and the Aspen Music Festival.

title: Symphony No. 5 (Rouse)
text: It was completed in Baltimore on February 15, 2015, and was first performed by the Dallas Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jaap van Zweden at the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center on February 9, 2017.

title: Alternative Energy (composition)
text: Alternative Energy is a symphony for electronica and orchestra in four movements by the American composer Mason Bates.

title: Alternative Energy (composition)
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for whom Bates was then composer-in-residence.

title: Alternative Energy (composition)
text: It was premiered by the orchestra under conductor Riccardo Muti at Symphony Center in Chicago, February 2, 2012.

title: The Seamstress (Clyne)
text: The Seamstress is a concerto for solo violin and orchestra by the British-born composer Anna Clyne.

title: The Seamstress (Clyne)
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for which Clyne was then composer-in-residence.

title: The Seamstress (Clyne)
text: It was first performed May 28, 2015 at Symphony Center, Chicago by the violinist Jennifer Koh and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under conductor Ludovic Morlot.

title: The Seamstress (Clyne)
text: "The Seamstress" marks the second collaboration between Clyne and Koh, who had previously premiered Clyne's double violin concerto "Prince of Clouds" in November 2012.

title: Anthology of Fantastic Zoology
text: Anthology of Fantastic Zoology is an orchestral symphony by the American composer Mason Bates.

title: Anthology of Fantastic Zoology
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for whom Bates was then composer-in-residence.

title: Anthology of Fantastic Zoology
text: It was premiered June 18, 2015 at Symphony Center in Chicago, with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra performing under conductor Riccardo Muti, to whom the work is dedicated.

title: Anthology of Fantastic Zoology
text: The piece is based on the eponymous book by Jorge Luis Borges.

title: Proceed, Moon
text: Proceed, Moon: Fantasy for Orchestra is an orchestral composition by the American composer Melinda Wagner.

title: Proceed, Moon
text: The work was Wagner's third commission from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which first performed the piece under the conductor Susanna Mälkki at the Symphony Center, Chicago, on June 15, 2017.

title: Proceed, Moon
text: Wagner dedicated the score to Mälkki and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Clarinet Concerto (Rouse)
text: The Clarinet Concerto is a concerto for clarinet and orchestra by the American composer Christopher Rouse.

title: Clarinet Concerto (Rouse)
text: The work was commissioned for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its principal clarinetist Larry Combs by the Institute for American Music.

title: Clarinet Concerto (Rouse)
text: It was completed December 11, 2000 and premiered May 17, 2001 at Symphony Center in Chicago with Christoph Eschenbach conducting the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Clarinet Concerto (Rouse)
text: The piece is dedicated to Rouse's friend and fellow composer Augusta Read Thomas.

title: Spangled Unicorn
text: Spangled Unicorn is a composition for brass ensemble by the British-born composer Anna Clyne.

title: Spangled Unicorn
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for which Clyne was then composer-in-residence.

title: Spangled Unicorn
text: It was first performed on March 21, 2011 at Symphony Center, Chicago by the brass section of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Soundings (Carter)
text: Soundings is an orchestral composition by the American composer Elliott Carter.

title: Soundings (Carter)
text: The work was commissioned by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for their final season with the conductor Daniel Barenboim as music director.

title: Soundings (Carter)
text: It was first performed on October 6, 2005 at the Symphony Center, Chicago, by Barenboim and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

title: Symphony Center
text: Symphony Center is a music complex located at 220 South Michigan Avenue in the Loop area of Chicago, Illinois.

title: Symphony Center
text: Home to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra; Chicago Symphony Chorus; Civic Orchestra of Chicago; and the Institute for Learning, Access, and Training; Symphony Center includes the 2,522-seat Orchestra Hall, which dates from 1904; Buntrock Hall, a rehearsal and performance space; Grainger Ballroom, an event space overlooking Michigan Avenue and the Art Institute of Chicago; a public multi-story rotunda; tesori restaurant; and administrative offices.

title: Symphony Center
text: In June 1993, plans to significantly renovate and expand Orchestra Hall were approved and the $110 million project resulting in Symphony Center began in 1995 and was completed in 1997.

title: VMF-413
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 413 (VMF-413) was a fighter squadron of the Marine Forces Reserve during the Cold War.

title: VMF-413
text: It descended from bombing squadron VMB-413, which was the Marine Corps' first medium bomber squadron and had fought during World War II.

title: VMF-413
text: Best known as “Night Hecklers” and the “Shamrocks”, the squadron fought in many areas of the Pacific War.

title: VMF-215
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 215 (VMF-215) was a fighter squadron of the United States Marine Corps that was activated and fought during World War II.

title: VMF-215
text: Known as "The Fighting Corsairs", they fought in many areas of the Pacific War, including the Battle of Bougainville.

title: VMF-215
text: During their four-and-a-half month tour, the squadron was credited with shooting down 137 enemy aircraft, fourth most in Marine Corps aviation history.

title: VMF-222
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 222 (VMF-222) was a fighter squadron of the United States Marine Corps that was activated and fought during World War II.

title: VMF-222
text: Known as “The Flying Deuces”, they fell under the command of Marine Aircraft Group 14 (MAG-14) and fought in many areas of the Pacific War, including the Philippines campaign (1944–45) and the Battle of Okinawa.

title: VMF-222
text: During the war, the squadron was credited with shooting down 53 enemy aircraft and was the sister squadron to VMF-215.

title: VMF-222
text: They were deactivated on December 31, 1949.

title: VMF-111
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 111 (VMF-111) was a reserve fighter squadron in the United States Marine Corps.

title: VMF-111
text: Nicknamed the “Devil Dogs”, the squadron was one of the first aviation squadrons in the Marine Corps and gained national attention in the 1930s as the Marine Corps show unit.

title: VMF-111
text: The squadron fought in World War II and was later transferred to the Reserves where they fell under the command of Marine Aircraft Group 41 (MAG-41) and the 4th Marine Aircraft Wing (4th MAW) while stationed at Naval Air Station Dallas, Texas.

title: VMF-111
text: They were decommissioned on October 22, 1965.

title: VMF-511
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 511 (VMF-511) was a fighter squadron of the Marine Corps and Marine Forces Reserve during World War II and the Cold War which flew aircraft types such as the F6F Hellcat, F4U Corsair, and the F-8 Crusader.

title: VMF-511
text: They were originally activated during World War II and fought during the Battle of Okinawa and the Battle of Balikpapan (1945).

title: VMF-511
text: They specialized in close air support and during the course of the war were credited with only one plane shot down.

title: VMF-221
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 221 (VMF-221) was a fighter squadron of the United States Marine Corps in World War II.

title: VMF-221
text: During the war, they flew the Brewster F2A-3, and after reconstitution in 1943, the F4U Corsair.

title: VMF-221
text: The squadron, also known as the “Fighting Falcons”, is most notable for its actions on June 4, 1942, during the Battle of Midway, which resulted in 23 members of the squadron, many posthumously, being awarded the Navy Cross for their actions in combat.

title: VMF-221
text: VMF-221 ended WW II with 185 air-to-air victories, the second most of any Marine Fighting Squadron in the war.

title: VMF-512
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 512 (VMF-512) was a fighter squadron of the United States Marine Corps during World War II.

title: VMF-512
text: The squadron was aircraft carrier during the last year of the war and supported combat operations during the Okinawa and the Battle of Balikpapan (1945).

title: VMF-512
text: Following the end of World War II they were deactivated on 10 March 1946 and remain in an inactive status today.

title: VMF-213
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 213 (VMF-213) was a reserve fighter squadron in the United States Marine Corps.

title: VMF-213
text: Nicknamed the "Hell Hawks", the squadron fought during World War II in the Philippines and at the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa.

title: VMF-213
text: With its assignment to the USS Essex (CV-9) and "Air Group 4", VMF-213 along with VMF-124 was one of the first two Marine squadrons to augment carrier air groups during World War II.

title: VMF-213
text: The squadron was credited with downing 117 enemy aircraft during the war.

title: VMF-236
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 236 (VMF-236) was a fighter squadron in the United States Marine Corps.

title: VMF-236
text: The squadron, also known as the “Black Panthers”, was part of the Marine Forces Reserve for a short time following World War II and were based at Naval Air Station Denver, Colorado until their disestablishment.

title: VMF-236
text: Originally established during World War II, they fought in the Pacific War most notably during the Bougainville Campaign and the campaign to liberate the Philippines.

title: VMF-236
text: The squadron conducted the first dive bombing attack against Bougainville and was credited with downing 4 Japanese aircraft during the course of the war.

title: VMF-236
text: VMSB-236 was disestablished on August 1, 1945 at Mindanao, Philippines two weeks before the surrender of Japan They were reactivated as part of the Reserves but were again deactivated in the late 1960s and remain in an inactive status today.

title: VMF-452
text: Marine Fighting Squadron 452 (VMF-452) was a fighter squadron of the United States Marine Corps that was commissioned and fought during World War II.

title: VMF-452
text: Known as the “Sky Raiders”, they flew the F4U Corsair, and the Grumman TBF Avenger, fell under the command of Marine Carrier Group 5 (MCVG-5) and fought in the Battle of Okinawa.

title: VMF-452
text: The squadron is best known for being aboard the USS Franklin (CV-13) when she was severely damaged by Japanese kamikaze planes of the coast of Okinawa on March 19, 1945.

title: VMF-452
text: VMF-452 was deactivated on December 31, 1949 and has remained in an inactive status since.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: The Davey Tree Expert Company, also known as Davey Tree, is an American multinational employee-owned corporation that provides tree, utility, lawn care, and environmental consulting services in the green industry throughout the United States and Canada.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: It is the largest residential tree care company in North America and was founded in 1880 making it the first national tree care company.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: John Davey, its founder, is considered the father of the science of tree surgery and arboriculture.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: The company's core services include tree, utility services, large tree moving, commercial grounds management and consulting services.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: It has been employee owned since 1979 and is the largest employee-owned company in the state of Ohio and one of the top 20 largest in the United States.

title: Davey Tree Expert Company
text: Davey is organized in two segments, Residential and Commercial, and Utility.

title: Nitrogen assimilation
text: Nitrogen assimilation is the formation of organic nitrogen compounds like amino acids from inorganic nitrogen compounds present in the environment.

title: Nitrogen assimilation
text: Organisms like plants, fungi and certain bacteria that cannot fix nitrogen gas (N) depend on the ability to assimilate nitrate or ammonia for their needs.

title: Nitrogen assimilation
text: Other organisms, like animals, depend entirely on organic nitrogen from their food.

title: Pachypodium lealii
text: The Bottle tree ("Pachypodium lealii" Welw.)

title: Pachypodium lealii
text: is a species of plant included in the "genus" "Pachypodium".

title: Pachypodium lealii
text: The scientific name derives from the 19th century Portuguese geologist Fernando da Costa Leal, who described the Bottle tree during an exploration in southern Angola.

title: Parkia timoriana
text: Parkia timoriana is a species of flowering plant in the legume family.

title: Parkia timoriana
text: English common names include tree bean.

title: Parkia timoriana
text: Common names in other languages and regions include petai hutan in Borneo, yongchak in Manipur, India, nitta tree and riang in Thailand, kedawung and peundung in Java, alai in Sumatra, petai kerayong and batai hutan in Malaysia, and kupang and amarang in the Philippines.

title: Parkia timoriana
text: It is native to Thailand, Malaysia, Myanmar, Indonesia, and Assam in India.

title: Parkia timoriana
text: It is widely cultivated for food and wood, and as an ornamental.

title: Fractal tree index
text: In computer science, a Fractal Tree index is a tree data structure that keeps data sorted and allows searches and sequential access in the same time as a B-tree but with insertions and deletions that are asymptotically faster than a B-tree.

title: Fractal tree index
text: Like a B-tree, a Fractal Tree index is a generalization of a binary search tree in that a node can have more than two children.

title: Fractal tree index
text: Furthermore, unlike a B-tree, a Fractal Tree index has buffers at each node, which allow insertions, deletions and other changes to be stored in intermediate locations.

title: Fractal tree index
text: The goal of the buffers is to schedule disk writes so that each write performs a large amount of useful work, thereby avoiding the worst-case performance of B-trees, in which each disk write may change a small amount of data on disk.

title: Fractal tree index
text: Like a B-tree, Fractal Tree indexes are optimized for systems that read and write large blocks of data.

title: Fractal tree index
text: The Fractal Tree index has been commercialized in databases by Tokutek.

title: Fractal tree index
text: Originally, it was implemented as a cache-oblivious lookahead array, but the current implementation is an extension of the B tree.

title: Fractal tree index
text: The B is related to the Buffered Repository Tree.

title: Fractal tree index
