text: The Buffered Repository Tree has degree 2, whereas the B tree has degree B.

title: Fractal tree index
text: The Fractal Tree index has also been used in a prototype filesystem.

title: Fractal tree index
text: An open source implementation of the Fractal Tree index is available, which demonstrates the implementation details outlined below.

title: Weak heap
text: A weak heap is a combination of the binary heap and binomial heap data structures for implementing priority queues.

title: Weak heap
text: It can be stored in an array as an implicit binary tree like the former, and has the efficiency guarantees of the latter.

title: Coprosma repens
text: Coprosma repens is a species of flowering shrub or small tree of the genus "Coprosma", in the family Rubiaceae, native to New Zealand.

title: Coprosma repens
text: Common names include tree bedstraw, taupata, mirror bush, looking-glass bush, New Zealand laurel and shiny leaf.

title: Durvillaea willana
text: Durvillaea willana is a kelp species.

title: Durvillaea willana
text: It is similar to "D. antarctica" but is found in more sheltered coasts.

title: Durvillaea willana
text: "D. willana" has smaller blades than "D. antarctica" and is usually found lower on the shoreline because its tolerance of wave action is not as great as "D. antarctica" (Bradstock, 1989).

title: Durvillaea willana
text: "D. willana" has no common name in New Zealand, however is usually mistaken for bull kelp, "Durvillaea antarctica".

title: Durvillaea willana
text: "D. willana" stipes are thick and long.

title: Durvillaea willana
text: Off the stipe there are side branches of small fronds, this gives the algae a tree like form.

title: Durvillaea willana
text: The fronds are not honeycombed like "D. antarctica".

title: Durvillaea willana
text: The holdfast becomes large and spreads like a plate on rocky substrates (Bradstock, 1989).

title: Duncan Brinsmead
text: Duncan Brinsmead (born January 26, 1960 in Edmonton, Alberta) is a Canadian software programmer, best known for patents on the simulation of natural environments in 3D computer graphics (CGI).

title: Duncan Brinsmead
text: He created the Maya "Paint Effects" for digitally painting instances like plants or hair in a virtual 3D environment.

title: Duncan Brinsmead
text: In 2008, together with Jos Stam, Julia Pakalns and Martin Werner he received an Academy Award for Technical Achievement for the design and implementation of the Maya "Fluid Effects" system.

title: Duncan Brinsmead
text: Fluid Effects are based on the simulation of fluid mechanics in software and used for simulating natural phenomena such as fog, steam or smoke.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The poem begins with the description of the tree.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The poet says that the creeper has wound itself round the rugged trunk of the Casuarina Tree, like a huge Python.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The creeper has left deep marks on the trunk of the tree.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The tree is so strong that it bears the tight hold of the creeper.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The tree is described as being gallant, and possibly brave, as very few trees could survive in the strangle-hold of this creeper.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The poet then goes on to describe the life that thrives amidst every facet of the tree.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The tree is metaphorical said as a giant due to its huge size, strength and boldness.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The Casuarina Tree is covered with creeper which bears red crimson flowers which appear as though the tree is wearing a colorful scarf.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: Often at night, the garden echoes and it seems to be jubilant and the song (of a nightingale) has no end; it continues till dawn.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: At dawn when the poet opens her window she is delighted to see the Casuarina Tree.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: Mostly in winters a gray baboon is seen sitting on the crest of the tree seeing the sunrise with her younger ones leaping and playing in the tree's boughs.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The shadow of the tree appears to fall on the huge water tank.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: Toru Dutt says that it is not because of the majestic appearance of the Casuarina Tree that it is dear to her heart and soul, but also that she along with her siblings spent happy moments under it.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: Toru Dutt has brought out the theme of nature as something that shares feeling with humans, that lightens the burden on the heart.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The poet continues with a description of how strong the image of the tree is, even when in lands far away.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: Even in France and Italy (where the poet studied), she can hear the tree's lament.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: The poet wishes to consecrate the tree's memory and importance for the sake of those who are now dead - and looks ahead to her own death, hoping that the tree be spared obscurity (or that no-one will remember it).

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: She immortalizes the tree through this poem like how Wordsworth sanctified the Yew trees of Borrowdale.

title: Our Casuarina Tree
text: She says "May love defend thee from Oblivion's curse'"- by which she means that she is glad that her love for the Casuarina will protect it from the curse of being forgotten.

title: X-Men: The Official Game
text: X-Men: The Official Game (also known as X3: The Official Game) is Activision's tie-in video game to the 2006 film "".

title: X-Men: The Official Game
text: The game covers the events of the films "X2" and "", specifically following the characters of Wolverine, Iceman, and Nightcrawler.

title: X-Men: The Official Game
text: It also bridges the gap between the two films, explaining why Nightcrawler is not present for "The Last Stand", and also introduces new foes to the "X-Men" film canon, such as HYDRA.

title: Lego Knights' Kingdom
text: Lego Knights' Kingdom is an action-adventure video game based on the Lego toy brand.

title: Lego Knights' Kingdom
text: It was developed by Razorback Developments and published in 2004 by THQ for the Game Boy Advance handheld system.

title: Lego Knights' Kingdom
text: It was the second game based on the Knights' Kingdom theme, after "".

title: Lego Knights' Kingdom
text: However, that game was based on the first version of Knights' Kingdom, while the GBA game is based on the second version.

title: Jordan Fry
text: Jordan Paul Fry (born June 7, 1993) is an American actor, best known for his roles as Mike Teavee in the 2005 film "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory", and its tie-in video game, and as Lewis/Cornelius Robinson in "Meet the Robinsons".

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: Mighty Max was a series of toys that were manufactured by Bluebird Toys PLC in the UK in 1992, and designed by Big Monster Toys.

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: The toys were similar to the earlier Polly Pocket toyline; however, these toys were marketed primarily towards young boys.

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: In Canada and the USA, they were distributed by Irwin Toy Limited and Mattel Inc. respectively.

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: The original toyline consisted mainly of "Doom Zones" and "Horror Heads."

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: "Doom Zones" were small playsets with a horror theme and featured miniature figurines of menacing creatures and the hero Max, a young boy with blond hair, jeans, a white t-shirt with a red "M" on it, and a baseball cap (the color varied based on the playset purchased) which also always had an "M" on it.

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: The "Horror Heads" were smaller-sized playsets, also shaped like the heads of creatures and contained miniature figures.

title: Mighty Max (toyline)
text: It was later adapted into a TV series, as well as a tie-in video game produced by Ocean Software for the Super NES and Mega Drive/Genesis.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: Star Trek is a third-person action-adventure "Star Trek" video game.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: It was developed by Digital Extremes and co-published by Namco Bandai Games and Paramount Pictures in association with CBS Studios International.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: The game was first released in the United States on April 23, 2013, for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and Microsoft Windows platforms.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: It took three years to produce, and was the first in-house video game development by Paramount Studios, who opted not to license development to a third party.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: The production team aimed for it to be a collaboration with those working on the "Star Trek" films to avoid the typical pitfalls associated with film tie-in video games.

title: Star Trek (2013 video game)
text: Video games which influenced "Star Trek" included the "Mass Effect" series, "Uncharted" and "Metroid Prime", and certain elements of "Star Trek" reflected episodes of "" such as "" and "Amok Time".

title: Catwoman (video game)
text: Catwoman is an action-adventure tie-in video game based on the 2004 film of the same name based on the fictional character.

title: Catwoman (video game)
text: It features the likeness of the film's lead actress, Halle Berry, though the character's voice is provided by actress Jennifer Hale.

title: Tron: Evolution
text: Tron: Evolution is a third-person action-adventure, tie-in video game for the film "" by Propaganda Games, published by Disney Interactive.

title: Tron: Evolution
text: It was officially announced at the Spike Video Game Awards and was released for the Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, PlayStation Portable and Xbox 360 platforms in 2010.

title: Lego Star Wars: The Video Game
text: Lego Star Wars: The Video Game is a Lego-themed, action-adventure video game based on the Lego Star Wars line of toys, and the first game in TT Games' Lego video game franchise.

title: Lego Star Wars: The Video Game
text: It was first released on 29 March 2005, and is a video game adaptation of the "Star Wars" prequel trilogy: "" (1999), "" (2002) and "" (2005), with a bonus segment from "A New Hope" (1977).

title: Tron Evolution: Battle Grids
text: Tron Evolution: Battle Grids is a video game based on the 2010 film "" and the Wii and Nintendo DS version of the third-person action-adventure tie-in video game by the .

title: Tron Evolution: Battle Grids
text: Its storyline predates that of the other versions.

title: Tron Evolution: Battle Grids
text: The video game was developed by n-Space and published by Disney Interactive Studios.

title: Shrek Forever After (video game)
text: Shrek Forever After (also known as Shrek 4, and Shrek Forever After: The Final Chapter) is an action-adventure video game based on the film of the same name.

title: Shrek Forever After (video game)
text: It was released on May 18, 2010, in North America.

title: Shrek Forever After (video game)
text: It is the fourth and final video game based on the movie series of "Shrek".

title: Shrek Forever After (video game)
text: This was also the last Shrek game to be developed by Activison.

title: Sam Long
text: Samuel Patrick Robert Long (born 16 January 1995) is an English professional footballer who plays as a defender for Oxford United.

title: Mirco Scarantino
text: Mirco Scarantino (born 16 January 1995) is an Italian weightlifter.

title: Mirco Scarantino
text: He competed at the 2012 Summer Olympics in the Men's 56 kg, finishing 14th and at the 2016 Summer Olympics in the Men's 56 kg, finishing 7th.

title: Filming of James Bond in the 1990s
text: Principal photography for the film began on 16 January 1995 and continued until 6 June.

title: Filming of James Bond in the 1990s
text: The producers were unable to film at Pinewood Studios, the usual location for Bond films, because it had been reserved for "First Knight".

title: Filming of James Bond in the 1990s
text: Instead, an old Rolls-Royce factory at the Leavesden Aerodrome in Hertfordshire was converted into a new studio.

title: Filming of James Bond in the 1990s
text: The producers later said Pinewood would have been too small.

title: Donald Duffy
text: Donald Grant Duffy (1 January 1915 – 16 January 1995) was an Australian doctor and surgeon.

title: Donald Duffy
text: He served in the Australian Army in World War II and was a president of the Melbourne Football Club.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: "Home and Away" is an Australian soap opera first broadcast on the Seven Network on 17 January 1988.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: The following is a list of characters that first appeared in 1995, by order of first appearance.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: They were all introduced by the show's then executive producer John Holmes.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: The 8th season of "Home and Away" began airing on 16 January 1995.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: The first introduction of the year was Daniel Goddard as drug dealer Eric Phillips.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Adrian Lee began portraying teacher Andrew Warren in March.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Nic Testoni joined the serial in April as Travis Nash.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Kristy Wright took on the role of Chloe Richards in June.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Kimberley Joseph began playing Joanne Brennan from July.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Katrina Hobbs began playing doctor Kelly Watson in August.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: Nick Freedman debuted as Alex Bennett in October.

title: List of Home and Away characters (1995)
text: The following month, David Ritchie arrived as Alex's father, Saul.

title: 1995 Benson and Hedges Open
text: The 1995 Benson and Hedges Open was a men's tennis tournament held in Auckland, New Zealand and played on outdoor hard courts.

title: 1995 Benson and Hedges Open
text: The event was part of the World Series of the 1995 ATP Tour.

title: 1995 Benson and Hedges Open
text: It was the 28th edition of the tournament and was held from 9 January through 16 January 1995.

title: 1995 Benson and Hedges Open
text: Unseeded Thomas Enqvist won the singles title.

title: BBC World News
text: BBC World News is the BBC's international news and current affairs television channel.

title: BBC World News
text: It has the largest audience of any BBC channel, with an estimated 99 million viewers weekly in 2015/16, part of the estimated 265 million users of the BBC's four main international news services.

title: BBC World News
text: Launched on 11 March 1991 as BBC World Service Television outside Europe, its name was changed to BBC World on 16 January 1995 and to BBC World News on 21 April 2008.

title: BBC World News
text: It broadcasts news bulletins, documentaries, lifestyle programmes and interview shows.

title: BBC World News
text: Unlike the BBC's domestic channels, BBC World News is owned and operated by BBC Global News Ltd., part of the BBC's commercial group of companies, and is funded by subscription and advertising revenues, and not by the United Kingdom television licence.

title: BBC World News
text: It is not owned by BBC Worldwide.

title: Danny Bakker (footballer, born 16 January 1995)
text: Danny Bakker (born 16 January 1995) is a Dutch footballer who plays as a midfielder for ADO Den Haag.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: Kurama Tatsuya (16 December 1952 - 26 January 1995) was a sumo wrestler from Yasu, Shiga Prefecture, Japan.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He fought under his real name for his entire career, never adopting a traditional shikona.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He made his debut for the Tokitsukaze stable in September 1968.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He was called the "last disiciple of Futabayama," as the great yokozuna who had founded the stable died at the end of the year.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He was ranked in the top makuuchi division for 62 tournaments from 1976 to 1988, reaching a highest rank of sekiwake which he held for one tournament in May 1978.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He won two Technique and one Fighting Spirit prize, and earned two kinboshi for defeating yokozuna.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He was a highly popular wrestler, and was regarded as one of the most handsome rikishi of his time (alongside Wakanohana II).

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He retired in September 1989, and was the oldest man in any of the professional sumo divisions at the time.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: His retirement followed a diagnosis of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He became an elder of the Japan Sumo Association under the name Shikoroyama, but left his role in 1990 due to ill health.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He became a tarento and sumo commentator, although he kept his illness secret from the public.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: He died of leukemia in January 1995 at the age of 42.

title: Kurama Tatsuya
text: His wife , an actress, wrote a best-selling book about their struggles with his illness.

title: Julia Ormond
text: Julia Karin Ormond (born 4 January 1965) is an English actress.

title: Julia Ormond
text: She rose to prominence appearing in such films as "The Baby of Mâcon" (1993), "Legends of the Fall" (1994), "First Knight" (1995), "Sabrina" (1995), "Smilla's Sense of Snow" (1997) and "The Barber of Siberia" (1998).

title: Julia Ormond
text: She won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie for her role in the HBO film "Temple Grandin" (2010).

title: Kenneth Posner
text: Kenneth Posner is an American theatrical lighting designer, working on Broadway, Off-Broadway, and in American regional theatre.

title: Kenneth Posner
text: His most notable designs include the musicals "Wicked" and "Hairspray", two highly regarded musicals of the early 21st century.

title: Kenneth Posner
text: He has been nominated for the Tony Award for Best Lighting Design 10 times, including nods for "Merchant of Venice" (2011), "The Coast of Utopia" (2007), "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels" (2005), "Wicked" (2004), "Hairspray" (2003), and "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" (2001).

title: Kenneth Posner
text: He has also been nominated 10 times for the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Lighting Design, and won both the Tony and Drama Desk award in 2007 for "The Coast of Utopia".

title: Kenneth Posner
text: He also has received an Obie Award for Sustained Excellence in Lighting.

title: Kenneth Posner
text: He also designed the lights for "Little Women".

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance
text: The Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance is an annual award presented by Drama Desk in recognition of achievements in the theatre among Broadway, Off Broadway and Off-Off Broadway productions.

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance
text: The category was first presented at the 1984 ceremony, when it was known as the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding One-Person Show.

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance
text: The award has been known by its current name since 1999.

title: Open Admissions
text: Open Admissions is a play in two acts by Shirley Lauro that premiered in 1982 at the Long Wharf Theatre under the direction of Arvin Brown.

title: Open Admissions
text: The play had its Broadway debut on January 29, 1984 at the Music Box Theatre where it ran for a total of 17 performances.

title: Open Admissions
text: The Broadway production starred Calvin Levels as Calvin Jefferson, Marilyn Rockafellow as Ginny Carlsen, Nan-Lynn Nelson as Salina Jones, Pam Potillo as Georgia Jones, and Sloane Shelton as Professor Clare Block.

title: Open Admissions
text: The play depicts the travails of a professor at a second-rate college, including an unsupportive husband.

title: Open Admissions
text: Levels won a Theatre World Award and was nominated for both a Tony Award and Drama Desk Award for his performance.

title: Open Admissions
text: Rockafellow also received a Drama Desk Award nomination.

title: Open Admissions
text: On Broadway, "Open Admissions" received a Theatre World Award, The Dramatists Guild Hull-Warriner Award.

title: Gerard Alessandrini
text: Gerard Alessandrini (born November 27, 1953) is an American playwright, parodist, actor and theatre director best known for creating the award-winning off-Broadway musical theatre parody revue "Forbidden Broadway".

title: Gerard Alessandrini
text: He is the recipient of Tony Honors for Excellence in Theatre, an Obie Award, four Drama Desk Awards (including the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Lyrics and the Drama Desk Special Award), an Outer Critics Circle Award, and two Lucille Lortel Awards, as well as the Drama League Award for Lifetime Achievement in Musical Theatre.

title: Brad Alexander
text: Brad Alexander (born February 2, 1971) is an American songwriter and musical theater composer, most notably of the musical "See Rock City & Other Destinations", which won the 2011 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Book of a Musical, the Richard Rodgers Award and the BMI Foundation’s Jerry Bock Award.

title: Brad Alexander
text: He wrote the music and orchestrations for Theatreworks USA’s "Click, Clack, Moo", which premiered Off-Broadway at the Lucille Lortel Theater and received a Drama Desk Award nomination for Outstanding Lyrics and Lucille Lortel Award nominations for Outstanding Choreographer, Outstanding Lyrics and Outstanding Musical.

title: Brad Alexander
text: His songs have been featured on Sony Records, Select Records, Showtime’s The L Word, VH1's “Celebreality” campaign, Sirius XM Radio and web series Submissions Only.

title: Brad Alexander
text: He is a member of the Songwriters Hall of Fame, National Alliance for Musical Theatre, Dramatists Guild of America and member Emeritus of The BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop.

title: Brad Alexander
text: He is married to actress and writer Jill Abramovitz.

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director
text: This is a list of winners of the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director introduced in 1955 to honour directors of plays and directors of musicals.

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director
text: From 1968, multiple awards were presented for each season.

title: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director
text: In 1975 the category was retired and divided into Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Play and Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Musical, with each discipline receiving its own.

title: Nick Cordero
text: Nick Cordero is a Canadian actor.

title: Nick Cordero
text: He appeared on Broadway in 2014 in the musical "Bullets Over Broadway" in the role of Cheech, for which he was nominated for the Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Musical and the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actor in a Musical.

title: Nick Cordero
text: He won the Outer Critics Circle Award for Outstanding Featured Actor in a Musical and a Theater World Award for the role.

title: Nick Cordero
text: He originated the title role in the Off-Broadway production of "The Toxic Avenger".

title: Nick Cordero
text: He also played the role of Dennis in "Rock of Ages" on Broadway in 2012 and on tour.

title: Nick Cordero
text: In March 2016, he joined the Broadway production of "Waitress", playing the role of Earl.

title: Nick Cordero
text: He left "Waitress" to join the Broadway premier of the musical "A Bronx Tale", as "Sonny" at the Longacre Theatre starting on November 3, 2016.

title: Grease: The New Broadway Cast Recording
text: Grease: The New Broadway Cast Recording is the cast album for the 2007 Broadway production of the hit musical, "Grease".

title: Grease: The New Broadway Cast Recording
text: The show, directed by Tony Award-winner Kathleen Marshall, played at the Brooks Atkinson Theatre in New York City.

title: Grease: The New Broadway Cast Recording
text: This recording features performances from the cast of "Grease" including Jenny Powers, Matthew Saldivar, and "" winners, Laura Osnes and Max Crumm as Sandy Dumbrowski and Danny Zuko, respectively.

title: Laura Osnes
text: Laura Ann Osnes (born November 19, 1985) is an American actress and singer known for her work on the Broadway stage.

title: Laura Osnes
text: She has played starring roles in "Grease" as Sandy, "South Pacific" as Nellie Forbush, "Anything Goes" as Hope Harcourt, and "Bonnie and Clyde" as Bonnie Parker, for which she received a Tony Award nomination for Best Actress in a Musical.

title: Laura Osnes
text: She also starred in the title role of Rodgers & Hammerstein's "Cinderella" on Broadway, for which she received a Drama Desk Award and her second Tony Award nomination for Best Actress in a Musical.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: 9 to 5: The Musical is a musical based on the 1980 movie of the same name, with music and lyrics by Dolly Parton.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: It features a book by Patricia Resnick, based on the screenplay by Resnick and Colin Higgins.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: The musical premiered in Los Angeles in September 2008, and opened on Broadway in April 2009.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: It received 15 Drama Desk Award nominations, the most received by a production in a single year, as well as four Tony Awards nominations.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: The Broadway production however was short-lived, closing in September 2009.

title: 9 to 5 (musical)
text: A national tour of the US launched in 2010, followed by a UK premiere in 2012 and returns to the UK in 2017 in a new production at The Gatehouse in London with a West End cast, as part of a fringe festival.

title: Sachin H. Jain
text: Sachin H. Jain (born in 1980 in New York City and raised in Alpine, New Jersey) is an American physician and health policy analyst who held leadership positions in the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC).

title: Sachin H. Jain
text: He is president and chief executive officer at the CareMore Health System after serving as Chief Medical Information and Innovation Officer at Merck and Co, lecturer in health care policy at Harvard Medical School, and attending physician at the Boston VA Hospital.

title: Sachin H. Jain
text: He is also co-founder and co-Editor-in-Chief of "Healthcare: The Science of Delivery and Innovation", consulting professor of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine, and a Contributor at Forbes.

title: Barbara Jordan Health Policy Scholars
text: Known informally at the BJ scholars, this summer fellowship is sponsored by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

title: Barbara Jordan Health Policy Scholars
text: The program brings talented African American, Hispanic/Latino, American Indian/Alaska Native, Asian, and Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander college seniors and recent graduates to Washington, D.C., where they are placed in congressional offices and learn about health policy.

title: Barbara Jordan Health Policy Scholars
text: Through the nine-week program, scholars gain knowledge about federal legislative procedure and health policy issues, while further developing their critical thinking and leadership skills.

title: Barbara Jordan Health Policy Scholars
text: In addition to gaining experience in a congressional office, Scholars participate in seminars and site visits to augment their knowledge of health care issues, and write and present a health policy research memo.

title: Everette James
text: Everette James is Professor of Health Policy and Management at the University of Pittsburgh and Director of the University of Pittsburgh’s Health Policy Institute (HPI).

title: Everette James
text: In September, 2014 he was named to the M. Allen Pond Endowed Chair in Health Policy and Management.

title: Everette James
text: He teaches graduate courses on the history of U.S. health reform and writes and speaks frequently on healthcare business and legal issues.

title: Marion Greene
text: Marion C. Greene (born July 16, 1970) is a Hennepin County commissioner (District 3) and a former member of the Minnesota House of Representatives who represented District 60A, which included portions of the city of Minneapolis in Hennepin County, which is in the Twin Cities metropolitan area.

title: Marion Greene
text: A Democrat, she was a health policy analyst for St. Jude Medical in Little Canada.

title: 25 Field Ambulance
text: 25 (Toronto) Field Ambulance (formerly "25 (Toronto) Medical Company") is a Canadian Forces Primary Reserve (militia) medical unit in Toronto, Ontario.

title: 25 Field Ambulance
text: The company-strength formation is part of 4 Health Services Group, which is headquartered in Montreal, Quebec.

title: 25 Field Ambulance
text: It is the only Primary Reserve medical unit in Toronto.

title: 25 Field Ambulance
text: The unit fields a medical company, a services support company, and an HQ element.

title: 25 Field Ambulance
text: The unit's name is often abbreviated to 25 Fd Amb.

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: The California Center for Public Health Advocacy, located in Davis, California, is a nonprofit lobbying organization founded in 1999 by California’s two public health associations which, according to its website, "tackles the underlying factors that perpetuate childhood obesity and undermine parents’ desire to keep their children healthy: multibillion-dollar marketing and overwhelming availability of unhealthy foods and beverages, limited access to fresh fruits and vegetables in far too many communities, schools failing to provide quality physical education, cities designed for cars rather than pedestrians and bicyclists, and lack of safe places for children to play."

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: They run the anti-soft drink website Kickthecan.info, which has launched a petition to the beverage industry to "be a (real) part of the solution" whose signatories include Laurie David, Michael Jacobson, Robert Kenner, and Marion Nestle, and are behind a number of soda tax bills in their home state, such as that introduced by Bill Monning in February 2013.

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: Its executive director, Harold Goldstein, has written an opinion piece in the Los Angeles Daily News regarding what he considers the benefits of soda taxation.

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: He has also authored a policy brief by the University of California Los Angeles.

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: Goldstein has also authored an article calling for celebrities to "stop accepting sugary drink endorsements," as well as a commentary in the Journal of Public Health Policy regarding the reasons why scientific research is not easily transformed into public health policy, and about the CCPHA's campaigns to, among other things, remove soda and junk food from public schools.

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: Goldstein has also gone on record as saying that sugary drinks "should be prohibited in all public places, including community centres and sports arenas."

title: California Center for Public Health Advocacy
text: The Center has also published research concluding that were California Assembly Bill 669 to be passed, that "85 percent  or $1.4 billion, would be returned to counties, in proportion to their population, to pay for education and children’s health programs."

title: Diana Zuckerman
text: Diana M. Zuckerman (born 16 June 1950) is an American health policy analyst who focuses on the implications of policies for public health and patients’ health.

title: Diana Zuckerman
text: She is an expert on national health policy, particularly in women's health and the safety and effectiveness of medical products.

title: Diana Zuckerman
text: She is the President of the National Center for Health Research (formerly National Research Center for Women & Families) and the Cancer Prevention and Treatment Fund.

title: Health services research
text: Health services research (HSR), also known as health systems research or health policy and systems research (HPSR), is a multidisciplinary scientific field that examines how people get access to health care practitioners and health care services, how much care costs, and what happens to patients as a result of this care.

title: Health services research
text: Studies in HSR investigate how social factors, health policy, financing systems, organizational structures and processes, medical technology, and personal behaviors affect access to health care, the quality and cost of health care, and quantity and quality of life.

title: Health services research
text: Compared with medical research, HSR is a relatively young science that developed through the bringing together of social science perspectives with the contributions of individuals and institutions engaged in delivering health services.

title: National Association for Public Health Policy
text: The National Association for Public Health Policy was founded in 1980 by a group of past-presidents of the American Public Health Association led by Milton Terris, MD, MPH.

title: National Association for Public Health Policy
text: The purpose of the Association is “to improve the health of the people of the United States by helping to develop health policy, formulating and initiating legislation to implement such policy, and supporting measures to strengthen the public health services.”

title: National Association for Public Health Policy
text: It sponsors the "Journal of Public Health Policy" and the online journal "NAPHP.ORG".

title: Forward surgical teams
text: In the United States Army, Medical Detachments (Forward Surgical), popularly known as Forward Surgical Teams (FST), are small, mobile surgical units fielded since the 1990s.

title: Forward surgical teams
text: FSTs are utilized in a variety of ways, and can fielded with support elements, including a Forward Support Medical Company (FSMC), Area Support Medical Company (ASMC), Brigade Medical Company also known as C-Med or in some cases stand alone (although The FST is not designed, staffed, or equipped for standalone

title: Lepidozamia
text: Lepidozamia is a genus of two species of cycad, both endemic to Australia.

title: Lepidozamia
text: The name, derived from the Greek word lepidos, meaning scaly, refers to the scale-like structure of the stem and leaf bases.

title: Lepidozamia
text: They are native to rainforest climates in eastern Queensland and eastern New South Wales.

title: Lepidozamia
text: They have a chromosome number of 2n = 18.

title: Eucryphia
text: Eucryphia is a small genus of trees and large shrubs native to the south temperate regions of South America and coastal eastern Australia.

title: Eucryphia
text: Sometimes placed in a family of their own, the Eucryphiaceae, more recent classifications place them in the Cunoniaceae.

title: Eucryphia
text: There are seven species, two in South America and five in Australia, and several named hybrids.

title: Eucryphia
text: They are mostly evergreen though one species ("E. glutinosa") is usually deciduous.

title: George Frideric Handel
text: George Frideric (or Frederick) Handel ( ; born Georg Friedrich Händel ] ; 23 February 1685 (O.S.)  – 14 April 1759) was a German, later British, baroque composer who spent the bulk of his career in London, becoming well known for his operas, oratorios, anthems, and organ concertos. Handel received important training in Halle and worked as a composer in Hamburg and Italy before settling in London in 1712; he became a naturalised British subject in 1727.

title: George Frideric Handel
text: He was strongly influenced both by the great composers of the Italian Baroque and by the middle-German polyphonic choral tradition.

title: Tomaso Albinoni
text: Tomaso Giovanni Albinoni (8 June 1671 – 17 January 1751) was an Italian Baroque composer.

title: Tomaso Albinoni
text: While famous in his day as an opera composer, he is mainly remembered today for his instrumental music, such as the concerti.

title: Luigi Rossi
text: Luigi Rossi (c. 1597 – 20 February 1653) was an Italian Baroque composer.

title: Luigi Rossi
text: Rossi was born in Torremaggiore, a small town near Foggia, in the ancient kingdom of Naples and at an early age he went to Naples.

title: Luigi Rossi
text: There he studied music with the Franco-Flemish composer Jean de Macque who was organist of the Santa Casa dell’Annunziata and "maestro di cappella" to the Spanish viceroy.

title: Luigi Rossi
text: Rossi later entered the service of the Caetani, dukes of Traetta.

title: Domenico Scarlatti
text: Giuseppe Domenico Scarlatti (Naples, 26 October 1685 Madrid, 23 July 1757) was an Italian composer who spent much of his life in the service of the Portuguese and Spanish royal families.

title: Domenico Scarlatti
text: He is classified primarily as a Baroque composer chronologically, although his music was influential in the development of the Classical style and he was one of the few Baroque composers to transition into the classical period.

title: Domenico Scarlatti
text: Like his renowned father Alessandro Scarlatti, he composed in a variety of musical forms, although today he is known mainly for his 555 keyboard sonatas.

title: L'estro armonico
text: L'estro armonico (the harmonic inspiration), Antonio Vivaldi's Op.

title: L'estro armonico
text: 3, is a set of 12 concertos for stringed instruments, first published in Amsterdam in 1711.

title: L'estro armonico
text: Vivaldi's Twelve Trio Sonatas, Op. 1, and Twelve Violin Sonatas, Op. 2, only contained sonatas, thus "L'estro armonico" was his first collection of concertos appearing in print.

title: L'estro armonico
text: It was also the first time he chose a foreign publisher, Estienne Roger, instead of an Italian.

title: L'estro armonico
text: Each concerto was printed in eight parts: four violins, two violas, cello and continuo.

title: L'estro armonico
text: The continuo part was printed as a figured bass for violone and harpsichord.

title: Antonio Vivaldi
text: Antonio Lucio Vivaldi (] ; 4 March 1678 – 28 July 1741) was an Italian Baroque composer, virtuoso violinist, teacher and cleric.

title: Antonio Vivaldi
text: Born in Venice, he is recognized as one of the greatest Baroque composers, and his influence during his lifetime was widespread across Europe.

title: Antonio Vivaldi
text: He composed many instrumental concertos, for the violin and a variety of other instruments, as well as sacred choral works and more than forty operas. His best-known work is a series of violin concertos known as "The Four Seasons".

title: Lorenzo Ratti
text: Lorenzo Ratti (ca. 1589–1630) was an Italian baroque composer.

title: Lorenzo Ratti
text: He was the predecessor of Carissimi at the Collegium Germanicum.

title: Lorenzo Ratti
text: He composed six Gospel Dialogues for the oratory.

title: Lorenzo Ratti
text: He was a teacher of Benevoli.

title: Francesco Scarlatti
text: Francesco Scarlatti (5 December 1666 – c. 1741) was an Italian Baroque composer and musician and the younger brother of the better known Alessandro Scarlatti.

title: Jean-Baptiste Senaillé
text: Jean Baptiste Senaillé (23 November 1687 in Paris – 15 October 1730 idem) was a French born Baroque composer and violin virtuoso.

title: Jean-Baptiste Senaillé
text: His father was a member of Les Vingt-quatre Violons du Roi.

title: Jean-Baptiste Senaillé
text: Senaillé studied under Jean-Baptiste Anet, Giovanni Antonio Piani and in Italy under Tomaso Antonio Vitali and imported Italian musical techniques and pieces into the French court.

title: Jean-Baptiste Senaillé
text: He wrote around 50 violin sonatas.

title: Jean-Baptiste Senaillé
text: He is most well known for a fast 2/4 movement from one of these sonatas, "Allegro Spiritoso", which has had versions published transcribed for a wide variety of instruments, from violoncello to bassoon to euphonium.

title: Antonio Lotti
text: Antonio Lotti (5 January 1667 – 5 January 1740) was an Italian Baroque composer.

title: Mister Pipeline
text: Mister Pipeline is a title given to masters of the waves at the North Shore's Pipeline.

title: Mister Pipeline
text: It was first given to Butch Van Artsdalen, and is passed on from generation to generation, by consensus.

title: Mister Pipeline
text: Other holders of the title have included sometime actor Gerry Lopez and bodyboarding legend Mike Stewart.

title: Lake surfing
text: Lake surfing is surfing on any lake with sufficient surface area for wind to produce suitable waves.

title: Lake surfing
text: As with ocean surfing, ideal wave conditions are when the wind switches offshore.

title: Lake surfing
text: However, when this occurs over a lake the waves generated by previous onshore wind subside relatively quickly.

title: Lake surfing
text: This means lake surfers have a shorter window of opportunity to surf ideal waves.

title: Lake surfing
text: Lake surfers are often out during and experiencing the same storm that creates the waves whereas ocean surfers are more often surfing on swell produced by storms hundreds of miles away and that may have taken days to reach shore.

title: Lake surfing
text: In addition to making it more difficult to manage surfboards, high winds can make the face of a wave and water surface rough.

title: Lake surfing
text: Increased wave frequency due to shorter fetch results in less rest between waves and sets of waves.

title: Lake surfing
text: This can make it necessary to paddle out through waves because there may not be a long enough pause between sets to paddle out between them.

title: Lake surfing
text: Though not significant enough to necessitate surfboard design changes, the reduced buoyancy of fresh water results in increased drag when paddling.

title: Lake surfing
text: Lake surfers enjoy water that is fresh ("sweet" as opposed to salty) and do not have to worry about the dangers from marine life (e.g. sharks, jellyfish, etc.) that ocean surfers may have to contend with.

title: Brylan Van Artsdalen
text: Brylan Van Artsdalen (born August 14, 1984) is an American mixed martial artist currently competing in the Featherweight division.

title: Brylan Van Artsdalen
text: A professional competitor since 2010, Van Artsdalen has formerly competed for Bellator and CES MMA.

title: Skimboarding
text: Skimboarding (or skimming) is a boardsport in which a "skimboard" (much like a surfboard but smaller and without fins) is used to glide across the water's surface to meet an incoming breaking wave, and ride it back to shore.

title: Skimboarding
text: Wave-riding skimboarders perform a variety of surface and air maneuvers, at various stages of their ride, out to, and back with, the wave.

title: Skimboarding
text: Some of these are known as "wraps," "big spins," "360 shove-its" and "180s."

title: Skimboarding
text: Unlike surfing, skimboarding begins on the beach by dropping the board onto the thin wash of previous waves.

title: Skimboarding
text: Skimboarders use their momentum to skim out to breaking waves, which they then catch back into shore in a manner similar to surfing.

title: Skimboarding
text: Another aspect of skimboarding is "flatland," which involves performing tricks derived from skateboarding such as ollies and shove-its on the wash of waves without catching shore breaks. Skimboarding originated in Southern California when Laguna Beach lifeguards wanted to surf the local shore breaks that was too fast and shallow for surfboards.

title: Skimboarding
text: Skimboarding has developed since then to ride waves much like surfing, performing aerial maneuvers and pulling into the barrel of the wave.

title: Skimboarding
text: Even further, professionals have started getting towed by waverunners into much larger waves.

title: Skimboarding
text: Professional Skimboarder, Brad Domke, displayed the new technique in this video.

title: Donald West VanArtsdalen
text: Donald West VanArtsdalen (sometimes listed as Van Artsdalen; born October 21, 1919) is a Senior United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

title: Butch Van Artsdalen
text: Charles M. Van Artsdalen (January 31, 1941 – July 18, 1979) was a legendary surfer.

title: Butch Van Artsdalen
text: He moved to La Jolla, California, from his birthplace of Norfolk, Virginia, at age 14.

title: Butch Van Artsdalen
text: Van Artsdalen is best known as a pioneer of surfing 25-foot waves at such North Shore locations as Waimea Bay and Sunset Beach; and tube riding in Hawaii during the early 1960-1970s.

title: Butch Van Artsdalen
text: A member of the Duke Kahanamoku Surf Team, he appeared in several surf movies and remained a fixture of the international surfing community until his death from alcohol-related illness in 1979.

title: Tow-in surfing
text: Tow-in surfing is a surfing technique which uses artificial assistance to allow the surfer to catch faster moving waves than was traditionally possible when paddling by hand.

title: Tow-in surfing
text: Tow-in surfing was invented by surfers who wanted to catch big waves and break the 30 foot barrier.

title: Tow-in surfing
text: It has been one of the biggest breakthroughs in surfing history.

title: Waimea Bay, Hawaii
text: Waimea Bay is located in Haleiwa on the North Shore of O'ahu in the Hawaiian Islands at the mouth of the Waimea River.

title: Waimea Bay, Hawaii
text: Waimea Valley extends behind Waimea Bay.

title: Waimea Bay, Hawaii
text: "Waimea" means "reddish water" in Hawaiian.

title: Waimea Canyon State Park
text: Waimea Canyon, also known as the "Grand Canyon of the Pacific", is a large canyon, approximately ten miles (16 km) long and up to 3,000 feet (900 m) deep, located on the western side of Kauaʻ i in the Hawaiian Islands of the United States.

title: Waimea Canyon State Park
text: Waimea is Hawaiian for "reddish water", a reference to the erosion of the canyon's red soil.

title: Waimea Canyon State Park
text: The canyon was formed by a deep incision of the Waimea River arising from the extreme rainfall on the island's central peak, Mount Waiʻ aleʻ ale, among the wettest places on earth.

title: Waimea
text: Waimea is a common name in Hawaii and New Zealand.

title: Waimea
text: In Hawaiian, it means reddish water, but in Maori it has no meaning.

title: Waimea
text: It may refer to:

title: Eugene Habecker
text: Dr. Eugene B. Habecker is the 30th president of Taylor University and chairman of Christianity Today.

title: Eugene Habecker
text: Previously, Habecker was president of the American Bible Society.

title: Eugene Habecker
text: He is also the author of several books, two coauthored with his wife, Marylou Habecker.

title: Eugene Habecker
text: He was inaugurated in a ceremony on Friday, April 28, 2006, in Odle Arena on the Upland campus, only two days after a tragic fatal car accident involving several students and employees.

title: Eugene Melnyk
text: Eugene Melnyk (born May 27, 1959) is a Ukrainian Canadian businessman who has resided in Barbados since February 1991.

title: Eugene Melnyk
text: He is the current and sole owner, governor, and chairman of the Ottawa Senators professional ice hockey franchise of the National Hockey League (NHL).

title: Eugene Melnyk
text: He is the founder, former chairman and CEO of Biovail Corporation which was acquired by Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

title: Eugene Melnyk
text: Canadian Business magazine ranked Melnyk 79th with a net worth of $1.21 billion on its 2017 list of Canada's 100 wealthiest people.

title: Eugene Melnyk
text: He is also one of the richest residents of Barbados, where he now lives.

title: Type I Rifle
text: The Type I rifle "Arisaka" (イ式小銃 , "I-shiki shōjū" ) was produced during the early years of World War II for the Japanese Empire by the Kingdom of Italy ("Type I" is not a numeric symbol, it denominates "Italian").

title: Type I Rifle
text: After the invasion of China, all Arisaka production was required for use of the Imperial Army, so under the terms of the Anti-Comintern Pact, the Imperial Navy contracted with Italy for this weapon in 1937.

title: Type I Rifle
text: The Type I is based on the Type 38 rifle and utilizes a Carcano action, but retains the Arisaka/Mauser type 5-round box magazine.

title: Type I Rifle
text: The Type I was utilized primarily by Japanese Imperial Naval Forces.

title: Type I Rifle
text: It is chambered for the 6.5 x 50 mm cartridge.

title: Type I Rifle
text: Approximately 80,000 Type I rifles were produced in 1938 and 1939, 40,000 manufactured by Beretta and an equal number by Italian government arsenals; the final shipment to Japan left Venice by submarine in 1941.

title: Eugene Cross Park
text: Eugene Cross Park is a rugby and cricket ground in Ebbw Vale, Wales.

title: Eugene Cross Park
text: In November 1919 the Ebbw Vale Welfare Association was formed and bought the "Bridgend Field".

title: Eugene Cross Park
text: The 6 acre of land became known as the Welfare Ground, and in 1973 its name was changed to its present title in honour of Sir Eugene Cross, the influential and long-standing Chairman of the Welfare Trustees.

title: Eugene Cross Park
text: The ground has terraces, a stand which was bought due to a fire which burnt the previous stands and a clubhouse which boasts a pub, a club shop open at match days and award-winning hospitality packages.

title: Eugene Cross Park
text: The stadium is adjacent to the B4486 road, the Newchurch Road and the Ebbw River.

title: Eugene R. Black Sr.
text: Eugene "Gene" Robert Black Sr. (May 1, 1898 – February 20, 1992) was President of the World Bank from 1949 to 1963.

title: Eugene R. Black Sr.
text: His father, a 1930s Chairman of the Federal Reserve, also named Eugene Robert Black, did not use the "Sr." suffix; Gene's son (the third in line) became Eugene Robert Black Jr.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: The Type 4 Rifle, often referred to as the Type 5 Rifle, (Japanese: 四式自動小銃 "Yon-shiki jidousyoujyuu") was a Japanese experimental semi-automatic rifle.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: It was a copy of the American M1 Garand but with an integral 10-round magazine and chambered for the Japanese 7.7×58mm Arisaka cartridge.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: Where the Garand used an en-bloc clip, the Type 4's integral magazine was charged with two 5-round stripper clips and the rifle also used Japanese-style tangent sights.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: The Type 4 had been developed alongside several other experimental semi-automatic rifles.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: However, none of the rifles entered into service before the end of World War II, with only 250 being made, and many others were never assembled.

title: Type 4 rifle
text: There were several problems with jamming and feed systems, which also delayed its testing.

title: Eugene Brody
text: Eugene Brody, (Eugene Bloor Brody), (1921–2010) was an American psychiatrist.

title: Eugene Brody
text: Brody was chairman of the department of psychiatry at the University of Maryland School of Medicine and Dean for social and behavioral studies at the University of Maryland.

title: QBB-95
text: The QBB-95 (Type 95) () is the light support weapon variant of the Chinese Type 95 family.

title: QBB-95
text: Based on the QBZ-95, the standard issue to most PLA units, most parts and ammunition of them are interchangeable (while small number of units are issued with Type 56, Type 81, or Type 03 Assault rifle, the latter of which also chambers the same 5.8×42mm DBP87 round).

title: QBB-95
text: This family includes a standard Assault rifle variant, a compact carbine variant and this particular light support weapon/Squad automatic weapon variant.

title: QBB-95
text: The longer, heavier barrel and 80-round drum magazine of the QBB-95 allow sustained firing, however the standard 30-round box magazine is also compatible.

title: Edward E. Cox
text: Edward Eugene "Eugene" or "Goober" Cox (April 3, 1880 – December 24, 1952) served as a U.S. Representative from Georgia for nearly twenty-eight years.

title: Edward E. Cox
text: A conservative Democrat who supported segregation and opposed President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's "New Deal," Cox became the most senior Democrat on the House Committee on Rules.

title: Edward E. Cox
text: Two special investigative committees that he chaired were heavily criticized as result-oriented persecutions of those Cox did not like.

title: Edward E. Cox
text: A failed attempt to create another such committee would turn out to have far-reaching consequences: in 1941, with American entry into World War II seeming inevitable, Cox proposed an investigative committee, similar to the Civil War-era Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War, to deal with matters of national defense.

title: Edward E. Cox
text: When Roosevelt learned of Cox's intentions, he pre-empted them by agreeing to a similar proposal from Missouri Senator Harry S. Truman; the Truman Committee would come to be seen as a significant asset to the war effort, and its chairman - a little-known "backbencher" at the time of its founding - would become Roosevelt's Vice President and, after his death in 1945, President of the United States.

title: Chasing Daylight (book)
text: Chasing Daylight is a biography and a common-sense guidebook on how to embrace death without fear or sadness by Eugene O'Kelly, who is the Ex-Chairman and former CEO of KPMG, one of the largest U.S. accounting firms.

title: Chasing Daylight (book)
text: The biography won, among other awards, the International Business Book Award from the Financial Times.

title: Chasing Daylight (book)
text: The author, Eugene O’Kelly, was the CEO and Chairman of KPMG until being diagnosed with a terminal brain tumor at 53.

title: Chasing Daylight (book)
text: He quit his job to settle his accounts with friends and family and write his book to convey how he lived the last 100 days of his life and make it the best time of his life.

title: 127 Hours (soundtrack)
text: 127 Hours: Music from the Motion Picture is the soundtrack to Danny Boyle's 2010 film of the same name.

title: 127 Hours (soundtrack)
text: It was composed by two-time Academy Award Winner A. R. Rahman, Boyle's previous collaborator on "Slumdog Millionaire".

title: 127 Hours (soundtrack)
text: The score, centred on guitar, was recorded mainly in London and was completed in three weeks.

title: 127 Hours (soundtrack)
text: The soundtrack was released digitally on 2 November and physically on 22 November, by Interscope Records.

title: 127 Hours (soundtrack)
text: The score is briefly orchestral and the song's main theme, "If I Rise" features Rahman playing the Harpejji.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: The Academy Award for Best Film Editing is one of the annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: Nominations for this award are closely correlated with the Academy Award for Best Picture.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: For 33 consecutive years, 1981 to 2013, every Best Picture winner had also been nominated for the Film Editing Oscar, and about two thirds of the Best Picture winners have also won for Film Editing.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: Only the principal, "above the line" editor(s) as listed in the film's credits are named on the award; additional editors, supervising editors, etc. are not currently eligible.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: The nominations for this Academy Award are determined by a ballot of the voting members of the Editing Branch of the Academy; there were 220 members of the Editing Branch in 2012.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: The members may vote for up to five of the eligible films in the order of their preference; the five films with the largest vote totals are selected as nominees.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: The Academy Award itself is selected from the nominated films by a subsequent ballot of all active and life members of the Academy.

title: Academy Award for Best Film Editing
text: This process is essentially the reverse of that of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA); nominations for the BAFTA Award for Best Editing are done by a general ballot of Academy voters, and the winner is selected by members of the editing chapter.

title: James Franco
text: James Edward Franco (born April 19, 1978) is an American actor, director, screenwriter, and producer.

title: James Franco
text: For his role in "127 Hours" (2010), Franco was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor.

title: James Franco
text: He is known for his roles in live-action films such as "Milk" (2008), "Pineapple Express" (2008), "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" (2011), "Spring Breakers" (2012), "Oz the Great and Powerful" (2013), "This Is the End" (2013), " The Disaster Artist" (2017), and Sam Raimi's "Spider-Man" trilogy, while also voicing characters in the animated films "The Little Prince" (2015) and "Sausage Party" (2016).

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: This is a list of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: This list details the performances of Polish actors, actresses, and films that have either been submitted or nominated for, or have won, an Academy Award.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: This list is current as of the 80th Academy Awards ceremony held on February 24, 2008.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: There were 12 Academy Awards given to Polish filmmakers or their work (see Foreign Film category), including two Honorary Academy Awards and a Technical Achievement Award.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: The category of Cinematography has the strongest presence of Polish filmmakers, with two wins (both by Janusz Kamiński) and five other nominations (including two noms for Kamiński).

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: As of that, the cinematographer Janusz Kamiński is the most Oscar-awarded Polish filmmaker.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: The second most-awarded Pole was designer Anton Grot, who won one Academy Award and was nominated to the Oscars five times more.

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: The director Roman Polanski won an Oscar and was nominated four more times (additionally, "Knife in the Water", film directed and written by him was also nominated).

title: List of Polish Academy Award winners and nominees
text: The composer Bronislau Kaper was awarded an Oscar and was nominated three times more.

title: People Like Us (soundtrack)
text: People Like Us: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack is the soundtrack to Alex Kurtzman's 2012 film of the same name.

title: People Like Us (soundtrack)
text: It is composed by Academy Award winning composer A.R. Rahman whose last successful international release was "127 Hours".

title: People Like Us (soundtrack)
text: Rahman began recording the patch work of score in 2011 and the score was completed by late September 2011.

title: People Like Us (soundtrack)
text: The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack was released on June 19, 2012, under the label Lakeshore Records.

title: 127 Hours
text: 127 Hours is a 2010 biographical survival found footage drama film directed, co-written, and produced by Danny Boyle.

title: 127 Hours
text: The film stars James Franco as Aron Ralston, a canyoneer who becomes trapped by a boulder in an isolated slot canyon in Blue John Canyon, southeastern Utah, in April 2003.

title: 127 Hours
text: It is a British and American venture produced by Everest Entertainment, Film4 Productions, HandMade Films and Cloud Eight Films.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: "127 Hours" is a 2010 British independent biographical adventure film directed by Danny Boyle.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: It stars James Franco in the principal role as real-life mountain climber Aron Ralston, whose hand was trapped under a boulder in a Utah ravine for more than five days in April 2003.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: Adapted from Ralston's autobiography "Between a Rock and a Hard Place", "127 Hours"' s screenplay was written by Boyle and Simon Beaufoy.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: Distributors Fox Searchlight and Pathé gave the feature limited releases in the United States and United Kingdom on 5 November 2010 and 7 January 2011, respectively.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: It grossed £35.8 million at the box office by the end of its worldwide theatrical run.

title: List of accolades received by 127 Hours
text: Rotten Tomatoes, a review aggregator surveyed 215 reviews and judged 93% to be positive.

title: Treat Williams
text: Richard Treat Williams (born December 1, 1951) is an American actor and children's book author who has appeared on film, stage and television.

title: Treat Williams
text: He first became well known for his starring role in the 1979 film "Hair", and later also starred in the films "Prince of the City", "Once Upon a Time in America", "The Late Shift" and "127 Hours".

title: Treat Williams
text: From 2002 to 2006, he was the lead of the television series "Everwood" and was nominated for two Screen Actors Guild Awards.

title: Danny Boyle
text: Danny Boyle (born 20 October 1956) is an English director, producer, screenwriter and theatre director, known for his work on films including "Shallow Grave", "Trainspotting", "The Beach", "28 Days Later", "Sunshine", "Slumdog Millionaire", "127 Hours", and "Steve Jobs".

title: Danny Boyle
text: His debut film "Shallow Grave" won the BAFTA Award for Best British Film.

title: Danny Boyle
text: Boyle's 2008 film "Slumdog Millionaire" was nominated for ten Academy Awards and won eight, including the Academy Award for Best Director.

title: Danny Boyle
text: He also won the Golden Globe and BAFTA Award for Best Director.

title: Danny Boyle
text: Boyle was presented with the Extraordinary Contribution to Filmmaking Award at the 2008 Austin Film Festival, where he also introduced that year's AFF Audience Award Winner "Slumdog Millionaire".

title: Silicon Imaging
text: The Silicon Imaging (SI-2K) was a 2K digital video camera built on a single 16mm-sized CMOS sensor manufactured by Altasens.

title: Silicon Imaging
text: It was able to record direct to disk in the compressed CineForm RAW format, and was notable for its tiny detachable camera head, which can be positioned up to 100m from the recording unit through an ethernet cable.

title: Silicon Imaging
text: Danny Boyle and his director of photography Anthony Dod Mantle used the camera on the films Slumdog Millionaire (Academy Award for Best Cinematography) and 127 Hours.

title: Silicon Imaging
text: The head and the recording unit together cost (c.a. 2011) $23,000.

title: Silicon Imaging
text: The head by itself costs $13,750, and could be used to record to a laptop that had appropriate specifications and software.

title: Ambulance (TV series)

text: Detective Inspector Humphrey Goodman is a character in the crime drama television series "Death in Paradise", portrayed by Kris Marshall.

text: Five series have been shown so far.

title: Gameel Al-Batouti
text: Gameel Al-Batouti (Arabic: جميل البطوطي‎ ‎ ; also rendered "Gamil El Batouti" or "El Batouty" in U.S. official reports; 2 February 1940 – 31 October 1999) was a pilot for EgyptAir and a former officer for the Egyptian Air Force.

title: Gameel Al-Batouti
text: On 31 October 1999, all 217 people aboard EgyptAir Flight 990 were killed when it crashed into the Atlantic Ocean about 60 mi southeast of Nantucket Island, Massachusetts.

title: Gameel Al-Batouti
text: The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) concluded that the official probable cause of the crash was a series of control inputs made by Al-Batouti, who was in the position of relief first officer in command at the time of the crash.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: The LeRoy W. Homer Jr.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: Foundation is a national 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded in memory of First Officer LeRoy W. Homer Jr..

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: LeRoy Homer was the co-pilot of United Airlines Flight #93, which crashed in Shanksville, Pennsylvania on September 11, 2001.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: The flight recordings revealed that Dahl and Homer survived the initial attack and were still alive after the hijackers took over the plane.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: It is believed that Dahl and Homer took actions to interfere with the hijackers, including disengaging the autopilot just before the hijackers took over in order to prevent them from setting the plane's target coordinates for Washington, D.C., and switching the output of the pilots' microphones from the cabin address speakers to the radio transmitter so that Jarrah's attempts to communicate with the passengers would instead be heard by air traffic controllers.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: After learning of the earlier crashes at the thumb|right|World Trade CenterMelodie and the Pentagon, the crew and passengers attempted to foil the hijacking and reclaim the aircraft.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: Meanwhile, the hijackers were not able to disengage the autopilot.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: Dahl continued to struggle in the cockpit, refusing to allow a hijacker to deactivate the autopilot so he could fly the plane manually.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: The hijackers were heard to say "Inform them, and tell him to talk to the pilot; bring back the pilot", possibly referring toLaurel Homer (CVR transcripts).

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: However, the uprising of crew and passengers took place and during the attempt the plane crashed into a field in Stonycreek Township, Pennsylvania2002.

title: LeRoy W. Homer Jr. Foundation
text: The crash killed everyone on board.

title: Garuda Indonesia Flight 200
text: Garuda Indonesia Flight 200 (GA200/GIA 200) was a scheduled domestic passenger flight of a Boeing 737-400 operated by Garuda Indonesia between Jakarta and Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

title: Garuda Indonesia Flight 200
text: The aircraft overran the runway, crashed into a rice field and burst into flames while landing at Adisucipto International Airport on 7 March 2007.

title: Garuda Indonesia Flight 200
text: Twenty passengers and one crew member were killed.

title: Garuda Indonesia Flight 200
text: Both the captain and the first officer survived.

title: EgyptAir Flight 990
text: EgyptAir Flight 990 (MS990/MSR990) was a regularly scheduled flight from Los Angeles International Airport, United States, to Cairo International Airport, Egypt, with a stop at John F. Kennedy International Airport, New York City.

title: EgyptAir Flight 990
text: On October 31, 1999, the Boeing 767 operating the route crashed into the Atlantic Ocean about 60 mi south of Nantucket Island, Massachusetts, killing all 217 people on board.

title: EgyptAir Flight 990
text: The official probable cause of the crash was deliberate action by the relief first officer.

title: FedEx Express Flight 80
text: FedEx Express Flight 80 was a scheduled cargo flight from Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport in the People's Republic of China, to Narita International Airport in Narita, Chiba Prefecture (near Tokyo), Japan.

title: FedEx Express Flight 80
text: On March 23, 2009, a McDonnell Douglas MD-11F (N526FE) operating the flight crashed at 6:48 am JST (21:48 UTC, March 22), while attempting a landing on Runway 34L in gusty wind conditions.

title: FedEx Express Flight 80
text: The aircraft became destabilized at flare and touchdown resulting in an unrecovered "bounced" landing with structural failure of the landing gear and airframe, and came to rest off the runway, inverted, and burning fiercely.

title: FedEx Express Flight 80
text: The captain and first officer, the jet's only occupants, were both killed.

title: Third officer (aeronautics)
text: Third officer is a lesser used civil aviation rank.

title: Third officer (aeronautics)
text: It was primarily used by Pan American World Airways, particularly on its "Clippers" during the infancy of extended range airline routes.

title: Third officer (aeronautics)
text: The third officer served as a relief pilot and aircrew member and could move between pilot, co-pilot, radio officer, and flight engineer positions to provide a rest period for the primary crews ("Flying The World In Clipper Ships").

title: Third officer (aeronautics)
text: Third officers in modern civil aviation are often not formally titled as such.

title: Third officer (aeronautics)
text: Rather, these relief pilots take on a junior first officer rank or in some cases a second officer rank.

title: Aurelio Valle
text: Aurelio Valle is an American singer, guitarist, composer and visual art residing in New York, New York born in Chicago, Illinois and raised in Kingsville, Texas.

title: Aurelio Valle
text: He is a founding member of the experimental rock group CALLA from New York City/Brooklyn, New York and is best known for his work with that group.

title: Aurelio Valle
text: The band was formed in New York City in 1997 along with Wayne Magruder and Sean Donovan, later adding member Peter Gannon.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: On May 27, 2017, Summit Air flight 409, a Let L-410, crashed short of the runway threshold whilst attempting landing at Tenzing–Hillary Airport in Nepal.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: It was on final approach to Lukla's runway 06 at about 1404 Local Time when the aircraft hit trees short of the runway and subsequently crashed on the ground 3 m below runway level.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: The aircraft the slid down the slope before coming to a rest about 200 m below runway level.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: The captain and the first officer died as result of the accident, another crew member received injuries.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: At the time of the accident, local visibility was substantially reduced by ground fog.

title: Summit Air Flight 409
text: The up-slope runway 06 is an all visual runway without any instrument approach guidance.

title: Air Tahoma Flight 185
text: Air Tahoma Flight 185 was a scheduled cargo flight from Memphis to the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport conducted by Air Tahoma as part of a contract to freight parcels for courier firm DHL.

title: Air Tahoma Flight 185
text: On August 13, 2004, the flight crashed during approach to landing just one mile short of the runway.

title: Air Tahoma Flight 185
text: The Convair 580, which is a twin engine turboprop, was destroyed upon impact.

title: Air Tahoma Flight 185
text: The first officer was killed and the captain received minor injuries.

title: James Franco

text: For his role in "127 Hours" (2010), Franco was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor.

text: He is known for his roles in live-action films such as "Milk" (2008), "Pineapple Express" (2008), "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" (2011), "Spring Breakers" (2012), "Oz the Great and Powerful" (2013), "This Is the End" (2013), " The Disaster Artist" (2017), and Sam Raimi's "Spider-Man" trilogy, while also voicing characters in the animated films "The Little Prince" (2015) and "Sausage Party" (2016).

text: The film tells the story of Oscar Diggs, a deceptive magician who arrives in the Land of Oz and encounters three witches: Theodora, Evanora, and Glinda.

text: Oscar is then enlisted to restore order in Oz, while struggling to resolve conflicts with the witches and himself.

text: The Marvelous Land of Oz: Being an Account of the Further Adventures of the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman, commonly shortened to The Land of Oz, published on July 5, 1904 , is the second of L. Frank Baum's books set in the Land of Oz, and the sequel to "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz" (1900).

title: Loverboy
text: Loverboy is a Canadian rock band formed in 1979 in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Loverboy
text: Loverboy's hit singles, particularly "Turn Me Loose" and "Working for the Weekend", have become arena rock staples and are still heard on many classic rock and classic hits radio stations across Canada.

title: Loverboy
text: The band is based in Vancouver.

title: Dead Jesus
text: Dead Jesus was a Canadian melodic death metal band formed in 1998 in Edmonton.

title: Dead Jesus
text: The band became notorious for its live performances which often involved blood and viscera being hurled into the audience.

title: Dead Jesus
text: Dead Jesus derived its name from the core belief that all organized religions are detrimental to human progress, and should be laid to rest.

title: Dead Jesus
text: The band played their final show on Easter Sunday in 2011 in Coaldale, Alberta.

title: The Smalls
text: The Smalls are a Canadian hard rock/metal band formed in 1989 in Edmonton.

title: The Smalls
text: They were influenced by jazz, hardcore punk, speed metal and country music.

title: The Smalls
text: They were one of the most prominent Alberta bands in the second wave of performers that came out of the Canadian west coast DIY scene that was first ushered into Alberta by the iconic hardcore punk band SNFU in the mid-1980s.

title: Beija Flor
text: Beija Flor is an indie rock band formed in 2003 from Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

title: Beija Flor
text: The band is made up of Stephen van Kampen (vocals, guitar), Paul van Kampen (vocals, piano), Dan Wilson (vocals, drums), Brett Gunther (vocals, guitar), Henry Hsieh (vocals, bass), and Hoyee Wong (vocals, violin).

title: Beija Flor
text: The band is also known for their self-orchestrated light show, consisting of a case of colored and strobe lights that are controlled by Stephen through a circuit of foot switches.

text: Jane Vain and the Dark Matter is an indie rock band formed in 2005 from Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

text: The band is fronted by Calgary native Jamie Fooks, and signed to Edmonton’s Rectangle Records.

text: They describe their sound as indie electro-pop.

text: He is of Turkish descent.

title: 2010 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2010 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the fourth round of the 2010 IndyCar Series season, and took place on April 18, 2010.

title: 2010 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race was contested over 85 laps of the 1.968 mi street course in Long Beach, California, and was telecast by Versus in the United States.

title: 2010 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race also marked the 25th consecutive year of Toyota's sponsorship of the Grand Prix of Long Beach, one of the longest-running active sponsorships of a motor race in North America.

title: 2014 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2014 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the 40th annual running of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach and the second race of the 2014 IndyCar Series season.

title: 2014 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: It took place on April 13, 2014 in Long Beach, California on its temporary street circuit.

title: 2014 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: It was won by Mike Conway.

title: 2006 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2006 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the first round of the 2006 Bridgestone Presents the Champ Car World Series Powered by Ford season, held on April 9, 2006 on the streets of Long Beach, California.

title: 2006 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The pole and race win were both captured by the two-time running Champ Car champion, Sébastien Bourdais.

title: 2006 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race was billed at the time as Jimmy Vasser's final Champ Car race, ending a 15-year career that featured 10 wins and the series championship in 1996, though he would later make a come out of retirement to drive in the 2008 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, the final race run under Champ Car sanction.

title: 2013 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2013 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the 39th annual running of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, and is also the third race of the 2013 IndyCar Series season, taking place on April 21, 2013 in Long Beach, California on its temporary street circuit.

title: 2013 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race was won by Takuma Sato of A. J. Foyt Enterprises.

title: 2017 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2017 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the second round of the 2017 IndyCar Series and the 43rd annual running of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach.

title: 2017 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race was contested over 85 laps on a temporary street circuit in Long Beach, California on April 9, 2017.

title: 2017 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Hélio Castroneves won the pole, while James Hinchcliffe won the race.

title: Ryan Hunter-Reay
text: Ryan Christopher Hunter-Reay Azambuja (born December 17, 1980) is a professional American racing driver best known as a winner of both the Indianapolis 500 (2014) and the IndyCar Series championship 2012.

title: Ryan Hunter-Reay
text: In each accomplishment Hunter-Reay became the first American to win since Sam Hornish, Jr. in 2006.

title: Ryan Hunter-Reay
text: Hunter-Reay also won in the defunct Champ World Series twice and the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach.

title: Ryan Hunter-Reay
text: In addition to his experience in Indy car racing Hunter-Reay has competed in the Race of Champions, A1 Grand Prix and various forms of sports car racing (the American Le Mans Series, the Rolex Grand-Am Sports Car Series and the IMSA Tudor United SportsCar Championship).

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the third round of the 2016 IndyCar Series and the 42nd annual running of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The race was contested over 80 laps on a temporary street circuit in Long Beach, California on April 17, 2016.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Hélio Castroneves qualified on pole for the second consecutive race with a time of 1:07.1246.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Chip Ganassi Racing's Scott Dixon started alongside him in second.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Some confusion surrounded the second round of qualifying as timing and scoring malfunctioned.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: IndyCar officials would correct the mistakes caused by this and set the correct Fast Six qualifiers shortly after round two ended.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Fast six qualifying was briefly delayed when Will Power clipped a tire barrier and went into a run-off area.

title: 2016 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Power started sixth due to his mishap.

title: 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
