text: The 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach was the 41st annual running of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach and the third race of the 2015 IndyCar Series season.

title: 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: It took place on April 19, 2015 in Long Beach, California on its temporary street circuit.

title: 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: It was won by Scott Dixon for the Chip Ganassi Racing team.

title: 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: Hélio Castroneves took second and Juan Pablo Montoya both of whom race for Team Penske.

title: 2015 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach
text: The top finishing rookie in the race, as in the previous round, was Gabby Chaves, who finished in 16th position.

title: Stefan Leko
text: Stefan "Blitz" Leko (born June 3, 1974) is a Croatian-German heavyweight kickboxer.

title: Stefan Leko
text: He is the current WKA Super-Heavyweight world champion in kickboxing, and former Muay Thai world heavyweight champion and Kickboxing world super-heavyweight champion, WMTA, WKN, IKBO, IKBF and WKA world champion, K-1 European Grand Prix 1998 champion, 1999 K-1 Dream champion and two time K-1 World Grand Prix in Las Vegas tournament champion.

title: Stefan Leko
text: He fights out of Team Golden Glory in Breda, Netherlands under Cor Hemmers.

title: Stefan Leko
text: Since 2011 Stefan Leko is coached and managed by Tom Trautsch and won two Heavyweight World Champion Titles.

title: Toyota Pro/Celebrity Race
text: The Toyota Pro/Celebrity Race was an annual 10-lap auto race held each April since 1977 until 2016 as part of the United States Grand Prix West, and later the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach weekend at Long Beach, California.

title: Toyota Pro/Celebrity Race
text: Beginning in 1991, the event raised money for "Racing for Kids," a national fund-raising program benefiting children's hospitals in Long Beach and Orange County.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: Ismail Yusuf College, is the fourth oldest college of Mumbai, India.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: "I Y college", as it is popularly known, is managed by Government of Maharashtra.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: It is the oldest college in North Mumbai.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: It was established in 1930 with a large donation from Sir Mohammed Yusuf Ismail,K.T. on Jogeshwari Hill.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: The foundation stone was laid by Sir Leslie Orme Wilson, Governor of Bombay in 1924.

title: Ismail Yusuf College
text: The vision of founding fathers shape up a temple of learning in the sandstone in the regal Persian style with arches and specious corridors, surrounded by the country's big abundantly bearded banyans and palms.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Campbell Field, officially Marv Kay Stadium at Harry D. Campbell Field, is an American college football stadium located in Golden, Colorado.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: The stadium serves as the home field of the Colorado Mines Orediggers football team representing the Colorado School of Mines.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Campbell Field is one of the oldest football fields in existence, the oldest west of the Mississippi River and the oldest in NCAA Division II.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Originally it was a dirt surface all-purpose athletic field in exactly its current configuration, built within a clay pit, a fitting mined-out home for the Orediggers.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Its first athletic contest, held on May 20, 1893, was the first annual Colorado Inter-Collegiate Athletic Association Field Day, featuring many athletic contests between the University of Colorado, Colorado A&M, Colorado School of Mines, and the University of Denver, in which Mines claimed the most medals.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Its first football game took place on October 7, 1893, a 6-0 Mines victory over the University of Denver.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: It has been home to the football Orediggers through all but the first five seasons of their existence (their previous home were the now-destroyed grounds at the southeast corner of 19th and Illinois streets in Golden), and has been renovated several times throughout its existence.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: The field was originally called Athletic Park, renamed Brooks Field after Mines trustee and benefactor Ralph D. Brooks in 1922, and renamed Campbell Field after 1939 undefeated team member and benefactor Harry D. Campbell in 2010.

title: Campbell Field (Colorado)
text: Campbell Field is the oldest football field in the west, the oldest in NCAA Division II football and the 5th oldest college football field in the nation.

title: Trinity Hall Boat Club
text: Trinity Hall Boat Club (THBC) is the rowing club of Trinity Hall, a college of the University of Cambridge.

title: Trinity Hall Boat Club
text: Founded in 1827 it is amongst the oldest college boat clubs in Cambridge, England.

title: Trinity Hall Boat Club
text: Historically, it is the most successful Cambridge college at Henley Royal Regatta with a number of wins, including winning all the events but one in 1887.

title: College of Charleston
text: The College of Charleston (also known as CofC, The College, or simply, Charleston) is a public sea-grant and space-grant university located in historic downtown Charleston, South Carolina, United States.

title: College of Charleston
text: Founded in 1770 and chartered in 1785, it is the oldest college in South Carolina, the 13th oldest institution of higher learning in the United States, and the oldest municipal college in the country.

title: College of Charleston
text: The founders of The College include three (at that time) future signers of the Declaration of Independence (Edward Rutledge, Arthur Middleton and Thomas Heyward) and three future signers of the United States Constitution (John Rutledge, Charles Pinckney and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney).

title: College of Charleston
text: Founded to "encourage and institute youth in the several branches of liberal education," the university is one of the oldest universities in the United States.

title: Ohio University College of Arts and Sciences
text: The College of Arts and Sciences of Ohio University is one of eleven colleges at Ohio University, centrally located in Wilson Hall on the College Green in Athens, Ohio.

title: Ohio University College of Arts and Sciences
text: The college is often referred to as Ohio University's oldest college, but that reference is not entirely precise.

title: Ohio University College of Arts and Sciences
text: Whether or not the college can claim to be the university's oldest, it does remain at the institution's core.

title: Ohio University College of Arts and Sciences
text: The college currently features eighteen organized academic departments.

title: Peterhouse, Cambridge
text: Peterhouse is a constituent college of the University of Cambridge, England.

title: Peterhouse, Cambridge
text: It is the oldest college of the university, having been founded in 1284 by Hugo de Balsham, Bishop of Ely, and granted its charter by King Edward I.

title: Peterhouse, Cambridge
text: Today, Peterhouse has 226 undergraduates, 86 full-time graduate students and 45 fellows.

title: Peterhouse, Cambridge
text: The modern name of Peterhouse does not include the word "college".

title: Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy
text: The Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy is awarded annually to the winner of the Division III college football game between Ripon College Red Hawks and the Lawrence University Vikings.

title: Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy
text: The Ripon-Lawrence rivalry is the oldest college football rivalry in the state of Wisconsin dating back to 1893.

title: Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy
text: The game is the 14th oldest college football rivalry in the nation.

title: Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy
text: Ripon holds a 56-46-7 advantage in the series.

title: Scott Christian College
text: The Scott Christian College is a college in Nagercoil, Tamil Nadu.

title: Scott Christian College
text: It was established in 1809.

title: Scott Christian College
text: It is one "A" College under NAAC ranking and is rated 5-star.

title: Scott Christian College
text: It is also one of the nine colleges in Tamil nadu which were recognised by the central government as 'Institutes of Potential Research and Excellence' along with Madras University and Madurai Kamaraj University.

title: Scott Christian College
text: Scott Christian College is one of the earliest colleges in India along with Fort William College, Calcutta, started in 1800 which was closed in 1835, the Hindu College established in 1817 which was later named as Presidency University, Kolkata; the Serampore College in Serampore (Bengal) established in 1818 and the Bishop’s College, Calcutta(1820).

title: Scott Christian College
text: It is the oldest college in the Erstwhile state of Travancore and Madras Presidency.

title: Scott Christian College
text: Wikipedia says: "The Maharaja had occasion to visit a school that was imparting instruction in English at Nagarcoil under the auspices of the London Missionary Society (LMS).

title: Scott Christian College
text: He was impressed by the school and the quality of the education given there and was convinced that the new type of school held out great prospects for the people of the state.

title: Scott Christian College
text: The school later evolved into Scott Christian College, Nagercoil.

title: Scott Christian College
text: Shortly thereafter he invited Mr. Roberts who was in-charge of the school at Nagarcoil to come to Thiruvananthapuram and start a similar school there.

title: Scott Christian College
text: The educationist, who was an Englishman, agreed and a new school was started in 1834."

title: Scott Christian College
text: The school started by Mr. Roberts has now blossomed into the University College, Thiruvananthapuram.

title: Scott Christian College
text: So Scott Christian College is also linked to University college, and both are now reputed colleges.

title: Scott Christian College
text: The alumni of the college are called Scottians.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: Wolfson College is a constituent college of the University of Cambridge in Cambridge, England.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: The majority of students at the college are postgraduates.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: The college also admits "mature" undergraduates (aged 21 and above), with around 15% of students studying undergraduate degree courses at the university.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: The college was founded in 1965 as "University College", and changed its name to Wolfson College in 1973 in recognition of the benefaction of the Wolfson Foundation.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: Wolfson is located to the west of Cambridge city centre, near the University Library.

title: Wolfson College, Cambridge
text: It was the first college of the university to admit men and women as both students and Fellows.

title: UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources
text: The College of Natural Resources (CNR), a college of the University of California, Berkeley, is the oldest college in the UC system and home to several internationally top-ranked programs.

title: UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources
text: CNR is considered to be one of the most prestigious schools in Agricultural Economics in the world, ranking #1 according to the Journal of Agricultural and Applied Economics, #1 by the Chronicle of Higher Education, #1 by Perry for its Ph.D. programs and in International Trade, #1 by the National Research Council in Agricultural & Resource Economics, and #1 by U.S. News in Environmental/Environmental Health.

title: UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources
text: In environmental disciplines, QS World Rankings recognizes the University of California, Berkeley, as the world's leading university in Environmental Studies with 100 points in Academic Reputation.

title: UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources
text: U.S. News also ranks it as the best global university for environment and ecology.

title: UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources
text: A study of AJAE authors and their university affiliations found it to have the highest number of pages per research faculty member.

title: Suicide Kings
text: Suicide Kings is a 1997 American mystery crime film based on Don Stanford's short story "The Hostage" and directed by Peter O'Fallon.

title: Suicide Kings
text: It stars Christopher Walken, Denis Leary, Sean Patrick Flanery, Johnny Galecki, Jay Mohr, Jeremy Sisto and Henry Thomas.

title: Suicide Kings
text: The film follows the group of criminals who kidnap a respected Mafia figure.

title: Suicide Kings
text: It has a 34% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes and grossed $1.7 million in the US.

title: Herbert Brean
text: Herbert Brean (10 December 1907 – May 7, 1973) was an American journalist and crime fiction writer, best known for his recurring series characters William Deacon and Reynold Frame.

title: Herbert Brean
text: He was a director and former executive vice president of the Mystery Writers of America, a group for which he also taught a class in mystery writing.

title: Herbert Brean
text: Aside from his seven mystery crime novels, he also published non-fiction books and articles, and mystery magazine short stories.

title: Herbert Brean
text: Alfred Hitchcock used "A Case of Identity" (1953), one of Brean's many articles for "Life", as the basis for Hitchcock's film "The Wrong Man" (1957).

title: Grief Street
text: Grief Street is a 1931 American Pre-Code mystery crime film directed by Richard Thorpe and starring Barbara Kent and John Holland.

title: Grief Street
text: It was produced and distributed by the Chesterfield Motion Pictures Corporation.

title: Morgan's Ferry
text: Morgan's Ferry is a 2001 American crime drama film starring Billy Zane, Henry Rollins, Kelly McGillis, Roscoe Lee Browne, Johnny Galecki, Muse Watson and directed by Sam Pillsbury.

title: Kingston: Confidential
text: Kingston: Confidential is an American mystery crime drama that aired on NBC for 13 episodes during the spring of 1977, following the success of a 1976 made-for-TV movie entitled "Kingston".

title: Kingston: Confidential
text: The series was produced by R.B. Productions, Inc. and Groverton Productions, Inc. in association with Universal Television.

title: Mystic River (film)
text: Mystic River is a 2003 American mystery crime drama film directed and scored by Clint Eastwood.

title: Mystic River (film)
text: It stars Sean Penn, Tim Robbins, Kevin Bacon, Laurence Fishburne, Marcia Gay Harden, and Laura Linney.

title: Mystic River (film)
text: The screenplay by Brian Helgeland was based on the novel "Mystic River" by Dennis Lehane.

title: Mystic River (film)
text: The film was produced by Robert Lorenz, Judie G. Hoyt and Eastwood.

title: Mystic River (film)
text: It is the first film on which Eastwood was credited as composer of the score.

title: The Renegades
text: The Renegades is an American mystery crime drama series about a street gang that becomes a special police undercover unit in order to avoid jail time.

title: The Renegades
text: The show starred Patrick Swayze as "Bandit", the leader of the gang.

title: The Law & Harry McGraw
text: The Law & Harry McGraw is an American mystery crime drama series and a spin-off of "Murder, She Wrote" that aired on CBS from September 27, 1987 to February 10, 1988.

title: Penny (The Big Bang Theory)
text: Penny is a fictional character on the American CBS sitcom "The Big Bang Theory", portrayed by actress Kaley Cuoco.

title: Penny (The Big Bang Theory)
text: She is the primary female character in the series, befriending her across-the-hall neighbors Leonard Hofstadter (Johnny Galecki) and Sheldon Cooper (Jim Parsons), two physicists who work at the nearby California Institute of Technology (Caltech).

title: Penny (The Big Bang Theory)
text: Penny's lack of advanced education, but outgoing personality and common sense drastically contrast with the personalities of the primary male characters in the series, even though she is considered part of their group.

title: Penny (The Big Bang Theory)
text: She is the love interest of Leonard, with whom she maintains a brief romantic relationship during the third season, which is later resumed in the fifth season and culminates in an engagement at the end of the seventh season and a wedding at the start of season 9.

title: Penny (The Big Bang Theory)
text: Penny is the only main character of the show whose last name has not been revealed, although she has been occasionally referred to or addressed with the last name Hofstadter since her wedding.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: The Mystery of the Yellow Room is a 1919 American crime drama film made by the Mayflower Photoplay Company and distributed through Realart Pictures Corporation.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: Emile Chautard was a French actor, director, and producer.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: Chautard was 55 years old when "The Mystery of the Yellow Room" was released in 1919.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: "The Mystery of the Yellow Room" (in French "Le mystère de la chambre jaune") was first a novel by Gaston Leroux.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: The novel was one of the first locked room mystery crime fiction novels.

title: The Mystery of the Yellow Room (1919 film)
text: It was first published in France in the periodical "L'Illustration" from September 1907 to November 1907, then in its own right as a book in 1908.

title: VELUX
text: VELUX is a Danish manufacturing company that specializes in roof windows and skylights.

title: VELUX
text: The first VELUX roof window was installed in a Danish school over 75 years ago by the founder of the company, Villum Kann Rasmussen.

title: VELUX
text: The company has been steadily growing since, entering the German market in 1952 in a partnership with Ernst Günter Albers and then later between the sons, Lars Kann-Rasmussen and Peter Albers

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: The Ford flathead V8 (often called simply the Ford flathead, flathead Ford, or flatty when the context is implicit, such as in hot-rodding) is a V8 engine of the valve-in-block type designed by the Ford Motor Company and built by Ford and various licensees.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: During the engine's first decade of production, when overhead-valve engines were rare, it was usually known simply as the Ford V‐8, and the first car model in which it was installed, the Model 18, was (and still is) often called simply the "Ford V‐8", after its new engine.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: Although the V8 configuration was not new when the Ford V8 was introduced in 1932, the latter was a market first in the respect that it made an 8-cylinder affordable and a V engine affordable to the emerging mass market consumer for the first time.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: It was the first independently designed and built V8 engine produced by Ford for mass production, and it ranks as one of the company's most important developments.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: A fascination with ever-more-powerful engines was perhaps the most salient aspect of the American car and truck market for a half century, from 1923 until 1973.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: The Ford flathead V8 was perfectly in tune with the cultural moment of its introduction, leading the way into a future of which the Ford company was a principal architect.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: Thus it became a phenomenal success.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: The engine design, with various changes but no major ones, was installed in Ford passenger cars and trucks until 1953, making the engine's 21-year production run for the U.S. consumer market longer than the 19-year run of the Ford Model T engine for that market.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: The engine was on Ward's list of the 10 best engines of the 20th century.

title: Ford flathead V8 engine
text: It was a staple of hot rodders in the 1950s, and it remains famous in the classic car hobbies even today, despite the huge variety of other popular V8s that followed.

title: Vetigel
text: Veti-gel is a veterinary product, a plant-derived injectable gel that is claimed to quickly stop traumatic bleeding on external and internal wounds.

title: Vetigel
text: Its name is coined from Medi-Gel, from the video game Mass Effect.

title: Vetigel
text: It uses a plant-based haemophilic polymer made from polysaccharides that forms a mesh which seals the wound.

title: Vetigel
text: It is manufactured by Suneris Inc, an American biotechnology company, which is also exploring human products derived from its technology, slated to launch as early as 2016.

title: Vetigel
text: The company plans on releasing a product for the military and the emergency medicine market first, followed by a product for the human surgical market when FDA approval is granted.

title: Verão Vermelho
text: "Verão Vermelho" is a song by Santana which came off the album "Festival".

title: Verão Vermelho
text: Carlos Santana pays homage to Brazilian singer, Elis Regina.

title: Verão Vermelho
text: This song features some excellent acoustic guitar with The Waters Family backing vocalists (Julia, Oren, and Maxine Willard Waters) singing the meaningless words, ”Badadup, badadup, badadup, ba pa pa ba pa pa.”

title: Verão Vermelho
text: It is carried along by a marching drum beat and maracas. Santana plays a flamenco guitar solo during the intro and at the conclusion.

title: Verão Vermelho
text: This is a first for him.

title: Verão Vermelho
text: The flamenco guitar solo during the coda is accompanied by a keyboard flourish by Tom Coster.

title: Walton and Willett Stone Store
text: Walton and Willett Stone Store, also known as Cahill's Fish Market, is a historic commercial building located at Oswego in Oswego County, New York.

title: Walton and Willett Stone Store
text: It is a three and four story, limestone structure with a distinctive stepped gable roof on the banks of the Oswego River.

title: Walton and Willett Stone Store
text: The oldest commercial building in the city of Oswego, it was built in 1828 and first used as a ship chandlery.

title: Walton and Willett Stone Store
text: In later years, it housed a newspaper office, customs collector, steamboat ticket and freight office, and warehouse.

title: Walton and Willett Stone Store
text: In 1945, it was purchased for use as a fish market.

title: Chatta Bazaar
text: Chatta Bazaar (English: under roof market), is located in Hyderabad, India.

title: Chatta Bazaar
text: Chatta Bazar is one of the oldest bazaars in Hyderabad and was the first to organize shops under a roof for better storage of goods.

title: Rove goat
text: The Rove is a breed of goat first domesticated in France.

title: Rove goat
text: The breed was previously considered endangered, but as of 2003, more than 5000 registered Roves are on French farms.

title: Rove goat
text: The goat was originally bred for meat, but because the current French market for goat meat is poor, farmers have begun to use the Rove for dairying, instead.

title: Friendship Hall
text: Friendship Hall is a historic home located at East New Market, Dorchester County, Maryland.

title: Friendship Hall
text: It is a Georgian-style brick dwelling.

title: Friendship Hall
text: It consists of a large five-bay, two-story main block built about 1790; a two-bay one-story passage; and a 1 ⁄ -story kitchen wing.

title: Friendship Hall
text: Also on the property is a tall frame smokehouse with board-and-batten siding and a steep gable roof.

title: Friendship Hall
text: It is associated with the locally prominent Sulivane family, who first came to Maryland in 1695.

title: Hey Pa! There's a Goat on the Roof
text: Hey Pa!

title: Hey Pa! There's a Goat on the Roof
text: There's a Goat on the Roof was a children's board game issued by Parker Brothers in 1966.

title: Pashmina
text: Pashmina is a fine type of cashmere wool.

title: Pashmina
text: The textiles made from it were first woven in Kashmir, India.

title: Pashmina
text: The name comes from Persian: پشمینه‎ ‎ / "pašmina", meaning "made from wool" and literally translates to "Soft Gold" in Kashmiri.

title: Pashmina
text: Pashmina shawls are known to pass entirely through a wearable ring with diameter of about half an inch.

title: Pashmina
text: Pashmina came to be known as 'cashmere' in the West because Europeans first encountered this fibre in Kashmir.

title: Pashmina
text: The wool comes from four distinct breeds of the Cashmere goat; namely the Changthangi or Kashmir Pashmina goat from the Changthang plateau in Kashmir region, the Malra from Kargil area in Kashmir region, the Chegu from Himachal Pradesh in northern India and Pakistan, and Chyangara or Nepalese Pashmina goat from Nepal.

title: Pashmina
text: These shawls are hand spun, and woven in Kashmir and Nepal, and made from fine cashmere fibre.

title: Bill Leavy
text: Bill Leavy (pronounced LEE-vee) is a retired American football official who officiated in the National Football League (NFL) from the 1995 through 2014 seasons, wore uniform number 127, and is also a retired San Jose, California police officer and firefighter, serving for 27 years.

title: Bill Leavy
text: Leavy was, in his twenty-year NFL officiating career, assigned to fifteen playoff games, including two Super Bowls.

title: Bill Leavy
text: He was selected as a back judge on the Super Bowl XXXIV officiating crew in 2000 and most recently headed up the Super Bowl XL officiating crew as referee in 2006.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: Super Bowl XXXVII was an American football game between the American Football Conference (AFC) champion Oakland Raiders and the National Football Conference (NFC) champion Tampa Bay Buccaneers to decide the National Football League (NFL) champion for the 2002 season.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: The Buccaneers defeated the Raiders by the score of 48–21, tied with Super Bowl XXXV for the seventh largest Super Bowl margin of victory, and winning their first ever Super Bowl.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: The game, played on January 26, 2003 at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego, California, was the sixth Super Bowl to be held a week after the conference championship games (XVII, XXV, XXVIII, XXXIV, and XXXVI).

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: It was also the last Super Bowl played in the month of January.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: Super Bowl XXXVI was the first to be played in February, due to the NFL postponing games for a week after the September 11 attacks.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: Starting with Super Bowl XXXVIII in 2004, the Super Bowl has been permanently played in February.

title: Super Bowl XXXVII
text: This was the last Super Bowl until Super Bowl 50 to take place in California.

title: Todd Collins (linebacker)
text: Todd Franklin Collins (born May 27, 1970) is a former National Football League linebacker.

title: Todd Collins (linebacker)
text: He started for the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXI, and Super Bowl XXXIV for the Rams.

title: Super Bowl XXXIV
text: Super Bowl XXXIV was an American football game between the National Football Conference (NFC) champion St. Louis Rams (now the Los Angeles Rams) and the American Football Conference (AFC) champion Tennessee Titans to decide the National Football League (NFL) champion for the 1999 season.

title: Super Bowl XXXIV
text: The Rams defeated the Titans by the score of 23–16, capturing their first Super Bowl win and first NFL championship since 1951.

title: Super Bowl XXXIV
text: The game, played on January 30, 2000 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, was the fourth Super Bowl to be held a week after the conference championship games (the previous time this happened was Super Bowl XXVIII, and coincidentally that game was also played on January 30 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta).

title: Ricky Proehl
text: Richard Scott Proehl (born March 7, 1968) is a former American football wide receiver in the National Football League.

title: Ricky Proehl
text: Proehl played 17 seasons with the Phoenix/Arizona Cardinals, Seattle Seahawks, Chicago Bears, St. Louis Rams, Carolina Panthers, and Indianapolis Colts.

title: Ricky Proehl
text: He played in four Super Bowls and won two: Super Bowl XXXIV with the Rams and Super Bowl XLI with the Colts.

title: Ted Plumb
text: Thomas E. "Ted" Plumb (born August 20, 1939) is a former American football player & coach.

title: Ted Plumb
text: His playing career ended after a neck injury in training camp as he looked like a promising young receiver for the Buffalo Bills out of Baylor University.

title: Ted Plumb
text: Although his playing career was cut short by injury, it helped lift him into what became a long and exciting coaching career in: High School, College, & onto the NFL.

title: Ted Plumb
text: Ted Plumb's NFL coaching career is special and unique as he was a coach for two of the most legendary Super Bowl champions in the history of the NFL; The Super Bowl XX Champion 1985 Bears, and the Super Bowl XXXIV Champion 2000 St. Louis Rams.

title: Ted Plumb
text: Teddy served as the Wide Receivers Coach with the "Monsters of the Midway" Chicago Bears, and he served as the Director of Pro Scouting for the "Greatest Show on Turf" 2000 St. Louis Rams (according to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch April 19, 2000).

title: Ted Plumb
text: Plumb retired after that 2000 season to his home in Alba, Texas.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: This is a list of seasons completed by the Tennessee Titans, an American football franchise of the National Football League (NFL).

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: The list documents the season-by-season records of the Titans' franchise from 1960 to the present, including postseason records and league awards for individual players or head coaches.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: The Titans were originally known as the Houston Oilers and were a part of the inaugural season of the American Football League (AFL) in 1960.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: In 1997, the franchise moved to Tennessee, playing in Memphis temporarily until settling in Nashville.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: The team was rebranded as the Titans following the 1998 season.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: The Titans have yet to win a Super Bowl, falling short in their only appearance in Super Bowl XXXIV, although the team does have two championships from its early years in the AFL.

title: List of Tennessee Titans seasons
text: During their tenure in Tennessee they have defeated all 31 other franchises at least once, enjoying a perfect record against the Detroit Lions (5-0).

title: Jeff Robinson (American football)
text: Jeffrey William "Jeff" Robinson (born February 20, 1970) is a former professional football player, last as long snapper for the Seattle Seahawks of the National Football League.

title: Jeff Robinson (American football)
text: He was selected in the fourth round of the 1993 NFL Draft by the Denver Broncos, the 98th overall pick.

title: Jeff Robinson (American football)
text: Robinson later played for the St. Louis Rams and Dallas Cowboys; he earned a Super Bowl ring with the Rams in Super Bowl XXXIV.

title: Jeff Robinson (American football)
text: Robinson played college football at Idaho, where he was a four-year starter at defensive end.

title: Super Bowl LIII
text: Super Bowl LIII, the 53rd Super Bowl and the 49th modern-era National Football League (NFL) championship game, will decide the league champion for the 2018 NFL season.

title: Super Bowl LIII
text: The game will be played on Sunday, February 3, 2019, at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: Super Bowl LIII
text: This will be the third Super Bowl in Atlanta, having previously hosted Super Bowl XXVIII in 1994 and Super Bowl XXXIV in 2000.

title: Super Bowl LIII
text: The game is set to be televised nationally by CBS.

title: Dré Bly
text: Donald André "Dré" Bly (born May 22, 1977) is a retired American college and professional football player who was a cornerback in the National Football League (NFL) for eleven seasons.

title: Dré Bly
text: He played college football for the University of North Carolina (UNC), and earned All-American honors twice.

title: Dré Bly
text: Bly was drafted by the St. Louis Rams in the second round of the 1999 NFL Draft, and spent four seasons with the Rams, earning a Super Bowl ring with them in Super Bowl XXXIV over the Tennessee Titans.

title: Dré Bly
text: He was selected to two Pro Bowls during his four-year tenure with the Detroit Lions, and also played for the Denver Broncos and San Francisco 49ers.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Illinois
text: The Interstate Highways in Illinois are all segments of the Interstate Highway System that are owned and maintained by the U.S. state of Illinois.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Illinois
text: The Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT) is responsible for maintaining these highways in Illinois.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Illinois
text: The Interstate Highway System in Illinois consists of 13 primary highways and 11 auxiliary highways which cover 2,248.93 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Illinois
text: The Interstate Highway with the longest section in Illinois is Interstate 57 at 358.57 mi ; the shortest is Interstate 41 at 0.90 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Florida
text: The Interstate Highways in the state of Florida are owned and maintained by the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT).

title: List of Interstate Highways in Florida
text: There are four primary interstate highways and eight auxiliary highways, with a ninth proposed, totaling 1497.58 mi interstate miles in Florida.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Florida
text: The longest interstate is I-75, extending 470.678 mi , and the shortest is I-395, extending just 1.292 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: The following is a list of Interstate Highways in Maryland.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: There are currently 16 Interstate Highways that exist entirely or partially in the U.S. state of Maryland.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: Six of these are primary Interstates while ten are auxiliary Interstates related to one of the primary Interstates.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: The longest primary Interstate in Maryland is Interstate 95 (commonly abbreviated I-95) at 110.01 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: The shortest primary Interstate in Maryland is I-81 at 12.08 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: I-97 is the shortest primary Interstate at 17.62 mi and the shortest intrastate Interstate.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: I-97 is also the only primary Interstate to be located entirely within one county and to not connect with any other primary Interstate.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: The longest auxiliary Interstate in Maryland is I-695 at 51.48 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: The shortest auxiliary Interstate in Maryland is I-295 at 0.80 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: All Interstates are maintained by the Maryland State Highway Administration except for all of I-395, all of I-895, a small part of I-695, I-95 within and north of Baltimore, and I-83 within Baltimore.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: Maryland has one unsigned Interstate, I-595; that highway is marked as U.S. Route 50 and US 301, which are concurrent with I-595 for its entire length.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Maryland
text: Maryland has one former Interstate, I-170, which is shaded in dark gray in the list.

title: List of auxiliary Interstate Highways
text: The auxiliary Interstate Highways (also called three-digit Interstate Highways) are a supplemental subset of the freeways within the Interstate Highway System of the United States.

title: List of auxiliary Interstate Highways
text: Similar to the mainline Interstate Highways, these highways also meet all Interstate Highway Standards (with rare exceptions), they receive the same percentage of federal funding (90%), and they comply with other federal standards.

title: Interstate 85 in Virginia
text: Interstate 85 (I-85) is a part of the Interstate Highway System that runs from Montgomery, Alabama to Petersburg, Virginia.

title: Interstate 85 in Virginia
text: In Virginia, the Interstate Highway runs 68.64 mi from the North Carolina state line near Bracey north to I-95 in Petersburg.

title: Interstate 85 in Virginia
text: I-85 passes through the eastern part of Southside Virginia, where it parallels U.S. Route 1 (US 1) from Petersburg, where the highway runs concurrently with US 460, to south of South Hill, where the highway intersects Southside's major east–west highway, US 58.

title: Interstate 85 in Virginia
text: The Interstate Highway is the primary connection between the Richmond–Petersburg metropolitan area and the Research Triangle and other major metropolitan areas of North Carolina.

title: Interstate 85 in Virginia
text: Like all mainline Interstate Highways, I-85 is a part of the National Highway System for its entire length in Virginia.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Texas
text: The Interstate Highways in Texas are all owned and maintained by the U.S. state of Texas.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Texas
text: The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) is the agency responsible for the day-to-day maintenance and operations of the Interstate Highways in Texas.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Texas
text: The Interstate Highway System in Texas covers 3239.7 mi and consists of twelve primary routes, seven auxiliary routes and Interstate 35 (I-35) which is split into two branches, I-35E and I-35W, that provide access to both Fort Worth and Dallas.

title: List of Interstate Highways in Texas
text: The longest segment of Interstate Highway in Texas is I-10 at 878.6 mi ; the shortest is I-110 at 0.9 mi .

title: List of Interstate Highways in New York
text: There are 32 Interstate Highways—9 main routes and 23 auxiliary routes—that exist entirely or partially in the U.S. state of New York.

title: List of Interstate Highways in New York
text: In New York, Interstate Highways are mostly maintained by the New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT), with some exceptions.

title: List of Interstate Highways in New York
text: Unlike in some other states, Interstate Highways in New York are not directly referenced by NYSDOT with their number; instead, the letter "I" is suffixed to the number of the route on reference markers and in internal documents.

title: List of Interstate Highways in New York
text: On the surface, there appears to be numerical duplication between several Interstate Highways and state routes—such as I-86 (I-86) and NY 86—but the "I" suffix that is appended to Interstate Highway numbers allows the Interstate Highway and state route to co-exist ("86I" versus "86", respectively).

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: Coinciding with the designation of several routes in the Interstate Highway System through Utah, the Utah State Legislature made several changes to the Utah State Route system.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: The bulk of these changes were not visible to the public, but were to unsigned legislative designations only.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: The primary effect was designating route numbers 1 through 5 for future corridors of the Interstate Highways in Utah.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: There were also changes made to a few unsigned highways serving state parks and institutions.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: Several other routes were truncated or re-assigned or split into multiple designations to allow the Interstate Highway corridors to have a single route number assigned.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: As very little of the Interstate Highway System had been constructed in Utah by 1962, these changes were primarily to support future construction.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: There were a number of cases where the legislative change enacted in 1962 would not be built and signed until years later.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: Few of the changes made in 1962 are still valid today.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: As construction of the Interstate Highway system proceeded, additional changes were made.

title: 1962 Utah state route renumbering
text: The legislature made a larger change in route designations in 1977, eliminating unsigned legislative and concurrences in the process.

title: Interstate 81 in Virginia
text: Interstate 81 (I-81) is an 855 mi highway.

title: Interstate 81 in Virginia
text: In the U.S. state of Virginia, I-81 runs for 324.92 mi , making the portion in Virginia longer than any other state's portion.

title: Interstate 81 in Virginia
text: It is also the longest Interstate highway within the borders of Virginia.

title: Interstate 81 in Virginia
text: It stretches from the Tennessee state line near Bristol to the West Virginia state line near Winchester.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: Interstate 40 (I-40) is a part of the Interstate Highway System that runs from Barstow, California to Wilmington, North Carolina.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: In North Carolina, I-40 enters the state along the Pigeon River Gorge, from Tennessee.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: Crossing the entire state, it connects the cities of Asheville, Winston-Salem, Greensboro, Durham and Raleigh before ending along U.S. Highway 117/North Carolina Highway 132 (US 117/NC 132) in Wilmington.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: The landscapes traversed by I-40 include the Blue Ridge Mountains, foothills of western North Carolina, suburban communities, the urban core of several Piedmont cities, along with eastern North Carolina farmland.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: At a total of 423.55 mi , it is the longest interstate highway in North Carolina.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: There are five auxiliary Interstates in the state related to I-40, as well as one business loop which currently runs through Winston-Salem.

title: Interstate 40 in North Carolina
text: The route is labeled east-west for the entire route (as are all even-numbered Interstate highways), however the eastern portion (from Hillsboro to Wilmington) follows a much more north-south alignment.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: The Mexican Mafia (Spanish: "Mafia Mexicana"), also known as La eMe (Spanish for "the M"), is a highly organized Mexican American criminal organization in the United States.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: Despite its name, the Mexican Mafia did not originate in Mexico, and is entirely a U.S. criminal prison organization.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: Sureños, including MS-13 is a Mexican gange.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: and Florencia 13, use the number 13 to show allegiance to the Mexican Mafia.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: M is the 13th letter of the alphabet.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: Law enforcement officials report that La eMe is the most powerful gang within the California prison system.

title: Mexican Mafia
text: Government officials state that there are currently 155–300 official members of the Mexican Mafia with around 990 associates who assist La eMe in carrying out its illegal activities in the hopes of becoming full members.

title: The Sopranos
text: The Sopranos is an American crime drama television series created by David Chase.

title: The Sopranos
text: The story revolves around the fictional character, New Jersey-based Italian American mobster Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini).

title: The Sopranos
text: The series portrays the difficulties he faces as he tries to balance the conflicting requirements of his home life and his criminal organization.

title: The Sopranos
text: These are often highlighted during his therapy sessions with psychiatrist Jennifer Melfi (Lorraine Bracco).

title: The Sopranos
text: The series features Tony's family members, mafia colleagues and rivals, in prominent roles and story arcs, most notably his wife Carmela (Edie Falco) and protégé Christopher Moltisanti (Michael Imperioli).

title: Operation Power Outage
text: Operation Power Outage was a law enforcement sting operation targeted at arresting and indicting members of the Armenian American criminal group Armenian Power operating in the United States.

title: Operation Power Outage
text: The group is accused of racketeering offenses, bank fraud schemes, kidnappings, and drug trafficking.

title: Operation Power Outage
text: Armenian Power (also known as AP-13) which originated 20 years ago in East Hollywood and has over 200 members, has developed from a street gang into an international criminal organization.

title: Armenian Power
text: Armenian Power, also known as West Side AP XIII, AP, the Armenian Mob, or Armenian Mafia is an Armenian American criminal organization and street gang located in Los Angeles County, California.

title: Armenian Power
text: They are involved in drug trafficking, murder, assault, fraud, identity theft, illegal gambling, kidnapping, racketeering, robbery and extortion.

title: Armenian Power
text: They are believed to have over 150 documented members and hundreds of associates, according to the U.S. attorney’s office.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: The National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit institution honoring exceptional U.S. athletes of Italian descent.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: In 1977 George Randazzo created the Italian American Boxing Hall of Fame.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: This was as a means for raising money for local Catholic youth programs.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: After a successful year and dinner honoring 23 former Italian American boxing champions, Randazzo created the National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: The original location was in Elmwood Park, Illinois.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: The first induction ceremony honored Lou Ambers, Eddie Arcaro, Charley Trippi, Gino Marchetti, Dom DiMaggio, Joe DiMaggio, and Vince Lombardi.

title: National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame
text: Since its founding in 1978, more than 230 Italian Americans have been inducted into this hall of fame.

title: Joseph LoPiccolo (organized crime)
text: Joseph "Baldie" LoPiccolo (1918–1999) was an American criminal and member of the New York Gambino crime family and a capo under Santo Trafficante, Jr.'s criminal organization.

title: Joseph LoPiccolo (organized crime)
text: His specialty was narcotics trafficking.

title: Barrow Gang
text: The Barrow Gang was an American criminal organization active between 1932 and 1934.

title: Barrow Gang
text: They were well known outlaws, robbers, and criminals who as a gang traveled the Central United States during the Great Depression.

title: Barrow Gang
text: Their exploits were known nationwide.

title: Barrow Gang
text: They captured the attention of the American press and its readership during what is sometimes referred to as the "public enemy era."

title: Barrow Gang
text: Though the gang was notorious for the bank robberies they committed, they preferred to rob small stores or gas stations over banks.

title: Barrow Gang
text: The gang was believed to have killed at least nine police officers, among several other murders.

title: Philadelphia crime family
text: The Philadelphia crime family, (pronounced ] ) also known as the Philadelphia Mafia, the Philly Mob/Mafia, the Bruno-Scarfo family, the South Philly Mob/Mafia, or the Philadelphia-South Jersey Mob/Mafia is an Italian American criminal organization based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: Philadelphia crime family
text: Formed and based in South Philadelphia, the family primarily operates in various areas and neighborhoods throughout the Philadelphia metropolitan area and Delaware Valley, Southeastern Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, especially South Jersey.

title: Philadelphia crime family
text: The Philadelphia family is notorious for its violence, due in particular to its succession of violent bosses and multiple mob wars.

title: Los Angeles crime family
text: The Los Angeles crime family is an Italian American criminal organization based in California, as part of the American Mafia (or Cosa Nostra).

title: Los Angeles crime family
text: Since its inception in the early 20th century, it has spread throughout Southern California.

title: Los Angeles crime family
text: Like most Mafia families in the United States, the L.A. crime family gained power bootlegging during the Prohibition Era.

title: Los Angeles crime family
text: The L.A. family reached its peak in the 1940s and early 1950s under Jack Dragna, who was on The Commission, although the L.A. family was never bigger than the New York or Chicago families.

title: Los Angeles crime family
text: Since his death the crime family has been on a gradual decline, with the Chicago Outfit representing them on The Commission.

title: Italian American One Voice Coalition
text: The Italian American One Voice Coalition is a nationwide anti-bias organization that defends Italian American heritage and combats all forms of bigotry through information, education, legislation, and advocacy.

title: Italian American One Voice Coalition
text: Its goal is to project a united front in dealing with defamation, discrimination and negative stereotyping of Italian American culture and heritage.

title: Italian American One Voice Coalition
text: It is the only national Italian American organization of its type.

title: Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau
text: Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau, also given as Du Cerceau, DuCerceau, or Ducerceau (1510–1584) was a well-known French designer of architecture, ornament, furniture, metalwork and other decorative designs during the 16th century, and the founder of the Androuet du Cerceau family.

title: Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau
text: He introduced Renaissance architecture to France with the assistance of Pierre Lescot, Philibert Delorme and Jean Bullant.

title: Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau
text: Though he was referred to by contemporaries as "architecte" and was even appointed "architecte du roi", he is remembered especially for his suites of engravings produced from 1549 (beginning with a suite of Triumphal arches) from his printshop in Orléans.

title: Jean Androuet du Cerceau
text: Jean Androuet du Cerceau (c.1585–1650) was a French architect, the son of Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau, the outstanding Parisian architect of his generation.

title: Androuet du Cerceau
text: Androuet du Cerceau was a family of French architects and designers active in the 16th and early 17th century.

title: Henry III of France
text: Henry III (19 September 1551 – 2 August 1589; born "Alexandre Édouard de France", Polish: "Henryk Walezy" , Lithuanian: "Henrikas Valua" ) was King of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1573 to 1575 and King of France from 1574 until his death.

title: Henry III of France
text: He was the last French monarch of the House of Valois.

title: Salomon de Brosse
text: Salomon de Brosse (1571 – 9 December 1626) was an influential early 17th-century French architect, a major influence on François Mansart.

title: Salomon de Brosse
text: Salomon was born in Verneuil-en-Halatte, Oise, into a prominent Huguenot family, the grandson through his mother of the designer Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau and the son of the architect Jean de Brosse.

title: Salomon de Brosse
text: He was established in practice in Paris in 1598 and was promoted to court architect in 1608.

title: Jacques Androuet II du Cerceau
text: Jacques Androuet du Cerceau, the younger (1550 – 16 September 1614), was a French architect.

title: Warsaw Confederation
text: The Warsaw Confederation, signed on January 28, 1573 by the Polish national assembly ("sejm konwokacyjny") in Warsaw, was the first European act granting religious freedoms.

title: Warsaw Confederation
text: It was an important development in the history of Poland and Lithuania that extended religious tolerance to nobility and free persons within the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and is considered the formal beginning of religious freedom in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.

title: Warsaw Confederation
text: While it did not prevent all conflict based on religion, it did make the Commonwealth a much safer and more tolerant place than most of contemporaneous Europe, especially during the subsequent Thirty Years' War.

title: Paul Androuet du Cerceau
text: Paul Androuet du Cerceau (1623–1710), was a French goldsmith and engraver, who was active in Paris around 1610.

title: Paul Androuet du Cerceau
text: According to "Benezit", Reynaud presumes he is the son of the architect Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau, who built the Pont Neuf in Paris, but Paul is now believed to be the grandson of Jacques II Androuet du Cerceau.

title: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau
text: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau (1544/47–1590) was a French architect who designed the Pont Neuf (1579), spanning the Seine, Paris, and became supervisor of the royal works under Henri III and Henri IV, including the Louvre.

title: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau
text: Several "hôtels particuliers" are ascribed to him.

title: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau
text: The Hôtel d'Angoulême, the Hôtel de Lamoignon (1584), which houses the Historical Library of the City of Paris, and the Hôtel de Mayenne (rue St-Antoine in the Marais).

title: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau
text: The Hôtel de Mayenne, with rhythmically varied dormer windows set in a high slate roof, has the pediments of its piano nobile windows superposed on the frieze above.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: Jean Baptiste Assenede (also Jan Baptist Assenede, Jean Baptiste Assenie, Jean Baptiste Asseny and nickname Lantaren was a Flemish painter from the Baroque who was active in Italy in the middle of the 17th century.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: He was born in Tournai in the first half of 17th century.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: He is recorded in Rome from 1646 to 1655.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: Here he became a member of the Bentvueghels, an association of mainly Dutch and Flemish artists active in Rome.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: His nickname (the so-called 'bent-name') was 'Lantaren', which is Dutch for 'Lantern'.

title: Jean Baptiste Assenede
text: No existing work of his hand is known today.

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: "Let That Be Your Last Battlefield" is the fifteenth episode of the of the original American science fiction television show, "".

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: It was first broadcast January 10, 1969, on NBC and repeated August 12, 1969.

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: It was written by Oliver Crawford, based on a story by Gene L. Coon (writing under his pen name "Lee Cronin") and directed by Jud Taylor.

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: The script evolved from an outline by Barry Trivers for a possible first season episode called "A Portrait in Black and White".

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: The script was accepted for the third season following budget cuts.

title: Let That Be Your Last Battlefield
text: The episode guest-stars Lou Antonio and Frank Gorshin (the latter best known for his role as The Riddler in the "Batman" live-action television series).

title: Old 8×10
text: Old 8×10 is the third studio album by country music star Randy Travis.

title: Old 8×10
text: It was released on July 12, 1988 by Warner Bros.

title: Old 8×10
text: Records Nashville.

title: Old 8×10
text: The album produced the singles "Honky Tonk Moon", "Deeper Than the Holler", "Is It Still Over", and "Promises".

title: Old 8×10
text: All of these except "Promises" reached Number One on the Hot Country Songs charts in the late 1980s.

title: Old 8×10
text: The German edition of the album (the first Randy Travis release in that country) contained the bonus track "Forever and Ever, Amen".

title: Old 8×10
text: In January 1990, Old 8×10 earned Travis three American Music Awards for 'Favorite Country Male Artist', 'Favorite Country Album', and 'Favorite Country Single' (Deeper Than the Holler).

title: Joey Miyashima
text: Joey Miyashima (born November 18, 1957) is a Japanese American television and film actor.

title: Joey Miyashima
text: Miyashima played Pee-wee Herman's Japanese pen pal, Oki Doki, in "Accidental Playhouse", an episode of "Pee-Wee's Playhouse".

title: Joey Miyashima
text: He had a role in an episode ("9 Minutes and 52 Seconds Over Tokyo") of "The Tracey Ullman Show", and another in its spin-off, "The Simpsons", as the voice of Toshiro, the apprentice chef, in the episode called "One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish".

title: Joey Miyashima
text: In 2006, he played the role of Principal Dave Matsui in the Disney Channel Original Movie "High School Musical", and reprised it in "" (2008).

title: Joey Miyashima
text: In 2009 he had a cameo as a police officer in the new DCOM "Dadnapped".

title: It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia (season 6)
text: The sixth season of the American comedy television series "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" premiered on FX on September 16, 2010.

title: It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia (season 6)
text: The season contains 14 episodes and concluded airing on December 9, 2010 with the hour-long Christmas special (which was produced for season 5, however aired as part of season 6).

title: It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia (season 6)
text: An additional episode called "The Gang Gets Successful" (production code IP06004) was produced for this season, but was not aired, despite scenes from the episode being included in promotional material for season 6.

title: It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia (season 6)
text: It was later re-edited with new scenes to create the season 7 episode "How Mac Got Fat".

title: The Surreal Life: Fame Games
text: The Surreal Life: Fame Games is an American reality television series that was originally broadcast on the VH1 cable network.

title: The Surreal Life: Fame Games
text: A spin-off of the VH1 show, "The Surreal Life", the show assembles ten alumni of the show's 6 prior seasons to compete in a ten-week competition that takes place in Las Vegas, with the winner taking home a prize of $100,000 provided by the online gaming site Golden Palace.net.

title: The Surreal Life: Fame Games
text: Robin Leach is the host.

title: The Surreal Life: Fame Games
text: The contestants also compete in a game show format elimination round in each episode called "Back to Reality" that sees the losers, in the first 3 weeks of the competition, sent to "the B-List" which consists of living in a less luxurious wing of the mansion than the rest of the housemates, who are designated as "the A-List".

title: The Surreal Life: Fame Games
text: In the later weeks, when the teams are split evenly, they compete in team competitions where the losing team must send 3 members to play "Back to Reality" to eliminate one person from the competition entirely.

title: Emily Bowker
text: Emily Bowker is a British actress who has appeared on television in programmes such as Neighbours, High School Musical The TV Show Starring Emily Bowker "Upstairs Downstairs", "Shameless", "Torchwood", "Holby City", "Wire in the Blood", and "The Bill".

title: Emily Bowker
text: Her theatrical career to date includes plays at The Birmingham Rep, West Yorkshire Playhouse, The Salisbury Playhouse, The Arcola Theatre, Finborough Theatre, Bristol Old Vic, Cheltenham Everyman and Theatre Clywd.

title: Emily Bowker
text: She has also performed in various plays for BBC Radio 4 and appeared in the independent British feature film "City Rats".

title: Emily Bowker
text: In Torchwood, she appeared as Ellie Johnson in a 2006 episode called "Countrycide".

title: Emily Bowker
text: Emily is also predicted to reunite Zanessa as a romantic couple in future years.

title: Amber Hunt (journalist)
text: Amber Hunt is a journalist and true crime author.

title: Amber Hunt (journalist)
text: After covering local news at small papers in Iowa and Michigan, Hunt was hired at the "Detroit Free Press", where she covered crime for nearly eight years.

title: Amber Hunt (journalist)
text: In 2005, she won the Al Nakkula Award for Police Reporting.

title: Amber Hunt (journalist)
text: In 2007 and 2008, she appeared on NBC's "Dateline" program, first in an episode called "The Valentine's Day Mystery" and then in "Disappearance at the Dairy Queen" (later renamed "The Case of the Girl Who Never Came Home.")

title: Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna
text: Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna is the debut extended play (EP) by the cast of the musical television series "Glee".

title: Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna
text: It contains eight songs from the season one "Glee" episode, "The Power of Madonna", which was a tribute episode dedicated to American recording artist Madonna.

title: Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna
text: She had sold the rights to her entire catalog of music to "Glee" in 2009, and producers of the show developed the episode called "The Power of Madonna"; the show featured a number of cover versions of Madonna's songs by the cast.

title: Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna
text: The accompanying EP released with the airing of the show was called "Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna".

title: Back Up, Dancer
text: "Back Up, Dancer" is the second episode of the seventh season of the American television series "Will & Grace".

title: Back Up, Dancer
text: It was written by Tracy Poust and Jon Kinnally and directed by series producer James Burrows.

title: Back Up, Dancer
text: The episode originally aired on the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in the United States on September 23, 2004.

title: Back Up, Dancer
text: Guest stars in "Back Up, Dancer" include Will Arnett, Bobby Cannavale, and Janet Jackson.

title: My Generation (talk show)
text: My Generation, hosted by Leeza Gibbons, is a lively lifestyle show covering issues from health and money to relationships and enjoying life.

title: My Generation (talk show)
text: It also profiles inspiring individuals who make a difference by giving back.

title: My Generation (talk show)
text: One full episode called, “Quiet Heroes”, nominated for an Emmy Award, includes stories about a running club started to help homeless men get back on their feet and African American Giving Circles.

title: United States Army
text: The United States Army (USA) is the largest branch of the United States Armed Forces and performs land-based military operations.

title: United States Army
text: It is one of the seven uniformed services of the United States and is designated as the Army of the United States in the United States Constitution, Article 2, Section 2, Clause 1 and United States Code, Title 10, Subtitle B, Chapter 301, Section 3001.

title: United States Army
text: As the oldest and most senior branch of the U.S. military in order of precedence, the modern U.S. Army has its roots in the Continental Army, which was formed (14 June 1775) to fight the American Revolutionary War (1775–1783)—before the United States of America was established as a country.

title: United States Army
text: After the Revolutionary War, the Congress of the Confederation created the United States Army on 3 June 1784 to replace the disbanded Continental Army.

title: United States Army
text: The United States Army considers itself descended from the Continental Army, and dates its institutional inception from the origin of that armed force in 1775.

title: MV Empire Windrush
text: HMT "Empire Windrush, originally MV "Monte Rosa, was a passenger liner and cruise ship launched in Germany in 1930.

title: MV Empire Windrush
text: During the 1930s, she operated as a German cruise ship under the name "Monte Rosa".

title: MV Empire Windrush
text: During World War II, she was operated by the German navy as a troopship.

title: MV Empire Windrush
text: She was acquired by the United Kingdom as a prize of war at the end of the war and renamed "Empire Windrush".

title: MV Empire Windrush
text: In British service, she continued to be used mainly as a troopship until March 1954, when the vessel caught fire and sank in the Mediterranean Sea with the loss of four crew.

title: USS Proton (AG-147)
text: USS "Proton" (AG-147/AKS-28) -- also known as USS "LST-1078" – was an "LST-542"-class tank landing ship launched by the U.S. Navy during the final months of World War II.

title: USS Proton (AG-147)
text: "Proton" served as a troop ship, a cargo ship and as an electronic parts supply ship for the U.S. Pacific Fleet and was decommissioned following the Korean War.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: Tobago was a ship launched in 1790.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: She came into British hands in 1793 and was probably a prize taken immediately after the outbreak of the French Revolutionary Wars in early 1793.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: She traded with Tobago for several years before new owners purchased her for whaling.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: She made two whaling voyages to the East Coast of Africa before her owners sold her to new owners.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: She then made two voyages as a slave ship.

title: Tobago (1793 ship)
text: She is last listed in "Lloyd's Register" in 1806.

title: USS Electron (AG-146)
text: USS "Electron" (AG-146/AKS-27) -- also known as USS "LST-1070" – was an "LST-542"-class tank landing ship launched by the U.S. Navy during the final months of World War II.

title: USS Electron (AG-146)
text: "Electron" served as both a cargo ship and as an electronic parts supply ship for the U.S. Pacific Fleet and was decommissioned following the Korean War.

title: USS Zeilin (APA-3)
text: USS "Zeilin" (APA-3) was an Emergency Fleet Corporation Design 1029 ship launched for the United States Shipping Board (USSB) on 19 March 1921 by Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Newport News, Virginia as Silver State.

title: USS Zeilin (APA-3)
text: After operation by commercial lines for the USSB, during which the ship was renamed President Jackson, the ship was purchased and operated commercially until laid up in the late 1930s.

title: Robert Plampin
text: Vice-Admiral Robert Plampin (1762 – 14 February 1834), was a British Royal Navy officer during the late 18th and early 19th centuries, serving in the American Revolutionary War, the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars, but best known for his time as commander of the British colony of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic during the period when former Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte was imprisoned there.

title: Robert Plampin
text: Born into a Navy family, Plampin went to sea at age 13 and fought throughout the American Revolutionary War, based principally in the Caribbean Sea.

title: Robert Plampin
text: During the French Revolutionary Wars, Plampin served in a number of ships with mixed success, once being involved in a shipwreck and twice serving ashore during sieges.

title: Robert Plampin
text: After the Peace of Amiens, Plampin took command of the ship of the line HMS "Powerful" and operated successfully in the Atlantic and the Indian Ocean.

title: Robert Plampin
text: In 1816, following the defeat and capture of the French Emperor, Plampin was placed in command of the squadron at the Cape of Good Hope, which also had responsibility for Saint Helena, which Plampin regularly visited and had numerous conversations with Napoleon.

title: HMS Vulture (1776)
text: HMS "Vulture" was a 14 to 16-gun ship sloop of the "Swan" class, launched for the Royal Navy on 18 March 1776.

title: HMS Vulture (1776)
text: She served during both the American Revolutionary War and the French Revolutionary War, before the Navy sold her in 1802.

title: HMS Vulture (1776)
text: "Vulture" is perhaps best known for being the warship to which Benedict Arnold fled on the Hudson River in 1780 after unsuccessfully trying to betray the Continental Army's fortress at West Point, New York to the British.

title: SS General von Steuben
text: SS "General von Steuben was a German passenger liner and later an armed transport in the Kriegsmarine of Nazi Germany that was sunk during World War II.

title: SS General von Steuben
text: She was launched as München (sometimes spelled Muenchen), renamed in 1930 as General von Steuben (after the famous German officer of the American Revolutionary War), and renamed again in 1938 as Steuben".

title: HMS Swan (1767)
text: HMS "Swan" was the lead ship in the 14-gun "Swan" class of ship sloops, to which design 25 vessels were built in the 1760s and 1770s; she was launched on 21 November 1767.

title: HMS Swan (1767)
text: She bore the name HMS "Explosion" between 1779 and 1783 whilst being used as a fireship.

title: HMS Swan (1767)
text: She served during both the American Revolutionary War and the French Revolutionary War before being laid up in 1801; she was sold for disposal in 1814.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: Bjørnøya (English: Bear Island ) is a populated island in Haram Municipality in Møre og Romsdal county, Norway.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: It is connected to the Norwegian mainland through a man-made causeway.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: The nearest larger village on the mainland is Søvik.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: To the east of the Bjørnøya (between Bjørnøya and Søvik) lies the island of Terøya.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: The two islands are separated by the Bjørnøysundet.

title: Bjørnøya, Haram
text: The island was part of the former municipality of Borgund until 1965 when it joined Haram.

title: Loppa Church
text: Loppa Church (Norwegian: "Loppa kirke" ) is a parish church in the municipality of Loppa in Finnmark county, Norway.

title: Loppa Church
text: It is located in the village of Loppa on the sparsely populated island of Loppa.

title: Loppa Church
text: The church is part of the Loppa parish in the Alta deanery in the Diocese of Nord-Hålogaland.

title: Loppa Church
text: The small white wooden church was built in 1953.

title: Loppa Church
text: The church seats about 150 people, but it is rarely used since the island has few residents.

title: Church of the Guanche People
text: The Church of the Guanche People (Spanish: "Iglesia del Pueblo Guanche" ) is a religious organisation, founded in 2001 in the city of San Cristóbal de La Laguna (Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain).

title: Church of the Guanche People
text: It aims to perpetuate and spread the pagan religion of the ancient Guanche people.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: Karlsøy Church (Norwegian: "Karlsøy kirke" ) is a historic parish church in the municipality of Karlsøy in Troms county, Norway.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: It is located on the island of Karlsøya.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: The church is part of the Karlsøy parish in the Tromsø arch-deanery in the Diocese of Nord-Hålogaland.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: The white wooden church was built in 1854 and it seats about 570 people.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: The church is no longer in regular use, since it is on a remote, now-sparsely populated island.

title: Karlsøy Church
text: The church holds special services occasionally including one summer service each year.

title: Pungdo
text: Pung Island (Korean: 풍도 , Pungdo) is a small populated island on the Yellow Sea, located in within the municipal borders of Ansan city, Gyeonggi Province, South Korea, about 74 km South West of Seoul, the country's capital town, and 24 km south of the larger Daebudo island.

title: Vilsandi
text: The island of Vilsandi, Kihelkonna Parish, Saare County, Estonia is located in the Baltic Sea.

title: Vilsandi
text: It covers an area of some 9 square km and is the westernmost populated island in Estonia.

title: Vilsandi
text: The surrounding waters are shallow and rocky and many ships travelling the Baltic have perished nearby.

title: Vilsandi
text: The island of Vilsandi can be reached by boat, by truck having suitable clearance or on foot by wading from Saaremaa.

title: Vilsandi
text: Much of the island is now part of Vilsandi National Park, which grew from a bird reserve founded in 1910.

title: Vilsandi
text: It is a highly sensitive ecosystem due to the use of the area by many migratory birds as a breeding and nesting ground.

title: Vilsandi
text: Hunting is absolutely prohibited.

title: Vilsandi
text: This park is a popular tourist destination not only for local Estonians, but also people of Finland who are visiting Estonia in greater and greater numbers.

title: Guanche mummies
text: Guanche mummies are the intentionally desiccated remains of members of the indigenous Guanche people of the Canary Islands.

title: Guanche mummies
text: The majority of Guanche mummies were made during the eras prior to Spanish settlement of the area in the 15th century.

title: Guanche mummies
text: The methods of embalming are similar to those that were used by the Ancient Egyptians, though fewer mummies remain from the Guanche due to looting and desecration.

title: Tenerife
text: Tenerife ( ; ] ) is the largest and most populated island of the seven Canary Islands.

title: Tenerife
text: It is also the most populated island of Spain, with a land area of 2034.38 km2 and 898,680 inhabitants, 43 percent of the total population of the Canary Islands.

title: Tenerife
text: Tenerife is the largest and most populous island of Macaronesia.

title: Wheeling Island
text: Wheeling Island is the most populated island in the Ohio River.

title: Wheeling Island
text: It lies within the city of Wheeling in Ohio County, West Virginia, in the United States.

title: Wheeling Island
text: The 2000 census showed a resident population of 3,142 people on the island, which has a land area of 1.514 km2 (374 acres).

title: Wheeling Island
text: Neville Island, PA is larger (3.4 km2) but has fewer people (1,232).

title: Mactan
text: Mactan or Maktan is a densely populated island located a few kilometres (~1 mile) from Cebu Island in the Philippines.

title: Mactan
text: The island is part of Cebu Province and it is divided into Lapu-Lapu City and the municipality of Cordova.

title: Mactan
text: The island is separated from Cebu by the Mactan Channel which is crossed by two bridges: the Marcelo Fernan Bridge and the Mactan-Mandaue Bridge.

title: Mactan
text: The island covers some 65 km2 and is home to some 470,000 people, making it the nation's most densely populated island.

title: Mactan
text: Along with Olango Island Group, the isles are administered as 1 city and a municipality covering 75.25 km2 .

title: Shagai Plateau
text: Shagai Plateau, also referred to as Shagai Heights is an area of flat lands along the Khyber Pass.

title: Shagai Plateau
text: Fort Al Creator was nearby.

title: Shagai Plateau
text: The ascent to the Shagai Plateau begins near the entrance to the Khyber Pass from the southeast at Peshawar in what is now Pakistan.

title: Shagai Plateau
text: It was the site of a British encampment during the Second Anglo-Afghan War which began in November 1878 when Great Britain, fearful of what it saw as growing Russian influence in Afghanistan, invaded the country from British India.

title: Shagai Plateau
text: The first phase of the war ended in May 1879 with the Treaty of Gandamak, which permitted the Afghans to maintain internal sovereignty but forced them to cede control over their foreign policy to the British.

title: Shagai Plateau
text: Fighting resumed in September 1879, after an anti-British uprising in Kabul, and finally concluded in September 1880 with the decisive Battle of Kandahar.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: The Emirate of Afghanistan (Pashto: د افغانستان امارت‎ "Da Afghānistān Amārat ") was an emirate between Central Asia and South Asia, which is today's Islamic Republic of Afghanistan.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: The emirate emerged from the Durrani Empire, when Dost Mohammed Khan, the founder of the Barakzai dynasty in Kabul, prevailed.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: The history of the Emirate was dominated by 'the Great Game' between the Russian Empire and the United Kingdom for supremacy in Central Asia.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: This period was characterized by the expansion of European colonial interests in South Asia.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: The Emirate of Afghanistan continued the war with the Sikh Empire, which led to the invasion of Afghanistan by British-led Indian forces who completely wiped out the Afghans in 1842 but did not fulfil their initial war objectives.

title: Emirate of Afghanistan
text: However, during the Second Anglo-Afghan War, the British again defeated the Afghans and this time the British took control of Afghanistan's foreign affairs until Emir Amanullah Khan regained them after the Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919 was signed following the Third Anglo-Afghan War.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War
text: The Second Anglo–Afghan War (Pashto: د افغان-انګرېز دويمه جګړه) was a military conflict fought between the British Raj and the Emirate of Afghanistan from 1878 to 1880, when the latter was ruled by Sher Ali Khan of the Barakzai dynasty, the son of former Emir Dost Mohammad Khan.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War
text: This was the second time British India invaded Afghanistan.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War
text: The war ended after the British emerged victorious against the Afghan rebels and the Afghans agreed to let the British attain all of their geopolitical objectives from the Treaty of Gandamak.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War
text: Most of the British and Indian soldiers withdrew from Afghanistan.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War
text: The Afghan tribes were permitted to maintain internal rule and local customs but they had to cede control of the area's foreign relations to the British, who, in turn, guaranteed the area's freedom from foreign military domination as a buffer between the British Raj and the Russian Empire.

title: Edict of Amboise
text: The Edict of Amboise also known as the Edict of Pacification, was signed at the Château of Amboise on 19 March 1563 by Catherine de' Medici, acting as regent for her son Charles IX of France.

title: Edict of Amboise
text: The treaty officially ended the first phase of the French Wars of Religion.

title: Edict of Amboise
text: Moreover, the treaty restored peace to France by guaranteeing the Huguenots religious privileges and freedoms.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
