text: The Afghan Civil War fought between 1996 and 2001 was part of the wider War in Afghanistan ongoing since 1978.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: In 1996 the Taliban captured the Afghan capital Kabul and established the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: The Islamic State of Afghanistan government remained the internationally recognized government of Afghanistan.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: The Taliban's Emirate received recognition only from Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: The defense minister of the Islamic State of Afghanistan, Ahmad Shah Massoud, created the United Front (Northern Alliance) in opposition to the Taliban.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: The United Front included all Afghan ethnicities: Tajiks, Uzbeks, Hazaras, Turkmens, some Pashtuns and others.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: During the conflict, the Taliban received military support from Pakistan and financial support from Saudi Arabia.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: Pakistan militarily intervened in Afghanistan, deploying battalions and regiments of its Frontier Corps and Army against the United Front.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: Al Qaeda supported the Taliban with thousands of imported fighters from Pakistan, Arab countries, and Central Asia.

title: Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)
text: <ref name="Ahmed Rashid/The Telegraph"> </ref>

title: Working Group on Internet Governance
text: The Working Group on Internet Governance (WGIG) was a United Nations multistakeholder Working group initiated after the 2003 World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) first phase Summit in Geneva failed to agree on the future of Internet governance.

title: Working Group on Internet Governance
text: The first phase of World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) agreed to continue the dialogue on Internet Governance in the Declaration of Principles and Action Plan adopted on 12 December 2003, to prepare for a decision at the second phase of the WSIS in Tunis during November 2005.

title: Working Group on Internet Governance
text: In this regard, the first phase of the Summit requested the United Nations Secretary-General to establish a Working Group on Internet Governance (WGIG).

title: Treaty of Gandamak
text: The Treaty of Gandamak officially ended the first phase of the Second Anglo-Afghan War.

title: Treaty of Gandamak
text: Mohammad Yaqub Khan ceded various frontier areas to Britain while retaining full sovereignty over Afghanistan.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves included severe heat waves that impacted most of the United States, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, China, Hong Kong, North Africa and the European continent as a whole, along with parts of Canada, Russia, Indochina, South Korea and Japan during May, June, July, and August 2010.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The first phase of the global heatwaves was caused by a moderate El Niño event, which lasted from June 2009 to May 2010.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The first phase lasted only from April 2010 to June 2010, and caused only moderate above average temperatures in the areas affected.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: But it also set new record high temperatures for most of the area affected, in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The second phase (the main, and most devastating phase) was caused by a very strong La Niña event, which lasted from June 2010 to June 2011.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: According to meteorologists, the 2010–11 La Niña event was one of the strongest La Niña events ever observed.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: That same La Niña event also had devastating effects in the Eastern states of Australia.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The second phase lasted from June 2010 to October 2010, caused severe heat waves, and multiple record-breaking temperatures.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The heatwaves began on April 2010, when strong anticyclones began to develop, over most of the affected regions, in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: 2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves
text: The heatwaves ended in October 2010, when the powerful anticyclones over most of the affected areas dissipated.

title: Line 2, Suzhou Rail Transit
text: Line 2 is the main north-south line of Suzhou Rail Transit.

title: Line 2, Suzhou Rail Transit
text: The length of first phase is 26.557 km, among them, 6.57 km is elevated, 19.146 km is underground and 0.67 km is open wide.

title: Line 2, Suzhou Rail Transit
text: The line's first phase started from Suzhou North Railway Station (高铁苏州北站) and ended in Baodaiqiao South Station (宝带桥南站) near Baodai Bridge (宝带桥).

title: Line 2, Suzhou Rail Transit
text: The line goes across five districts of Suzhou, including 22 stations(17 underground, 5 overhead).

title: Line 2, Suzhou Rail Transit
text: The first phase part was started to operation on December 28, 2013.

title: Bukhara operation (1920)
text: The Bukhara operation (1920), was a military conflict fought between the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic and the Young Bukharians against the Emirate of Bukhara.

title: Bukhara operation (1920)
text: The war lasted between 28 August and 2 September 1920, ending in the defeat of the Bukhara Emirate, which was instead replaced by the RSFSR controlled Bukharan PSR.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: Founded in 2012 by Scott Cross, Sean Cross, Eduardo Sanchez-Navarro Redo, Alfonso Pasquel, Juan Gallardo Thurlow, Eduardo Sanchez-Navarro Rivera Torres, and Pablo Sanchez-Navarro, the Los Cabos International Film Festival is an international film festival that takes place annually in mid-November in Los Cabos, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2012 Los Cabos International Film Festival (formerly Baja International Film Festival) took place November 14–17 in Los Cabos, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2013 Los Cabos International Film Festival took place November 13–16 in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2014 Los Cabos International Film Festival took place November 12–16, 2014 in Los Cabos, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2015 Los Cabos International Film Festival took place November 11–15, 2015 in Los Cabos, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2016 Los Cabos International Film Festival took place November 9–13, 2016 in Los Cabos, Mexico.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: The 2017 festival will take place November 8-12, 2017.

title: Los Cabos International Film Festival
text: Held in one of Mexico's premier resort destinations, the festival draws attendees and filmmakers from across Mexico, the United States and around the world.

title: Račak massacre
text: The Račak massacre ()) or Račak operation (Serbian: Акција Рачак/Akcija Račak ) was the mass killing of 45 Kosovo Albanians that took place in the village of Račak () in central Kosovo in January 1999.

title: Račak massacre
text: The killings were perpetrated by Serbian security forces.

title: Račak massacre
text: The Serbian government refused to let a war crimes prosecutor visit the site, and maintained that the casualties were all members of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army killed in combat with state security forces.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: The Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence was a deadly tornado outbreak sequence that struck most of the Southern United States from April 2–5, 1957.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: The outbreak killed at least 21 people across three states and produced at least 72 tornadoes from Texas to Virginia.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: The outbreak was most notable due to a tornado that hit a densely populated area of the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area, killing 10 people and injuring 200 or more.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: The tornado, highly visible for most of its path, was at the time the most observed and best-documented tornado in recorded history; hundreds of people photographed or filmed the F3 tornado as it moved just west of Downtown Dallas.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: The film of this tornado is still known for its unusually high quality and sharpness, considering the photography techniques and technology of the 1950s.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: Damage from the Dallas tornado reached as high as $4 million (1957 USD).

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: Besides the famous Dallas tornado, other deadly tornadoes struck portions of Mississippi, Texas, and Oklahoma.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: Two F4 tornadoes struck southern Oklahoma on April 2, killing five people.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: Three other significant, F2-rated tornadoes that day killed two people in Texas and one more in Oklahoma.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: An F3 tornado struck rural Mississippi on April 4, killing one more person.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: In addition to confirmed tornadoes, a possible tornado hit Ballard County, Kentucky, on April 3, unroofing homes, destroying a drive-in theater, and uprooting trees.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: A loud roaring noise was heard.

title: Early-April 1957 tornado outbreak sequence
text: Two other brief tornadoes may have hit near Westlake and at Tallulah, Louisiana, late on April 4.

title: Oikos University shooting
text: The Oikos University shooting occurred on April 2, 2012, when a gunman shot at people inside Oikos University, a Korean Christian college in Oakland, California, United States.

title: Oikos University shooting
text: Within a few hours, the number of reported fatalities reached seven.

title: Oikos University shooting
text: 43-year-old One L. Goh, a former student at the school, was taken into custody and identified as the suspect in the shootings.

title: Oikos University shooting
text: Along with the California State University, Fullerton massacre, this was the fourth-deadliest university shooting in United States history, after the Virginia Tech massacre, the University of Texas Clock Tower shooting, and the Umpqua Community College shooting, and the eighth-deadliest U.S. school massacre overall.

title: Oikos University shooting
text: It is also considered the deadliest mass killing in the city's history.

title: Tezno massacre
text: The Tezno massacre (Croatian: "Pokolj u Teznom" ) was the mass killing of POWs of the Independent State of Croatia (NDH) that took place in Tezno near Maribor, after the end of World War II in Yugoslavia.

title: Tezno massacre
text: The killings were perpetrated by units of the Yugoslav Partisans in May 1945, following the Bleiburg repatriations.

title: Tezno massacre
text: Summary executions began on 19 May when first prisoners arrived to the Tezno forest from nearby prison camps and continued until 26 May.

title: Tezno massacre
text: Most of the bodies were buried in a several kilometers long antitank trench, which the Yugoslav authorities concealed and kept secret.

title: Gymnastics at the 2002 Asian Games
text: Gymnastics was contested at the 2002 Asian Games in Busan, South Korea.

title: Gymnastics at the 2002 Asian Games
text: Artistic gymnastics took place from October 1 to October 5.

title: Gymnastics at the 2002 Asian Games
text: Rhythmic gymnastics took place on October 8 and 9.

title: Gymnastics at the 2002 Asian Games
text: All Gymnastics events took place at Sajik Gymnasium.

title: April 2007 Mosul massacre
text: The 2007 Mosul massacre was a mass killing that took place on April 23, 2007 in Mosul, in northern Iraq.

title: April 2007 Mosul massacre
text: A bus carrying workers from the Mosul Textile Factory was hijacked by unidentified attackers.

title: April 2007 Mosul massacre
text: The attackers checked the passengers' identity cards, telling Muslims and Christians to get off the bus.

title: April 2007 Mosul massacre
text: They then drove the bus to eastern Mosul with 23 remaining passengers, all Yazidis, where the hostages were made to lie face down in front of a wall and shot.

title: 1972 American League Championship Series
text: The 1972 American League Championship Series took place between October 7 and 12, 1972.

title: 1972 American League Championship Series
text: The Oakland Athletics (93–62 on the season) played the Detroit Tigers (86–70 on the season) for the right to go to the 1972 World Series, with the A's coming out on top in the five-game series, 3–2.

title: 1972 American League Championship Series
text: Games 1 and 2 took place at the Oakland Coliseum, and 3 through 5 took place at Tiger Stadium.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: The October 2011 Baghdad bombings were a series of bombing attacks that hit the capital of Iraq between the 7 and the 13 of October 2011.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: The first attacks took place on the 7 October when a magnetic bomb and two IED blasts killed 7 and injured 39 in the north and south districts of Baghdad.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: On the 10 October three explosions hit the mainly Shia neighborhood of Washash, killing ten and injuring 18 more.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: Two days later a string of bombings and shootings took place all across the city - at least two police stations in the northwestern and central districts were attacked by suicide car bombers, killing 22 (including 13 policemen) and leaving at least 55 wounded.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: In total at least 29 people died on this day and 86 were injured.

title: October 2011 Baghdad bombings
text: On the next evening four powerful roadside bombs exploded next to a local market and a crowded coffeeshop in the Sadr City district, killing 18 and injuring 47.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008 (also known as Robinson: Fans vs. Paradise) was the eleventh season of the Danish versions of the Swedish show "Expedition Robinson".

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: This season premiered on September 1, 2008 and aired until November 24, 2008.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The main twist this season was that every contestant was either a fan of Robinson or was a former contestant on the show "Paradise Hotel".

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The fan tribe was called "Tenga", while the Paradise tribe was called "Sembilang".

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: There were many additional twists this season, the first taking place in episode 1 when all of the contestants were made to take part in an elimination challenge.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Mirja Østergaard lost the challenge and was immediately eliminated.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The next twist took place in episode 2 when Jan Novaa, who had been voted out in episode one, returned to the game.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The next twist took place in episode 3 when Emil Debski swapped tribes in order to even up the tribe numbers.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: In episode 4 a larger tribal swap took place in which Jan Novaa, Mads Jensen, and Michelle Jensen swapped from the Sembilang tribe to the Tenga tribe and Emil Debski, Hilde Austad, Martin Persson, Chiro "Sido" Kiarie swapped from the Tenga tribe to the Sembilang tribe.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The next twist came in episode 5 when jokers Laila Neilsen and Nick Zitouni entered the game with Laila joining the Sembilang tribe and Nick joining the Tenga tribe.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: In episode 6 an individual challenge took place in which the winner would be allowed to eliminate a player from the opposing tribe.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Haider Mohamad won the challenge and chose to eliminate Sheila Nymann.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Immediately following the merge in episode 7, Haider won the same type of challenge and chose to eliminate Karina Strunge from the game.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The next twist came in episode 10 when contestant Hilde Austad used the "Talisman" she had to void any votes cast against her in tribal council.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: This led to the elimination of Laila Neilsen who had the second most votes.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: When it came time for the final four, the remaining contestants competed in two challenges.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: The winners of these challenges would earn the right to eliminate one of the losers.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Emil won the first challenge and chose to eliminate Martin and Daniela won the second challenge and chose to eliminate Emil.

title: Robinson Ekspeditionen 2008
text: Ultimately, it was Daniela Hansen from Paradise Hotel 2006 who won the season over Robinson fan Hilde Austad by a tiebreaking cointoss after the jury vote ended in a 4-4 tie.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: The Rats were an American garage punk band from Portland, Oregon, formed by Fred Cole previously of the garage rock band, The Lollipop Shoppe.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Cole played guitar and sang, his wife, "Toody" played bass and sang, and initially Rod Rat played drums.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Their sound was a raw mix of punk rock with occasional country touches.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Their self-titled debut album appeared on Cole's Whizeagle label in 1980.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Soon after, Rod Rat left the band, though he guested on the 1981 follow-up "Intermittent Signals" before his death by suicide.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: (Prior to his suicide Rod Rat (aka Rod Hibbert) also played drums in 1980-81 for Portland power pop band Domino Theory).

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Sam Henry, formerly of the Wipers, played drums on this LP but left to join another Portland band, Napalm Beach.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Louis Samora was on the drum throne for the 1983 album "In a Desperate Red", still on Whizeagle.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Samora left in 1984 to concentrate on his rockabilly band, The Jackals.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: The band broke up, but Bill Barker of Profile Studios in Vancouver, British Columbia convinced the band to reunite for a single.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: It appeared under the band name The Desperate Edge later in 1984.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: Soon after, Cole assembled a country band, Western Front, and he and Toody later reunited in Dead Moon.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: The Rats' records have long been out of print and sell for high prices on eBay.

title: The Rats (American band)
text: In 2008, Portland's Mississippi Records reissued the first album on vinyl.

title: All Join Hands
text: "All Join Hands" is a song by the British rock band Slade, released in 1984 as the lead single from the band's twelfth studio album "Rogues Gallery".

title: All Join Hands
text: The song was written by lead vocalist Noddy Holder and bassist Jim Lea, and produced by John Punter.

title: All Join Hands
text: It reached No. 15 in the UK, remaining in the chart for ten weeks.

title: Crackers: The Christmas Party Album
text: Crackers – The Christmas Party Album is a studio/compilation album by the British rock band Slade.

title: Crackers: The Christmas Party Album
text: It was released on 18 November 1985 and reached No. 34 in the UK charts.

title: Crackers: The Christmas Party Album
text: It was certified Gold by the BPI that same month.

title: Crackers: The Christmas Party Album
text: The album was produced by bassist Jim Lea except "All Join Hands", "Do You Believe in Miracles", "My Oh My" and "Run Runaway", which were all produced by John Punter.

title: Crackers: The Christmas Party Album
text: The album contained a mix of the band's previous hits, some re-recorded songs and a selection of covers.

title: Rise Above (Dirty Projectors album)
text: Rise Above is an album by indie rock band Dirty Projectors, released on September 11, 2007.

title: Rise Above (Dirty Projectors album)
text: The album was band leader Dave Longstreth's reinterpretation of Black Flag album "Damaged", having not heard it in 15 years.

title: Rise Above (Dirty Projectors album)
text: The album features Longstreth on guitar and vocals, Amber Coffman on vocals and guitar, Brian McOmber on drums, Nat Baldwin on bass, and Susanna Waiche on vocals.

title: Rise Above (Dirty Projectors album)
text: Angel Deradoorian would join the band shortly before the "Rise Above" tour on bass and vocals.

title: Rise Above (Dirty Projectors album)
text: This album is the first that presents Dirty Projectors as a fully realized band rather than an individual project of Longstreth.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: "You're Gonna Go Far, Kid" is a song by American punk rock band the Offspring.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: It is the third track on the band's eighth studio album "Rise and Fall, Rage and Grace" (2008) and was released as the second single from the album on September 4, 2008.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: The song had previously impacted radio on August 12.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: This is the band's 3rd No.1 single on the Hot Modern Rock Tracks chart after "Come Out and Play" and "Hit That".

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: The song stayed at No. 1 for 11 weeks, making it the longest consecutive run for any Offspring single at No. 1.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: "You're Gonna Go Far, Kid" is certified Gold by the RIAA; despite this, "Rise and Fall, Rage and Grace" has never been certified by the RIAA.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: It also reached No. 1 on KROQ's Top 106.7 songs of 2008 countdown list.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: It is the band's most successful hit of the 2000s and overall one of the most popular songs by the band.

title: You're Gonna Go Far, Kid
text: On the album Rise and Fall, Rage and Grace, it appears as the third track after Trust in You.

title: Join Hands
text: Join Hands is the second studio album by the English post-punk band Siouxsie and the Banshees.

title: Join Hands
text: It was released in September 1979 by the record label Polydor.

title: Join Hands
text: Upon its release, it was hailed by the British press, including "Melody Maker", "Sounds", "NME" and "Record Mirror".

title: The Joys of Living 2008–2010
text: The Joys of Living 2008–2010 is a compilation album by the British rock band Sharks, released 5 April 2011.

title: The Joys of Living 2008–2010
text: It compiles tracks recorded during the band's first two years, including their "Shallow Waters" EP (2008), "Common Grounds" single (2009), and "Show of Hands" EP (2010), along with the new tracks "Sweet Harness" and "The Joys of Living".

title: The Joys of Living 2008–2010
text: It serves as a debut for the band in the United States, where their prior releases were available only as imports.

title: The Joys of Living 2008–2010
text: The album was released through the band's imprint Velvet Scene, a joint venture with Rise Records.

title: The Joys of Living 2008–2010
text: The band supported the album by touring the United States with Social Distortion and Chuck Ragan in April and May 2011, and by playing the 2011 Warped Tour.

title: Playground Twist
text: "Playground Twist" is a song by English post-punk band Siouxsie and the Banshees.

title: Playground Twist
text: It was released in 1979 by record Polydor as the sole single from the band's second album, "Join Hands" (1979).

title: Join the Dots (Toy album)
text: Join the Dots is the second studio album by British psychedelic rock band TOY, released on 9 December 2013 in Europe and the UK (17 December, USA) through Heavenly Recordings.

title: Join the Dots (Toy album)
text: The band recorded the album with Dan Carey, who also produced their debut album, and it took twice as long as their first album to record and master.

title: Join the Dots (Toy album)
text: The first single to be released from the album was "Join the Dots", released in October, 2013, as a download and limited hand-stamped seven-inch vinyl.

title: Join the Dots (Toy album)
text: A limited edition of the album included the EP "Join the Dubs" containing five Dub remixes.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: This is the discography of Tom Morello, an American Grammy-award winning rock guitarist most known for his work with the bands Rage Against the Machine, Audioslave, Street Sweeper Social Club and as his folk alter-ego The Nightwatchman.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: Morello started playing guitar in the mid 80's in the band Electric Sheep together with future Tool guitarist Adam Jones on bass.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: After graduating "" from Harvard University in 1986 with a BA in political science, he moved to Los Angeles, where he briefly worked as an aide to Senator Alan Cranston.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: Later Adam Jones moved to L.A. as well; Morello introduced Jones and Maynard James Keenan to Danny Carey, who would come to form the band Tool.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: In the late 80's Morello was recruited to replace original guitar player Mike Livingston in the rock band Lock Up, in 1986 the band released its only album Something Bitchin' This Way Comes.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: In 1991 Morello left Lock Up to start a new band, after being impressed by Zack de la Rocha freestyle rapping he invited him to join his band, he also drafted Brad Wilk who had previously auditioned as a drummer for Lock Up.

title: Tom Morello discography
text: After Zack convinced his childhood friend Tim Commerford to join as the band's bass player the line up was complete.

title: Klenger Burger
text: Klenger Burger is an Indonesian restaurant chain based in Jakarta, operated by PT Kinarya Anak Negeri.

title: Klenger Burger
text: The restaurant chain served halal hamburgers designed to suit the Indonesian palate.

title: Klenger Burger
text: The company sold a variety of burgers, including a 25 cm Raja Klenger (King Klenger) designed to serve seven people.

title: Klenger Burger
text: It also sold pizza, grilled and fried duck and chicken, and Indonesian snacks such as rempeyek and emping.

title: Fazoli's
text: Fazoli's is an Italian-American fast casual restaurant chain based out of Lexington, Kentucky.

title: Fazoli's
text: It was founded in 1988 and is now owned by Seed Restaurant Group, Inc.

title: Fazoli's
text: Today, there are more than 200 Fazoli's located nationwide with plans to expand overseas.

title: Fazoli's
text: The restaurant chain specializes in Italian cuisine and dishes.

title: Fazoli's
text: Carl Howard is the company's president and CEO.

title: KFC
text: KFC, until 1991 known as Kentucky Fried Chicken, is an American fast food restaurant chain that specializes in fried chicken.

title: KFC
text: Headquartered in Louisville, Kentucky, it is the world's second-largest restaurant chain (as measured by sales) after McDonald's, with almost 20,000 locations globally in 123 countries and territories as of December 2015 .

title: KFC
text: The chain is a subsidiary of Yum!

title: KFC
text: Brands, a restaurant company that also owns the Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains.

title: The Chessels
text: The Chessels is an area of Bedminster, Bristol that runs from the midsection of Luckwell Rd to the former White Horse pub on West Street.

title: The Chessels
text: Chessel Street is the main road.

title: The Chessels
text: The name "Chessel" is taken from the name of a field, recorded in 1350.

title: The Chessels
text: The White Horse was redeveloped into flats by 2013, but was once used as a location for the fictional Nags Head pub in the BBC television series "Only Fools and Horses".

title: The Works (restaurant)
text: The Works is a Canadian restaurant chain based in Ottawa, Ontario.

title: The Works (restaurant)
text: The restaurant chain started by Brad Fennema in Ottawa in 2001, has grown to 27 locations across southern Ontario.

title: Piccadilly Pub
text: Piccadilly Pub was a chain of casual dining restaurants headquartered in the US state of Massachusetts.

title: Piccadilly Pub
text: The first Piccadilly Pub restaurant was opened by William C. Martin in 1973 in the town of Westborough, Massachusetts.

title: Dee's Drive-In
text: Dee's Drive-In was a fast food hamburger drive-in restaurant chain based in Utah.

title: Dee's Drive-In
text: The chain was founded by Dee Frederick Anderson, who got his start selling hamburgers operating the Ute Hamburger Shop near the University of Utah in the 1920s.

title: Dee's Drive-In
text: Anderson opened the first Dee's Restaurant in 1932.

title: Dee's Drive-In
text: Dee's would evolve into two separate but related restaurant chains: Dee's Family Restaurant and Dee's Drive-In.

title: VIP's
text: VIP's, alternatively written Vip's, is a defunct restaurant chain in the Western United States that operated from 1968 until the late 1980s, based in Salem, Oregon.

title: VIP's
text: With more than 50 locations, it was once the largest restaurant chain based in Oregon.

title: VIP's
text: It was a Denny's-style restaurant, a type that was commonly known at that time as a "coffee shop" but is now more commonly known as a casual dining restaurant.

title: VIP's
text: Most restaurants were located near freeways and were open 24 hours.

title: VIP's
text: At its peak, the chain had locations in five states: Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Nevada and northern California.

title: Chefette
text: Chefette Restaurants is the largest fast food restaurant chain based in the Caribbean island nation of Barbados.

title: Chefette
text: Currently operating throughout the island in 14 locations, Chefette is known for its broasted chicken meals as well as a local curried-'meat + vegetable' (similar to the European Gyro) roll-up or wrap, locally known as a roti.

title: Chefette
text: Chefette was founded by a Trinidadian businessman named Assad John Haloute, who migrated to Barbados in 1971.

title: Chefette
text: In 1972, he opened the first Chefette Restaurant at Fontabelle, St. Michael.

title: Chefette
text: As the success of the chain grew over the next three decades, the restaurant chain continued its expansion.

title: Chefette
text: The company's trademark colours are yellow and purple.

title: Todai (restaurant)
text: Todai is a restaurant chain based in the United States.

title: Todai (restaurant)
text: As of 2016, the chain had over 19 restaurants in the United States, 7 restaurants in South Korea, one restaurant in Hong Kong, one restaurant in Canada, one restaurant in Indonesia, one restaurant in Singapore and one restaurant in Malaysia.

title: The Inventors
text: The Inventors is a children's novel, co-written by Alexander Gordon Smith and his brother Jamie Webb.

title: The Inventors
text: It follows the story of two best friends, Nate and Cat, young inventors who win a year-long scholarship at Saint Solutions, a giant skyscraper.

title: The Inventors
text: There, under the eye of the world's greatest inventor, Ebenezer Saint, they are given free rein to invent whatever they want.

title: The Inventors
text: But things take a dark turn when Saint refuses to let them leave the complex, and what started as the opportunity of a lifetime turns to a fight for not only their lives, but for the world.

title: Irish prose fiction
text: Although the epics of Celtic Ireland were written in prose and not verse, most people would probably consider that Irish fiction proper begins in the 18th century.

title: Irish prose fiction
text: However, there are aspects of Early Irish prose that appear to have had some influence on the Irish novel: the use of exaggeration for humorous effect, a near obsession with lists, and a strong sense of satire.

title: Irish prose fiction
text: This article is concerned with the history of Irish fiction written in English.

title: Irish prose fiction
text: For Irish fiction written in Irish, see Modern literature in Irish.

title: Irish prose fiction
text: For a general overview of Irish writing in all genres, see Irish literature.

title: Escape from Furnace
text: Escape from Furnace is a series of novel by Alexander Gordon Smith.

title: Escape from Furnace
text: Escape from Furnace is the United States title of the series.

title: Escape from Furnace
text: In the United Kingdom the series is known as "Furnace".

title: Escape from Furnace
text: The books are written from the point of view of the teenage protagonist Alex Sawyer, and are about his incarceration in the fictional London prison Furnace Penitentiary.

title: Escape from Furnace
text: "Escape from Furnace: Lockdown" is followed by "Solitary", "Death Sentence", "Fugitives" and "Execution".

title: Escape from Furnace
text: Smith followed up the series with a novella, "The Night Children", which tells the story of the 17-year-old commissioned officer Kreuz (known as Warden Cross in the series) and his meeting with Alfred Furnace, the prison's enigmatic founder, and his creatures in the Belgian woods during World War II.

title: Grant Smith (footballer)
text: Grant Gordon Smith (born 5 May 1980 in Irvine) is a Scottish footballer midfielder.

title: Grant Smith (footballer)
text: He is the son of former Rangers and Brighton & Hove Albion striker and former Scottish Football Association chief executive Gordon Smith.

title: Alexander Gordon Smith
text: Alexander Gordon Smith (27 February 1979, Norwich, England) is an author of children and Young Adult fiction.

title: Junior school
text: A Junior school is a type of school which provides primary education to children, often in the age range from 8 and 13, following attendance at Infant school which covers the age range 5-7.

title: Junior school
text: (As both Infant and Junior schools are giving Primary Education pupils are commonly placed in a unified building housing the age ranges of both Infants and Juniors - a Primary school).

title: Christ the King College, Isle of Wight
text: Christ the King College is a joint Church of England and Catholic secondary school and sixth form college located in Newport on the Isle of Wight.

title: Christ the King College, Isle of Wight
text: It was created in September 2008 by amalgamating two older schools, Archbishop King Catholic Middle School and Trinity Church of England Middle School.

title: Christ the King College, Isle of Wight
text: As such, the school is on two separate campuses, both located close to each other on Wellington Road.

title: Christ the King College, Isle of Wight
text: Having previously accommodated a middle school age range, the school now takes students from years 7 to 13 after its plans to extend the age range and become a Church of England and Catholic secondary school and sixth form.

title: Sugardaddyforme.com
text: Sugardaddyforme.com is an online dating site for sugar daddies and sugar babies (see Age disparity in sexual relationships).

title: Sugardaddyforme.com
text: In 2013 the dating site had over 4 million members and over 2,000 new sugar daddy and sugar baby profiles every day.

title: Sugardaddyforme.com
text: The website gets 1.5 million unique new visitors every month.

title: Sugardaddyforme.com
text: The age range for women is predominantly 18-45 and for men the age range is predominantly 25-60.

title: James Ogilvie
text: James Ogilvie  (died 1518) was a late medieval Scottish prelate.

title: James Ogilvie
text: After the death of William Elphinstone (died 24 October 1514), the bishopric of Aberdeen became vacant.

title: James Ogilvie
text: Ogilvy was nominated for the vacancy by John Stewart, Duke of Albany.

title: James Ogilvie
text: At Rome however, Pope Leo X provided Robert Forman to the vacant see, while the canons of Aberdeen elect Alexander Gordon, allegedly under pressure from the latter's cousin Alexander Gordon, 3rd Earl of Huntly.

title: George Gordon (bishop)
text: George Gordon (died 1588) was a 16th-century Scottish prelate.

title: George Gordon (bishop)
text: He was the son of Alexander Gordon, Bishop of Galloway, and the brother of John Gordon, also Bishop of Galloway.

title: George Gordon (bishop)
text: He was a cousin of the earls of Huntly, being the great-grandson of Alexander Gordon, 3rd Earl of Huntly.

title: Appius and Virginia
text: Appius and Virginia is an early 17th-century stage play, a tragedy by John Webster (and perhaps Thomas Heywood).

title: Appius and Virginia
text: It is the third and least famous of his tragedies, after "The White Devil" and "The Duchess of Malfi".

title: Revengers Tragedy (album)
text: Revengers Tragedy is a 2003 album by Chumbawamba which served as the soundtrack to the 2003 film adaptation of the 1606 play "The Revenger's Tragedy".

title: Revengers Tragedy
text: Revengers Tragedy is a film adaptation of the 1606 play "The Revenger's Tragedy" (attributed to Thomas Middleton in the credits, following the current scholarly consensus).

title: Revengers Tragedy
text: It was directed by Alex Cox and adapted for the screen by Cox's fellow Liverpudlian, Frank Cottrell Boyce.

title: Revengers Tragedy
text: The film stars Christopher Eccleston as the revenge-obsessed Vindice, with Derek Jacobi as the evil Duke, Eddie Izzard as his lecherous son Lussurioso, Diana Quick as the Duchess, Andrew Schofield as Vindice's brother Carlo (a version of the play's Hippolito), Carla Henry as his virtuous sister Castiza, and Marc Warren and Justin Salinger as the Duchess's sons Supervacuo and Ambitioso.

title: The Duchess of Malfi (Brecht)
text: The Duchess of Malfi is an adaptation by the twentieth-century German dramatist Bertolt Brecht of the English seventeenth-century tragedy by John Webster.

title: The Duchess of Malfi (Brecht)
text: He collaborated with H. R. Hays and Anglo American poet, W. H. Auden.

title: The Duchess of Malfi (Brecht)
text: It was written during Brecht's period of exile in the United States.

title: The Duchess of Malfi (Brecht)
text: In premiered in New York, in 1946.

title: The Revengers' Comedies
text: The Revengers' Comedies is a play by Alan Ayckbourn.

title: The Revengers' Comedies
text: Its title references that of "The Revenger's Tragedy".

title: The Revengers' Comedies
text: The play is an epic piece running more than five hours and was designed to be presented in two parts.

title: The Revengers' Comedies
text: It was inspired by the playwright's love of films and references many notable movies, particularly the Alfred Hitchcock classic "Strangers on a Train".

title: Revengers Tragedy (song)
text: "Revengers Tragedy" is a song performed by British anarcho-punk band Chumbawamba.

title: Revengers Tragedy (song)
text: The song was produced in 2003 as the original soundtrack for Alex Cox's movie, "Revengers Tragedy.

title: Revengers Tragedy (song)
text: It was released as a single on their independent label, MUTT Records.

title: The Duchess of Padua
text: The Duchess of Padua is a play by Oscar Wilde.

title: The Duchess of Padua
text: It is a five-act melodramatic tragedy set in Padua and written in blank verse.

title: The Duchess of Padua
text: It was written for the actress Mary Anderson in early 1883 while in Paris.

title: The Duchess of Padua
text: After she turned it down, it was abandoned until its first performance at the Broadway Theatre in New York City under the title "Guido Ferranti" on 26 January 1891, where it ran for three weeks.

title: The Duchess of Padua
text: It has been rarely revived or studied.

title: Grand Duke's Official Birthday
text: The Grand Duke's Official Birthday (French: "Célébration publique de l'anniversaire du souverain" ), also known as Luxembourgish National Day (French: "Fête nationale luxembourgeoise" , Luxembourgish: "Lëtzebuerger Nationalfeierdag" ), is celebrated as the annual national holiday of Luxembourg.

title: Grand Duke's Official Birthday
text: It is celebrated on 23 June, although this has never been the actual birthday of any ruler of Luxembourg.

title: Grand Duke's Official Birthday
text: When the monarch of Luxembourg is female, it is known as the Grand Duchess' Official Birthday.

title: Murder of Grace Brown
text: Grace Mae Brown (March 20, 1886 – July 11, 1906) was an American skirt factory worker whose murder caused a nationwide sensation, and whose life inspired the fictional character Roberta Alden in the 1925 Theodore Dreiser novel, "An American Tragedy", as well as the 2003 Jennifer Donnelly novel, "A Northern Light".

title: Murder of Grace Brown
text: The facts of the real murder are laid out in the two non-fiction books, both published in 1986: "Adirondack Tragedy: The Gillette Murder Case of 1906", written by Joseph W. Brownell and Patricia A. Wawrzaszek, and "Murder in the Adirondacks: An American Tragedy Revisited", by Craig Brandon.

title: Murder of Grace Brown
text: Shelley Winters was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actress for her performance in the role inspired by Grace Brown (with the name changed to 'Alice Tripp') in the 1951 film "A Place in the Sun," loosely based on the Dreiser novel.

title: Emily Jewell
text: Emily Jewell is an English actress.

title: Emily Jewell
text: She trained at the Central School of Speech and Drama.

title: Emily Jewell
text: Jewell has appeared in "Look Back in Anger" (as Alison) and "The Duchess of Malfi" (as the Duchess) at the Twister Theatre Company.

title: Emily Jewell
text: She also appeared in the film "The Duchess".

title: Farhaan Faasil
text: Farhaan Faasil is an Indian film actor working in Malayalam cinema.

title: Farhaan Faasil
text: He debuted in 2014 with "Njan Steve Lopez" directed by Rajeev Ravi.

title: Farhaan Faasil
text: He is the younger brother of actor Fahadh Faasil.

title: Njan Steve Lopez
text: Njan Steve Lopez ("English: I am Steve Lopez)" is a 2014 Malayalam film, directed by Rajeev Ravi.

title: Njan Steve Lopez
text: The production is also supported by Jar Pictures, M.R Filmworks and Media Mill.

title: Njan Steve Lopez
text: The film is set in Thiruvananthapuram city and stars Farhaan Faasil and debutante Ahaana Krishna.

title: Njan Steve Lopez
text: It released on August 8, 2014.

title: The Fear Merchants
text: "The Fear Merchants" is the second episode of the fifth series of the 1960s cult British spy-fi television series "The Avengers", starring Patrick Macnee and Diana Rigg, and guest starring Patrick Cargill, Brian Wilde, Annette Carell, and Garfield Morgan.

title: The Fear Merchants
text: It was first aired on ABC on 21 January 1967.

title: The Fear Merchants
text: The episode was directed by Gordon Flemyng, and written by Philip Levene.

title: True Love (book)
text: True Love (Spanish: Amor Verdadero) is a book written by the American entertainer Jennifer Lopez.

title: True Love (book)
text: A hardcover edition of the book was published in English and Spanish on November 4, 2014, by Celebra, a division of the Penguin Group.

title: True Love (book)
text: A portion of the proceeds from "True Love" goes to the Lopez Family Foundation, a nonprofit organization co-founded by Lopez that is dedicated to improving the health and well-being of women and children.

title: Ruben Guthrie
text: Ruben Guthrie is a 2015 Australian romantic drama film starring Patrick Brammall as the title character, with Alex Dimitriades and Abbey Lee Kershaw in supporting roles.

title: Ruben Guthrie
text: The film was written and directed by Brendan Cowell, based on his play of the same name.

title: Alencier Ley Lopez
text: Alencier Ley Lopez is an Indian film and theatre actor, who acts in Malayalam films. Lopez debuted in the Malayalam film "Daya" in 1998; he amassed recognition through the films "Annayum Rasoolum" (2013), "Njan Steve Lopez" (2013) and "Maheshinte Prathikaaram" (2016).

title: The Soloist
text: The Soloist is a 2009 British-American drama film directed by Joe Wright, and starring Jamie Foxx and Robert Downey, Jr..

title: The Soloist
text: It is based on the true story of Nathaniel Ayers, a musician who developed schizophrenia and became homeless.

title: The Soloist
text: The screenplay by Susannah Grant is based on the book, "The Soloist" by Steve Lopez.

title: Can't Buy Me Love (film)
text: Can't Buy Me Love is a 1987 American teen romantic comedy feature film starring Patrick Dempsey and Amanda Peterson in a story about a nerd at a high school in Tucson, Arizona who gives a cheerleader $1,000 to pretend to be his girlfriend for a month.

title: Can't Buy Me Love (film)
text: The film was directed by Steve Rash and takes its title from a Beatles song with the same title.

title: The Three Lives of Thomasina
text: The Three Lives of Thomasina is a 1963 British fantasy film starring Patrick McGoohan, Susan Hampshire, child actor Matthew Garber and child actress Karen Dotrice in a story about a cat and her influence on a family.

title: The Three Lives of Thomasina
text: The screenplay was written by Robert Westerby and Paul Gallico.

title: The Three Lives of Thomasina
text: It was based upon Gallico's 1957 novel "Thomasina, the Cat Who Thought She Was God".

title: The Three Lives of Thomasina
text: The film was directed by Don Chaffey, and shot in Inveraray, Argyll, Scotland, and Pinewood Studios, England.

title: The Three Lives of Thomasina
text: "Thomasina" has been broadcast on television and released to VHS and DVD.

title: Third and Indiana
text: Third and Indiana is a novel written by Steve Lopez.

title: Third and Indiana
text: It is about the experiences of several people connected to 14-year-old Gabriel Santoro, while living in the dangerous gang-controlled streets of the Badlands section of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States.

title: Third and Indiana
text: The novel gave notoriety to the real life intersection of Third Street and Indiana Avenue, a real life intersection in the Fairhill area known for the prevalence of drug dealers.

title: Third and Indiana
text: The first printing had 50,000 copies printed.

title: Third and Indiana
text: Published in 1994, it was Lopez's first novel.

title: Susan Gerbic
text: Susan Marie Gerbic (born August 8, 1962) is an American skeptical activist living in Salinas, California.

title: Susan Gerbic
text: Gerbic is the co-founder of Monterey County Skeptics, founder of Skeptic Action, founder and leader of the Guerrilla Skepticism on Wikipedia (GSoW) project, a recurring contributor to the "Skepticality" podcast, and she regularly contributes to "Skeptical Inquirer".

title: Susan Gerbic
text: Gerbic has focused much of her skeptical activism on people claiming to be "clairvoyant mediums," such as Sylvia Brown and Tyler Henry, who she calls "Grief Vampires".

title: Exeter incident
text: The Exeter incident was a highly publicized UFO sighting that occurred on September 3, 1965, approximately 5 miles (8 km) south of Exeter, New Hampshire, in the neighboring town of Kensington.

title: Exeter incident
text: Although several separate sightings had been made by numerous witnesses in the weeks leading up to September 3, the specific incident, eventually to become by far the most famous, involved a local teenager and two police officers.

title: Exeter incident
text: The November/December 2011 edition of "Skeptical Inquirer" offers an explanation of the incident, based on details reported by the eyewitnesses.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: Barry L Beyerstein (May 19, 1947 – June 25, 2007) was a scientific skeptic and professor of psychology at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: Beyerstein's research explored brain mechanisms of perception and consciousness, the effects of drugs on the brain and mind, sense of smell and its lesser-known contributions to human cognition and emotion.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: He was founder and chair of the BC Skeptics Society.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: A Fellow and member of the Executive Council of the Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal (CSICOP), now known as the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: Associate editor of the "Scientific Review of Alternative Medicine" Journal as well as a contributor to Skeptical Inquirer Magazine.

title: Barry Beyerstein
text: Beyerstein was one of the original faculty of CSICOP's Skeptic's Toolbox.

title: Harriet A. Hall
text: Harriet A. Hall (born July 2, 1945) is a U.S. retired family physician, former U.S. Air Force flight surgeon and skeptic who writes about alternative medicine and quackery for "Skeptic" and "Skeptical Inquirer".

title: CSICon
text: CSICon or CSIConference is an annual skeptical conference typically held in the United States.

title: CSICon
text: CSICon is hosted by the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI), which is a program of the Center for Inquiry (CFI).

title: CSICon
text: CSI publishes "Skeptical Inquirer", subtitled "The Magazine for Science and Reason".

title: William R. Harwood
text: William R. Harwood is a scientist and author, contributor to "Skeptical Inquirer", "Free Inquiry", and contributing editor to the "American Rationalist".

title: William R. Harwood
text: He is the author of over 50 books including "Mythology’s Last Gods" (Prometheus, 1992), "God, Jesus and the Bible: The Origin and Evolution of Religion", "Dictionary of Contemporary Mythology; The Disinformation Cycle"; several novels, and the two-volume "The Fully Translated Bible" (ed/tr), as well as over 600 articles and book reviews for periodicals in nine countries.

title: James Alcock
text: James E. Alcock (born 24 December 1942) is a Canadian educator.

title: James Alcock
text: He has been a Professor of Psychology at York University (Canada) since 1973.

title: James Alcock
text: Alcock is a noted critic of parapsychology and is a Fellow and Member of the Executive Council for the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry.

title: James Alcock
text: He is a member of the Editorial Board of "The Skeptical Inquirer", and a frequent contributor to the magazine.

title: James Alcock
text: He has also been a columnist for "Humanist Perspectives" Magazine.

title: James Alcock
text: In 1999, a panel of skeptics named him among the two dozen most outstanding skeptics of the 20th century.

title: James Alcock
text: In May 2004, CSICOP awarded Alcock CSI's highest honor, the In Praise of Reason Award.

title: James Alcock
text: Alcock is also an amateur magician and is a member of the International Brotherhood of Magicians.

title: Kendrick Frazier
text: Kendrick Crosby Frazier (born March 19, 1942) is a science writer and longtime editor of "Skeptical Inquirer" magazine.

title: Kendrick Frazier
text: He is also a former editor of "Science News", author or editor of ten books, and a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS).

title: Kendrick Frazier
text: He is a fellow and a member of the executive council of Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI), an international organization which promotes scientific inquiry.

title: Wonder en is gheen Wonder
text: Wonder en is gheen Wonder ("Mystery is no Mystery") is a popular science magazine of the Flemish skeptical association SKEPP.

title: Wonder en is gheen Wonder
text: The paper was founded in 2000 by Tom Schoepen, who also served as its editor for its first ten years.

title: Wonder en is gheen Wonder
text: The magazine is published four times a year and addresses pseudoscientific as well as science philosophical topics.

title: Wonder en is gheen Wonder
text: The title is a reference to the 16th century Flemish mathematician and engineer Simon Stevin's commentary to his famous thought experiment: even if something looks strange, it can still have a naturalistic explanation.

title: Wonder en is gheen Wonder
text: The subtitle "Tijdschrift voor wetenschap en rede" ("Magazine for science and reason") was taken from "Skeptical Inquirer", the most world-renowned skeptical magazine that is published by the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry.

title: Skeptical Inquirer
text: Skeptical Inquirer is a bimonthly American magazine published by the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI) with the subtitle: "The Magazine for Science and Reason".

title: Skeptical Inquirer
text: In 2016 it celebrated its fortieth anniversary.

title: Skeptical Inquirer
text: For most of its existence, the Skeptical Inquirer (SI) was published by the Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal, widely known by its acronym CSICOP.

title: Skeptical Inquirer
text: In 2006 the CSICOP Executive Council shortened CSICOP’s name to the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI) and broadened its mission statement.

title: Swati Sen
text: Swati Sen is an Indian film actress born in Nagpur, Maharashtra, most known for her roles in "Udedh Bun", which won the Silver Bear for Best Short Film at the 2008 Berlin International Film Festival, and the National Film Award-winning "Antardwand" (2010), which won her critical acclaim as well as Best Actress MAMI.

title: Sara Botsford
text: Sara Botsford (born August 4, 1951) is a Canadian television and film actress.

title: Sara Botsford
text: She plays Marilla in the 2016 "Anne of Green Gables" TV movie, opposite Martin Sheen, and plays Lady Covington in the Nickelodeon YTV series "RIDE".

title: Sara Botsford
text: She is probably best known for her role of Ann Hildebrand in the television series "E.N.G." for which she won a Gemini Award for Best Performance by an Actress in a Continuing Leading Dramatic Role.

title: Sara Botsford
text: Prior to that role, her most remembered role would be the wickedly evil character of Lillith McKechnie, AKA Isabella, on the daytime drama "As the World Turns" from 1988 to 1990.

title: Sara Botsford
text: In "Dangerous Offender: The Marlene Moore Story" (1996), she portrayed Marlene Moore's (Brooke Johnson) lawyer.

title: Sara Botsford
text: In 2002 she portrayed Kathleen Sinclair in the TV movie "Trudeau" about the life of the late Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: Sara Botsford
text: In 2003 she appeared in "Burn: The Robert Wraight Story".

title: Gina Pareño
text: Gina Pareño (born "Geraldine Acthley", October 20, 1949) is a Filipino actress born to a German-American father and a Filipina mother.

title: Gina Pareño
text: She started her career in the 1960s as an extra in several films and then later on became one of the artists of Sampaguita Pictures.

title: Gina Pareño
text: In 2006, she gained international recognition for her role in "Kubrador" ("The Bet Collector") wherein she won the Best Actress award at the Osian's Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema and at the Brussels International Independent Film Festival.

title: Gina Pareño
text: Pareño also won the Metro Manila Film Festival Award for Best Supporting Actress as an outspoken and brash mother in the movie "Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo" and then later on received accolades for the same film and category in the FAMAS Awards as well as the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards in that same year.

title: Julie Ordon
text: Julie Ordon (born June 27, 1984) is a Swiss model and actress born in Geneva, Switzerland.

title: Daniela Castillo
text: Daniela Paz Castillo Vicuña (born September 26, 1984 in Santiago) is a Chilean female pop singer and actress born in Santiago.

title: Daniela Castillo
text: She debuted in 2002 as a solo artist on the Chilean TV show "Rojo: Fama Contra Fama".

title: Daniela Castillo
text: She studied four years at the Alicia Puccio Academy where she met the casting crew for the TV show "Rojo".

title: Daniela Castillo
text: Although she did not win first place in the singer talent contest, she became very popular due to her voice.

title: Evelina Simonaho
text: Evelina Anima Simonaho is a Swedish actress born in Falkenberg 1984.

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: Lisa E. Wilcox (born April 27, 1964) is an American actress and designer.

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: She made her film debut in the 1984 film "Gimme an 'F'".

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: Wilcox is best known for her role as Alice Johnson in "" (1988) and the 1989 sequel "".

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: Wilcox is also known for her role as Yuta in an episode of "" called "The Vengeance Factor" (1989).

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: She subsequently starred in "Men Seeking Women" (1997), "Watchers Reborn" (1998), "Clinger" (2015), and "The Church" (2016).

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: Wilcox has had guest appearances on several television series, such as "Knots Landing" (1989), "Boy Meets World" (1993-95), as well as a lead role on "Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventures" (1992).

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: In 2009, Wilcox portrayed Nurse Owens in the web series "Fear Clinic".

title: Lisa Wilcox
text: In 2010, Wilcox appeared as herself in the documentary "".

title: Kishore Dang
text: Kishore Dang (born 1 July 1958) is an Indian director.

title: Kishore Dang
text: He has had a 30-year long career in TV shows, production and film making.

title: Kishore Dang
text: Dang was also a member of the Jury of the 53rd National Film Awards organized by the Government of India.

title: Kishore Dang
text: Dang has been associated with foreign films such as Gandhi (film), The Far Pavilions, Kim (1984 film), Mountbatten: The Last Viceroy, The Deceivers, The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles, In Custody and The Jungle Book.

title: Kishore Dang
text: He has been associated with the Theatre Group “Ank” for four years that was led by Mr. Dinesh Thakur.

title: Kishore Dang
text: His famous shows include Maila Aanchal, Nooriee, Uttarkatha, Humsafar The Train, Detective Karan and Faujji...The Iron Man.

title: Kishore Dang
text: He has also directed a documentary film called Kab Tak that participated in Mumbai International Film Festival 2012.

title: Kishore Dang
text: Other films include Aakhri Dastak - a film made for the Indian Army.

title: Marlene (1984 film)
text: Marlene, also known in Germany as Marlene Dietrich - Porträt eines Mythos, is a 1984 documentary film made by Maximilian Schell about the legendary film star Marlene Dietrich.

title: Marlene (1984 film)
text: It was made by Bayerischer Rundfunk (BR) and OKO-Film and released by Futura Film, Munich and Alive Films, (USA).

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: Madhuri Dixit is an Indian actress known for her work in Bollywood films.

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: She made her acting debut with the role of a young bride in the 1984 film "Abodh".

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: Dixit went on to appear in several films over the next two years, including the dramas "Awara Baap" (1985) and "Swati" (1986), though none of them garnered her much recognition.

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: Her breakthrough role came in 1988 with N. Chandra's thriller "Tezaab", the highest-grossing film of that year.

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: "Ek Do Teen", a dance number that she performed in the film, was widely popular.

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: She continued to play the lead in the commercially successful action-dramas "Ram Lakhan" (1989), "Tridev" (1989), and "Kishen Kanhaiya" (1990).

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: The role of a wealthy brat in the 1990 romantic drama "Dil" earned Dixit her first Filmfare Award for Best Actress.

title: Madhuri Dixit filmography
text: The following year, she starred in "Saajan", and won a second Best Actress award at Filmfare for playing a woman who rebels against her manipulative mother-in-law in the drama "Beta".

title: Wilton, Maine
text: Wilton is a town in Franklin County, Maine, United States.

title: Wilton, Maine
text: The population was 4,116 at the 2010 census.

title: Wilton, Maine
text: Situated beside Wilson Pond, the former mill town is today primarily a recreation area.

title: Manor of Rivington
text: The Manor of Rivington was a manorial estate in Rivington, Lancashire, England that possibly predates the Domesday survey.

title: Manor of Rivington
text: Before 1212 the Pilkington family owned six oxgangs of land.

title: Manor of Rivington
text: Over time it became separated in moieties and by the 16th century the Pilkingtons of Rivington Hall owned a 5/8 share.

title: Manor of Rivington
text: In 1605 the Lathoms of Irlam owned a quarter share and the Shaws 1/8.

title: Rivington Hall Barn
text: Rivington Hall Barn adjoins Rivington Hall in Rivington, Lancashire, near Chorley and Bolton.

title: Rivington Hall Barn
text: The barn may date from between the 9th and 13th centuries, but more likely the 16th century, and was restored, altered and enlarged in 1905 by Jonathan Simpson for Lord Leverhulme.

title: Rivington Hall Barn
text: It is a Grade II Listed building.

title: Rivington Hall
text: Rivington Hall is a Grade II* listed building in Rivington, Lancashire, England.

title: Rivington Hall
text: It was the manor house for the Lords of the Manor of Rivington.

title: Rivington Hall
text: The hall is of various builds as successor to a 15th-century timber-framed courtyard house that was built near to the present building of which no trace remains.

title: Rivington Hall
text: It is a private residence.

title: Savage, Maryland
text: Savage is an unincorporated community and census-designated place located in Howard County, Maryland, about 18 mi south of Baltimore and 21 mi north of Washington, D.C. It is situated close to the city of Laurel and to the planned community of Columbia.

title: Savage, Maryland
text: As of the 2010 census it had a population of 7,054.

title: Savage, Maryland
text: The former mill town is a registered historic place, and has many original buildings preserved within and around the Savage Mill Historic District.

title: Bolton
text: Bolton ( or locally ] ) is a town in Greater Manchester in North West England.

title: Bolton
text: A former mill town, Bolton has been a production centre for textiles since Flemish weavers settled in the area in the 14th century, introducing a wool and cotton-weaving tradition.

title: Bolton
text: The urbanisation and development of the town largely coincided with the introduction of textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution.

title: Bolton
text: Bolton was a 19th-century boomtown, and at its zenith in 1929 its 216 cotton mills and 26 bleaching and dyeing works made it one of the largest and most productive centres of cotton spinning in the world.

title: Bolton
text: The British cotton industry declined sharply after the First World War, and by the 1980s cotton manufacture had virtually ceased in Bolton.

title: Stank Hall
text: Stank Hall is a historic building in Beeston, a suburb of Leeds in England.

title: Stank Hall
text: It was built in the late 15th century for the Beeston family.

title: Stank Hall
text: It has been listed as Grade II by English Heritage since 19 October 1951.

title: Stank Hall
text: Immediately to the north stands a Grade II*–listed barn of the late 15th – early 16th century that was also built for the Beeston family and was acquired by the Hodgson family in the 17th century.

title: Stank Hall
text: In 2014, the barn was acquired from the Leeds City Council by the Friends of Stank Hall Barn, with the intent of restoring it.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District is a national historic district located at the Village of Muddy Creek Forks in East Hopewell, Fawn, and Lower Chanceford Townships in York County, Pennsylvania.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: The district includes 12 contributing buildings, 1 contributing site, and 5 contributing structures.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: The buildings and structures were constructed between about 1800 and 1935.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: The buildings include the general store, six houses, a mill, grain elevator, warehouse, and Sweitzer barn.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: Most of the buildings incorporate Late Victorian style details.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: The structures are two bridges, a corn crib, a weigh station, and a mill race.

title: Muddy Creek Forks Historic District
text: The site is the site of a former mill and mill pond.

title: Baron Burnham
text: Baron Burnham, of Hall Barn in the Parish of Beaconsfield in the County of Buckingham, is a title in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Baron Burnham
text: It was created in 1903 for the influential newspaper magnate Sir Edward Levy-Lawson, 1st Baronet, owner of the "Daily Telegraph".

title: Baron Burnham
text: He had already been created a Baronet, of Hall Barn in The Parish of Beaconsfield in the County of Buckingham, in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom in 1892.

title: Baron Burnham
text: Levy-Lawson was the son of Joseph Moses Levy, who acquired the "Daily Telegraph" only months after its founding.

title: Almonte, Ontario
text: Almonte (pronounced "AL-mont" as opposed to the original Spanish pronunciation of "al-MON-tay") is a former mill town located in Lanark County, in the eastern portion of Ontario, Canada.

title: Almonte, Ontario
text: Formerly a separate municipality, Almonte is now a ward of the town of Mississippi Mills, which was created on January 1, 1998 by the merging of Almonte with Ramsay and Pakenham townships.

title: Almonte, Ontario
text: Almonte is located 46 km south-west of downtown Ottawa.

title: Almonte, Ontario
text: Its population as of 2013 is about 5,000.

title: Stoddard engine
text: Elliott J. Stoddard invented and patented two versions of the Stoddard engine, the first in 1919 and the second in 1933.

title: Stoddard engine
text: The general engine classification is an external combustion engine with valves and single-phase gaseous working fluid (i.e. a "hot air engine").

title: Stoddard engine
text: The internal working fluid was originally air, although in modern versions, other gases such as helium or hydrogen may be used.

title: Stephen Boreham
text: Charles Stephen Boreham (19 December 1857 – 15 May 1925) was a New Zealand shearer and trade unionist.

title: Stephen Boreham
text: He was born in Richmond, Tasmania, Australia on 19 December 1857.

title: Daboll trumpet
text: A Daboll trumpet is an air trumpet foghorn which was developed by an American, Celadon Leeds Daboll, of New London, Connecticut.

title: Daboll trumpet
text: It was basically a small coal-fired hot air engine, which compressed air in a cylinder on top of which was a reed horn.

title: George Cayley
text: Sir George Cayley, 6th Baronet (27 December 1773 – 15 December 1857) was a prolific English engineer and is one of the most important people in the history of aeronautics.

title: George Cayley
text: Many consider him to be the first true scientific aerial investigator and the first person to understand the underlying principles and forces of flight.

title: Hot air engine
text: A hot air engine (historically called an air engine or caloric engine) is any heat engine that uses the expansion and contraction of air under the influence of a temperature change to convert thermal energy into mechanical work.

title: Hot air engine
text: These engines may be based on a number of thermodynamic cycles encompassing both open cycle devices such as those of Sir George Cayley and John Ericsson and the closed cycle engine of Robert Stirling.

title: Hot air engine
text: Hot air engines are distinct from the better known internal combustion based engine and steam engine.

title: Gas-generator cycle
text: The gas-generator cycle is a power cycle of a bipropellant rocket engine.

title: Gas-generator cycle
text: Some of the propellant is burned in a gas generator and the resulting hot gas is used to power the engine's pumps.

title: Gas-generator cycle
text: The gas is then exhausted.

title: Gas-generator cycle
text: Because something is "thrown away" this type of engine is also known as open cycle.

title: External combustion engine
text: An external combustion engine (EC engine) is a heat engine where a working fluid, contained internally, is heated by combustion in an external source, through the engine wall or a heat exchanger.

title: External combustion engine
text: The fluid then, by expanding and acting on the mechanism of the engine, produces motion and usable work.

title: External combustion engine
text: The fluid is then cooled, compressed and reused (closed cycle), or (less commonly) dumped, and cool fluid pulled in (open cycle air engine).

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: A Manson-Guise engine is an improved version of a Manson engine.

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: It is a type of hot air engine, converting a temperature difference into motion.

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: There is a hot side and a cold side to the engine.

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: Providing there is a large enough temperature difference between the two sides the engine will run.

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: The Manson-Guise engine is probably the simplest type of hot air engines having only a single con-rod, with a displacer piston and power piston that move at the same time.

title: Manson-Guise Engine
text: Manson-Guise engines seem to be fairly unique in the fact that they can run in either direction (flywheel can run clockwise or anti-clockwise).

title: Piccard Balloons
text: Piccard Balloons, along with Raven Industries (founded by Ed Yost), SEMCO, and The Balloon Works (now Firefly Balloons), was among the first manufacturers of hot air balloons.

title: Piccard Balloons
text: Don Piccard, descended from a long line of aeronauts, built and sold some of the first modern hot air balloons, beginning in the mid-1960s.

title: Piccard Balloons
text: Piccard Balloons contributed much to the sport of Hot air ballooning, through innovative design and construction.

title: Working fluid
text: A working fluid is a pressurized gas or liquid that actuates a machine.

title: Working fluid
text: Examples include steam in a steam engine, air in a hot air engine and hydraulic fluid in a hydraulic motor or hydraulic cylinder.

title: Working fluid
text: More generally, in a thermodynamic system, the working fluid is a liquid or gas that absorbs or transmits energy.

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: Dog Tales is a 1958 Warner Brothers animated cartoon which consists of a series of blackout gags involving dogs (e.g., one in which a doberman pinscher viciously pinches an overweight U.S. Army private identified as "Doberman" (a reference to, and caricature of, the character played by Maurice Gosfield on "The Phil Silvers Show"); and another in which the narrator can't make up his mind whether the dog pictured is a pointer or a setter, and then finally shows a picture of a "point-setter").

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: A basset hound declares that she's a TV star (a reference to Cleo the Dog, from the contemporary TV sitcom "The People's Choice"), we learn the unusual breed of a Newfoundland puppy's grandfather, and a great dane named "Victor Barky" plays the piano.

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: Reused animation from Chuck Jones' "Often an Orphan" (1949) and Friz Freleng's "Piker's Peak" (1957) is also seen here.

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: In the former case, Charlie Dog makes a cameo - his final appearance in a Warner Bros. cartoon as well as his only cartoon to not be directed by Chuck Jones.

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: This animated film features the voices of Mel Blanc, Robert C. Bruce and Julie Bennett, and was directed by Robert McKimson and written by Tedd Pierce.

title: Dog Tales (1958 film)
text: It was released in theaters on July 26, 1958.

title: Bulldog
text: The Bulldog is a medium-sized breed of dog commonly referred to as the English Bulldog or British Bulldog.

title: Bulldog
text: Other scent-hound breeds include the Small Greek Domestic Dog, Irish Wolfhound, Bluetick Coonhound, Finnish Lapphund, and the Basset Hound.

title: Bulldog
text: The Bulldog is a muscular, hefty dog with a wrinkled face and a distinctive pushed-in nose.

title: Bulldog
text: The American Kennel Club (AKC), The Kennel Club (UK), and the United Kennel Club (UKC) oversee breeding records.

title: Bulldog
text: Bulldogs were the fourth most popular purebreed in the US in 2007 according to the American Kennel Club.

title: List of U.S. state dogs
text: Twelve states of the United States have designated an official state dog breed.

title: List of U.S. state dogs
text: Maryland was the first state to name a dog breed as a state symbol, naming the Chesapeake Bay Retriever in 1964.

title: List of U.S. state dogs
text: Pennsylvania followed the year after, naming the Great Dane as its official breed.

title: List of U.S. state dogs
text: Dog breeds are mostly affiliated with the states that they originated in.

title: List of U.S. state dogs
text: North Carolina chose the Plott Hound as it was the only dog breed indigenous to the state.

title: Leonberger
text: The Leonberger is a giant dog breed.

title: Leonberger
text: The breed's name derives from the city of Leonberg in Baden-Württemberg, Germany.

title: Leonberger
text: According to legend, the Leonberger was ostensibly bred as a "symbolic dog" that would mimic the lion in the town crest.

title: Leonberger
text: It is in the Working Group for dog shows such as Crufts, but not at the World Dog Show.

title: Barnyard Dawg
text: (The) Barnyard Dawg (also known as George P. Dog) is a "Looney Tunes" character.

title: Barnyard Dawg
text: An adult anthropomorphic basset hound, he is the archenemy of Foghorn Leghorn.

title: Barnyard Dawg
text: He was created by Robert McKimson, who also created Foghorn, and was voiced by Mel Blanc.

title: Barnyard Dawg
text: Dawg also feuds with other enemies as well like Henery Hawk, the Weasel, Daffy Duck and Sylvester.

title: Barnyard Dawg
text: He appeared in 22 Golden Age–era Warner Bros. shorts.

title: Giant dog breed
text: A giant dog breed has no universal height or weight classification, although some groups define "giant breeds" as those heavier than 50 kg .

title: Giant dog breed
text: Giant breeds grow rapidly, but take longer to mature into their full adult sizes than smaller dogs.

title: Cão de Gado Transmontano
text: The Cão de Gado Transmontano (] ; English: Transmontano Mastiff or Transmontano Cattle Dog) is a rare molosser working giant dog breed, originating in and largely limited to the region of Trás-os-Montes e Alto Douro Province, Portugal.

title: Cão de Gado Transmontano
text: Their primary function is flock and herd protection, and their success is interlinked to the welfare of the flock and the presence of wolves, particularly.

title: Cão de Gado Transmontano
text: Although they are a regional breed, their wolf defense capacity has led to limited experimental importation elsewhere.

title: Breed standard (dogs)
text: A breed standard (also called bench standard or the standard) in the dog fancy is a set of guidelines covering specific "externally observable" qualities such as "appearance", "movement", and "temperament" for that dog breed.

title: Breed standard (dogs)
text: Breed standards are not scientific documents, but are written for each breed by clubs of hobbyists called breed clubs for their own specific requirements.

title: Breed standard (dogs)
text: Details and definitions within breed standards for a specific dog breed may vary from breed club to breed club and from country to country.

title: Breed standard (dogs)
text: Dog breed standards are similar in form and function to breed standards for other domesticated animals.

title: Basset Hound
text: The Basset Hound is a short-legged breed of dog of the hound family.

title: Basset Hound
text: The Basset is a scent hound that was originally bred for the purpose of hunting hare.

title: Basset Hound
text: Their sense of smell and ability to ground-scent is second only to that of the Bloodhound.

title: Basset Hound
text: Basset Hounds are one of 6 recognised basset-type breeds in France.

title: Fred Basset
text: Fred Basset is a comic strip about a male basset hound.

title: Fred Basset
text: The cartoon was created by Scottish cartoonist Alex Graham and published first in the "Daily Mail" on 8 July 1963.

title: Fred Basset
text: It has since been syndicated around the world.

title: Staten Island Community Board 1
text: Staten Island Community Board 1 is a local government unit of the city of New York, encompassing the Staten Island neighborhoods of Arlington, northern Castleton Corners, Clifton Concord, Elm Park, Fort Wadsworth, northern Graniteville, Grymes Hill, Livingston, Mariners' Harbor, northern Meiers Corners, New Brighton, Port Ivory, Port Richmond, Randall Manor, Rosebank, Staten Island, St. George, Shore Acres, Silver Lake, Stapleton, Sunnyside, Tompkinsville, West Brighton, Westerleigh, and northern Willowbrook.

title: Staten Island Community Board 1
text: Community Board 1 is essentially the entire area of Staten Island north of the Staten Island Expressway.

title: Staten Island Borough Hall
text: Staten Island Borough Hall is the primary municipal building for the borough of Staten Island in New York City.

title: Staten Island Borough Hall
text: It is located at 10 Richmond Terrace, next to the Richmond County Courthouse and opposite the Staten Island Ferry Terminal.

title: Staten Island Borough Hall
text: Staten Island Borough Hall houses the Borough President's office, offices of the Departments of Buildings and T

title: Staten Island Register
text: The Staten Island Register was a weekly newspaper serving the borough of Staten Island in New York City as an independent alternative to other news sources, including the "Staten Island Advance".

title: Staten Island Register
text: It began publication in 1966 under the ownership of the Sclafani family.

title: Staten Island Register
text: Joseph was the Owner.

title: Staten Island Register
text: The "Staten Island Register" was sold in August 2002 to Elauwit, LLC, a company formed by Daniel McDonough of New Jersey, was sold by McDonough to an investor in 2004, and ceased publication in December 2005.

title: Staten Island Technical High School
text: Staten Island Technical High School, commonly called Staten Island Tech or SITHS, was founded in 1988.

title: Staten Island Technical High School
text: Located in Staten Island, New York City, the school is operated by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Staten Island Technical High School
text: In 2005, Staten Island Tech became the only Specialized High School in Staten Island.

title: Staten Island Technical High School
text: It consistently ranks among the best schools in New York City in graduation rate, Regents test scores, and attendance.

title: Staten Island Technical High School
