text: The first British edition was issued by Atlas Publishing in 1952; part of the run was issued in a hardcover binding.

title: From Unknown Worlds
text: This edition omitted the story "One Man's Harp."

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: Suanfa tongzong (General Source of Computational Methods) is a mathematical text written by sixteenth century Chinese mathematician Cheng Dawei (1533–1606) and published in the year 1592.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: The book contains 595 problems divided into 17 chapters.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: The book is essentially general arithmetic for the abacus.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: The book was the main source available to scholars concerning mathematics as it developed in China’s tradition.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: Six years after the publication of Suanfa Tongzong, Cheng Dawei published another book titled "Suanfa Zuanyao" ("A Compendium of calculating Methods").

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: About 90% of the content of the new book came from the contents of four chapters of the first book with some rearrangement.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: It is said that when Suanfa Tongzong was first published, it sold so many copies that the cost of paper went up and the lucrative sales resulted in unscrupulous people beginning to print pirated copies of the book with many errors.

title: Suanfa tongzong
text: it was this that forced the author to print an abridged version.

title: Gollum: How We Made Movie Magic
text: "Gollum" details how a three-week commission for Andy Serkis to provide a voice-over for Gollum grew into a five-year commitment to breathe life and soul into "The Lord of the Rings"' most challenging creation.

title: Gollum: How We Made Movie Magic
text: Andy Serkis tackles various subjects throughout the book, including character conception (Gollum's "cough" is derived from his cat coughing up a hairball) as well as the hard work it took to act out Gollum and replace it with CGI.

title: Gollum: How We Made Movie Magic
text: He also discusses the controversy of whether he should have been eligible for an Academy Award for his work as Gollum.

title: Sega All Stars
text: Sega All Stars was Sega's budget series for the Dreamcast, similar to Platinum Hits, Greatest Hits, and Player's Choice, for games that have sold many copies.

title: Sega All Stars
text: When a title became a Sega All Stars title, it was sold at a lower price ($19.95) and given reprinted labeling.

title: Sega All Stars
text: Sega All Stars was exclusive to North America, game covers were given an orange bar (as opposed to Europe's blue color scheme) with the brand name written from top to bottom.

title: Sega All Stars
text: The disc labels were also changed to include a small circle and the Sega All Stars brand printed inside of it.

title: Sega All Stars
text: 17 titles were made into Sega All Stars titles.

title: Sega All Stars
text: Also, in printing, original releases said "Sega Dreamcast" on the disc but the All-stars versions just simply said "Dreamcast" to match up games released with the black label like "D2", "Jet Set Radio", "Sega GT", and "Sonic Adventure 2".

title: Sega All Stars
text: Original Dreamcast games were released in the white labels and said "Sega Dreamcast" on the inlay like the Sega All-stars labels.

title: Ingerophrynus
text: Ingerophrynus is a genus of true toads with 12 species.

title: Ingerophrynus
text: These species distributed in southern Yunnan and Indochina; peninsular Thailand and Malaya to Sumatra, Borneo, Java, Nias Island, Sulawesi, and the Philippines.

title: Ingerophrynus
text: This genus was established after a major taxonomical revision of frogs.

title: Ingerophrynus
text: Ten of the species in this genus were formerly considered species of the genus "Bufo".

title: Ingerophrynus
text: In 2007 a new species, "Ingerophrynus gollum", was added to this genus.

title: Ingerophrynus
text: This species is named after the character Gollum created by J. R. R. Tolkien.

title: Cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics
text: The cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics, proposed by Anthony Aguirre and Max Tegmark, is an interpretation of quantum mechanics that applies in the context of eternal cosmological inflation, which arguably predicts an infinite three-dimensional space with infinitely many planets and infinitely many copies of any quantum system.

title: Cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics
text: According to this interpretation, the wavefunction for a quantum system describes not some imaginary ensemble of possibilities for what the system might be doing, but rather the actual spatial collection of identical copies of the system that exist in our infinite space.

title: Cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics
text: Its collapse can be avoided.

title: Cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics
text: Moreover, the quantum uncertainty that you experience simply reflects your inability to self-locate in space, i.e., to know which of your infinitely many copies throughout space is the one having your subjective perceptions.

title: Gollum (genus)
text: Gollum is a genus of ground sharks in the family Pseudotriakidae, native to the southwestern Pacific Ocean.

title: Gollum (genus)
text: The genus was described in 1973 by biologist Leonard Compagno, who named it named after the character Gollum from J. R. R. Tolkien's works, noting the species "Gollum attenuatus" (the slender smooth-hound) "bears some resemblance in form and habits".

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: Perfect Day is the second studio album released by German Eurodance group Cascada.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: The entire album was produced by the group's two DJs, Yanou and DJ Manian.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: Like its predecessor, the album is comprised heavily of uptempo Eurodance tracks, many of which are cover songs.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: This album, however, features covers of songs from the early 2000s of the rock and country genres, with the exception of Because the Night (originally released by Patti Smith) which was released in 1978.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: Two edited tracks, "Endless Summer" and "I Will Believe It" that were previously recorded under the "Siria" name are also featured.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: Musically, the album is composed of Eurodance tracks with euphoric trance-style synths, drum programmings with a tempo over 140 beats per minute, and Europop lyrics.

title: Perfect Day (Cascada album)
text: Lyrically, the albums is composed of love, partying and romance.

title: Barbie Girl
text: "Barbie Girl" is a song by the Danish-Norwegian dance-pop group Aqua.

title: Barbie Girl
text: It was released in May 1997 as their third single overall, and the first United Kingdom release, it is included on the album "Aquarium".

title: Barbie Girl
text: The song was written by Søren Rasted, Claus Norreen, René Dif, and Lene Nystrøm, and it was produced by Johnny Jam, Delgado, Rasted, and Norreen.

title: Barbie Girl
text: It was written after Rasted saw an exhibit on kitsch culture in Denmark which featured Barbie dolls.

title: Daze (band)
text: Daze is a Danish Eurodance/bubblegum dance band whose 1997 debut album "Super Heroes" became a double platinum international hit.

title: Daze (band)
text: The band is a trio composed of Lucas Sieber, Jesper Tønnov, and Trine Bix, and their style of "zany" "turbo-pop" music is compared to the Danish pop band Aqua.

title: Daze (band)
text: "Super Heroes", initially published in Scandinavia by Sony Music, sold 31,000 copies on the release day and was later released in the United States by Columbia Records and in Non-Nordic global territories by Epic Records.

title: Daze (band)
text: Hit singles included "Superhero", "Tamogotchi" and "Toy Boy".

title: Daze (band)
text: In February 1998, Daze won the Danish Grammy Award for Best Dance Album of 1997.

title: Daze (band)
text: The single "Superhero" was nominated as 1997 Danish hit of the year by G.A.F.F.A. magazine.

title: Daze (band)
text: It was also very famous in Argentina during those years.

title: Søren Rasted
text: Søren Nystrøm Rasted (born Søren Rasted on 13 June 1969 in Blovstrød, Denmark) is a Danish musician, singer, songwriter and record producer.

title: Søren Rasted
text: He plays keyboard, guitar and sings backing vocals.

title: Søren Rasted
text: He is one of the four members of Danish eurodance group Aqua, and was married to the Aqua vocalist Lene Nystrøm.

title: Aquarium (Aqua album)
text: Aquarium is the debut studio album by Danish-Norwegian band Aqua.

title: Aquarium (Aqua album)
text: The album was released in Scandinavia on 26 March 1997 and in the United States on 9 September 1997.

title: Aquarium (Aqua album)
text: Although the group had been together for three years under their original name Joyspeed, their only release under that name was a single called "Itzy Bitsy Spider".

title: Aquarium (Aqua album)
text: The album is best known for including the successful singles "Barbie Girl", "Doctor Jones" and "Turn Back Time", the first of those being a huge hit across the globe.

title: Aquarium (Aqua album)
text: (The album was preceded by the two singles "Roses Are Red" and "My Oh My", with the latter re-released in 1998.)

title: Lene Nystrøm
text: Lene Nystrøm Rasted (born Lene Grawford Nystrøm on 2 October 1973), better known by her stage name Lene, is a Norwegian musician and singer-songwriter who is the lead vocalist of the Danish eurodance group Aqua.

title: René Dif
text: René Dif (born 17 October 1967 in Copenhagen, Denmark) is a Danish musician, singer-songwriter, DJ and actor, best known as the male lead vocalist of the Danish eurodance group Aqua.

title: Lollipop (Candyman)
text: "Lollipop (Candyman)" is a song recorded by Danish dance-pop group Aqua.

title: Lollipop (Candyman)
text: It was released as the fourth overall single from their debut album "Aquarium" as the follow-up to their most successful song "Barbie Girl" in Australasia, North America and Mainland Europe (it was not released in the United Kingdom.)

title: Lollipop (Candyman)
text: Although it said to be one of the group's favorite songs, "Lollipop (Candyman)" failed to replicate the success of "Barbie Girl", "Doctor Jones" and "My Oh My" where it was released.

title: Doctor Jones
text: "Doctor Jones" is a song by Danish dance-pop group Aqua.

title: Doctor Jones
text: Released as the band's fifth single overall, it was the follow-up to their most successful song "Barbie Girl" in many regions.

title: Doctor Jones
text: "Doctor Jones" was a similarly pop-oriented hit which sold well across the globe and ended the assumptions that Aqua would be a one-hit wonder; although they would remain so in America as "Barbie Girl" was their only hit there until "Lollipop (Candyman)" was released and hit the top 40 on the Hot 100.

title: Aqua (band)
text: Aqua is a Danish eurodance group, best known for their 1997 breakthrough single "Barbie Girl".

title: Aqua (band)
text: The group formed in 1989 and achieved huge success around the globe in the late 1990s and early 2000s.

title: Aqua (band)
text: The group released three albums: "Aquarium" in 1997, "Aquarius" in 2000 and "Megalomania" in 2011.

title: Aqua (band)
text: The group sold an estimated 33 million albums and singles, making them the most profitable Danish band ever.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: During the tenure of Morrison Waite as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States (March 4, 1874 through March 23, 1888), the Supreme Court heard an unprecedented volume and frequency of criminal cases.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: In just fourteen years, the Court heard 106 criminal cases, almost as many cases as the Supreme Court had heard in the period from its creation to the appointment of Waite as Chief Justice.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: Notable cases include "United States v. Cruikshank" (1875), "United States v. Reese" (1875), "Reynolds v. United States" (1878), "Wilkerson v. Utah" (1879), the "Trade-Mark Cases" (1879), "Strauder v. West Virginia" (1880), "Pace v. Alabama" (1883), "United States v. Harris" (1883), "Ex parte Crow Dog" (1883), "Hurtado v. California" (1884), "Clawson v. United States" (1885), "Yick Wo v. Hopkins" (1886), "United States v. Kagama" (1886), "Ker v. Illinois" (1886), and "Mugler v. Kansas" (1887).

title: Reynolds v. United States
text: Reynolds v. United States, 98 U.S. (8 Otto.)

title: Reynolds v. United States
text: 145 (1878), was a Supreme Court of the United States case that held that religious duty was not a defense to a criminal indictment.

title: Reynolds v. United States
text: "Reynolds" was the first Supreme Court opinion to address the Impartial Jury and the Confrontation Clauses of the Sixth Amendment.

title: Reynolds v. Sims
text: Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533 (1964) was a United States Supreme Court case that ruled that unlike in the election of the United States Senate, in the election of "any" chamber of a state legislature the electoral districts must be roughly equal in population (thus negating the traditional function of a State Senate, which was to allow rural counties to counter balance large towns and cities).

title: Reynolds v. Sims
text: The case was brought on behalf of voters in Alabama by M.O. Sims, a taxpayer in Birmingham, Alabama, but affected both northern and southern states that had similarly failed to reapportion their legislatures in keeping with changes in state population after its application in five companion cases in Colorado, New York, Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware.

title: Reynolds v. Pegler
text: Reynolds v. Pegler, 223 F.2d 429 (2nd Cir.

title: Reynolds v. Pegler
text: 1955), was a landmark libel decision in which Quentin Reynolds successfully sued right-wing columnist Westbrook Pegler, resulting in a record judgment of $175,001.

title: West v. Barnes
text: West v. Barnes, 2 U.S. 401 (1791), was the first United States Supreme Court decision and the earliest case calling for oral argument. "

title: West v. Barnes
text: Van Staphorst v. Maryland" (1791) was docketed prior to "West v. Barnes" but settled before the Court heard the case: "West" was argued on August 2, 1791 and decided on August 3, 1791. "

title: West v. Barnes
text: Collet v. Collet" (1791) was the first appellate case docketed with the Court but was dropped before it could be heard.

title: West v. Barnes
text: Supreme Court Reporter Alexander Dallas did not publish the justices' full opinions in "West v. Barnes", which were published in various newspapers around the country at the time, but he published an abbreviated summary of the decisions.

title: Charles Morgan Jr.
text: Charles "Chuck" Morgan Jr. (March 11, 1930 – January 8, 2009) was an American civil rights attorney from Alabama who played a key role in establishing the principle of "one man, one vote" in the Supreme Court of the United States decision in the 1964 case "Reynolds v. Sims" and represented Julian Bond and Muhammad Ali in their legal battles.

title: Jameel v Wall Street Journal Europe Sprl
text: Jameel v Wall Street Journal Europe was a House of Lords judgment on English defamation law.

title: Jameel v Wall Street Journal Europe Sprl
text: The judgment was an affirmation of "Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd" and effectively upholds a public interest defence in libel cases.

title: Selle v. Gibb
text: Selle v. Gibb, 741 F.2d 896 (7th Cir.

title: Selle v. Gibb
text: 1984) was a landmark ruling on the doctrine of striking similarities.

title: Selle v. Gibb
text: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled that while copying must be proved by access and substantial similarity, where evidence of access does not exist, striking similarities may raise an inference of copying by showing that the work could not have been the result of independent creation, coincidence, or common source.

title: Selle v. Gibb
text: Striking similarity alone is not enough to infer access.

title: Selle v. Gibb
text: The similarity must preclude independent creation in order to infer access.

title: George Reynolds (Mormon)
text: George Reynolds (January 1, 1842 – August 9, 1909) was a general authority of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), a longtime secretary to the First Presidency of the LDS Church, and a party to the 1878 United States Supreme Court case "Reynolds v. United States", the first freedom of religion case to issue from that court.

title: Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd
text: Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd was a House of Lords case in English defamation law concerning qualified privilege for publication of defamatory statements in the public interest.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: Love It or List It Vancouver is a Canadian home design reality TV series airing on the W Network.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: The show was the first spin off from "Love It or List It" and was the second show in the "Love it or List It" franchise.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: The show is produced by Big Coat Productions and is based in the Greater Vancouver area and other surrounding areas in British Columbia, Canada.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: The show premiered as a prime-time program on W Network in January 2013.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: It stars former "The Bachelor" and "The Bachelorette" star Jillian Harris, and real estate agent Todd Talbot.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: In the United States, the show is titled Love It or List It, Too, and airs on the HGTV network.

title: Love It or List It Vancouver
text: In Canada, new episodes of season three started airing on July 6, 2015 on W Network at 10pm; in the US new episodes of "Love It or List It, Too" (the US title, season five) started airing on July 24, 2015.

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe is a 2016 stand alone British Christmas movie based on the Hank Zipzer series of books by Henry Winkler and Lin Oliver and the TV series airing on CBBC.

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: The film will be airing on CBBC on 12 December 2016.

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: It is written by Joe Williams and is directed by Matt Bloom.

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: The film is produced by Kindle Entertainment in association with Walker Productions and DHX Media with support from Screen Yorkshire’s Yorkshire Content Fund.

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: It is the fourth movie based on a CBBC programme after "", "Shaun the Sheep Movie" and "".

title: Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe
text: It is the second movie based on a CBBC show, which has not been released in cinemas and only shown on TV after ""

title: Pakdam Pakdai
text: Pakdam Pakdai, also known internationally as Rat-A-Tat, is an Indian animated comedy TV series airing formerly on Nickelodeon India and currently airing in Sonic Nickelodeon.

title: Pakdam Pakdai
text: It is inspired by "Oggy and the Cockroaches", a French animated series based on the silent and friendly war between a cat, Oggy, and three cockroaches.

title: Pakdam Pakdai
text: The show began in April 2013.

title: I Hate My Kitchen
text: I Hate My Kitchen is a renovation reality television series airing on DIY Network and HGTV Network.

title: I Hate My Kitchen
text: The series began airing sometime in early October 2010.

title: I Hate My Kitchen
text: DIY Network announced a new season, hosted by licensed contractor James Young, starting in October, 2011.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride (仮面ライダーバトル ガンバライド , Kamen Raidā Batoru Ganbaraido , "Masked Rider Battle: Ganbaride") is a combination of an arcade game and a collectible item game featuring the protagonists of the Kamen Rider Series.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: The game is being released as part of the 10th anniversary of the Heisei run Kamen Rider Series by Toei, TV Asahi, Ishimori Productions, and Bandai and features heavy tie-ins with the television series "Kamen Rider Decade", whose protagonists use cards similar to those used in the game.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: It is played in a similar fashion to Sega's "" and "Dinosaur King" games, and uses special Data Cardass cards released by Bandai.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: The game's card input uses collectible card game terminologies, and has resemblance and functionality similarly to the Decadriver in "Decade".

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: As the series progresses, the game controls change to suit the new Kamen Rider.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: During the airing of "Kamen Rider OOO", "Ganbaride" arcade systems included an OOO Driver interface for the toy Core Medals, and with the broadcast of "Kamen Rider Fourze", slots for the Astro Switches became available, and the system became 3 VS. 3.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: With the current broadcast of "Kamen Rider Wizard", Wizard Rings are available to use, and the game has reverted to 2 VS. 2 battles.

title: Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride
text: Ever since "Kamen Rider Gaim"'s TV series airing until onwards, the game is now renamed to Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbarizing (仮面ライダーバトル ガンバライジング , Kamen Raidā Batoru Ganbaraizingu , "Masked Rider Battle: Ganbarizing") .

title: Cool Center
text: Cool Center is a Philippine live comedy talk show TV series airing on GMA Network starting from March 14, 2009.

title: Cool Center
text: Cool Center is hosted by Eugene Domingo and Anjo Yllana and serves as a replacement for Nuts Entertainment.

title: Cool Center
text: Due to Anjo Yllana's vice-mayoral's run for local elections, Eugene Domingo was given a new project Comedy Bar with Allan K. and Fabio Ide—it replaced this show which made its finale on April 17, 2010.

title: Mamie Gummer
text: Mary Willa "Mamie" Gummer (born August 3, 1983) is an American actress.

title: Mamie Gummer
text: She starred in the title role of The CW series "Emily Owens, M.D." (2012–13), and played the recurring role of Nancy Crozier on "The Good Wife" (2010–15).

title: Mamie Gummer
text: She has also appeared in the films "Evening" (2007), "Side Effects" (2013), "Cake" (2014), and "Ricki and the Flash" (2015).

title: Mamie Gummer
text: She was nominated for the 2016 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Play for the original production of "Ugly Lies the Bone".

title: Burt Gummer
text: Burt Gummer is a fictional character, played by actor Michael Gross, from the "Tremors" film series and the short lived SciFi Channel TV program of the same name.

title: Burt Gummer
text: Appearing in "Tremors", "", "", "", and most episodes of the TV series, Burt Gummer is a firearms enthusiast and a paranoid survivalist.

title: Burt Gummer
text: He and his former wife, Heather Gummer (played by Reba McEntire), were the first persons in the film series to directly kill a Graboid.

title: Burt Gummer
text: He has an "overkill" approach to trouble and takes himself deadly seriously.

title: Burt Gummer
text: Although he is only the central character in "Tremors 3" and the TV series, his eccentric personality has made him a favorite among Tremors fans and the de facto star of the franchise, along with the vicious Graboids who oppose him.

title: Burt Gummer
text: His ancestor, Hiram Gummer (also played by Gross), appears in "".

title: Burt Gummer
text: He finds out he has a son Travis B. Welker in Tremors 5 who is the son of the girlfriend he had before he married Heather.

title: The Lightkeepers
text: The Lightkeepers is a 2009 romantic comedy film written and directed by Daniel Adams, and stars Richard Dreyfuss, Blythe Danner, Mamie Gummer, Tom Wisdom and Julie Harris in her final film role.

title: The Lightkeepers
text: Zana Messia wrote the film's theme song.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: The Voice Kids: Ahla Sawt (meaning Best Voice), is an Arabic TV Series airing on MBC 1.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: It premiered on January 2, 2016.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: The three judges for the inaugural season were Tamer Hosny, Nancy Ajram and Kadhim Al-Sahir.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: There are four stages starting with the Blind Auditions.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: Contestants sing without being seen by the judges.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: If a coach likes the contestant's performance, they turn their chair.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: Each coach is allowed to have 15 contestants on their team.

title: The Voice Kids (Arabic TV series)
text: The season 1 finale was on March 5, 2016 and the winning contestant was Lynn Hayek from Lebanon from Team Kadim Al-Sahir.

title: Lahore Qalandars in 2016
text: The Lahore Qalandars is a franchise cricket team that represents Lahore in the Pakistan Super League.

title: Lahore Qalandars in 2016
text: They are one of the five teams that had a competition in the 2016 Pakistan Super League.

title: Lahore Qalandars in 2016
text: The team was captained by Azhar Ali, and they stand on fifth position after winning just two matches from their eight matches in the PSL 2016, as a result they were eliminated in group stage.

title: Lahore Qalandars in 2016
text: Umar Akmal with 335 runs in 7 matches was leading run scorer of the tournament.

title: Kamran Rasheed
text: Kamran Rasheed Khan (born 1949) is a Pakistani American first-class cricketer as well cricket administrator who played for United States of America national cricket team from 1979 to 1990 as well as played domestic cricket for Lahore cricket team, Pakistan Railways cricket team, Punjab University cricket team from 1964/65 to 1970/71 as a wicket-keeper.

title: Kamran Rasheed
text: He was also the President of United States of America Cricket Association for brief period of time 1999 to 2000.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: Zulqarnain Haider (Urdu: ‎ , born 23 April 1986 in Lahore) is Pakistani cricketer who has played for his national team.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: Having played for Pakistan Under-19s, Haider was called up to the senior national side in 2010 as cover for wicket-keeper Kamran Akmal during their tour of England.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: Haider made his Test debut during the tour, but a broken finger limited him to one match.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: Later that year he made his One Day International (ODI) debut against South Africa, against whom he has played all four of his ODIs to date.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: After the fourth match Haider fled to London amid fears for his safety.

title: Zulqarnain Haider
text: A right-handed batsman, Haider has represented both Lahore Blues and Pakistan Telecommunication Company Limited in Pakistani domestic cricket, and now plays for Zarai Taraqiati Bank Ltd.

title: Mohammad Salman (cricketer, born 1981)
text: Mohammad Salman (born 7 August 1981, Karachi) is an international cricketer from Pakistan.

title: Mohammad Salman (cricketer, born 1981)
text: He is a right handed batsman and a wicketkeeper.

title: Mohammad Salman (cricketer, born 1981)
text: He was brought in as a replacement for Kamran Akmal.

title: Umar Akmal
text: Umar Akmal (Urdu: ‎ ; born 26 May 1990) is a Pakistani cricketer.

title: Umar Akmal
text: He made his ODI debut on 1 August 2009 against Sri Lanka and made his Test debut against New Zealand on 23 November 2009.

title: Umar Akmal
text: He is a right-handed batsman and a part-time spinner.

title: Umar Akmal
text: Like his two brothers, Adnan and Kamran, Umar has kept wicket for the national team any many ODIs.

title: Umar Akmal
text: His wife name is noor Fatima.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: Kamran Akmal (Urdu: ‎ ; born 13 January 1982) is a Pakistani cricketer.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: His brothers are Adnan Akmal and Umar Akmal, who are also professional cricketers, the former being a keeper-batsman and the latter being a specialist batsman as well as part-time wicket-keeper.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: He married in 2006 and lives with his wife, Aiza, their daughter, Laiba, and their son Ayyan.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: He is a graduate of Beaconhouse School System Garden Town, Lahore.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: He is a right-handed wicket-keeper-batsman who has played Tests, ODIs and T20Is for Pakistan.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: He started his international career in November 2002 with a Test match which Pakistan won at Harare Sports Club.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: He has made 2648 runs in 53 Test matches with the help of six centuries, while in 137 ODIs, he has scored 2924 runs with the help of five centuries.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: In T20Is, he has scored 704 runs.

title: Kamran Akmal
text: As a wicket-keeper, he has dismissed 206, 169 and 52 batsmen in Tests, ODIs and T20Is respectively.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: 999 (read in Malay as "sembilan sembilan sembilan") is a Malaysian investigative reality television series show (similar to "COPS" in the United States); which focusing to crimes in the country.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: The show has aired on TV3 since 2004 and has aired every Tuesday at 9:00 pm since January 2014.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: Previously it aired every Thursday at 9:00 pm since it first aired.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: The current host as of 2014 is Hazlin Hussain.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: Former hosts of the show were Zakiah Anas, Mazidul Akmal Sidek, Halim Din and Omar Abdullah.

title: 999 (Malaysian TV series)
text: In its first year, it was one of Malaysia's most watched TV programmes with audiences of over 3 million.

title: 2013 East Africa Premier League
text: The 2013 East Africa Premier League was the third edition of Cricket Kenya's East Africa Premier League competitions.

title: 2013 East Africa Premier League
text: The competition took place at the Nairobi Club Ground and Simba Union Club Ground from the 7th to 11 August 2013.

title: 2013 East Africa Premier League
text: It featured several significant changes from the first two editions, including the massive overhaul of the identities of the Kenyan franchises participating as well as the participation of several high-profile Pakistani cricketers suck as Kamran Akmal and Imran Nazir.

title: 2013 East Africa Premier League
text: The tournament was won by Rising Stars Chuis who defeated Ruwenzori Warriors by 9 wickets in the final.

title: Imran Ali (cricketer, born 1985)
text: Imran Ali (born 14 August 1985) is a Pakistani cricketer who played a single List A match for the Multan Tigers during the 2012–13 season.

title: Imran Ali (cricketer, born 1985)
text: From Sahiwal, Punjab, little else is known of Imran's life.

title: Imran Ali (cricketer, born 1985)
text: A fast bowler, he played his sole match for Multan in the 2012–13 edition of the Faysal Bank One-Day Cup, against the Lahore Eagles.

title: Imran Ali (cricketer, born 1985)
text: In the match, played at the Multan Cricket Stadium in March 2013, Imran took the wicket of the Eagles' captain, Adnan Akmal, in Lahore's innings, finishing with 1/28 from his nine overs, including two maidens.

title: Adnan Akmal
text: Adnan Akmal (Urdu: ‎ ), born 13 March 1985, is a Pakistani cricketer.

title: Adnan Akmal
text: He is a right-handed batsman and wicket-keeper who plays for Zarai Taraqiati Bank Ltd Cricket Team and has represented his country at U-17 level.

title: Adnan Akmal
text: Most recently, he was called up for Pakistan's tour against South Africa in the UAE, as a replacement for the first choice keeper, Zulqarnain Haider.

title: Adnan Akmal
text: His brothers, Kamran Akmal and Umar Akmal, both have central contracts with the Pakistan Cricket Board, and are regular fixtures in the national side.

title: Adnan Akmal
text: Adnan made his Test debut against South Africa on 12 November 2010.

title: The Four Seasons (band)
text: The Four Seasons is an American rock and pop band that became internationally successful in the 1960s and 1970s.

title: The Four Seasons (band)
text: The Vocal Group Hall of Fame has stated that the group was the most popular rock band before the Beatles.

title: The Four Seasons (band)
text: Since 1970, they have also been known at times as Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons.

title: The Four Seasons (band)
text: In 1960, the group known as the Four Lovers evolved into the Four Seasons, with Frankie Valli as the lead singer, Bob Gaudio (formerly of the Royal Teens) on keyboards and tenor vocals, Tommy DeVito on lead guitar and baritone vocals, and Nick Massi on electric bass and bass vocals.

title: The Proud One
text: "The Proud One" is a 1966 single written by Bob Gaudio and Bob Crewe and originally performed by Frankie Valli and The Four Seasons, and credited to Valli solo; that version peaked at #68.

title: Can't Take My Eyes Off You
text: "Can't Take My Eyes Off You" is a 1967 single credited to Frankie Valli.

title: Can't Take My Eyes Off You
text: The song was among his biggest hits, earning a gold record and reaching No. 2 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 for a week, stuck behind "Windy" by The Association.

title: Can't Take My Eyes Off You
text: It was co-written by Bob Gaudio, a bandmate of Valli's in The Four Seasons.

title: Can't Take My Eyes Off You
text: It was Valli's biggest solo hit until he hit #1 in 1974 with "My Eyes Adored You".

title: Bobby Fox
text: Bobby Fox is an Irish born Australian actor who originated the role of Franki Valli in the Australian production of "Jersey Boys".

title: Bobby Fox
text: He is a former 4 times World Irish Dance Champion and toured with dance productions "Riverdance", "Dancing on Dangerous Ground" (principal understudy), "To Dance on the Moon" (principal dancer) and starred in the revival of Australian musical "Hot Shoe Shuffle" as Spring.

title: Bobby Fox
text: Fox has also had roles in "Ladies in Black", "Blood Brothers", "Mamma Mia!

title: Bobby Fox
text: ", "Leader of the Pack", "Dusty – The Original Pop Diva", "We Will Rock You", "Spamalot" and The Production Company’s "Sweet Charity" and "Damn Yankees".

title: Dean Valli
text: Dean Valli (born October 5, 1983 in North Vancouver, British Columbia) is an offensive lineman with the Canadian Football League's British Columbia Lions.

title: Dean Valli
text: Valli attended Simon Fraser University and played for their football team, the Simon Fraser Clan.

title: Dean Valli
text: He played four full seasons with the Clan from 2002 to 2005.

title: Dean Valli
text: Dean graduated with a bachelor of arts from Simon Fraser University in 2006.

title: Dean Valli
text: In 2005, Valli was named to the Canada West Universities Athletic Association all-star team.

title: Dean Valli
text: He also represented SFU at the 2005 East West Bowl held in Waterloo, Ontario.

title: Dean Valli
text: Valli was selected in the 1st round, 6th overall, by the Lions in the 2006 CFL draft.

title: Dean Valli
text: 2006 was his first year playing professional football.

title: Valli (album)
text: Valli was the sixth solo LP album by Frankie Valli of The Four Seasons, released by Private Stock under catalog number PS-2017 as a stereo recording in 1976.

title: Valli (album)
text: It was reissued on compact disc in 2008, paired with his first solo effort from Private Stock, "Close Up", by Collector's Choice.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: "My Eyes Adored You" is a 1974 song written by Bob Crewe and Kenny Nolan.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: It was originally recorded by The Four Seasons in early 1974.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: After the Motown label balked at the idea of releasing it, the recording was sold to lead singer Frankie Valli for $4000.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: After rejections by Capitol and Atlantic Records, Valli succeeded in getting the recording released on Private Stock Records, but the owner/founder of the label wanted only Valli's name on the label.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: The single was released in the US in November 1974 and topped the "Billboard" Hot 100 in March 1975.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: "My Eyes Adored You" also went to number 2 on the Easy Listening chart.

title: My Eyes Adored You
text: "Billboard" ranked it as the No. 5 song for 1975.

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording is the Grammy-winning cast album for the Broadway musical "Jersey Boys", the story of Frankie Valli and The Four Seasons.

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: The album was produced by original Four Season, Bob Gaudio.

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: Principal vocals include Christian Hoff as "Tommy DeVito," Daniel Reichard as "Bob Gaudio," J. Robert Spencer as "Nick Massi" and John Lloyd Young as lead-singer "Frankie Valli."

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: It was released November 1, 2005 by Rhino Entertainment and reached number eighty-five on the "Billboard" 200.

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: In February 2008, the album was certified Gold by the RIAA.

title: Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording
text: As of December 2014, the album has sold 1.4 million copies in the US.

title: Roy Roman
text: Roy Roman is a high note trumpet player who has performed lead with Lionel Hampton, the Benny Goodman Orchestra, Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Bob Hope, Sammy Davis, Jr. and Franki Valli, among others.

title: Roy Roman
text: Roman began playing the trumpet at age 19.

title: Roy Roman
text: After an injury to one of his front teeth, he was introduced to Roy Stevens, the teacher of a scientific method of embouchure development pioneered by William Costello.

title: Roy Roman
text: Today, Roman is the world's leading expert on the Stevens/Costello Method, a technique that allows the player to increase range, endurance and control.

title: The Wonder Who?
text: The Wonder Who?

title: The Wonder Who?
text: was a "nom de disque" of The Four Seasons for four single records released from 1965 to 1967.

title: The Wonder Who?
text: It was one of a handful of "names" used by the group at that time, including Frankie Valli (as a "solo" artist even though the Four Seasons were present on the record) and The Valli Boys.

title: The Wonder Who?
text: Wonder Who?

title: The Wonder Who?
text: recordings generally feature the falsetto singing by Valli, but with a softer falsetto than on "typical" Four Seasons recordings.

title: Brintonia
text: Brintonia is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the sunflower family, containing the single species Brintonia discoidea.

title: Brintonia
text: It is known commonly as the rayless mock goldenrod.

title: Brintonia
text: It is native to the southeastern United States, where it is distributed in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, and Mississippi.

title: Solidago curtisii
text: Solidago curtisii, commonly called Curtis' goldenrod and mountain decumbent goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago curtisii
text: It is the eastern part of the United States from Pennsylvania to Mississippi and Alabama, primarily in the southern Appalachian Mountains.

title: Solidago ouachitensis
text: Solidago ouachitensis is a North American species of flowering plants in the aster family known by the common name Ouachita Mountain goldenrod.

title: Solidago ouachitensis
text: It has a very limited range, found only in the Ouachita Mountains along the border between Arkansas and Oklahoma in the United States.

title: Solidago rupestris
text: Solidago rupestris , the rock goldenrod or riverbank goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago rupestris
text: It is found in the eastern United States, found today in the States of Maryland, Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee.

title: Solidago rupestris
text: There are historical records of it formerly growing in Indiana and Pennsylvania as well, but these populations now appear to have been extirpated.

title: Solidago uliginosa
text: Solidago uliginosa, or bog goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago uliginosa
text: It is found in eastern Canada (from Nunavut to Newfoundland and Manitoba) and the eastern United States (Great Lakes, Northeast, and Appalachian Mountains as far south as northeastern Georgia.

title: Solidago uliginosa
text: There are historical reports of the species growing in Alabama, but these populations appear now to have been extirpated).

title: Bigelowia nudata
text: Bigelowia nudata (pineland rayless goldenrod) is a species of North American flowering plants in the daisy family, native to the coastal plain of the southeastern United States (from eastern Louisiana to North Carolina).

title: Solidago rugosa
text: Solidago rugosa, the wrinkleleaf goldenrod or rough-stemmed goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago rugosa
text: It is widespread across eastern and central Canada (from Newfoundland to Ontario) and the eastern and central United States (Maine west as far as Wisconsin and Iowa, south to Florida and Texas).

title: Bigelowia nuttallii
text: Bigelowia nuttallii (Nuttall's rayless goldenrod) is a species of North American flowering plants in the daisy family, native to the southern United States (Texas, Louisiana, Alabama, Georgia, and Florida).

title: Solidago elongata
text: Solidago elongata, commonly called West Coast Canada goldenrod or Cascade Canada goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago elongata
text: It is native to western Canada, western United States, and northwestern Mexico, primarily in British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, California, and Baja California, with a few populations in Nevada and Idaho.

title: Solidago elongata
text: It grows in the Coast Ranges, the Sierra Nevada, the Cascades, and other mountain ranges in the region.

title: Solidago speciosa
text: Solidago speciosa, the showy goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family.

title: Solidago speciosa
text: It grows in the province of Ontario in central Canada, as well as in the eastern and central United States (from the Atlantic coast west as far as the Great Plains, so from Maine to Georgia (except Delaware) west as far as Texas, Nebraska, and the Dakotas).

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: The 2016 Kansas City Royals season was the 48th for the franchise, and their 44th at Kauffman Stadium.

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Royals entered the season as the defending World Series champions determined to become the first team since the 1999 New York Yankees to win back-to-back World Series titles.

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: The season started on April 3 with a World Series rematch at home against the New York Mets.

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: The first series began with a 10 mile long relay of the first pitch from Kansas City Union Station to Kauffman Stadium benefiting the Kansas City MLB Urban Youth Academy.

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Royals were eliminated from postseason contention with one game yet to play, marking four straight World Series champions that missed the playoffs the following year.

title: 2016 Kansas City Royals season
text: They finished the season with an 81–81 record and third place in the division.

title: 2017 Kansas City Royals season
text: The 2017 Kansas City Royals season was the 49th season for the franchise, and their 45th at Kauffman Stadium.

title: 2017 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Royals opened the season at the Minnesota Twins on April 3, 2017 and finished the season at home against the Arizona Diamondbacks on October 1.

title: Truman Sports Complex
text: The Harry S. Truman Sports Complex is a sports and entertainment facility located in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: Truman Sports Complex
text: It is home to two major sports venues: Arrowhead Stadium—home of the National Football League's Kansas City Chiefs, and Kauffman Stadium—home of Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals.

title: Truman Sports Complex
text: The complex also hosts various other events during the year.

title: 2009 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Kansas City Royals' 2009 season began on April 7 with a game against the Chicago White Sox at U. S. Cellular Field, which Chicago won.

title: 2009 Kansas City Royals season
text: On April 10, the Royals hosted the New York Yankees in the first game at the newly renovated Kauffman Stadium for the Royals' home opener.

title: 2009 Kansas City Royals season
text: Interleague opponents included the St. Louis Cardinals, Arizona Diamondbacks, Cincinnati Reds, Houston Astros and Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Charles Deaton
text: Charles Utter Deaton (January 1, 1921 – December 18, 1996) was an American architect.

title: Charles Deaton
text: He designed several athletic stadiums, and is noted for his futuristic Sculptured House that was featured in the 1973 film "Sleeper".

title: Charles Deaton
text: He is also noted as the designer of Kansas City's Arrowhead Stadium and Kauffman Stadium.

title: Arrowhead Stadium
text: Arrowhead Stadium is a football stadium in Kansas City, Missouri, United States, that primarily serves as the home venue of the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Arrowhead Stadium
text: It is part of the Truman Sports Complex with adjacent Kauffman Stadium, the home of the Kansas City Royals of Major League Baseball (MLB).

title: Arrowhead Stadium
text: Arrowhead has a seating capacity of 76,416, making it the 28th largest stadium in North America and sixth largest NFL stadium.

title: Arrowhead Stadium
text: It is also the largest sports facility by capacity in the state of Missouri.

title: Arrowhead Stadium
text: A $375 million renovation was completed in 2010.

title: 2012 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Kansas City Royals' season of 2012 was the 44th for the Royals franchise.

title: 2012 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Royals hosted the 83rd MLB All-Star Game on July 10 at Kauffman Stadium, where the team played its 40th season of home games.

title: 2012 Kansas City Royals season
text: The Royals finished 72-90, 3rd place in the AL Central.

title: 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
text: The 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game was the 83rd edition of the Major League Baseball All-Star Game.

title: 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
text: It was held on July 10, 2012, during the 2012 Major League Baseball season at Kauffman Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri, home of the Kansas City Royals.

title: 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
text: This marked the third time the Mid-summer Classic had been played in Kansas City, with Kauffman Stadium (then named Royals Stadium) last hosting the event in 1973, the stadium's first year of existence.

title: 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
text: The event was also held at Municipal Stadium in 1960, when the Athletics were still based there, one of two played that season.

title: 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star Game
text: The game was televised in the United States by Fox.

title: Kauffman Stadium
text: Kauffman Stadium ( ), often called "The K", is a baseball park located in Kansas City, Missouri, that is home to the Kansas City Royals of Major League Baseball (MLB).

title: Kauffman Stadium
text: It is part of the Truman Sports Complex together with the adjacent Arrowhead Stadium, home of the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League.

title: Kauffman Stadium
text: The ballpark is named for Ewing Kauffman, the founder and first owner of the Royals.

title: Kauffman Stadium
text: It opened in 1973 as Royals Stadium and was named for Kauffman on July 2, 1993.

title: Kauffman Stadium
text: The ballpark's listed seating capacity since 2009 is 37,903.

title: Sculptured House
text: The Sculptured House, also known as the Sleeper House, is a distinctive elliptical curved house built on Genesee Mountain in 1963 by architect Charles Deaton.

title: Sculptured House
text: It is featured prominently in the 1973 Woody Allen sci-fi comedy "Sleeper".

title: 4 Tune Kookies
text: 4 Tune Kookies is an Indian classic-rock band formed about thirty-five years ago (as ‘People’).

title: 4 Tune Kookies
text: The band was started in the 1970s when the band culture was fairly unknown in India.

title: 4 Tune Kookies
text: The band comprises Babu(Saiprasad)Choudhary - (lead guitarist), Hosi Nanji (bass guitarist), Ranjit Barot (former drummer), Derick Gomes (current drummer) and Ronnie Desai (vocalist, rhythm guitarist and song writer)

title: Patrick Johansson (musician)
text: Patrick Johansson (born March 29, 1976 in Falun, Sweden) is a Swedish drummer and the current drummer for Yngwie Malmsteen.

title: Patrick Johansson (musician)
text: In the past he has played and toured with many bands, including Without Grief, Stormwind, W.A.S.P., Spelled Moon and G3.

title: Patrick Johansson (musician)
text: Johansson currently resides in West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Patrick Johansson (musician)
text: He recently played a few gigs with Sabaton while their drummer Daniel Mullback recovered from a knee injury.

title: Patrick Johansson (musician)
text: His favorite band is Kiss, and he has tattoos of all 4 original band members.

title: Mat Madiro

title: Kent Stax
text: Kent Stax is the original and current drummer of the DC hardcore punk band Scream, considered, with perhaps the exception of Minor Threat (both of these bands recorded on the now famous underground Dischord Records label), one of the most influential and successful hardcore punk band to emerge from the music movement which thrived during the 1980s.

title: Kent Stax
text: Along with brothers Franz and Peter Stahl and bassist Skeeter Thompson, Stax helped create the lightning-fast tempo that was a trademark of the punk rock genre.

title: Kent Stax
text: Considered one of the fastest and most energetic drummers in the field at that time, his talents lent themselves to keeping a thrashing powerful musical force under control, giving Scream its homegrown reputation as pioneers in the genre which transcended into some international notoriety.

title: Kent Stax
text: In the late eighties Stax left the band for personal reasons and David Grohl, a local drummer who was working with local band Dain Bramage replaced the longtime drummer.

title: Kent Stax
text: Stax played drums in a series of bands throughout the 1990s that drew influence from English punk and Oi music, most notably The Suspects (a band that had many muttering about a DC hardcore revival not seen since 1983) United 121 and Spitfires United.

title: Kent Stax
text: In the 2000s he played drums in the DC Oi-core band Alleged Bricks.

title: Mark Castillo
text: Mark Castillo, (born October 10, 1980) is an American musician.

title: Mark Castillo
text: He is a former drummer of the deathcore band Emmure, a former drummer of the hard rock band Crossfade, a former drummer of the progressive metal band Between the Buried and Me, and a founding member and current drummer of American metalcore band Bury Your Dead.

title: The Unguided
text: The Unguided is a melodic death metal band from Sweden, formed by Richard Sjunnesson, after his departure from Sonic Syndicate.

title: The Unguided
text: Later, he was joined by (also former Sonic Syndicate singer) Roland Johansson, and (then) Sonic Syndicate guitarist Roger Sjunnesson and drummer John Bengtsson and current Cipher System bassist Henric Liljesand.

title: The Unguided
text: Drummer John Bengtsson left the band and in late 2012 The Unguided found their current drummer, Richard Schill.

title: The Unguided
text: In December 2016, the band revealed that vocalist/guitarist Roland Johansson had left the band and they found their current vocalist/guitarist, former touring member Jonathan Thorpenberg.

title: Timothy "Yogi" Watts
text: Timothy "Yogi" Watts is second and current drummer for the Christian Metal band, Demon Hunter.

title: Timothy "Yogi" Watts
text: He was the fourth drummer for The Showdown, original drummer for The Lonely Hearts (originally named Holland), and fill-in drummer for Throwdown as well as The Becoming.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: Raimund Emmanuel Parcon Marasigan, (born May 22, 1971) or simply known as Raimund Marasigan, is a Rock musician and record producer in the Philippines.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: Often, his first name is misspelled as "Raymond", "Raymund", "Raimond" and other variants.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: The breadth of his projects has made him one of the most well-respected mainstays of the Philippine rock band scene.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: He was the drummer, vocalist and lyricist alongside bandmate Ely Buendia of The Eraserheads, and the current keyboard/synths player for Pedicab, former rhythm guitarist and now frontman of Sandwich, current drummer of Cambio, vocalist of Project 1 and the man behind Squid 9.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: Currently, he holds bass for his newest band, Gaijin.

title: Raimund Marasigan
text: Aside from writing songs and being a musician, he is also a record producer, voice actor, TV host and product endorser.

title: Hans Orifice
text: Hans Orifice is a drummer best known as a member of Gwar.

title: Hans Orifice
text: Born Jim Thomson, in Alexandria, Virginia, he first took the name Hans Sphincter, and assumed his current name in 1987.

title: Hans Orifice
text: Thomson left due to touring commitments with his main band, the Alter Natives, who released three albums on SST Records.

title: Hans Orifice
text: Richmond drummer Rob Mosby of the Richmond, Virginia punk group White Cross then joined Gwar until 1989.

title: Hans Orifice
text: Hans Orifice returned briefly in 1989 after Mosby left the group.

title: Hans Orifice
text: During this time Thomson co-wrote "Sick of You" with the band and completed a U.S. and Canadian tour.

title: Hans Orifice
text: After the tour Thomson left Gwar on good terms to tour with The Alter Natives.

title: Hans Orifice
text: He was replaced by current drummer Jizmak Da Gusha.

title: Peter Morén (drummer)
text: Peter Morén (born in Gävle, Sweden) is the current drummer of the bands Tad Morose, Steel Attack and Inmoria.

title: Peter Morén (drummer)
text: Peter is perhaps most known as being the drummer for the metal band Tad Morose.

title: Peter Morén (drummer)
text: In the summer of 1994 that band asked Peter to join, and he did.

title: Peter Morén (drummer)
text: Therefore he left his at that time current band called Bedtime Circus, which pretty early after that was disbanded.

title: Peter Morén (drummer)
text: Peter's first recording with Tad Morose was with their album "Sender of Thoughts" in 1994, and he has since then been the band's drummer.

title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse
text: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse is a 2015 American horror comedy film directed by Christopher B. Landon and written by Landon, Carrie Evans, Emi Mochizuki and Lona Williams.

title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse
text: The film stars Tye Sheridan, Logan Miller, Joey Morgan, Sarah Dumont and David Koechner.

title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse
text: The film was released on October 30, 2015 by Paramount Pictures.

title: Jessica Rothe
text: Jessica Rothe (born Jessica Rothenberg, May 28, 1987) is an American actress.

title: Jessica Rothe
text: She stars in the upcoming 2017 film "Happy Death Day".

title: Jessica Rothe
text: She appeared in 2016's "La La Land", .

title: Forever My Girl
text: Forever My Girl is a 2017 romance film starring Alex Roe, Jessica Rothe, John Benjamin Hickey, and directed by Bethany Ashton Wolf.

title: Forever My Girl
text: It is due for release in October 2017.

title: Happy Death Day
text: Happy Death Day is an upcoming American slasher film directed by Christopher B. Landon and written by Scott Lobdell.

title: Happy Death Day
text: It stars Jessica Rothe and Israel Broussard.

title: Happy Death Day
text: The film was produced by Jason Blum through his Blumhouse Productions banner.

title: My Bloody Valentine 3D
text: My Bloody Valentine 3D is a 2009 American slasher film.

title: My Bloody Valentine 3D
text: It is a reboot of the 1981 Canadian slasher film of the same name.

title: My Bloody Valentine 3D
text: The film was directed and edited by Patrick Lussier, and stars Jensen Ackles, Jaime King, Betsy Rue, and Kerr Smith.

title: My Bloody Valentine 3D
text: The film had a 3D theatrical release; it was released on January 16, 2009 by Lionsgate to generally mixed reviews but nevertheless a box office success.

title: My Bloody Valentine 3D
text: It was released on DVD and Blu-ray on May 19, 2009.

title: Fatal Games
text: Fatal Games (originally known as The Killing Touch and also released as Olympic Nightmare) is a 1984 American slasher film written and directed by Michael Elliott and starring Sally Kirkland, Lynn Banashek, Sean Masterson, Michael O'Leary, Teal Roberts, and Spice Williams-Crosby.

title: Fatal Games
text: The plot consists of a mad slasher wielding a javelin killing off various members of a high school gymnastics team.

title: Fatal Games
text: The film shares many of its plot points with an earlier slasher film, "Graduation Day".

title: Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones
text: Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones is a 2014 American found footage supernatural horror film written and directed by Christopher B. Landon.

title: Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones
text: Released on January 3, 2014 in the United States, it is the spin-off film of the "Paranormal Activity" film series.

title: Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones
text: It is also Landon's second directorial film, after "Burning Palms".

title: The Preppie Connection
text: The Preppie Connection is a 2015 American-French crime drama film written and directed by Joseph Castelo and based on the infamous 1984 incident where Choate Rosemary Hall student Derek Oatis, along with a handful of friends, ran a cocaine smuggling operation on the school's campus.

title: The Preppie Connection
text: The film stars Thomas Mann, Lucy Fry, Sam Page, Bill Sage, Jessica Rothe.

title: The Preppie Connection
text: The film had world premiere at the Hamptons International Film Festival on October 10, 2015.

title: The Preppie Connection
text: The film was released on March 18, 2016, in a limited release, and through video on demand by IFC Films.

title: Parallels (film)
text: Parallels is a 2015 American science-fiction adventure film, originally conceived as a television pilot, derived from a story by Christopher Leone and Laura Harkcom.

title: Parallels (film)
text: Mark Hapka, Jessica Rothe, Eric Jungmann, and Constance Wu star as people who are thrown into alternate Earths that range from subtly different to post-apocalyptic.

title: Parallels (film)
text: It was released in March 2015 on the Netflix streaming service.

title: Parallels (film)
text: It was announced on November 16, 2016 that Neil Gaiman would be collaborating with Christopher Leone and Albert Kim to adapt the teaser / trailer movie into a TV series, titled "The Building".

title: Savage Weekend
text: Savage Weekend is a 1979 American slasher film directed by David Paulsen and starring Christopher Allport, David Gale, William Sanderson, and Caitlin O'Heaney.

title: Savage Weekend
text: The film follows a woman who retreats to upstate New York with her wealthy boyfriend, her sister, and friend, only to be stalked by a killer in a disfigured mask.

title: Savage Weekend
text: Filmed in 1976 as "The Killer Behind the Mask", the film was also titled "The Upstate Murders" before being released in 1979 by Cannon Films.

title: Savage Weekend
text: It has been cited as an early prototype for the slasher film, predating "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th".

title: Leader of Sinn Féin
text: The leader of Sinn Féin (alternatively known as the "Uachtarán Shinn Féin" or "President of Sinn Féin") is the most senior politician within the Sinn Féin political party in Ireland.

title: Leader of Sinn Féin
text: Since 13 November 1983, the office has been held by Gerry Adams, following the resignation of Ruairí Ó Brádaigh as leader of the party.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: The 1916 Republican National Convention was held in Chicago from June 7 to June 10.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: A major goal of the party's bosses at the convention was to heal the bitter split within the party that had occurred in the 1912 presidential campaign.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: In that year, Theodore Roosevelt bolted the GOP and formed his own political party, the Progressive Party, which contained most of the GOP's liberals.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: William Howard Taft, the incumbent president, won the nomination of the regular Republican Party.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: This split in the GOP ranks divided the Republican vote and led to the election of Democrat Woodrow Wilson.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: Although several candidates were openly competing for the 1916 nomination—most prominently conservative Senator Elihu Root of New York, Senator John W. Weeks of Massachusetts, and liberal Senator Albert Cummins of Iowa—the party's bosses wanted a moderate who would be acceptable to all factions of the party.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: They turned to Supreme Court Justice Charles Evans Hughes, who had served on the court since 1910 and thus had the advantage of not having publicly spoken about political issues in six years.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: Although he had not sought the nomination, Hughes made it known that he would not turn it down; he won the nomination on the third ballot.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: Former Vice-President Charles W. Fairbanks was nominated as his running mate.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: Hughes was the only Supreme Court Justice to be nominated for president by a major political party.

title: 1916 Republican National Convention
text: Fairbanks (as of 2016) was the last former vice president, to be nominated for vice president.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: The Iraqi National Dialogue Council is a Sunni Islamist political party initially established as an umbrella organization of approximately ten smaller Sunni parties to take part in the 2005 Iraqi Constitution drafting process.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: The party was founded by Saleh al-Mutlaq and Khalaf al-Ulayyan.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: During the Iraqi Constitution drafting negotiations in 2005, the party was advised by Sadoun al-Zubaydi, an Iraqi foreign policy expert and former personal translator to Saddam Hussein.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: In the lead-up to the December 2005 elections, Mutlaq left the National Dialogue Council and formed his own party and gave it a similar name: the Iraqi National Dialogue Front.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: 'Ulayan now leads the party, which is the smallest of three parties that compose the Iraqi Accord Front ("Tawafuq") coalition.

title: Iraqi National Dialogue Council
text: The parties which compose the organisation originate from Iraq's wider Arab populated region.

title: Sinn Féin Front Bench
text: Sinn Féin is the third-largest political party in the Oireachtas.

title: Sinn Féin Front Bench
text: The Sinn Féin leader appoints a team of TDs and Senators to speak for the party on different issues.

title: Sinn Féin Front Bench
text: Their areas of responsibility broadly correspond to those of Government ministers.

title: Republican Sinn Féin
text: Republican Sinn Féin or RSF (Irish: "Sinn Féin Poblachtach" ) is an Irish republican political party in Ireland.

title: Republican Sinn Féin
text: RSF claims to be heirs of the Sinn Féin party founded in 1905 and took its present form in 1986 following a split in Sinn Féin.

title: Republican Sinn Féin
text: RSF members take seats when elected to local Irish councils but do not recognise the validity of the partition of Ireland and subsequently the legitimacy of the Northern Ireland (Stormont) or Republic of Ireland (Leinster House) parliaments, so the party does not register itself with them.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The Unity Party (Ossetian: Иудзинад , Georgian: ერთიანობის , Russian: Единство ; officially, the South Ossetian Republican Political Party "Unity") is a major political party with a socially conservative ideology in South Ossetia, a partially recognized Caucasian republic, considered by most countries to be a part of Georgia.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The Unity Party, founded in 2003, supported former President Eduard Kokoity, and was for a decade the largest political party in South Ossetia.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: After the 2009 elections, the party held 17 out of 34 seats in South Ossetia's parliament.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: It is modeled after and is closely linked to the United Russia party, with which it has signed an inter-party cooperation agreement.

title: Unity Party (South Ossetia)
text: The party is a winner of the 2004 and 2009 parliamentary elections.

title: Workers' Party of Ireland
text: The Workers' Party (Irish: "Páirtí na nOibrithe" ), originally known as Official Sinn Féin, is a Marxist–Leninist political party active throughout Ireland.

title: Workers' Party of Ireland
text: The party originated with a split between factions of Sinn Féin (which was founded in 1905) and the Irish Republican Army (IRA), which took place in 1969–70, early in the Troubles.

title: Workers' Party of Ireland
text: The faction that broke away became known as the Provisional Irish Republican Army and Provisional Sinn Féin.

title: Workers' Party of Ireland
text: The Officials' leaders at the time the Provisionals left were Cathal Goulding and Tomás Mac Giolla.

title: Sinn Féin Republican Youth
text: Sinn Féin Republican Youth (known as Ógra Shinn Féin until 2012) (Irish: "Sinn Féin Óige Phoblachtach" ) is the youth wing of the Irish political party Sinn Féin.

title: Sinn Féin Republican Youth
text: SFRY is active and organised throughout Ireland and the United Kingdom.

title: Volunteer Political Party
text: The Volunteer Political Party (VPP) was a loyalist political party launched in Northern Ireland on 22 June 1974 by members of the then recently legalised Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF).

title: Volunteer Political Party
text: The Chairman was Ken Gibson from East Belfast, an ex-internee and UVF chief of staff at the time.

title: Volunteer Political Party
text: The success of the Ulster Workers Council Strike had shown some UVF leaders the political power they held and they sought to develop this potential further.

title: Volunteer Political Party
text: The UVF had been banned by the unionist government in 1966, but was legalised at the same time as Sinn Féin by Labour Secretary of State Merlyn Rees in April 1974 in order to encourage a political path for Loyalist and republican paramilitary groups.

title: History of Sinn Féin
text: Sinn Féin (""We Ourselves"", often mistranslated as "Ourselves Alone") is the name of an Irish political party founded in 1905 by Arthur Griffith.

title: History of Sinn Féin
text: It subsequently became a focus for various forms of Irish nationalism, especially Irish republicanism.

title: History of Sinn Féin
text: Its splits during the Irish Civil War in 1922 and again at the beginning of the Troubles in 1969 had dramatic effects on politics in Ireland.

title: History of Sinn Féin
text: Sinn Féin today is a republican, left-wing and secular party.

title: USS Belleau Wood
text: Two ships of the United States Navy have been named Belleau Wood, after the Battle of Belleau Wood near Château-Thierry in France.

title: Battle of Belleau Wood
text: The Battle of Belleau Wood (1–26 June 1918) occurred during the German Spring Offensive in World War I, near the Marne River in France.

title: Battle of Belleau Wood
text: The battle was fought between the U.S. 2nd (under the command of Major General Omar Bundy) and 3rd Divisions along with French and British forces against an assortment of German units including elements from the 237th, 10th, 197th, 87th, and 28th Divisions.

title: Battle of Belleau Wood
text: The battle has become a key component of the lore of the United States Marine Corps.

title: Clifton B. Cates
text: Clifton B. Cates (born Clifton Bledsoe Cates; August 31, 1893 – June 4, 1970) was a senior officer of the United States Marine Corps who served as the 19th Commandant of the Marine Corps from 1948 to 1951.

title: Clifton B. Cates
text: He was honored for his heroism during World War I at the Battle of Belleau Wood, and in World War II for inspired combat leadership at the Battle of Iwo Jima.

title: Clifton B. Cates
text: He is considered one of the most distinguished young officers of the Great War.

title: Clifton B. Cates
text: Cates was one of the few officers from any branch of service to have commanded a platoon, a company, a battalion, a regiment, and a division each in combat.

title: Darel McKinney
text: Darel McKinney served in the United States Marine Corps during World War I.

title: Darel McKinney
text: He would be awarded the Navy Cross and Distinguished Service Cross for his actions during the Battle of Belleau Wood.

title: American Expeditionary Forces
text: The American Expeditionary Forces (AEF) was the expeditionary force of the United States Army during World War I.

title: American Expeditionary Forces
text: It was established on July 5, 1917, in France under the command of General John J. Pershing.

title: American Expeditionary Forces
text: During the United States campaigns in World War I it fought alongside the French Army, British Army, and Canadian Army on the Western Front, against the German Empire.

title: American Expeditionary Forces
text: A minority of the AEF troops also fought alongside the Italian Army in that same year, against the Austro-Hungarian Army.

title: American Expeditionary Forces
text: The AEF helped the French Army on the Western Front during the Aisne Offensive (at the Battle of Château-Thierry (1918) and Battle of Belleau Wood) in the summer of 1918, and the AEF fought its major actions in the Battle of Saint-Mihiel and the Meuse-Argonne Offensive in the latter part of 1918.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: St Elmo Murray Haney (1898 - 1979) was a Master Gunnery Sergeant in the United States Marine Corps.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: As a veteran of many early campaigns in the Marine Corps, he was considered the epitome of the "old breed" Marine and a source of inspiration during the tough battles of the Pacific Campaign in World War II.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: Author Eugene Sledge described Haney as being, "everywhere at once, correcting mistakes and helping out".

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: As one who fought in some of the most fiercest fighting of the time, he had the respect of the Marines.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: In World War I, he fought in the Battle of Belleau Wood with the 5th Marine Regiment.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: In 1930, between the wars, he was stationed in Shanghai and played in the outfield for the Fourth Marine Regiment Baseball Team.

title: Elmo M. Haney
text: He also served in France, Nicaragua, Iceland and on the Amazon.

title: USS Belleau Wood (CVL-24)
text: USS "Belleau Wood was a United States Navy "Independence"-class light aircraft carrier active during World War II in the Pacific Theater, from 1943 to 1945.

title: USS Belleau Wood (CVL-24)
text: The ship also served in the First Indochina War under French Navy temporary service as Bois Belleau".

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: The Battle of Norfolk was a tank battle fought on February 27, 1991, during the Persian Gulf War, between armored forces of the United States and United Kingdom, and those of the Ba'athist Iraqi Republican Guard.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: The primary participants were the U.S. 2nd Armored Division (Forward),1st Infantry Division (Mechanized), and the Iraqi 18th Mechanized and 9th Armoured Brigades of the Republican Guard Tawakalna Mechanized Infantry Division along with elements from eleven other Iraqi divisions.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: The 2nd Armored Division(Fwd) was assigned to the American 1st Infantry Division as its 3rd maneuver brigade due to the fact that one of its brigades was not deployed.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: The British 1st Armoured division was responsible for protecting the right flank of VII Corps.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: Its main adversary being the Iraqi 52nd Armored Division and multiple infantry divisions.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: It was the final battle of the war before the unilateral ceasefire took effect.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: Two more battles occurred at Objective Dorset and near the oil field at Rumaila after the ceasefire.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: The Battle of Norfolk has been recognized by some sources as the second largest tank battle in American history and the largest tank battle of the 1st Gulf War.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: No fewer than 12 divisions participated in the Battle of Norfolk along with multiple brigades and elements of a regiment.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: American and British forces destroyed approximately 750 Iraqi tanks and hundreds of other types of combat vehicles.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: This goes without even taking into consideration the destruction of two additional Republican Guard divisions at Objective Dorset by the 3rd Armored Division on 28 February 1991.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: During this action the 3rd Armored Division destroyed 250 enemy vehicles and captured 2,500 Iraqi soldiers.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: Over a decade passed after the conflict before quality references became available on most of the battles that took place during the 1st Gulf War.

title: Battle of Norfolk
text: Many of the land battles during Operation Desert Storm were larger than the majority of the battles that took place in southern and western Europe during World War Two, at least as far as the quantity of equipment involved.

title: Aisne-Marne American Cemetery and Memorial
text: The Aisne-Marne American Cemetery and Memorial is a 42 acre World War I cemetery in Belleau, Northern France.

title: Aisne-Marne American Cemetery and Memorial
text: It is at the foot of the hill where the Battle of Belleau Wood was fought, with many American fatalities.

title: Aisne-Marne American Cemetery and Memorial
text: The cemetery also contains burials from the Battle of Château-Thierry, later that summer.

title: USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3)
text: USS "Belleau Wood" (LHA-3), nicknamed "Devil Dog", was the second ship named after the Battle of Belleau Wood in World War I.

title: USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3)
text: Her keel was laid down on 5 March 1973 at Pascagoula, Mississippi, by Ingalls Shipbuilding.

title: USS Belleau Wood (LHA-3)
text: She was launched on 11 April 1977, and commissioned on 23 September 1978, with Captain T.C. Steele in command.

title: Royal Australian Navy
text: The Royal Australian Navy (RAN) is the naval branch of the Australian Defence Force.

title: Royal Australian Navy
text: Following the Federation of Australia in 1901, the ships and resources of the separate colonial navies were integrated into a national force: the Commonwealth Naval Forces.

title: Royal Australian Navy
text: Originally intended for local defence, the navy was granted the title of 'Royal Australian Navy' in 1911, and became increasingly responsible for defence of the region.

title: Defence Long Service Medal
text: The Defence Long Service Medal is an Australian Military award given for long service by permanent and reserve members of the Australian Defence Force, irrespective of rank.

title: Defence Long Service Medal
text: It was introduced in 1998, and replaced the suite of defence force service awards introduced in 1982, which comprised the Defence Force Service Medal, the Reserve Force Medal and the Reserve Force Decoration.

title: List of ships of the Yugoslav Navy
text: The Yugoslav Navy ("Jugoslavenska ratna mornarica"; JRM) was the naval branch of the Yugoslav People's Army ("Jugoslavenska narodna armija"; JNA).

title: List of ships of the Yugoslav Navy
text: Organized as a coastal defence force with the main task of preventing enemy landings on its long and indented coastline, the navy's inventory reflected its foreign relations as well as the growing capabilities of its domestic shipyards and scientific institutions.

title: List of ships of the Yugoslav Navy
text: The period immediately after the end of the Second World War was marked by relying on equipment that was captured, salvaged or obtained from the Western Bloc through reparations or lend-lease programs.

title: Vietnam People's Navy
text: The Vietnam People's Navy (Vietnamese: "Hải quân nhân dân Việt Nam" ), commonly known as the Vietnamese Navy or the Vietnamese People's Navy, is the naval branch of the Vietnam People's Army and is responsible for the protection of the country's national waters, islands, and interests of the maritime economy, as well as for the co-ordination of maritime police, customs service and the border defence force.

title: Garden Island Naval Chapel
text: The Naval Chapel at Garden Island dockyard is the oldest Christian chapel of the Royal Australian Navy (RAN).

title: Garden Island Naval Chapel
text: It was established in 1902 after conversion from the former sail loft, and has stained glass windows and plaques from that era to the present.

title: Garden Island Naval Chapel
text: The building is the oldest on Garden Island, two storey, built of stuccoed brick with stone sills, arches and columns.

title: Garden Island Naval Chapel
text: The original loft floor of timber remains, caulked with oakum and bitumen.

title: Defence Force Service Medal
text: The Defence Force Service Medal (DFSM) is an Australian Military award given for long service by permanent members of the Australian Defence Force.

title: Defence Force Service Medal
text: It is part of the suite of defence force service awards introduced in 1982, which also included the Reserve Force Decoration (RFD, for officers of the Australian Defence Force Reserves) and the Reserve Force Medal (RFM, for non-commissioned members of the Reserve forces).

title: Defence Force Service Medal
text: All three medals were replaced in 2002 with a single medal, the Defence Long Service Medal, which is now awarded to all permanent and reserve members irrespective of rank.

title: Australian Transformation and Innovation Centre
text: The Australian Transformation and Innovation Centre (ATIC) is a Thales Australia facility based at the Garden Island Naval Base in Sydney.
