text: The bridge was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1998.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: The Old Allamakee County Courthouse, located on 2nd Street in Lansing, is a short-lived former county courthouse of Allamakee County, Iowa.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: The courthouse was completed in 1861 amid a fight between Lansing and Waukon over which community deserved to be the county seat.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: Lansing had lost a vote on the county seat to Waukon in 1859, but they won another vote in 1861 after teaming up with the community of Columbus.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: Waukon built its own courthouse in the meantime, but it failed to win back the county seat in yet another vote in 1864.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: The county sheriff, a Waukon resident, attempted to seize the county's records from the Lansing courthouse in 1866; however, a posse from Lansing stopped him before he could return to Waukon.

title: Old Allamakee County Courthouse (Lansing, Iowa)
text: The Iowa Supreme Court decided the county seat battle in favor of Waukon the following year; it has remained there since.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: The Cerro Gordo County Courthouse is located in Mason City, Iowa, United States.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: When Cerro Gordo County was created in 1855 and Mason City was selected to be the county seat.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: Dissatisfaction in the western part of the county led the Iowa legislature to appoint three new commissioners who would move the county seat to Livonia.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: A courthouse was built there.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: A petition signed by over half of the citizens of the county requested that the county seat be moved back to Mason City.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: Mason City also won the election in 1858 to decide the matter 155-48.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: Two courthouses have stood in Mason City prior to the present Modernist structure that was occupied by the county in 1960.

title: Cerro Gordo County Courthouse (Iowa)
text: It had been built as the Standard Oil Building, and was acquired by the county in 1959 for $159,400 and then remodeled for their use.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The Gardnerville Branch Jail is a historic jail located at 1440 Courthouse St. in Gardnerville, Nevada.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The jail was built in 1910 and served as Douglas County's only jail from 1910 to 1915.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Prior to 1910, the only county jail was in Genoa, the county seat; however, since Gardnerville was several miles from Genoa, it resorted to housing prisoners in the local judge's granary.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: As the granary was considered unfit for holding prisoners, the community petitioned the county to construct a new jail.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: However, local leaders in Minden, who wanted to move the county seat to their town, protested the move, as they suspected that Gardnerville was attempting to claim the county seat itself.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Nonetheless, the county approved the construction of the new jail.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The jail housed its first prisoners before construction even finished, as the Genoa jail burned down; one prisoner was briefly chained to a post until the new jail could accommodate him.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Once completed, the jail served the county until 1915, when Minden became the county seat and opened its own county jail.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: The Sutliff Bridge is a bridge over the Cedar River at Sutliff, a Johnson County community near Lisbon, Iowa, United States.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: A Parker truss bridge, it was built in 1897 and 1898 at a cost of approximately $12,000.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: J.R. Sheely was the engineer for the original Sutliff Bridge.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: After a modern replacement was built over the Cedar in 1983, the bridge was slated for destruction, but it was ultimately saved, and on May 15, 1998, it was added to the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: Although the bridge remained a celebrated location for locals and for visitors from across Iowa, including a 5k foot race beloved as the “worst road race in America", it succumbed to massive floods in the second week of June 2008: while the river normally flowed many feet below the bottom of the bridge, the floods topped the bridge's deck, and one of the bridge's spans was washed away on June 13 as the surrounding countryside was inundated with vast amounts of water.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: It is estimated that restoring the bridge will cost $1.7 million.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: Most of this money would come from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), with the rest coming from donations and local governments; both FEMA and the Johnson County Board of Supervisors have agreed in principle to repair the bridge.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: The bridge reconstruction was supervised by VJ Engineering of Coralville, Iowa and construction was completed by Iowa Bridge and Culvert of Washington, Iowa.

title: Sutliff Bridge
text: In October 2012 a ribbon cutting ceremony was held opening the bridge to public use for the first time in four years.

title: J.C. Bartlett House
text: The J.C. Bartlett House is a historic house located at 12 Walnut Street in Taunton, Massachusetts.

title: J.C. Bartlett House
text: The house was built in 1880 for J.C. Bartlett, a prosperous mining engineer.

title: J.C. Bartlett House
text: It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1984.

title: Murree rebellion of 1857
text: The Murree Rebellion of 1857, sometimes termed a war of Independence, was part of the Indian Rebellion of 1857.

title: Murree rebellion of 1857
text: It was a rebel skirmish between the tribes surrounding the Hill Station of Murree (in modern-day Pakistan) and the colonial government of British India.

title: Murree rebellion of 1857
text: Resentment toward colonial rule had been mounting for many years following the British establishment in the subcontinent.

title: Murree rebellion of 1857
text: There had been occasional isolated uprisings toward the British.

title: Murree rebellion of 1857
text: The significance of the 1857 events was that, although not centrally coordinated, the uprisings had the feel of something much larger with real anticipation that colonial rule would be overthrown.

title: Human rights in Niger
text: According to the Republic of Niger's Constitution of 1999, most human rights, as defined by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, are upheld and protected.

title: Human rights in Niger
text: Despite these protections, concerns of both domestic and international human rights organizations have been raised over the behavior of the government, military, police forces, and over the continuation of traditional practices which contravene the 1999 constitution.

title: Human rights in Niger
text: Under French colonial rule (1900–1960) and from independence until 1992, citizens of Niger had few political rights, and lived under arbitrary government power.

title: Human rights in Niger
text: Although the situation has improved since the return to civilian rule, criticisms remain over the state of human rights in the country.

title: 1985 Hong Kong electoral reform
text: The 1985 Hong Kong electoral reform introduced the first ever indirect election to the colonial legislature during the last years of the British colonial rule in Hong Kong.

title: 1985 Hong Kong electoral reform
text: The reform proposals was first carried out in the Green Paper: the Further Development of Representative Government in Hong Kong in July 1984 right before the Sino-British Joint Declaration in December.

title: 1985 Hong Kong electoral reform
text: The reform laid the foundation of the representative democracy in Hong Kong which developed throughout the last years of the colonial rule and succeeded by the democratic development in Hong Kong after the handover of Hong Kong in 1997.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: Philippe Soupault (2 August 1897, Chaville, Hauts-de-Seine – 12 March 1990, Paris) was a French writer and poet, novelist, critic, and political activist.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: He was active in Dadaism and later founded the Surrealist movement with André Breton.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: Soupault initiated the periodical "Littérature" together with the writers Breton and Louis Aragon in Paris in 1919, which, for many, marks the beginnings of Surrealism.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: The first book of automatic writing, "Les champs magnétiques" (1920), was co-authored by Soupault and Breton.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: In 1927 Soupault, with the help of his wife Marie-Louise, translated William Blake's "Songs of Innocence and Experience" into French.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: The next year, Soupault authored a monograph on Blake, arguing the poet was a "genius" whose work anticipated the Surrealist movement in literature.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: He directed Radio Tunis from 1937 to 1940, when he was arrested by the pro-Vichy regime.

title: Philippe Soupault
text: He fled successfully to Algiers.

title: L'affiche rouge
text: "L'Affiche rouge" is a song from the album "Les Chansons d'Aragon" (1961) by Léo Ferré.

title: L'affiche rouge
text: Its lyrics are based on the poem Strophes pour se souvenir ("Strophes to remember") which Louis Aragon wrote in 1955 for the inauguration of a street in the 20th arrondissement in Paris, named "rue du Groupe Manouchian" in honor of 23 members of the FTP-MOI executed by the Nazis in the Mont-Valérien.

title: L'affiche rouge
text: The affair became known by the name of the "Affiche rouge" ("Red Poster") because the Germans plastered Paris in the spring of 1944 with thousands of red posters denouncing those executed as immigrants and Resistants.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: The origins of the Sri Lankan Civil War lie in the continuous political rancor between the majority Sinhalese and the minority Sri Lankan Tamils.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: Before and during the early part of colonial rule by Europeans, Sri Lanka was under the rule of three separate kingdoms.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: War and peace was a status quo between nations, unlike the present status quo of war crimes and terrorism between majorities and minorities.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: During the colonial rule by Portuguese and then the Dutch, the three sovereign states were ruled as separate entities.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: The final British colonial rule amalgamated the entire island into a single administrative entity after independence the minorities were handed over to the mercy of the majority who were warring parties before the period of the European colonisation.

title: Origins of the Sri Lankan civil war
text: According to Jonathan Spencer, a social anthropologist from the School of Social and Political Studies of the University of Edinburgh, the war is an outcome of how modern ethnic identities have been made and re-made since the colonial period, with the political struggle between minority Tamils and the Sinhala-dominant government accompanied by rhetorical wars over archeological sites and place name etymologies, and the political use of the national past.

title: Mwambutsa IV of Burundi
text: Mwambutsa IV Bangiricenge (6 May 1912–26 March 1977) was king ("mwami") of Burundi who ruled between 1915 and 1966.

title: Mwambutsa IV of Burundi
text: He succeeded to the throne on the death of his father Mutaga IV Mbikije ( 1908–15 ).

title: Mwambutsa IV of Burundi
text: Born while Burundi was under German colonial rule, Mwambutsa's reign mostly coincided with Belgian colonial rule (1916–62).

title: Mwambutsa IV of Burundi
text: The Belgians retained the monarchs of both Rwanda and Burundi under the policy of indirect rule.

title: Les Chansons d'Aragon
text: Les Chansons d'Aragon (English: ""Songs of Aragon"") is an album by Léo Ferré, released in 1961 by Barclay Records.

title: Les Chansons d'Aragon
text: It is his second album dedicated to a poet, after Baudelaire's "Les Fleurs du mal" in 1957.

title: Les Chansons d'Aragon
text: Here, Ferré focuses on former surrealist Louis Aragon, but the body of work he chooses (poetry collection "Le Roman inachevé", mostly) is not surrealistic.

title: Fort Diu
text: Fort Diu, is located on the west coast of India in Diu, a Union Territory, administered by the Government of India.

title: Fort Diu
text: The fort was built by the Portuguese during their colonial rule of the Diu island.

title: Fort Diu
text: The Diu town is located to the west of the fort.

title: Fort Diu
text: The fort was built in 1535 subsequent to a defense alliance forged by Bahadur Shah, the Sultan of Gujarat and the Portuguese when Humayun, the Mughal Emperor waged war to annex this territory.

title: Fort Diu
text: The fort was strengthened over the years, till 1546.

title: Fort Diu
text: Portuguese ruled over this territory from 1537 (from the year they took control of the fort and also the Diu town fully) till 1961 (for 424 years, the longest period by any colonial rule in the world) they were forced to quit only in December 1961 (even though India became an independent country in 1947) during a military action called the "Operation Vijay" launched by the Government of India, whereafter Diu was merged with India and became a centrally administered Union Territory (UT).

title: J. G. Farrell
text: James Gordon Farrell (25 January 1935 – 11 August 1979) was a Liverpool-born novelist of Irish descent.

title: J. G. Farrell
text: He gained prominence for a series of novels known as the "Empire Trilogy" ("Troubles", "The Siege of Krishnapur" and "The Singapore Grip"), which deal with the political and human consequences of British colonial rule.

title: Shadow War
text: The Shadow Wars are a fictional series of wars involving the Shadows in the television science fiction series "Babylon 5".

title: Shadow War
text: There have actually been many Shadow Wars since ancient times in the galaxy.

title: Shadow War
text: Roughly every thousand years, the Shadows begin a new Shadow War to promote chaos in the universe in accordance with their ideology of growth through conflict.

title: Shadow War
text: During the first two seasons, "The Shadow War" typically refers to the previous Shadow War in the cycle, a thousand years earlier.

title: Shadow War
text: At this point the one that takes place within the series itself is referred to as "the Coming Shadow War", as it is anticipated but not yet begun.

title: Shadow War
text: This last war is mainly referred to as "the Shadow War" in the fourth and fifth seasons.

title: Gargoyles (TV series)
text: Gargoyles is an American animated series produced by Walt Disney Television and Buena Vista Television, and originally aired from October 24, 1994 to February 15, 1997.

title: Gargoyles (TV series)
text: The series features a species of nocturnal creatures known as gargoyles that turn to stone during the day.

title: Gargoyles (TV series)
text: After spending a thousand years in an enchantedly petrified state, the gargoyles (who have been transported from medieval Scotland) are reawakened in modern-day New York City, and take on roles as the city's secret night-time protectors.

title: Quaternary
text: Quaternary ( ) is the current and most recent of the three periods of the Cenozoic Era in the geologic time scale of the International Commission on Stratigraphy (ICS).

title: Quaternary
text: It follows the Neogene Period and spans from 2.588 ± 0.005 million years ago to the present.

title: Quaternary
text: The Quaternary Period is divided into two epochs: the Pleistocene (2.588 million years ago to 11.7 thousand years ago) and the Holocene (11.7 thousand years ago to today).

title: Quaternary
text: The informal term "Late Quaternary" refers to the past 0.5–1.0 million years.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park (also known as Escalante State Park) is a state park of Utah, USA, located a half-mile (0.8 km) north of the town of Escalante.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: A visitor center was built in 1991, and features displays of plant and marine fossils, petrified wood and fossilized dinosaur bones over 150 million years old (Upper Jurassic Period).

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: The Petrified Forest Trail is a one-mile (1.6 km) loop, winding up the side of a mesa to the top where most of the fossil wood occurs.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: Logs two feet or more in diameter are seen at several places along the trail where it is eroding from the conglomerate capping the mesa.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: This conglomerate lies near the top of the Brushy Basin Member of the Morrison Formation.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: The wood is multicolored (mostly red, yellow, white, and black) and was prized by hobbyists before the Park was established.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: The logs are believed to be of conifers that were transported by a river before being buried and later fossilized as agate.

title: Escalante Petrified Forest State Park
text: A 50 foot (15m) log is displayed near the trail head and is one of the most complete fossil logs known from the Morrison Formation.

title: Rainbow Girl
text: Rainbow Girl (Dori Aandraison of the planet Xolnar) is a fictional character and a DC Comics super heroine.

title: Rainbow Girl
text: She first appeared in "Adventure Comics" #309 (June 1963) as a rejected Legion of Super-Heroes applicant.

title: Rainbow Girl
text: Her second appearance was 25 years later in "Who's Who in the Legion of Super-Heroes" #5 as a socialite.

title: Rainbow Girl
text: She did not appear again for nearly 20 years until "Action Comics" #862 as a member of the Legion of Substitute Heroes, an organization of teenage heroes that exists one thousand years in a future universe.

title: Race of a Thousand Years
text: The 2000 Race of a Thousand Years was an endurance race and the final round of the 2000 American Le Mans Series.

title: Race of a Thousand Years
text: It was run on the Adelaide Street Circuit in Australia on New Year's Eve, 31 December 2000.

title: Race of a Thousand Years
text: The race was run on the full 3.780 km (2.349 mi) Grand Prix circuit used by Formula One for the Australian Grand Prix between 1985-1995, rather than the shorter 3.219 km (2.012 mi) V8 Supercars version of the circuit used since 1999.

title: Race of a Thousand Years
text: The Race of a Thousand Years was intended to be run for 1000 kilometres but was stopped short due to time constraints, two hours before midnight, after completing 850 kilometres.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken is a direct-to-video animated film from The Walt Disney Company.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: The film is actually the five-episode pilot ("Awakening") of the animated television series "Gargoyles" edited into one long feature film, approximately 100 minutes in length.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: As a result, numerous scenes from the original broadcast episodes were cut due to time constraints.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: In addition, a number of scenes were also moved around and some dialogues were changed.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: The episodes were produced and aired in 1994, and the film was released to laserdisc and VHS in February 1995 and featured an interactive VHS/LD board game.

title: Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken
text: As the pilot episodes have been released to DVD as part of "Gargoyles": Season 1, this feature is unlikely to be released independently again.

title: Desert kite
text: Desert kites are constructions aimed at trapping game animals, found in the Middle East.

title: Desert kite
text: Known to the local Bedouin as the Works of the Old Men, are found across the deserts of Syria, Jordan, Southern Israel and Saudi Arabia.

title: Desert kite
text: They are believed to have been used for hunting wild animals and consist of long dry-stone walls converging on a neck which opens into a confined space which was used as the killing floor.

title: Desert kite
text: The length of the walls can run to hundreds of metres and can be best seen from the air.

title: Desert kite
text: They were given their name by pilots who first saw them from the air in the 1920s.

title: Desert kite
text: Almost 2,000 have been identified across Jordan and Syria.

title: Desert kite
text: No research has been done across the Saudi Arabian Desert.

title: Desert kite
text: Modern research has proven that the "desert kites" were mainly used for hunting herds of migrating goitered or Persian gazelle, a species which became extinct in Southern Levant during the 19th century.

title: Desert kite
text: Most desert kites have been dated through scientific methods to be between 3 and 5 thousand years old.

title: Desert kite
text: The claim of older ages (8 to 9 thousand years) has been contradicted by more recent studies.

title: Desert kite
text: Younger dates mean that the mass hunting did not occur in prehistory and was not done by hunter-gatherers, but during a later period, by agriculturalists who were already growing most of their food.

title: Desert kite
text: Rock art in the vicinity of some of the kites indicates that the hunt could represent a large social effort, done together by people from several settlements, and showing religious connotations.

title: Beer in Hungary
text: Beer in Hungary has been brewed for well over a thousand years, but in the modern age, most beer is mass-produced.

title: Beer in Hungary
text: Beer has been made there for around a thousand years and the country has a significant history of commercial beer production.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years, subtitled "What I Learned While Editing My Life", is the sixth book by Donald Miller.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: After writing a successful book, author Donald Miller's life stalled.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: Instead of enjoying the fruits of his labor, Miller had slipped into a dark point in his life.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: He had no desire to participate in the daily responsibility of life and found himself questioning what his purpose was.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: While in this slump he was approached by two movie producers wanting to turn his book into a movie.

title: A Million Miles in a Thousand Years
text: "A Million Miles in a Thousand Years" centers on the realizations that Miller came to while editing his successful memoir "Blue Like Jazz" into a screenplay for a movie, directed by Steve Taylor.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: Paresh Mokashi (born 6 February 1969) is an Indian filmmaker, producer, actor and Theatre director-producer; working predominantly in Marathi cinema and Marathi theatre.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: He started working as a backstage worker for theatre and did few minor roles for plays as well as films.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: Mokashi made his directorial debut for theatre with the Marathi play, "Sangeet Debuchya Mulee" in 1999.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: He continued to work for theatre and made his directorial debut for cinema with the 2009 Marathi feature film, "Harishchandrachi Factory".

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: The film depicts the making of India's first full-length feature film, "Raja Harishchandra" (1913), made by Dadasaheb Phalke.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: The film was acclaimed critically and won several awards.

title: Paresh Mokashi
text: It was also selected as India's official entry to 82nd Academy Awards in the Best Foreign Language Film category.

title: Spare Me (film)
text: Spare Me is a 1992 "bowling noir" film that, as one film reviewer wrote, "twists conventions of the Western and thriller genres within its parallel universe of bowling monomania."

title: Spare Me (film)
text: Matthew Harrison's feature film directorial debut, the 16mm feature was made for less than $80,000 US and won awards at the Rome Film Festival, New Orleans Film Festival, Long Island Film Festival and others.

title: Spare Me (film)
text: Harrison used the cash award from a prize at the Avignon Film Festival to make his second feature, the Sundance Jury Prize winning "Rhythm Thief".

title: Peter McKay (cricketer)
text: Peter John McKay (born 12 October 1994 in Burton-upon-Trent) is an English cricketer who plays for Warwickshire.

title: Peter McKay (cricketer)
text: He is a left-handed batsman who also plays as a wicket-keeper.

title: Peter McKay (cricketer)
text: McKay made his first-class debut for Warwickshire against Oxford MCCU in April 2013.

title: You Can't Kill Stephen King
text: You Can't Kill Stephen King is a 2012 American comedy horror film that was directed by Monroe Mann, Ronnie Khalil, and Jorge Valdés-Iga, and is the directorial debut of Khalil and the feature film directorial debut of Mann.

title: You Can't Kill Stephen King
text: The film had its world premiere on 14 April 2012 at the Lewiston Auburn Film Festival and was later released to DVD on 9 December 2014 through Big Screen Entertainment Group.

title: You Can't Kill Stephen King
text: The film follows a group of friends that decide to visit the area horror author Stephen King lives, but find themselves threatened with their own potential deaths.

title: Brandon Dickerson
text: Brandon Dickerson is an American writer, director, and producer whose work includes film, music video, documentary film, and television commercials.

title: Brandon Dickerson
text: He made his feature film directorial debut with the 2011 feature film "Sironia", which won the Audience Award at the 2011 Austin Film Festival in October 2011 before its release through Filmbuff.

title: Brandon Dickerson
text: His second feature film as writer-director, "Victor", is set for release in 2017 as is his documentary film "A Single Frame".

title: Brady Corbet
text: Brady James Monson Corbet ( ; born August 17, 1988) is an American actor and filmmaker.

title: Brady Corbet
text: Corbet is known for playing Mason Freeland in the film "Thirteen", Brian Lackey in the film "Mysterious Skin", Alan Tracy in the 2004 film "Thunderbirds", and Peter in the 2008 film "Funny Games".

title: Brady Corbet
text: He has made guest appearances on many television shows.

title: Brady Corbet
text: He made his feature film directorial debut with "The Childhood of a Leader" and won Best Debut film and Best Director award at 72nd Venice International Film Festival.

title: Chimères (film)
text: Chimères (English: "Chimeras") is a 2013 horror film and the feature film directorial debut of Olivier Beguin.

title: Chimères (film)
text: The movie had its world premiere on July 5, 2013 at the Neuchâtel International Fantastic Film Festival, where it won a special mention for best feature film.

title: Chimères (film)
text: It stars Yannick Rosset as a young man that ends up contracting vampirism after receiving a blood transfusion.

title: ATL (film)
text: ATL is a 2006 American comedy-drama film, and the feature film directorial debut of music video director Chris Robinson.

title: ATL (film)
text: The screenplay was written by Tina Gordon Chism from an original story by Antwone Fisher, and is loosely based on the experiences of the film's producers Dallas Austin and Tionne "T-Boz" Watkins (of the R&B group TLC) growing up in Atlanta, Georgia (ATL).

title: ATL (film)
text: The film is a coming-of-age tale concerning Rashad, played by Atlanta native and hip hop artist T.I. in his film debut, and his friends in their final year in high school and on the verge of adulthood.

title: ATL (film)
text: The film also stars Antwan Andre Patton, aka Big Boi of the hip hop group OutKast, Evan Ross, Jackie Long, Lauren London, and Mykelti Williamson.

title: Chris McKay
text: Chris McKay, also known as Chris Taylor, is an American film and television director, producer, editor, animator, and visual effects artist.

title: Chris McKay
text: He is best known for directing and editing three seasons of "Robot Chicken" and two seasons of "Moral Orel".

title: Chris McKay
text: He worked as an animation co-director on "The Lego Movie" (2014) with Phil Lord and Christopher Miller.

title: Chris McKay
text: He made his feature film directorial debut with "The Lego Batman Movie" (2017)"."

title: Chris McKay
text: He is attached to direct a live-action film about Nightwing.

title: Afflicted (film)
text: Afflicted is a 2013 Canadian found footage horror film that was written and directed by Derek Lee and Clif Prowse, and is their feature film directorial debut.

title: Afflicted (film)
text: It had its world premiere on September 9, 2013 at the Toronto International Film Festival, where it won a special jury citation for Best Canadian First Feature Film.

title: Afflicted (film)
text: Lee and Prowse also star in "Afflicted" as two friends whose goal to film themselves traveling the world is cut short when one of them contracts a mysterious disease.

title: Whirligig
text: A whirligig is an object that spins or whirls, or has at least one part that spins or whirls.

title: Whirligig
text: Whirligigs are also known as pinwheels, buzzers, comic weathervanes, gee-haws, spinners, whirlygigs, whirlijig, whirlyjig, whirlybird, or plain whirly.

title: Whirligig
text: Whirligigs are most commonly powered by the wind but can be hand, friction, or motor powered.

title: Whirligig
text: They can be used as a kinetic garden ornament.

title: Whirligig
text: They can be designed to transmit sound and vibration into the ground to repel burrowing rodents in yards, gardens, and backyards.

title: Wind chime
text: Wind chimes are a type of percussion instrument constructed from suspended tubes, rods, bells or other objects that are often made of metal or wood.

title: Wind chime
text: The tubes or rods are suspended along with some type of weight or surface which the tubes or rods can strike when they or another wind-catching surface are blown by the natural movement of air outside.

title: Wind chime
text: They are usually hung outside of a building or residence as a visual and aural garden ornament.

title: Wind chime
text: Since the percussion instruments are struck according to the random effects of the wind blowing the chimes, wind chimes have been considered an example of chance-based music.

title: Wind chime
text: The tubes or rods may sound either indistinct pitches, or fairly distinct pitches.

title: Wind chime
text: Wind chimes that sound fairly distinct pitches can, through the chance movement of air, create simple melodies or broken chords.

title: Bird bath
text: A bird bath is an artificial puddle or small shallow pond, created with a water-filled basin, in which birds may drink, bathe, and cool themselves.

title: Bird bath
text: A bird bath can be a garden ornament, small reflecting pool, outdoor sculpture, and part of creating a vital wildlife garden.

title: Borghese Vase
text: The Borghese Vase is a monumental bell-shaped krater sculpted in Athens from Pentelic marble in the second half of the 1st century BC as a garden ornament for the Roman market; it is now in the Louvre Museum.

title: Medici Vase
text: The Medici Vase is a monumental marble bell-shaped krater sculpted in Athens in the second half of the 1st century AD as a garden ornament for the Roman market.

title: Medici Vase
text: It is now in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.

title: Waterloo Vase
text: The Waterloo Vase is a great urn, 15ft (5m) high and weighing 20 tons, fashioned from a single piece of Carrara marble.

title: Waterloo Vase
text: Since 1906, it has been used as a garden ornament in the garden of Buckingham Palace, London.

title: Garden ornament
text: A Garden ornament is an item used for garden, landscape, and park enhancement and decoration.

title: Garden ornament
Achalla
text: Achalla is the capital of Awka North, a Local Government Area in Anambra State, south-central Nigeria.

title: Achalla
text: It comprises eight villages: Umudiani, Amukabia, Odawa, Umuogbe, Umunagu, Umuezede, Udezu and Amadim.

title: Achalla
text: Achalla's current Monarch is HRH Igwe Alex Nwokedi(OON).

title: Achalla
text: However, the traditional monarchical heritage of Achalla is linked to the MUOLOKWU dynasty in ODAWA village.

title: Achalla
text: Historically, Achalla is said to have migrated from Arochukwu kingdom in present-day Abia state.

title: Achalla
text: In early ages, some Achalla people is also believed to have emigrated to form a community known to this day as Achalla-ibuzo in present Delta state.

title: Achalla
text: Some of its prominent sons include the current King, Igwe Alex Nwokedi who was a former chief press secretary to former head of State, General Olusegun Obasanjo, and also a retired Nigeria Custom Service boss, Comptroller Edwin U. Achum(retired) who was a philanthropist and known as the "Ozumba 1" of Achalla, and whose residence was once used as the secretariat of the local government until the government was able to build a permanent place to serve as the local government secretariat.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: The Abbotsford Club was a text publication society founded in Edinburgh in 1833 or 1834.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: This was the year after the death of Sir Walter Scott, whose residence of Abbotsford House gave the society its name, and whose literature the club's publications sought to illuminate.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: The club was modelled on the Roxburghe Club, of which Scott himself had been a member, as well as the Bannatyne Club, which was founded by Scott, and the Glasgow-centred Maitland Club.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: The founder and first secretary of the club was William Barclay Turnbull, a young Edinburgh lawyer.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: The stated objective of the Abbotsford Club was "the printing of Miscellaneous Pieces, illustrative of History, Literature, and Antiquities."

title: Abbotsford Club
text: Through its publishing activity, the club did much to promote the proliferation of Middle English literature.

title: Abbotsford Club
text: The Abbotsford Club effectively ceased publication in 1866.

title: Suikinkutsu
text: A suikinkutsu (水琴窟 , literally "water koto cave") is a type of Japanese garden ornament and music device.

title: Suikinkutsu
text: It consists of an upside down buried pot with a hole at the top.

title: Suikinkutsu
text: Water drips through the hole at the top onto a small pool of water inside of the pot, creating a pleasant splashing sound that rings inside of the pot similar to a bell or a Japanese zither called koto.

title: Suikinkutsu
text: It is usually built next to a traditional Japanese stone basin called "chōzubachi", part of a "tsukubai" for washing hands before the Japanese tea ceremony.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Scott County Transit operates the Shakopee Transit Buses which runs the Route 496E East Circulator and Route 496W West Circulator in Scott County, Minnesota.

title: Scott County Transit
text: These buses loop as local routes through Shakopee, Minnesota.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Shakopee Transit along with the Prior Lake Laker Lines operate the BlueXpress, which is a direct express to Minneapolis.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Scott County operates a Dial-A-Ride for anyone in Scott, Carver, and surrounding Counties.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Each ride is a one way ride to their destination with no transfers.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Riding in Shakopee is $2.00 In Scott County (Out of Shakopee but in the County) and Chaska (Carver County) $3.00.

title: Scott County Transit
text: Prices are different in other counties.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: Mankato ( ) is a city in Blue Earth, Nicollet, and Le Sueur counties in the state of Minnesota.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: It is the 22nd biggest city in Minnesota.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: The population was 41,044 according to 2015 US census estimates, making it the fifth largest city in Minnesota outside of the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: The county seat of Blue Earth County, it is located along a large bend of the Minnesota River at its confluence with the Blue Earth River.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: Mankato is across the Minnesota River from North Mankato.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: Mankato and North Mankato have a combined population of over 53,000, according to the 2010 census.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: It completely encompasses the town of Skyline.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: North of Mankato Regional Airport, a tiny non-contiguous part of the city is located within Le Sueur County.

title: Mankato, Minnesota
text: Most of the city of Mankato is located within Blue Earth County.

title: Scott Sandelin
text: Scott Alan Sandelin (born August 8, 1964) is an American former professional ice hockey player.

title: Scott Sandelin
text: He is currently the head coach of the Minnesota-Duluth Bulldogs men's ice hockey team.

title: Scott Sandelin
text: In 2011, he became the first coach in Bulldog history to lead them to a national title.

title: Scott Sandelin
text: It was a 3–2 overtime game against the University of Michigan at the Xcel Energy Center in Saint Paul, Minnesota.

title: Scott Sandelin
text: He grew up in Hibbing, Minnesota where he went on to be drafted in the second round by the Montreal Canadiens (40th overall) and play collegiate hockey for the North Dakota Fighting Sioux.

title: John Scott (ice hockey)
text: John Howard Scott (born September 26, 1982) is a Canadian retired professional ice hockey defenceman/winger who most recently played for the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League.

title: John Scott (ice hockey)
text: Scott previously played for the Minnesota Wild, Chicago Blackhawks, New York Rangers, San Jose Sharks, Buffalo Sabres and the Arizona Coyotes of the NHL.

title: John Scott (ice hockey)
text: Scott was born in Edmonton, Alberta, but grew up in St. Catharines, Ontario.

title: John Scott (ice hockey)
text: He graduated from Michigan Technological University in 2006.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: Lewiston is an extinct community in Sciota Township in Dakota County, Minnesota, United States.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: It lies northeast of Northfield, and nearest to the small city of Randolph.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: A town once larger than nearby Northfield; gone in only fifteen years.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: but this town set near the Cannon River and Alta Avenue was home to many Minnesotan politicians, such as Edward J. Thye, Minnesota's governor; Pierce Butler became a United States supreme court justice, and Loren W. Collins was a Minnesota supreme court justice.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: A flourished town with a horseracing track and a hotel was the home of these political figures.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: From 1851 to 1866 a magnificent town stood where farmland is today.

title: Lewiston, Dakota County, Minnesota
text: A good pitstop between Hastings and Faribault all that remains of the now abandoned town is the 1860 schoolhouse turned Sciota township hall.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: Jonathan, Minnesota is a homeowners' association that is a remnant of a planned community development within the city of Chaska, Minnesota in Carver County.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: It was named for Jonathan Carver, for whom Carver County also is named.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: In 2008, it is the largest homeowners' association in the State of Minnesota, with 2,300 households.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: It was planned by the Jonathan Development Corporation and begun in 1967.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: It was the idea of Minnesota State Senator and real estate developer Henry T. McKnight.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: The planners chose a site outside the Twin Cities urban area and Interstate 494/694 belt line.

title: Jonathan, Minnesota
text: The town site was centered on the intersection of Minnesota State Highway 41 and the Pacific Extension of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad.

title: Audra, Texas
text: Audra is a ghost town in Taylor County, Texas.

title: Audra, Texas
text: Established around the beginning of the 20th century, the town grew around a general store built by C. Meno Hunt, Fred Robinson, and Frank Sheppard.

title: Audra, Texas
text: The town was named after Sheppard's daughter.

title: Audra, Texas
text: In 1905, the population grew to a peak of around 75.

title: Audra, Texas
text: However, in response to the construction of a railroad through the area, the town was abandoned and its residents founded the town of Bradshaw to the east.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: The Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District is a national historic district located at Scottsburg, Scott County, Indiana.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: The district encompasses 48 contributing buildings and 8 contributing objects in the central business district of Scottsburg centered on the Scott County Courthouse.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: It developed between about 1873 and 1952, and includes notable examples of Italianate, Romanesque Revival, Gothic Revival, and Stick Style / Eastlake Movement style architecture.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: The courthouse was built in 1873-1874 after the decision was made to finally locate the county seat of Scott County into a central location within the county, which caused the founding of Scottsburg.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: Located in the district is the separately listed Scottsburg Depot.

title: Scottsburg Courthouse Square Historic District
text: Other notable contributing resources include the Town Tavern (1924), A&P Grocery (1923), Corner Drugstore (c. 1880), Harmon Building (1907), City Hall (1899-1900), Napper's Hospital (1936), Scott Theatre (1946), Scott County Public (Carnegie) Library (1919), Scott County Bank (1906), Prosser's Hardware (1912), and a statue of William Hayden English (1908).

title: Mike Beard (politician)
text: Michael "Mike" Beard (born July 22, 1953) is a Minnesota politician and former member of the Minnesota House of Representatives, who retired in 2014.

title: Mike Beard (politician)
text: A member of the Republican Party of Minnesota, he represented District 55A, which includes portions of Scott County in the southwestern part of the Twin Cities metropolitan area.

title: Mike Beard (politician)
text: Communities in the district include Shakopee, Jackson Township, and Louisville Township.

title: Mike Beard (politician)
text: He is also a local businessman and newspaper publisher.

title: Mike Beard (politician)
text: He is now also co-chair of a coal energy advocacy group, Coalition for a Secure Energy Future and serves as Scott County Commissioner, District 3.

title: Martin Mahoney
text: Martin Vincent Mahoney (February 22, 1915 - August 22, 1969) was a Scott County, Minnesota justice of the peace who presided over the initial trial in the case of "First National Bank of Montgomery v. Jerome Daly", Dec. 9, 1968 (Justice Court, Township of Credit River, Scott County, Minnesota), also known as the "Credit River" case.

title: Martin Mahoney
text: This case has been cited by various conspiracy theorists and anti-Federal Reserve System protesters as authority for the proposition that foreclosure is illegal.

title: Martin Mahoney
text: According to a statement published at the Minnesota State Law Library web site, the "Credit River" decision is not legal precedent, since it was undertaken by a justice of the peace (see also Subject-matter jurisdiction), and was eventually overruled by other court decisions.

title: Martin Mahoney
text: The defendant, Jerome Daly, was a longtime tax protester and attorney who was later disbarred by a decision of the Minnesota Supreme Court.

title: Brother Bear
text: Brother Bear is a 2003 American animated comedy-drama film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Brother Bear
text: It is the 44th Disney animated feature film.

title: Brother Bear
text: In the film, an Inuit boy named Kenai pursues a bear in revenge for a battle that he provoked in which his oldest brother Sitka is killed.

title: Brother Bear
text: He tracks down the bear and kills it, but the Spirits, angered by this needless death, change Kenai into a bear himself as punishment.

title: Brother Bear
text: In order to be human again, Kenai must travel to a mountain where the Northern lights touch the earth, and learn to see through another's eyes, feel through another's heart, and discover the meaning of brotherhood.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: Home on the Range is a 2004 American animated musical western comedy film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: The 45th Disney animated feature film, it was the last 2D animated Disney film released until "The Princess and the Frog" in 2009.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: Named after the popular country song of the same name, "Home on the Range" features the voices of Roseanne Barr, Judi Dench, Jennifer Tilly, Cuba Gooding Jr., Randy Quaid, and Steve Buscemi.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: The film is set in the Old West, and centers on a mismatched trio of dairy cows—brash, adventurous Maggie; prim, proper Mrs. Caloway; and ditzy, happy-go-lucky Grace.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: The three cows must capture an infamous cattle rustler named Alameda Slim for his bounty in order to save their idyllic farm from foreclosure.

title: Home on the Range (2004 film)
text: Aiding them in their quest is Lucky Jack, a feisty, peg-legged rabbit, but a selfish horse named Buck, eagerly working in the service of Rico, a famous bounty hunter, seeks the glory for himself.

title: Dinosaur (film)
text: Dinosaur is a 2000 American CGI animated adventure film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and The Secret Lab and released by Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Dinosaur (film)
text: It is the 39th Disney animated feature film and Disney's The Secret Lab computer animated feature, though it is not officially labeled as one of the animated classics in the United Kingdom, where "The Wild" (2006) is included in the canon instead.

title: Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)
text: Beauty and the Beast is a 1991 American animated musical romantic fantasy film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)
text: The 30th Disney animated feature film and the third released during the Disney Renaissance period, it is based on the French fairy tale of the same name by Jeanne-Marie Leprince de Beaumont (who was also credited in the English version as well as in the French version), and ideas from the 1946 French film of the same name directed by Jean Cocteau.

title: Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)
text: "Beauty and the Beast" focuses on the relationship between the Beast (voice of Robby Benson), a prince who is magically transformed into a monster and his servants into household objects as punishment for his arrogance, and Belle (voice of Paige O'Hara), a young woman whom he imprisons in his castle.

title: Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)
text: To become a prince again, Beast must learn to love Belle and earn her love in return to avoid remaining a monster forever.

title: Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)
text: The film also features the voices of Richard White, Jerry Orbach, David Ogden Stiers, and Angela Lansbury.

title: Tarzan (1999 film)
text: Tarzan is a 1999 American animated drama adventure film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation for Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Tarzan (1999 film)
text: The 37th Disney animated feature film and the last film produced during the Disney Renaissance era, it is based on the story "Tarzan of the Apes" by Edgar Rice Burroughs, and is the first animated major motion picture version of the "Tarzan" story.

title: Tarzan (1999 film)
text: Directed by Chris Buck and Kevin Lima with a screenplay by Tab Murphy, Bob Tzudiker, and Noni White, "Tarzan" features the voices of Tony Goldwyn, Minnie Driver, Glenn Close, and Rosie O'Donnell with Brian Blessed, Lance Henriksen, Wayne Knight, and Nigel Hawthorne.

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The Sword in the Stone is a 1963 American animated musical fantasy comedy film produced by Walt Disney and released by Buena Vista Distribution.

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The 18th Disney animated feature film, it was the final Disney animated film to be released before Walt Disney's death.

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The songs in the film were written and composed by the Sherman Brothers, who later wrote music for other Disney films like "Mary Poppins" (1964), "The Jungle Book" (1967), "The Aristocats" (1970), and "Bedknobs and Broomsticks" (1971).

title: Lady and the Tramp
text: Lady and the Tramp is a 1955 American animated romantic musical comedy-drama film produced by Walt Disney and released to theaters on June 22, 1955 by Buena Vista Distribution.

title: Lady and the Tramp
text: The 15th Disney animated feature film, it was the first animated feature filmed in the CinemaScope widescreen film process.

title: Lady and the Tramp
text: Based on "Happy Dan, The Whistling Dog" by Ward Greene, "Lady and the Tramp" tells the story of a female American Cocker Spaniel named Lady who lives with a refined, upper-middle-class family, and a male stray mongrel called the Tramp.

title: Lady and the Tramp
text: When the two dogs meet, they embark on many romantic adventures.

title: Lady and the Tramp
text: A direct-to-video sequel, "", was released in 2001.

title: Peter Pan (1953 film)
text: Peter Pan is a 1953 American animated adventure film produced by Walt Disney and based on the play "Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up" by J. M. Barrie.

title: Peter Pan (1953 film)
text: It is the 14th Disney animated feature film and was originally released on February 5, 1953, by RKO Radio Pictures.

title: Peter Pan (1953 film)
text: "Peter Pan" is the final Disney animated feature released through RKO before Walt Disney's founding of his own distribution company, Buena Vista Distribution, later in 1953 after the film was released.

title: Peter Pan (1953 film)
text: "Peter Pan" is also the final Disney film in which all nine members of Disney's Nine Old Men worked together as directing animators.

title: Peter Pan (1953 film)
text: It is also the second Disney animated film starring Kathryn Beaumont, Heather Angel, and Bill Thompson after their roles in the animated feature "Alice in Wonderland".

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The Hunchback of Notre Dame is a 1996 American animated musical drama film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation for Walt Disney Pictures.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The 34th Disney animated feature film, the film is based on Victor Hugo's novel of the same name.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: The plot centers on Quasimodo, the deformed bell-ringer of Notre Dame, and his struggle to gain acceptance into society.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)
text: Directed by Kirk Wise and Gary Trousdale and produced by Don Hahn, the film's voice cast features Tom Hulce, Demi Moore, Tony Jay, Kevin Kline, Paul Kandel, Jason Alexander, Charles Kimbrough, David Ogden Stiers, and Mary Wickes in her final film role.

title: Hercules (1997 film)
text: Hercules is a 1997 American animated musical fantasy comedy film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation for Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Hercules (1997 film)
text: The 35th Disney animated feature film, the film was directed by Ron Clements and John Musker.

title: Hercules (1997 film)
text: The film is loosely based on the legendary hero Heracles (known in the film by his Roman name, Hercules), the son of Zeus, in Greek mythology.

title: Hercules (1997 film)
text: The film also featured the first positive portrayal of African American women in a Disney animated film.

title: Petty treason
text: Petty treason or petit treason was an offence under the common law of England which involved the betrayal (including murder) of a superior by a subordinate.

title: Petty treason
text: It differed from the better-known high treason in that high treason can only be committed against the Sovereign.

title: Petty treason
text: In England and Wales, petty treason ceased to be a distinct offence from murder by virtue of the Offences against the Person Act 1828.

title: Petty treason
text: It was abolished in Ireland in 1829.

title: Petty treason
text: It never existed in Scotland.

title: Petty treason
text: It has also been abolished in other common-law countries.

title: Uterine cancer
text: Uterine cancer or womb cancer is any type of cancer that emerges from the tissue of the uterus.

title: Uterine cancer
text: It can refer to several types of cancer, with cervical cancer (arising from the lower portion of the uterus) being the most common type worldwide and the second most common cancer in women in developing countries.

title: Uterine cancer
text: Endometrial cancer (or cancer of the inner lining of the uterus) is the second most common type, and fourth most common cancer in women from developed countries.

title: Uterine cancer
text: Risk factors depend on specific type, but obesity, older age, and human papillomavirus infection add the greatest risk of developing uterine cancer.

title: Uterine cancer
text: Early on, there may be no symptoms, but irregular vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain or fullness may develop.

title: Uterine cancer
text: If caught early, most types of uterine cancer can be cured using surgical or medical methods.

title: Uterine cancer
text: When the cancer has extended beyond the uterine tissue, more advanced treatments including combinations of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgery may be required.

title: Kegelhelm
text: The Kegelhelm (German: "cone helm") or Kegel type is a type of helmet.

title: Kegelhelm
text: It is an open-faced helmet of roughly conical shape, sometimes with extensions at the sides to protect the cheeks, or a crest-holder on top.

title: Kegelhelm
text: It was made of bronze, sometimes in several pieces.

title: Kegelhelm
text: It was the progenitor of many Greek helmets, especially the "Illyrian" type helmet.

title: Kegelhelm
text: It did not outlast the eighth century BC.

title: W. Morgan Petty
text: W. Morgan Petty is the creation of Brian Bethell.

title: W. Morgan Petty
text: W. Morgan Petty would write crank letters to numerous organizations expressing typical concerns for mid-1980s Britain like nuclear war and the common market.

title: W. Morgan Petty
text: Collections of his letters include:

title: Imprest system
text: The imprest system is a form of financial accounting system.

title: Imprest system
text: The most common imprest system is the petty cash system.

title: Imprest system
text: The base characteristic of an imprest system is that a fixed amount is reserved, which after a certain period of time or when circumstances require, because money was spent, it will be replenished.

title: Imprest system
text: This replenishment will come from another account source, e.g., petty cash will be replenished by cashing a cheque drawn on a bank account.

title: High treason
text: Treason is criminal disloyalty.

title: High treason
text: Historically, in common law countries, high treason is treason against the state.

title: High treason
text: It was differentiated from petty treason (or "petit" treason), which was treason against a lesser lawful superior (such as a servant killing his master).

title: High treason
text: Petty treason was restricted to cases of homicide in 1351, and came to be considered a more serious degree of murder.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: M Music & Musicians (alternatively known as Music & Musicians and often shortened to just M) is an American magazine based out of Redondo Beach, California, that covers the music industry.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: It was established in November 2009.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: The central management team is made up of Merlin David (formerly of "Performing Songwriter"), editor Rick Taylor ("Performing Songwriter", American Media, Inc.), creative director Terrill Thomas (T13 Media, AtomFilms), senior editor Chris Neal ("Performing Songwriter", American Media, Inc.), technology editor Doug Doppler and photographer Kent Kallberg.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: According to its initial press release, ""M" matches first-class features, interviews and reviews with a new distribution model" and offers "insightful, in-depth coverage from rock, pop and hip-hop to R&B, country, folk and jazz."

title: M Music & Musicians
text: Alicia Keys was featured on the cover of the first issue, dated January/February 2010.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: Subsequent cover-story subjects have included Sting, Ringo Starr, Tom Petty, Mary J. Blige and Sheryl Crow.

title: M Music & Musicians
text: The "Encore" section regularly features work from archives of veteran rock photographers such as Henry Diltz and Norman Seeff.

title: Petit jury
text: In common law, a petit jury (or trial jury, sometimes petty jury) hears the evidence in a trial as presented by both the plaintiff (petitioner) and the defendant (respondent).

title: Petit jury
text: After hearing the evidence and often jury instructions from the judge, the group retires for deliberation, to consider a verdict.

title: Petit jury
text: The majority required for a verdict varies.

title: Petit jury
text: In some cases it must be unanimous, while in other jurisdictions it may be a majority or supermajority.

title: Petit jury
text: A jury that is unable to come to a verdict is referred to as a hung jury.

title: Petit jury
text: The size of the jury varies; in criminal cases involving serious felonies there are usually 12 jurors, although Scotland uses 15.

title: Petit jury
text: A number of countries that are not in the English common law tradition have quasi-juries on which lay judges or jurors and professional judges deliberate together regarding criminal cases.

title: Petit jury
text: However, the common law trial jury is the most common type of jury system.

title: J. T. Petty
text: J. T. Petty (born February 28, 1977 in Raleigh, North Carolina) is an American filmmaker and video game writer.

title: J. T. Petty
text: Petty's film and short novels contain elements of the horror genre.

title: J. T. Petty
text: He wrote the Ubisoft video game, "Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell" as well as the survival horror games "Outlast" and "Outlast 2".

title: J. T. Petty
text: He currently resides in Brooklyn, New York .

title: Write strategy
text: In DVD authoring, a write strategy is a set of low-level parameters that enables an optical disc drive to write on a specific type of blank media according to its optimum specifications.

title: Write strategy
text: The media type is identified by the manufacturer and media ID, which is often unrelated to the brand of the media due to rebadging.

title: Write strategy
text: Write strategies are essential for compatibility with various types of blank media, and are typically stored in the drive's firmware.

title: Write strategy
text: If a drive lacks a write strategy for a media type, it will only be able to write using minimum speed.

title: Write strategy
text: Drive manufacturers typically include new or improved write strategies as part of a firmware upgrade, in order to extend or improve compatibility with blank media.

title: Write strategy
text: In cases where official support for a drive has been discontinued or is deemed unsatisfactory, users have come up with ways to patch the write strategies by modding the drive's firmware.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: Dukenfield Hall is a country house located between Knutsford and Mobberley in Cheshire, England.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: Now a symmetrical brick building, it originated in the late 16th or early 17th century as a small cruck-framed house, entered at one end.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: During the 17th century it was faced with brick, cross wings were added and the roof was heightened.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: The house was originally called Podmore House.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: Further additions were made to the house in the 19th and 20th centuries.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: It is constructed in plum-coloured brick with stone dressings, and has a stone-slate roof.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: The house is in two storeys plus an attic.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: Its entrance front is E-shaped, and has three projecting wings with gables.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: The house is recorded in the National Heritage List for England as a designated Grade II* listed building.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: Associated with the house are two structures listed at Grade II.

title: Dukenfield Hall
text: These are the gate piers to the forecourt, and a barn.

title: Jeff Hoover
text: Jeff Hoover (born January 18, 1960 in Albany, Kentucky) is a Republican member of the Kentucky House of Representatives representing the 83rd district where he has served since 1996.

title: Jeff Hoover
text: Hoover was selected to serve as House Minority Caucus Chair in 1999, and served as House Minority Leader, a position he held 2001 to 2017.

title: Jeff Hoover
text: Hoover is a 1982 graduate of Centre College and a 1987 graduate of Cumberland School of Law.

title: Jeff Hoover
text: Hoover unsuccessfully ran for Lieutenant Governor of the State of Kentucky in 2007 as the running mate of former U.S. Rep. Anne Northup; their slate received 36.5% of the vote in the primary against Gov. Ernie Fletcher.

title: Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema
text: The Barry R. Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema, more commonly referred to as the Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema, is a film school and one of the graduate schools of Brooklyn College, a senior college within the City University of New York.

title: Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema
text: It is located on the Steiner Studios film lot in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema
text: Feirstein is the first public graduate film school in New York City and is the only public graduate film school in the United States located on a working film lot.

title: Feirstein Graduate School of Cinema
text: The school is named after Barry Feirstein, a donor and Brooklyn College alumnus.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: Charles T. Holt House is a historic home located at Haw River, Alamance County, North Carolina.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: It was designed by noted architect George Franklin Barber and built in 1897.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: The house is a 2 1/2-story, rectangular dwelling sheathed in wood, slate, brick and stone in the Queen Anne style.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: It features peaks, turrets and decorative chimney stacks.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: Also on the property are the contributing carriage house, servant's quarters, gas house, corn crib, barn, and well house / flowerhouse.

title: Charles T. Holt House
text: It was built for textile businessman Charles T Holt, the son of Thomas Michael Holt, governor of North Carolina, and his wife Gena Jones Holt, the daughter of Thomas Goode Jones, governor of Alabama.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The Thomas H. Gale House, or simply Thomas Gale House, is a house located in the Chicago suburb of Oak Park, Illinois, United States.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The house was designed by famous American architect Frank Lloyd Wright in 1892 and is an example of his early work.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The house was designed by Wright independently while he was still employed by Adler and Sullivan, something architect Louis Sullivan forbade.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The house is significant because of what it shows about the architect's early development period.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The Parker House is listed as contributing property to a U.S. federally Registered Historic District.

title: Thomas H. Gale House
text: The house was designated an Oak Park Landmark in 2002.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: Julia Morgan School for Girls is an all-girls middle school in Oakland, California named for Julia Morgan, the building's architect and the first woman to be licensed in California as an architect.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: The school is housed in a historic and architecturally significant building she designed.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: The building was constructed in 1924 and was originally used for The Ming Quong Home for Chinese girls, an orphanage.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: It was purchased and donated to Mills College in 1936 and became known as Graduate House.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: After 1960 it was known as Alderwood Hall.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: In 2004, the building was renovated for use as the Julia Morgan School for Girls.

title: Julia Morgan School for Girls
text: The building is located at 5000 MacArthur Boulevard.

title: House of the Jesuits, Cartagena
text: The Casa de los Jesuitas is a large building located in Cartagena de Indias, in Colombia.

title: House of the Jesuits, Cartagena
text: The first Jesuit House in Cartagena, home of the College of the Company in 1604, was located in the old Plaza del Muelle, now it is located on Calle de la Ronda street, and serves as headquarters for the Naval Museum.

title: House of the Jesuits, Cartagena
text: When the section of the Walls that closed the city to the southwest was built, a part of it occupied the ground of the Jesuit College, reason why the governor don Francisco de Murga authorized to the Company of Jesus to raise their house on the Wall, not without it triggering a heated debate.

title: House of the Jesuits, Cartagena
text: Years later, the governor don Melchor Aguilera obtained a royal cedula that ordered the demolition of the House of the Company of Jesus, to which opposed the disciples of Loyola, being instituted a long litigation, whose solution entrusted the King to the governor of Cartagena de Indias , Don Luis Fernández de Córdoba.

title: Farr House
text: The Farr House is a historic house located at 106 E. Wynoka St. in Pierre, South Dakota.

title: Farr House
text: Built in 1904, the house was designed by architect E. J. Donahue in the Colonial Revival style.

title: Farr House
text: Donahue's design exhibits Georgian and Adamesque influences and features Ionic columns on the porch, two-story Ionic pilasters at the front corners, Palladian windows, and a dentillated cornice.

title: Farr House
text: The house's first owner, Colonel Farr, was a veteran and banker; his wife, Mary Noyes-Farr, was one of the first female doctors in Pierre.

title: Farr House
text: Peter Norbeck later lived in the house during his term as South Dakota Governor, and Governor Carl Gunderson also lived in the house for a short time.

title: Farr House
text: The house is now a bed and breakfast.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: The Gateway College of Architecture and Design has been set up by Gateway Education and offers a five-year B. Architecture program.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: This society has as a partner, an architect who has a strong desire of providing education to the young people, aspiring to lead a creative life of an architect, a platform that is based on idealistic but pragmatic thinking.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: The college is being guided by another architect who has a vast experience in architectural education and believes in using contemporary teaching methods for effective education.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: The group has the long term plans of becoming a University offering a variety of under graduate and post-graduate courses.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: The group is running a successful, modern CBSE school, an Engineering College and a Hotel Management College.

title: Gateway College of Architecture and Design
text: GCAD was awarded the best upcoming architecture institute in Haryana.

title: Governor's House, Knutsford
text: The former Governor's House is located in Toft Road, Knutsford, Cheshire, England.

title: Governor's House, Knutsford
text: It was built for the governor of Knutsford Gaol, and has later been used as a Tourist Information Centre.

title: Governor's House, Knutsford
text: It was built in 1844 and designed by the Lancaster architect Edmund Sharpe.

title: Governor's House, Knutsford
text: It is recorded in the National Heritage List for England as a designated Grade II listed building.

title: Governor's House, Knutsford
text: The house is constructed in red brick in Georgian style.

title: Love Streams (album)
text: Love Streams is the eighth studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on April 8, 2016 on 4AD and Paper Bag Records.

title: Love Streams (album)
text: The album was recorded throughout 2014 and 2015 at Greenhouse Studios in Reykjavík, Iceland, where parts of Hecker's last two albums "Virgins" (2013) and "Ravedeath, 1972" (2011) were recorded.

title: Radio Amor
text: Radio Amor is the second studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on March 25, 2003 on Mille Plateaux, and re-released on Alien8 Recordings on January 23, 2007.

title: Tim Hecker
text: Tim Hecker is an electronic musician and sound artist based in Los Angeles, United States and Montreal, Canada.

title: Tim Hecker
text: Hecker previously recorded under the moniker Jetone, but has become known internationally for ambient recordings released under his own name, such as "Harmony in Ultraviolet" (2006) and "Ravedeath, 1972" (2011).

title: Tim Hecker
text: He has released eight albums and a number of EPs in addition to collaborations with artists such as Ben Frost, Daniel Lopatin, and Aidan Baker.

title: Tim Hecker
text: His latest album "Love Streams" was released on his new label 4AD on 8 April 2016.

title: Harmony in Ultraviolet
text: Harmony in Ultraviolet is the fourth studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on October 16, 2006 on Kranky.

title: An Imaginary Country
text: An Imaginary Country is the fifth studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on March 10, 2009 by Kranky.

title: An Imaginary Country
text: The album is available on either CD or 2×LP.

title: Mirages (album)
text: Mirages is the third studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on September 21, 2004 on Alien8 Recordings.

title: Mirages (album)
text: It is described on the Alien8 website as “an ambient-death-metal classic in waiting.”

title: Mirages (album)
text: The album is composed primarily of heavily distorted and processed guitar.

title: Mirages (album)
text: Relatively free of beats, this album moves rhythmically along in a glitch fashion, acquiring rhythm through pulsating or droning bass and some sounds resembling digital malfunction.

title: Mirages (album)
text: In addition to sharing similar moods and tones, the tracks bleed into each other, making this a nearly seamless composition.

title: Mirages (album)
text: The distortion guitar and feedback elements with delicate underlying melodies may call to mind the textural rock compositions of shoegaze.

title: Ravedeath, 1972
text: Ravedeath, 1972 is the sixth studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on February 14, 2011 by Kranky.

title: Ravedeath, 1972
text: Musically sparse, the album was recorded primarily in Frikirkjan Church, Reykjavík, with contributions from Ben Frost.

title: Ravedeath, 1972
text: The album's central theme is of the degradation of music itself.

title: Ravedeath, 1972
text: Critical response was largely warm, with many reviewers acknowledging the album as Hecker's finest.

title: Virgins (Tim Hecker album)
text: Virgins is the seventh studio album by Canadian electronic music musician Tim Hecker, released on October 14, 2013 by Kranky and Paper Bag Records.

title: Virgins (Tim Hecker album)
text: The album features contributions from Kara-Lis Coverdale.

title: Haunt Me, Haunt Me Do It Again
text: Haunt Me, Haunt Me Do It Again is the debut studio album by Canadian electronic musician Tim Hecker, released on November 20, 2001, on Substractif, a sub-label of Alien8 Recordings.

title: Haunt Me, Haunt Me Do It Again
text: The album mixes the digital signal processing of glitch with post-rock structures and melodies.

title: Haunt Me, Haunt Me Do It Again
text: The sounds used for this album, as well as most of Tim Hecker’s other works, originate from a guitar, piano, and laptop.

title: Haunt Me, Haunt Me Do It Again
text: The title of the song “The Work of Art in the Age of Cultural Overproduction” is a reference to Walter Benjamin's essay, "The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction".

title: Music Maker (label)
text: Music Maker Relief Foundation is an American non-profit, based in Hillsborough, North Carolina.

title: Music Maker (label)
text: Music Maker Relief Foundation was founded in 1994 by Tim and Denise Duffy to "help the true pioneers and forgotten heroes of Southern music gain recognition and meet their day-to-day needs.

title: Music Maker (label)
text: Music Maker presents these musical traditions to the world so American culture will flourish and be preserved for future generations."

title: Lowe's
text: Lowe's Companies, Inc. is a Fortune 500 American company that operates a chain of retail home improvement and appliance stores in the United States, Canada, and Mexico.

title: Lowe's
text: Founded in 1946 in North Wilkesboro, North Carolina, the chain has 1,840 stores in the United States, Canada, and Mexico.

title: Brico Dépôt
text: Brico Dépôt (] ) is a French chain of DIY and Home Improvement stores, headquartered in Longpont-sur-Orge.

title: Brico Dépôt
text: The chain was created in 1993 by Castorama Dubois Investment, Castorama Dubois was later purchased by the UK Kingfisher Group.

title: Brico Dépôt
text: There are over 100 stores in France.

title: Brico Dépôt
text: There are also 16 in Spain, 3 in Portugal and 5 in Poland.

title: Brico Dépôt
text: Some (15) were also opened in Romania after the acquisition of the Bricostore chain by Kingfisher.

title: Yardbirds Home Center
text: Yardbirds Home Center is a defunct chain of home improvement stores based in Petaluma, California, United States.

title: Yardbirds Home Center
text: Their trademark colors were yellow and white.

title: Yardbirds Home Center
text: Their mascot was a white buzzard with yellow overalls.

title: Yardbirds Home Center
text: These stores were not affiliated with the Yard Birds stores based out of Chehalis, Washington that used a black bird with a yellow beak as its mascot.

title: EpiCentre K
text: EpiCentre K (Ukrainian: Епіцентр К ) is a national chain of stores in Ukraine that specializes in home improvement and gardening.

title: EpiCentre K
text: The company is one of the first in the nation to introduce a chain of home improvement stores and has attained a great deal of success in expending throughout Ukraine in short period of time.

title: Lithia Motors
text: Lithia Motors, Inc. is an American nationwide automotive retailer headquartered in Medford, Oregon.

title: Lithia Motors
text: It is the fourth largest automotive retailer in the United States.

title: Lithia Motors
text: In 2015, Lithia Motors broke into the Fortune 500 list at #482, making it one of only three Oregon-based companies in the Fortune 500.

title: Lithia Motors
text: This followed a year that saw the acquisition of the DCH Auto Group, one of the 10 largest dealer groups in the country, with 27 dealerships, before being purchased by Lithia Motors.

title: Lithia Motors
text: In 2016, Lithia climbed to #346 and that same year made the Fortune 500 List of Top Ten Companies with the biggest Jump in rank on the Fortune 500.

title: Lithia Motors
text: Today, Lithia is ranked #318 on the Fortune 500.

title: Lithia Motors
text: Lithia employs more than 11,100 people in stores across the nation including Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Lithia Motors
text: Lithia operates 160 stores in 18 states.

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: The Charlotte metropolitan area (also Metrolina, Charlotte Metro, or Charlotte USA) is a metropolitan area/region of North and South Carolina within and surrounding the city of Charlotte.

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: Located in the Piedmont of the Southeastern United States, the Charlotte metropolitan area is well known for its auto racing history (especially NASCAR).

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: The region is headquarters to 8 Fortune 500 and 7 Fortune 1000 companies including Bank of America, Duke Energy, Sealed Air Corporation, Nucor Steel, and Lowe's Home Improvement Stores.

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: Additional headquarters include Harris Teeter, Food Lion, Cheerwine and Sundrop.

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: It is home to one of the world's busiest airports , Charlotte Douglas International Airport, and is also the Carolinas' largest manufacturing region.

title: Charlotte metropolitan area
text: The Charlotte MSA is the largest in the Carolinas, and the fourth largest metropolitan area in the Southeastern region of the United States behind, Miami, Atlanta, and Tampa.

title: Mitre 10 (New Zealand)
text: Mitre 10 is a major New Zealand chain of home improvement stores established in June 1974.

title: Mitre 10 (New Zealand)
text: It employs close to 5000 team members combined and functions as a co-operative, with over 80 stores run by 60 local owner-operators.

title: Pergament Home Centers
