title: Palm Meadows Thoroughbred Training Center
text: Palm Meadows Thoroughbred Training Center is an American stable and training facility for Thoroughbred racehorses located near Boynton Beach, Florida, just north of the Gulfstream Park racetrack.

title: Palm Meadows Thoroughbred Training Center
text: It is owned by Stronach Group.

title: Palm Meadows Thoroughbred Training Center
text: It was built by MI Developments (MID) at a cost of $90 million.

title: Palm Meadows Thoroughbred Training Center
text: The 304 acre center opened in November 2002 and is regarded as one of horse racing's largest and most modern training centers in the United States.

title: Night Raid
text: Night Raid (foaled 1918 in England) was a Leading sire in Australia of Thoroughbred racehorses.

title: Night Raid
text: He sired two leading racehorses, namely Phar Lap and Nightmarch.

title: Equix
text: Equix is a company in Lexington, Kentucky, founded in 1984.

title: Equix
text: The company evaluates equine biometrics and motion through the use of high-speed digital tools for the purpose of finding athletic potential.

title: Equix
text: Their products are used mainly on two-year-old Thoroughbred racehorses at training sales.

title: Equix
text: Equix uses the measurements of horses in order to predict potential, and in so doing helps clients select both racehorses and breeding matches.

title: 2010 World Thoroughbred Rankings
text: The 2010 World Thoroughbred Rankings was the 2010 edition of the World Thoroughbred Rankings.

title: 2010 World Thoroughbred Rankings
text: It was an assessment of Thoroughbred racehorses issued by the International Federation of Horseracing Authorities (IFHA) in January 2011.

title: 2010 World Thoroughbred Rankings
text: It included horses aged three or older which competed in flat races during 2010.

title: 2010 World Thoroughbred Rankings
text: It was open to all horses irrespective of where they raced or were trained.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: Jens Ritter Instruments is a manufacturer of high-end electric stringed instruments.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: It was founded by Jens Ritter in the mid-1990s and was known as Ritter Bass Guitars until 2010 when Jens expanded his line to include guitars.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: Jens produces 50 to 60 handmade instruments each year in his shop located in the small wine town of Deidesheim, Germany.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: A number of well-known bassists play Ritter Basses including Phil Lesh, Josh Dunham and Doug Wimbish.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: Jens Ritter Instruments are best known for their progressive design and construction, artistic appearance and limited availability.

title: Jens Ritter Instruments
text: They also produce strings and other accessories.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: An NTFS symbolic link (symlink) is a filesystem object in the NTFS filesystem that points to another filesystem object.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: The object being pointed to is called the target.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: Symbolic links should be transparent to users; the links appear as normal files or directories, and can be acted upon by the user or application in exactly the same manner.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: Symbolic links to directories or volumes, called junction points and mount points, were introduced with NTFS 3.0 that shipped with Windows 2000.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: From NTFS 3.1 onwards, symbolic links can be created for any kind of file system object.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: NTFS 3.1 was introduced together with Windows XP, but the functionality was not made available (through ntfs.sys) to user mode applications.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: Third-party filter drivers such as Masatoshi Kimura's opensource codice_1 driver could however be installed to make the feature available in user mode as well.

title: NTFS symbolic link
text: The ntfs.sys released with Windows Vista made the functionality available to user mode applications by default.

title: Extensibility
text: Extensibility is a software engineering and systems design principle where the implementation takes future growth into consideration.

title: Extensibility
text: The term extensibility can also be seen as a systemic measure of the ability to extend a system and the level of effort required to implement the extension.

title: Extensibility
text: Extensions can be through the addition of new functionality or through modification of existing functionality.

title: Extensibility
text: The central theme is to provide for change – typically enhancements – while minimizing impact to existing system functions.

title: Extensibility
text: An extensible system is one whose internal structure and data flow are minimally or not affected by new or modified functionality, for example recompiling or changing the original source code might be unnecessary when changing a system’s behavior, either by the creator or other programmers.

title: Extensibility
text: Because software systems are long lived and will be modified for new features and added functionalities demanded by users, extensibility enables developers to expand or add to the software’s capabilities and facilitates systematic reuse.

title: Extensibility
text: Some of its approaches include facilities for allowing users’ own program routines to be inserted and the abilities to define new data types as well as to define new formatting markup tags.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: Workflow Resource Planning is a new term coined by Charles Lim Chee Pang(the founder of Peliontech) in the year 2003, to name a new class of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Software.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: Conventional ERP software work in a data entry and processing model.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: Mr. Charles Lim changed that when he introduced the first WRP software that incorporates workflow functionality into its core design and released this new ERP called Radix ERP.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: Work flow functionality was not new.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: Lotus Notes was the pioneer of workflow systems until it went out of favor in early 2000.

title: Workflow Resource Planning
text: From the designs of Lotus Notes, Mr. Charles combined the idea into ERP systems and created Radix WRP, a new class of ERP system with workflow manageability.

title: HTML attribute
text: An HTML attribute is a modifier of an "HTML element type".

title: HTML attribute
text: An attribute either modifies the default functionality of an element type or provides functionality to certain element types unable to function correctly without them.

title: HTML attribute
text: In HTML syntax, an attribute is added to an "HTML start tag".

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Bio-inspired robotic locomotion is a fairly new subcategory of bio-inspired design.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: It is about learning concepts from nature and applying them to the design of real-world engineered systems.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: More specifically, this field is about making robots that are inspired by biological systems.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Biomimicry and bio-inspired design are sometimes confused.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Biomimicry is copying the nature while bio-inspired design is learning from nature and making a mechanism that is simpler and more effective than the system observed in nature.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Biomimicry has led to the development of a different branch of robotics called soft robotics.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: The biological systems have been optimized for specific tasks according to their habitat.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: However, they are multifunctional and are not designed for only one specific functionality.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Bio-inspired robotics is about studying biological systems, and look for the mechanisms that may solve a problem in the engineering field.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: The designer should then try to simplify and enhance that mechanism for the specific task of interest.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Bio-inspired roboticists are usually interested in biosensors (e.g. eye), bioactuators (e.g. muscle), or biomaterials (e.g. spider silk).

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Most of the robots have some type of locomotion system.

title: Bio-inspired robotics
text: Thus, in this article different modes of animal locomotion and few examples of the corresponding bio-inspired robots are introduced.

title: Jens Risom
text: Jens Risom ( ; 8 May 1916 – 9 December 2016) was a Danish American furniture designer.

title: Jens Risom
text: An exemplar of Mid-Century modern design, Risom was one of the first designers to introduce Scandinavian design in the United States.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: In United States trademark law, the functionality doctrine prevents manufacturers from protecting specific features of a product by means of trademark law.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: There are two branches of the functionality doctrine: utilitarian functionality and aesthetic functionality.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: The rationale behind functionality doctrine is that product markets would not be truly competitive if newcomers could not make a product with a feature that consumers demand.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: Utilitarian functionality provides grounds to deny federal trademark protection to product features which do something useful.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: Patent law, not trademark, protects useful processes, machines, and material inventions. Patented designs are presumed to be functional until proven otherwise.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: Aesthetic functionality provides grounds to deny trademark protection to design features which are included to make the product more aesthetically appealing and commercially desirable.

title: Functionality doctrine
text: Aesthetic features are within the purview of copyright law, which provides protection to creative and original works of authorship.

title: Scandinavian design
text: Scandinavian design is a design movement characterized by simplicity, minimalism and functionality that emerged in the 1950s in the five Nordic countries of Finland, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Denmark.

title: Scandinavian design
text: While the term Scandinavia only refers to the three kingdoms of Denmark, Sweden and Norway, it is often used colloquially to refer to all five of these countries.

title: Jacqueline Winsor
text: Jacqueline "Jackie" Winsor (born October 20, 1941, in St. John's, Newfoundland) is a Canadian-American sculptor.

title: Jacqueline Winsor
text: Her style, which developed in the early 1970s as a reaction to the work of minimal artists, has been characterized as post-minimal, anti-form, and process art.

title: Jacqueline Winsor
text: Informed by her own personal history, Winsor's sculptures from this period sit at the intersection of Minimalism and feminism, maintaining an attention to elementary geometry and symmetrical form while eschewing Minimalism's reliance on industrial materials and methods through the incorporation of hand-crafted, organic materials such as wood and hemp.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2
text: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2 is a 2015 American dystopian science fiction adventure film directed by Francis Lawrence, with a screenplay by Peter Craig and Danny Strong.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2
text: It is the fourth and final installment in "The Hunger Games" film series, and the second of two films based on the novel "Mockingjay", the final book in "The Hunger Games" trilogy, by Suzanne Collins.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2
text: Produced by Nina Jacobson and Jon Kilik, and distributed by Lionsgate, the film features an ensemble cast that includes Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, Liam Hemsworth, Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Banks, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, and Donald Sutherland.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2
text: Hoffman died in February 2014, making "Mockingjay – Part 2" his final film role.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2
text: Principal photography on both parts of the film began on September 23, 2013 in Atlanta, before moving to Paris for two weeks of back-to-back filming and officially concluding on June 20, 2014, in Berlin and at Babelsberg Studios, Germany.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: American entertainer Justin Timberlake has released four video albums and has been featured in thirty-seven music videos, seventeen films, fifteen television shows, and six commercials.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: He achieved early fame when he appeared in the Disney Channel television series "The New Mickey Mouse Club", alongside singers Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera and actor Ryan Gosling.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: Timberlake rose to fame in the late 1990s as the lead singer of the boy band NSYNC.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: In 2002, he launched his solo career and released his solo debut single "Like I Love You", the music video for which was directed by Bucky Chrome.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: Francis Lawrence directed the video for "Cry Me a River".

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: The video features Timberlake's character as he spies on a former lover, who according to the director portrays his former romantic interest Spears.

title: Justin Timberlake videography
text: At the 2003 MTV Video Music Awards, the video won the accolades for Best Male Video and Best Pop Video.

title: Rich Lee
text: Rich Lee is an American music video and commercial director signed to Native Content in Hollywood, California.

title: Rich Lee
text: He has directed music videos for Lana Del Rey, Maroon 5, Eminem, The Black Eyed Peas, Norah Jones, Michael Bublé and The All-American Rejects.

title: Rich Lee
text: Rich Lee started his professional career as a sculptor and fabricator for Broadway shows in New York City.

title: Rich Lee
text: He later moved on to computer graphics and created 3-D previsualizations for big budget Hollywood feature films such as the first three "Pirates of the Caribbean" films, "I Am Legend", "Minority Report" and "Constantine".

title: Rich Lee
text: From the encouragement of feature film directors he moved into directing music videos and commercials.

title: Rich Lee
text: He has directed commercials for brands like Fiat, Hyundai, Honda, Beats by Dre etc.

title: The Hunger Games (film series)
text: The Hunger Games film series consists of four science fiction dystopian adventure films based on "The Hunger Games" trilogy of novels, by the American author Suzanne Collins.

title: The Hunger Games (film series)
text: Distributed by Lionsgate and produced by Nina Jacobson and Jon Kilik, it stars Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss Everdeen, Josh Hutcherson as Peeta Mellark, Woody Harrelson as Haymitch Abernathy, Elizabeth Banks as Effie Trinket, Philip Seymour Hoffman as Plutarch Heavensbee, Stanley Tucci as Caesar Flickerman, Donald Sutherland as President Snow and Liam Hemsworth as Gale Hawthorne.

title: The Hunger Games (film series)
text: Gary Ross directed the first film, while Francis Lawrence directed the next three films.

title: Kristof Konrad
text: Kristof Konrad (born 1962 as Krzysztof Wojslaw) is a Polish-American film, television, theatre, and voice actor.

title: Kristof Konrad
text: For over twenty years, he has successfully worked in film and television in both the United States and Europe, working with directors such as Kenneth Branagh, Francis Lawrence, Ron Howard, and Roland Emmerich and working opposite actors such as Jennifer Lawrence, Robin Wright, Kerry Washington, Jennifer Garner, and many more.

title: Kristof Konrad
text: He currently resides in Los Angeles and works internationally.

title: Pilot (Touch)
text: "Pilot" (also known as "Tales of the Red Thread") is the first episode of the first season of the American supernatural thriller drama television series "Touch".

title: Pilot (Touch)
text: The episode premiered in the United States on Fox on January 25, 2012.

title: Pilot (Touch)
text: The episode was written by series creator Tim Kring and directed by Francis Lawrence.

title: Pilot (Touch)
text: The concept of "Touch" was devised by Kring, who developed the science fiction drama "Heroes" for the NBC network.

title: Rhythm Divine
text: "Rhythm Divine" is a song by Spanish recording artist Enrique Iglesias, taken from his fourth studio album and debut English-language record "Enrique" (1999).

title: Rhythm Divine
text: It was released on 9 October 1999, by Interscope Records as the second single from the project.

title: Rhythm Divine
text: The song was written by Paul Barry and Mark Taylor, while production was handled by Taylor and Brian Rawling.

title: Rhythm Divine
text: An accompanying music video was directed by Francis Lawrence.

title: Rhythm Divine
text: The single sold over 3 million copies in 2000.

title: What's So Different?
text: "What's So Different?"

title: What's So Different?
text: is a song by R&B singer Ginuwine.

title: What's So Different?
text: It was the second single for his second album "100% Ginuwine".

title: What's So Different?
text: The song peaked one position below the Top 20 as an R&B hit and peaked within the Top 50 portion as a pop hit.

title: What's So Different?
text: "What's So Different" lyrically describes the narrator questioning his lover who is cheating on her boyfriend to be with him.

title: What's So Different?
text: He claims that if she is cheating on another man to be with him, she may also cheat on him to be with someone else.

title: What's So Different?
text: The music video was directed by Francis Lawrence.

title: What's So Different?
text: "What's So Different" samples the Monkees 1968 #3 U.S. single, "Valleri".

title: Red Sparrow
text: Red Sparrow is an upcoming American spy thriller film directed by Francis Lawrence, based on the book of the same name, written by Jason Matthews.

title: Red Sparrow
text: The film stars Jennifer Lawrence, Joel Edgerton, Matthias Schoenaerts, Charlotte Rampling, and Jeremy Irons.

title: Red Sparrow
text: It is scheduled to be released on March 2, 2018.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1
text: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1 is a 2014 American dystopian science fiction adventure film directed by Francis Lawrence with a screenplay by Peter Craig and Danny Strong.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1
text: It is the first of two films based on Suzanne Collins' novel " Mockingjay", the final book in "The Hunger Games" trilogy, and the third installment in "The Hunger Games" film series, produced by Nina Jacobson and Jon Kilik and distributed by Lionsgate.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1
text: The film features an ensemble cast that includes Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, Liam Hemsworth, Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Banks, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Jeffrey Wright, Stanley Tucci, and Donald Sutherland.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1
text: Principal photography for both parts of the film began on September 23, 2013, in Atlanta, before moving to Paris for two weeks of filming and officially concluding on June 20, 2014, in Berlin.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: Live!

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: The Last Concert is a live album by American singer Selena.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: It was recorded on February 26, 1995, at the Houston Astrodome and was televised live on Univision.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: The album was posthumously released by EMI Latin on March 27, 2001.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: The singer shared the concert with Tejano singer Emilio Navaira and performed to 66,994 people, which broke the previous attendance record held by Selena the previous year.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: The concert was critically acclaim for outperforming ticket sales by country music singers Vince Gill, Reba Mcentire, and George Strait.

title: Live! The Last Concert
text: Selena's performance at the astrodome became her final televised concert before she was shot and killed on March 31, 1995.

title: Fearless (Eighth Wonder album)
text: Fearless is the 1988 debut album by British pop group Eighth Wonder.

title: Fearless (Eighth Wonder album)
text: It is the group's only UK album release, is entirely uptempo, and contains six UK-issued singles (the earliest, "Stay With Me", dating back to 1985) including their highest-selling and best-remembered track, the Pet Shop Boys-produced and written "I'm Not Scared" (a #7 hit), and "Cross My Heart" (#13).

title: Fearless (Eighth Wonder album)
text: "Fearless" peaked at #47 on the UK Albums Chart.

title: Fearless (Eighth Wonder album)
text: Eighth Wonder split up in 1989, with lead singer Patsy Kensit going on to devote herself to her acting career.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: Brewster McCloud is a 1970 experimental film directed by Robert Altman.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: It concerns a young recluse (Bud Cort, as the title character) who lives in a fallout shelter of the Houston Astrodome, where he is building a pair of wings so he can fly.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: He is helped by his comely and enigmatic "fairy godmother", played by Sally Kellerman, as he becomes a suspect in a series of murders.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: The film was shot on location in Houston, Texas.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: During the opening credits, shots of the downtown Houston skyline (with One Shell Plaza under construction) zoom toward the Houston Astrodome and Astrohall, with the emerging Texas Medical Center in the background.

title: Brewster McCloud
text: It was the first film shot inside the Astrodome.

title: Walter Suggs
text: Walt Suggs was a college and professional American football player.

title: Walter Suggs
text: An offensive and defensive lineman, he played college football at Mississippi State University, and played professionally in the American Football League for the Houston Oilers from 1962 through 1969, and for the National Football League Oilers in 1970 and 1971.

title: Walter Suggs
text: Suggs played in 137 consecutive games.

title: Walter Suggs
text: He played in the first pro football game played in the Houston Astrodome in 1967.

title: Walter Suggs
text: He was an American Football League All-Star in 1967 and 1968.

title: 1973 Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl
text: The 1973 Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl, part of the 1973 bowl game season, took place on December 29, 1973, at the Houston Astrodome in Houston, Texas.

title: 1973 Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl
text: The competing teams were the Tulane Green Wave and Houston Cougars, with each competing as a football independent.

title: 1973 Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl
text: Houston won the game 47–7.

title: Shreveport Steamer
text: The Shreveport Steamer were a professional American football team in the World Football League.

title: Shreveport Steamer
text: The franchise began the 1974 season in Houston, Texas, as the Houston Texans, who are in no way related to the current NFL team of the same name, playing their home games at the Houston Astrodome.

title: Shreveport Steamer
text: Toward the end of the season the team relocated to Shreveport, Louisiana, and became the Shreveport Steamer.

title: Shreveport Steamer
text: They played at the 30,000-seat State Fair Stadium, now named Independence Stadium.

title: For the Last Time: Live from the Astrodome
text: For the Last Time: Live From the Astrodome is the first live album released by George Strait in 2003.

title: For the Last Time: Live from the Astrodome
text: The title refers to the fact that this concert was the final event that took place at the Houston Astrodome.

title: 1965 Houston Astros season
text: The 1965 Houston Astros season was the franchise's first season in the Houston Astrodome, as well as its first season as the Astros after three seasons known as the Colt .45s.

title: 1965 Houston Astros season
text: It involved the Houston Astros finishing in ninth place in the National League with a record of 65–97, 32 games behind the eventual World Series champion Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: 1965 Houston Astros season
text: The Astros were managed by Lum Harris.

title: Astrodome
text: The NRG Astrodome, also known as the Houston Astrodome or simply The Astrodome, is the world's first multi-purpose, domed sports stadium, located in Houston, Texas.

title: Astrodome
text: Construction on the stadium began in 1962, and it officially opened in 1965.

title: Astrodome
text: It served as home to the Houston Astros of Major League Baseball (MLB) from its opening in 1965 until 1999, and the home to the Houston Oilers of the National Football League (NFL) from 1968 until 1996, and also the part-time home of the Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association (NBA) from 1971 until 1975.

title: Astrodome
text: Additionally, the Astrodome was the primary venue of the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo from 1966 until 2002.

title: Astrodome
text: When opened, it was named the Harris County Domed Stadium and was nicknamed the "Eighth Wonder of the World".

title: 1968 Houston Oilers season
text: The 1968 Houston Oilers season was the team's ninth season.

title: 1968 Houston Oilers season
text: The club would play their home games in the Houston Astrodome.

title: 1968 Houston Oilers season
text: The Oilers would become the first team in professional football to play their games in a domed stadium.

title: Paddy O'Rourke (Meath footballer)
text: Paddy O'Rourke (born 10 May 1989) is an Irish Gaelic footballer who plays as a Goalkeeper for his club Skryne and the Meath senior footballers.

title: Paddy O'Rourke (Meath footballer)
text: O'Rourke is the nephew of former Skryne and Meath player Colm O'Rourke and first cousin to current Meath player Shane O'Rourke.

title: Paddy O'Rourke (Meath footballer)
text: He played for the Skryne juvenile team at a young age and eventually became the Skryne senior team's first choice goalkeeper, aged 16.

title: Paddy O'Rourke (Meath footballer)
text: He has since moved outfield to a forward position.

title: Paddy O'Rourke (Meath footballer)
text: O'Rourke was top scorer on the 2010 SFC Skryne winning team.

title: Give War a Chance

title: Give War a Chance
text: <ref name="The Independent - 5 September 1992 -BOOK REVIEW / Eating marxism for breakfast: Give war a chance - P J O'Rourke"> </ref>

title: Despoina
text: In Greek mythology, Despoina, Despoena or Despoine, was the daughter of Demeter and Poseidon and sister of Arion.

title: Despoina
text: She was the goddess of mysteries of Arcadian cults worshipped under the title "Despoina", "the mistress" alongside her mother Demeter, one of the goddesses of the Eleusinian mysteries.

title: Despoina
text: Her real name could not be revealed to anyone except those initiated to her mysteries.

title: Despoina
text: Pausanias spoke of Demeter as having two daughters; Kore being born first, then later Despoina.

title: Despoina
text: With Zeus being the father of Kore, and Poseidon as the father of Despoina.

title: Despoina
text: Pausanias made it clear that Kore is Persephone, though he wouldn't reveal Despoina's proper name.

title: Augustine of Canterbury
text: Augustine of Canterbury (born first third of the 6th century – died probably 26 May 604) was a Catholic Benedictine monk who became the first Archbishop of Canterbury in the year 597.

title: Augustine of Canterbury
text: He is considered the "Apostle to the English" and a founder of the Catholic Church in England.

title: Patricio Echegaray
text: Patricio Echegaray (17 October 1946 – 9 August 2017) was an Argentine politician.

title: Patricio Echegaray
text: He was born in San José de Jáchal, Argentina.

title: Patricio Echegaray
text: He served as General Secretary of the Communist Party of Argentina from 1986 until his death in 2017.

title: Patricio Echegaray
text: Before, Echegaray served as the 26th General Secretary of the Juvenile Communist Federation from 1980 through 1985.

title: Patricio Echegaray
text: He was a member of the Buenos Aires City Legislature from 2000 to 2003.

title: List of Lab Rats characters
text: "Lab Rats", also known as "Lab Rats: Bionic Island" for its fourth season, is an American television sitcom that premiered on February 27, 2012, on Disney XD.

title: List of Lab Rats characters
text: It focuses on the life of teenager Leo Dooley, whose mother, Tasha, marries billionaire genius Donald Davenport.

title: List of Lab Rats characters
text: He meets Adam, Bree, and Chase, three bionic superhumans, with whom he develops an immediate friendship.

title: List of Lab Rats characters
text: It should be noted that the names of the Lab Rats imply that they were originally known as subjects A, B, C and D. Adam was born first, then Bree, then Chase, and finally Daniel.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody is an American humor book that was first published in 1973.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: It was a spin-off from "National Lampoon" magazine.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: The book was a parody of a high school yearbook from the early 1960s.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: It was edited by P. J. O'Rourke and Doug Kenney and art directed by David Kaestle.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: Much of the writing was by P. J. O'Rourke and Doug Kenney.

title: National Lampoon 1964 High School Yearbook Parody
text: The "literary magazine" was written by Sean Kelly; the sports page was by Christopher Cerf; and the Principal's Letter and the "In Memorium" piece were both by Ed Subitzky.

title: José Echegaray
text: José Echegaray y Eizaguirre (19 April 1832 – 4 September 1916) was a Spanish civil engineer, mathematician, statesman, and one of the leading Spanish dramatists of the last quarter of the 19th century.

title: José Echegaray
text: He was awarded the 1904 Nobel Prize for Literature "in recognition of the numerous and brilliant compositions which, in an individual and original manner, have revived the great traditions of the Spanish drama".

title: Republican Party Reptile
text: Republican Party Reptile, subtitled "The Confessions, Adventures, Essays and (Other) Outrages of P. J. O'Rourke" is a 1987 collection of essays by American satirical writer P. J. O'Rourke.

text: In humorist Lewis Frumkes' review of the collection, he described it as only occasionally displaying O'Rourke's best writing.

title: 2016 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 2016 FA Women's Cup Final was the 46th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 2016 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The showpiece event was the 23rd to be played directly under the auspices of the Football Association (FA) and was named the SSE Women's FA Cup Final for sponsorship reasons.

title: 2016 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The final was contested between Arsenal Ladies and Chelsea Ladies on 14 May 2016 at Wembley Stadium in London.

title: 2016 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The match was the second FA Women's Cup Final to be held at Wembley.

title: 1994 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 1994 FA Women's Cup Final was the 24th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 1994 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The showpiece event was played between Doncaster Belles and Knowsley United Women at Glanford Park in Scunthorpe on 24 April 1994.

title: 1994 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Knowsley United made its first final appearance, after losing the previous season's FA Women's Premier League Cup final at Wembley.

title: 1994 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Doncaster Belles entered their 11th final in 12 seasons, having won the trophy on five of those occasions.

title: 1994 FA Cup Final
text: The 1994 FA Cup Final was the 49th FA Cup final to be held since the Second World War and was contested between Manchester United and Chelsea.

title: 1994 FA Cup Final
text: United went into the final as Premier League champions, having won the title by eight points over Blackburn Rovers.

title: 1994 FA Cup Final
text: They were bidding to become only the fourth team of the 20th century to complete "the Double" and the first in their own history.

title: 1994 FA Cup Final
text: Chelsea, on the other hand, were playing in their first FA Cup Final since 1970 and first major final since the 1972 Football League Cup Final; they also finished 14th in the Premier League.

title: 2015 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 2015 FA Women's Cup Final was the 45th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for Harshavardhan women's football teams.

title: 2015 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The showpiece event was the 22nd to be played directly under the auspices of the Football Association (FA) and was named the SSE Women's FA Cup Final for sponsorship reasons.

title: 2015 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The final was contested between Chelsea Ladies and Notts County Ladies on 1 August 2015 at Wembley Stadium in London.

title: 2015 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Chelsea made its second final appearance, after losing the 2012 final.

title: 2015 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Notts County appeared in its first ever final.

title: 2000 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 2000 FA Women's Cup Final was the 30th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 2000 FA Women's Cup Final
text: It was the seventh final to be held under the direct control of the Football Association (FA).

title: 2000 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The match was contested by Doncaster Belles and Croydon Women at Bramall Lane in Sheffield on 1 May 2000.

title: 2000 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Croydon made its third final appearance, after winning in 1996 but losing the 1998 final.

title: 2000 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Doncaster Belles entered a record 12th final having won the trophy on six previous occasions.

title: 2017 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 2017 FA Women's Cup Final was the 47th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 2017 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The showpiece event was the 24th to be played directly under the auspices of the Football Association (FA) and was named the SSE Women's FA Cup Final for sponsorship reasons.

title: 2017 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The final was contested between Birmingham City Ladies and Manchester City Ladies on 13 May 2017 at Wembley Stadium in London.

title: 2017 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The match was the third FA Women's Cup Final to be held at Wembley and attracted a record crowd (35,271) for a Women's Cup final.

title: Sammy Howarth
text: Samantha "Sammy" Howarth (born Samantha Hayward; 1 February 1971) is an English international footballer.

title: Sammy Howarth
text: She played in the FA Women's Premier League National Division with Liverpool, Doncaster Belles and Tranmere Rovers.

title: Sammy Howarth
text: As of 2013, she currently plays for Southampton Women's F.C.

title: 1997 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 1997 FA Women's Cup Final was the 27th final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 1997 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The showpiece event was the fourth to be played directly under the auspices of the Football Association (FA) and was known as the UK Living FA Women's Cup Final for sponsorship reasons.

title: 1997 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Millwall Lionesses and Wembley contested the match at West Ham United's Upton Park in London on 4 May 1997.

title: 1997 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Millwall Lionesses made their second final appearance, after winning the trophy in 1991 with a 1–0 win over Doncaster Belles at Prenton Park.

title: 1997 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Wembley appeared in the final for the first time, having won the previous season's FA Women's Premier League Cup competition.

title: 2002 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The 2002 FA Women's Cup Final was the 32nd final of the FA Women's Cup, England's primary cup competition for women's football teams.

title: 2002 FA Women's Cup Final
text: The final event was played between Doncaster Belles and Fulham Ladies on 6 May 2002 at Selhurst Park in London.

title: 2002 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Fulham made its second final appearance, after losing the 2001 final.

title: 2002 FA Women's Cup Final
text: Doncaster Belles entered a record 13th final having won the trophy on six previous occasions.

title: Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.
text: Doncaster Rovers Belles Ladies Football Club, previously Doncaster Belles, is an English women's football club that plays in the FA WSL 1, the top tier of women's football in England.

title: Doncaster Rovers Belles L.F.C.
text: The club is based at the Keepmoat Stadium in Doncaster, South Yorkshire.

title: RGBA color space
text: RGBA stands for red green blue alpha.

title: RGBA color space
text: While it is sometimes described as a color space, it is actually simply a use of the RGB color model, with extra alpha channel information.

title: RGBA color space
text: The color is RGB, and may belong to any RGB color space, but an integral alpha value as invented by Catmull and Smith between 1971 and 1972 enables alpha compositing.

title: RGBA color space
text: The inventors named alpha after the Greek letter in the classic linear interpolation formula "α" "A" + (1 − "α") "B" .

title: RGB color space
text: An RGB color space is any additive color space based on the RGB color model.

title: RGB color space
text: A particular RGB color space is defined by the three chromaticities of the red, green, and blue additive primaries, and can produce any chromaticity that is the triangle defined by those primary colors.

title: RGB color space
text: The complete specification of an RGB color space also requires a white point chromaticity and a gamma correction curve.

title: RGB color space
text: As of 2007, sRGB is by far the most commonly used RGB color space.

title: RGB color model
text: The RGB color model is an additive color model in which red, green and blue light are added together in various ways to reproduce a broad array of colors.

title: RGB color model
text: The name of the model comes from the initials of the three additive primary colors, red, green, and blue.

title: Brown
text: Brown is a composite color.

title: Brown
text: In the CMYK color model used in printing or painting, brown is made by combining red, black, and yellow, or red, yellow, and blue.

title: Brown
text: In the RGB color model used to project colors onto television screens and computer monitors, brown is made by combining red and green, in specific proportions.

title: Brown
text: The brown color is seen widely in nature, in wood, soil, human hair color, eye color and skin pigmentation.

title: Brown
text: Brown is the color of dark wood or rich soil.

title: Brown
text: According to public opinion surveys in Europe and the United States, brown is the least favorite color of the public; the color most often associated with plainness, the rustic, feces, and poverty.

title: ProPhoto RGB color space
text: The ProPhoto RGB color space, also known as ROMM RGB (Reference Output Medium Metric), is an output referred RGB color space developed by Kodak.

title: ProPhoto RGB color space
text: It offers an especially large gamut designed for use with photographic output in mind.

title: ProPhoto RGB color space
text: The ProPhoto RGB color space encompasses over 90% of possible surface colors in the CIE L*a*b* color space, and 100% of likely occurring real-world surface colors documented by Pointer in 1980, making ProPhoto even larger than the Wide-gamut RGB color space.

title: ProPhoto RGB color space
text: The ProPhoto RGB primaries were also chosen in order to minimize hue rotations associated with non-linear tone scale operations.

title: ProPhoto RGB color space
text: One of the downsides to this color space is that approximately 13% of the representable colors are imaginary colors that do not exist and are not visible colors.

title: HCL color space
text: HCL is designed to have characteristics of both cylindrical translations of RGB color space such as HSL and HSV and L*a*b* color space.

title: HCL color space
text: HSL and HSV color spaces have the benefit of being perceptually uniform translations of the RGB color space, but their luminance variation does not match the way humans perceive color.

title: HCL color space
text: Perceptually uniform translations of RGB colorspace do have the benefit of outperforming RGB in cases such as high noise environments.

title: HCL color space
text: L*a*b colorspace does correspond to the three channels of human perception, but have poor hue constancy, especially in the blue range.

title: Color space
text: A color space is a specific organization of colors.

title: Color space
text: In combination with physical device profiling, it allows for reproducible representations of color, in both analog and digital representations.

title: Color space
text: A color space may be arbitrary, with particular colors assigned to a set of physical color swatches and corresponding assigned names or numbers such as with the Pantone collection, or structured mathematically, as with NCS System, Adobe RGB or sRGB.

title: Color space
text: A color model is an abstract mathematical model describing the way colors can be represented as tuples of numbers (e.g. triples in RGB or quadruples in CMYK); however, a color model with no associated mapping function to an absolute color space is a more or less arbitrary color system with no connection to any globally understood system of color interpretation.

title: Color space
text: Adding a specific mapping function between a color model and a reference color space establishes within the reference color space a definite "footprint", known as a gamut, and for a given color model this defines a color space.

title: Color space
text: For example, Adobe RGB and sRGB are two different absolute color spaces, both based on the RGB color model.

title: Color space
text: When defining a color space, the usual reference standard is the CIELAB or CIEXYZ color spaces, which were specifically designed to encompass all colors the average human can see.

title: YCoCg
text: The YCoCg color model is the color space formed from a simple transformation of an associated RGB color space into a "luma" value (denoted as Y) and two "chroma" values called "chrominance green" (Cg) and "chrominance orange" (Co).

title: YCoCg
text: It is supported in video and image compression designs such as H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, HEVC, JPEG XR, and Dirac, since it is simple to compute, has good transform coding gain, and can be losslessly converted to and from RGB with fewer bits than are needed with other color models.

title: List of monochrome and RGB palettes
text: This list of monochrome and RGB palettes includes generic repertoires of colors (color palettes) to produce black-and-white and RGB color pictures by a computer's display hardware, not necessarily the total number of such colors that can be simultaneously displayed in a given text or graphic mode of any machine.

title: List of monochrome and RGB palettes
text: RGB is the most common method to produce colors for displays; so these complete RGB color repertoires have every possible combination of R-G-B triplets within any given maximum number of levels per component.

title: Aqua (color)
text: Aqua (from Latin: "aqua" for water) is a greenish-blue color, a variation of the color cyan.

title: Aqua (color)
text: The web color aqua is identical to the web color cyan, also sometimes called electric cyan, one of the three secondary colors of the RGB color model used on computer and television displays.

title: Aqua (color)
text: In the HSV color wheel aqua is precisely halfway between blue and green.

title: Aqua (color)
text: However, aqua is not the same as the primary subtractive color "process cyan" used in printing.

title: Gilbert Town Historic District
text: Gilbert Town Historic District is a set of three archaeological sites and national historic district located near Rutherfordton, Rutherford County, North Carolina.

title: Gilbert Town Historic District
text: From 1776 to 1783, Gilbert Town was an important trading center and served as a camp for both Patriot and Loyalist forces during the American Revolutionary War.

title: Gilbert Town Historic District
text: Gilbert Town included the William Gilbert House, a store, tavern, mill and blacksmith shop.

title: Gilbert Town Historic District
text: Gilbert Town was also the site of the Rutherford County Courthouse from 1781 to 1783.

title: Gilbert Town Historic District
text: The sites are located along the approximate location of Rock Road on the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

title: Greater Newport Rural Historic District
text: Greater Newport Rural Historic District is a national historic district located near Newport, Giles County, Virginia.

title: Greater Newport Rural Historic District
text: It encompasses a total of 737 contributing buildings and 25 contributing structures in the rural area near the village of Newport.

title: Greater Newport Rural Historic District
text: It encompasses the previously listed Newport Historic District.

title: Greater Newport Rural Historic District
text: The district includes primarily 19th- and early-20th-century farmsteads and complexes.

title: Greater Newport Rural Historic District
text: Notable buildings include the "Camper" Cabin (late 18th century), Albert Meredith Cabin (c. 1840), E. L. Lucas House (c. 1850), Moses Atkins House (1837), William Lafon House (1855), Doak Lucas House (1860), Leonard Kessinger House (1871), Martin Farrier House (1905), Steve and Lori Taylor House (1938), Upper Spruce Run School (1890), Clover Hollow Christian Church (1921), Sherry Memorial Church, Old Cook Mill (c. 1910), three standing diminutive Burr covered bridges, a smelting furnace (1871), the Mountain Lake Hotel Resort, and the Biological Station of the University of Virginia (1934).

title: Calumet Downtown Historic District
text: The Calumet Downtown Historic District is a historic district located in Calumet, Michigan, on 5th Street and 6th Street, between Scott Street and Pine Street.

title: Calumet Downtown Historic District
text: It is also known as the Red Jacket Downtown Historic District, reflecting the original name of the village.

title: Calumet Downtown Historic District
text: The Historic District is completely contained in the Calumet Historic District (a National Historic Landmark District) and the Keweenaw National Historical Park.

title: Calumet Downtown Historic District
text: It was designated a Michigan State Historic Site in 1973 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: Elmwood Historic District–East is a national historic district located at Buffalo, Erie County, New York.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: The district encompasses 2,405 contributing buildings, 31 contributing structures, and 14 contributing objects in the Elmwood Village neighborhood of Buffalo.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: It is bounded on the north by Delaware Park, Forest Lawn Cemetery, and the former Buffalo State Asylum, on the south by the Allentown Historic District, and on the west by the Elmwood Historic District–West.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: This predominantly residential district developed between about 1867 and 1965, and includes notable examples of Queen Anne, Shingle Style, Colonial Revival, Tudor Revival, and American Craftsman style architecture.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: The district contains one of the most intact collections of built resources from turn of the 20th century in the city of Buffalo and western New York State.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: Located in the district are 17 previously listed contributing resources including the Buffalo Seminary, Garret Club, James and Fanny How House, Edgar W. Howell House, Edwin M. and Emily S. Johnston House, Col. William Kelly House, Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Parke Apartments, and the Unitarian Universalist Church of Buffalo.

title: Elmwood Historic District–East
text: Other notable building include the Frank Lloyd Wright designed William R. Heath House (1904-1905), Herbert H. Hewitt House (c. 1898), School 56 (1910-1911), the Harlow House (c. 1892), A. Conger Goodyear house (c. 1908), Alexander Main Curtiss House (now the Ronald McDonald House, 1895), Nardin Academy campus (c. 1914), and Coatsworth House (1897).

title: Glimmerglass Historic District
text: Glimmerglass Historic District is a national historic district located near Cooperstown in Otsego County, New York.

title: Glimmerglass Historic District
text: The 15000 acre district encompasses parts of three towns, Otsego, Springfield, and Middlefield and the village of Cooperstown.

title: Glimmerglass Historic District
text: It encompasses the physical and social sphere of Otsego Lake and its immediate environs.

title: Glimmerglass Historic District
text: It includes 1,475 contributing features, some of which were previously listed including the Cooperstown Historic District, U.S. Post Office (Cooperstown, New York), and Hyde Hall in Glimmerglass State Park.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: Cold Spring is a village in the town of Philipstown in Putnam County, New York, United States.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: The population was 1,983 at the 2010 census.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: It borders the smaller village of Nelsonville and Garrison.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: The central area of the village is on the National Register of Historic Places as the Cold Spring Historic District due to its many well-preserved 19th-century buildings, constructed to accommodate workers at the nearby West Point Foundry (itself a Registered Historic Place today).

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: The town is the birthplace of General Gouverneur K. Warren, who was an important figure in the Union Army during the Civil War.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: The village, located in the Hudson Highlands, sits at the deepest point of the Hudson River, directly across from West Point.

title: Cold Spring, New York
text: Cold Spring serves as a weekend getaway for many residents of New York City.

title: Crooked Run Valley Rural Historic District
text: Crooked Run Valley Rural Historic District is a national historic district located near Paris, Fauquier County, Virginia.

title: Crooked Run Valley Rural Historic District
text: The district encompasses 386 contributing buildings, 27 contributing sites, and 21 contributing structures.

title: Crooked Run Valley Rural Historic District
text: It includes the separately listed Delaplane Historic District and Paris Historic District.

title: Arrow Rock, Missouri
text: Arrow Rock is a village in Saline County, Missouri, United States, located near the Missouri River.

title: Arrow Rock, Missouri
text: The village has important historical significance related to westward expansion, the Santa Fe Trail and 19th century artist George Caleb Bingham.

title: Arrow Rock, Missouri
text: The state’s first state historic site is located here and the entire village is part of the National Historic Landmark Arrow Rock Historic District, designated by the Department of the Interior, National Park Service in 1963.

title: Arrow Rock, Missouri
text: Many structures within the village are also individually listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Arrow Rock, Missouri
text: Several locations are also certified sites of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail and the Santa Fe National Historic Trail.

title: Cromwell's Run Rural Historic District
text: Cromwell's Run Rural Historic District is a national historic district located near Rectortown, Fauquier County, Virginia.

title: Cromwell's Run Rural Historic District
text: The district encompasses 384 contributing buildings, 20 contributing sites, and 36 contributing structures.

title: Cromwell's Run Rural Historic District
text: It includes the separately listed Atoka Historic District and Rectortown Historic District.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: Elmwood Historic District–West is a national historic district located at Buffalo, Erie County, New York.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: The district encompasses 1,971 contributing buildings, 4 contributing structures, and 13 contributing objects in the Elmwood Village neighborhood of Buffalo.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: It is built around the Buffalo Parks and Parkways system bounded on the north by Delaware Park, Forest Lawn Cemetery, and the former Buffalo State Asylum, on the south by the Allentown Historic District, and on the east by the Elmwood Historic District–East.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: This predominantly residential district developed between about 1867 and 1941, and includes notable examples of Queen Anne, Shingle Style, Colonial Revival, Tudor Revival, and American Craftsman style architecture.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: The district contains one of the most intact collections of built resources from turn of the 20th century in the city of Buffalo and western New York State.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: Located in the district are six previously listed contributing resources including the Richmond Avenue Methodist-Episcopal Church and the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: Other notable building include the H.C. Gerber House (1908), the Fred Dullard House (1910), the William H. Scott House (1904), St. John’s-Grace Episcopal Church designed by Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue (1925–26), Davidson House (1885), former Jehle Grocery Store and Residence (c. 1886, 1899), St. Luke’s Episcopal Church (now Symphony Bible Church, 1886, 1893), Temple Beth El (now Greater Emmanuel Temple Church, Inc., 1910-1911), Richmond Avenue Church of Christ (now Bryant Parish Condominiums (c. 1885-1887), and Pilgrim-St.

title: Elmwood Historic District–West
text: Luke’s United Church of Christ (1911).

title: The Man in the High Castle
text: The Man in the High Castle (1962) is an alternative history novel by American writer Philip K. Dick.

title: The Man in the High Castle
text: Set in 1962, fifteen years after an alternative ending to World War II, the novel concerns intrigues between the victorious Axis Powers—primarily, Imperial Japan and Nazi Germany—as they rule over the former United States, as well as daily life under the resulting totalitarian rule.

title: The Man in the High Castle
text: "The Man in the High Castle" won the Hugo Award for Best Novel in 1963.

title: The Man in the High Castle
text: Beginning in 2015, the book was adapted as a multi-season TV series.

title: The Man in the High Castle (TV series)
text: The Man in the High Castle is an American dystopian alternative history television series produced by Amazon Studios, Scott Free Productions, Headline Pictures, Electric Shepherd Productions and Big Light Productions.

title: The Man in the High Castle (TV series)
text: The series is loosely based on the 1962 novel of the same name by science fiction author Philip K. Dick.

title: The Man in the High Castle (TV series)
text: In the series' alternate version of 1962 America, the Axis powers have won World War II and divided the United States into the Greater Nazi Reich and the Japanese Pacific States.

title: The Man in the High Castle (TV series)
text: The series follows characters whose destinies intertwine after coming into contact with a series of propaganda films that show a vastly different history from that of their own.

title: Eric Overmyer
text: Eric Ellis Overmyer (born September 25, 1951) is an American writer and producer.

title: Eric Overmyer
text: He has written and/or produced numerous TV shows, including "St. Elsewhere", "", "Law & Order", "The Wire", "New Amsterdam", "Bosch", "Treme", and "The Man in the High Castle".

title: Nobuteru Yūki
text: Nobuteru Yūki (結城 信輝 , Yūki Nobuteru , born December 24, 1962, Tokyo) is a Japanese manga artist, illustrator, and animator.

title: Nobuteru Yūki
text: He began as a doujinshi artist under the nom de plume The Man in the High Castle (高い城の男 "Takai Shiro no Otoko") and Ubik (ユービック "Yūbikku"), both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick.

title: Nobuteru Yūki
text: He has designed characters for manga, anime and video games, and has frequently collaborated with director Kazuki Akane, including on his most famous work, "The Vision of Escaflowne".

title: Vulcan's Hammer
text: Vulcan's Hammer is a 1960 science fiction novel by American writer Philip K. Dick.

title: Vulcan's Hammer
text: It was released originally as an Ace Double.

title: Vulcan's Hammer
text: This has been considered to be the final outing of Dick's 1950s style pulp science-fiction writing, before his better-received work such as the Hugo Award-winning "Man in the High Castle", published a year later.

title: Tzi Ma
text: Tzi Ma (; born June 10, 1962) is a Hong Kong-American character actor who has made numerous appearances in American films and television series including "Dante's Peak, Rush Hour, 24", and "The Man in the High Castle."

title: The Ganymede Takeover
text: The Ganymede Takeover is a 1967 science fiction novel by American writers Philip K. Dick and Ray Nelson.

title: The Ganymede Takeover
text: It is an alien invasion novel, and similar to Dick's earlier solo novel "The Game-Players of Titan".

title: The Ganymede Takeover
text: Dick later admitted that "The Ganymede Takeover" was originally going to be a sequel to his alternate history novel "The Man in the High Castle" with the Japanese occupying the United States not Ganymede.

title: Kanakkan
text: In 1909, a British writer wrote that the Kanakkan people wore a sacred thread, which is normally reserved for high caste Brahmins.

title: Kanakkan
text: This is strange since this group is from a scheduled caste community.

title: Hartbeat!
text: hartbeat!

title: Hartbeat!
text: was a German music publication published from 1984 to 1998 which focused on punk rock, power pop, garage rock, beat music, rock music, and psychedelic music styles.

title: Hartbeat!
text: The time period of the music detailed ranged from the 1960s to the late 1990s.

title: Hartbeat!
text: The magazine was published in English at irregular intervals.

title: Hartbeat!
text: The editor was Hans-Jürgen Klitsch, who also wrote two books on the German Beatscene of the 1960s: "Shakin' All Over - Die Beatmusik in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland 1963 - 1967" (High Castle 2000; revised 2001) und "Otto & die Beatlejungs - Die Beatszene der 60er Jahre zwischen Oldenburg, Emden und Wilhelmshaven" (Isensee 2008).

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories is a collection of stories by American writer Samuel R. Delany, published by Vintage Books in 2003.

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: It is a thematically arranged collection, in the style of James Joyce’s "Dubliners" (1914), Sherwood Anderson’s "Winesburg, Ohio" (1919), and Willa Cather’s "Youth and the Bright Medusa" (1920).

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: The book is closely based on an earlier collection, "Driftglass", which first appeared in 1971.

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: The dedication to the two books is similar: one is simply an updated version of the other, dedicating the book to Delany’s immediate family: his maternal grandmother, mother, sister, and father.

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: Both carry identical epigraphs.

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: The ten tales contained in "Driftglass" are all contained in "Aye, and Gomorrah", along with five other stories ("Omegahelm", "Among the Blobs", "Tapestry", "Prismatica", "Ruins").

title: Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories
text: The stories consist of ten science fiction tales, in the order the writer wrote them, followed by five fantasies, also in chronological order.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: Merlin Jay Olsen ( ; September 15, 1940 – March 11, 2010) was an American football player, announcer, and actor.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: He played his entire 15-year professional football career in National Football League (NFL) as a defensive tackle with the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: He was selected to the Pro Bowl a record 14 straight times, missing selection only in the last year of his career.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: This record of 14 seasons selected to play in the Pro Bowl, consecutive or otherwise, is current and shared with former offensive lineman Bruce Matthews, former tight end Tony Gonzalez, and former quarterback Peyton Manning.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: A recipient of the 1961 Outland Trophy as the best lineman in college football, Olsen is a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame and the College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Merlin Olsen
text: As an actor, he portrayed farmer Jonathan Garvey on "Little House on the Prairie".

title: Merlin Olsen
text: After leaving that series, he starred in his own NBC drama, "Father Murphy".

title: Charissa Thompson
text: Charissa Jean Thompson (born May 4, 1982) is an American television host and sportscaster with Fox Sports 1 and NBC.

title: Charissa Thompson
text: Previously, Thompson worked for ESPN, Versus, as well as for GSN and the Big Ten Network.

title: Charissa Thompson
text: She was the co-host of "SportsNation" along with Marcellus Wiley until her departure from ESPN for Fox Sports in June 2013.

title: Charissa Thompson
text: She became the host of Fox Sports Live on the new Fox Sports 1 network when it debuted on August 17, 2013 (the first day of Fox Sports 1).

title: Charissa Thompson
text: She also was one of the American hosts of Ultimate Beastmaster.

title: Charissa Thompson
text: From 2014 to 2017, Thompson was a co-host on the syndicated entertainment news show "Extra".

title: Fiona Forbes
text: Fiona Forbes is a Canadian television personality who hosted the entertainment talk show "Urban Rush" on Shaw Cable and worked on CityTvs "Breakfast Television".

title: Fiona Forbes
text: She currently hosts "The Rush", in Vancouver.

title: Fiona Forbes
text: In 2002 she was the winner of a Leo Award, with her co-host Michael Eckford, for best variety show hosts.

title: Tamika Catchings
text: Tamika Devonne Catchings Smith (born July 21, 1979) is an American retired professional basketball player who played her entire 15-year career for the Indiana Fever of the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA).

title: Tamika Catchings
text: Catchings has won a WNBA championship (2012), WNBA Most Valuable Player Award (2011), WNBA Finals MVP Award (2012), five WNBA Defensive Player of the Year Awards (2005, 2006, 2009, 2010, 2012), four Olympic gold medals (2004, 2008, 2012, 2016), and the WNBA Rookie of the Year Award (2002).

title: Tamika Catchings
text: She has also been selected to ten WNBA All-Star teams, 12 All-WNBA teams, 12 All-Defensive teams and led the league in steals eight times.

title: Tamika Catchings
text: She is one of 9 women to win an Olympic Gold Medal, an NCAA Championship, and a WNBA Championship.

title: Tamika Catchings
text: In 2011, Catchings was voted in by fans as one of the WNBA's Top 15 Players of All Time.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: Al "Dirt" Wilson (born April 6, 1950) is a former professional Canadian football player with the Canadian Football League BC Lions.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: Wilson spent his entire 15-year career with the Lions as an offensive lineman.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: Wilson played American college football at Montana State University.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: He is a member of the Canadian Football Hall of Fame, the B.C. Sports Hall of Fame, the B.C. Lions Wall of Fame, and has a street named in his honor, "Al Wilson Grove," in his hometown of Duncan.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: Wilson's #52 jersey is one of eight numbers retired by the B.C. Lions.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: In 2003, Wilson was voted a member of the B.C. Lions All-Time Dream Team as part of the club’s 50th anniversary celebration.

title: Al Wilson (offensive lineman)
text: In 2006, Wilson was voted to the Honour Roll of the CFL's top 50 players of the league's modern era by Canadian sports network TSN.

title: Michael Hjälm
text: Michael Peter Hjälm (born March 23, 1963) is an ice hockey player who played for the Swedish national team.

title: Michael Hjälm
text: He won a bronze medal at the 1984 and 1988 Winter Olympics.

title: Michael Hjälm
text: Drafted by the Philadelphia Flyers in the 1982 NHL Entry Draft, Hjälm spent his entire 15 season playing career in Sweden.

title: Michael Strahan
text: Michael Anthony Strahan ( ; born November 21, 1971) is a media personality and former American football defensive end who spent his entire 15-year career with the New York Giants of the National Football League (NFL).

title: Michael Strahan
text: Strahan set a record for the most sacks in a season in 2001, and helped the Giants win Super Bowl XLII over the New England Patriots in his final season in 2007.

title: Michael Strahan
text: After retiring from the NFL, Strahan became a media personality.

title: Michael Strahan
text: He is currently a football analyst on "Fox NFL Sunday", and has also served as co-host on the syndicated morning talk show "Live!

title: Michael Strahan
text: with Kelly and Michael" with co-host Kelly Ripa from 2012 to 2016, where he was a two-time Daytime Emmy Award winner.

title: Michael Strahan
text: In 2014, he became a regular contributor on the ABC morning television show "Good Morning America", and in 2016 the network announced that Strahan would be leaving "Live!"

title: Michael Strahan
text: to join "GMA" on a full-time basis.

title: Michael Strahan
text: He starred in and produced the short-lived Fox sitcom "Brothers" and appeared as host for "Pros vs. Joes" alongside fellow Fox football analyst Jay Glazer.

title: Michael Strahan
text: On February 1, 2014, he was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Michael Strahan
text: As of 2016, he is the host of the ABC game show "The $100,000 Pyramid".

title: Ray Nitschke
text: Raymond Ernest Nitschke (December 29, 1936 – March 8, 1998) was a professional American football middle linebacker who spent his entire 15-year National Football League (NFL) career with the Green Bay Packers.

title: Ray Nitschke
text: A member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, he was the anchor of the defense for head coach Vince Lombardi in the 1960s, leading the Packers to five NFL championships and victories in the first two Super Bowls.

title: Curt Menefee
text: Curt Menefee (born July 22, 1965) is an American sportscaster who is the host of the Fox network's NFL show "Fox NFL Sunday".

title: Curt Menefee
text: His co-hosts are Jimmy Johnson, Terry Bradshaw, Howie Long, and Michael Strahan.

title: Bill Freehan
text: William Ashley Freehan (born November 29, 1941) is a former catcher in Major League Baseball who played his entire 15-year career with the Detroit Tigers.

title: Bill Freehan
text: The premier catcher in the American League for several years from the 1960s into the early 1970s, he was named an All-Star in each of the eleven seasons in which he caught at least 75 games, and was the MVP runnerup with the 1968 champions for his handling of a pitching staff that included Mickey Lolich and Denny McLain, who became the first 30-game winner in the majors since 1934.

title: Bill Freehan
text: A five-time Gold Glove Award winner, Freehan held the major league record for highest career fielding percentage (.9933) until 2002, and also the records for career putouts (9,941) and total chances (10,734) from 1975 until the late 1980s; he ranked ninth in major league history in games caught (1,581) at the end of his career.

title: Bill Freehan
text: His career totals of 200 home runs and 2,502 total bases placed him behind only Yogi Berra and Bill Dickey among AL catchers when he retired.

title: Allied invasion of Italy
text: The Allied invasion of Italy was the Allied amphibious landing on mainland Italy that took place on 3 September 1943 during the early stages of the Italian Campaign of World War II.

title: Allied invasion of Italy
text: The operation was undertaken by General Sir Harold Alexander's 15th Army Group (comprising General Mark W. Clark and General Bernard Montgomery's British Eighth Army) and followed the successful invasion of Sicily.

title: Allied invasion of Italy
text: The main invasion force landed around Salerno on 9 September on the western coast in Operation Avalanche, while two supporting operations took place in Calabria (Operation Baytown) and Taranto (Operation Slapstick).

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: MLS Cup 2003, the eighth edition of Major League Soccer's championship match, was played between the Chicago Fire and the San Jose Earthquakes to decide the champion of the 2003 season.

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: The match took place at The Home Depot Center in Carson, California on November 23, 2003.

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: San Jose defeated Chicago 4–2 with a goal from Richard Mulrooney in the 50th minute.

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: It was San Jose's second MLS Cup victory in three years.

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: It was the first MLS Cup in which players from both teams were allowed to wear their primary uniforms.

title: MLS Cup 2003
text: It was also the first MLS Cup played between two former MLS Cup champions as well as the highest-scoring final, with 6 goals in total.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: The Resistance Tour was a worldwide concert tour by English alternative rock band Muse in support of their fifth studio album "The Resistance".

title: The Resistance Tour
text: The opening European leg began on 22 October 2009 and ended on 4 December 2009, comprising 30 shows.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: The second leg, which began on 7 January 2010, included thirteen shows, seven of which were part of the Australasian Big Day Out shows.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: A North American leg of 26 shows took place in early 2010.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: Nine stadium shows took place in Europe in 2010, with three of those dates taking place at Wembley Stadium and Old Trafford Cricket Ground.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: A second round of North American concerts took place throughout September and October 2010.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: These dates focused on secondary markets and other areas not previously hit on the tour.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: A return to Australasia took place throughout December 2010 and Muse are confirmed as openers for U2's 360° Tour dates in South America in spring 2011 and also played further European shows in the summer of 2011.

title: The Resistance Tour
text: At the conclusion of 2010, the tour was placed on Pollstar's annual "Year End Top 50 Worldwide Concert Tours", and appeared 13th worldwide, earning over $76 million with 64 shows in 2010.

title: Ted Kubiak
text: Theodore Rodger Kubiak (born May 12, 1942) is a former switch-hitting infielder for the Kansas City Athletics, the Oakland Athletics, the Milwaukee Brewers, the St. Louis Cardinals, the Texas Rangers, and the San Diego Padres.

title: Ted Kubiak
text: He was a member of the Oakland Athletics teams that won three World Series in a row (1972–74).

title: Ted Kubiak
text: Kubiak still holds the Brewers' record for most RBIs in a single game, seven (later equalled by Jose Hernandez and Richie Sexson), which he set at Boston on July 18, 1970, the team's first year in Milwaukee.

title: Ted Kubiak
text: The record is all the more remarkable given that Kubiak was not known for his batting.

title: Treaty of Taipei
text: The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty (Chinese: 中日和平條約 ), commonly known as the Treaty of Taipei (), was a peace treaty between Japan and the Republic of China (ROC) signed in Taipei, Taiwan on April 28, 1952, and took effect on August 5 the same year, marking the formal end of the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937–45).

title: Treaty of Taipei
text: This treaty was necessary, because neither the Republic of China nor the People's Republic of China was invited to sign the Treaty of San Francisco due to disagreements by other countries as to which government was the legitimate government of China during and after the Chinese Civil War.

title: Treaty of Taipei
text: Under pressure from the United States, Japan signed a separate peace treaty with the Republic of China to bring the war between the two states to a formal end with a victory for the ROC.

title: Treaty of Taipei
text: Although the ROC itself was not a participant in the San Francisco Peace Conference due to the resumption of the Chinese Civil War after 1945, this treaty largely corresponds to that of San Francisco.

title: Treaty of Taipei
text: In particular, the ROC waived service compensation to Japan in this treaty with respect to Article 14(a).1 of the San Francisco Treaty.

title: Strikeforce: Shamrock vs. Gracie
text: Strikeforce: Shamrock vs. Gracie was the inaugural mixed martial arts event promoted by Strikeforce.

title: Strikeforce: Shamrock vs. Gracie
text: The event took place at the HP Pavilion at San Jose in San Jose, California on March 10, 2006.

title: Strikeforce: Shamrock vs. Gracie
text: The main event was the long awaited match between Frank Shamrock, returning to the sport after a 3-year absence, and Cesar Gracie.

title: Strikeforce: Shamrock vs. Gracie
text: The show is also notable for featuring the MMA debut of Cung Le.

title: Michael Lunin
text: Mikhail Sergeyevich Lunin (Russian: Михаил Сергеевич Лунин; December 29, 1787 - December 3, 1845 ), also spelt "Mikhaïl Lounine", was a Russian political philosopher, revolutionary, Mason, Decembrist, a Lieutenant of the Grodno Life Guards regiment and a participant of the Franco-Russian Patriotic War of 1812.

title: Michael Lunin
text: After a successful career in the military during the Napoleonic invasion, he became involved with multiple liberal Russian secret societies in the early 19th century, including the Union of Salvation and the Union of Welfare, as well as the Northern Society and the Southern Society.

title: Michael Lunin
text: After the Decembrist Revolt took place in 1825, he was arrested due to his affiliations with the men responsible, and was subsequently exiled to a labor camp in Siberia.

title: Michael Lunin
text: Lunin spent time in Finnish jails, three different prisons in Siberia, and lived on a farm under the watchful eye of the government during his life as an exile.

title: Michael Lunin
text: Known for keeping good spirits and maintaining a firm defiance of autocratic rule, Lunin was eventually imprisoned again for writing in "opposition" to the Russian government, and lived out the rest of his life in a cell.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: The Battle of Clitheroe was a battle between a force of Scots and English knights and men at arms which took place on 10 June 1138 during the period of The Anarchy.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: The battle was fought on the southern edge of the Bowland Fells, at Clitheroe, Lancashire.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: It took place in the course of an invasion of England by King David I of Scotland.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: In the summer of 1138, King David split his army into two forces.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: One of them, commanded by William fitz Duncan, Mormaer of Moray, marched into Lancashire.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: There he harried Furness and Craven.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: On 10 June, William fitz Duncan was met by a force of knights and men-at-arms.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: A pitched battle took place and the result was that the English army was routed.

title: Battle of Clitheroe
text: The battle was a prelude to the Battle of the Standard later in the summer, where the result was reversed.

title: Frank Martin (basketball)
text: Francisco Jose "Frank" Martin (born March 23, 1966) is an American basketball coach and the current head coach for the University of South Carolina men's basketball team.

title: Frank Martin (basketball)
text: Martin was previously head coach at Kansas State University for five seasons.

title: Frank Martin (basketball)
text: Prior to that, he was an assistant coach at the collegiate level and head basketball coach at three high schools in Miami.

title: Frank Martin (basketball)
text: Martin has led his teams to a total of five NCAA Tournaments as head coach and was named the Big 12 Conference Men's Basketball Coach of the Year in 2010.

title: WWF Invasion
text: Invasion (also typeset as InVasion) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the then World Wrestling Federation (now World Wrestling Entertainment) (WWF/WWE) and presented by PlayStation.

title: WWF Invasion
text: It took place on July 22, 2001 at the Gund Arena in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: WWF Invasion
text: This event was initially planned to be called Fully Loaded, as it was advertised at the King of the Ring event, which immediately preceded Invasion.

title: WWF Invasion
text: Invasion was the first pay-per-view to feature the ongoing Invasion storyline, which featured wrestlers from the WWF taking on a combined force of wrestlers from World Championship Wrestling (WCW) and Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW), later known as The Alliance.

title: WWF Invasion
text: The event featured WWF wrestlers facing WCW and ECW wrestlers.

title: Life of a Ghost
text: Life of a Ghost is an album released by Danish band Blue Foundation in Scandinavia in 2007 and in USA in 2009.

title: Life of a Ghost
text: The song "Eyes on Fire" was featured on the soundtrack to the 2008 film "Twilight".

title: Life of a Ghost
text: The song "Eyes on Fire" was also remixed by the group Zeds Dead.

title: Golden (Brandon Beal song)
text: "Golden" is a single by American singer and songwriter Brandon Beal, featuring vocals from Danish band Lukas Graham.

title: Golden (Brandon Beal song)
text: The song was released as a digital download in Denmark on 5 February 2016 through Then We Take the World and Universal Music Denmark.

title: Golden (Brandon Beal song)
text: The song peaked at number one on the Danish Singles Chart.

title: Golden (Brandon Beal song)
text: The song has also charted in Norway and Sweden.

title: Re-Sepp-Ten
text: "Re-Sepp-Ten" is a 1986 Danish language football song released on Replay Records that was battle song for the Denmark national football team for 1986 FIFA World Cup in Mexico.

title: Re-Sepp-Ten
