text: Based on its proprietary game engine technologies, they are building various applications and are also working with licensed clients who use ParaEngine in their projects.

title: ParaEngine
text: They believe that game technology is the driving force to a new 3D Internet or Web3D.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: Zero is a proprietary game engine created by Pandemic Studios.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: It was used first in the game "" and later used in several "Star Wars" games including the popular "Battlefront" series.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: "Battlezone II: Combat Commander" and "Dark Reign 2" both feature an in-engine editor accessible via commands.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: The engine was revamped for "" to accommodate consoles and third person gameplay.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: The engine was again retooled for "" and the level editor was made a separate entity from the game engine.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: A set of modding tools including ZeroEdit, the new level creation tool, were released for use with "Star Wars: Battlefront" on December 23, 2004.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: An updated version of the tools were released on February 2, 2006 for "".

title: Zero (game engine)
text: Pandemic used Zero as their primary engine for several of their games developed in their Los Angeles, California studio.

title: Zero (game engine)
text: A modified version of the Zero engine was also used in Pandemic's "Mercenaries 2: World in Flames".

title: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare
text: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare is a first-person shooter video game developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision.

title: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare
text: The fourth installment in the "Call of Duty" series, it was released in 2007 for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and Microsoft Windows.

title: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare
text: The game breaks away from the World War II setting of previous entries in the series and is instead set in modern times.

title: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare
text: Developed for over two years, the game uses a proprietary game engine.

title: Charlie Murder
text: Charlie Murder is an action role-playing beat 'em up video game developed by Ska Studios and published by Microsoft Game Studios for the Xbox 360 and Ska Studios for PC.

title: Charlie Murder
text: First revealed in January 2010 as an Xbox Live Indie Games title, the studio announced in May 2010 that the game would undergo a "complete overhaul" and be published in 2012 through Xbox Live Arcade for the Xbox 360.

title: Charlie Murder
text: "Charlie Murder" was eventually released on 14 August 2013 to positive reviews, with critics praising the game's soundtrack and hand-illustrated visuals.

title: Charlie Murder
text: Versions for Microsoft Windows, Linux and macOS were released on May 12, 2017 via Steam.

title: Rana Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The Rana Power Station ("Rana kraftverk") is a hydroelectric power station located in Rana, Nordland, Norway.

title: Rana Hydroelectric Power Station
text: It operates at an installed capacity of 500 MW , with an average annual production of about 2,100 GWh.

title: Rana Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The station is owned by Statkraft.

title: Rana Hydroelectric Power Station
text: In terms of annual production in Norway the station is second only to Svartisen Hydroelectric Power Station.

title: Sima Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The Sima Power Station is a hydroelectric power station located in the municipality Eidfjord in Hordaland, Norway.

title: Sima Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The facility Lang-Sima operates at an installed capacity of 500 MW , and has an average annual production of 1,212 GWh.

title: Sima Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The facility Sy-Sima has an installed capacity of 620 MW , and an average annual production of 1,640 GWh.

title: Sima Hydroelectric Power Station
text: Operator is Statkraft.

title: Svartisen Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The Svartisen Power Station is a hydroelectric power station located in the municipality Meløy in Nordland, Norway.

title: Svartisen Hydroelectric Power Station
text: It operates at an installed capacity of 600 MW , with an average annual production of about 2,200 GWh making it the largest in Norway in terms of annual production.

title: Svartisen Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The station is owned by Statkraft.

title: Wengie
text: Wendy Ayche (born January 9 1986) known professionally as Wengie, is an Australian YouTube personality and vlogger.

title: Wengie
text: She was born in Guangzhou, China.

title: Wengie
text: She got the nickname "Wengie" at a dance class when two people gave her a nickname inspired by her Chinese name, Wén Jié.

title: Wengie
text: Since starting her channel on February 11 2013, her videos have received over 281 million views, and her channel has accumulated over 11 followers In the January 2016 edition of "ElleGirl Japan", she was nominated as a channel to watch.

title: Wengie
text: In August 2016, she was ranked the 5th Fastest growing channel in the world.

title: Wengie
text: Ayche was featured in the annual YouTube Rewind in 2016 and was also singled out by Google as one of the top beauty creators in the Asia region.

title: Wengie
text: Ayche reached 5 million YouTube subscribers in January 2017, and her channel is currently in the 12th most subscribed How-To & Style Channel on YouTube.

title: Wengie
text: She is also currently a board member of the Internet Creators Guild, a non-profit focused on providing the protection, representation and guidance to online creators.

title: Wengie
text: Her YouTube channel also recently got awarded with "Best Channel" as well as "Overall Winner" for the Australian Online Video Awards.

title: Nore Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The Nore Power Station is a hydroelectric power station located in the municipality Nore og Uvdal in Buskerud, Norway.

title: Nore Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The oldest plant Nore I operates at an installed capacity of 206 MW , with an average annual production of 1,110 GWh.

title: Nore Hydroelectric Power Station
text: The plant Nore II has an installed capacity of 52 MW , with an average annual production of 314 GWh.

title: Blast! (musical)
text: Blast!

title: Blast! (musical)
text: is a Broadway production created by James Mason for Cook Group Incorporated, the director and organization formerly operating the Star of Indiana Drum and Bugle Corps.

title: Blast! (musical)
text: It was the 2001 winner of the Tony Award for "Best Special Theatrical Event" and also won the 2001 Emmy Award for "Best Choreography".

title: Apostle (production company)
text: Apostle is a New York-based production company specializing in television production created by stand-up comedian and actor Denis Leary and his business partner Jim Serpico.

title: Apostle (production company)
text: Apostle created the hit TV series "Rescue Me" about a post-9/11 FDNY crew and the drama in their personal lives.

title: Tubular Bells for Two
text: Tubular Bells for Two is a music-theatre production created and performed by Australian multi-instrumentalists Aidan Roberts and Daniel Holdsworth.

title: Tubular Bells for Two
text: In the show the two musicians re-create Mike Oldfield's 1973 album "Tubular Bells" live with over twenty instruments.

title: Tubular Bells for Two
text: They won The Sydney Fringe award for 'Best Musical Moment' in 2010, and have since featured at major arts festivals around Australia and the Pacific, including Sydney Festival and NZ International Arts Festival.

title: Tubular Bells for Two
text: The production made its European début at the 2012 Edinburgh Festival Fringe where it won two awards, going on to tour Europe in 2013 for the 40th anniversary of the original Oldfield album.

title: Automotive industry in Brazil
text: The Brazilian automotive industry competed with other Latin American ones (Mexico and Argentina) comparably till 1960, but had two jumps then, making Brazil as a regional leader at first and one of the World's leaders moreover.

title: Automotive industry in Brazil
text: Near the end of the 1970s new capacities were built by US and Germany.

title: Automotive industry in Brazil
text: In addition to available and annual production, which exceeded one million and provided world's 10th place for country.

title: Automotive industry in Brazil
text: After some decrease near 1990, the new and more strong growth by help of same foreign players plus Japan and France allows Brazil to beat such old auto makers as Belgium, United Kingdom, United States, Canada, Russia, Spain, France and annual production exceeded 3,7 million vehicles in 2013 seventh largest in the World, although they have fallen substantially more recently.

title: Return to Eden
text: Return to Eden is an Australian television drama/soap opera mini-series and later weekly serial starring Rebecca Gilling, James Reyne, Wendy Hughes and James Smillie.

title: Return to Eden
text: It began as a three-part six hour mini-series, shown on Network Ten in 1983.

title: Return to Eden
text: Gilling and Smillie, now joined by Peta Toppano would reprise their roles for a 22-part weekly series screened in 1986.

title: Return to Eden
text: The Production created by Michael Laurence was successful international, particularly in France, and has been shown 13 times.

title: Archdeaconry of St Andrews
text: The Archdeaconry of St Andrews was a sub-division of the diocese of St Andrews, one of two archdeaconries within the diocese.

title: Archdeaconry of St Andrews
text: The St Andrews archdeaconry was headed by the Archdeacon of St Andrews, a subordinate of the Bishop of St Andrews.

title: Archdeaconry of St Andrews
text: In the medieval period, the Archdeaconry of St Andrews contained five deaneries with a total of 124 parish churches.

title: Archdeaconry of St Andrews
text: The deaneries were Mearns (14 churches), Angus (38 churches), Gowrie (20 churches), Fife (28 churches) and Fothriff (24 churches).

title: Prior of St Andrews
text: The Prior of St Andrews was the head of the property and community of Augustinian canons of St Andrews Cathedral Priory, St Andrews, Fife, Scotland.

title: Prior of St Andrews
text: It was established by King David I in 1140 with canons from Nostell Priory, West Yorkshire.

title: Prior of St Andrews
text: It is possible that, initially at least, the prior of St Andrews was subordinate to the bishop as abbot, but by the 13th century the canons of St Andrews were given freedom by the bishop to elect their prior.

title: Prior of St Andrews
text: By the end of the 13th century, the abbacy of the native canons (i.e. the "Céli Dé", or Culdees) was no longer there to challenge the position of the priory, and the native canons themselves had been formed into a collegiate church.

title: University of St Andrews
text: The University of St Andrews (informally known as St Andrews University or simply St Andrews; abbreviated as St And, from the Latin "Sancti Andreae", in post-nominals) is a British public research university in St Andrews, Fife, Scotland.

title: University of St Andrews
text: It is the oldest of the four ancient universities of Scotland and the third oldest university in the English-speaking world (following Oxford and Cambridge Universities).

title: University of St Andrews
text: St Andrews was founded between 1410 and 1413, when the Avignon Antipope Benedict XIII issued a papal bull to a small founding group of Augustinian clergy.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: There are thirty-two medical schools in the United Kingdom that are recognised by the General Medical Council and from which students can obtain a medical degree.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: There are twenty-four such schools in England, five in Scotland, two in Wales and one in Northern Ireland.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: All but Warwick Medical School and Swansea Medical School offer undergraduate courses in medicine.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: The Bute Medical School (University of St Andrews) and Durham Medical School offer undergraduate pre-clinical courses only, with students proceeding to another medical school for clinical studies.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: Although Oxford University and Cambridge University offer both pre-clinical and clinical courses in medicine, students who study pre-clinical medicine at one of these universities may move to another university for clinical studies.

title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
text: At other universities students stay at the same university for both pre-clinical and clinical work.

title: Pulham Market
text: Pulham Market and its sister village Pulham St Mary are situated approximately 9 miles (14.5 kilometres) north of Diss in Norfolk, England.

title: Pulham Market
text: It covers an area of 12.08 km2 and had a population of 999 in 443 households as of the 2001 census, the population falling to 977 at the 2011 Census.

title: St Andrews Links
text: St Andrews Links in the town of St Andrews, Fife, Scotland, is regarded as the "Home of Golf".

title: St Andrews Links
text: It has one of the oldest courses in the world, where the game has been played since the 15th century.

title: St Andrews Links
text: Today there are seven public golf courses; the Balgove, Eden, Jubilee, Strathtyrum, New, the Old Course (which is widely considered one of the finest, and certainly the most famous and traditional course in the world), and The Castle Course, sited on the cliffs a mile to the east of St Andrews and designed by the architect David McLay Kidd, which opened in June 2008.

title: St Andrews Links
text: The courses of St Andrews Links are owned by the local authorities and operated by St Andrews Links Trust, a charitable organization.

title: St Andrews Links
text: St Andrews is also home to the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews, one of the most prestigious golf clubs and until 2004 one of the two rulemaking authorities of golf (in that year, the Royal and Ancient Club passed on its rulemaking authority to an offshoot organisation, The R&A).

title: John MacGregor
text: John MacGregor, John Macgregor or John McGregor may refer to:

title: John MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market
text: John Roddick Russell MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market, OBE PC FKC (born 14 February 1937), is a politician in the United Kingdom.

title: John MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market
text: He was educated at Merchiston Castle School, then at the University of St Andrews (MA economics and history, 1959) and at King's College London (LLB, 1962).

title: John MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market
text: Prior to the 1979 general election he worked for Hill Samuel, a merchant bank.

title: University of St Andrews Boat Club
text: The University of St Andrews Boat Club, founded in 1965, is the rowing team affiliated to the University of St Andrews.

title: University of St Andrews Boat Club
text: Operating under the University of St Andrews Athletic Union, the University of St Andrews Boat Club (also known as UStABC) competes in head races and regattas across Scotland and England, including the Head of the River Race (London), British University Championships 'BUCS' Regatta and Henley Royal Regatta.

title: University of St Andrews Boat Club
text: Its national governing body is Scottish Rowing and the registration code of 'SAU'.

title: John MacGregor (VC)
text: John MacGregor VC MC & Bar DCM ED (1 February 1889 – 9 June 1952) was a Scottish-Canadian soldier.

title: John MacGregor (VC)
text: MacGregor was a recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

title: John MacGregor (VC)
text: MacGregor served in the Canadian army in both world wars.

title: Treehouse (game)
text: Treehouse is a game in which players try to get their configuration of Icehouse pieces to match the central configuration, shared by all players.

title: Treehouse (game)
text: The rolling of the special "Treehouse Die" tells the player what kind of move to make to change his own or the central configuration, and then he does so to best move towards the goal.

title: Love in Motion (song)
text: "Love in Motion" is the first new material released by the Australian rock synthpop band Icehouse as a 7" vinyl single-only in October 1981 on Regular Records for the Australian market.

title: Love in Motion (song)
text: The band had been known as Flowers until 27 June 1981 after which they changed their name to Icehouse, they had signed to Chrysalis Records and most of Flowers' material was released under the new name into Europe, UK and US markets.

title: Love in Motion (song)
text: "Love in Motion" peaked at #10 on the Australian singles charts.

title: Love in Motion (song)
text: The B-side, "Goodnight, Mr. Matthews" was included on the 1982 album "Primitive Man" with "Love in Motion" included on the Chrysalis Records US / European versions of the album, the UK 1983 version of the album was re-titled "Love in Motion".

title: Can't Help Myself
text: "Can't Help Myself" is the first single released by the Australian synthpop/rock band Flowers, later known as Icehouse.

title: Can't Help Myself
text: It was released in May 1980 as a 7" vinyl single on independent label, Regular Records, five months ahead of debut album "Icehouse".

title: Can't Help Myself
text: A 10" vinyl single was released in July and had a cover depicting individual images of band members diagonally across the band's name and the single's title (see infobox at right middle).

title: Can't Help Myself
text: It peaked at #10 on the Australian Singles Charts.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: The Nameless One is a two-headed demon.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: The Nameless One first appeared in "Sub-Mariner" #22 (February 1970), and was created by Roy Thomas and Marie Severin.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: He was the leader of the Undying Ones, and led them to conquer the Earth millennia ago.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: The Undying Ones ruled the Earth for ages, though eventually their powers waned and were forced to return to their own realm.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: The Nameless One continued to rule them when they were exiled from Earth, and during several attempts to conquer it again in modern times.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: Later, another demon became a successor to the previous, two-headed Nameless One as leader of the Undying Ones.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: This demon tried to use Wolverine to kill Doctor Strange.

title: List of Marvel Comics characters: N
text: Wolverine, enhanced by demonic magic, slew this Nameless One and many of the Undying Ones.

title: Kill Doctor Lucky
text: Kill Doctor Lucky is a humorous board game designed by James Ernest and released in 1996 by Cheapass Games.

title: Kill Doctor Lucky
text: In 1998, "Kill Doctor Lucky" won the Origins Award for "Best Abstract Board Game of 1997".

title: No Promises (Icehouse song)
text: "No Promises" is the first single released by Australian band, Icehouse from the band's 1986 album, "Measure for Measure" and was released in November 1985 on Regular Records as 7" Vinyl Single and 12" Vinyl Single formats.

title: No Promises (Icehouse song)
text: It was also released in the UK and Europe by Chrysalis Records again on 7" and 12" formats but with different track listings.

title: No Promises (Icehouse song)
text: It was subsequently released in the US by Chrysalis on 7" and 12" formats, again with different track listings.

title: No Promises (Icehouse song)
text: It peaked at #30 on the Australian singles charts.

title: No Promises (Icehouse song)
text: A remix version by  tatto was released on the Icehouse album "Meltdown" in 2002.

title: Icehouse (song)
text: "Icehouse" is a song by the Australian rock band Flowers.

title: Icehouse (song)
text: It was released as a single in Europe in 1982 by Chrysalis Records from the band's first album, "Icehouse", after the band changed its name to Icehouse.

title: Icehouse (song)
text: In the United States, the song peaked at number 28 on the "Billboard" Top Tracks chart in 1981.

title: Boxes (Icehouse album)
text: Boxes is a soundtrack album by Australian band Icehouse, released by Festival Records / Chrysalis Records in November 1985.

title: Boxes (Icehouse album)
text: The work was originally conceived by its composers, Iva Davies and Robert Kretschmer, in collaboration with choreographer Graeme Murphy of the Sydney Dance Company for performance as the ballet "Boxes".

title: Boxes (Icehouse album)
text: The first live performance of "Boxes" was given by the Sydney Dance Company together with Davies and Kretschmer of Icehouse and guest percussionist Masaki Tanazawa in the Opera Theatre of the Sydney Opera House on 7 November 1985.

title: Boxes (Icehouse album)
text: "Boxes" was released in the US under the name Sydney Dance Company.

title: Boxes (Icehouse album)
text: The single "No Promises" was released as a 12" in November and a cassingle in December on Regular Records for Australian and New Zealand markets, it contained other tracks from "Boxes"; two tracks from "Boxes" were later released on their next studio album "Measure for Measure" in April 1986.

title: Icehouse pieces
text: Icehouse pieces, or Icehouse Pyramids, Treehouse pieces, Treehouse Pyramids and officially Looney Pyramids, are nestable and stackable pyramid-shaped gaming pieces and a game system.

title: Icehouse pieces
text: The game system was invented by Andrew Looney and John Cooper in 1987, originally for use in the game of Icehouse.

title: We Can Get Together
text: "We Can Get Together" is the second single released by the Australian rock band Flowers, later known as Icehouse.

title: We Can Get Together
text: It was released in October 1980, on the independent label Regular Records from their first album, "Icehouse", two weeks before the album itself was released.

title: We Can Get Together
text: It peaked at #16 on the Australian Kent Music Report Singles Charts.

title: Slash's Blues Ball
text: Slash's Blues Ball was an American blues rock band that formed in Los Angeles, California in 1996.

title: Slash's Blues Ball
text: The band, which comprised lead guitarist Slash, lead vocalist Teddy "Big Bag Zig Zag" Andreadis, bassist Johnny Griparic, drummer Alvino Bennet, rhythm guitarist Bobby Schneck and saxophonist Dave McLaurin, toured as a cover band for two years following the departure of Slash from American hard rock band Guns N' Roses.

title: Slash's Blues Ball
text: The band did not release any albums.

title: Five Horse Johnson
text: Five Horse Johnson is an American blues rock band from Toledo, Ohio, formed in 1995.

title: Five Horse Johnson
text: They have toured with such popular groups as Clutch and Halfway to Gone.

title: Five Horse Johnson
text: The band combines hard rock, blues and other influences into a blend of stoner rock/blues music they call their own.

title: Five Horse Johnson
text: Their second to latest album "The Mystery Spot" featured many special guests including drummer Jean-Paul Gaster from Clutch; on a related note they have played a worldwide tour with Clutch and Dub Trio.

title: Live at Carnegie Hall (Stevie Ray Vaughan album)
text: Live at Carnegie Hall is the ninth album (and third live album) by American blues rock band Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble, released by Epic Records in July 1997.

title: Live at Carnegie Hall (Stevie Ray Vaughan album)
text: The album consists of live selections from their sold-out October 4, 1984 benefit concert at Carnegie Hall for the T.J. Martell Foundation.

title: Live at Carnegie Hall (Stevie Ray Vaughan album)
text: Backed by a ten-piece big band for the second half of the event, Vaughan had celebrated his thirtieth birthday the night before, and called the concert his "best birthday ever, forever".

title: Live at Carnegie Hall (Stevie Ray Vaughan album)
text: The band's double-set performance, which included several blues and R&B standards, was highly successful, receiving mostly positive reviews from music critics.

title: The Muggs
text: The Muggs is an American blues rock band from Detroit, Michigan.

title: The Muggs
text: Formed in February 2000 by guitarist Danny Methric, bassist Tony DeNardo and drummer Matt Rost.

title: The Muggs
text: They were ranked in December 2008 on the "100 Hot Unsigned Band" list by "Music Connection".

title: The Muggs
text: They won several awards including the Best Blues Artist and the Best Rock Band for 2007.

title: The Electric Flag
text: The Electric Flag was an American blues rock soul group, led by guitarist Mike Bloomfield, keyboardist Barry Goldberg and drummer Buddy Miles, and featuring other musicians such as vocalist Nick Gravenites and bassist Harvey Brooks.

title: The Electric Flag
text: Bloomfield formed the Electric Flag in 1967, following his stint with the Butterfield Blues Band.

title: The Electric Flag
text: The band reached its peak with the 1968 release, "A Long Time Comin'", a fusion of rock, jazz, and R&B styles that charted well in the "Billboard" Pop Albums chart.

title: The Electric Flag
text: Their initial recording was a soundtrack for "The Trip", a movie about an LSD experience by Peter Fonda, written by Jack Nicholson and directed by Roger Corman.

title: Double Trouble (band)
text: Double Trouble is an American blues rock band from Austin, Texas, formed by guitarist/singer Stevie Ray Vaughan in 1978.

title: Double Trouble (band)
text: The group was active throughout the 1980s and responsible for reviving the blues, inspiring many later blues and rock musicians.

title: Double Trouble (band)
text: Formed in Austin, Texas, by 1985 the group consisted of Vaughan, Chris Layton (drums), Tommy Shannon (bass), and eventually Reese Wynans (keyboards).

title: Double Trouble (band)
text: While with Vaughan the band was billed Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble.

title: Double Trouble (band)
text: Rooted in blues and rock music, the group worked in many genres ranging from ballads to soul, often incorporating jazz and other elements.

title: List of Canned Heat members
text: The following list details musicians who have been, and still are, members of the American blues rock band Canned Heat.

title: List of Canned Heat members
text: Since the band formed in 1965, 43 different members have passed through the band.

title: List of Canned Heat members
text: The band's current lineup includes bassist Larry "The Mole" Taylor who first joined the band in 1967, drummer Adolfo "Fito" de la Parra who has been with the group since 1967, guitarist Harvey "The Snake" Mandel who first joined the band in 1969 and vocalist Dale Spalding who joined the band in 2008.

title: Frank Beard (musician)
text: Frank Lee Beard (born June 11, 1949) is the drummer in the American rock band ZZ Top.

title: Frank Beard (musician)
text: Beard was formerly with the bands The Cellar Dwellers, who originally were a three-piece band, The Hustlers, The Warlocks, and American Blues before starting to play and record with Billy Gibbons and Dusty Hill as ZZ Top.

title: Chris Robinson Brotherhood
text: Chris Robinson Brotherhood is an American blues rock band formed in 2011 by Black Crowes singer Chris Robinson while The Black Crowes were on hiatus.

title: Chris Robinson Brotherhood
text: The band has released four studio albums: "Big Moon Ritual", "The Magic Door", "Phosphorescent Harvest", and "Any Way You Love, We Know How You Feel".

title: Chris Robinson Brotherhood
text: The band consists of Robinson, guitarist Neal Casal, keyboardist Adam MacDougall, bassist Jeff Hill (who replaced original bassist Mark Dutton in 2016), and drummer Tony Leone (who replaced original drummer George Sluppick in January 2015).

title: Mabel Greer's Toyshop
text: Mabel Greer's Toyshop are an English progressive rock (initially as psychedelic rock) band formed in London, active from 1966 to 1968 that was the precursor to the rock band Yes.

title: Mabel Greer's Toyshop
text: Their music was marked by a combination of psychedelic, American blues and classically influenced arrangements with poetic lyrics.

title: Mabel Greer's Toyshop
text: Members included Chris Squire, Peter Banks, Tony Kaye, Bill Bruford, and Jon Anderson.

title: Mabel Greer's Toyshop
text: The band reformed in 2014 with original members, singer and guitarist Clive Bayley and drummer Robert Hagger, along with Hugo Barré, Tony Kaye, and Billy Sherwood.

title: Tulu cinema
text: Tulu cinema is a part of Indian cinema.

title: Tulu cinema
text: The Tulu film industry is also called Coastalwood.

title: Tulu cinema
text: It produces 5 to 7 films annually.

title: Tulu cinema
text: The first Tulu film was "Enna Thangadi" released in 1971.

title: Tulu cinema
text: Usually, earlier, these films were released in theatres across the Tulu Nadu region.

title: Tulu cinema
text: But currently the Tulu film industry has grown to the level where films are being released simultaneously in Mangalore, Udupi and Mumbai, Bangalore and Gulf countries.

title: Tulu cinema
text: The critically acclaimed Tulu film "Suddha" won the award for the best Indian Film at the Osian's Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema held in New Delhi in 2006.

title: Tulu cinema
text: In 2011, the Tulu film Industry got second life with the release of the film "Oriyardori Asal".

title: Tulu cinema
text: The film turned out to be the biggest hit in Tulu film history to date. "

title: Tulu cinema
text: Chaali Polilu" is the longest running film in Tulu film industry.

title: Tulu cinema
text: This movie is the highest grossing film in the Tulu film industry.

title: Tulu cinema
text: It has successfully completed 470 days at PVR Cinemas in Mangalore.

title: Duniya Vijay
text: Vijay a.k.a. Duniya Vijay is an Indian actor who appears in Kannada films.

title: Duniya Vijay
text: He started off as a junior film artist in the industry playing small insignificant roles, before he got the big break in "Duniya" (2007).

title: Duniya Vijay
text: He is noted for his performances in various films such as "Chanda" (2007), "Junglee" (2009), "Johny Mera Naam Preethi Mera Kaam" (2011) and "Jayammana Maga" (2013).

title: Mera Damad
text: Mera Damad is a 1985 family-drama Indian Hindi film directed by Partho Ghosh and produced by Shipra Biswas and Tushar Mazumdar.

title: Mera Damad
text: It starred Utpal Dutt (in his final film appearance), Ashok Kumar, Farooq Sheikh, Zarina Wahab, Rakesh Bedi, Prema Narayan, and Jankidas in lead roles.

title: Mera Damad
text: Music for the film was scored by Salil Choudhury and Babul Bose.>

title: Amitash Pradhan
text: Amitash Pradhan (born 12 October 1990) is an actor in the "Indian Film Industry" prominently known for his antagonist role in blockbuster hit movie "Velaiyilla Pattadhari" starring South-Indian film actor Dhanush and for playing the lead in "Heartbeats", a film Directed by Duane Adler (creator of the Step UP Franchise) becoming the first south Indian actor to play the lead in a Hollywood film.

title: Doddanna
text: Doddanna (Kannada: ದೊಡ್ಡಣ್ಣ ; born 11 November 1949) is an Indian actor in the Kannada film industry who has acted in about 500 films.

title: Doddanna
text: He started his career as a theatre actor.

title: Doddanna
text: During this time and later entered the Kannada film industry as a character actor.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Sunil Rawal (born 23 May 1983) is a film producer and actor active in the Nepali film industry.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: He has been involved in the film industry since 2012.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: His first movie as a producer and actor was "Saayad", produced under the banner of Durgish Films Pvt. Ltd. and directed by Suraj Subba.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: He is Managing Director of Durgish Films Pvt. Ltd.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Since his involvement in the industry, he has been the center point of attraction to both filmmaker and audience.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: His First movie Saayad in 2011 was the trend breaker.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Rawal collected numerous award from that movie.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Being a Member of Nepal Film Producer Association, He was awarded by Nepal Film Producer Association for the best product, Saayad.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Then his dedication of filmmaking reached to another level, which helped him to produce another blockbuster movie HOSTEL, 2012, which was the heart of youth nepali audience.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Hostel too got numbers of award including national award.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: After grand success of Hostel, Rawal came with another blockbuster movie Hostel Returns, Sequel of Hostel in 2015.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Till the date Rawal is only the producer in Nepali Film Industry with No flops.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Rawal is inspiration and role model to many youth who is willing to make their career in Nepali Film Industry.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Sequel of his first Film Saayad, Saayad 2 is set to release on 14 July 2017.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Beside Filmmaking, Rawal is busy on serving the society, in his initiation, library was established in Nirankari Aadarsha Bidhya Mandir, Kailali.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: He was one of the active filmmaker to serve earthquake victims in different part of Nepal.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: He has great contribution to flood victims of eastern and western Nepal.

title: Sunil Rawal
text: Getting Back to film Industry, His upcoming Projects, Laaure and Woolen Marry is running smoothly on Pre-production.

title: Komal
text: Komal Kumar (; born 4 July) is an Indian actor in the Kannada film industry, known for comedic roles.

title: Komal
text: He is also a film producer and distributor.

title: Komal
text: Komal made his cinema debut in the year 1992 as a second hero for the movie called "Super nan Maga" produced by his brother in law N. Srinivas.

title: Komal
text: Since his debut Komal has acted in over 100 films as a comedy actor and eventually as a lead actor in the film called "Chamkaisi chindi Udaisi".

title: Komal
text: He is the younger brother of actor Jaggesh, with whom he has frequently collaborated professionally.

title: Tariq Khan (actor)
text: Tariq Hussain Khan was an Indian film actor known for his works in Hindi cinema.

title: Tariq Khan (actor)
text: He made his debut with his father Nasir Hussain's directed 1973 hit film Yaadon Ki Baraat.

title: Tariq Khan (actor)
text: He acted in Nasir Hussain's next hit film "Hum Kisise Kum Nahin" (1977).

title: Tariq Khan (actor)
text: Although both were hit films, Tariq's career never took off successfully.

title: Tariq Khan (actor)
text: After appearing in a handful of other films, he quit acting after his last film Mera Damad in 1995.

title: Fayyaz Hashmi
text: Fayyaz Hashmi (Urdu: ‎ ) was a Pakistani poet and dialogue writer who worked both in the Indian and Pakistani film industry.

title: Fayyaz Hashmi
text: He penned some memorable songs such as the famous ghazal Aaj Jaane Ki Zid Na Karo and "Tasveer teri dil mera behela nah sake gi".

title: Fayyaz Hashmi
text: The latter made the singer Talat Mahmood famous in India back in 1941 and was instrumental in introducing him to the Calcutta film industry.

title: Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri
text: Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri (Malayalam : കൃഷ്ണഭാസ്ക്കർ മംഗലശ്ശേരി)is an Indian actor, Model, Academic, Novelist, and Screenwriter who works in the Malayalam film industry.

title: Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri
text: Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri made his acting debut in the Malayalam film "Puthiya Theerangal" (2012) under ace director of Malayalam film industry Sathyan Anthikad and later starred in the movie directed by Martin Prakkat starring Dulquer Salman and Aparna Gopinath in lead roles.

title: Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri
text: He co-wrote and also enacted a leading role as a police officer in movie Asha Black with supreme star Sarath Kumar.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: The Jeep Liberty (KK), or Jeep Cherokee (KK) outside North America, is a compact SUV that was produced by Jeep.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: Introduced for the 2008 model year as a successor for the first generation Liberty.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: The Liberty featured unibody-construction.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: It was assembled at the Toledo North Assembly Plant in the United States, as well as in other countries including Egypt and Venezuela.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: In 2010 estimates by Jeep were that 70% of Liberty buyers were new to the marque.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: The second generation Liberty ceased production on August 16, 2012.

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: For its followup, the name of Liberty was retired; the next generation restored the name of "Cherokee".

title: Jeep Liberty (KK)
text: The model remains on sale in Venezuela as of early 2016 having yet to be replaced by FCA Venezuela with the KL model Cherokee.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: The Jeep Liberty, or Jeep Cherokee (KJ/KK) outside North America, is a compact SUV that was produced by Jeep for the model years 2002–2012.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: Introduced as a replacement for the Cherokee (XJ), the Liberty was priced between the Wrangler and Grand Cherokee.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: It was the smallest of the 4-door Jeep SUVs until the car based 4-door Compass and Patriot arrived for 2007.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: The Liberty featured unibody-construction.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: It was assembled at the Toledo North Assembly Plant in the United States, as well as in other countries including Egypt and Venezuela.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: The Liberty ceased production on August 16, 2012.

title: Jeep Liberty
text: The next generation restored the previous nameplate of Jeep Cherokee that was always used outside of North America.

title: Jeep Cherokee (KL)
text: The Jeep Cherokee (KL) is a mid-size crossover SUV produced by Jeep.

title: Jeep Cherokee (KL)
text: It was introduced for the 2014 model year at the 2013 New York International Auto Show and the sales started in November 2013.

title: Jeep Cherokee (KL)
text: The Cherokee is the first Jeep vehicle to be built on the Fiat Compact/Compact U.S. Wide platform, co-developed by Chrysler and Fiat.

title: Jeep Cherokee (KL)
text: The Jeep Cherokee is built at Belvidere Assembly Plant in Belvidere, Illinois.

title: Richard A. Teague
text: Richard A. (Dick) Teague (December 26, 1923 – May 5, 1991), born in Los Angeles, California, was an American industrial designer in the North American automotive industry.

title: Richard A. Teague
text: He held automotive design positions at General Motors, Packard, and Chrysler before becoming Vice President of Design for American Motors Corporation (AMC), and designed several notable show cars and production vehicles including AMC's Pacer, Gremlin and Hornet models, as well as the Jeep Cherokee XJ and even had a hand in designing/assisted in the designing of later cars for Chrysler after American Motor's buyout such as the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Neon.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ) is the first generation of the Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicle.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: Introduced in 1992 for the 1993 model year, development of the ZJ Grand Cherokee started under American Motors and continued after their acquisition by Chrysler in 1987.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: It originally came in three trim levels: base, Laredo, and Limited.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The base model included features such as full instrumentation, cloth interior, a standard five-speed manual transmission, and was given the "SE" name for the 1994 model year.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: Power windows and locks were not standard equipment on the base and SE, although they were finally included in 1995.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The minimal difference in price resulted in low consumer demand, so the low-line model was eventually discontinued.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: Additional standard features included a driver-side air bag and four-wheel anti-lock braking system (ABS).

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The Laredo was the mid-scale model with standard features that included power windows, power door locks, and cruise control.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: Exterior features included medium-grey plastic paneling on the lower body and five-spoke aluminum wheels.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The Limited was the premium model, featuring lower body paneling that was the same color as the rest of the vehicle.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The Limited also had standard features such as leather seating, power sunroof, heated mirrors, heated power seats, and a keyless entry system.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: The "Up-Country" version was also offered between 1993 and 1997, often painted "Champagne Pearl" or black.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: It came with 4WD and a 4.0 straight-6.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ)
text: Package groups with the various trim levels included: Convenience, Fog Lamp / Skid Plate, Lighting, Luxury, Power, Security, Trailer/Towing.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: The fourth-generation Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2) is a mid-size luxury SUV introduced in Spring 2010 for the 2011 model year by Jeep.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: It was unveiled at the 2009 New York Auto Show.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: The fourth-generation Grand Cherokee retains its classic Jeep styling combined with a modern and sleek body style.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: The interior is luxurious, featuring leather trim and real wood accents, plus state-of-the-art electronics options.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: The 2011 Grand Cherokee has won 30 awards for off-road capability, luxury, value, best-in-class, and safety, making it the most awarded SUV ever.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)
text: Among the awards are: Top Safety Pick for 2011 from the IIHS, listed as a "Consumers Digest" Best Buy for 2011, Safest SUV in America by MSN Autos, and Truck of the Year for 2011 by "The Detroit News".

title: Jeep Cherokee (XJ)
text: The Jeep Cherokee (XJ) is a sport utility vehicle that was manufactured and marketed by Jeep from 1983 to 2001.

title: Jeep Cherokee (XJ)
text: Sharing the name of the original full-size SJ model, but without a traditional body-on-frame chassis, the XJ instead featured a light-weight unibody design, The models were originally marketed as Sportwagons and became the precursor to the modern sport utility vehicle (SUV) as that term was not yet in use.

title: Jeep Liberty (KJ)
text: The Jeep Liberty (KJ), or Jeep Cherokee (KJ) outside North America, is a compact SUV that was produced by Jeep and designed by Bob Boniface through early 1998.

title: Jeep Liberty (KJ)
text: Introduced in May 2001 for the 2002 model year as a replacement for the Cherokee (XJ), the Liberty was priced between the Wrangler and Grand Cherokee.

title: Jeep Liberty (KJ)
text: It was the smallest of the 4-door Jeep SUVs up until the car platform based 4-door Compass and Patriot arrived for 2007.

title: Jeep Liberty (KJ)
text: The Liberty featured unibody-construction.

title: Jeep Liberty (KJ)
text: It was assembled at the Toledo North Assembly Plant in the United States, as well as in other countries including Egypt and Venezuela.

title: Jeep Cherokee
text: The Jeep Cherokee is a line of vehicles sold by Jeep under various vehicle classes.

title: Jeep Cherokee
text: Originally sold as a variant of the popular Jeep Wagoneer, the Cherokee has evolved from a full-size SUV to one of the first compact SUVs and eventually into its current incarnation as a crossover SUV.

title: Jeep Cherokee
text: The nameplate has been in continuous use in some form since 1974 and also spawned Jeep's most successful vehicle, the Jeep Grand Cherokee, which was originally slated to be part of the Cherokee's lineup.

title: Jeep Cherokee
text: The vehicle is named after the Cherokee tribe of Native Americans.

title: Jeep Cherokee (SJ)
text: The SJ series Jeep Cherokee is a full-size SUV that was produced from 1974 through 1983 by Jeep.

title: Jeep Cherokee (SJ)
text: It was based on the Wagoneer that was originally designed by Brooks Stevens in 1963.

title: Edwin L. Mechem
text: Edwin Leard Mechem (July 2, 1912November 27, 2002) was a prominent Republican politician from New Mexico.

title: Edwin L. Mechem
text: He served as the 15th, 17th and 19th Governor of New Mexico and represented the state in the United States Senate.

title: Edwin L. Mechem
text: Mechem was the first person born in the 20th century to become the state's governor, as well as the first person born in New Mexico after statehood to succeed to the office.

title: Edwin L. Mechem
text: He later served as a Federal Judge.

title: Foreign-born Japanese
text: A foreign-born Japanese (外国生まれの日本人 , gaikoku umare no nihonjin , literally "Japanese person born in a foreign country") is a Japanese person of foreign descent or heritage, who was born outside Japan and later acquired Japanese citizenship.

title: Foreign-born Japanese
text: This category encompasses persons of both Japanese and non-Japanese descent.

title: Foreign-born Japanese
text: The former subcategory is considered because of intricacies of national and international laws regarding the citizenship of newborn persons.

title: Antonia Gerena Rivera
text: Antonia Gerena Rivera (May 19, 1900 – June 2, 2015) was a Puerto Rican supercentenarian who, at the time of her death at the age of 115 years, 14 days, was the world's sixth oldest living person, and the third oldest American behind Jeralean Talley (died 15 days later of the death of Rivera) and Susannah Mushatt Jones.

title: Antonia Gerena Rivera
text: Rivera is the oldest documented woman and second oldest ever verified person born in Puerto Rico and the oldest ever resident of Florida.

title: Camille Zamora
text: Camille Amy Zamora (born December 14, 1970) is an American soprano recognized for her performance of opera, zarzuela, oratorio, art song and American songbook.

title: Camille Zamora
text: She performs repertoire ranging from the early Baroque to 21st century premieres by composers including Grammy Award winners Robert Aldridge and Herschel Garfein as well as Prix de Rome winner Christopher Theofanidis.

title: Mamzer
text: A mamzer (Hebrew: ממזר‎ ‎ ) is a person born from certain forbidden relationships, or the descendant of such a person, in the Hebrew Bible and Jewish religious law.

title: Mamzer
text: A "mamzer" in modern Jewish culture is someone who is either born out of adultery by a married Jewish woman and a Jewish man who is not her husband, or born out of incest (as defined by the Bible), or someone who has a "mamzer" as a parent.

title: Mamzer
text: Mamzer status is not synonymous with illegitimacy, since it does not include children whose mothers were unmarried.

title: Apprentice Adept
text: Apprentice Adept is a heptalogy of fantasy and science fiction novels written by English American author Piers Anthony.

title: Apprentice Adept
text: The series takes place on "Phaze" and "Proton", two worlds occupying the same space in two different dimensional planes.

title: Apprentice Adept
text: Phaze is a lush planet of magic, where Proton is a barren mining planet of science.

title: Apprentice Adept
text: As the series opens, each person born on Phaze and Proton has an alternate self living on the other world.

title: Apprentice Adept
text: But if a person on either world lacks a duplicate (for instance if a Proton citizen immigrated there from another planet, or a counterpart from the opposite frame died), he can cross to the other through an energy "curtain" that circumscribes each frame.

title: Fred H. Hale Sr.
text: Frederick "Fred" Harold Hale Sr. (December 1, 1890 – November 19, 2004) was an American supercentenarian.

title: Fred H. Hale Sr.
text: After the death of John Ingram McMorran in February 2003, at the age of 112 years, Hale was recognized as the oldest living man in the United States.

title: Fred H. Hale Sr.
text: In March 2004, at 113, he became the oldest living man in the world, following the death of the Spaniard Joan Riudavets.

title: Fred H. Hale Sr.
text: Hale is verified to be one of the ten oldest men in recorded history, as well as the oldest recorded person born in the state of Maine.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: Myrna Docia Sharlow (19 July 1893 – after 1935) was an American soprano who had an active performance career in operas and concerts during the 1910s through the 1930s.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: She began her career in 1912 with the Boston Opera Company and became one of Chicago's more active sopranos from 1915–1920, and again in 1923–1924 and 1926–1927.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: She sang with several other important American opera companies during her career, including one season at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: She made only a handful of opera appearances in Europe during her career, most notably singing in the English premiere of Riccardo Zandonai's "Francesca da Rimini" at Covent Garden in 1914.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: Her repertoire spanned a wide range from leading dramatic soprano roles to lighter lyric soprano fair and comprimario parts.

title: Myrna Sharlow
text: She even performed a few roles traditionally sung by mezzo-sopranos or contraltos.

title: Les Irwin
text: Leslie Herbert "Les" Irwin, CBE (1 May 1898 – 28 January 1985) was an Australian politician.

title: Les Irwin
text: Born in Newcastle, New South Wales, he was educated at state schools and underwent military service 1916–30.

title: Les Irwin
text: Upon the end of his service, he became a bank manager.

title: Les Irwin
text: In 1963, he was selected as the Liberal candidate for the seat of Mitchell in the Australian House of Representatives.

title: Les Irwin
text: He was the last person born in the nineteenth century, the last person born before Federation, and the last World War I veteran elected to the House.

title: Les Irwin
text: He held Mitchell until his defeat in 1972.

title: Les Irwin
text: Irwin died in 1985.

title: Nabi Tajima
text: Nabi Tajima (田島 ナビ , Tajima Nabi , born 4 August 1900) is a Japanese supercentenarian.

title: Nabi Tajima
text: At the age of , she is the world's oldest verified living person and the last surviving person born in the 19th century.

title: Nabi Tajima
text: She is the oldest verified Japanese and Asian person ever.

title: C24 Gallery
text: C24 Gallery is a contemporary art gallery founded in 2011 by Emre & Maide Kurttepeli, Mel Dogan and located in Chelsea, New York City.

title: C24 Gallery
text: A two-level 5000 sqft space focuses on presenting exhibitions from both local and international prominent artists.

title: C24 Gallery
text: Voted one of the "500 Best Galleries Worldwide" in the 2013 & 2015 Annual Gallery Issue of Modern Painters magazine, C24 Gallery also attends yearly art fairs in New York, Miami and Europe.

title: C24 Gallery
text: C24 Gallery represents artists such as Carole Feuerman, Katja Loher, Irfan Önürmen, Christian Vincent, Dil Hildebrand, Seckin Pirim, Nick Gentry, Mike Dargas, Robert Montgomery and Regina Scully.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Jessica Todd Harper is a portrait photographer with a B.A.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: in art history from Bryn Mawr College and an M.F.A. in photography from Rochester Institute of Technology.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Her photographs have been featured in Photo District News; Camera Austria; Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung; Newsweek; and O, The Oprah Magazine.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Exhibits include The International Museum of Photography, George Eastman House, Rochester, NY; The Houston Museum of Fine Arts; the Allentown Art Museum; the Woodmere Art Museum in Philadelphia; Blue Sky Gallery in Portland; Paul Kopeikin Gallery in L.A.; Cohen Amador Gallery in New York; The Photographic Center Northwest in Seattle; and The Photographic Resource Center in Boston.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Harper is a recent project competition winner at Center (formally the Sante Fe Center for Photography) and selected artist of "PDN's 30: Our Choice of Emerging Photographers to Watch."

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Harper is represented by Cohen Amador Gallery in New York and teaches at Swarthmore College.

title: Jessica Todd Harper
text: Harper was a finalist for Smithsonian Institution's National Portrait Gallery 2016 Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition.

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: Carl Richard Jacobi (July 10, 1908 – August 25, 1997) was an American journalist and author.

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: He wrote short stories in the horror and fantasy genres for the pulp magazine market, appearing in such pulps of the bizarre and uncanny as Thrilling, "Ghost Stories", Startling Stories, Thrilling Wonder Stories, Planet Stories and Strange Stories.

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: He also write stories crime and adventure which appeared in such pulps as Thrilling Adventures, "Complete Stories", Top-Notch, Short Stories, The Skipper, Doc Savage, and "Dime Adventures Magazine".

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: He also produced some science fiction, mainly space opera, published in such magazines as Planet Stories.

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: He was one of the last surviving pulp-fictioneers to have contributed to the legendary American horror magazine "Weird Tales" during its "glory days" (the 1920s and 1930s).

title: Carl Richard Jacobi
text: His stories have been translated into French, Swedish, Danish and Dutch.

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: Henry James O'Brien Bedford-Jones (1887–1949) was a Canadian historical, adventure fantasy, science fiction, crime and Western writer who became a naturalized United States citizen in 1908.

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: After being encouraged to try writing by his friend, writer William Wallace Cook, Bedford-Jones began writing dime novels and pulp magazine stories.

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: Bedford-Jones was an enormously prolific writer; the pulp editor Harold Hersey once recalled meeting Bedford-Jones in Paris, where he was working on two novels simultaneously, each story on its own separate typewriter.

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: Bedford-Jones cited Alexandre Dumas as his main influence, and wrote a sequel to Dumas' "The Three Musketeers", "D'Artagnan" (1928).

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: He wrote over 100 novels, earning the nickname "King of the Pulps".

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: His works appeared in a number of pulp magazines.

title: H. Bedford-Jones
text: Bedford-Jones' main publisher was "Blue Book" magazine; he also appeared in "Adventure", "All-Story Weekly", "Argosy", "Short Stories", "Top-Notch Magazine", "The Magic Carpet", "Golden Fleece", "Ace-High Magazine", "People's Story Magazine", "Hutchinson's Adventure-Story Magazine", "Detective Fiction Weekly", "Western Story Magazine", and "Weird Tales".

title: Dime Magazine
text: Dime Magazine is an American basketball magazine that began circulation in 2001.

title: Dime Magazine
text: The magazine publishes six issues a year for its worldwide readership, as well as a handful of editions of "Dime China", a Chinese-language version consisting of regular "Dime" content translated from English and original content from editorial staff in China.

title: Dime Magazine
text: It makes an appearance as an endorsement in "NBA 2K12", and "NBA 2K13".

title: Dime Magazine
text: It is owned by Uproxx itself a brand of Woven Digital.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: Vanguard was a periodical produced in Vancouver, British Columbia from 1972 to 1989, containing reviews and critical articles on Canadian art and artists.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: The magazine was successor to the "Vancouver Art Gallery Bulletin" which existed between 1933 and 1971.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: It was published monthly by the Vancouver Art Gallery from 1972 to 1984.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: The first issue of "Vanguard" appeared in January 1972.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: In February 1979 it was redesigned as a glossy magazine and its coverage expanded to include national art events.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: The magazine was published by the Vancouver Society for Critical Arts Publications from 1985 to 1989, when it ceased publication.

title: Vanguard (magazine)
text: Full holdings can be found at the Vancouver Art Gallery library.

title: Dime novel
text: The dime novel is a form of late 19th-century and early 20th-century U.S. popular fiction issued in series of inexpensive paperbound editions.

title: Dime novel
text: The term "dime novel" has been used as a catchall term for several different but related forms, referring to dime novels, story papers, five- and ten-cent weeklies, "thick book" reprints, and sometimes early pulp magazines.

title: Dime novel
text: The term was used as a title as late as 1940, in the short-lived pulp magazine "Western Dime Novels".

title: Dime novel
text: Dime novels are the antecedent of today's mass-market paperbacks, comic books, television shows and movies based on dime-novel genres.

title: Dime novel
text: In the modern age, the term "dime novel" has been used to refer to quickly written, lurid potboilers, usually as a pejorative to describe a sensationalized but superficial literary work.

title: The Little Review Gallery
text: The Little Review Gallery was a small Modern Art gallery associated with the magazine American literary magazine "The Little Review".

title: The Little Review Gallery
text: The gallery was owned and operated from 1924 to 1927 by Jane Heap, the acting editor of "The Little Review" at that time.

title: The Little Review Gallery
text: The gallery was primarily devoted to Constructivism, Dadaism, and Machine-inspired art.

title: Pluck and Luck
text: Pluck and Luck: Complete Stories of Adventure was an American dime novel first published by Frank Tousey and was the longest-running dime novel.

title: Pluck and Luck
text: It numbered 1605 issues from January 12, 1898 to March 5, 1929.

title: Pluck and Luck
text: The 32-page magazine was semi-monthly for the first 22 issues and then weekly.

title: Pluck and Luck
text: Its size was 8 x 11 inches (through No. 1144) and 6 x 9 inches thereafter, and it featured color covers.

title: Pluck and Luck
text: Issues No. 1002-1464 were published by Harry Wolff and the rest by Westbury.

title: Linda Duvall
text: Linda Duvall is a Canadian artist and educator based in Saskatchewan and Toronto.

title: Linda Duvall
text: Her social art projects, exhibitions and research have taken up questions of conscience, truth, and the nature of interpersonal relationships, particularly as they are enacted through conversation.

title: Linda Duvall
text: Her art employs photography, video, installation, performance art, and community-based research including Internet-based archiving.

title: Linda Duvall
text: They often feature invitations for individuals or groups to participate in specific tasks involving conversation or expression.

title: Linda Duvall
text: Overall Duvall's work investigates speech acts (such as, confessions, gossip and expressions of regret), the nature of truth, the process of grieving, intimacy and vulnerability.

title: Linda Duvall
text: Her solo exhibitions have been hosted by Art Gallery of Hamilton, Dunlop Art Gallery, Art Gallery of Mississauga, Museo Nacional de Arte Moderno Guatemala City, Custom House Gallery Westport Ireland, Box Hotel Gallery Barcelona and Thunder Bay Art Gallery.

title: Linda Duvall
text: She has served on a number of boards of artist-run organizations including, Paved Arts, Red Head Gallery, The Photographer's Gallery (now known as PAVED Arts), "BlackFlash" Magazine.

title: Let America be America Again
text: "Let America Be America Again" is a poem written in 1935 by American poet Langston Hughes.

title: Let America be America Again
text: It was originally published in the July 1936 issue of "Esquire Magazine".

title: Let America be America Again
text: It was later republished in the 1937 to be read issue of "Kansas Magazine" and was revised and included in a small collection of Langston Hughes poems entitled "A New Song", published by the International Workers Order in 1938.

title: Langston Hughes Medal
text: The Langston Hughes Medal has been awarded annually since 1978 to recognize an influential and distinguished writer associated with the African diaspora for their "impressive works of poetry, fiction, drama, autobiography and critical essays that help to celebrate the memory and tradition of Langston Hughes".

title: Langston Hughes House
text: Langston Hughes House is a historic home located in Harlem, Manhattan, New York City.

title: Langston Hughes House
text: It is an Italianate style dwelling built in 1869.

title: Langston Hughes House
text: It is a three story with basement, rowhouse faced in brownstone and measuring 20 feet wide and 45 feet deep.

title: Langston Hughes House
text: Noted African American poet and author Langston Hughes (1902-1967) occupied the top floor as his workroom from 1947 to 1967.

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: The Daydreamer is a 1994 children's novel by British author Ian McEwan.

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: Illustrated by Anthony Browne.

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: The novel was first published by Jonathan Cape.

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: It draws its plot directly from the Rankin/Bass movie, "The Daydreamer" (1966) in which a young boy daydreams and enters a world of Hans Christian Andersen stories.

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: It is considered to be McEwan's first book for children, or second if taking into account the picture book "Rose Blanche" (1985).

title: The Daydreamer (novel)
text: Critics praised McEwan's imagination, but noted that the book had high "sweetness-and-light levels".

title: Robert Earl Jones
text: Robert Earl Jones (February 3, 1910 – September 7, 2006), sometimes credited as Earl Jones, was an American actor and prizefighter.

title: Robert Earl Jones
text: One of the first prominent African-American film stars, Jones was a living link with the Harlem renaissance of the 1920s and 1930s, having worked with Langston Hughes early in his career.

title: Robert Earl Jones
text: In New York in the 1930s Jones worked with young people on the Works Progress Administration, the largest New Deal agency, through which he met Langston Hughes, who cast him in his 1938 play, "Don't You Want to Be Free?"

title: Robert Earl Jones
text: Jones was best known for his leading roles in films such as "Lying Lips" (1939) and later in his career for supporting roles in films such as "The Sting" (1973), "Trading Places" (1983), "The Cotton Club" (1984) and "Witness" (1985).

title: Robert Earl Jones
text: Jones was the father of actor James Earl Jones.

title: Le Conversazioni
text: Le Conversazioni is an anglophone literary festival organized by Italian film personalities Antonio Monda and Davide Azzolini, and financed by the Italian government and various corporations.

title: Le Conversazioni
text: It is held on the island of Capri.

title: Le Conversazioni
text: The festival was first held in 2006.

title: Le Conversazioni
text: These gatherings have attracted a wide range of notable writers, including Martin Amis, Paul Auster, Chuck Palahniuk, Elizabeth Strout, Colum McCann, Donna Tartt, Nathan Englander, Nicole Krauss, EL Doctorow, Jeffrey Eugenides, Ian McEwan, Claire Messud, Annie Proulx, Stephen Sondheim, Michael Chabon, Wole Soyinka, Jamaica Kincaid, Jonathan Safran Foer, David Sedaris, Ian McEwan, Zadie Smith, Philip Gourevitch, David Foster Wallace, and others.

title: Black Nativity
text: Black Nativity is a retelling of the classic Nativity story with an entirely black cast.

title: Black Nativity
text: Traditional Christmas carols are sung in gospel style, with a few songs created specifically for the show.

title: Black Nativity
text: Originally written by Langston Hughes, the show was first performed Off-Broadway on December 11, 1961, and was one of the first plays written by an African American to be staged there.

title: Black Nativity
text: The show had a successful tour of Europe in 1962, one of its appearances being at the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds in Italy.

title: Black Nativity
text: "Black Nativity" has been performed annually in Boston, Massachusetts at various locations, such as: the Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts, Boston Opera House, Tremont Temple, Roxbury Community College, Northeastern's Blackman Auditorium, and presently at Emerson College's Paramount Theater since 1969 & is considered the longest-running production of Langston Hughes' "Black Nativity."

title: Black Nativity
text: The original 160 singers were arranged by age group and vocal range, with an assortment of soloists, along with the narrator, and Mary and Joseph, who are both mute, as well as musicians & ASL interpreters.

title: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center
text: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Institute (LHPAI) is an arts venue in Seattle, Washington, USA, operated by City of Seattle Office of Arts and Culture and named after African-American writer Langston Hughes.

title: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center
text: The building has Seattle landmark status.

title: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center
text: Dating from 1915, it was originally a synagogue, designed by B. Marcus Priteca for the Orthodox Jewish congregation Chevra Bikur Cholim, now Bikur Cholim Machzikay Hadath.

title: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center
text: As of 2009, it will soon undergo a US$2.5 million upgrade, including its second round of seismic retrofitting.

title: I, Too (Langston Hughes poem)
text: I, Too is a poem written by Langston Hughes that demonstrates a yearning for equality through perseverance while disproving the idea that patriotism is limited by race.

title: I, Too (Langston Hughes poem)
text: It was first published in 1926, and published in "The First Collection of Poems of Langston Hughes."

title: I, Too (Langston Hughes poem)
text: This poem, along with other works by Hughes, helped define the Harlem Renaissance, a period in the early 1920s and 30s of newfound cultural identity for blacks in America who had discovered the power of literature, art, music, and poetry as a means of personal and collective expression in the scope of civil rights.

title: Langston Hughes Society
text: The Langston Hughes Society is a United States-based literary society concerned with the work of African American poet Langston Hughes.

title: Langston Hughes Society
text: The society was the first national organisation to be dedicated to the work of an African American writer.

title: Langston Hughes Society
text: Founded after the poet's death and in the wake of the Langston Hughes Study conference of 1981 by Hughes' literary assistant George Houston Bass, the society's official publication is the "Langston Hughes Review", published by Institute for African American Studies at The University of Georgia.

title: Langston Hughes Society
text: The organisation also presents the "Langston Hughes Award" annually.

title: Bedok Mall
text: Bedok Mall (Chinese: 勿落广场) is a large suburban shopping mall in Bedok, Singapore and part of a mixed development compromising of retail and residential development that is integrated with a bus interchange.

title: Bedok Mall
text: Located at the heart of Bedok, the integrated retail and residential development comprises a 3-storey lifestyle and family shopping mall and eight 15-storey residential towers called Bedok Residences.

title: Bedok Mall
text: It was the first major shopping mall to open in Bedok and was built on the site of the former Bedok bus interchange.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: Mall of Georgia is an enclosed super-regional shopping mall located in Gwinnett County, Georgia, near the city of Buford, 30 mi northeast of Atlanta.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: Built in 1999, it is currently the largest shopping mall in the state of Georgia, consisting of more than two hundred stores on three levels.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: The mall's anchor stores include Belk, Dillard's, JCPenney, Macy's and Von Maur, other major stores include Barnes & Noble, Dick's Sporting Goods, and Haverty's.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: Also, located in the Mall of Georgia Crossing is Best Buy, Nordstrom Rack, T.J. Maxx, and Target.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: Also featured in the mall is a large village section, comprising lifestyle tenants and restaurants in an outdoor setting, as well as a 500-seat amphitheater.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: The mall attracts many high end stores such as Coach, Swarovski, Clarks, J.Crew, and Aveda.

title: Mall of Georgia
text: Simon Property Group manages the Mall of Georgia.

title: Park City Center
text: Park City Center is a shopping mall located in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and is the largest enclosed shopping center in Lancaster County.

title: Park City Center
text: It is situated at the intersection of U.S. Route 30 and Harrisburg Pike.

title: Park City Center
text: The shape of the mall resembles a snowflake, with its stores occupying 8 corridors extending from the center.

title: Park City Center
text: The roof in the center of the mall is a large white tent, and encloses the octagonal Center Court.

title: Park City Center
text: The mall underwent a major renovation in 2008, which took 18 months and included updates to every part of the mall.

title: Park City Center
text: During its early years Park City was also called "Mall of Four Seasons" because of the seasonal names given to the 4 corridors leading to each anchor.

title: Park City Center
text: Going clockwise from west to east was JC Penney in the two-story Winter quadrant, Sears in Spring, Gimbel's (future Pomeroy's/Boscov's) in Summer and Watt & Shand (later Bon-Ton) in Autumn.

title: Park City Center
text: The high tech mall located in the heart of Amish country was one of the first to have its own closed-circuit television.

title: Park City Center
text: Studios for Park City Communications and Lancaster/York/Harrisburg CBS affiliate WLYH-TV 15 were located on the first floor in the Winter wing alongside an ice skating rink.

title: Kentucky Oaks Mall
text: Kentucky Oaks Mall is an enclosed super-regional shopping mall in Paducah, Kentucky, USA.

title: Kentucky Oaks Mall
text: Managed by Cafaro Company, the mall includes more than 90 inline stores, as well as regional radio station Rock 98.3 WJLI.

title: Kentucky Oaks Mall
text: Its anchor stores comprise JCPenney, Best Buy, Elder-Beerman, a Dillard's store divided into two sub-stores, and Dick's Sporting Goods.

title: Kentucky Oaks Mall
text: It was the largest mall in Kentucky by gross leasable area when it opened, and remains the state's third-largest, behind Fayette Mall in Lexington and Mall St. Matthews in Louisville.

title: SM City Cebu
text: SM City Cebu, also known locally as SM Cebu, is a large shopping mall located in Cebu City, Philippines.

title: SM City Cebu
text: It is the 4th shopping mall owned and developed by SM Prime Holdings, the country's largest shopping mall owner and developer.

title: SM City Cebu
text: It is the company's first shopping mall outside of Metro Manila and the 6th largest shopping mall in the Philippines.

title: SM City Cebu
text: It has a land area of 11.8 hectares and a gross floor area of 268,611 m2

title: Tower City station
text: Tower City Rapid Station is a rapid transit station in Cleveland, Ohio, USA.

title: Tower City station
text: It is the central station on the RTA Red Line and the major station on the RTA Green and Blue Lines.

title: Tower City station
text: The station is located directly beneath Prospect Avenue in the middle of the Tower City Center shopping mall.

title: Tower City station
text: The station is only accessible through the Tower City Center shopping complex, and, for this reason, the public concourse of the shopping mall is open at all times that the RTA Rapid Transit is in operation.

title: Mall of New Hampshire
text: The Mall of New Hampshire is a shopping mall located in the Lower South Willow neighborhood of Manchester, New Hampshire.

title: Mall of New Hampshire
text: Its major anchoring stores are Macy's, Old Navy, JCPenney, Sears and Best Buy.

title: Mall of New Hampshire
text: The mall has over 120 stores as well as a large food court and is 930000 sqft , making it the third largest mall in New Hampshire after the Mall at Rockingham Park in Salem, and the Pheasant Lane Mall in Nashua, which opened in 1991 and 1986, respectively.

title: Mall of New Hampshire
text: This was the first large-scale shopping mall in New Hampshire; initial construction of the mall was completed in August 1977, though it has since been dramatically expanded.

title: Plaza Las Américas
text: Plaza Las Américas is a shopping mall in Hato Rey, San Juan, Puerto Rico, located at the intersection of Routes 18 and 22.

title: Plaza Las Américas
text: It is near the Roberto Clemente Coliseum, the Hiram Bithorn Stadium, and the WKAQ-TV's studios. "

title: Plaza Las Américas
text: "Plaza"", as it is known to many Puerto Ricans, was the first indoor shopping mall built in Puerto Rico.

title: Plaza Las Américas
text: It is the largest shopping mall in the Caribbean and the second largest in Latin America.

title: KGOT
text: KGOT (101.3 FM) is a commercial Top 40 (CHR) radio station in Anchorage, Alaska.

title: KGOT
text: The station is owned by iHeartMedia, Inc. and broadcasts (along with its sister stations) from studios in the Dimond Center.

title: Pavilion Mall
text: Pavilion Mall is a shopping mall located in Biñan City, Laguna in the Philippines.

title: Pavilion Mall
text: This is the first large shopping mall in Biñan City, which opened on October, 1999, and is currently being managed by the Ayala Malls, the third largest shopping mall chain in the Philippines.

title: Pavilion Mall
text: The mall is very accessible via National Highway or via Mamplasan Exit in South Luzon Expressway.

title: Platinum Pied Pipers
text: Platinum Pied Pipers is a Detroit-based hip hop and R&B group composed of producer Waajeed (Robert O'Bryant), and multi-instrumentalist Saadiq (Darnell Bolden, not to be confused with Raphael Saadiq).

title: Platinum Pied Pipers
text: Their music usually features a rotating and varied array of artists.

title: Thirty Eight (album)
text: Thirty Eight is the fourth studio album by Detroit-based hip hop producer Apollo Brown, released digitally on April 29, 2014 by Mello Music Group.

title: Thirty Eight (album)
text: The album was later released physically, on CD and vinyl, with their own bonus tracks.

title: Thirty Eight (album)
text: Apollo Brown described "Thirty Eight" as a ride through Detroit of the early 1980s, that was inspired by various 1970s and 1980s films' soundtracks.

title: Thirty Eight (album)
text: One single was released from the album, "The Answer", as a preorder bonus.

title: Bizarre (rapper)
text: Rufus Arthur Johnson (born July 5, 1976), better known by his stage name Bizarre, is an American rapper, best known for his work with the Detroit-based hip hop group D12.

title: Bad Meets Evil
text: Bad Meets Evil is an American hip hop duo composed of Detroit-based rappers, Royce da 5'9" (Bad) and Eminem (Evil).

title: Bad Meets Evil
text: Bad Meets Evil was formed in 1997, thanks to the duo's mutual friend, Proof.

title: Bad Meets Evil
text: Their discography consists of one extended play (EP) and four singles.

title: Bad Meets Evil
text: In 1999, the duo released a double non-album single, "Nuttin' to Do" and "Scary Movies"; the former peaked at 36 on the Hot Rap Songs chart, while the latter peaked at 63 on the UK Singles Chart, and was featured on the soundtrack of the 2000 horror comedy parody film "Scary Movie".

title: Swifty McVay
text: Ondre Moore (born March 17, 1976), better known by his stage name Swifty McVay, is an American rapper, best known for his work with the Detroit-based hip hop group D12.

title: Swifty McVay
text: He was accepted into the group as a replacement for Bugz.

title: Uptown 3000
text: Uptown 3000 was a Korean American hip hop duo on the record label The Machine Group CEO Alvin & Calvin Waters which consisted of Carlos Galvan aka "Cali-Mexci" and Steve Kim aka "Kwon".

title: Uptown 3000
text: The duo was a spinoff of Uptown, a Korean hip hop group which was active in the late 1990s whose sales reached 6 million.

title: Uptown 3000
text: The duo is considered defunct as the original Uptown made its comeback in Korea in 2006, which Kim and Galvan were a part of.

title: Uptown 3000
text: The group has been credited with being the first Korean hip hop group to closely resemble anything similar to American style hip hop.

title: Clouds (Apollo Brown album)
text: Clouds is the third studio album by Detroit-based hip hop producer Apollo Brown, released on February 22, 2011, by Mello Music Group.

title: Xtended Play Version 3.13
text: Xtended Play Version 3.13 is the third studio album by Detroit-based hip hop duo Frank n Dank, released on October 24, 2006.

title: Xtended Play Version 3.13
text: The album features production from the likes of J Dilla, Oh No and Rich Kidd, and includes guest appearances from Brick & Lace, Kardinal Offishall, Saukrates, Jeru the Damaja and more.

title: Lawless Element
text: Lawless Element is an underground hip hop duo from Detroit, Michigan.

title: Lawless Element
text: The duo is composed of cousins Griot (West African for "Storyteller", born Alfred Austin) as emcee and Magnif (born Kavi Tapsico) as DJ, producer and emcee.

title: Lawless Element
text: The duo of Magnif and Griot became engulfed in hip hop culture at the ages of 6 and 9, and spent their teenage years honing their skills on the production boards and on the microphone.

title: Lawless Element
text: At the ages of 16 and 19, the duo released their first single, titled "Mic Check", in 2003 on Running Man Records.

title: Lawless Element
text: The next year, the duo hooked up with fellow Detroit native, producer J Dilla, to release the single "The Shining".

title: Lawless Element
text: In early 2005, LE worked with Dilla's Jaylib partner Madlib on the single "High", which landed them a deal with popular independent rap label Babygrande Records.

title: Lawless Element
text: Their debut album, "", was released in September 2005 to generally positive reviews.

title: Lawless Element
text: "Soundvision" featured production from Magnif, J Dilla and Madlib and guest appearances from Dilla, Melanie Rutherford, Phat Kat, Big Tone, P.Dot, SelfSays and Diverse.

title: Lawless Element
text: "Rules Pt. 2" was the album's lead single, and also became the duo's first music video.

title: Lawless Element
