text: MTV mini movie "The Sellars", starring in Vogue photographer Max Doyles "Arc", playing a variety of roles she played in a comedy independent film Super Awesome.

title: Ashley Cheadle
text: Played four roles in "The Scenarist, Cheadle also co-wrote a short film in a day with her close friend Bernard Worner 2016, she co-produced the film and played two characters in the mini film Façade, focusing on the danger of the internet Facade we try to create, it was featured at the International Film Festival out of Santa Monica.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Branko Tomović (Serbian Cyrillic: "Бранко Томовић"; born June 17, 1980) is a German-Serbian actor.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was born in Münster, Germany, though his actual origin is from the Carpathians in Serbia.

title: Branko Tomović
text: His parents emigrated in the '70s from the Golubac Fortress area on the Danube and Branko was raised between Germany and Serbia before he studied acting at the prestigious Lee Strasberg Theatre Institute in New York City.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Tomović was first seen on the big screen in the lead role in the American Film Institute/Sundance drama "Remote Control", for which he received the OmU-Award at the Potsdam Film Festival.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Currently settled in London, with his dark, brooding looks he has appeared in striking roles on British Television.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He played the creepy main suspect Antoni Pricha, the Morgue Man, in Jack the Ripper thriller "Whitechapel", the pyromaniac Junky-Henchman Marek Lisowski in the final episodes of "A Touch of Frost" and Polish fighter pilot Miroslaw Feric in the World War II drama "The Untold Battle of Britain".

title: Branko Tomović
text: Tomovic has worked with internationally respected film directors as Ken Loach, Sönke Wortmann and Paul Greengrass.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was named "One to Watch" by "Moviescope Magazine" in 2008 and recent film credits include The Bourne Ultimatum opposite Matt Damon (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Paul Greengrass), It's a Free World... (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Ken Loach), "The Wolf Man" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Joe Johnston), "Pope Joan" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Sönke Wortmann) and "Interview with a Hitman" (Dir.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Perry Bhandal).

title: Branko Tomović
text: In 2010, he won the 'Best Actor' Award at the San Francisco Short Film Festival and at The Accolade Film Awards for his performance as a Serbian soldier who is tormented by grief and guilt after being a witness of war crimes in the drama Inbetween.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He also stars opposite Debbie Harry in Jimmy Cauty's Road movie Believe the Magic and Steve Stone's ghost thriller Entity with Dervla Kirwan and Charlotte Riley.

title: Branko Tomović
text: Entity won two awards at the London Independent Film Festival 2013 and Best Film at the British Horror Film Festival where Branko was also nominated for Best Actor.

title: Branko Tomović
text: The British Filmmakers Alliance honoured him as Best International Actor for his role and he was also chosen as a Rising Star by Icon Magazine.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He is set to play the title character of Nikola Tesla in the upcoming bio-pic Tesla.

title: Branko Tomović
text: In 2014, he played Jack Bauer's right-hand man, the mysterious and dangerous Belcheck, next to Kiefer Sutherland in 24: Live Another Day.

title: Branko Tomović
text: He was also seen opposite Brad Pitt and Logan Lerman in David Ayer's WWII drama Fury.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: Dirty Pretty Things were an English band fronted by Carl Barât, a member of The Libertines.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: The formation of the band was announced in September 2005, after a dispute between Barât and Pete Doherty led to the breakup of The Libertines in 2004.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: Barât had worked with Vertigo Records and had previously revealed that his new project was with the label.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: Didz Hammond announced he was leaving the Cooper Temple Clause to join the band alongside Libertines drummer Gary Powell and guitarist Anthony Rossomando, who had filled in for Doherty following his departure from The Libertines.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: They played their first shows in October 2005 in Italy and Paris, France.

title: Dirty Pretty Things (band)
text: They announced their split on 1 October 2008 and played their final shows during November.

title: Bang Bang You're Dead (song)
text: "Bang Bang You're Dead" is a song by the band Dirty Pretty Things.

title: Bang Bang You're Dead (song)
text: It was released as a single on 24 April 2006 and was the first to be released from the band's debut album "Waterloo to Anywhere".

title: Bang Bang You're Dead (song)
text: It proved very successful, charting at #5 on the UK Singles Chart (see 2006 in British music).

title: Bang Bang You're Dead (song)
text: In 2006, it was used as the theme tune to the BBC series "Sorted".

title: Carl Barât
text: Carlos Ashley Raphael Barât (born 6 June 1978) is a British musician, best known for being the co-frontman with Peter Doherty of the garage rock band The Libertines.

title: Carl Barât
text: He was the frontman and lead guitarist of Dirty Pretty Things, and in 2010 debuted a solo album.

title: Carl Barât
text: In 2014 he announced the creation of his new band, The Jackals.

title: Didz Hammond
text: David Jonathan Hammond (born 19 July 1981), better known as Didz Hammond, is an English bassist.

title: Didz Hammond
text: He was the bassist and backing vocalist in The Cooper Temple Clause (while also occasionally playing other instruments), and in Carl Barât's Dirty Pretty Things.

title: Didz Hammond
text: The band's second album, "Romance At Short Notice", saw Hammond taking on more vocal duties within the band, for example contributing all the vocals on the ballad "The North".

title: Didz Hammond
text: He is also the bass player in Brett Anderson's live electric band.

title: Didz Hammond
text: Before music, Didz made his trade as a stand up comedian in Reading.

title: Johanna Bennett
text: Johanna Bennett (born 30 September 1984 in Peterborough, England) is an English musician.

title: Johanna Bennett
text: She was the frontwoman of the band Totalizer, whose demos were produced by Dirty Pretty Things guitarist Anthony Rossomando.

title: Johanna Bennett
text: The band played a couple of shows and folded in November 2007.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: Anthony Rossomando is an American writer-producer, composer, and guitarist.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: He along with Carl Barât was a founding member of Dirty Pretty Things.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: He previously stood in for Pete Doherty in The Libertines as a touring member.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: He has also been a live member of British New Rave band Klaxons.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: He was also a member of Boston-based band The Damn Personals.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: He also has co-written songs with D'angelo, Mark Ronson and Andrew Wyatt, Cathy Dennis.

title: Anthony Rossomando
text: Anthony Rossomando's songs are represented by Downtown Music Publishing.

title: Wondering (Dirty Pretty Things song)
text: "Wondering" is a song by the band Dirty Pretty Things.

title: Wondering (Dirty Pretty Things song)
text: It was released as a single on 15 October 2006 and was the third to be released from the band's debut album "Waterloo to Anywhere".

title: Wondering (Dirty Pretty Things song)
text: Early versions of the song generally sported the title "If You Were Wondering", the single-word title being settled upon for the final release of "Waterloo to Anywhere".

title: Mirage (Digitalism album)
text: Mirage is the third studio album by German electronic music duo Digitalism, released on 13 May 2016 by Magnetism Recording Co. through PIAS.

title: Mirage (Digitalism album)
text: Jens Moelle and İsmail Tüfekçi produced all songs on the album, with Moelle providing all vocals aside from Anthony Rossomando of the band Dirty Pretty Things on "Battlecry" and the band's former tour bus driver Anthony Wilson providing a freestyle rap on the hip hop track "The Ism".

title: Deadwood (song)
text: "Deadwood" is a song by the band Dirty Pretty Things.

title: Deadwood (song)
text: It was released as a single on 10 July 2006 and was the second to be released from the band's debut album "Waterloo to Anywhere".

title: Deadwood (song)
text: The band recruited fans via their web site to appear for the filming of the video, which occurred on a farm in the Essex countryside on Tuesday 16 May.

title: Deadwood (song)
text: In 2006 the song was used as the theme tune to "Russell Brand's Got Issues", and later "The Russell Brand Show".

title: Tired of England
text: Tired of England is the first single from "Romance at Short Notice", the second album by Dirty Pretty Things, which was released on 23 June 2008.

title: Rodel Flordeliz
text: Rodel Flordeliz (born Rodelio Pasquito Flordeliz) is a Filipino model and TV Host.

title: Rodel Flordeliz
text: He used to be one of the pioneer field reporters of "SBN channel 21" in the news program "Ito ang Balita".

title: Rodel Flordeliz
text: In 2004 he transferred to "UNTV 37" to host a kiddie show Teleskwela

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: The Itchy & Scratchy Show (often shortened as Itchy & Scratchy) is a running gag and fictional animated television series featured in the American animated television series "The Simpsons".

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: It usually appears as a part of "The Krusty the Clown Show", watched regularly by Bart Simpson and Lisa Simpson.

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: Itself an animated cartoon, "The Itchy & Scratchy Show" depicts a sadistic anthropomorphic blue mouse, Itchy (voiced by Dan Castellaneta), who repeatedly maims and kills an anthropomorphic, hapless threadbare black cat, Scratchy (voiced by Harry Shearer).

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: The cartoon first appeared in "The Tracey Ullman Show" short "The Bart Simpson Show", which originally aired November 20, 1988.

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: The cartoon's first appearance in "The Simpsons" was in the 1990 episode "There's No Disgrace Like Home".

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: Typically presented as 15-to-60-second-long cartoons, the show is filled with gratuitous violence.

title: The Itchy & Scratchy Show
text: "The Simpsons" also occasionally features characters who are involved with the production of "The Itchy & Scratchy Show", including Roger Meyers Jr. (voiced by Alex Rocco, and, later, Hank Azaria), who runs the studio and produces the show.

title: A Day with Doodles
text: A Day With Doodles was an American children's television program that aired in 1964 in syndication through National Telefilm Associates.

title: A Day with Doodles
text: The segments starred Doodles Weaver in comedic slapstick stories in which the main character encountered various mix-ups and failures.

title: A Day with Doodles
text: The stories were all performed by Weaver in assorted costumes while a narrator described the situation in first person plural (e.g., "Today we are a movie producer...").

title: A Day with Doodles
text: The show was marketed for inclusion in local "kiddie show" TV programs where producers would select nationally syndicated cartoon and live action shows and combine them with in-studio material to create a locally produced variety program.

title: Krusty the Clown
text: Herschel Shmoikel Pinchas Yerucham Krustofsky, better known as Krusty the Clown (sometimes spelled as Krusty the Klown), is a cartoon character in the animated television series "The Simpsons".

title: Krusty the Clown
text: He is voiced by Dan Castellaneta.

title: Krusty the Clown
text: He is the long-time clown host of Bart and Lisa's favorite TV show, a combination of kiddie variety television hijinks and cartoons including "The Itchy & Scratchy Show".

title: Krusty the Clown
text: Krusty is often portrayed as a cynical, burnt-out, addiction-riddled smoker who is made miserable by show business but continues on anyway.

title: Krusty the Clown
text: He has become one of the most common characters outside of the main Simpson family and has been the focus of several episodes, most of which also spotlight Bart.

title: Bart to the Future
text: "Bart to the Future" is the seventeenth episode of the eleventh season of the American animated television sitcom "The Simpsons".

title: Bart to the Future
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on March 19, 2000.

title: Bart to the Future
text: In the episode, after their picnic in the park is cut short due to a mosquito infestation, the Simpsons stop by at an Indian casino.

title: Bart to the Future
text: There, Bart is prevented from entering because of his age.

title: Bart to the Future
text: He manages to sneak in but is caught by the guards and sent to the casino manager's office.

title: Bart to the Future
text: The Native American manager shows Bart a vision of his future as a washed-up, wannabe rock musician living with Ralph Wiggum, while Lisa has become the President of the United States and tries to get the country out of financial trouble.

title: Bart to the Future
text: "Bart to the Future" was the second episode of "The Simpsons" after "Lisa's Wedding" to be set in the future.

title: The Telltale Head
text: "The Telltale Head" is the eighth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> first season.

title: The Telltale Head
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on February 25, 1990.

title: The Telltale Head
text: It was written by Al Jean, Mike Reiss, Sam Simon and Matt Groening, and directed by Rich Moore.

title: The Telltale Head
text: In the episode, Bart cuts the head off the statue of Jebediah Springfield in the center of town to impress Jimbo, Kearney and Dolph, three older kids he admires.

title: The Telltale Head
text: The town's residents, including the three boys, are horrified and Bart regrets his actions.

title: The Telltale Head
text: After telling his family, Homer and Bart head to the center of town, where they are met by an angry mob.

title: The Telltale Head
text: After Bart tells the mob he has made a mistake, the townspeople forgive Bart and he places the head back on the statue.

title: The Telltale Head
text: The episode's title is a reference to the short story "The Tell-Tale Heart" by Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Good Night (The Simpsons short)
text: "Good Night" (also known as "Good Night Simpsons") is the first of forty-eight Simpsons shorts that appeared on the variety show "The Tracey Ullman Show".

title: Good Night (The Simpsons short)
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on April 19, 1987, during the third episode of "The Tracey Ullman Show" and marks the first appearance of the Simpson family — Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie — on television.

title: Good Night (The Simpsons short)
text: After three seasons on Tracey Ullman, the shorts would be adapted into the animated show "The Simpsons".

title: Good Night (The Simpsons short)
text: "Good Night" has since been aired on the show in the episode "The Simpsons 138th Episode Spectacular" (in its entirety), along with several other Ullman shorts, and is one of the few shorts to ever be released on DVD, being included in the Season 1 DVD set.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: "Bart Gets Hit by a Car" is the tenth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> second season.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on January 10, 1991.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: At the start of the episode, Bart is hit by Mr. Burns<nowiki>'</nowiki> car.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: Prompted by ambulance-chasing lawyer Lionel Hutz and quack doctor Dr. Nick Riviera, the Simpsons sue Mr. Burns, seeking extensive damages for Bart's injuries.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: Hutz and Dr. Nick exaggerate Bart's injuries so they can gain sympathy at the trial.

title: Bart Gets Hit by a Car
text: Marge is against the whole thing and grows concerned with the fact that Homer is asking Bart to lie.

title: Postcards from the Wedge
text: "Postcards from the Wedge" is the fourteenth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> twenty-first season.

title: Postcards from the Wedge
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on March 14, 2010.

title: Postcards from the Wedge
text: In the episode, Homer and Marge once again try to discipline Bart after Mrs. Krabappel tells them that Bart has not been doing his homework, but Bart has a plan to manipulate Homer's strictness and Marge's sympathetic ear, which backfires when Homer and Marge see through the plan and decide to ignore Bart.

title: Postcards from the Wedge
text: These themes had been seeded in the previous season (e.g. "Double, Double, Boy in Trouble", and "The Good, the Sad, and the Drugly"), would culminate in the show's first ever true grounding, and the first to stand for the rest of the episode.

title: Postcards from the Wedge
text: It would also be the last episode to feature a grounding, until "The Marge-ian Chronicles" in Season 27, six years later (also written by Brian Kelley).

title: Bart the Fink
text: "Bart the Fink" is the fifteenth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> seventh season.

title: Bart the Fink
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on February 11, 1996.

title: Bart the Fink
text: In this episode, Bart ruins Krusty the Clown's career by accidentally exposing Krusty as one of the biggest tax cheats in American history.

title: Bart the Fink
text: Driven to despair, Krusty fakes a suicide in order to start life anew as a sailor; feeling guilty for what he did, Bart convinces Krusty to become a television clown again.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: Birchwood Mall is an enclosed shopping mall located in Fort Gratiot Township, outside the city of Port Huron, Michigan, United States.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: It is owned and managed by Rouse Properties, one of the largest mall owners in the United States.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: The Mall features more than 100 stores, a ten-screen movie theater run by AMC Theatres, and a food court.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: Carson's, JCPenney, Macy's, and Target are the mall's anchor stores.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: The fifth anchor was Sears which closed in 2016.

title: Birchwood Mall
text: The mall is located on Pine Grove Avenue (M-25), north of Interstate 69 (I-69) and I-94.

title: Original Outlet Mall
text: The Original Outlet Mall was an indoor outlet mall located in Kenosha, Wisconsin.

title: Original Outlet Mall
text: The mall opened in 1982 as Wisconsin's first outlet mall.

title: Original Outlet Mall
text: In 2005 the mall was demolished by its new owners, Tucker Development of Highland Park, Illinois.

title: Original Outlet Mall
text: An Ashley Furniture store now occupies a portion of the land on which the mall stood.

title: Karcher Mall
text: Karcher Mall is an enclosed shopping mall located in Nampa, Idaho, U.S..

title: Karcher Mall
text: The mall opened in August 1965 with Buttrey Food & Drug, Rasco-Tempo, and Skaggs Drug Centers as anchor stores.

title: Karcher Mall
text: The mall was the largest shopping center in the Treasure Valley until 1988 when the Boise Towne Square Mall was opened in Boise.

title: Karcher Mall
text: The new mall directed traffic away for the Karcher Mall and several retailers, including 20-year-old anchor JCPenney, departed the mall to move to Boise.

title: Karcher Mall
text: Since then, the mall has been sold to numerous owners, each of which attempted to revitalize the mall to mixed results.

title: Karcher Mall
text: Today, the mall has 28 stores, including anchor stores Burlington Coat Factory, Discount Furniture, Jo-Ann Fabrics, Ross Dress for Less, and Mor Furniture, and is owned by Milan Properties, Inc.

title: Hubert Wilton
text: Hubertus "Huib" Wilton (12 March 1921 in Rotterdam – 29 October 1959) was a Dutch tennis player.

title: Hubert Wilton
text: He was on the 1953 Netherlands Davis Cup team which also included among others Hans van Swol (his partner in the men's doubles), Boebi van Meegeren and Ivo Rinkel.

title: Hubert Wilton
text: In 1950 Wilton reached the second round at Wimbledon, losing to Henry Billington of Great Britain 6–1 7–5 11–9.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: Pierre Bossier Mall is an enclosed shopping mall located at the intersection of Interstate 20 and Airline Drive (Louisiana Highway 3105) in Bossier City, Louisiana.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: The mall, as is the city it is located in, is named after early settler Pierre Bossier.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: The mall was purchased by General Growth Properties, who built and sold it in the 1980s, for $26 million in October 1998.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: It is currently owned and managed by Rouse Properties, one of the largest mall owners in the United States.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: Its anchor stores are J. C. Penney, Sears, Dillard's, Virginia College, and Forever 21, formerly Stage, established with the sale in 1994 by Horace Ladymon of the Beall-Ladymon Corporation.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: The mall had a theater, The Bossier 6.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: It was opened September 10, 1982 and was operated by AMC.

title: Pierre Bossier Mall
text: It closed in 2000.

title: Viaport Rotterdam
text: Viaport Rotterdam, formerly Rotterdam Square, is a shopping mall located in Rotterdam, New York, United States.

title: Viaport Rotterdam
text: When it opened, the mall was originally called Rotterdam Square and owned by Wilmorite Properties (who also owned Wilton Mall in Wilton) until 2005, when Wilmorite was acquired by The Macerich Company, who then took over ownership and management of most of their properties.

title: Viaport Rotterdam
text: The mall has an area of 900000 sqft on one level with over 80 stores, a 450-seat food court as well as restaurants and a seven-screen Sony-Loews Cineplex, now operated by Zurich Cinemas (independent company).

title: Viaport Rotterdam
text: The mall was purchased by Kohan Retail Investment Group in January 2014, and was later sold to Via Properties in June 2015.

title: Viaport Rotterdam
text: In 2016 Via Properties renamed the mall to Via Port Rotterdam

title: Saratoga Mall
text: Saratoga Mall was an enclosed shopping mall in Wilton, New York near the city of Saratoga Springs, New York.

title: Saratoga Mall
text: It was demolished in 1999.

title: Saratoga Mall
text: It was previously known as Pyramid Mall Saratoga and was located on Route 50 just off Exit 15 on I-87 (the Adirondack Northway portion).

title: Saratoga Mall
text: After demolition, it was replaced by a big box strip center known as Wilton Square.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: Eastland Mall was a shopping mall in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: The center opened in 1975 as the then-largest mall in North Carolina with three anchor department stores, Belk, J.C. Penney and Ivey's, and a Sears store joined four years later.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: Burlington Coat Factory, the mall's final anchor, has closed, leaving all anchors vacant.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: The mall was owned by Glimcher Realty Trust and the City of Charlotte.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: Glimcher requested the mall be put into receivership due to heavy debt, and there were reports of the mall entering foreclosure.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: LNR sold the interior space in the mall to Boxer Properties of Houston for $2 million.

title: Eastland Mall (Charlotte, North Carolina)
text: It ceased operations as of June 30, 2010, and was purchased by the city of Charlotte from Boxer Properties, and the owners of the vacant anchors in hopes of selling it to a developer.

title: ViaPort Florida
text: ViaPort Florida (formerly known as Lake Square Mall) is an enclosed shopping mall in Leesburg, Florida.

title: ViaPort Florida
text: Opened on September 24, 1980, it is managed by Lake Square Mall Realty Management and Via Properties.

title: ViaPort Florida
text: Anchor stores are Belk, Sears, and Via Entertainment

title: Wilton Mall
text: Wilton Mall at Saratoga (or simply The Wilton Mall) is a regional shopping center, located off Interstate 87 exit 15 in the town of Wilton, directly north of Saratoga Springs, New York.

title: Wilton Mall
text: The mall has a gross leasable area of 763270 sqft .

title: Wilton Mall
text: The mall is anchored by Bon-Ton, Dick's Sporting Goods, JCPenney, HomeGoods, and Sears; in addition, it features a food court and movie theater.

title: Wilton Mall
text: It is currently owned by Macerich, having been purchased from Wilmorite Properties of Rochester, New York in 2004.

title: Jerry Lucas
text: Jerry Ray Lucas (born March 30, 1940) is an American former basketball player and memory education expert.

title: Jerry Lucas
text: He was a nationally-awarded high school player, national college star at Ohio State, and 1960 gold medal Olympian and international player before starring as a professional player in the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Jerry Lucas
text: As a collegian, Lucas led the Ohio State Buckeyes to the 1960 college national championship and three straight NCAA finals.

title: Jerry Lucas
text: He remains today the only three-time Big Ten Player of the Year, and was also twice named NCAA Player of the Year.

title: Jerry Lucas
text: As a professional, Lucas was named All-NBA First Team three times, a NBA All-Star seven times, was 1964 NBA Rookie of the Year, and was named Most Valuable Player of the 1965 NBA All-Star Game among other honors and awards.

title: Jerry Lucas
text: He was inducted to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 1980.

title: Curt Smith (basketball)
text: Curt "Trouble" Smith (born 1971) is an American former basketball player best known as a streetball legend in the Washington, D.C. and Maryland areas.

title: Curt Smith (basketball)
text: He played college basketball at Compton College and then Drake University.

title: Curt Smith (basketball)
text: While at Drake, Smith was named the Missouri Valley Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year as a junior in 1992–93.

title: Richie Garner
text: Richard "Richie" Garner (born in Mount Vernon, New York) is an American former basketball player who is best known for his NCAA Division I career at Manhattan College.

title: Richie Garner
text: Garner played for the Jaspers between 1968–69 and 1971–72.

title: Richie Garner
text: During his four-year career, he scored over 1,000 points, has a career shooting percentage of better than .500, and set a since-broken single season school record 121 assists in 1970–71.

title: Richie Garner
text: Garner was the first player from Manhattan College to win the Haggerty Award, an annual award presented to the best male collegiate basketball player in the greater New York City area since 1935–36.

title: Richie Garner
text: He earned it as a senior and was the co-recipient with Fordham's Tom Sullivan.

title: Jay Williams (basketball)
text: Jason David Williams (born September 10, 1981) is an American former basketball player and current college basketball analyst.

title: Jay Williams (basketball)
text: He played college basketball for the Duke University Blue Devils and professionally for the Chicago Bulls in the NBA.

title: Jay Williams (basketball)
text: He last signed with the Austin Toros of the NBA Development League, but was waived by the Toros on December 30, 2006 due to lingering physical effects from a 2003 motorcycle accident.

title: Jay Williams (basketball)
text: Although he had been known as Jason, he asked to be called Jay on joining the Bulls in 2002, to avoid confusion with two other players in the NBA at the time, Jason Williams and Jayson Williams.

title: Eduardo Portela
text: Eduardo Portela Marín (born 1934 in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain) is a Spanish former basketball player, former basketball coach, and basketball executive.

title: Eduardo Portela
text: He is the former head of the ACB, the governing body of the top-tier level Spanish professional club basketball league, and the former head of ULEB, the Union of European Leagues of Basketball.

title: Delray Brooks
text: Delray Brooks (October 24, 1965) is an American basketball coach and former basketball player.

title: Delray Brooks
text: Brooks was an Indiana high school basketball star who was named both 1984 Co-Indiana Mr. Basketball and 1984 USA Today Player of the Year.

title: Delray Brooks
text: After high school, he first attended Indiana University to play basketball for Bobby Knight.

title: Delray Brooks
text: When he didn't fit into the team plans as he had hoped he transferred to play for Rick Pitino at Providence College, where the team was one of the most successful in school history.

title: Delray Brooks
text: As a professional player, his career floundered in various leagues before he began coaching basketball as an assistant for Pitino at the University of Kentucky.

title: Delray Brooks
text: He reached the NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship final four as both a player and assistant coach.

title: Delray Brooks
text: When Pitino left for the NBA, he moved on to a head coaching position at the University of Texas-Pan American.

title: Delray Brooks
text: He was eventually caught up in a scandal and fired.

title: Delray Brooks
text: He has since coached various high school teams.

title: Delray Brooks
text: , he is the head coach for the men's basketball team at Clay High School.

title: Mike Edwards (basketball)
text: Mike Edwards (born early 1950s) is an American former basketball player best known for his high school and collegiate careers in the United States rather than his professional career in Mexico.

title: Mike Edwards (basketball)
text: He played for the University of Tennessee between 1970–71 and 1972–73 and was named the 1972 co-Southeastern Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year.

title: Mike Edwards (basketball)
text: He has been enshrined in the Indiana Basketball Hall of Fame as part of its Class of 2003, and in February 2009 was chosen to the Tennessee All-Century Team, commemorating the greatest 20 players in program history.

title: Von McDade
text: Von McDade (born June 7, 1967) is an American former basketball player.

title: Von McDade
text: He played college basketball for the Oklahoma State Cowboys and Milwaukee Panthers basketball teams.

title: Von McDade
text: In 1991, he was third in the nation among college basketball players in points per game, with an average of 29.6.

title: Von McDade
text: He was drafted in the second round of the 1991 NBA draft by the New Jersey Nets, but he did not play in the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Ricky Rubio
text: Ricard Rubio i Vives (born October 21, 1990) is a Spanish professional basketball player for the Utah Jazz of the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Ricky Rubio
text: Rubio became the youngest player ever to play in the Spanish ACB League on October 15, 2005, at age 14.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: He made his EuroLeague debut on October 24, 2006, at age 16, becoming the first player born in the 1990s to play in a EuroLeague game.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: He is the fifth-youngest player to make their debut in the EuroLeague.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: On June 25, 2009, he was drafted with the fifth pick in the first round of the 2009 NBA draft by the Timberwolves, making him the first player born in the 1990s to be drafted by the NBA.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: The Timberwolves had an agreement in principle with his former Spanish team, DKV Joventut, to buy out his contract, but Rubio backed out of the deal.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: On August 31, 2009, Joventut traded the rights to Rubio to FC Barcelona, and Rubio signed a six-year contract with FC Barcelona the following day.

title: Ricky Rubio
text: In 2011, Rubio joined the Minnesota Timberwolves, and spent six seasons in Minnesota before being traded to the Jazz in June 2017.

title: 2000–01 Minnesota Timberwolves season
text: The 2000–01 NBA season was the Timberwolves' 12th season in the National Basketball Association.

title: 2000–01 Minnesota Timberwolves season
text: After the death of Malik Sealy, the Timberwolves scrambled to find a replacement for him, signing free agent Chauncey Billups, a close friend of Kevin Garnett while signing LaPhonso Ellis.

title: 2000–01 Minnesota Timberwolves season
text: Meanwhile, the Timberwolves secret free agent deal signed by Joe Smith was voided by the NBA, who ruled their proper procedure in signing the contract, while stripping their first round draft picks for the next five seasons and fined $3.5 million.

title: 2000–01 Minnesota Timberwolves season
text: Smith would sign with the Detroit Pistons, and the Timberwolves' owner Glen Taylor, and vice president Kevin McHale were both suspended for one year.

title: 2000–01 Minnesota Timberwolves season
text: Despite the troubles, the Timberwolves posted an 11-game winning streak midway through the season, and finished fourth in the Midwest Division with a 47–35 record, with Garnett being selected for the 2001 NBA All-Star Game.

title: Marietta Air Force Station
text: Marietta Air Force Station (ADC ID: M-111, NORAD ID: Z-111) is a closed United States Air Force General Surveillance Radar station.

title: Marietta Air Force Station
text: It is located 2.1 mi northeast of Smyrna, Georgia.

title: Marietta Air Force Station
text: It was closed in 1968.

title: RAF Warmwell
text: RAF Warmwell is a former Royal Air Force station near Warmwell in Dorset, England from 1937 to 1946, located about 5 miles east-southeast of Dorchester; 100 miles southwest of London.

title: 302d Air Division
text: The 302d Air Division is an inactive United States Air Force Division.

title: 302d Air Division
text: Its last assignment was with Fourteenth Air Force at Marietta Air Force Base, Georgia, where it was inactivated on 27 June 1949.

title: 410th Bombardment Squadron
text: The 410th Bombardment Squadron is an inactive United States Air Force unit.

title: 410th Bombardment Squadron
text: It was last assigned to the 94th Bombardment Group.

title: 410th Bombardment Squadron
text: It was inactivated at Marietta Air Force Base, Georgia on 20 March 1951.

title: Stony Brook Air Force Station
text: Stony Brook Air Force Station is a former Air Force Station that operated from the 1950s until 1972.

title: Stony Brook Air Force Station
text: It is located in Ludlow, Massachusetts, adjacent to Westover Joint Air Reserve Base.

title: Stony Brook Air Force Station
text: Between 1954 and 1962 Stony Brook AFS was an Operational Storage Site for Air Materiel Command (AMC-OSS), one of five in the United States, and the nuclear weapons storage and maintenance facility for Westover Air Force Base alert aircraft.

title: Stony Brook Air Force Station
text: In July 1962 it was transferred to the operational control of the Strategic Air Command (SAC).

title: Camp Pedricktown radar station
text: The Camp Pedricktown Air Defense Base was a Cold War Missile Master installation with an Army Air Defense Command Post, and associated search, height finder, and identification friend or foe radars.

title: Camp Pedricktown radar station
text: The station's radars were subsequently replaced with radars at Gibbsboro Air Force Station 15 miles away.

title: Camp Pedricktown radar station
text: The obsolete Martin AN/FSG-1 Antiaircraft Defense System,a 1957-vintage vacuum tube computer, was removed after command of the defense area was transferred to the command post at Highlands Air Force Station near New York City.

title: Camp Pedricktown radar station
text: The Highlands AFS command post controlled the combined New York-Philadelphia Defense Area.

title: RAF Cottesmore
text: Royal Air Force Station Cottesmore or more simply RAF Cottesmore is a former Royal Air Force station in Rutland, England, situated between Cottesmore and Market Overton.

title: RAF Cottesmore
text: The station housed all the operational Harrier GR9 squadrons in the Royal Air Force, and No. 122 Expeditionary Air Wing.

title: RAF Cottesmore
text: On 15 December 2009 it was announced that the station would close in 2013 as part of defence spending cuts, along with the retirement of the Harrier GR9 and the disbandment of Joint Force Harrier.

title: RAF Cottesmore
text: However the formal closing ceremony took place on 31 March 2011 with the airfield becoming a satellite to RAF Wittering until March 2012.

title: Eldorado Air Force Station
text: Eldorado Air Force Station located 35 miles south of San Angelo, Texas was one of the four unique AN/FPS-115 PAVE PAWS, early-warning phased-array radar systems.

title: Eldorado Air Force Station
text: The 8th Space Warning Squadron, 21st Space Wing, Air Force Space Command operated at Eldorado Air Force Station.

title: Topsham Air Force Station
text: Topsham Air Force Station is a closed United States Air Force station.

title: Topsham Air Force Station
text: It is located 2.1 mi north of Brunswick, Maine.

title: Topsham Air Force Station
text: It was closed in 1969.

title: Stramshall
text: Stramshall is a village within the civil parish of Uttoxeter Rural in the county of Staffordshire, England.

title: Stramshall
text: The village is 2.1 miles north of the town of Uttoxeter, 16.3 miles north east of Stafford and 143 miles north west of London.

title: Stramshall
text: The village lies 0.8 miles north of the A50 that links Warrington to Leicester.

title: Stramshall
text: The nearest railway station is at Uttoxeter for the Crewe to Derby line.

title: Stramshall
text: The nearest airport is East Midlands Airport.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: Rishi Chanda (Bengali: ঋষি চন্দ ) is an Indian music director, composer and singer,based out of Mumbai.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: It all began with playing the Mandolin, performing at the AIR studios then as a child artist.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: In the early years of his career, he made his mark with the Bangla Band Parash Pathor.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: Thereafter, he has performed with the inimitable Hip Pocket, a rock band based in Kolkata, across the country and abroad.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: The world of entertainment has changed since.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: But for Rishi, the love for music has only grown.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: Today with several chart toppers under his belt and many upcoming big banner releases, Rishi Chanda is a leading music composer in Bengali Films.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: Apart from composing for films and stage performances, Rishi has composed for several ad films and jingles in a career spanning almost two decades.

title: Rishi Chanda
text: Airtel, SREI, TATA Cummins, Lafarge, Vivel, Max Fashion, The times of India and lots more.

title: Araby Lockhart
text: Araby Lockhart (born December 4, 1926) is a Canadian stage and television actress, best known for her performances in the films "Capote" and "Police Academy" and her stage performances as a member of Hart House Theatre and the Straw Hat Players.

title: Araby Lockhart
text: Lockhart has also served as President of the Actors' Fund of Canada.

title: Manorama (Tamil actress)
text: Gopishantha (26 May 1937 – 10 October 2015), better known by her stage name Manorama, also called as Aachi, was an Indian actress and comedian who had appeared in more than 1,500 films, 5,000 stage performances, and several television series until 2015.

title: Manorama (Tamil actress)
text: She entered the "Guinness World Records" for acting in more than 1000 number of films in 1985.

title: Manorama (Tamil actress)
text: By 2015, she had acted in more than 1,500 films.

title: Manorama (Tamil actress)
text: She was a recipient of the Kalaimamani award, Padma Shri (2002), National Film Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in film "Pudhiya Padhai" (1989), and Filmfare Lifetime Achievement Award – South (1995).

title: Buried Country
text: Buried Country is a highly regarded documentary film, book and soundtrack album and now also a stageshow as well.

title: Buried Country
text: It is a prosopography, created by noted writer Clinton Walker, that tells the story of Australian country music in the Aboriginal community by focussing on the genre's most important stars.

title: E. J. Carroll
text: Edward John Carroll (1874-1931), better known as E.J. Carroll, was an Australian theatre and film entrepreneur.

title: E. J. Carroll
text: He produced several films of Snowy Baker and Raymond Longford and helped establish Birch, Carroll and Coyle.

title: E. J. Carroll
text: Difficulties in securing international distribution for his films turned him away from production towards exhibition.

title: Milan Murray
text: Margaretha Murray (stage name Milan Murray) (30 October 1974) is a South African actress.

title: Milan Murray
text: She is most well known to the South African public for roles in various soap operas, but she has also played and starred in feature films, and regularly does stage performances.

title: Milan Murray
text: In addition she co-anchors "Ontbytsake", a weekly Breakfast show on kykNET, an Afrikaans channel on DStv.

title: Milan Murray
text: She lives in Johannesburg with her husband, Schalk van der Merwe, her son Steph and daughter Lua.

title: Milan Murray
text: She was raised in the Cape Province, South Africa.

title: Leah Flanagan
text: Leah Flanagan is a singer-songwriter from Sydney, NSW.

title: Leah Flanagan
text: Leah has appeared on Australian TV shows Spicks & Specks and RockQuiz, has released 2 albums and toured extensively through Australia with her music and part of festival ensembles.

title: Leah Flanagan
text: Leah’s status as an Indigenous musician is one of pride and respect; she has helped make history with such recent essential albums as Archie Roach’s 25th anniversary reissue of Charcoal Lane and Buried Country 1.5, The Story of Aboriginal Country Music.

title: Leah Flanagan
text: Her latest album Saudades was recorded at the studio of Midnight Oil's Jim Moginie and mixed by Paul McKercher (You Am I, Augie March)

title: Sine Novela
text: Sine Novela is a Philippine daytime soap opera aired on GMA Network which showcases old classic movies from Viva Films turned into a mini-series.

title: Sine Novela
text: The show was stars and lead into an ensemble cast.

title: Woody Guthrie Folk Festival
text: The Woody Guthrie Folk Festival is held annually in mid-July to commemorate the life and music of Woody Guthrie.

title: Woody Guthrie Folk Festival
text: The festival is held on the weekend closest to July 14 - the date of Guthrie's birth - in Guthrie's hometown of Okemah, Oklahoma.

title: Woody Guthrie Folk Festival
text: Daytime main stage performances are held indoors at the Brick Street Cafe and the Crystal Theater.

title: Woody Guthrie Folk Festival
text: Evening main stage performances are held outdoors at the Pastures of Plenty.

title: Woody Guthrie Folk Festival
text: The festival is planned and implemented annually by the Woody Guthrie Coalition, a non-profit corporation, whose goal is simply to ensure Guthrie's musical legacy.

title: Clinton Walker
text: Clinton Walker (born 1957) is an Australian writer, best known for his works on popular music but with a broader interest in social and cultural history and theory.

title: Clinton Walker
text: Sydney's "Sun-Herald" has called him "our best chronicler of Australian grass-roots culture."

title: Clinton Walker
text: He has always been ahead of the curve.

title: Clinton Walker
text: As "Rhythms" magazine said in 2015, "Like many of Walker’s projects, "Buried Country" was at least a decade ahead of its time," and as such he is remarkable as a critic who has exerted a pro-active impact on Australian music and its development; groundbreaking books like "Inner City Sound" (1981) and "Buried Country" (2000) especially have informed and inspired successive generations of musicians.

title: Clinton Walker
text: Similarly, while he found best-selling success as Bon Scott's biographer, Walker's non-music books like "Football Life" (1998) and "Golden Miles" (2005) have innovatively offered an appreciation of subjects hitherto hardly deemed worthy of serious consideration.

title: All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film
text: All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film, a Gallery East Production in association with Stone Films/NYC, is a documentary directed by Drew Stone, which had its world premier at the Independent Film Festival of Boston on April 27, 2012.

title: All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film
text: The film features interviews, archival footage and the music of Boston’s early hardcore bands including Deep Wound, DYS, Gang Green, Impact Unit, Jerry's Kids, Negative FX, SS Decontrol, The Freeze and The F.U.'s.

title: All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film
text: Also featured in the film are interviews with renowned author Michael Patrick MacDonald ("Easter Rising", "All Souls"), Actress Christine Elise McCarthy, Advertising Executive Jonathan Anastas, Thrasher Magazine Editor Jake Phelps, "American Hardcore" Director Paul Rachman, and Newbury Comics owner Michael Dreese.

title: All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film
text: "All Ages" has been released on DVD with numerous extras and director's commentary.

title: I Against I
text: I Against I is the third studio album by the American hardcore punk band Bad Brains.

title: I Against I
text: It was released in November 1986 through SST Records with the catalog number SST 065.

title: I Against I
text: The best-selling album in the band's catalog, "I Against I" is a critically acclaimed album that mixes American hardcore punk with funk, soul, reggae and heavy metal.

title: I Against I
text: It is also included in the book "1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die".

title: I Against I
text: The album featured an MTV video for the title track directed by Paul Rachman who later went on to direct the documentary feature film "American Hardcore".

title: Black Market Baby
text: Black Market Baby was an American hardcore punk band from Washington, D.C.They are considered one of the seminal groups that created the original hardcore scene in the Washington area, which along with Los Angeles and New York, became the most affluent hardcore scene in America during the early 1980s, considered the high tide of the musical movement.

title: Hellfest (American music festival)
text: Hellfest was an American hardcore punk festival.

title: Hellfest (American music festival)
text: Named for the intense summer heat at the show, the festival originally began featuring hardcore bands before crossing into several genres later on.

title: Hellfest (American music festival)
text: Hellfest was known for its fan-friendly atmosphere, (including a lack of barriers, providing easy access to the stage for stage diving) and for its high social-awareness, focusing on such causes as animal rights, with many attendees following the straight edge and/or vegan lifestyle.

title: Hellfest (American music festival)
text: It continued as an annual event until it was cancelled in 2005.

title: Hellfest (American music festival)
text: After its cancellation less than thirty-six hours before doors were scheduled to open on the festival's ninth year, some fans, unhappy with the inadequate processing of refunds, filed small claims court lawsuits against promoter Keith Allen.

title: Pagan Babies (punk band)
text: Pagan Babies is an American hardcore punk band from Philadelphia, PA, founded by Michael J. McManus, vocals and lyrics, Eric Squadroni, lead guitar, Mark Pingitore, bass, Dan McGinnis, rhythm guitar, and Bruce Boyd, drums.

title: Pagan Babies (punk band)
text: From their first practices in the Fall of 1986 to their last shows in the Winter of 1989, the Pagan Babies were an active and influential band in the hardcore/punk community.

title: Pagan Babies (punk band)
text: The Pagan Babies fused hardcore punk, with rap and hip hop.

title: Punk's Not Dead (2007 film)
text: Punk's Not Dead is a 2007 documentary film directed by Susan Dynner, an American hardcore punk fan.

title: Punk's Not Dead (2007 film)
text: The film claims to infiltrate American clubs, malls, recording studios, etc. where it sets out to claim hardcore punk and pop punk music is "thriving" from an American perspective.

title: Punk's Not Dead (2007 film)
text: Its content features performances largely from 1980s hardcore bands and MTV skate punk and pop punk/rock acts.

title: Punk's Not Dead (2007 film)
text: It also includes various interviews and behind-the-scenes footage with the bands, labels and fans.

title: When People Grow, People Go
text: When People Grow, People Go is the fourth studio album by American hardcore punk band Blacklisted.

title: When People Grow, People Go
text: The album was released on February 10, 2015 through Deathwish Inc. "When People Grow, People Go" is the first release from Blacklisted since 2012's "So, You Are A Magician?"

title: When People Grow, People Go
text: EP, and first full-length studio album since 2009's "No One Deserves to Be Here More Than Me".

title: When People Grow, People Go
text: Writing for the album began in late 2013 and sonically is described as being a mix of the band's more experimental styles and hardcore styles.

title: When People Grow, People Go
text: In December 2014, Blacklisted previewed the track "Deeper Kind" for online streaming followed by a stream of "Burnt Palms" and a music video for "Turn in the Pike" both in January 2015.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: Deadfall is a 1993 crime drama film directed by Christopher Coppola.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: Coppola co-wrote the script with Nick Vallelonga.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: The film stars Michael Biehn, Nicolas Cage, Charlie Sheen, James Coburn, and Peter Fonda.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: It is also the prime influence on the song 'Deadfall', written by the American hardcore punk band Snot.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: A prequel/sequel, "Arsenal", starring Nicolas Cage as his character Eddie King, was released in 2017.

title: The Suicide File
text: The Suicide File was an American hardcore punk band from Boston, Massachusetts that formed in April 2001.

title: The Suicide File
text: The band wrote songs with a mostly political message, although many songs also dealt with social and personal problems.

title: The Suicide File
text: Most of the band's output was released on the Southern California-based hardcore label Indecision Records.

title: The Suicide File
text: The band reunited in June 2006 to embark on their first European Tour.

title: The Suicide File
text: Members of the bands are or have been affiliated with The Hope Conspiracy, Death By Stereo, When Tigers Fight, Adamantium, Give Up the Ghost/American Nightmare, Clouds, Panic and many more.

title: The Suicide File
text: Most of these are bands with whom Alexander has drummed for short periods of time.

title: The Suicide File
text: Dave Weinberg was also known for his frequent collaborations and duets with Julie Ecker and James "Boom Boom" Auclair (cf. unpublished correspondence with the artists).

title: The Suicide File
text: Despite their short tenure, The Suicide File continues to be revered within the hardcore punk community for their musical output and lasting impression on the flourishing Boston hardcore scene.

title: The Suicide File
text: The band since 2006 has played a small number of successfully sized reunion sets.

title: Combat Zone Wrestling
text: Combat Zone Wrestling (CZW) is an American independent wrestling promotion.

title: Combat Zone Wrestling
text: In 1999, John Zandig and five of his students, Ric Blade, T.C.K, Lobo, Nick Gage, and Justice Pain (along with trainer Jon Dahmer) began to run professional wrestling shows in New Jersey and Delaware, showcasing a brand of hardcore wrestling dubbed as "ultraviolence".

title: Combat Zone Wrestling
text: Ladders, tables, steel folding chairs, thumbtacks, barbed wire, weed whackers, light tubes, panes of glass, and fire are all common elements of "ultraviolent wrestling" in CZW.

title: Combat Zone Wrestling
text: The company filled a niche for hardcore wrestling fans that had been left open by the folding of Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW).

title: Combat Zone Wrestling
text: CZW established themselves as the leading American hardcore wrestling promotion at the ECW Arena with their "Cage of Death 3" show in 2001, the year ECW folded.

title: Generosity: An Enhancement
text: Generosity: An Enhancement is the tenth novel by American author Richard Powers.

title: Generosity: An Enhancement
text: Like other Powers novels it is idea-driven, strongly focusing on social alienation and scientific progress.

title: Generosity: An Enhancement
text: The novel employs metafiction, including real-time intrusions by the narrator who explicitly sets the novel in a "parallel" Chicago.

title: Eve Unsell
text: Eve Unsell (1887 – July 6, 1937) was an American screenwriter.

title: Eve Unsell
text: She wrote for 96 films between 1914 and 1933.

title: Eve Unsell
text: She was born in Chicago, Illinois, and died in Hollywood, California.

title: Eve Unsell
text: Eve was an American scenarist who was known to also use the pseudonym Oliver W. Geoffreys as well as E.M. Unsell.

title: Eve Unsell
text: She was born in Chicago, Illinois, and died on July 6, 1937.

title: Eve Unsell
text: There is little documentation of her private life except that she was married in 1911 until her death, to a man named Lester Blankfield.

title: Eve Unsell
text: Eve Unsell was a professional in her career as a scenarist, overcoming many challenges along the way.

title: Eve Unsell
text: Eve wrote for over 96 films in her lifetime, and edited over ten.

title: Eve Unsell
text: Some of her most famous screen writes turned into productions include "Shadows" (1922), "The Ancient Mariner" (1925), "The Plastic Age" (1925), and "The Spirit of Youth" (1929).

title: Eve Unsell
text: Although she was most famous for her work in scenario writing she can also be given credit as an adapter, company director, editor, play reader, screenwriter, theatre actress, and writer.

title: Eve Unsell
text: She helped in the writing of many novels as long as editing many different pieces from literature to theatrical writing.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: Shadows in Flight is a science fiction novel by Orson Scott Card.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: When released in 2012, it became the tenth novel published in the "Ender's Game" series.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: The story follows on from where the original four "Shadow series" books left off.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: It is about Bean and his children discovering an ancient Formic "ark" during their journey in space.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: A sample chapter was released on November 28, 2011.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: The hardcover version was released on January 17, 2012, and the paperback was released on January 29, 2013.

title: Shadows in Flight
text: It was nominated for the Goodreads Choice Award for science fiction.

title: Persistence of Memory
text: Persistence of Memory is the tenth novel by American teen author Amelia Atwater-Rhodes and is the fifth novel in her Den of Shadows series.

title: Persistence of Memory
text: Published on December 9, 2008 the novel tells the story of Erin Misrahe and her struggles with her alter-ego Shevaun, who is in fact a vampire with whom Erin has a link.

title: Persistence of Memory
text: The novel also mentions a character from Atwater-Rhodes's previous novel, "In the Forests of the Night" (1999), Alexander, the brother of the protagonist, Risika.

title: Persistence of Memory
text: The poem by Edgar Allan Poe entitled "A Dream Within a Dream" is featured in the novel.

title: "J" Is for Judgment
text: "J" Is for Judgment is the tenth novel in Sue Grafton's "Alphabet" series of mystery novels and features Kinsey Millhone, a private eye based in Santa Teresa, California.

title: "J" Is for Judgment
text: The novel features a significant development in Kinsey's personal back-story, as she discovers that she has extensive family living in the Lompoc area.

title: Walter Sorrells
text: Walter Sorrells is an award-winning author of mystery and suspense novels for adults and teens.

title: Walter Sorrells
text: He has written many novels, including "Fake I.D.", named one of the ten Best Mysteries by Booklist magazine in 2005 and several novels based-on the television series Flight 29 Down.

title: Walter Sorrells
text: He also writes under the pseudonyms Lynn Abercrombie and Ruth Birmingham.

title: Walter Sorrells
text: He graduated from Haverford College in 1985, where he majored in History.

title: The Diamond Chariot
text: The Diamond Chariot (Russian: Алмазная Колесница , the Russian term for the "Diamond Vehicle" ("kongōjō") school of Tantric Buddhism) is a historical mystery novel by internationally acclaimed Russian detective story writer Boris Akunin, published originally in 2003.

title: The Diamond Chariot
text: It is the tenth novel in Akunin's Erast Fandorin series of historical detective novels.

title: The Diamond Chariot
text: As with all of the other Fandorin novels, "The Diamond Chariot" was hugely successful in Russia, selling out its first printing of 200,000 copies in a week.

title: A Sleeping Life
text: A Sleeping Life is a crime-novel by British writer Ruth Rendell, first published in 1978.

title: A Sleeping Life
text: It features her popular investigator Detective Inspector Wexford, and is the tenth novel in the series.

title: A Sleeping Life
text: It was shortlisted for the Mystery Writers' Of America Edgar Award, making it one of only two Inspector Wexford novels ever to have been shortlisted for either of the "big two" crime-fiction awards, the Edgar or the CWA Gold Dagger, despite the series' huge commercial popularity. "

title: A Sleeping Life
text: An Unkindness of Ravens" was also nominated several years later.

title: Merlin Book 10: Shadows on the Stars
text: "Shadows on the Stars" is a work of fiction by T. A. Barron, published by Penguin Young Readers Group.

title: Merlin Book 10: Shadows on the Stars
text: The book is the tenth novel in the 12-book series known as Merlin Saga.

title: Merlin Book 10: Shadows on the Stars
text: It was originally published as "The Great Tree of Avalon: Shadows on the Stars", the second novel in "The Great Tree of Avalon" trilogy, and is set in a world made up of a great tree and its seven roots inhabited by creatures.

title: Castle Richmond
text: Castle Richmond is the third of five novels set in Ireland by Anthony Trollope.

title: Castle Richmond
text: "Castle Richmond" was written between 4 August 1859 and 31 March 1860, and was published in three volumes on 10 May 1860.

title: Castle Richmond
text: It was his tenth novel.

title: Castle Richmond
text: Trollope signed the contract for the novel on 2 August 1859.

title: Castle Richmond
text: He received £600, £200 more than the payment for his previous novel, "The Bertrams," reflecting his growing popular success.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team was an American football team that represented Arizona State University in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1958 college football season.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their first season under head coach Frank Kush, the Sun Devils compiled a 7–3 record (3–1 against BIAA opponents) and outscored their opponents by a combined total of 271 to 131.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Cecil Coleman, Chuck Fairbanks, Paul Kemp, & Dick Tamburo.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Arizona State's team captains were QB John Hangartner and RT Tom Ford.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (5-2) at home and (2-1) at home.

title: 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: One home game was played at Goodwin Stadium and six home games were played at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team was an American football team that represented Arizona State University in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1959 college football season.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their second season under head coach Frank Kush, the Sun Devils compiled a 10–1 record (5–0 against BIAA opponents), won the BIAA championship and outscored their opponents by a combined total of 272 to 151.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Chuck Fairbanks, Gene Felker, Paul Kemp, & Dick Tamburo.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Arizona State's team captains were TE Karl Kiefer and WR Bill Spanko.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (7-0) at home and (3-1) on the road.

title: 1959 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: All home games were played at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team was an American football team that represented Arizona State College (later renamed Arizona State University) in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1956 college football season.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their second season under head coach Dan Devine, the Sun Devils compiled a 9–1 record (2–1 against BIAA opponents) and outscored their opponents by a combined total of 306 to 83.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Tom Fletcher, Frank Kush, Al Onofrio, & Gordon Serr.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Arizona State's team captain was WR Charlie Mackey.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (5-1) at home and (4-0) on the road.

title: 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: All home games were played at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: 1955 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

text: Assistant Coaches were Robert Carey, Tom Fletcher, Frank Kush, & Al Onofrio.

title: 1955 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

text: The Sun Devils finished (5-1) at home and (3-1-1) on the road.

title: 1955 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Harold Brown and Bob White were assistant coaches.

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: All home games were played at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1960 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1960 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their third and final season under head coach Clyde B. Smith, the Sun Devils compiled an 5-5 record (3–1 against BIAA opponents) and were outscored by their opponents 228 to 178.

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Gene Fetter, Tom Fletcher, & Bob White.

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (3-3) at home and (2-2) on the road.

title: 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team was an American football team that represented Arizona State University in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1961 college football season.

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their fourth season under head coach Frank Kush, the Sun Devils compiled a 7–3 record (3–1 against BIAA opponents), won the BIAA championship, and outscored their opponents by a combined total of 287 to 163.

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Chuck Fairbanks, Gene Felker, Bill Kajikawa, Paul Kemp, & Dick Tamburo.

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Arizona State's team captains were LG Dick Locke and C Fred Rhoades.

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (4-2) at home and (3-1) on the road.

title: 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team

title: Arizona State Sun Devils football
text: The Arizona State Sun Devils football team represents Arizona State University in the sport of American football.

title: Arizona State Sun Devils football
text: The Sun Devils team competes in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and the South Division of the Pac-12 Conference (Pac-12).

title: Arizona State Sun Devils football
text: Arizona State University has fielded a football team since 1897 and has an all-time record of 600-382-24 (a .608 winning percentage).

title: Arizona State Sun Devils football
text: The Sun Devils are currently led by head coach Todd Graham and play their home games at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: Arizona State Sun Devils football
text: The Sun Devils have won seventeen conference titles, including three Pac-12 titles.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team was an American football team that represented Arizona State College (later renamed Arizona State University) in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1952 college football season.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: In their first season under head coach Clyde B. Smith, the Sun Devils compiled a 6–3 record (4–0 against BIAA opponents) and outscored their opponents by a combined total of 247 to 121.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Assistant Coaches were Harold Brown and Bob White.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: All home games were played at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: The Sun Devils finished (4-3) at home and (2-0) on the road.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: ASC finished in 1st place of the Border Conference in 1952.

title: 1952 Arizona State Sun Devils football team
text: Arizona State's team captain was C Virgil Savage.

title: Jaeger O'Meara
text: Jaeger O'Meara (born 23 February 1994) is a professional Australian rules footballer playing for the Hawthorn Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Jaeger O'Meara
text: He previously played for the Gold Coast Football Club between 2013 and 2016.

title: Jaeger O'Meara
text: O'Meara won the AFL Rising Star award in his first season in 2013.

title: Kevin Sheehan
text: Kevin Vincent Sheehan (born 1 August 1953) is a former Australian rules footballer for Geelong and the current Australian Football League (AFL) National Talent and International Manager, a member of the AFL football operations sub-committee and a selector for the AFL Rising Star award.

title: AFL Rising Star
text: The NAB AFL Rising Star award is given annually to a standout young player in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: AFL Rising Star
text: The first award was made in 1993.

title: AFL Rising Star
text: Since 2007, the winner has been presented with the Ron Evans Medal.

title: AFL Rising Star
text: It was originally known as the Norwich Rising Star award due to sponsorship reasons from 1993 to 1999, Ansett sponsored the award in 2000 and 2001 and the National Australia Bank (NAB) has been the major sponsor since 2002.

title: Clayton Oliver
text: Clayton Oliver (born 22 July 1997) is a professional Australian rules footballer playing for the Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Clayton Oliver
text: A midfielder, 1.87 m tall and weighing 88 kg , Oliver is known for his capabilities on the inside due to his handball and clearance work.

title: Clayton Oliver
text: He was a late bloomer in his junior career, where he struggled to play in the TAC Cup in 2014 and he missed selection in the 2015 AFL Under 18 Championships.

title: Clayton Oliver
text: After playing with the Murray Bushrangers in 2015, his achievements included best and fairest wins for the league and the Murray Bushrangers, which resulted in Melbourne drafting him with the fourth selection in the 2015 AFL draft.

title: Clayton Oliver
text: He made his debut in the 2016 season, which garnered a Rising Star nomination.

title: Clayton Oliver
text: After his second season in the AFL, he was adjudged the best young player by the AFL coaches.

title: Marcus Bontempelli
text: Marcus Bontempelli (born 24 November 1995) is an Australian rules footballer who represents the Western Bulldogs in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Marcus Bontempelli
text: Bontempelli was drafted by the Bulldogs with pick 4 in the 2013 AFL Draft.

title: Marcus Bontempelli
text: After a successful debut season, he won the Best First-Year Player award for 2014 and was runner up in the 2014 AFL Rising Star award, finishing one vote behind Lewis Taylor.

title: Sam Butler
text: Samuel Butler (born 14 January 1986) is a former professional Australian rules footballer who played for the West Coast Eagles in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Sam Butler
text: A talented underage soccer player from Gawler, South Australia, who only took up football as a teenager, he was drafted by West Coast with the 20th pick at the 2003 National Draft, having played in a SANFL reserves premiership for Central District the year he was drafted.

title: Sam Butler
text: Butler debuted for West Coast during the 2004 season, and was nominated for the AFL Rising Star award.

title: Sam Butler
text: A mid-sized defender and occasional midfielder, he played in West Coast's 2006 premiership team, but missed the entire next season due to injury.

title: Sam Butler
text: Butler has struggled with injury throughout his career, only playing his 100th game during the 2013 season, ten seasons after his debut.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: Rising Star Award (known from 2013 as EE Rising Star Award, previously known as Orange Rising Star Award) is one of the award categories for the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) which acknowledges new talents in the acting industry.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: The award was created after Mary Selway's death in 2004.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: She has been recognised for her successful role as a casting director and has helped many new actors and actresses to their claim to fame.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: The five nominees have been chosen regardless of gender, nationality and whether they have made a breakthrough in television, film or both.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: Despite the nominees being chosen by the BAFTA juries, the winner is chosen entirely by the public votes via text, internet or phone.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: This award was sponsored by Orange UK until 2012.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: From 2013, it was sponsored by EE.

title: BAFTA Rising Star Award
text: The first winner was James McAvoy in 2006.

title: Daniel Talia
text: Daniel Talia (born 2 October 1991) is a professional Australian rules football player who plays for the Adelaide Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Daniel Talia
text: He was drafted with selection 13 in the 2009 National Draft from the Calder Cannons.

title: Daniel Talia
text: In 2012 he won the AFL Rising Star award as the best young player in the league.

title: Daniel Talia
text: Talia is the great-grandson of former Footscray player Arthur Stevens, and the grandson of Harvey Stevens who played in Footscray's 1954 VFL Grand Final victory.

title: Daniel Talia
text: His younger brother, Michael Talia, played for the Western Bulldogs before being traded to the Sydney Swans after the 2015 season.

title: Stephen Coniglio
text: Stephen J. Coniglio (born 15 December 1993) is a professional Australian rules footballer playing for the Greater Western Sydney Giants in the Australian Football League (AFL).

title: Stephen Coniglio
text: He previously played for Swan Districts in the West Australian Football League (WAFL), and represented Western Australia at the 2010 and 2011 National Under 18 Championships, winning the Larke Medal as the best player in the competition in 2011.

title: Stephen Coniglio
text: Drafted with the second pick in the 2011 AFL National Draft, Coniglio made his debut for Greater Western Sydney in the first round of the 2012 season, and was later nominated for the 2012 AFL Rising Star award.

title: Nick Holland
text: Nick Holland (born 29 July 1974) is a former professional Australian rules football player who played 179 games for Australian Football League (AFL) club Hawthorn between 1994 and 2005, serving as Vice Captain between 1999 and 2003.

title: Nick Holland
text: Holland is an AFL Rising Star Award winner, a best and fairest and leading goal kicker at Hawthorn and represented Australia in International Rules.

title: Nick Holland
text: He is now a lawyer and media personality.

title: Rock in Rio USA
text: Rock in Rio USA was a music festival held in Las Vegas, Nevada in 2015.

title: Rock in Rio USA
text: A spin-off of Rio de Janeiro's "Rock in Rio" festival, it was first held on May 8 and 9, 2015 at the Las Vegas Festival Grounds—a purpose-built venue on the Las Vegas Strip developed in cooperation with the festival's organizers.

title: Rock in Rio USA
text: It shared a similar structure and format to its Brazilian counterpart, hosting at least 120 acts for its first and only edition.

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: The Las Vegas metropolitan area is home to many sports, most of which take place in the unincorporated communities around Las Vegas rather than in the city itself.

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: The Las Vegas Valley has one major league professional team: the Vegas Golden Knights of the National Hockey League (NHL) who began play in 2017 as the region's first major pro team.

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: The Oakland Raiders of the National Football League (NFL) will begin play in Las Vegas as the "Las Vegas Raiders" by 2020 and become the region's second major professional team.

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: Las Vegas is also home to one minor league sports team: the Las Vegas 51s of the Triple-A Pacific Coast League (Minor League Baseball).

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: The 51s are currently the only team to actually play in the city of Las Vegas, playing at the city owned Cashman Field.

title: Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area
text: They will be joined in 2018 by the Las Vegas Lights FC of the United Soccer League, one of two leagues that collectively make up the second level of the U.S. men's soccer league system.

title: Las Vegas Uncork'd
text: Las Vegas Uncork'd (also referred to as Vegas Uncork'd and Vegas Uncorked) is an annual culinary and wine event in Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: Las Vegas Uncork'd
text: The concept was developed by the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, their advertising agency R&R Partners and Las Vegas resort partners who originally considered a number of magazine partners such as Bon Appetit, Food & Wine and Gourmet.

title: Las Vegas Uncork'd
text: Bon Appetit was selected as the magazine partner after a review with each magazine.

title: Las Vegas Uncork'd
text: The event was launched in 2007 by the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, "Bon Appétit" magazine led by Editor-in-Chief Barbara Fairchild and co-creator and Executive Director Rob O'Keefe who led the first five years of development of what Eater.com called "the world's most innovative culinary event".

title: Las Vegas Uncork'd
text: Las Vegas resort partners over the years include Bellagio, Caesars Palace and Wynn Las Vegas, MGM Grand, Mandalay Bay, The Venetian, Las Vegas and The Palazzo and each year the event features more than 80 celebrated chefs and over 25 events occurring over a spectacular four-day weekend.

title: Air Vegas
text: Air Vegas (IATA: 6V, ICAO: VGA, Call sign: Air Vegas) was an airline with its headquarters on the grounds of the North Las Vegas Air Terminal in North Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: Air Vegas
text: It operated daily sightseeing flights from Las Vegas to the Grand Canyon.

title: Air Vegas
text: Prior to moving to the North Las Vegas Airport its main bases were McCarran International Airport (LAS), Las Vegas and Henderson Executive Airport (HND), Las Vegas.

title: Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino
text: The Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino is a hotel and casino in Winchester, Nevada.

title: Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino
text: It is owned by Westgate Resorts and operated by Navegante Group.

title: Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino
text: It has 2,956 hotel rooms including 305 suites.

title: Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino
text: It opened in 1969 as the International Hotel, and was known for many years as the Las Vegas Hilton, then briefly as the LVH – Las Vegas Hotel and Casino.

title: Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino
text: It was renamed the Westgate Las Vegas on July 1, 2014.

title: Tropicana – Las Vegas Boulevard intersection
text: The Tropicana – Las Vegas Boulevard intersection on the Las Vegas Strip (Tropicana Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard), is noteworthy for several reasons.

title: Tropicana – Las Vegas Boulevard intersection
text: It was the first intersection in Las Vegas completely closed to street level pedestrian traffic and its four corners are home to four major resorts: Excalibur Hotel and Casino, Tropicana Las Vegas, New York-New York Hotel and Casino and MGM Grand Las Vegas—the latter has 5,044 rooms and was once the largest hotel in the world.

title: Tropicana – Las Vegas Boulevard intersection
text: The resorts at the four corners have a total of 12,536 hotel rooms as of 2016.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: The Boots and Hearts Music Festival is a multi-day country music and camping festival produced by Republic Live Inc. and owned by Stan and Eva Dunford.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: It is held annually at the custom-designed festival grounds, Burl’s Creek Event Grounds in Oro-Medonte, Ontario, Canada.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
