text: Since its inception in 2012, Boots and Hearts has quickly grown to become Canada's largest country music festival and considered the second largest music festival in North America behind only the CMA Music Festival.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: The festival offers multiple stages, meet and greets, VIP offerings, an on-site farmers market, and more to 45,000+ festival-goers over the course of 4 days.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: Boots and Hearts was awarded the CCMA (Canadian Country Music Association) “Festival of the Year” Award in 2014, 2015, and 2016, as well as the Canadian Music Week “Festival of the Year” in 2015, with repeat nominations in 2016 and 2017.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: Boots and Hearts has seen the acts of world-renowned artists such as Carrie Underwood, Luke Bryan, Blake Shelton, Toby Keith, Jason Aldean, Miranda Lambert, Tim McGraw, Rascal Flatts, Brad Paisley, Eric Church, Florida Georgia Line and many other country music stars.

title: Boots and Hearts Music Festival
text: The 2017 edition of Boots and Hearts Music will be taking place from August 10 – 13, 2017.

title: Trump International Hotel Las Vegas
text: The Trump International Hotel Las Vegas is a 64-story luxury hotel, condominium, and timeshare located on Fashion Show Drive near Las Vegas Boulevard, just off the Las Vegas Strip in Paradise, Nevada, named for real estate developer and the 45th and current President of the United States Donald Trump.

title: Trump International Hotel Las Vegas
text: It is located across the street from Wynn Las Vegas, behind Alon Las Vegas on 3.46 acre , near the Fashion Show Mall, and features both non-residential hotel condominiums and residential condominiums.

title: Trump International Hotel Las Vegas
text: The exterior glass is infused with gold.

title: Trump International Hotel Las Vegas
text: The hotel is a member of The Leading Hotels of the World.

title: Downtown Las Vegas
text: Downtown Las Vegas (commonly abbreviated as DTLV) is the central business district and historic center of Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: Downtown Las Vegas
text: It is the original townsite and was the gambling district of Las Vegas prior to the Strip, and the area still incorporates downtown gaming.

title: Downtown Las Vegas
text: As the urban core of the Las Vegas Valley, it features a variety of hotel and business highrises, cultural centers, historical buildings and government institutions, as well as residential and retail developments.

title: Downtown Las Vegas
text: Downtown is located in the center of the Las Vegas Valley and just north of the Las Vegas Strip, centered on Fremont Street, the Fremont Street Experience and Fremont East.

title: Downtown Las Vegas
text: The city defines the area as bounded by I-15 on the west, Washington Avenue on the north, Maryland Parkway on the east and Sahara Avenue on the south.

title: Las Vegas Festival Grounds
text: Las Vegas Festival Grounds (formerly MGM Resorts Festival Grounds) is a 33 acre open-air venue located on the Las Vegas Strip, north of the MGM-owned Circus Circus Hotel and Casino in Winchester, Nevada.

title: A Christmas Carol
text: A Christmas Carol in Prose, Being a Ghost-Story of Christmas, commonly known as A Christmas Carol, is a novella by Charles Dickens, first published in London by Chapman & Hall in 1843; the first edition was illustrated by John Leech.

title: A Christmas Carol
text: "A Christmas Carol" tells the story of Ebenezer Scrooge, an old miser who is visited by the ghost of his former business partner Jacob Marley and the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Yet to Come.

title: A Christmas Carol
text: After their visits Scrooge is transformed into a kinder, gentler man.

title: List of The Muppets productions
text: This is a list of productions based on The Muppets characters and franchise, including films, television series and specials, and other media.

title: List of The Muppets productions
text: The franchise's main work is "The Muppet Show", a syndicated television series which ran from 1976 to 1981.

title: List of The Muppets productions
text: The franchise includes eight feature films; "The Muppet Movie", "The Great Muppet Caper", "The Muppets Take Manhattan", "The Muppet Christmas Carol", "Muppet Treasure Island", "Muppets from Space", "The Muppets", and "Muppets Most Wanted".

title: List of The Muppets productions
text: The franchise also includes other series such as "Muppets Tonight" and "The Muppets".

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
text: The Muppet Christmas Carol is a 1992 American-British musical fantasy comedy-drama film and an adaptation of Charles Dickens's 1843 novel "A Christmas Carol".

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
text: It is the fourth in a series of live-action musical films featuring The Muppets, with Michael Caine starring as Ebenezer Scrooge.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
text: Although it is a comedic film with contemporary songs, "The Muppet Christmas Carol" otherwise follows Dickens's original story closely.

title: The Muppet Christmas Carol
text: The film was produced and directed by Brian Henson for Jim Henson Productions and released by Walt Disney Pictures.

title: Kalanta Xristougenon
text: Kalanta Xristougenon (Κάλαντα Χριστουγέννων) is a Greek traditional Christmas carol (kalanta) translated into English simply as "Christmas Carol."

title: Kalanta Xristougenon
text: This carol is commonly abbreviated as "Kalanta" or "Kalanda", some other common titles for this Christmas carol are Kalin Iméran and Christos Genate.

title: Kalanta Xristougenon
text: This carol is commonly sung around Christmas and accompanied by light percussion instruments such as the Triangle (musical instrument) and Guitar.

title: Gonzo (Muppet)
text: Developed and performed by Dave Goelz, Gonzo made his first appearance in the 1970 special "The Great Santa Claus Switch", as the "Cigar Box Frackle".

title: Gonzo (Muppet)
text: Originally a minor figure in "The Muppet Show", he soon evolved into one of the franchise's primary characters.

title: Gonzo (Muppet)
text: Gonzo has appeared in every Muppet film, including "The Muppet Christmas Carol", where he portrayed author Charles Dickens and developed a double act with Rizzo the Rat.

title: Rizzo the Rat
text: Rizzo the Rat is a Muppet character, created and performed by Steve Whitmire.

title: Rizzo the Rat
text: He is a fictional rat who appeared on "The Muppet Show" and numerous films, with a starring role in the 1992 film "The Muppet Christmas Carol".

title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks
text: Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a 1971 British-American musical fantasy film produced by Walt Disney Productions and released by Buena Vista Distribution Company in North America on December 13, 1971.

title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks
text: It is based upon the books "The Magic Bedknob; or, How to Become a Witch in Ten Easy Lessons" (1943) and "Bonfires and Broomsticks" (1945) by English children's author Mary Norton.

title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks
text: The film, which combines live action and animation, stars Angela Lansbury and David Tomlinson.

title: Sam Eagle
text: Sam Eagle is a Muppet character originating from the television show "The Muppet Show", where he was performed by Frank Oz.

title: Sam Eagle
text: Sam has appeared in every Muppet film; as himself in "The Muppet Movie", "The Great Muppet Caper", "The Muppets Take Manhattan", "Muppets from Space", and "The Muppets", as well as the Head Schoolmaster in "The Muppet Christmas Carol," Samuel Arrow in "Muppet Treasure Island" and a CIA agent in "Muppets Most Wanted."

title: Sam Eagle
text: He also appears in the television series, "The Muppets."

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The Sword in the Stone is a 1963 American animated musical fantasy comedy film produced by Walt Disney and released by Buena Vista Distribution.

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The 18th Disney animated feature film, it was the final Disney animated film to be released before Walt Disney's death.

title: The Sword in the Stone (film)
text: The songs in the film were written and composed by the Sherman Brothers, who later wrote music for other Disney films like "Mary Poppins" (1964), "The Jungle Book" (1967), "The Aristocats" (1970), and "Bedknobs and Broomsticks" (1971).

title: Bill Barretta
text: William Paul "Bill" Barretta (born June 19, 1964) is an American puppeteer and producer who has been performing with The Muppets since 1991, when he puppeteered the body of Sinclair family patriarch, Earl Sinclair on "Dinosaurs".

title: Bill Barretta
text: He later developed several new characters on "Muppets Tonight", including Pepe the King Prawn, Johnny Fiama, Big Mean Carl and Bobo the Bear.

title: Bill Barretta
text: Along with having his own Muppet characters, Barretta has taken over several of Jim Henson's roles, such as Dr. Teeth, Rowlf the Dog, Mahna Mahna and Swedish Chef, and briefly took over Jerry Nelson's role of Lew Zealand.

title: Bill Barretta
text: His film debut as a principal puppeteer was in 1996's "Muppet Treasure Island" as Clueless Morgan.

title: Bill Barretta
text: In addition, Barretta has produced two of the Muppets' television films, "It's a Very Merry Muppet Christmas Movie" (2002) and "The Muppets' Wizard of Oz" (2005).

title: Bill Barretta
text: Barretta also provides additional voices on "Kim Possible".

title: Bill Barretta
text: His most recent film performance was in Disney's "Muppets Most Wanted", where he also served as a co-producer.

title: Bill Barretta
text: Barretta also served as an executive producer on the ABC series, "The Muppets".

title: Pearl River (China)
text: The Pearl River, also known by its Chinese name Zhujiang and formerly often known as the Canton River , is an extensive river system in southern China.

title: Pearl River (China)
text: The name "Pearl River" is also often used as a catch-all for the watersheds of the Xi ("West"), Bei ("North"), and Dong ("East") rivers of Guangdong.

title: Pearl River (China)
text: These rivers are all considered tributaries of the Pearl River because they share a common delta, the Pearl River Delta.

title: Pearl River (China)
text: Measured from the farthest reaches of the Xi River, the Pearl River system is China's third-longest river, 2400 km , after the Yangtze River and the Yellow River, and second largest by volume, after the Yangtze.

title: Pearl River (China)
text: The 409480 km2 Pearl River Basin (珠江流域 ) drains the majority of Liangguang (Guangdong and Guangxi provinces), as well as parts of Yunnan, Guizhou, Hunan and Jiangxi in China; it also drains northern parts of Vietnam's Northeast Cao Bằng and Lạng Sơn provinces.

title: Thái Bình river system
text: The Thái Bình river system is one of the two major river systems in the Red River Delta, Vietnam.

title: Thái Bình river system
text: (the other one is the Red River system).

title: Thái Bình river system
text: The system consists of 8 rivers flowing in northern Vietnam.

title: Thái Bình river system
text: This system joining with Red River system creates the Red River Delta.

title: Cotter River System
text: The Cotter River System (CRS) is located in the Australian Capital Territory and was constructed in 1912.

title: Cotter River System
text: A feature of the Namadgi National Park, the Cotter River System is one of two main sources for the Australian Capital Territory's water supply, the other being the Queanbeyan River located north of the Australian Capital Territory in New South Wales.

title: Cotter River System
text: Nevertheless, the Cotter River System is a larger catchment area and due to recent drought conditions the Queanbeyan River has been seen as obsolete in comparison.

title: Wekiva River
text: The Wekiva River (sometimes spelled Wekiwa, a Creek word meaning "spring of water") is a 16.0 mi river in Central Florida, north of Orlando in the United States.

title: Wekiva River
text: It originates in Apopka and joins the St. Johns River, the longest river in the state, in DeBary.

title: Wekiva River
text: The Wekiva River system includes the main stem joined by three main tributaries - Rock Springs Run, Blackwater Creek, and the Little Wekiva River - and about 30 contributing groundwater springs.

title: Wekiva River
text: It is designated as a Florida State Canoe Trail, an Outstanding Florida Water, and an Aquatic Preserve by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Wekiva River
text: The Wekiva River system is also one of the two rivers in Florida federally designated as a National Wild and Scenic River for its scenery, recreation, geology, and diverse habitats.

title: Brisbane River cod
text: The Brisbane River cod was a unique form of "Maccullochella" cod that occurred naturally in the Brisbane River system, an east coast river system in south east Queensland, Australia.

title: Brisbane River cod
text: Their exact taxonomic status is not known, but based on several genetic studies it is suspected that Brisbane River Cod were a species intermediate between eastern freshwater cod ("Maccullochella ikei") of the Clarence River and Richmond River systems in northern New South Wales and Mary River cod of the Mary River in central Queensland.

title: Eastern freshwater cod
text: Eastern freshwater cod ("Maccullochella ikei"), also known as eastern cod or Clarence River cod, are a large predatory freshwater fish of the "Maccullochella" genus and the family Percichthyidae, that occur in the coastal Clarence River system of north-eastern New South Wales.

title: Eastern freshwater cod
text: Eastern freshwater cod are closely related to the Murray cod of the Murray-Darling River system, and are considered an icon of the Clarence River system.

title: Thái Bình River
text: Thái Bình river (Vietnamese: Sông Thái Bình) is the name of the Thái Bình river system's main river in Northern Vietnam.

title: Thái Bình River
text: This river system joining with Red River system have brought alluvium to create Red River Delta.

title: Blackback barb
text: the blackback barb ("Enteromius barnardi"), is a species of cyprinid fish native to Africa where it is known to occur in shallow, vegetated waters of the Zambezi River system, the Cunene River system and the Zambian portion of the Congo River system.

title: Blackback barb
text: This species can reach a length of 7 cm SL.

title: Zambezi River System Action Plan
text: Zambezi River System Action Plan (ZACPLAN) is a multinational plan under the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) to incorporate effective use, and management of the Zambezi River system.

title: Zambezi River System Action Plan
text: ZACPLAN encompasses eight countries: Angola, Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.

title: Zambezi River System Action Plan
text: The Zambezi river basin is used by all these South African countries; this plan attempts to manage resources collectively amongst, and between SADCC Nations to reasonably meet national, and international goals for water resources.

title: Zambezi River System Action Plan
text: Due to the immense river basin formed by the Zambezi River together with its tributaries, the Zambezi River System Plan is a culmination of a UN commission, to focus on the projection that the demand for the basins water resources would increase.

title: Zambezi River System Action Plan
text: This competition creates negative utilization, and inefficient use of resources for all these countries in a profitable manner.

title: Red River system
text: The Red River system is a network of rivers surrounding the main river - Red River in North Vietnam.

title: Red River system
text: These branches of the system contribute to or receive water from Red River.

title: Red River system
text: Red River system, joining with the Thái Bình river system in the northeast, creates the Red River Delta - the second largest delta in Vietnam.

title: Red River system
text: Because of the close relation between Red River system and Thái Bình river system, the two system are known as the common name "Red and Thai Binh rivers system".

title: Red River system
text: Alluvium of the Red River system creates the central and south Red River Delta.

title: Red River system
text: Two banks of the rivers are protected by a great dyke system.

title: Glasgow North East by-election, 2009
text: The 2009 Glasgow North East by-election was a by-election for the Parliament of the United Kingdom's House of Commons constituency of Glasgow North East.

title: Glasgow North East by-election, 2009
text: The by-election was held on 12 November 2009 following the resignation of Michael Martin as an MP and as Speaker of the House of Commons following the MPs' expenses scandal.

title: Glasgow North East by-election, 2009
text: Martin was the first Speaker since Sir John Trevor in 1695 to be forced from office.

title: Glasgow North East by-election, 2009
text: Willie Bain, the Scottish Labour Party candidate, won with 59% of the vote.

title: Glasgow North East by-election, 2009
text: Just 33% of the electorate voted, which is the lowest ever percentage turnout in a Scottish by-election to the House of Commons.

title: Jean-Marie Boisvert
text: Jean-Marie Boisvert (born September 20, 1939) is a former Canadian politician and teacher.

title: Jean-Marie Boisvert
text: He was elected to the Canadian House of Commons in the 1972 election as a Member of the Social Credit Party to represent the riding of Drummond.

title: Jean-Marie Boisvert
text: During his political career, he sat on various parliamentary committees including the Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Legal Affairs, Canadian House of Commons Special Committee on Trends in Food Prices, Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Justice and Legal Affairs and the Standing Joint Committee on the Library of Parliament.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: Baron Dunalley, of Kilboy in the County of Tipperary, is a title in the Peerage of Ireland.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: It was created in 1800 for Henry Prittie, who had previously represented Banagher, Gowran and County Tipperary in the Irish House of Commons.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: His son, the second Baron, represented Carlow in the Irish Parliament and Okehampton in the British House of Commons and also sat in the House of Lords as an Irish Representative Peer from 1828 to 1854.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: He was succeeded by his nephew, the third Baron.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: When he died the barony was inherited by his son, the fourth Baron.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: He was an Irish Representative Peer between 1891 and 1927 and served as Lord Lieutenant of County Tipperary.

title: Baron Dunalley
text: s of 2014 the title is held by his great-grandson, the seventh Baron, who succeeded his father in 1992.

title: Prosper Boulanger
text: Prosper Boulanger (November 17, 1918 December 5, 2002) was a Canadian politician and businessman.

title: Prosper Boulanger
text: He was elected to the Canadian House of Commons in 1962 as a Member of the Liberal Party to represent the riding of Mercier.

title: Prosper Boulanger
text: He was re-elected in 1963, 1965, 1968, 1972 and 1974.

title: Prosper Boulanger
text: During his political career, he was Chair of the Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Veterans Affairs and also a member of the Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Fisheries and Forestry and the Canadian House of Commons Standing Committee on Procedure and Organization and served as Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole.

title: Prosper Boulanger
text: Boulanger was also a councillor on the Montreal City Council and also served in the Royal Canadian Air Force between 1939 and 1946.

title: Canadian federal election, 1926
text: The Canadian federal election of 1926 was held on September 14 to elect members of the Canadian House of Commons of the 16th Parliament of Canada.

title: Canadian federal election, 1926
text: The election was called following an event known as the King-Byng Affair.

title: Canadian federal election, 1926
text: In the 1925 federal election, Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King's Liberal Party of Canada won fewer seats in the Canadian House of Commons than the Liberal-Conservatives of Arthur Meighen.

title: Canadian federal election, 1926
text: Mackenzie King, however, was determined to continue to govern with the support of the Progressive Party.

title: Canadian federal election, 1926
text: The combined Liberal and Progressive caucuses gave Mackenzie King a plurality of seats in the House of Commons, and the ability to form a minority government.

title: Congleton (UK Parliament constituency)
text: Congleton is a constituency in Cheshire, represented in the House of Commons of the UK Parliament since 2010 by Fiona Bruce of the Conservative Party.

title: Earl Belmore
text: Earl Belmore, in County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland, is a title in the Peerage of Ireland created in 1797 for Armar Lowry-Corry, 1st Viscount Belmore, who had previously represented County Tyrone in the Irish House of Commons.

title: Earl Belmore
text: He had already been created Baron Belmore, of Castle Coole in County Fermanagh, in 1781 and Viscount Belmore in 1789, also in the Peerage of Ireland.

title: Earl Belmore
text: Born Armar Lowry, he was the son of Galbraith Lowry, Member of the Irish House of Commons for County Tyrone, and his wife Sarah, daughter of Colonel John Corry.

title: Earl Belmore
text: In 1774 he assumed by Royal licence the additional surname of Corry.

title: Earl Belmore
text: He was succeeded by his eldest son, the second Earl.

title: Earl Belmore
text: He represented County Tyrone in both the Irish and British House of Commons, sat in the House of Lords as an Irish Representative Peer from 1819 to 1841 and served as Governor of Jamaica from 1828 to 1832.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: Earl of Lanesborough was a title in the Peerage of Ireland.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: It was created in 1756 for Humphrey Butler, 2nd Viscount Lanesborough.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: The Butler family descended from Theophilus Butler, who represented County Cavan and Belturbet in the Irish House of Commons.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: In 1715 he was raised to the Peerage of Ireland as Baron Newtown-Butler, of the County of Fermanagh, with remainder to the heirs male of his father.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He was succeeded according to the special remainder by his brother, Brinsley, the second Baron.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He had previously represented Kells and Belturbet in the Irish Parliament.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: In 1728 he was created Viscount Lanesborough in the Peerage of Ireland.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He was succeeded by his son, Humphrey, the aforementioned second Viscount, who was elevated to an earldom in 1728.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: The first Earl was succeeded by his son, Brinsley, the second Earl.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He represented County Cavan in the Irish House of Commons.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: His grandson, the fifth Earl, sat in the British House of Lords as an Irish Representative Peer from 1849 to 1866.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: The latter was succeeded by his nephew, the sixth Earl.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He served as Lord-Lieutenant of Cavan from 1876 to 1900 and was an Irish Representative Peer from 1870 to 1905.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He was succeeded by his son, the seventh Earl.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: He was an Irish Representative Peer from 1913 to 1929.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: On his death the titles passed to his younger brother, the eighth Earl.

title: Earl of Lanesborough
text: The titles became extinct on the death of the latter's eldest son, the ninth Earl, in 1998.

title: Baron Crofton
text: Baron Crofton is a title in the Peerage of Ireland.

title: Baron Crofton
text: It was created in 1797 (as Baroness Crofton) for Dame Anne Crofton.

title: Baron Crofton
text: She was the widow of Sir Edward Crofton, 2nd Baronet, of the Mote, who had represented Roscommon in the Irish House of Commons and had been offered a peerage just before his death.

title: Baron Crofton
text: The peerage was instead bestowed upon his widow.

title: Baron Crofton
text: She was succeeded by her grandson, the second Baron, who had already succeeded as fourth Baronet.

title: Baron Crofton
text: He sat in the House of Lords as an Irish Representative Peer from 1840 to 1869 and served as a Lord-in-Waiting (government whip in the House of Lords) in the three Conservative administrations of the Earl of Derby and in Benjamin Disraeli's first government.

title: Baron Crofton
text: His son, the third Baron, served as an Irish Representative Peer between 1873 and 1912 and was also State Steward to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

title: Baron Crofton
text: His nephew, the fourth Baron, was an Irish Representative Peer from 1916 to 1942.

title: Baron Crofton
text: s of 2014 the titles are held by the latter's great-great-grandson, the eighth Baron, who succeeded his father in 2007.

title: Dean of the House (Canada)
text: In Canada, the Dean of the House is the Member of the House of Commons with the longest unbroken record of service who is not a Cabinet Minister, party Leader, House Leader or Whip.

title: Dean of the House (Canada)
text: The Dean is responsible for presiding over the election of the Speaker of the House of Commons at the beginning of each Parliament.

title: Dean of the House (Canada)
text: The position is the equivalent of the Father of the House in the British House of Commons.

title: Lawnmower Dog
text: "Lawnmower Dog" is the second episode of "Rick and Morty".

title: Lawnmower Dog
text: It premiered on Adult Swim on December 9, 2013, was written by Ryan Ridley, and directed by John Rice.

title: Lawnmower Dog
text: In the episode, Rick gives Jerry a device to enhance the dog's intelligence, whilst Rick and Morty get lost in the dreams of Morty's math teacher.

title: Lawnmower Dog
text: The episode was well received, with approximately 1.5 million viewers when airing.

title: The Ricks Must Be Crazy
text: "The Ricks Must Be Crazy" is the sixth episode in the second season of the American animated television sitcom "Rick and Morty", and the seventeenth overall episode in the series.

title: The Ricks Must Be Crazy
text: Written by Dan Guterman and directed by Dominic Polcino, the episode first aired on Adult Swim in the United States on August 30, 2015.

title: The Ricks Must Be Crazy
text: It is speculated that the title of the episode is a reference to the 1980 film "The Gods Must Be Crazy".

title: The Wedding Squanchers
text: "The Wedding Squanchers" is the tenth and final episode of the second season of the American animated television sitcom "Rick and Morty", and the 21st overall episode of the series.

title: The Wedding Squanchers
text: Written by Tom Kauffman and directed by Wes Archer, the episode first aired on Adult Swim in the United States on October 4, 2015.

title: Meeseeks and Destroy
text: "Meeseeks and Destroy" is the fifth episode of the first season of "Rick and Morty".

title: Meeseeks and Destroy
text: It premiered on Adult Swim on January 20, 2014.

title: Meeseeks and Destroy
text: The episode was written by Ryan Ridley and directed by Bryan Newton.

title: Meeseeks and Destroy
text: In the episode, Rick provides the family with a solution to their problems, freeing him up to go on an adventure led by Morty.

title: Meeseeks and Destroy
text: The episode has been well received, and was seen by about 1.6 million viewers when it was first aired on the Adult Swim channel.

title: Pilot (Rick and Morty)
text: "Pilot" is the first episode of "Rick and Morty".

title: Pilot (Rick and Morty)
text: It premiered on Adult Swim on December 2, 2013.

title: Pilot (Rick and Morty)
text: It is written by series creators Dan Harmon and Justin Roiland, and directed by Roiland.

title: Pilot (Rick and Morty)
text: The series introduces protagonists, alcoholic scientist Rick Sanchez and his innocent teenage grandson Morty Smith, as they embark on a dangerous interdimensional adventure to fetch Mega tree seeds.

title: Pilot (Rick and Morty)
text: The pilot had a mixed to positive reception and was seen by about 1.1 million viewers when airing.

title: Rixty Minutes
text: "Rixty Minutes" is the eighth episode of the first season of "Rick and Morty".

title: Rixty Minutes
text: It premiered on Adult Swim on March 17, 2014.

title: Rixty Minutes
text: The episode was written by Tom Kauffman and Justin Roiland, and directed by Bryan Newton.

title: Rixty Minutes
text: In the episode, Rick and Morty watch cable from other dimensions, while Jerry, Beth, and Summer watch alternate reality versions of themselves using a pair of interdimensional goggles.

title: Rixty Minutes
text: The episode was well received and watched by about 1.48 million viewers in the United States.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: Gangland Undercover is an American factual based drama television series written and created by Executive Producer Stephen Kemp and co-writer Noel Baker.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: It was inspired by the story of Charles Falco a former ATF confidential informant (CI) who infiltrated an outlaw motorcycle club.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: The series is based on Falco's 2013 memoir, "Vagos, Mongols, and Outlaws: My Infiltration of America's Deadliest Biker Gangs".

title: Gangland Undercover
text: It premiered on Tuesday, February 24, 2015, on the History Channel at 10/9c.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: In Canada, Season 2 premiered on September 26, 2016.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: In the U.S., only the first episode of season 2 aired on December 8, 2016 on A&E.

title: Gangland Undercover
text: According to the trailer, "the new season" (Season 2) premiered on March 2, 2017.

title: Rick Potion No. 9
text: "Rick Potion #9" is the sixth episode of "Rick and Morty".

title: Rick Potion No. 9
text: It premiered on Adult Swim on January 27, 2014, was written by Justin Roiland, and directed by Stephen Sandoval.

title: Rick Potion No. 9
text: In the episode, a love potion goes wrong, creating a virus that begins to infect the entire world population, making everyone fall in love with Morty.

title: Rick Potion No. 9
text: The episode has been well received, and was seen by about 1.7 million viewers when airing.

title: Rick Potion No. 9
text: The title of the episode is in reference to the 1959 song "Love Potion No. 9" by the Clovers.

title: Wrath of the Villains: Pinewood
text: "Wrath of the Villains: Pinewood" is the eighteenth episode of the second season, and 40th episode overall from the Fox series "Gotham".

title: Wrath of the Villains: Pinewood
text: The episode was written by co-executive producer Robert Hull and Megan Mostyn-Brown and directed by executive producer John Stephens in his first "Gotham" episode directed.

title: Wrath of the Villains: Pinewood
text: It was first broadcast on April 18, 2016.

title: Wrath of the Villains: Pinewood
text: In the episode, Bruce and Alfred set to find out information about a program called Pinewood Farms which had something to do with Thomas Wayne's death and involvement while Gordon sets out to find The Lady and Dr. Strange continues his experiments.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: Angry Birds Stella is a Finnish computer-animated TV series based on the game "Angry Birds Stella" that was produced by Rovio Entertainment.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: The first episode, "A Fork in the Friendship", aired on ToonsTV in November 1, 2014.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: The series recounts the tale of Stella, along with her friends Luca, Willow, Poppy and Dahlia, as they work their way against Gale, the former friend of Stella, that is the queen of the pigs in Golden Island.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: The first season focuses on Gale trying to hunt for the Golden Egg, but, fails as seen in the final episode of season 1, "To The Bitter End".

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: The second season focuses on Gale returning and trying to hunt for the Golden Egg again, and she succeeded as seen in "The Golden Queen", the 9th episode of season 2.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: Also, Dahlia, one of the birds, tries searching for the egg as well for an experiment, but this time, she fails, as seen in "It's Mine!"

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: , the 6th episode of season 2.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: Soon enough, the birds realize how dangerous this egg can be, as seen in "Premonition", the 11th episode in season 2, which in when Gale with the Golden Egg, anything that is touched with it, turns to gold.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: However, when that happens, another thing turns to stone, the opposite of gold, which causes nature, and even worse, food to be turned to stone as well.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: Now, it is up to the Stella gang to save Golden Island before it is too late.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: They do succeed, as seen in "You Asked For It", the 13th and final episode of season 2 and the series finale of "Angry Birds Stella", where after a long awful night, Stella and her gang launch the Golden Egg out of the island, never to be seen again.

title: Angry Birds Stella (TV series)
text: Gale does not mind because when she saw the Golden Egg after she broke out of the gold in the episode, she ran away, back into her castle.

title: 2006 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2006 Brownlow Medal was the 79th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2006 Brownlow Medal
text: Adam Goodes of the Sydney Swans won the medal by polling twenty-six votes during the 2006 AFL season.

title: 2006 Brownlow Medal
text: It was Goodes' second Brownlow Medal win, after his victory in 2003.

title: 2005 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2005 Brownlow Medal was the 78th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2005 Brownlow Medal
text: Ben Cousins of the West Coast Eagles won the medal by polling twenty votes during the 2005 AFL season.

title: 2005 Brownlow Medal
text: It was Cousins' first Brownlow Medal win, and with Daniel Kerr finishing the runner up, it was the first time in 86 years that the top two votesgetters were from the same club.

title: 2007 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2007 Brownlow Medal was the 80th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2007 Brownlow Medal
text: Jimmy Bartel of the Geelong Football Club won the medal by polling twenty-nine votes during the 2007 AFL season.

title: 2011 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2011 Brownlow Medal was the 84th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2011 Brownlow Medal
text: Dane Swan of the Collingwood Football Club won the medal by polling thirty-four votes during the 2011 AFL season a then-record number of votes in a Brownlow Medal counted under the 3-2-1 voting system, it was surpassed by Patrick Dangerfield in 2016, where he polled thirty-five votes.

title: 2011 Brownlow Medal
text: It was then again surpassed by Dustin Martin in 2017 where he polled thirty-six votes

title: 2015 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2015 Brownlow Medal was the 88th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2015 Brownlow Medal
text: Nat Fyfe of the Fremantle Football Club won the medal by polling thirty-one votes during the 2015 AFL season.

title: 2015 Brownlow Medal
text: He became the first Fremantle player to win the Brownlow Medal.

title: 1976 Brownlow Medal
text: The 1976 Brownlow Medal was the 49th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Victorian Football League (VFL) home and away season.

title: 1976 Brownlow Medal
text: Graham Moss of the Essendon Football Club won the medal by polling forty-eight votes during the 1976 VFL season.

title: 1976 Brownlow Medal
text: The count was the first of two occasions in which the two field umpires independently voted for the best players on the ground under the 3-2-1 system.

title: 1976 Brownlow Medal
text: This meant that the winner of the Brownlow had a higher number of votes than usual.

title: 1976 Brownlow Medal
text: From 1978 onwards, the field umpires conferred after each game and awarded a single set of votes, rather than voting independently.

title: 1995 Brownlow Medal
text: The 1995 Brownlow Medal was the 68th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 1995 Brownlow Medal
text: Paul Kelly of the Sydney Swans won the medal by polling twenty-one votes during the 1995 AFL season.

title: 1995 Brownlow Medal
text: For the first time, the State Government legalised betting on the Brownlow Medal, a move which concerned some due to the high potential for corruption.

title: 1995 Brownlow Medal
text: The pre-count favourites for the medal were Wayne Carey (3/1), Wayne Campbell (7/2), Peter Matera (10/1), James Hird and Craig Bradley (each 12/1).

title: 1995 Brownlow Medal
text: Eventual winner Paul Kelly was considered a 25/1 outside chance.

title: 1993 Brownlow Medal
text: The 1993 Brownlow Medal was the 66th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 1993 Brownlow Medal
text: Gavin Wanganeen of the Essendon Football Club won the medal by polling eighteen votes during the 1993 AFL season.

title: 1993 Brownlow Medal
text: Wanganeen was the first Aboriginal player to win the Brownlow Medal in the history of the award and at age 20, he was the youngest winner since Denis Ryan in 1936.

title: 1993 Brownlow Medal
text: The South Australian also added a Premiership Medallion to his collection after Essendon defeated Carlton in the 1993 premiership decider.

title: 1993 Brownlow Medal
text: Both medals were already in addition to the 1993 Michael Tuck Medal Wanganeen was awarded for being 'best on ground' in the Night / Pre-Season Grand Final.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: The 2014 Brownlow Medal was the 87th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Australian Football League (AFL) home and away season.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: Matt Priddis of the West Coast Eagles won the medal by polling twenty-six votes during the 2014 AFL season.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: Defending Brownlow Medallist Gary Ablett of the Gold Coast Football Club was the short-priced favourite for the medal until he suffered a season-ending shoulder injury in round 16.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: Betting on the medal was suspended while the extent of the injury to Ablett was determined.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: Geelong captain Joel Selwood, Collingwood captain Scott Pendlebury and Sydney 's Josh Kennedy were considered to be among the new favourites in the wake of Ablett's injury, but at the end of the season Ablett was still second favourite to have polled enough votes before his injury to win the award.

title: 2014 Brownlow Medal
text: He ended up polling the equal-third most number of votes, tying with Sydney 's Lance Franklin on 22 votes.

title: 1977 Brownlow Medal
text: The 1977 Brownlow Medal was the 50th year the award was presented to the player adjudged the fairest and best player during the Victorian Football League (VFL) home and away season.

title: 1977 Brownlow Medal
text: Graham Teasdale of the South Melbourne Football Club won the medal by polling fifty-nine votes during the 1977 VFL season.

title: 1977 Brownlow Medal
text: The count was the second of two occasions in which the two field umpires independently voted for the best players on the ground under the 3-2-1 system.

title: 1977 Brownlow Medal
text: This meant that the winner of the Brownlow had a higher number of votes than usual, and Teasdale's fifty-nine votes set and holds the record for the most votes ever polled in a single season.

title: 1977 Brownlow Medal
text: From 1978 onwards, the field umpires conferred after each game and awarded a single set of votes, rather than voting independently.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: Wellingsbüttel Manor (German: Rittergut Wellingsbüttel, since Danish times: Kanzleigut Wellingsbüttel) is a former manor with a baroque manor house (German: "Herrenhaus") in Hamburg, Germany, which once enjoyed imperial immediacy ("Reichsfreiheit").

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: Wellingsbüttel was documented for the first time on 10 October 1296.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: Since 1937 it has formed part of the suburbs of Hamburg as the heart of the quarter of the same name, Wellingsbüttel, in the borough of Wandsbek.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: The owners of Wellingsbüttel Manor from the beginning of the 15th until the early 19th century were consecutively the Archbishops of Bremen, Heinrich Rantzau, Dietrich von Reinking, the Barons von Kurtzrock, Frederick VI of Denmark, Hercules Roß, the Jauch family, Cäcilie Behrens and Otto Jonathan Hübbe.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: In the early 19th century it was the residence and place of death of Friedrich Karl Ludwig, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck, the penultimate duke, who was an ancestor inter alia of the present-day British royal family.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: Wellingsbüttel Manor was elevated to the status of a Danish "chancellery manor" ("Kanzleigut").

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: It was then acquired by Grand Burgher of the Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg Johann Christian Jauch junior (1802–1880), becoming a country estate of the Jauch family.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: The manor house is together with Jenisch House ("Jenisch-Haus") one of Hamburg's best conserved examples of the Hanseatic lifestyle in the 19th century and jointly with the manor gatehouse a listed historical monument.

title: Wellingsbüttel Manor
text: The estate is located on the banks of the Alster River in the middle of the Alster valley ("Alstertal") nature reserve.

title: Battle of Berestechko
text: The Battle of Berestechko (Polish: "Bitwa pod Beresteczkiem" ; Ukrainian: Берестецька битва, Битва під Берестечком ) was fought between the Ukrainian Cossacks, led by Hetman Bohdan Khmelnytsky, aided by their Crimean Tatar allies, and a Polish army under King John II Casimir.

title: Battle of Berestechko
text: It was a battle of a Cossack rebellion in Ukraine that took place in the years 1648–1657 after the expiration of a two-year truce.

title: Battle of Berestechko
text: Fought from 28 to 30 June 1651, the battle took place in the province of Volhynia, on the hilly plain south of the Styr River.

title: Battle of Berestechko
text: The Polish camp was on the river opposite Berestechko and faced south, towards the Cossack army about two kilometers away, whose right flank was against the River Pliashivka (Pliashova) and the Tatar army on their left flank.

title: Battle of Berestechko
text: It was probably the largest European land battle of the 17th century.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: The Umba River is located in northeastern Tanzania in Tanga Region.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: It rises in Schageiuforest (Shagayu) in the West Usambara Mountains at 2,000 m altitude and flows on the north side of the mountain range to the east.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: At Lelwa it empties the Mbalamu River, which comes from the extreme north of the Usambara Mountains, and the Mglumi River into the Umba.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: Just before the Umba flows into the Indian Ocean, it crosses the border to Kenya.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: The mouth itself marks the most eastern point on the border between Tanzania and Kenya, which was largely made in a straight line to the northwest towards Lake Victoria in the 19th Century.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: On the upper reaches of the river in the mid-1960s rich deposits of precious stones, including sapphires and Spessartine, were discovered.

title: Umba River (Tanzania)
text: Also on the river is the Umba River Game Reserve, a wildlife reserve that includes along with the Mkomazi Game Reserve, about 2,600 km2.

title: Joseph L. Follett
text: Joseph Leonard Follett (February 16, 1843 – April 1, 1907) was an American soldier who fought in the American Civil War.

title: Joseph L. Follett
text: Follett received the country's highest award for bravery during combat, the Medal of Honor, for his action during the Battle of Island Number Ten in New Madrid, Missouri on 3 March 1862 and the Battle of Stones River in Tennessee on 31 December 1862.

title: Joseph L. Follett
text: He was honored with the award on 19 September 1890.

title: Battle of Glendale (Skye)
text: The Battle of Glendale was a battle fought on the Inner Hebridean island of Skye, between the MacDonalds of Sleat and the MacDonalds of Clanranald, against the MacLeods of Harris and Dunvegan and the MacLeods of Lewis.

title: Battle of Glendale (Skye)
text: According to MacLeod tradition preserved in the early 19th century, the battle was fought in about the year 1490; yet it has been recently suggested that the battle more likely took place sometime after 1513.

title: Battle of Glendale (Skye)
text: MacLeod tradition records that the battle was the 'most tremendous battle' that the clan ever fought—although the clan was victorious, it never fully recovered from its severe losses.

title: Battle of Glendale (Skye)
text: MacLeod tradition relates how the MacDonalds originally had the upper hand during the conflict, but when the MacLeod's sacred Fairy Flag was unfurled the MacLeods gained heart and won the battle.

title: Military history of Mexico
text: The military history of Mexico consists of several millennia of armed conflicts within what is now that nation's territory and includes activities of the Mexican military in peacekeeping and combat related affairs worldwide.

title: Military history of Mexico
text: Wars between prehispanic peoples marked the beginning of Mexico's military history, the most notable of these fought in the form of a "flower war".

title: Military history of Mexico
text: After the Spanish conquest of Mexico in the 16th century, indigenous tribes were defeated by Spain, thus beginning a three century era of Spanish dominance.

title: Military history of Mexico
text: Mexico's struggle for independence began primarily in the 19th century, and was marked by internal conflict of early rulers after defeating the Spanish in 1821.

title: Military history of Mexico
text: The Mexican–American War in the mid 19th century ended in the defeat of Mexican forces, and the loss of two-fifths of the national territory.

title: Military history of Mexico
text: In the remainder of the 19th century, a series of conflicts began in Mexico, as the War of the Reform and the defeat of the French during their intervention in Mexico marked events in that era.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Savage's Station was the wartime name of a supply depot, ammunition dump, field hospital, and command headquarters of the Army of the Potomac during the Peninsula Campaign of the American Civil War.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Savage's Station was located in Henrico County, Virginia on what was the Richmond and York River Railroad, however the historical department of the Norfolk Southern Railroad, the railroad track's current owner, has no record that an actual train station or station house ever existed on the property.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: A farmhouse is known to have been located in a copse of trees on a small knoll next to the railroad track and is visible in several period drawings and photographs made during the war.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house served as the nucleus of a large field hospital during and after the battle of Seven Pines and the Seven Days Battles.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house also functioned as General George B. McClellan's headquarters during the battle of Savage's Station on June 29, 1862.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Although the house survived the battle in 1862, it was burned by Federal cavalry under General Philip H. Sheridan in 1864.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house appears to have never been rebuilt, and no trace of it remains today.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: However, a smokehouse from the 19th century still existed on the property as late as the 1930s when it was photographed during a survey of local historical structures as a project of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The smokehouse fell into ruin and collapsed sometime prior to the 1980s.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: A small brick-walled cemetery from the 18th century still sits near the former location of the house not far from the railroad track.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: The Collins Ferry Historic District encompasses two historic farmsteads, as well as a mill and ferry site on the Staunton River in rural northern Halifax County, Virginia, west of Brookneal.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: The district covers 768 acre , extending south from the river roughly to Bull Creek Road, and westward from the mouth of Buffalo Creek, which roughly bisects the district.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: The Collins Farm, which is located at the end of McKeever's Trail, includes one of Halifax County's best-preserved Federal style plantation houses, built c. 1810 and located on a bluff overlooking the creek.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: The Collins Farm includes 19th century farm outbuildings, the family cemetery, a mill site along the river, and the site where stones for the mill's construction and grinding stones were quarried.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: The Hubbard Farm is located south and east of the Collins Farm, and is accessed via a private drive that forms part of the historic road leading to Collins Ferry.

title: Collins Ferry Historic District
text: Hubbard Farm includes a Greek Revival farmhouse built in 1856, and also includes 19th century outbuildings, a family cemetery, and the remains of a slave quarters.

title: Register Cliff
text: Register Cliff is a sandstone cliff and featured key navigational landmark prominently listed in the 19th century guidebooks about the Oregon Trail, and a place where many emigrants chiseled the names of their families on the soft stones of the cliff it was one of the key checkpoint landmarks for parties heading west along the Platte River valley west of Fort John, Wyoming which allowed travelers to verify they were on the correct path up to South Pass and not moving into impassable mountain terrainsgeographically, it is on the eastern ascent of the Continental divide leading upward out of the great plains in the east of the U.S. state of Wyoming.

title: Register Cliff
text: It is notable as a historic landmark for 'registering' hundreds of emigrants on the Oregon Trail (thus also the other northern Emigrant Trails that split off farther west such as the California Trail and Mormon Trail) who came to follow custom and inscribed their names on its rocks during the western migrations of the 19th century.

title: Register Cliff
text: An estimated 500,000 emigrants used these trails from 1843–1869, with up to one-tenth dying along the way, usually due to disease.

title: Pima Villages
text: Pima Villages, sometimes mistakenly called the Pimos Villages in the 19th century, were the Akimel O’odham (Pima) and Pee-Posh (Maricopa) villages in what is now the Gila River Indian Community in Pinal County, Arizona.

title: Pima Villages
text: First, recorded by Spanish explorers in the late 17th century as living on the south side of the Gila River, they were included in the Viceroyalty of New Spain, then in Provincias of Sonora, Ostimuri y Sinaloa or New Navarre to 1823.

title: Pima Villages
text: Then from 1824 to 1830, they were part of the Estado de Occidente of Mexico and from September 1830 they were part of the state of Sonora.

title: Pima Villages
text: These were the Pima villages encountered by American fur trappers, traders, soldiers and travelers along the middle Gila River from 1830's into the later 19th century.

title: Pima Villages
text: The Mexican Cession following the Mexican American War left them part of Mexico.

title: Pima Villages
text: The 1853 Gadsden Purchase made their lands part of the United States, Territory of New Mexico.

title: Pima Villages
text: During the American Civil War they became part of the Territory of Arizona.

title: Youngblood Hawke (film)
text: Youngblood Hawke is a 1964 drama film directed by Delmer Daves, starring James Franciscus and Suzanne Pleshette.

title: Youngblood Hawke (film)
text: Herman Wouk's novel was loosely based on the life of Thomas Wolfe.

title: Youngblood Hawke (film)
text: This was Mary Astor's next-to-last picture.

title: The Petrified Forest
text: The Petrified Forest is a 1936 American film, directed by Archie Mayo starring Leslie Howard, Bette Davis, and Humphrey Bogart.

title: The Petrified Forest
text: A precursor of "film noir", it was adapted from Robert E. Sherwood's stage play of the same name.

title: The Petrified Forest
text: The screenplay was written by Delmer Daves and Charles Kenyon, and adaptations were later performed on radio and television as well.

title: Destination Tokyo
text: Destination Tokyo is a 1943 black-and-white submarine war film.

title: Destination Tokyo
text: It was directed by Delmer Daves in his directorial debut, and the screenplay was written by Daves and Albert Maltz, based on an original story by former submariner Steve Fisher.

title: Destination Tokyo
text: The film stars Cary Grant and John Garfield and features Dane Clark, Robert Hutton, and Warner Anderson, along with John Ridgely, Alan Hale Sr., and William Prince.

title: Destination Tokyo
text: Production began on June 21, 1943 and continued through September 4 of that year.

title: Destination Tokyo
text: The film premiered in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on December 15, 1943 as a benefit for crippled children, and was released generally in the U.S. on December 31, 1943.

title: Drum Beat
text: Drum Beat is a 1954 CinemaScope western film in "WarnerColor" written and directed by Delmer Daves and co-produced by Daves and Alan Ladd in his first film for his Jaguar Productions company.

title: Drum Beat
text: Ladd stars along with Audrey Dalton, Charles Bronson as Captain Jack, and Hayden Rorke as President Ulysses S. Grant.

title: No More Women
text: No More Women is a 1934 American Pre-Code adventure film directed by Albert S. Rogell and written by John Mikale Strong, Lou Breslow, Grant Leenhouts and Delmer Daves.

title: No More Women
text: The film stars Edmund Lowe, Victor McLaglen, Sally Blane, Minna Gombell, Alphonse Ethier, J. P. McGowan and Harold Huber.

title: No More Women
text: The film was released on February 23, 1934, by Paramount Pictures.

title: Shipmates Forever
text: Shipmates Forever is a 1935 American musical film directed by Frank Borzage and written by Delmer Daves.

title: Shipmates Forever
text: Set at the United States Naval Academy, the film stars Dick Powell, Ruby Keeler, Lewis Stone, Ross Alexander, John Arledge, Eddie Acuff and Dick Foran.

title: Shipmates Forever
text: The film was released by Warner Bros. on October 12, 1935.

title: Broken Arrow (1950 film)
text: Broken Arrow is a western Technicolor film released in 1950.

title: Broken Arrow (1950 film)
text: It was directed by Delmer Daves and starred James Stewart as Tom Jeffords and Jeff Chandler as Cochise.

title: Broken Arrow (1950 film)
text: The film is based on these historical figures but fictionalizes their story in dramatized form.

title: Broken Arrow (1950 film)
text: It was nominated for three Academy Awards, and won a Golden Globe award for "Best Film Promoting International Understanding."

title: Broken Arrow (1950 film)
text: Film historians have said that the movie was one of the first major Westerns since the Second World War to portray the Indians sympathetically.

title: Parrish (film)
text: Parrish is a 1961 American drama film made by Warner Bros..

title: Parrish (film)
text: It was written, produced and directed by Delmer Daves, based on the 1958 novel of the same name by Mildred Savage.

title: Parrish (film)
text: The music score was by Max Steiner, the Technicolor cinematography by Harry Stradling Sr., the art direction by Leo K. Kuter and the costume design by Howard Shoup.

title: Dark Passage (film)
text: Dark Passage (1947) is a Warner Bros. film noir directed by Delmer Daves and starring Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall.

title: Dark Passage (film)
text: The film is based on the novel of the same name by David Goodis.

title: Dark Passage (film)
text: It was the third of four films real-life couple Bacall and Bogart made together.

title: The Hanging Tree
text: The Hanging Tree is a 1959 Technicolor Western film directed by Delmer Daves.

title: The Hanging Tree
text: Karl Malden took over directing duties for several days when Daves fell ill.

title: The Hanging Tree
text: The film stars Gary Cooper, Maria Schell, George C. Scott and Malden and is set in the gold fields of Montana during the gold rush of the 1860s and '70s.

title: The Hanging Tree
text: The story follows a doctor who saves a criminal from a lynch mob, then learns of the man's past and tries to manipulate him.

title: Circle. Square. Triangle
text: "Circle.

title: Circle. Square. Triangle
text: Square.

title: Circle. Square. Triangle
text: Triangle" is a song by Test Icicles which was released as the second single from their debut album "For Screening Purposes Only" on 24 October 2005.

title: Circle. Square. Triangle
text: The song is their most successful having peaked at #25 in the UK Singles Chart.

title: Jungle (X Ambassadors and Jamie N Commons song)
text: "Jungle" is a song by American rock band X Ambassadors and British blues rock singer Jamie N Commons.

title: Jungle (X Ambassadors and Jamie N Commons song)
text: It was released as a single on 18 December 2013 by KIDinaKORNER and Interscope.

title: Jungle (X Ambassadors and Jamie N Commons song)
text: The track appeared on X Ambassadors' 2014 EP "The Reason" and their 2015 studio album "VHS".

title: Boa vs. Python (song)
text: "Boa vs. Python" is a song by Test Icicles which was released as the first single from their debut album "For Screening Purposes Only".

title: Boa vs. Python (song)
text: It was released on the 1 August 2005.

title: Boa vs. Python (song)
text: The song peaked at #46 in the UK Singles Chart.

title: Rory Attwell
text: Rory Attwell is an English musician, best known for his part in UK punk trio Test Icicles, who formed in 2004 and played a handful of concerts before disbanding on 22 April 2006, after their sold out final show at the Astoria in London.

title: Rory Attwell
text: During their time together they released the album "For Screening Purposes Only", and had UK Top 40 singles with "What's Your Damage" and "Circle.

title: Rory Attwell
text: Square.

title: Rory Attwell
text: Triangle".

title: Test Icicles
text: Test Icicles were a short-lived dance-punk band that formed in England, primarily influenced by indie rock but containing musical elements from a variety of genres (notably hip hop, crossover thrash and punk).

title: Test Icicles
text: The band was formed in 2004 by Rory Attwell and Sam Mehran, who were later joined by Devonte Hynes.

title: Test Icicles
text: Hynes and Mehran were both 18 years old at the time of the band's inception.

title: Test Icicles
text: The group has since become notable due to the later success of its members.

title: For Screening Purposes Only
text: For Screening Purposes Only is the debut album by UK dance-punk trio Test Icicles.

title: For Screening Purposes Only
text: After being released in 2005, the album was critically praised for being unique and compelling in an increasingly homogenous indie music scene.

title: For Screening Purposes Only
text: Following the group's split in February 2006, the album remains Test Icicles' only LP.

title: Cannonball (Skylar Grey song)
text: Cannonball is a single released by American singer and songwriter, Skylar Grey.

title: Cannonball (Skylar Grey song)
text: The song was written by Grey, Sam Harris, Noah Feldshuh, Casey Harris, Adam Levin and Alex da Kid, produced by the latter, and features the band X Ambassadors.

title: Cannonball (Skylar Grey song)
text: "Cannonball" is on "FIFA 16" soundtrack, and was announced by "The Independent".

title: Cannonball (Skylar Grey song)
text: It received official digital release on September 25, 2015 "Cannonball" will support the US collaborative tour between Grey and X Ambassadors.

title: Cannonball (Skylar Grey song)
text: The song sold around 25,000 digital copies in the United States.

title: Dig Your Own Grave
text: Dig Your Own Grave was a CD/DVD EP released on 23 April 2006 by Test Icicles.

title: Dig Your Own Grave
text: It contained a CD of remixes and other previously unreleased material, which was accompanied by a DVD of music videos and live footage from a gig at the LSE in London, in November 2005.

title: Dig Your Own Grave
text: The EP was first sold on the band's final 5 show tour. "

title: Dig Your Own Grave
text: "Dig Your Own Grave"" then became available in record stores a week later.

title: The Ordinary Boys (album)
text: The Ordinary Boys is the self-titled fourth studio album by The Ordinary Boys released on 2 October 2015.

title: The Ordinary Boys (album)
text: The album has so far spawned the singles "Awkward" and "Four Letter Word".

title: The Ordinary Boys (album)
text: It was produced by Rory Attwell of Test Icicles and Matt Johnson of Hookworms.

title: Dev Hynes
text: David Joseph Michael Hynes (born December 23, 1985), better known as Devonté "Dev" Hynes or Blood Orange and formerly Lightspeed Champion, is a British singer, songwriter, composer, producer and author.

title: Dev Hynes
text: From 2004 to 2006, Hynes was a member of the band Test Icicles, playing guitar, synth, and occasionally performing vocals.

title: Dev Hynes
text: They released one full-length album in 2005.

title: Dev Hynes
text: Hynes went on to release two solo studio albums as Lightspeed Champion and subsequently three more as Blood Orange, between 2008 and 2016.

title: Dev Hynes
text: Dev has cited Prince, Hercules & The Love Affair and Gary Utteridge amongst his musical influences.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase
text: The Great Locomotive Chase is a 1956 Walt Disney Productions CinemaScope adventure film based on the real Great Locomotive Chase that occurred in 1862 during the American Civil War.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase
text: The film stars Fess Parker as James J. Andrews, the leader of a group of Union soldiers from various Ohio regiments who volunteered to go behind Confederate lines in civilian clothes, steal a Confederate train north of Atlanta, and drive it back to Union lines in Tennessee, tearing up railroad tracks and destroying bridges and telegraph lines along the way.

title: The Yonah (locomotive)
text: The Yonah was a type 4-4-0 steam locomotive that participated in the Great Locomotive Chase of the American Civil War.

title: Henry P. Haney
text: Henry P. Haney (November 25, 1846 - November 19, 1923) was an American Last survivor of The Great Locomotive Chase during the American Civil War.

title: Henry P. Haney
text: He was a 15-year-old fireman on the "Texas", the locomotive used by the "General's" crew to pursue the "General" on the second half of the chase after it was stolen by the Andrews Raiders.

title: Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works
text: Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works was a 19th-century manufacturer of railroad steam locomotives based in Paterson, in Passaic County, New Jersey, in the United States.

title: Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works
text: It built more than six thousand steam locomotives for railroads around the world.

title: Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works
text: Most railroads in 19th-century United States rostered at least one Rogers-built locomotive.

title: Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works
text: The company's most famous product was a locomotive named "The General", built in December 1855, which was one of the principals of the Great Locomotive Chase of the American Civil War.

title: The General (1926 film)
text: The General is a 1926 American silent comedy film released by United Artists.

title: The General (1926 film)
text: It was inspired by the Great Locomotive Chase, a true story of an event that occurred during the American Civil War.

title: The General (1926 film)
text: The story was adapted from the memoir "The Great Locomotive Chase" by William Pittenger.

title: The General (1926 film)
text: The film stars Buster Keaton who co-directed it with Clyde Bruckman.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival is a three-day celebration held in remembering the Great Locomotive Chase of April 12, 1862.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: It is held the first weekend each October in the center of downtown Adairsville, GA.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: The festival has arts and crafts booths, historical exhibits, concerts, entertainment, carnival rides, and over 40 food booths.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: The Grand Parade and multiple pageants are held on Friday and Saturday, as well as street dances.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: Gospel singing takes place on Sunday afternoon.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: The festival was founded by the towns Principle Marion Lacey.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: The schools fall festival had been canceled due to funding issues.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival
text: Mr. Lacey planned the festival in town to get the small businesses together and provide entertainment for the students each fall.

title: Cornelia, Georgia
text: Cornelia is a city in Habersham County, Georgia, United States.

title: Cornelia, Georgia
text: The population was 4,160 at the 2010 census, up from 3,674 at the 2000 census.

title: Cornelia, Georgia
text: It is home to one of the world's largest apple sculptures, which is displayed on top of an obelisk-shaped monument.

title: Cornelia, Georgia
text: Cornelia was the retirement home of baseball legend Ty Cobb who was born nearby, and was a base of operation for production of the 1956 Disney film "The Great Locomotive Chase" that was filmed along the Tallulah Falls Railway that ran from Cornelia northward along the rim of Tallulah Gorge to Franklin, North Carolina.

title: The Texas (locomotive)
text: Western & Atlantic Railroad #49 ""Texas"" is a 4-4-0 "American" type steam locomotive built in 1856 for the Western & Atlantic Railroad by Danforth, Cooke & Co., best known as the principal pursuit engine in the Great Locomotive Chase, chasing the "General" after the latter was stolen by Union saboteurs in an attempt to ruin the Confederate rail system during the American Civil War.

title: The Texas (locomotive)
text: The locomotive had been preserved at the Atlanta Cyclorama building within Grant Park in Atlanta, Georgia, and is listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Mark Wood (Medal of Honor)
text: Mark Wood (September 22, 1839 - July 11, 1866) was an American soldier who fought in the American Civil War.

title: Mark Wood (Medal of Honor)
text: Wood received his country's highest award for bravery during combat, the Medal of Honor, for his role in the celebrated Great Locomotive Chase.

title: Mark Wood (Medal of Honor)
text: Wood and a fellow participant in the raid, John A. Wilson, were captured close to Union lines in Stevenson, Alabama after they abandoned "The General".

title: Mark Wood (Medal of Honor)
text: Wood and Wilson escaped from captivity and after sailing down the Chattahoochee River, were rescued by a Union ship.

title: Mark Wood (Medal of Honor)
text: He was honored with the award on May 12, 1865.

title: The General (locomotive)
text: Western & Atlantic Railroad #3 "General" is a 4-4-0 "American" type steam locomotive built in 1855 by the Rogers, Ketchum & Grosvenor in Paterson, New Jersey for the Western & Atlantic Railroad, best known as the engine stolen by Union spies in the Great Locomotive Chase, an attempt to cripple the Confederate rail network during the American Civil War.

title: The General (locomotive)
text: Today, the locomotive is preserved at the Southern Museum of Civil War and Locomotive History in Kennesaw, Georgia, and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: Salem Creek (also known as Stone Church Hollow Creek, Seyberts Creek, or Varners Creek) is a tributary of the Susquehanna River in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania, in the United States.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: It is approximately 4.8 mi long and flows through Salem Township.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: The watershed of the creek has an area of 3.77 sqmi .

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: It has no named tributaries, but one unnamed tributary.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: Lee Mountain and Summer Hill are both in the vicinity of the creek.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: It flows through a gorge at one point.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: The creek is in the ridge and valley region and is near the southern terminus of the Wisconsinan glaciation.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: It served as a sluiceway for glacial meltwater during the aforementioned glacial period.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: The creek's discharge is considerably lower than it was during the previous glaciation.

title: Salem Creek (Pennsylvania)
text: Rock formations such as the Catskill Formation and the Trimmers Rock Formation occur near it, as does glacial till.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: Cow Creek is a tributary of the Missouri River, approximately 35 mi long, in north central Montana in the United States.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: Cow Creek rises in the southern foothills of the Bear Paw Mountains in western Blaine County and flows east and then south, joining the Missouri approximately 25 mi northeast of Winifred, Montana—or 22 mi upstream from the Fred Robinson Bridge.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: Cow Creek flows down to the Missouri in a canyon that passes through the Missouri Breaks, which are severely eroded badlands that extend out on either side from the Missouri River.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: The floor of Cow Creek canyon provided a pathway of travel from the Montana plains north of the river, down to the Missouri – at the mouth of Cow Creek, Cow Island made fording the Missouri easier – a steep but short trail on the south bank of the Missouri opposite Cow Creek completed this route which led from the northern Montana plains to the central and southern Montana plains.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: This pathway was used by migrating buffalo/bison and nomadic American Natives for centuries.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: During the steamboat era on the Missouri River, when low water prevented riverboats getting up to Fort Benton, the mouth of Cow Creek became a river landing and freighting depot, and it was the start of the Cow Island Trail by which freight was moved on to Fort Benton by going north up Cow Creek and then west.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: In 1877 the Nez Perce Indian Tribe, fleeing to Canada, had several skirmishes along Cow Creek including the "Battle of Cow Island", and several days later at a camp on Cow Creek the Nez Perce, thinking themselves now beyond the reach of the U.S. Army, made the fateful decision to slow down, rather than push on for the Canada–US border.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: Today, modern highways have by passed Cow Creek, and the buffalo and the nomadic Indian are gone.

title: Cow Creek (Montana)
text: Cow Creek is dormant, in one of the most remote spots of the isolated regions of the vast area known as the Montana Missouri Breaks.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: The Red Rock River is a roughly 70 mi river in southwestern Montana in the United States.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: Its drainage basin covers over 1548 mi2 .

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: Its furthest tributary, Hell Roaring Creek, originates in the Beaverhead National Forest within a few hundred meters of the North American Continental Divide and Montana-Idaho border near Brower's Spring, at an elevation of about 9100 ft .

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: Brower's Spring is near the furthest headwaters of the Missouri River, one of the major watercourses of the central United States.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: The drainage flows north and west with its name changing to "Red Rock Creek" into the Red Rock Lakes in the middle of a wide grassy valley; the Red Rock River issues from the west side of Lower Red Rock Lake.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: It flows west, receiving many tributaries such as Peet Creek and Long Creek, widening into the Lima Reservoir and then passing through a canyon, which ends near Lima, Montana.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: From there, it flows northwest through a valley, passing Kidd and Red Rock, and into Clark Canyon Reservoir.

title: Red Rock River (Montana)
text: Under the waters of the lake was once the confluence of the Red Rock and Horse Prairie Creek, forming the Beaverhead River, a tributary of the Jefferson River, in turn a headwater of the Missouri River.

title: Frenchmans Creek (California)
text: Frenchmans Creek is a 4.4 mi stream in San Mateo County, California.

title: Frenchmans Creek (California)
text: Locks Creek is its largest tributary.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Tomichi Creek is a 71.8 mi tributary of the Gunnison River in Gunnison County, Colorado.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Tomichi Creek originates north and west of Monarch Pass and flows to the southwest along the base of Monarch Mountain.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Congress Creek drains into Tomichi west of Old Monarch Pass where it flows south toward Sargents.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Agape Creek flows into Tomichi just north of Sargents where Marshall Creek flows from Marshall Pass.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Just below Sargents, Long Branch Creek, flowing out of Baldy Lake from the south, enters Tomichi Creek which takes a westward course where Needle Creek Reservoir drains into Tomichi east of Doyleville.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Hot Springs Reservoir drains down Wanita Canyon flowing into Tomichi Creek just west of Doyleville.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: The Tomichi Valley is a semi-wide valley allowing Tomichi Creek to meander and split into several waterways creating an excellent livestock range and being largely private ranch lands.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: At Parlin, Quartz Creek flows from Pitkin and Ohio into Tomichi Creek.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: Tomichi continues its westward journey, slightly northwest, where the Cochetopa Creek drains into Tomichi at State Highway 114 from the south at the intersection of U.S. Highway 50 and continues west to Gunnison where it enters the Gunnison River.

title: Tomichi Creek
text: A map can be viewed at the BLM Colorado website here.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: Lithia Springs Creek (also known as Johnsons Run or Lithia Spring Creek) is a tributary of the Susquehanna River in Northumberland County, Pennsylvania, in the United States.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: It is approximately 3.2 mi long and flows through Point Township.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: The watershed of the creek has an area of 8.96 sqmi .

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: It has a named tributary known as Johnson Creek.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: Waste of various types is discharged into Lithia Springs Creek from a variety of sources.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: At least one bridge more than 20 ft long crosses the creek.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: The creek is considered to be a Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery.

title: Lithia Springs Creek
text: It is inhabited by wild trout and possibly a few other species of fish.

title: Frenchmans Creek (New South Wales)
text: Frenchmans Creek is a short tributary of the Darling River in west New South Wales, measuring 7.51 km from its source south of Pooncarie, New South Wales at an elevation of 54.4 m to its confluence into the Darling River at an elevation of 48 m .

title: Jemez River
text: The Jemez River is a tributary of the Rio Grande in the U.S. state of New Mexico.

title: Jemez River
text: The river is formed by the confluence of the East Fork Jemez River and San Antonio Creek, which drain a number of tributaries in the area of the Jemez Mountains and Santa Fe National Forest.

title: Jemez River
text: The Jemez River is about 50 mi long, or about 80 mi long if its longest headwater tributary, San Antonio Creek, is included.

title: Jemez River
text: The East Fork Jemez River is about 22 mi long.

title: Jemez River
text: Both San Antonio Creek and the East Fork Jemez River flow through intricate meanders along their courses.

title: Jemez River
text: The East Fork Jemez is a National Wild and Scenic River.

title: East Branch South Fork Eel River
text: The East Branch South Fork Eel River, a tributary of the South Fork Eel River, is formed by the confluence of Cruso Cabin Creek and Elkhorn Creek, in Mendocino County in the U.S. state of California.

title: East Branch South Fork Eel River
text: The river is roughly 25 mi long, meandering west to its confluence with the South Fork Eel at Benbow Lake State Recreation Area.

title: East Branch South Fork Eel River
text: Major tributaries of the East Branch include Buck Mountain Creek, Squaw Creek, Rays Creek, and Tom Long Creek.

title: East Branch South Fork Eel River
text: The river flows west, turns north, and flows west again, through rugged terrain in the Coast Range of California.

title: East Branch South Fork Eel River
text: The East Branch is the South Fork Eel's largest tributary.

title: Locks Creek
text: Locks Creek is a 1.9 mi stream in San Mateo County, California.

title: Locks Creek
text: It is the largest tributary of Frenchmans Creek, a larger stream.

title: East Haven High School
text: East Haven High School is located at 35 Wheelbarrow Lane in East Haven, Connecticut.

title: East Haven High School
