text: (It was located at 200 Tyler Street until September 1997.)

title: East Haven High School
text: It is a co-educational public school serving grades nine through twelve.

title: East Haven High School
text: Its school colors are blue and gold and its mascot is the yellow jacket.

title: East Haven High School
text: The school is part of the Southern Connecticut Conference for athletics.

title: East Haven High School
text: East Haven High School is also known for its marching band.

title: Tyler Consolidated High School
text: Tyler Consolidated High School (TCHS) is a public secondary school in Sistersville, West Virginia, United States.

title: Tyler Consolidated High School
text: It is part of the Tyler County Schools district and is located at 1993 Silver Knight Drive.

title: Tyler Consolidated High School
text: The school was formed in 1993 when students from Sistersville High School and Tyler County High School consolidated to form one county high school.

title: Tyler Kalinoski
text: Tyler Kalinoski (born December 19, 1992) is an American basketball player for Antwerp Giants in the Belgian League.

title: Tyler Kalinoski
text: Kalinoski was a McDonald’s All-American nominee as a senior at Olathe East High School in Kansas and completed his college career for the Davidson Wildcats.

title: Tyler Kalinoski
text: He was named Atlantic 10 Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year in 2015.

title: Harvest Time Christian Academy
text: Harvest Time Christian Academy is a coeducational, private school located in Tyler, Texas.

title: Harvest Time Christian Academy
text: Founded in 2010 as a Christian ministry of the Harvest Time Church of Tyler, the school accepts students from Pre-K to 12th grade.

title: Woodville High School (Texas)
text: Woodville High School is a public high school located in the city of Woodville, Texas in Tyler County, United States and classified as a 3A school by the UIL.

title: Woodville High School (Texas)
text: It is a part of the Woodville Independent School District located in central Tyler County.

title: Woodville High School (Texas)
text: In 2015, the school was rated "Met Standard" by the Texas Education Agency.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: Calvin Tyler Scott is a Canadian basketball player for the UPEI Panthers.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: Tyler Scott was born and raised in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: Tyler Scott attended Halifax West High School and was the top scorer for the Halifax West Warriors.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: After graduating from Halifax West, Tyler Scott attended Lee Academy, a prep school in Maine.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: After Lee Academy, Tyler Scott went to Acadia University in New Minas, where he averaged 11.7 points per game, after realizing Acadia wasn't where he felt 100% comfortable he committed to UPEI with Tim Kendrick.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: At UPEI Tyler Scott went on to average 23 points per game in his first year and became a first team all Canadian and during his second and third year at UPEI, Tyler Scott was named second team all star and was 2nd in scoring in the AUS and 1st in scoring in his 5th year.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: On February 26, 2017, Tyler Scott made it into top 5 AUS scoring of all time.

title: Calvin Tyler Scott
text: During his 5th year Tyler Scott also passed 1700 career points.

title: Tyler School of Art
text: The Stella Elkins Tyler School of Art, also known as Tyler School of Art, is an art school at Temple University.

title: Tyler School of Art
text: The school was founded by sculptors Stella Elkins Tyler (of the Elkins/Widener family) and Boris Blai on a separate 14-acre estate in Elkins Park.

title: Tyler School of Art
text: In 2009, Tyler opened the doors to a new facility located on Temple's Main Campus.

title: Tyler School of Art
text: An allocation of $61.5 million from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania provided the cornerstone financial support for the new 255,000 square foot building, designed by award-winning architect Carlos Jimenez.

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: Middlebourne Historic District is a national historic district located at Middlebourne, Tyler County, West Virginia.

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: It encompasses 88 contributing buildings that include the civic, commercial, and residential core of Middlebourne.

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: Most of the buildings in the district date from the late-19th and early-20th century in popular architectural styles, such as Queen Anne and Classical Revival.

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: The two oldest are the Federal-style Quinif House (1805) and Gorrell-Wetzel House (1807).

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: Other notable buildings include the Tyler County High School (1907), First National Bank (1902), Smith's Drug Store (c. 1890), Nadene Theater (c. 1920), The Powell-Shore House (c. 1898-99; the town's best example of Queen Anne Architecture), the Weekley House (c. 1905), the Huth-Fletcher House (1895), and United Methodist Church and Parsonage (1910).

title: Middlebourne Historic District
text: Also located in the district is the separately listed Tyler County Courthouse and Jail (1854, 1874, 1922).

title: Council Rock High School North
text: Council Rock High School North is a high school located in Newtown, Bucks County, Pennsylvania.

title: Council Rock High School North
text: It is a part of the Council Rock School District.

title: Council Rock High School North
text: The school is located across from Newtown Middle School (formerly Newtown Junior High) and Tyler State Park, and near Bucks County Community College.

title: Council Rock High School North
text: The current student population is 2259 for grades 9-12.

title: Kevin Lockett
text: Kevin Eugene Lockett (born September 4, 1974) is a former American football wide receiver and punt returner in the National Football League for the Kansas City Chiefs, Washington Redskins, Jacksonville Jaguars and New York Jets.

title: Kevin Lockett
text: He played college football at Kansas State University where he was a football and Academic All-American.

title: Kevin Lockett
text: He went to high school at Booker T. Washington High School in Tulsa.

title: Kevin Lockett
text: His younger brother Aaron and son Tyler also played football at Kansas State and Tyler was later drafted by the Seattle Seahawks.

title: Henry Wharton (boxer)
text: Henry Wharton ( (1967--) 23 1967 (age 50 ) ) born in Leeds is an English professional middle/super middle/light heavy/cruiserweight boxer of the 1980s and '90s who won the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) British super middleweight, European Boxing Union (EBU) super middleweight title, and Commonwealth super middleweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Council (WBC) super middleweight title against Nigel Benn, and Robin Reid, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) super middleweight title against Chris Eubank, his professional fighting weight varied from 162 lb , i.e. middleweight to 179 lb , i.e. cruiserweight.

title: Chris Eubank Jr.
text: Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989) is a British professional boxer.

title: Chris Eubank Jr.
text: He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, having previously held the WBA interim and British middleweight titles between 2015 and 2016.

title: Chris Eubank Jr.
text: As of July 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's second best super middleweight by BoxRec, sixth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board, and seventh by "The Ring" magazine.

title: Chris Eubank Jr.
text: He is the son of former two-weight world boxing champion Chris Eubank.

title: Jermain Mackey
text: Jermain "Choo Choo" Mackey ( (1979--) 27 1979 (age 37 ) ) born in Nassau is a Bahamian professional middle/super middle/light heavyweight boxer of the 2000s and 2010s who won the Bahamas super middleweight title, World Boxing Council (WBC) Caribbean Boxing Federation (CABOFE) super middleweight title, World Boxing Association (WBA) Fedecaribe super middleweight title, Commonwealth super middleweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Organization (WBO) North American Boxing Organization (NABO) super middleweight title against Jean Pascal, WBC International super middleweight title against Adonis Stevenson, and World Boxing Association Fedelatin super middleweight title against Kirt Sinnette, his professional fighting weight varied from 160+3/4 lb , i.e. welterweight to 170 lb , i.e. light heavyweight.

title: Jermain Mackey
text: He represented the Bahamas at the 2002 Commonwealth Games.

title: Luke Blackledge
text: Luke 'Robbo' Blackledge ( (1990--) 6 1990 (age 27 ) ), born in Clitheroe, is an English professional super middleweight, and light heavyweight boxer who has won the British Masters light-heavyweight title, World Boxing Council (WBC) International Silver super middleweight title, and Commonwealth super middleweight title, and has been a challenger for the World Boxing Council (WBC) Youth World light heavyweight title, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) Youth Intercontinental light heavyweight title a defeat by Erik Skoglund, British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) Central (England) Area super middleweight title a draw with Alistair Warren, and Commonwealth (British Empire) super middleweight title a defeat by Rocky Fielding.

title: Andre Thysse
text: Andre Thysse ( (1968--) 07 1968 (age (2017)-(1968)-((11)<(02)or(11)==(02)and(30)<(07)) ) ) born in Germiston, is a South African professional super middle/light heavyweight boxer of the 1990s and 2000s who won the Gauteng super middleweight Title, South African super middleweight title, and Commonwealth super middleweight title, and was a challenger for the International Boxing Organization (IBO) super middleweight title against Brian Magee, World Boxing Council (WBC) super middleweight title against Markus Beyer, World Boxing Council (WBC) International super middleweight title against Mikkel Kessler, WBC International super middleweight title against Jürgen Brähmer, World Boxing Council (WBC) Continental Americas super middleweight title against Lucian Bute, World Boxing Council (WBC) International light heavyweight title against Adrian Diaconu, and International Boxing Federation (IBF) Australasian super middleweight title against Sakio Bika, his professional fighting weight varied from 163+3/4 lb , i.e. super middleweight to 175 lb , i.e. light heavyweight.

title: Natascha Ragosina
text: Natalia Yurievna Ragozina (Russian: Наталья Юрьевна Рагозина ), better known as Natascha Ragosina, is an undefeated retired professional boxer who spent much of her career ranked as the top female super middleweight in the world.

title: Natascha Ragosina
text: Though born in Kazakhstan (formerly a part of the Soviet Union) and currently residing in Moscow, she competed professionally for Russia and is of Russian descent.

title: Natascha Ragosina
text: She is the longest reigning WBA female super middleweight champion and WBC female super middleweight champion.

title: Natascha Ragosina
text: At the time of her retirement, she held all major female super middleweight titles and two heavyweight belts:

title: Rod Carr
text: Rod Carr ( (1968--) 09 1968 (age (2017)-(1968)-((11)<(10)or(11)==(10)and(30)<(09)) ) ) is an Australian professional welter/light middle/middle/super middle/light heavy/cruiserweight boxer of the 1980s and '90s who won the Oriental and Pacific Boxing Federation (OPBF) super middleweight title, Trans-Tasman super middleweight title, Australian super middleweight title, and inaugural Commonwealth super middleweight title, and was a challenger for the International Boxing Organization (IBO) super middleweight title against Rick Thornberry, and inaugural Pan Asian Boxing Association (PABA) light heavyweight title against Anthony Bigeni, his professional fighting weight varied from 164 lb , i.e. super middleweight to 180+1/2 lb , i.e. cruiserweight.

title: Ambrose Mendy
text: Ambrose Mendy (born August 1954) is a British boxing manager, advisor and sports agent.

title: Ambrose Mendy
text: He has managed and/or advised Nigel Benn; James DeGale; Chris Eubank Junior; Lloyd Honeyghan & Errol Christie among others during a career in boxing that started in the late 1970s.

title: Scott Dixon (boxer)
text: "Super" Scott Dixon ( (1976--) 28 1976 (age (2017)-(1976)-((11)<(09)or(11)==(09)and(30)<(28)) ) ) born in Hamilton is a Scottish professional feather/super feather/light/light welter/welter/light middle/middle/super middleweight boxer of the 1990s, 2000s and 2010s, who won the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) Scottish Area welterweight title, World Boxing Board (WBB) welterweight title, World Boxing Union (German Version) super middleweight title, and Commonwealth welterweight title, and was a challenger for the World Athletic Association (WAA) welterweight title against Michael Carruth, BBBofC British welterweight title against Derek Roche, World Boxing Federation (WBF) light middleweight title against Steve Roberts, World Boxing Organization (WBO) Inter-Continental light middleweight title against Anthony Farnell, and World Boxing Union (WBU) light middleweight title against Mehrdad Takalobigashi, his professional fighting weight varied from 125 lb , i.e. featherweight to 167+1/2 lb , i.e. Super middleweight.

title: Dean Francis
text: Dean "Star" Francis ( (1974--) 23 1974 (age (2017)-(1974)-((11)<(01)or(11)==(01)and(30)<(23)) ) ) is an English professional super middle/light heavy/cruiserweight boxer of the 1990s, 2000s and 2010s who has won the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) British super middleweight, BBBofC English cruiserweight title, European Boxing Union (EBU) super middleweight title, World Boxing Organization (WBO) Inter-Continental super middleweight title, International Boxing Organization (IBO) Inter-Continental light heavyweight title, BBBofC British light heavyweight title, British Masters light-heavy title, and Commonwealth super middleweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Council (WBC) International super middleweight title against Jaffa Ballogou, BBBofC British super middleweight title against Matthew Barney, his professional fighting weight has varied from 167 lb , i.e. super middleweight to 181 lb , i.e. cruiserweight.

title: Mickey Mehta
text: Mickey Mehta (born 29 August 1962) is an Indian holistic health, well-being, wellness, and fitness guru.

title: Mickey Mehta
text: He is a TV and radio presenter (94.3 Radio One Mumbai and Delhi) and a columnist in various publications and websites.

title: Mickey Mehta
text: He preaches the concept of holistic health and equipment free workouts and has done so by establishing a chain of Mickey Mehta Wellness Temples across Mumbai city.

title: Mickey Mehta
text: The media often refer to Mickey Mehta as 'India's Leading Holistic Health Guru'.

title: Mickey Mehta
text: Mehta also aspires to build the largest social media base across as many platforms possible, to reach out to his audience.

title: Rejuvelac
text: Rejuvelac is kind of grain water invented and promoted by Ann Wigmore.

title: Holistic dentistry
text: Holistic dentistry also called biological dentistry, biologic dentistry, alternative dentistry, unconventional dentistry, or biocompatible dentistry is the equivalent of complementary and alternative medicine for dentistry.

title: Holistic dentistry
text: Holistic dentistry emphasizes approaches to dental care said to consider dental health in the context of the patient's entire physical as well as emotional or spiritual health in some cases.

title: Holistic dentistry
text: Although the holistic dental community is diverse in its practices and approaches, common threads include strong opposition to the use of amalgam in materials in dental fillings, nonsurgical approaches to gum disease, and the belief that root canals may endanger systemic health of the patient through the spread of trapped dental bacteria to the body.

title: Holistic dentistry
text: Many dentists who use these terms also regard water fluoridation unfavorably.

title: Guelph Community Health Centre
text: The Guelph Community Health Centre (Guelph CHC, GCHC) is a public, non-profit organization that provides primary health care to the community of Guelph, Ontario, Canada, as well as a variety of programs that focus on holistic health promotion and community development.

title: Guelph Community Health Centre
text: The Guelph CHC is a member of the Association of Ontario Health Centres (AOHC) and one of over 300 CHCs in Canada.

title: Guelph Community Health Centre
text: The Guelph CHC has one main location in downtown Guelph, as well as a satellite clinic located on Shelldale Crescent, and an Early Years Satellite location, situated in the Stone Road Mall.

title: Ann Wigmore
text: Ann Wigmore (1909–1994) was a Lithuanian–American "holistic health" practitioner and raw food advocate.

title: Ann Wigmore
text: Wigmore wrote several books on her theories and lectured widely to promote her practices.

title: Viktoras Kulvinskas
text: Viktoras Peter Kulvinskas (born 23 February 1939) is a Lithuanian holistic health practitioner, nutritionist, raw foods advocate and author.

title: Kripalu Center
text: The Kripalu Center for Yoga & Health is a non-profit organization that operates a health and yoga retreat in Stockbridge, Massachusetts.

title: Kripalu Center
text: Its 160000 ft2 facility is a former Jesuit novitiate and juniorate seminary built in 1957.

title: Kripalu Center
text: The center has described itself as North America's largest residential facility for holistic health and education.

title: Kripalu Center
text: With 2013 revenue of $34.7 million, it employed about 626 people as of 2008 and can accommodate more than 650 overnight guests.

title: Crystal Bright
text: Crystal Dawn Bright (born April 9, 1981) is an award-winning musician and multimedia artist from Greensboro, North Carolina.

title: Crystal Bright
text: She is a singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, music teacher, performance artist, theatrical director & producer, and holistic health coach / nutritionist.

title: Crystal Bright
text: As founder and leader of the band Crystal Bright & the Silver Hands, she has released three studio albums and one live album, been reviewed internationally, and performed with the North Carolina Symphony.

title: Crystal Bright
text: She won the North Carolina Symphony's Triangle Talent Search in September 2010 and released an award-winning music video in October 2011.

title: Crystal Bright
text: The local "YES!

title: Crystal Bright
text: Weekly" named her Best Singer in March 2012, Best Songwriter in May 2014, and Best Musician in the Triad in May 2015.

title: Crystal Bright
text: Her music has been called "carnival folk, fairytale pop and gypsy jazz" and was described by the BBC as "a pleasant kind of bonkers."

title: Elizabeth Neilson
text: Elizabeth A. "Betty" Neilson, EDD (October 13, 1911 – October 4, 2001) was a prominent figure in the field of health education and a leader in promoting the wellness and holistic health perspectives in public health.

title: Susan Lark
text: Susan Lark is a medical doctor.

title: Susan Lark
text: She obtained her education from Northwestern Medical School, and has served as one of the clinical faculty members at Stanford University.

title: Susan Lark
text: At Stanford, Lark taught In the department of family and community medicine.

title: Susan Lark
text: As of now Lark works in the field of women’s health and preventive medicine.

title: Susan Lark
text: Lark is the founder and director of the Menopause Self Help Center located in Los Altos, California.

title: Susan Lark
text: She is well known for her innovative approaches to menopause and hormone management as well as her views on holistic women’s health.

title: Susan Lark
text: Her holistic approaches focus on hormone balance to assist in the prevention of different physical and emotional health conditions.

title: Susan Lark
text: She believes that maintaining a slightly alkaline body pH while ultimately lead to optimal health especially in the prevention of diseases such as, osteoporosis.

title: Susan Lark
text: Dr. Susan Lark has currently innovated and developed different types of nutritional supplements and all natural products in the field of women’s health and hormonal balance.

title: Susan Lark
text: Her products were invented to allow women to achieve hormone balance without having to utilize conventional hormone replacement therapies.

title: Susan Lark
text: According to Healthy Directions, “she is also a distinguished clinician, lecturer, and author of 13 best-selling books on women’s health, including Chemistry of Success and the cookbook Eat Papayas Naked, as well as a series of self-help books on women’s health topics like hot flashes, PMS, anxiety, and chronic fatigue.

title: Susan Lark
text: Her most recent book is Hormone Revolution, written with Kimberly S. Day.

title: Susan Lark
text: She has also been featured in many publications, including Real Simple, Reader’s Digest, Better Homes & Gardens, New Woman, Family Circle, Shape, The New York Times, and The San Francisco Chronicle.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: Merv Griffin Entertainment is an American production company founded by American media mogul Merv Griffin on May 13, 1996.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: It is a successor to Merv Griffin Enterprises.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: Its productions include revivals of recent franchises (such as "Dance Fever", revived in 2003 for the Freeform channel).

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: Griffin's company is part of The Griffin Group.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: Merv Griffin Entertainment owns "The Merv Griffin Show" and "Dance Fever", but Sony Pictures Television handles television distribution rights.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: The television division was run by Yani-Brune Entertainment from 2005 to 2008; hand-picked by Griffin himself.

title: Merv Griffin Entertainment
text: In 2008, ShineReveille International made a deal with Merv Griffin Entertainment to distribute all of MGE programming overseas.

title: Rupert Murdoch
text: Keith Rupert Murdoch, {'1': ", '2': 'AC KCSG', '3': ", '4': "} ( ; born 11 March 1931) is an Australian-born American media mogul.

title: Rupert Murdoch
text: His father, Sir Keith Murdoch, had been a reporter, editor, and senior executive of the "Herald" and "Weekly Times" newspaper publishing company, covering all Australian states except New South Wales.

title: Rupert Murdoch
text: After his father's death in 1952, Murdoch declined to join his late father's registered public company and created his own private company, News Limited.

title: Rupert Murdoch
text: Murdoch thus had full control as Chairman and CEO of global media holding company News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on 28 June 2013.

title: Media proprietor
text: A media proprietor, media mogul or media tycoon refers to a successful entrepreneur or businessperson who controls, through personal ownership or via a dominant position in any media related company or enterprise, media consumed by a large number of individuals.

title: Media proprietor
text: Those with significant control, ownership, and influence of a large company in the mass media may also be called a tycoon, baron, or business magnate.

title: Media proprietor
text: Social media creators and founders can also be considered media moguls, as such channels deliver media to a large consumer base.

title: Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference
text: The Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference is an annual media finance conference hosted and wholly independently funded by private investment firm Allen & Company.

title: Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference
text: The conference has taken place in Sun Valley, Idaho for one week each July since 1983.

title: Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference
text: The conference typically features business leaders, political figures, and major figures in the philanthropic and cultural spheres.

title: Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference
text: Previous conference guests have included Bill and Melinda Gates, Warren and Susan Buffett, Tony Blair, Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Allen alumnus and former Philippine Senator Mar Roxas, Google Chairman Eric Schmidt, Yahoo! co-founder Jerry Yang, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, Media Mogul Rupert Murdoch, eBay CEO Meg Whitman, BET founder Robert Johnson, Time Warner Chairman Richard Parsons, NBA player LeBron James, Governor Chris Christie, entertainer Dan Chan, Katharine Graham of "The Washington Post", Diane Sawyer, InterActiveCorp Chairman Barry Diller, Linkedin co-founder Reid Hoffman, Sandro Salsano from Salsano Group, and Washington Post CEO Donald E. Graham, and Oprah.

title: A Girl like Me (film)
text: A Girl like Me is a 2005 documentary by Kiri Davis.

title: A Girl like Me (film)
text: The seven-minute documentary examines such things as the importance of color, hair and facial features for young African American women.

title: A Girl like Me (film)
text: It won the Diversity Award at the 6th Annual Media That Matters film festival in New York City, and has received coverage on various American media sources, such as CNN, ABC, NPR.

title: A Girl like Me (film)
text: The documentary has been shown on HBO.

title: A Girl like Me (film)
text: The documentary was made as part of Reel Works Teen Filmmaking.

title: Mona Scott-Young
text: Mona Scott-Young (born February 15, 1967) is an American media mogul, television producer, executive producer and entrepreneur.

title: Mona Scott-Young
text: She is the CEO of the multi-media entertainment company Monami Entertainment, best known for producing the VH1 reality television franchise "Love & Hip Hop".

title: Caroline Spencer
text: Caroline Spencer is a fictional character from the CBS Daytime soap opera, "The Bold and the Beautiful", created by producer Bradley Bell.

title: Caroline Spencer
text: She is portrayed by actress Linsey Godfrey.

title: Caroline Spencer
text: She is the daughter of media mogul Karen Spencer (Joanna Johnson), niece of media mogul Bill Spencer, Jr. (Don Diamont) and namesake of her aunt, Caroline Spencer Forrester (Johnson).

title: Pat Robertson
text: Marion Gordon "Pat" Robertson (born March 22, 1930) is an American media mogul, executive chairman, and former Southern Baptist minister who advocates conservative Christian ideals.

title: Pat Robertson
text: He presently serves as chancellor and CEO of Regent University and chairman of the Christian Broadcasting Network.

title: Turner
text: American media mogul Ted Turner created several channels featuring his name:

title: Elisabeth Murdoch (businesswoman)
text: Elisabeth Murdoch ( ; born 22 August 1968) is an Australian-born American media executive based in the United Kingdom.

title: Elisabeth Murdoch (businesswoman)
text: Murdoch is the second daughter of Australian-born American multi-billionaire media proprietor Rupert Murdoch.

title: Elisabeth Murdoch (businesswoman)
text: She was a non-executive chairperson of Shine Group, the UK-based TV program production company she founded in 2001, until the company's parent, her father's 21st Century Fox on 1 January 2015 merged its Shine division with ApolloGlobal Management's Endemol and Core Media production houses, specializing in reality TV.

title: Bushie
text: A Bushie, or less commonly, Bushite or Bushy, is a term referring to a political supporter of George H. W. Bush or George W. Bush.

title: Bushie
text: More specifically, it is used to denote the inner circle of Bush advisors, appointees, and acolytes.

title: Bushie
text: The label carries much the same meaning as the terms "Reaganite" and "Clintonista," which are used to denote aides and followers of Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, respectively.

title: Elliott Abrams
text: Elliott Abrams (born January 24, 1948) is a former American diplomat, lawyer and political scientist who served in foreign policy positions for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush.

title: Elliott Abrams
text: Abrams was convicted of withholding information from Congress about the Iran–Contra affair while serving under Reagan, but was pardoned by President George H. W. Bush.

title: Otto Reich
text: Otto Juan Reich (born October 16, 1945), is an American former senior official in the administrations of Presidents Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush, and George W. Bush.

title: Otto Reich
text: Among other positions held, he has been the President's Special Envoy for the Western Hemisphere; Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs; United States Ambassador to Venezuela; and Assistant Administrator of the US Agency for International Development, a recess appointment.

title: Otto Reich
text: In 2003, Bush appointed him US Special Envoy to the Western Hemisphere.

title: Otto Reich
text: Since leaving the White House in 2004, he has headed his own international consulting firm, Otto Reich Associates, LLC, based in Washington, D.C..

title: Ronald Reagan judicial appointment controversies
text: During President Ronald Reagan's presidency, he nominated at least twelve people for various federal appellate judgeship who were not confirmed.

title: Ronald Reagan judicial appointment controversies
text: In some cases, the nominations were not processed by the Democratic-controlled Senate Judiciary Committee before Reagan's presidency ended, while in other cases, nominees were rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee or even blocked by unfriendly members of the Republican Party.

title: Ronald Reagan judicial appointment controversies
text: Three of the nominees were renominated by Reagan's successor, President George H. W. Bush.

title: Ronald Reagan judicial appointment controversies
text: Two of the nominees, Ferdinand Francis Fernandez and Guy G. Hurlbutt, were nominated after July 1, 1988, the traditional start date of the unofficial Thurmond Rule during a presidential election year.

title: Ronald Reagan judicial appointment controversies
text: Eight of the twelve seats eventually were filled by appointees of President George H. W. Bush.

title: First inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: The first inauguration of Ronald Reagan as the 40th President of the United States was held on Tuesday, January 20, 1981, on the West Front of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C..

title: First inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: This was the first inauguration to be held on the building's west side.

title: First inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: The inauguration marked the commencement of the first four-year term of Ronald Reagan as President and of George H. W. Bush as Vice President.

title: First inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger administered the presidential oath of office to Reagan, who placed his hand upon a family Bible given to him by his mother, open to .

title: First inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: Associate Justice Potter Stewart administered the vice presidential oath to Bush.

title: William Flynn Martin
text: William Flynn Martin (born October 4, 1950) is an American energy economist, educator and international diplomat.

title: William Flynn Martin
text: Martin served as Special Assistant to President Reagan for National Security Affairs, Executive Secretary of the National Security Council in the West Wing of the White House and Deputy Secretary of the Department of Energy during the Ronald Reagan administration.

title: William Flynn Martin
text: He was President of the Council of the University for Peace, appointed to the Council by Secretary General of the United Nations Kofi Annan and served as the Executive Director of the Republican Platform Committee during the re-election bid of George H.W. Bush.

title: William Flynn Martin
text: He has held senior appointments and advisory positions under several Presidents including: Ronald Reagan, George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush.

title: Reagan Democrat
text: A Reagan Democrat is a traditionally Democratic voter in the United States, referring especially to white working-class Rust Belt residents, who defected from their party to support Republican President Ronald Reagan in either or both of the 1980 and 1984 elections as well as Republican Presidents George H. W. Bush in the 1988 election and George W. Bush in either or both of the 2000 and 2004 elections.

title: Reagan Democrat
text: Part of this group also defected to Donald Trump, the Republican candidate in 2016, who won in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Iowa, all states that voted for Reagan but went Democratic in 2008 and 2012.

title: Second inauguration of Ronald Reagan
text: The second inauguration of Ronald Reagan as President of the United States was held privately on Sunday, January 20, 1985 in the Grand Foyer of the White House, and publicly the following day, January 21, 1985 at the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C. The inauguration marked the commencement of the second four-year term of Ronald Reagan as President and of George H. W. Bush as Vice President.

title: Lawrence Eagleburger
text: Lawrence Sidney Eagleburger (August 1, 1930 – June 4, 2011) was an American statesman and career diplomat, who served briefly as the Secretary of State under President George H. W. Bush.

title: Lawrence Eagleburger
text: Previously, he had served in lesser capacities under Presidents Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter, and Ronald Reagan, and as Deputy Secretary of State under George H. W. Bush.

title: Presidency of Ronald Reagan
text: The presidency of Ronald Reagan began on January 20, 1981, when Ronald Reagan was inaugurated as President of the United States, and ended on January 20, 1989.

title: Presidency of Ronald Reagan
text: Reagan, a Republican, took office as the 40th United States president following a landslide win over Democratic incumbent President Jimmy Carter in the 1980 presidential election.

title: Presidency of Ronald Reagan
text: Reagan was succeeded by his vice president, George H. W. Bush, who won the 1988 presidential election with Reagan's support.

title: Buena Vista Park
text: Buena Vista Park is a park in the Haight-Ashbury and Buena Vista Heights neighborhoods of San Francisco, California.

title: Buena Vista Park
text: It is the oldest official park in San Francisco, established in 1867 as Hill Park, later renamed Buena Vista.

title: Buena Vista Park
text: It is bounded by Haight Street to the north, and by Buena Vista Avenue West and Buena Vista Avenue East.

title: Buena Vista Park
text: The park is on a steep hill that peaks at 575 feet , and covers 37 acre .

title: Buena Vista Park
text: The lowest section is the north end along Haight.

title: Buena Vista and Ellaville Railroad
text: The Buena Vista and Ellaville Railroad is a historic railroad that operated in Georgia, USA.

title: Buena Vista and Ellaville Railroad
text: It was originally incorporated as the Buena Vista Railroad in 1880 and the name was changed to the Buena Vista and Ellaville Railroad in 1885 following a corporate reorganization.

title: Buena Vista and Ellaville Railroad
text: The railroad ran 30 mi of track between Buena Vista and Americus when, in 1888, it was merged with several other lines into the Savannah and Western Railroad, a subsidiary of the Central of Georgia Railway.

title: The Bears and I
text: The Bears and I is a 1974 American drama film directed by Bernard McEveety and written by John Whedon.

title: The Bears and I
text: The film stars Patrick Wayne, Chief Dan George, Andrew Duggan, Michael Ansara and Robert Pine.

title: The Bears and I
text: The film was released on July 31, 1974, by Buena Vista Distribution.

title: Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures
text: Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures (formerly Buena Vista Pictures Distribution and Buena Vista Film Distribution Company) is an American film distributor owned by The Walt Disney Company.

title: Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures
text: Established in 1953 as Buena Vista Film Distribution Company, the company handles theatrical distribution, marketing and promotion for films produced and released by the Walt Disney Studios, including Walt Disney Pictures, Walt Disney Animation Studios, Pixar Animation Studios, DisneyToon Studios, Marvel Studios, Lucasfilm, Disneynature, and Touchstone Pictures.

title: Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures
text: The division took on its current name in late 2007, which before that had been Buena Vista Pictures Distribution since 1987.

title: List of Walt Disney Pictures films
text: This is a list of films released theatrically under the Walt Disney Pictures banner (known as that since 1983, with "Never Cry Wolf" as its first release) and films released before that under the former name of the parent company, Walt Disney Productions (1929–1983).

title: List of Walt Disney Pictures films
text: Most films listed here were distributed in the United States by the company's distribution division, Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures (formerly known as Buena Vista Distribution Company  and Buena Vista Pictures Distribution ).

title: List of Walt Disney Pictures films
text: The Disney features produced before "Peter Pan" (1953) were originally distributed by RKO Radio Pictures, and are now distributed by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures.

title: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District
text: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District is a national historic district located at Buena Vista, Virginia.

title: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District
text: The district encompasses 38 contributing buildings and 1 contributing structure in the central business district of Buena Vista.

title: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District
text: The buildings are primarily one- and two-story masonry structures, with the earliest built in 1889-1890.

title: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District
text: Notable buildings include the Buena Vista Post Office (1930), Buena Vista War Memorial Building (1954), Peoples Bank of Buena Vista (1907), Dickinson Building (c. 1907), Royer’s Restaurant (c. 1940), the Advocate Building (1889), Buena Vista Masonic Building (c. 1910), and the Valley Steam Laundry Building (c. 1905).

title: Buena Vista Downtown Historic District
text: The Buena Vista Company Building (1890) is separately listed as the Old Courthouse.

title: Buena Vista (brand)
text: Buena Vista is a brand name which was historically often used for divisions and subsidiaries of The Walt Disney Company, whose primary studios, the Walt Disney Studios, are located on Buena Vista Street in Burbank, California.

title: Buena Vista (brand)
text: (The studio lot is also home to the Company's corporate headquarters, the Team Disney Burbank building.)

title: Buena Vista (brand)
text: The logos for the various Buena Vista brands featured the "Buena Vista" wordmark superimposed over the Disney Castle image to signal the affiliation between Buena Vista and Disney.

title: Buena Vista (brand)
text: The name literally means "good view" in Spanish.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: The Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel is a 325-room resort that is on the property of Walt Disney World Resort in Lake Buena Vista, Florida.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: The resort is located across from the Disney Springs area.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: The hotel originally opened in November 1972 as the Travelodge at Lake Buena Vista.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: It was operated by Travelodge from 1972 through 1983, then in 1984 the resort became the Viscount Hotel and operated as such until 1988.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: In 1989, it was reacquired by Travelodge.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: In 2000, the Travelodge hotel switched over to become the Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel.

title: Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel
text: The hotel was renovated in 2004 and has 2 outdoor pools.

title: Buena Vista, Pennsylvania
text: Buena Vista ( ) is an unincorporated community in Elizabeth Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, United States, located just outside Pittsburgh on the Youghiogheny River.

title: Buena Vista, Pennsylvania
text: The Great Allegheny Passage rail trail runs through the community.

title: Buena Vista, Pennsylvania
text: Buena Vista's ZIP code is 15018.

title: Buena Vista, Pennsylvania
text: For a time, Buena Vista served as a mining town.

title: Buena Vista, Pennsylvania
text: Like many places in the USA with this name, Buena Vista was named for the 1847 Battle of Buena Vista during the Mexican-American War.

title: Buena Vista High School (Michigan)
text: Buena Vista High School was a public high school located at 3945 East Holland in Buena Vista Charter Township, Michigan and was part of the former Buena Vista School District.

title: Buena Vista High School (Michigan)
text: The school was closed when the Buena Vista School District was dissolved in July 2013.

title: Buena Vista High School (Michigan)
text: Buena Vista's mascot was the Knights, and its colors were blue and white.

title: Buena Vista High School (Michigan)
text: The school's athletic program competed in the Greater Thumb Conference as a Class C, and later in the Highland Conference as a Class D school.

title: Masters and Johnson
text: The Masters and Johnson research team, composed of William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson, pioneered research into the nature of human sexual response and the diagnosis and treatment of sexual disorders and dysfunctions from 1957 until the 1990s.

title: William Masters
text: William Howell Masters (December 27, 1915 – February 16, 2001) was an American gynecologist, best known as the senior member of the Masters and Johnson sexuality research team.

title: William Masters
text: Along with his wife Virginia E. Johnson, he pioneered research into the nature of human sexual response and the diagnosis and treatment of sexual dysfunctions and disorders from 1957 until the 1990s.

title: AlphaPets
text: Alphapets is a series of children's books by Ruth Lerner Perle, Deborah Colvin Borgo, Judy Blankenship and Richard Max Kolding.

title: AlphaPets
text: They are similar to the "Sweet Pickles" books in that each letter of the alphabet is represented in a separate book with an animal representing each letter.

title: AlphaPets
text: Each story was filled with words and objects that begin with the letter of the alphabet featured in that book.

title: AlphaPets
text: A special word page at the end of each book provided extra practice in identifying letters and words.

title: AlphaPets
text: The series was initially published in the early 1990s.

title: Dana Shires
text: Dana L. Shires, Jr. (born November 22, 1932) is an American physician, research scientist, and inventor.

title: Dana Shires
text: He was a member of the research team that did the work leading to the invention of Gatorade.

title: Dana Shires
text: He is the co-founder and former CEO of LifeLink Foundation, an organization created to promote, support and assist in the transplantation therapy of organs and tissues.

title: Virginia E. Johnson
text: Virginia E. Johnson, born Mary Virginia Eshelman (February 11, 1925 – July 24, 2013), was an American sexologist, best known as a member of the Masters and Johnson sexuality research team.

title: Virginia E. Johnson
text: Along with William H. Masters, she pioneered research into the nature of human sexual response and the diagnosis and treatment of sexual dysfunctions and disorders from 1957 until the 1990s.

title: Sheep (novel)
text: Sheep is a horror novel by British author Simon Maginn, originally published in 1994 and reissued in 1997.

title: Sheep (novel)
text: It is now out of print.

title: Sheep (novel)
text: The book provided the basis for the 2005 film "The Dark", although the plot changed drastically in the conversion from book to film.

title: Bruce Bode
text: Bruce Bode, MD, FACE is a diabetes specialist with the Atlanta Diabetes Associates in Atlanta, GA and is a clinical associate professor at Emory University in the Department of Medicine.

title: Bruce Bode
text: He has served on the board of directors of the Atlanta chapters of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF), the American Diabetes Association (ADA), and various Georgia-based diabetes camps.

title: Bruce Bode
text: Bode is a member of the board of directors of Glytec and an active member of the JDRF research team validating the efficacy and safety of real-time continuous glucose monitoring (CGMS), and is a former president of the ADA Georgia Affiliate and editor of the ADA's 2004 edition of Medical Management of Type 1 Diabetes.

title: Josef Peukert
text: Josef Peukert (22 January 1855 – 3 March 1910) was a German Bohemian anarchist known for his autobiographical book "Memoirs from the proletarian revolutionary labour movement" (German: "Erinnerungen eines Proletariers aus der revolutionären Arbeiterbewegung" ).

title: Josef Peukert
text: The book provided a glimpse into the early days of the radical labour movement in Austria, the start of the anarchist movement in Germany and the exile of the anarchists in London and America at the time of Socialist Law (1878-1890).

title: Josef Peukert
text: The accuracy of the book was questioned by fellow anarchist and historian Max Nettlau, who looked upon it in a "highly-skeptical" manner.

title: Berlin Diary
text: Berlin Diary (1934–1941) is a first-hand account of the rise of Nazi Germany and its road to war, as witnessed by the American journalist William L. Shirer.

title: Berlin Diary
text: Shirer, a radio reporter for CBS, covered Germany for several years until the Nazi press censors made it impossible for him to report objectively to his listeners in the United States; feeling increasingly uncomfortable, he left the country.

title: Berlin Diary
text: The identities of many of Shirer's German sources were disguised to protect these people from retaliation by the German secret police, the Gestapo.

title: Berlin Diary
text: The contents of this book provided much of the material for his landmark book "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich".

title: Fukomys vandewoestijneae
text: Fukomys vandewoestijneae or Caroline’s mole rat was first noticed in 2002 by a research team from the University of Ghent.

title: Fukomys vandewoestijneae
text: This new species, distinguished by a distinctive skull shape, was recently described by Paul Van Daele and his team in Zootaxa while DNA and chromosome tests confirmed its novelty.

title: Fukomys vandewoestijneae
text: The new species was named after Van Daele's late wife, Caroline Van De Woestijne, who was a member of the research team and died of malaria while in Africa.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: Sherry Gunther is an American producer known for her work in animation.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: While at Klasky Csupo, Gunther worked on the television series "Duckman", "Rugrats", and early seasons of "The Simpsons", for which she won a Primetime Emmy Award in 1991.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: She was made senior vice president of production at Hanna-Barbera Cartoons in 1995.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: Under Hanna-Barbera President Fred Seibert she oversaw production of Turner Entertainment programs such as "Dexter's Laboratory", "Johnny Bravo", "The Real Adventures of Jonny Quest", and the "World Premiere Toons".

title: Sherry Gunther
text: Sherry then went on to Produce Family Guy and to found Twentieth Television's first in-house Prime-Time animation studio, and produced countless Prime-Time pilots for Imagine Television, Touchstone Television, Twentieth Television, Fox, and Carsey Warner.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: She also produced theatrical shorts of Looney Tunes for Warner Bros.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: Sherry has received four additional Primetime Emmy nominations, Festival Awards, and a Humanitas Award.

title: Sherry Gunther
text: a Daytime Emmy Award, two CableACE Award nominations, and a Humanitas Prize.

title: Steve Nallon
text: Steve Nallon (born 8 November 1960) is a British actor, writer, voice artist and impressionist.

title: Steve Nallon
text: Nallon began his career as a stand-up performer on the northern club circuit in the 1970s.

title: Steve Nallon
text: He is known for his work as a voice artist on the satirical puppet show "Spitting Image" and for impersonating Margaret Thatcher on television throughout her time as Prime Minister of the UK (1979–1990).

title: Steve Nallon
text: In his career Steve Nallon has performed a number of roles and characters as an actor and as a voice artist in theatre, film, television and radio.

title: Larry Drake
text: Larry Richard Drake (February 21, 1950 – March 17, 2016) was an American actor, voice artist, and comedian best known as Benny Stulwicz in "L.A. Law", Robert G. Durant in both "Darkman" and "" and the voice of Pops in "Johnny Bravo".

title: Jeff Bennett
text: Jeff Bennett (born October 2, 1962) is an American voice actor and singer.

title: Jeff Bennett
text: His voice roles include Johnny Bravo in the television series of the same name, Petrie in the "Land Before Time" films and television series, Mr. Smee and Bones in "Jake and the Never Land Pirates", The Man With the Yellow Hat in "Curious George", Raj in "Camp Lazlo", Kowalski in "The Penguins of Madagascar" series and various other characters in films, television shows and video games.

title: List of Johnny Bravo episodes
text: "Johnny Bravo" is an American animated television series created by Van Partible for the Cartoon Network.

title: List of Johnny Bravo episodes
text: The series premiered July 14, 1997, and ended officially August 27, 2004.

title: List of Johnny Bravo episodes
text: The series is a spin-off of "World Premiere Toons", also known as the "What a Cartoon!

title: List of Johnny Bravo episodes
text: Show".

title: Brian A. Miller
text: Brian A. Miller is an American television producer and the current Senior Vice President and General Manager of Cartoon Network Studios in Burbank, California, having assumed the title in 2000.

title: Brian A. Miller
text: He was formerly Vice President of Production at Nickelodeon Animation Studio, Vice President of Production at Hanna-Barbera, and Vice President of Production at DIC Entertainment.

title: Brian A. Miller
text: He also served as a production supervisor for "Alvin and the Chipmunks".

title: Brian A. Miller
text: He was also the executive in charge of production for various shows in the 1990s and early 2000s such as "Dexter's Laboratory", "CatDog", "Hey Arnold!

title: Brian A. Miller
text: ", "The Angry Beavers", "ChalkZone", "", "The Powerpuff Girls", "Captain Planet and the Planeteers", "Adventures of Sonic the Hedgehog", "Cow and Chicken", "Johnny Bravo", and the first season of "SpongeBob SquarePants".

title: Rumen Petkov
text: Rumen Petkov (Bulgarian: Румен Петков ) (born 26 January 1948) is a Bulgarian animator and comic creator.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: His influence spawned a new generation of young Bulgarian comic book artists as Vladimir Nedialkov, Koko Sarkisian, Ivan Kirjakov and others.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: He was one of the main artists of the comics magazine DUGA (Rainbow), which was the most popular comics for several generations of Bulgarian children.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: His most popular cartoon is "The Adventures of Choko the Stork and Boko the Frog" which was popular in Bulgaria during the 1970s and 1980s.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: Other famous animated films he directed are "Friends of Gosho the Elephant", "Treasure Planet", etc.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: He has won the Grand Prize at the Ottawa Animation Festival and the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: Recently Rumen Petkov has worked as a writer, storyboard artist, animation director and director on some episodes of "Johnny Bravo", "Dexter's Laboratory", "Cow and Chicken", "I Am Weasel", "The New Woody Woodpecker Show" and other series.

title: Rumen Petkov
text: He has said about animation: "Animation will never die because it's like music, because it's like running with the wind, because it's funny."

title: Van Partible
text: Van Partible (born Efrem Giovanni Bravo Partible on December 13, 1971) is a Filipino-born American animator, writer and producer best known for creating the animated television series "Johnny Bravo".

title: Festival of New Songs
text: Festival of New Songs (Slovene: "Festival novih skladb" , FENS; previously "Festival Nova scena" ) is a festival of new and as yet nonaffirmed musicians from Slovenia and abroad.

title: Festival of New Songs
text: It is the only festival in Slovenia where not only adults but children and teenagers compete too.

title: Festival of New Songs
text: It takes place in July each year in Izola and Koper and is broadcast by main Slovene television and radio stations.

title: Festival of New Songs
text: In its more than 20 years of history more than 500 rock, jazz, metal, and pop performers from Slovenia and abroad (Italy, Croatia, and France) have participated, amongst them Kingston, Tinkara Kovač, Lara Baruca, Ylenia Zobec, Siddharta, Alya, Polona Furlan, Andraž Hribar, Monika Pučelj, Sound Attack, Aleksandra Čermelj, Mambo Kings, Nude, Botri, Maja Slatinšek, Johnny Bravo, Foxy teens, and Eva Černe.

title: Festival of New Songs
text: Its long-term mission is to promote Slovene music, to establish the international cooperation and the exchange with other European countries.

title: Gryphon (film)
text: Gryphon also known as "Attack of the Gryphon" is a 2007 television film directed by Andrew Prowse, starring Amber Benson, Jonathan LaPaglia, and Larry Drake.

title: Gryphon (film)
text: It premiered on the Sci-Fi Channel on January 27, 2007.

title: Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children
text: Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children is a 2005 Japanese computer-animated science fantasy film directed by Tetsuya Nomura, written by Kazushige Nojima, and produced by Yoshinori Kitase and Shinji Hashimoto.

title: Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children
text: Developed by Visual Works and Square Enix, "Advent Children" is part of the "Compilation of Final Fantasy VII" series of media, which is based in the world and continuity of the highly successful 1997 role-playing video game "Final Fantasy VII".

title: Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children
text: "Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children" was released on DVD and Universal Media Discs with Japanese voice acting in Japan on September 14, 2005, and on April 25, 2006, with English voice acting in North America and Europe.

title: The Age of Not Believing
text: "The Age of Not Believing" is a song written by Robert and Richard Sherman for the 1971 Walt Disney musical film production "Bedknobs and Broomsticks".

title: The Age of Not Believing
text: Angela Lansbury sings the song in the motion picture.

title: The Age of Not Believing
text: In the lyrics, Lansbury's character Eglantine expresses how as children grow up, they lose their belief in magic and doubt themselves.

title: The Age of Not Believing
text: The song works on two levels, both on a personal, human level and thematically for the whole film- a Britain grown cynical from the pressures of war must learn to borrow from its own past magic in order to overcome the tremendous challenge which lies before it, while the characters in the film must finally learn to trust in Eglantine's magic to achieve their goals and save Britain from the Nazis.

title: Stark Electric Jesus
text: Stark Electric Jesus is a 2014 short film inspired by the poem "Prochondo Boidyutik Chhutar" or "Stark Electric Jesus" written by Malay Roy Choudhury.

title: Stark Electric Jesus
text: The film has won the official selection as the only Indian film at the Trinidad and Tobago Film Festivalin New Media section and has been selected for screening at Leeds Independent Film Festival.

title: Stark Electric Jesus
text: The Film has also won 27 official selection in 20 different countries and also won 'Best Video Art' from Poland, 'Most Promising Artist' Award from Madatac,06, Spain and 'Best Fantasy Film' award from Hrizantema International Horror & Fantasy Film Festival, Serbia.

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: Sianoa Smit-McPhee (born 21 February 1992), also known as Sianoa, is an Australian singer, songwriter and actress.

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: She is best known for her years in Australian soap opera "Neighbours" as Bree Timmins.

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: Her next role was in the children's television series "As the Bell Rings", which aired on the Disney Channel.

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: In 2007, she appeared as Desma, the lead character in the short fantasy film "Hugo".

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: From 2009 to 2011, she starred in the HBO series "Hung" as Darby Drecker.

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: In 2012, Sianoa featured in the TV movie ABC "Firelight" and the series "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia".

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: The following year, she starred in "All Cheerleaders Die".

title: Sianoa Smit-McPhee
text: Sianoa and her husband John Rush, a music producer, also wrote and produced the song "Take a Bite of My Heart", which was featured in the film and performed by Sianoa.

title: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV
text: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV is a 2016 Japanese computer-animated science fantasy film directed by Takeshi Nozue and scripted by Takashi Hasegawa from a story by Kazushige Nojima and Saori Itamuro.

title: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV
text: Developed primarily by Square Enix's exclusive CGI studio Visual Works, "Kingsglaive" is based on the setting and story of the 2016 video game "Final Fantasy XV", which is thematically connected to the "Fabula Nova Crystallis" subseries.

title: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV
text: "Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV" released theatrically in July 2016 in Japan by Aniplex, and received a limited theatrical run in August in North America by Stage 6 Films.

title: Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV
text: Digital and physical home video versions were released in October 2016, and the film was bundled with different editions of "Final Fantasy XV" alongside "".

title: Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1971
text: Elections to the Baseball Hall of Fame for 1971 featured a new committee on the Negro Leagues that met in February and selected Satchel Paige.

title: Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1971
text: The museum planned to honor Paige and those who would follow in a special permanent exhibit outside the Hall of Fame but controversy about the nature of the honor began at the event announcing his election, February 9, and continued until the induction ceremonies six months later.

title: Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1971
text: At the latter event Paige was inducted to the Hall of Fame itself, the same as the major league figures.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: Dicen que Soy un Mujeriego ("They Say I am a Womanizer") is a 1949 Mexican comedy-drama film directed by Roberto Rodríguez.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: This Mexican film classic was made during the Golden Age of Mexican cinema.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: In this film, Mexican superstar, Pedro Infante co-starred with Golden Age Mexican super star Sara Garcia (“Mexico’s grandmother”) as Dona Rosa, as well as with Silvia Derbez as Flor and child star "La Tucita" María Eugenia Llamas (five years old at the time).

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: In this comedy, Pedro Infante is Sara Garcia’s (“Dona Rosa”) philandering grandson.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: Dona Rosa is a prominent rancher.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: She deeply loves Pedro, but is constantly trying to get him to behave – with no success.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: While Pedro is ever popular with the ladies, he has his eye on Flor (Silvia Derbez), the niece of a neighboring rancher.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: Flor flirts with him and plays him off against the disreputable saloon owner and town mayor, Pablo (Rodolfo Landa).

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: Pablo tricks orphan Tucita into believing she is Pedro's daughter as a way to ruin Pedro's chances with Flor.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: Everyone is quick to believe that Pedro is Tucita's father.

title: Dicen que soy mujeriego
text: However, in the end, the plot is revealed and Pedro and Flor marry.

title: Tim Burton
text: Timothy Walter Burton ( ; born August 25, 1958) is an American film director, producer, artist, writer, and animator.

title: Tim Burton
text: He is known for his dark, gothic, eccentric, and quirky fantasy films such as "Beetlejuice" (1988), "Edward Scissorhands" (1990), the animated musical "The Nightmare Before Christmas" (1993), the biographical film "Ed Wood" (1994), the horror fantasy "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), and later efforts such as "Corpse Bride" (2005), "" (2007), "Dark Shadows" (2012), and "Frankenweenie" (2012).

title: Tim Burton
text: He is also known for blockbusters such as the adventure comedy "Pee-wee's Big Adventure" (1985), the superhero films "Batman" (1989) and its first sequel "Batman Returns" (1992), the sci-fi film "Planet of the Apes" (2001), the fantasy drama "Big Fish" (2003), the musical adventure film "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (2005), and the fantasy film "Alice in Wonderland" (2010), which garnered a worldwide gross of over $1 billion.

title: Once Upon a Time in Vietnam
text: Once Upon a Time in Vietnam (Vietnamese: Lửa Phật ) is a 2013 Vietnamese action fantasy film directed by and starring Dustin Nguyen along with Roger Yuan.

title: Once Upon a Time in Vietnam
text: It was released on August 22, 2013.

title: Once Upon a Time in Vietnam
text: This is the first Vietnamese action fantasy film.

title: The Golden Voyage of Sinbad
text: The Golden Voyage of Sinbad is a 1973 fantasy film directed by Gordon Hessler and featuring stop motion effects by Ray Harryhausen.

title: The Golden Voyage of Sinbad
text: It is the second of three Sinbad films released by Colombia Pictures, the others being "The 7th Voyage of Sinbad" (1958) and "Sinbad and the Eye of the Tiger" (1977).

title: The Golden Voyage of Sinbad
text: The film stars John Phillip Law, Tom Baker, Takis Emmanuel, and Caroline Munro.

title: The Golden Voyage of Sinbad
text: It won the first Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film.

title: Mick Carter
text: Michael "Mick" Carter is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" played by Danny Dyer, making his first appearance in the show in the episode originally broadcast in the United Kingdom on 25 December 2013.

title: Mick Carter
text: Dyer's casting was announced on 1 October 2013 with that of his on-screen partner, Linda Carter, played by Kellie Bright.

title: Mick Carter
text: He is the son of established character Shirley Carter (Linda Henry) and a member of the Carter family.

title: Mick Carter
text: Mick immediately becomes the new landlord of The Queen Victoria public house (referred to as "The Vic"), bringing Linda, their son Johnny Carter (Sam Strike/Ted Reilly) and pet dog Lady Di with him.

title: Mick Carter
text: They are later joined by daughter Nancy Carter (Maddy Hill), son Lee Carter (Danny-Boy Hatchard) and other members of the extended family.

title: The Gatehouse, Monmouth
text: The Gatehouse, also known as The Gate House, is a public house located next to Monnow Bridge in Monmouth, Wales.

title: The Gatehouse, Monmouth
text: The pub was known as the Barley Mow until it changed its name in 1993.

title: The Gatehouse, Monmouth
text: It is the only public house in Monmouth located beside a river.

title: The Gatehouse, Monmouth
text: The pub has a restaurant area, seated balcony and a function room.

title: Linda Carter
text: Linda Bernadette Carter is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Kellie Bright.

title: Linda Carter
text: She first appeared on 19 December 2013 and her casting was announced alongside her on-screen partner, Mick Carter (Danny Dyer).

title: Linda Carter
text: Linda was introduced by new executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins as part of the Carter family.

title: Linda Carter
text: Linda became landlady of The Queen Victoria public house and moved there with her family from her mother's pub in Watford.

title: Linda Carter
text: Although never credited with the name, in a small number of episodes, the character is referred to as Linda Peacock.

title: Linda Carter
text: In May 2016, Bright announced that she was pregnant with her second child and that she would be taking maternity leave.

title: Linda Carter
text: Linda departed the series on 25 December 2016 although she made two separate guest appearances on 16 March and 30 June 2017.

title: Linda Carter
text: She returned full-time on 7 August.

title: Adam & Eve, Birmingham
text: The Adam & Eve is a former public house located on the corner of Bradford Street and Warner Street, in Deritend, Birmingham, England.

title: Adam & Eve, Birmingham
text: There had been a public house of this name in this location for at least 200 years.

title: Nancy Carter
text: Nancy Carter is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Maddy Hill.

title: Nancy Carter
text: Nancy's first appearance is in a combination of the show's 4775th and 4776th episodes, originally broadcast in the United Kingdom on 1 January 2014.

title: Nancy Carter
text: A member of the Carter family, Nancy is the daughter of Mick Carter (Danny Dyer) and Linda Carter (Kellie Bright).

title: Nancy Carter
text: Her storylines include relationships with Wayne Ladlow (Malachi Kirby), Dexter Hartman (Khali Best) and Tamwar Masood (Himesh Patel), coping with the aftermath of her mother's rape, suffering from epilepsy and a feud with her older brother Lee Carter (Danny-Boy Hatchard).

title: Nancy Carter
text: On 12 March 2016, it was announced that Hill would be leaving the show, with Nancy making her final appearance alongside Tamwar on 22 April 2016.

title: Fat Cat Brewery
text: The Fat Cat Brewery is a brewery located at the "Fat Cat Brewery Tap", Lawson Road, Norwich in the English county of Norfolk.

title: Fat Cat Brewery
text: The brewery is owned by Colin Keatley landlord of the "Fat Cat" public house twice winner of the CAMRA National Pub of the Year.

title: Hare and Billet
text: The Hare and Billet is a public house located in Blackheath, London, overlooking parts of Greenwich Park.

title: Hare and Billet
text: In the 18th century, the Hare and Billet was a coaching inn.

title: Hare and Billet
text: The pub is now part of the Capital Pub Company, which was purchased by Greene King in 2011.

title: Hare and Billet
text: The pub received media coverage in 2014 after a south London MP made a speech in the House of Commons claiming a condiment they served was a "parasitic copy" of another brand of Worcester Sauce, leading to a backlash that was nicknamed "Hendogate".

title: Whitney Dean
text: Whitney Carter (also Dean) is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Shona McGarty.

title: Whitney Dean
text: The character is the adoptive daughter of long-running character Bianca Jackson (Patsy Palmer), and was introduced in April when Palmer returned to the series after a six-year absence.

title: Whitney Dean
text: Whitney is described by executive producer Diederick Santer as both an equal to, and younger version of Bianca, and is the oldest of Bianca's four children.

title: Whitney Dean
text: Her storylines have revolved around her fractured family life, her sexual abuse by Bianca's partner Tony King (Chris Coghill), her sexual exploitation by Rob Grayson (Jody Latham), her marriage to Lee Carter (Danny-Boy Hatchard) and miscarrying his baby, surviving a bus crash, falling in love with her father-in-law Mick Carter (Danny Dyer) and becoming engaged to Woody Woodward (Lee Ryan).

title: Whitney Dean
text: McGarty was temporarily written out of "EastEnders" for four weeks in July 2012 because of her repeated lateness to work.

title: Whitney Dean
text: McGarty took an extended break from the show in 2017, with Whitney departing on 29 May, she returned on 31 July.

title: Square and Compass, Worth Matravers
text: The Square and Compass is a Grade II listed public house in Worth Matravers, Dorset.

title: Square and Compass, Worth Matravers
text: Built in the 18th century as a pair of cottages before becoming a public house, the Square and Compass got its name in 1830 from a landlord who had been a stonemason.

title: Square and Compass, Worth Matravers
text: The building includes a museum of fossils and other local artefacts and the pub is one of only nine nationally that has been included in every edition of CAMRA's good pub guide.

title: Shakespeare Public House, Bristol
text: The Shakespeare Public House (grid reference  ) is a historic public house situated at 66-70 Prince Street in Bristol, England.

title: Shakespeare Public House, Bristol
text: Originally built in 1725 by the Bristol builder John Strahan as a pair of attached Georgian-style houses, it was converted into a public house in 1777 at which time it supplied refreshment to dock workers at the adjoining port.

title: Shakespeare Public House, Bristol
text: It has been a grade II* listed building since 1959.

title: Brian Dennehy
text: Brian Manion Dennehy (born July 9, 1938) is an American actor of film, stage, and television.

title: Brian Dennehy
text: A winner of one Golden Globe, two Tony Awards and a recipient of six Primetime Emmy Award nominations, he gained initial recognition for his role as the antagonistic Sheriff Will Teasle in "First Blood" (1982).

title: Brian Dennehy
text: He has had numerous roles in films such as "Gorky Park, Silverado, Cocoon, F/X, Romeo + Juliet", and "Knight of Cups".

title: Blythe Danner
text: Blythe Katherine Danner (born February 3, 1943) is an American actress.

title: Blythe Danner
text: She won two Primetime Emmy Awards for Best Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her role as Izzy Huffstodt on "Huff" (2004–2006), and a Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play for her performance in "Butterflies Are Free" (1969–1972).

title: Blythe Danner
text: Danner was nominated for two Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series for portraying Marilyn Truman on "Will & Grace" (2001–2006), and the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie for her roles in "We Were the Mulvaneys" (2002) and "Back When We Were Grownups" (2004).

title: Blythe Danner
text: For the latter, she was also nominated for the Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Miniseries or Television Film.

title: John Lithgow
text: John Arthur Lithgow ( ; born October 19 , 1945) is an American actor, musician, singer, comedian, voice actor, and author.

title: John Lithgow
text: He has received two Tony Awards, six Emmy Awards, two Golden Globe Awards, three Screen Actors Guild Awards, an American Comedy Award, four Drama Desk Awards and has also been nominated for two Academy Awards and four Grammy Awards.

title: John Lithgow
text: Lithgow has received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and has been inducted into the American Theater Hall of Fame.

title: Al Pacino on stage and screen
text: Al Pacino is an American film and stage actor and director.

title: Al Pacino on stage and screen
text: He is the receipient of one Academy Award, one BAFTA Award, two Primetime Emmy Awards, two Tony Awards, and four Golden Globe Awards.

title: List of awards and nominations received by Lost
text: Lost is an American drama series that aired on ABC from September 22, 2004 until May 23, 2010.

title: List of awards and nominations received by Lost
text: It has been nominated for a variety of different awards, including 54 Primetime Emmy Awards (eleven wins), 48 Saturn Awards (thirteen wins), 33 Teen Choice Awards, 17 Television Critics Association Awards (four wins), 12 Golden Reel Awards (five wins), eight Satellite Awards (one win), seven Golden Globe Awards (one win), six Producers Guild of America Awards (one win), six Writers Guild of America Awards (one win), five Directors Guild of America Awards, two NAACP Image Awards (one win), two Screen Actors Guild Awards (one win), and one BAFTA Award.

title: List of awards and nominations received by Lost
text: Amongst the wins for the series are a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series, a Golden Globe Award for Best Television Series – Drama, a Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series, and a Peabody Award.

title: Al Pacino
text: Alfredo James Pacino ( ; born April 25, 1940) is an American actor of stage and screen, filmmaker, and screenwriter.

title: Al Pacino
text: Pacino has had a career spanning over five decades, during which time he has received numerous accolades and honors both competitive and honorary, among them an Academy Award, two Tony Awards, two Primetime Emmy Awards, a British Academy Film Award, four Golden Globe Awards, the Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Film Institute, the Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award, and the National Medal of Arts.

title: Al Pacino
text: He is also one of few performers to have won a competitive Oscar, an Emmy and a Tony Award for acting, dubbed the "Triple Crown of Acting".

title: Betty Suarez
text: Beatriz U. "Betty" Suarez is the protagonist of the American comedy-drama series "Ugly Betty".

title: Betty Suarez
text: She is portrayed by America Ferrera, who won a 2007 Golden Globe and 2007 SAG award for her portrayal of the character, as well as the Outstanding Actress in a Comedy award for the role at the 59th Primetime Emmy Awards and was nominated again in the same category at the 60th Primetime Emmy Awards.

title: Betty Suarez
text: AOL named her one of the 100 Most Memorable Female TV Characters.

title: Laura Linney
text: Laura Leggett Linney (born February 5, 1964) is an American actress and singer.

title: Laura Linney
text: She is the recipient of several awards, including two Golden Globe Awards and four Primetime Emmy Awards.

title: Laura Linney
text: She has also been nominated for three Academy Awards and four Tony Awards.

title: 65th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards
text: The 65th Annual Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards ceremony was held on September 15, 2013, at the Nokia Theatre in Downtown Los Angeles.

title: 65th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards
text: The ceremony was held in conjunction with the annual Primetime Emmy Awards and is presented in recognition of technical and other similar achievements in American television programming, including guest acting roles.

title: 65th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards
text: The ceremony was highlighted by 8 Emmy wins for the HBO film "Behind the Candelabra", as well as Bob Newhart's win for a guest appearance on "The Big Bang Theory", his first Emmy win in a TV career spanning over 5 decades.

title: 65th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards
text: The ceremony was taped to air on Saturday, September 21, 2013, on FXX, one night before the live 65th Primetime Emmy Awards telecast on CBS.

title: Elisabeth Moss
text: Elisabeth Singleton Moss (born July 24, 1982) is an American film, stage, and television actor.

title: Elisabeth Moss
text: She is known for her roles as Zoey Bartlet, the youngest daughter of President Josiah Bartlet, on the NBC television series "The West Wing" (1999–2006); Peggy Olson, secretary-turned-copywriter, on the AMC series "Mad Men" (2007–2015), which earned her six Emmy Awards nominations and a Golden Globe nomination; Det. Robin Griffin in the BBC miniseries "Top of the Lake" (2013, 2017), which won her a Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Miniseries or TV Film; and Offred on the Hulu series "The Handmaid's Tale", for which she won the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series and the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series, as producer.

title: Walkers (law firm)
text: Walkers is a Cayman Islands based offshore law firm.

title: Walkers (law firm)
text: Although the firm now has offices in a number of jurisdictions, over half its staff remain based in the Cayman Islands.

title: Walkers (law firm)
text: Walkers (law firm) set up an branch in 15/F, Alexandra House, Hong Kong.

title: Cayman Islands national rugby sevens team
text: The Cayman Islands national rugby sevens team is a minor national rugby sevens side.

title: Cayman Islands national rugby sevens team
text: The Cayman Islands has competed at the Commonwealth Sevens.

title: Cayman Islands national rugby sevens team
text: They made their debut at the Hong Kong Sevens in 2016 making them the 60th team to play at Hong Kong.

title: Anthony Travers
text: Anthony Travers, OBE was the Chairman of the Board of Cayman Finance from 2009 to 2011.

title: Anthony Travers
text: Travers is also the Chairman of the Cayman Islands Stock Exchange and former Senior Partner and Managing Partner of international law firm Maples and Calder.

title: Anthony Travers
text: He has over thirty years experience in all aspects of Cayman Islands law, particularly mutual funds, structured finance, insurance and private client, and has throughout advised Government on the development of Cayman Islands legislation.

title: Carey Olsen
text: Carey Olsen is a market leading offshore law firm with offices in the British Virgin Islands, Cape Town, Cayman Islands, Guernsey, Hong Kong, Jersey, London and Singapore advising on British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Guernsey and Jersey law.

title: Phoenix Television
text: Phoenix Satellite Television Holdings Ltd or Phoenix Television is a Hong Kong–based, Cayman Islands registered Mandarin and Cantonese-language television broadcaster that serves the Chinese mainland and Hong Kong along with other markets with substantial Chinese viewers.

title: Phoenix Television
text: It has six different television channels, including Phoenix InfoNews Channel, Phoenix Chinese Channel, Phoenix Movies Channel, and Phoenix Hong Kong Channel.

title: Phoenix Television
text: Phoenix Television provides news, information, and entertainment programmes.

title: Cayman Enterprise City
text: Cayman Enterprise City is a special economic zone located in the Cayman Islands.

title: Cayman Enterprise City
text: It is government initiative that has been outsourced to Cayman Enterprise City, a privately owned development company.

title: Cayman Enterprise City
text: To facilitate the development of special economic zones in the Cayman Islands, special economic zones laws were enacted in September 2011 and February 2012.

title: Cayman Enterprise City
text: The government established the Special Economic Zone Authority ("SEZA") as the licensing and regulatory body.

title: Cayman Islands Open 2011
text: The Cayman Islands Open 2011 is the women's edition of the 2011 Cayman Islands Open, which is a tournament of the WSA World Series event Gold (Prize money: $68,500).

title: Cayman Islands Open 2011
