title: Environmental policy in China
text: Environmental policy in China is set by the National People's Congress and managed by the Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China.

title: Environmental policy in China
text: The Center for American Progress has described China's environmental policy as similar to that of the United States before 1970.

title: Environmental policy in China
text: That is, the central government issues fairly strict regulations, but the actual monitoring and enforcement is largely undertaken by local governments that have greater interest in economic growth.

title: Environmental policy in China
text: The environmental work of non-governmental forces, such as lawyers, journalists, and non-governmental organizations, is limited by government regulations.

title: Environmental policy in China
text: Under the Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China, the Department of Policies, Laws and Regulations is in charge of establishing and strengthening basic laws and policies such as environmental laws, administrative policies and economical regulations.

title: Environmental policy in China
text: It is also responsible for the development of national environmental protection policy and macro strategy.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: The Basic Laws of Israel (Hebrew: חוקי היסוד‎ ‎ , "ħuqey ha-yesod") are the constitutional laws of the State of Israel.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: These laws deal with the formation and role of the principal institutions of the state, and with the relations between the state's authorities.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: They also protect civil rights, although some of these rights were earlier protected at common law by the Supreme Court of Israel.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: The Basic Laws are intended to be draft chapters of the future Israeli constitution, postponed since 1950, and act as a "de facto" constitution until their future incorporation into a formal, unitary, written constitution.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: Israel as of 2017 functions according to an uncodified constitution consisting of both material constitutional law, based upon cases and precedents, common law, and the provisions of these formal statutes.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: The Basic Laws do not cover all constitutional issues, and there is no deadline set for the completion of the process of merging them into one comprehensive constitution.

title: Basic Laws of Israel
text: There is no clear rule determining the precedence of Basic Rules over regular legislation, and in many cases this issue is left to interpretation by the judicial system.

title: Katherine Kath
text: Katherine Kath (11 August 1920 – 17 November 2012) was a French prima ballerina at the Theatre du Chatelet in Paris, who became an actress after suffering from an injury which destroyed her chances of continuing her career.

title: Katherine Kath
text: She was born Lily Faess in Berck, Pas-de-Calais, France, where she also died, at age 92 in 2012 from undisclosed causes.

title: Jean de Chastelet
text: Jean du Chatelet, also known as Baron de Beausoleil and Auffembach (1578, Brabant – c. 1645, The Bastille, Paris), was a mineralogist, mining engineer and dowser.

title: Émilie du Châtelet
text: Gabrielle Émilie Le Tonnelier de Breteuil, Marquise Du Châtelet (] ; 17 December 1706 – 10 September 1749) was a French natural philosopher, mathematician, physicist, and author during the early 1730s until her untimely death due to childbirth in 1749.

title: Émilie du Châtelet
text: Her most recognized achievement is her translation of and commentary on Isaac Newton's book "Principia" containing basic laws of physics.

title: Émilie du Châtelet
text: The translation, published posthumously in 1759, is still considered the standard French translation today.

title: Émilie du Châtelet
text: Her commentary includes a profound contribution to Newtonian mechanics—the postulate of an additional conservation law for total energy, of which kinetic energy of motion is one element.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
text: The Physics of Superheroes is a popular science book by physics professor and long-time comic-book fan James Kakalios.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
text: First published in 2005, it explores the basic laws of physics.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
text: Kakalios does not set out to show where the world of superheroes contradicts modern science, granting the heroes one or more "miracle exceptions" from natural law.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
text: Instead, he focuses on examples of comic book scenes that can be used to understand the diverse laws of physics from an unusual angle, such as Gwen Stacy's death and Ant-Man's ability to punch his way out of a paper bag.

title: The Physics of Superheroes
text: Kakalios relates these elements of comic books to principles of physics, such as levers and torque, and in this way covers diverse topics, from mechanics to the quantum world.

title: Ethiopian Legal Information Website
text: The Ethiopian Legal Information Website is an online database of laws in Ethiopia.

title: Ethiopian Legal Information Website
text: It aims to provide the public, researchers, professors, law firms and legal professionals access to the basic laws on the web and other digital formats.

title: Ethiopian Legal Information Website
text: It was developed by Mekelle University Law Faculty in Ethiopia in cooperation with the Non-Western Law Department of Ghent University in Belgium.

title: Ethiopian Legal Information Website
text: While it contains only the laws of the federal government at this moment, it plans adding state, regional and other laws.

title: Laws of association
text: The principal laws of association are contiguity, repetition, attention, pleasure-pain, and similarity.

title: Laws of association
text: The basic laws were formulated by Aristotle in approximately 300 B.C. and by John Locke in the seventeenth century.

title: Laws of association
text: Both philosophers taught that the mind at birth is a blank slate and that all knowledge has to be acquired by learning.

title: Laws of association
text: The laws they taught still make up the backbone of modern learning theory.

title: 12 basic principles of animation
text: Disney's Twelve Basic Principles of Animation were introduced by the Disney animators Ollie Johnston and Frank Thomas in their 1981 book "".

title: 12 basic principles of animation
text: Johnston and Thomas in turn based their book on the work of the leading Disney animators from the 1930s onwards, and their effort to produce more realistic animations.

title: 12 basic principles of animation
text: The main purpose of the principles was to produce an illusion of characters adhering to the basic laws of physics, but they also dealt with more abstract issues, such as emotional timing and character appeal.

title: Constitution of Israel
text: The State of Israel has an unwritten constitution.

title: Constitution of Israel
text: Instead of a formal written constitution, and in accordance with the Harari Decision (החלטת הררי) of 13 June 1950 adopted during the Israeli Constituent Assembly, the State of Israel has enacted several Basic Laws of Israel dealing with the government arrangements and with human rights.

title: Constitution of Israel
text: The Israeli Supreme Court President Aharon Barak ruled that the Basic Laws should be considered the state's constitution, and that became the common approach throughout his tenure (1995-2006).

title: Constitution of Israel
text: Opponents of this approach include Barak's colleague, Judge of the Supreme Court Mishael Cheshin.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: Something for the Rest of Us is the ninth studio album by American rock band Goo Goo Dolls.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: It was released on August 28, 2010 in Australia and on August 31 in North America through Warner Bros.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: Records.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: The recording process took place during the spring to fall of 2009 in the GCR Audio studio in Buffalo and Paramount Studios as well as "the Ark" in Los Angeles, with producer Tim Palmer.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: A single had been originally slated to be released in November 2009 with an album release in February 2010, but the band went back into the studio in January 2010.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: According to lead singer and guitarist John Rzeznik, this was done to make further improvements on what they had previously thought had been a finished record.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: Several producers were brought in to assist on the production process, including Butch Vig, John Fields, Paul David Hager and Rob Cavallo.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: "Something for the Rest of Us" is the third Goo Goo Dolls studio album that Cavallo has produced ("Dizzy Up the Girl" and "Gutterflower").

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: When asked about the length of time between albums, Rzeznik admitted it was a mix of songwriting issues as well as taking time out for personal reasons; "I wanted to really dig deep and there are a million songs I threw away, like, “Nah, it's not good enough.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: I wanna do something different.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: I wanna do something better, go deeper.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: I also wanted to have a life with my girlfriend for a while.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: I owed it to her to spend some time with her and be normal and be in one place.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: That was kind of important."

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: In one of the Ustream sessions, Robby revealed that the album would have twelve songs and "Real" is not among them.

title: Something for the Rest of Us
text: In late May, John announced that "Home" would be the first single and was released onto radio and iTunes stores on June 8, 2010.

title: Waiting for the Rest of It
text: Waiting for the Rest of It is an EP released by the Goo Goo Dolls in 2010 for Warner Bros.

title: Waiting for the Rest of It
text: Records.

title: Waiting for the Rest of It

title: Waiting for the Rest of It

title: Hold Me Up
text: Hold Me Up is the third studio album by American rock band Goo Goo Dolls, released by Metal Blade Records in 1990.

title: Hold Me Up
text: This is considered the band's true major-label debut, as previous albums were organized by the band themselves.

title: Hold Me Up
text: It features their first single, "There You Are," which became their first music video as well.

title: Hold Me Up
text: Some consider this album the Goo Goo Dolls' last true "garage rock" album.

title: Hold Me Up
text: Also, this marks the beginning of John Rzeznik's emergence as the band's principal lead vocalist.

text: is the eponymous debut studio album by American rock band Goo Goo Dolls.

title: Goo Goo Dolls (album)
text: All of the songs are sung by bassist Robby Takac, who was originally the band's lead vocalist.

title: Goo Goo Dolls (album)
text: It is the hardest to find of all the band's studio albums, being only an LP, out of print, and not in wide circulation to begin with.

title: Goo Goo Dolls (album)
text: The song "I'm Addicted" was the only song from "Goo Goo Dolls" represented on the band's 2001 compilation album, "What I Learned About Ego, Opinion, Art & Commerce".

title: Goo Goo Dolls (album)
text: The song "Torn Apart" was also included on the compilation album "Volume Two", which consisted of other album tracks, b-sides and rarities.

title: Notbroken

title: Notbroken
text: It is the second single from their ninth studio album, "Something for the Rest of Us", which was released on August 31, 2010.

title: Notbroken
text: It was announced on Goo Goo Dolls' official website that "Notbroken" would be the second single from the new album.

title: Goo Goo Dolls
text: The Goo Goo Dolls are an American rock band formed in 1985 in Buffalo, New York, by vocalist and guitarist John Rzeznik, vocalist and bassist Robby Takac, and drummer George Tutuska.

title: Goo Goo Dolls
text: Mike Malinin was the band's drummer from January 1995 until December 27, 2013 (but not made an official member until 1998).

title: Goo Goo Dolls
text: Although renowned for their commercially successful 1998 single "Iris", they have had several other notable and popular singles including "Name" and "Naked" from 1995's "A Boy Named Goo". "

title: Goo Goo Dolls
text: Slide", "Black Balloon", "Dizzy", and "Broadway" from 1998's "Dizzy Up the Girl", "Here Is Gone" from 2002's "Gutterflower", "Better Days", "Give a Little Bit", and "Stay with You" from 2006's "Let Love In" (although "Give A Little Bit" was originally released on the 2004 live CD/DVD album ""), and "Home" from 2010's "Something for the Rest of Us".

title: Goo Goo Dolls
text: The Goo Goo Dolls have had 19 top ten singles on various charts, and have sold more than 12 million albums worldwide.

text: The tour is in support of their studio albums "Baptized" and "Magnetic".

title: Daughtry/Goo Goo Dolls Summer Tour

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004 is a live album by the American rock band Goo Goo Dolls.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: It includes a CD and a DVD, showing their concert in Buffalo, New York from July 4, 2004.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: The concert included performances of all their major hits, including "Iris", "Name", and "Slide".

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: There are nineteen (19) songs on the DVD total, plus a studio version of their Supertramp cover, "Give A Little Bit" on the CD.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: The concert was shot and recorded in downtown Buffalo on Niagara Square in front of Buffalo City Hall.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: As for the concert itself, the performance was enigmatic; garnering comparisons to the Talking Heads' "Stop Making Sense" from members of the band's crew.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: Over 60,000 fans attended the performance, braving a torrential downpour.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: The rain cleared in time for the Goo Goo Dolls to start the show, but during their performance of "January Friend", the rain began pouring down again, harder than before.

title: Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004
text: The band played on, finishing the set, despite being pulled off stage briefly for a safety precaution and skipping three songs* that were on the original set list.

title: ITunes Originals – Goo Goo Dolls

title: Joseph Vitale (politician)
text: Joseph F. Vitale (born November 10, 1954) is an American Democratic Party politician, who has been serving in the New Jersey State Senate since 1998, where he represents the 19th Legislative District.

title: Joseph Vitale (politician)
text: He is also the former Mayor of Woodbridge Township, New Jersey, having been elected by the Township Council in July 2006 to fill a temporary vacancy, following the death of Mayor Frank Pelzman.

title: Joseph Vitale (politician)
text: Senator Vitale came to the Senate in 1998 filling a vacancy created when Jim McGreevey stepped down from his seat as part of his ultimately unsuccessful bid for election as Governor of New Jersey in 1997.

title: United States Senate elections in Illinois, 2010
text: The 2010 United States Senate elections in Illinois took place on November 2, 2010.

title: United States Senate elections in Illinois, 2010
text: There were two ballot items for the same seat: a routine one, to fill the Class 3 seat beginning with the 112th United States Congress beginning on January 3, 2011, and a special item, to fill that seat for the final weeks of the 111th Congress, replacing the temporary appointment of Roland Burris to the vacancy created by Barack Obama's election to the presidency.

title: Brian DelGrosso
text: Brian DelGrosso (born c. 1973) is a former state representative in the U.S. state of Colorado.

title: Brian DelGrosso
text: Del Grosso, a small business owner, was originally appointed to office by a Republican Party vacancy committee in August 2009 to fill the vacancy created by Don Marostica's resignation.

title: Brian DelGrosso
text: DelGrosso represented House District 51, which encompasses the city of Loveland.

title: Brian DelGrosso
text: He was subsequently elected to the office in the 2010 election, and then re-elected in the 2012 and 2014 elections.

title: Brian DelGrosso
text: Term limited, he did not seek re-election in 2016, and he left office in early January, 2016.

title: Detroit mayoral election, 2009
text: The Detroit mayoral elections of 2009 took place on May 5, 2009, with a primary on February 24, 2009 to fill the vacancy created when Kwame Kilpatrick resigned as mayor.

title: Charlotte mayoral election, 2015
text: The 2015 Charlotte mayoral election took place on November 3, 2015, to elect the Mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Charlotte mayoral election, 2015
text: Mayoral elections in Charlotte are biennial, with the winner being sworn-in in December.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: Jane Marum Roush (born September 24, 1956) is a Virginia lawyer and Judge who served as an interim Justice of the Supreme Court of Virginia.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: On July 27, 2015, Governor Terry McAuliffe announced his appointment of Roush to fill the vacancy created by the retirement of Justice LeRoy F. Millette, Jr. effective July 31, 2015.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: Under the Constitution of Virginia, this original interim appointment was to expire thirty days after the commencement of the next session of the Virginia General Assembly, unless the legislature elected her to a full twelve-year term.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: On August 17, 2015, the General Assembly convened in special session but failed to elect anyone to the full twelve-year term before the Senate of Virginia purported to adjourn sine die.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: The Constitution prohibits one chamber of the legislature from adjourning for more than three days without the consent of the other chamber.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: The Governor claims that this provision applies only to regular sessions of the General Assembly; the House of Delegates and most Senate Republicans claim it applies to special sessions as well, and that the Senate's adjournment was invalid because the House did not consent.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: Because there is legal uncertainty about whether the legislature was still in session, it is unclear whether the governor could fill the vacancy created when Justice Roush's original interim appointment expired on September 16, 2015.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: Nevertheless, the governor announced his view that the legislature was not in session and purported to reappoint her for a second interim term.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: Whether this second interim appointment was valid or invalid has not been determined.

title: Jane Marum Roush
text: If valid, the second interim appointment expired on February 12, 2016, thirty days after the regular session of the General Assembly began on January 13, because the legislature did not elect her to a full twelve-year term.

title: United Kingdom local elections, 2013
text: The 2013 United Kingdom local elections took place on Thursday 2 May 2013.

title: United Kingdom local elections, 2013
text: Elections were held in 35 English councils: all 27 non-metropolitan county councils and eight unitary authorities, and in one Welsh unitary authority.

title: United Kingdom local elections, 2013

title: United Kingdom local elections, 2013

title: Jon Bramnick
text: Jon M. Bramnick (born February 24, 1953) is an American Republican Party politician, who has served in the New Jersey General Assembly since 2003, representing the 21st legislative district.

title: Jon Bramnick

title: Jon Bramnick
text: He was appointed to the Assembly in 2003 to fill the unexpired term of the vacancy created upon the selection of Thomas Kean, Jr. to fill an unexpired New Jersey Senate term.

title: Jon Bramnick
text: He was elected to a full two-year term later that year and was re-elected in 2005, 2007, 2009, 2011, 2013 and 2015.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: This is a list of municipal elections held in the city of Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: Elections for mayor were held annually until the 1923 election, when the election was for a two-year term.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: From the 1971 election, the mayoral term was three years.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: Elections for councillors and aldermen were held annually until the 1914 election, when the terms switched to two-year overlapping terms, with half of each council up for election each year.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: From the 1971 election, the aldermanic elections lined up fully with the mayoral elections, and were also for three-year terms.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: In 1976, the number of wards expanded to 14 (current number) with one alderman representing each ward for three years.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: On December 14, 2010, council voted to change the title to "councillor", which took effect in the October 2013 election.

title: List of Calgary municipal elections
text: In 2012 the Local Authorities Election Act was amended to increase the term length of the mayor and councillors to 4 years.

title: United States Senate election in Vermont, 1934
text: The 1934 United States Senate election in Vermont took place on November 6, 1934.

title: United States Senate election in Vermont, 1934
text: Incumbent Republican Warren Austin successfully ran for re-election to a full term in the United States Senate, defeating Democratic candidate Fred C. Martin.

title: United States Senate election in Vermont, 1934
text: Austin was elected in a 1931 special election to replace Frank C. Partridge, who was appointed to fill the vacancy created by the death of Frank L. Greene.

title: Luke Hubbins

text: He can play either as a right back or as a central midfielder.

title: Atiqur Rahman Meshu
text: Atiqur Rahman Meshu (Bengali: আতিকুর রহমান মিশু ; born 26 August 1988 ) is a Bangladeshi footballer who plays as a defender for Brothers Union and the Bangladesh national football team.

title: Atiqur Rahman Meshu
text: He plays either a centre back or right back.

title: Atiqur Rahman Meshu
text: In 2010 AFC Challenge Cup, his stunning diving header saw the Tajiks face their first ever defeat in history against Bangladesh.

title: Martin Linnes
text: Martin Linnes (born 20 September 1991) is a Norwegian professional footballer who plays as a right back for Turkish club Galatasaray.

title: Martin Linnes
text: As a versatile player, he also played as a left back, central midfielder, right midfielder and right winger.

title: Ibrahim Tall
text: Ibrahim Tall (born 23 June 1981 in Aubervilliers, Paris) is a Senegalese international footballer who plays for FC Stade Nyonnais.

title: Ibrahim Tall
text: He is a versatile defender capable of playing either right back or centre back.

title: Michalis Bakakis
text: Michalis Bakakis (Greek: Μιχάλης Μπακάκης ; born 18 March 1991) is a professional footballer, currently playing for AEK Athens.

title: Michalis Bakakis
text: Bakakis can play either right back or as a right midfielder.

title: Bjørn Helge Riise
text: Bjørn Helge Semundseth Riise (born 21 June 1983 in Ålesund) is a Norwegian professional footballer.

title: Bjørn Helge Riise
text: He currently plays for Aalesund.

title: Bjørn Helge Riise
text: Riise plays either a central midfielder or a right winger, and has earned 35 international caps for Norway.

title: Bjørn Helge Riise
text: He played for Fulham of the Premier League from July 2009 to August 2012.

title: Bjørn Helge Riise
text: He is the younger brother of former Liverpool and Fulham player John Arne Riise, also a Norwegian international.

title: Leigh Broxham
text: Leigh Michael Broxham (born 13 January 1988) is an Australian professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for Melbourne Victory in the A-League.

title: Leigh Broxham
text: A natural defensive midfielder, Broxham can also play as an attacking midfielder, central midfielder, centre back, left back or right back.

title: Bitið fast í vitið
text: Bitið fast í vitið (roughly "Bite Hard In Your Mind" in Icelandic) is the début EP of Icelander punk/pop group Tappi Tíkarrass .

title: Bitið fast í vitið
text: It was released in late-1982 on the Spor label, within a year of the band's formation in September 1981 – led by vocalists Björk and Eyþór Arnalds .

title: Bitið fast í vitið
text: This was the band's most punk-oriented release and contains five tracks, featuring one in English, "London".

title: Folk rock
text: Folk rock is a music genre combining elements of folk music and rock music.

title: Folk rock
text: In its earliest and narrowest sense, the term referred to a genre that arose in the United States and the United Kingdom around the mid-1960s.

title: Folk rock
text: The genre emerged from bands such as the Beatles, the Searchers, and the Animals in the UK, and Bob Dylan and the Byrds in the US, who played traditional folk music and songs with rock instrumentation.

title: Folk rock
text: The term "folk rock" is first noted as being used by the U.S. music press in June 1965 to describe the Byrds' music; the band's debut album was released the same month.

title: Rave music
text: Rave music may either refer to the late 1980s/early 1990s genres of house, breakbeat, acid house, techno and hardcore techno, which were the first genres of music to be played at rave parties, or to any other genre of electronic dance music (EDM) that may be played at a rave.

title: Rave music
text: The genre "rave", also known as hardcore by early ravers, first appeared amongst the UK "acid" movement during the late 1980s at warehouse parties and other underground venues, as well as on UK pirate radio stations.

title: Rave music
text: The genre would develop into oldschool hardcore, which lead onto newer forms of rave music such as drum and bass and 2-step, as well as other hardcore techno genres, such as gabber, hardstyle and happy hardcore.

title: Rave music
text: Rave music is usually presented in a DJ mix set, although live performances are not uncommon.

title: Kidandali
text: Kidandali is a stylistic music genre and one of only 2 music genres native to Uganda, the other being Kadongo Kamu.

title: Kidandali
text: Kidandali is a word from the Ganda language which in translation can mean "local party" or "celebration".

title: Kidandali
text: Music concerts and traditional wedding ceremonies (kwanjula) are examples of such "bidandali".

title: Kidandali
text: The music itself is given this name because most times it is the kind of music played or performed at such local parties and functions.

title: Kidandali
text: Some other sources and commentators refer to the genre alternatively as "Band music" while others refer to it as "Afrobeat".

title: Miranda (album)
text: Miranda is the only studio album by Icelandic punk band Tappi Tíkarrass.

title: Miranda (album)
text: It was released on December 23, 1983 through Gramm.

title: Disco polo
text: Disco polo is a musical genre of popular music that is dance music, created in Poland in the late 1980s, initially known as "sidewalks music" ("muzyka chodnikowa").

title: Disco polo
text: This trend, also known as city folklore music, was popular in the mid-late 1990s, with its peak taking place around 1995–1997.

title: Disco polo
text: Later observed a gradual decline in the popularity led to the temporary collapse in the early twenty-first century.

title: Disco polo
text: Disco polo have enjoyed a renaissance of popularity in late 2007.

title: Disco polo
text: Language Dictionary Polish Publishing PWN defines the genre as a Polish variant of disco music, with simple melodies.

title: Disco polo
text: It is derived from disco, Euro disco contemporary folk music influenced by Italo disco and Polish folk songs (specifically, the vulgarized subgenre of which is mostly played at weddings and feasts).

title: Nýtt líf
text: Nýtt Líf ( , English: "New Life") is an Icelandic film directed by Þráinn Bertelsson and released in 1983.

title: Nýtt líf
text: The film is a comedy shot in the Westman Islands and stars Eggert Þorleifsson and Karl Ágúst Úlfsson, among others.

title: Nýtt líf
text: The music features several musicians including the band Tappi Tíkarrass (of which Björk was a member), which contributed the songs "Sperglar" and "Kukl" (a.k.a. "Seiður").

title: Chamber jazz
text: Chamber jazz is a genre of jazz involving small, acoustic-based ensembles where group interplay is important.

title: Chamber jazz
text: It is influenced aesthetically by musical neoclassicism and is often influenced by classical forms of Western music as well as non-Western music or culture.

title: Chamber jazz
text: That stated, in many cases the influence is traditional Celtic music, , or Latin American music instead.

title: Chamber jazz
text: The genre primarily began in Europe so significant neoclassical composers of Europe, like Igor Stravinsky, are important in it.

title: Chamber jazz
text: The German ECM Records also played a role in it beginning in the late 1960s.

title: Chamber jazz
text: It is also noted for using instruments not normally associated with jazz.

title: Chamber jazz
text: For example, chamber jazz will make use of the oboe, mandolin, cymbalum, or the tabla.

title: Steeltown (band)
text: Steeltown were an Australian band based in the city of Brisbane who performed in the 90s a genre of synth, rock, pop and produced their greatest top forty chart hit with the song 'Hero' which was released in September 1991.

title: Steeltown (band)
text: They notably sold more recordings than any other band of the time based in the state of Queensland.

title: Steeltown (band)
text: (the video and a live performance can be seen on YouTube).

title: Steeltown (band)
text: The group members were Andy Richmond vocals, Peter Howard keyboards, Terry Gidman drums and Kate Richmond vocals and percussion and Reece Speceis Lead Guitar.

title: Steeltown (band)
text: The band were formed from the remnant members of a Scottish group called the Technicians who migrated to Australia in the 80s and who also attained top 40 status with their music releases, Hot for Love, Clockwork Clown and Sodier of Fortune through record companies Powderworks, EMI and BMG, and were published by MMA which was owned by legendary rock outfit INXS.

title: Tappi Tíkarrass
text: Tappi Tíkarrass was an Icelandic punk band which added elements of funk, rock and jazz to their music, marking a difference from other traditional bands at that time.

title: Tappi Tíkarrass
text: The band is also considered the first serious music project of now renowned singer Björk Guðmundsdóttir.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: Counter-Strike (also known as Half-Life: Counter-Strike) is a first-person shooter video game developed by Valve Corporation.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: It was initially developed and released as a "Half-Life" modification by Minh "Gooseman" Le and Jess Cliffe in 1999, before Le and Cliffe were hired and the game's intellectual property acquired.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: "Counter-Strike" was released by Valve on the Microsoft Windows platform in 2000.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: The game spawned a franchise, and is the first installment in the "Counter-Strike" series.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: Several remakes and Ports of "Counter-Strike" have been released on the Xbox console, as well as OS X and Linux.

title: Counter-Strike (video game)
text: It is sometimes referred to as Counter-Strike 1.6 to distinguish it from other titles of the series, 1.6 being the final major software update the game received.

title: Fez (video game)
text: Fez (stylized as FEZ) is an indie puzzle-platform video game developed by Polytron Corporation and published by Trapdoor.

title: Fez (video game)
text: The player-character Gomez receives a fez that reveals his two-dimensional (2D) world to be one of four sides of a three-dimensional (3D) world.

title: Fez (video game)
text: The player rotates between these four 2D views to realign platforms and solve the game's puzzles.

title: Fez (video game)
text: The object of the game is to collect cubes and cube fragments to restore order to the universe.

title: Portal 2
text: Portal 2 is a 2011 first-person puzzle-platform video game developed and published by Valve Corporation.

title: Portal 2
text: It is the sequel to "Portal" (2007) and was released on April 19, 2011, for Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360.

title: Portal 2
text: The retail versions of the game are distributed by Electronic Arts while online distribution of the Microsoft Windows, Mac OS X and Linux versions is handled by Valve's content delivery service Steam.

title: Portal 2
text: "Portal 2" was announced on March 5, 2010, following a week-long alternate reality game based on new patches to the original game.

title: Portal 2
text: Before the game's release on Steam, the company released the Potato Sack, a second multi-week alternate reality game, involving 13 independently developed titles which culminated in a distributed computing spoof to release "Portal 2" several hours early.

title: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative
text: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative is a 2014 first-person puzzle-platform video game developed by the Aperture Tag Team.

title: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative
text: Originally made as a modification of the Valve Corporation's "Portal" series, it was officially approved for sale by Valve and released on the software distribution platform Steam on July 15, 2014.

title: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative
text: The game lacks the iconic portal gun of the series and instead utilizes a newly created paint gun that fires two kinds of gel with different properties.

title: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative
text: The game features new characters and voice acting, along with twenty-seven levels and a co-op mode that also includes a level editor.

title: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast
text: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast is an additional level for the 2004 first-person shooter video game "Half-Life 2".

title: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast
text: Developed by Valve Corporation, it was released on October 27, 2005, through the Steam content delivery service as a free download to owners of the Microsoft Windows version of "Half-Life 2".

title: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast
text: "Lost Coast" serves as a technology demonstration, specifically showcasing the high-dynamic-range rendering implemented in the Source engine.

title: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast
text: The level was designed with a variety of appropriate environments to emphasize these effects.

title: Half-Life 2: Lost Coast
text: In addition, "Lost Coast" was the first video game developed by Valve to allow developers to explain various elements of design as the player progresses through the level.

title: Portal (video game)
text: Portal is a puzzle-platform video game developed and published by Valve Corporation.

title: Portal (video game)
text: It was released in a bundle package called "The Orange Box" for Microsoft Windows, Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in 2007.

title: Portal (video game)
text: The game has since been ported to other systems, including OS X, Linux, and Android.

title: Team Fortress 2
text: Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is a team-based multiplayer first-person shooter video game developed and published by Valve Corporation.

title: Team Fortress 2
text: It is the sequel to the 1996 mod "Team Fortress" for "Quake" and its 1999 remake, "Team Fortress Classic".

title: Team Fortress 2
text: It was released as part of the video game bundle "The Orange Box" in October 2007 for Microsoft Windows and the Xbox 360.

title: Team Fortress 2
text: A PlayStation 3 version followed in December 2007.

title: Team Fortress 2
text: The game was released for Windows as a standalone entry in April 2008, and was updated to support OS X in June 2010 and Linux in February 2013.

title: Team Fortress 2
text: It is distributed online through Valve's digital retailer Steam, with retail distribution being handled by Electronic Arts.

title: Portal (series)
text: Portal is a series of first-person puzzle-platform video games developed by Valve Corporation.

title: Portal (series)
text: Set in the "Half-Life" universe, the two main games in the series, "Portal" (2007) and "Portal 2" (2011), center on a woman, Chell, forced to undergo a series of tests within the Aperture Science Enrichment Center by a malicious artificial intelligence computer, GLaDOS, that controls the facility.

title: Portal (series)
text: Each test involves using the "Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device" - the "portal gun" - that creates a human-sized wormhole-like connection between nearly any two flat surfaces.

title: Portal (series)
text: The player-character or objects in the game world may move through portals, their momentum conserved.

title: Portal (series)
text: This allows complex "flinging" maneuvers to be used to cross wide gaps or perform other feats to reach the exit for each test chamber.

title: Portal (series)
text: A number of other mechanics, such as lasers, light bridges, tractor funnels, and turrets, exist to aid or hinder the player's goal to reach the exit.

title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
text: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is a third-person action-adventure puzzle-platform video game developed and published by Ubisoft.

title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
text: First revealed in March 2003, it was released across Game Boy Advance, PlayStation 2, GameCube, Xbox and Microsoft Windows in November 2003.

title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
text: "The Sands of Time" is a reboot of the "Prince of Persia" series, created by Jordan Mechner.

title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time
text: Mechner served as creative consultant, designer, and scenario writer for "The Sands of Time".

title: The Lost Vikings
text: The Lost Vikings is a puzzle-platform video game developed by Silicon & Synapse (now Blizzard Entertainment) and published by Interplay.

title: The Lost Vikings
text: It was originally released for the Super NES in 1992, then subsequently released for the Amiga, Amiga CD32, MS-DOS, and Mega Drive/Genesis systems the next year; the Mega Drive/Genesis version contains five stages not present in any other version of the game.

title: The Lost Vikings
text: Blizzard re-released the game for the Game Boy Advance in 2003.

title: The Lost Vikings
text: In 2014, the game was added to Battle.net as a free download emulated through DOSBox.

title: Loop of Henle
text: In the kidney, the loop of Henle ( ) (or Henle's loop, Henle loop, nephron loop or its Latin counterpart ansa nephroni) is the portion of a nephron that leads from the proximal convoluted tubule to the distal convoluted tubule.

title: Loop of Henle
text: Named after its discoverer, the German anatomist Friedrich Gustav Jakob Henle, the loop of Henle's main function is to create a concentration gradient in the medulla of the kidney.

title: Sodium-chloride symporter
text: The sodium-chloride symporter (also known as Na-Cl cotransporter, abbreviated as NCC or NCCT, or as the thiazide-sensitive Na-Cl cotransporter or TSC for short) is a cotransporter in the kidney which has the function of reabsorbing sodium and chloride ions from the tubular fluid into the cells of the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron.

title: Sodium-chloride symporter
text: It is a member of the SLC12 cotransporter family of electroneutral cation-coupled chloride cotransporters.

title: Sodium-chloride symporter
text: In humans, it is encoded by the gene "SLC12A3" (solute carrier family 12 member 3) located in 16q13.

title: Angiotensin
text: Angiotensin is a peptide hormone that causes vasoconstriction and a subsequent increase in blood pressure.

title: Angiotensin
text: It is part of the renin-angiotensin system, which is a major target for drugs that raises blood pressure.

title: Angiotensin
text: Angiotensin also stimulates the release of aldosterone, another hormone, from the adrenal cortex.

title: Angiotensin
text: Aldosterone promotes sodium retention in the distal nephron, in the kidney, which also drives blood pressure up.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: Low pressure receptors are baroreceptors located in the venae cavae and the pulmonary arteries, and in the atria.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: They are also called volume receptors.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: These receptors respond to changes in the wall tension, which is proportional to the filling state of the low pressure side of circulation (below 60mmHg).

title: Low pressure receptors
text: Their impulses regulate the secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH/Vasopressin), renin and aldosterone.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: An elevated atrial pressure produces a decrease in ADH and aldosterone secretion.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: The decrease in vasopressin secretion results in an increase in the volume of urine excreted, serving to lower blood pressure.

title: Low pressure receptors
text: In addition, stretching of atrial receptors increases secretion of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), which promotes increased water and sodium excretion through the urine.

title: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait
text: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait (8 January 1917 – 28 February 2003) ("née" Wardropper, known as Sylvia Simpson from 1941 to 1956) was an English biochemist and endocrinologist.

title: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait
text: She worked with her second husband, James Francis Tait, from 1948 until her death in 2003, a partnership described by the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography as "one of the most successful examples of husband-wife scientific collaboration".

title: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait
text: Together, they discovered and identified the hormone aldosterone, the last of a series of naturally occurring biologically potent steroid hormones to be isolated and identified between the 1920s to the 1950s, after the androgens, oestrogens, and glucocorticoid hormones.

title: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait
text: Aldosterone is part of the mechanism that regulates blood pressure, and causes conservation of sodium, secretion of potassium, increased water retention, and increased blood pressure.

title: Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait
text: It is thought to be responsible for 15 per cent of cases of high blood pressure.

title: Ascending limb of loop of Henle
text: Within the nephron of the kidney, the ascending limb of the loop of Henle is a segment of the loop of Henle downstream of the descending limb, after the sharp bend of the loop.

title: Ascending limb of loop of Henle
text: This part of the renal tubule is divided into a thin and thick ascending limb; the thick portion is also known as the distal straight tubule, in contrast with the distal convoluted tubule downstream.

title: Aldosterone
text: Aldosterone, the main mineralocorticoid hormone, is a steroid hormone produced by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex in the adrenal gland.

title: Aldosterone
text: It is essential for sodium conservation in the kidney, salivary glands, sweat glands and colon.

title: Aldosterone
text: It plays a central role in the regulation of the plasma sodium (Na), the extracellular potassium (K) and arterial blood pressure.

title: Aldosterone
text: It does so mainly by acting on the mineralocorticoid receptors in the distal tubules and collecting ducts of the nephron.

title: Aldosterone
text: It influences the reabsorption of sodium and excretion of potassium (from and into the tubular fluids, respectively) of the kidney, thereby indirectly influencing water retention or loss, blood pressure and blood volume.

title: Aldosterone
text: When dysregulated, aldosterone is pathogenic and contributes to the development and progression of cardiovascular and renal disease.

title: Aldosterone
text: Aldosterone has exactly the opposite function of the atrial natriuretic hormone secreted by the heart.

title: Tubuloglomerular feedback
text: In the physiology of the kidney, tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a feedback system inside the kidneys. Within each nephron, information from the renal tubules (a downstream area of the tubular fluid) is signaled to the glomerulus (an upstream area).

title: Tubuloglomerular feedback
text: Tubuloglomerular feedback is one of several mechanisms the kidney uses to regulate glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

title: Tubuloglomerular feedback
text: It involves the concept of purinergic signaling, in which an increased distal tubular sodium chloride concentration causes a basolateral release of adenosine from the macula densa cells.

title: Tubuloglomerular feedback
text: This initiates a cascade of events that ultimately brings GFR to an appropriate level.

title: Distal renal tubular acidosis
text: Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) or Type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is the classical form of RTA, being the first described.

title: Distal renal tubular acidosis
text: Distal RTA is characterized by a failure of acid secretion by the alpha intercalated cells of the cortical collecting duct of the distal nephron.

title: Distal renal tubular acidosis
text: This failure of acid secretion may be due to a number of causes, and it leads to an inability to acidify the urine to a pH of less than 5.3.

title: Renal tubular acidosis
text: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a medical condition that involves an accumulation of acid in the body due to a failure of the kidneys to appropriately acidify the urine.

title: Renal tubular acidosis
text: In renal physiology, when blood is filtered by the kidney, the filtrate passes through the tubules of the nephron, allowing for exchange of salts, acid equivalents, and other solutes before it drains into the bladder as urine.

title: Renal tubular acidosis
text: The metabolic acidosis that results from RTA may be caused either by failure to reabsorb sufficient bicarbonate ions (which are alkaline) from the filtrate in the early portion of the nephron (the proximal tubule) or by insufficient secretion of hydrogen ions (which are acidic) into the latter portions of the nephron (the distal tubule).

title: Renal tubular acidosis
text: Although a metabolic acidosis also occurs in those with renal insufficiency, the term RTA is reserved for individuals with poor urinary acidification in otherwise well-functioning kidneys.

title: Renal tubular acidosis
text: Several different types of RTA exist, which all have different syndromes and different causes.

title: United States elections, 2018
text: The 2018 United States elections will mostly be held on Tuesday, November 6, 2018.

title: United States elections, 2018
text: These midterm elections will take place in the middle of Republican President Donald Trump's term.

title: United States elections, 2018
text: All 435 seats in the United States House of Representatives and 33 of the 100 seats in the United States Senate will be contested.

title: United States elections, 2018
text: 39 state and territorial governorships and numerous other state and local elections will also be contested.

title: United States Senate elections, 2002
text: The United States Senate elections, 2002 featured a series of fiercely contested elections that resulted in a victory for the Republican Party, which gained two seats and thus a narrow majority from the Democratic Party in the United States Senate.

title: United States Senate elections, 2002
text: The Senate seats up for election, known as "class 2" Senate seats, were last up for regular election in 1996.

title: United States Senate elections, 2002
text: The election was held on November 5, 2002, almost fourteen months after the September 11, 2001 attacks.

title: TEAM Unity
text: Together Everybody Achieves More (TEAM) Unity was the political multi-party electoral alliance of the administration-backed senatorial line-up for the 2007 Philippine Midterm Elections.

title: TEAM Unity
text: TEAM Unity is composed mostly of supporters and erstwhile critics of ex-Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.

title: TEAM Unity
text: Team Unity sought to take several Senate seats in order to protect President Arroyo from impeachment attempts by the political opposition after the midterm elections.

title: United States midterm election
text: Midterm elections in the United States refer to general elections in the United States that are held two years after the quadrennial (four-year) elections for the President of the United States (i.e. near the midpoint of the four-year presidential term).

title: United States midterm election
text: Federal offices that are up for election during the midterms are members of the United States Congress, including all 435 seats in the United States House of Representatives, and the full terms for 33 or 34 of the 100 seats in the United States Senate.

title: Wisconsin elections, 2016
text: The Wisconsin general elections, 2016 were held in the U.S. state of Wisconsin on November 8, 2016.

title: Wisconsin elections, 2016
text: One of Wisconsin's U.S. Senate seats and all eight seats in the United States House of Representatives are up for election, as well as half of the Wisconsin Senate seats and all of the Wisconsin Assembly seats.

title: Wisconsin elections, 2016
text: Primary elections were held on August 9, 2016.

title: United States elections, 2002
text: The 2002 United States elections were held on November 5, in the middle of Republican President George W. Bush's first term.

title: United States elections, 2002
text: Unusual in midterm elections, the incumbent president's party gained seats in both chambers of the United States Congress.

title: United States elections, 2002
text: The Republicans picked up net gains of 2 Senate seats and 8 House seats.

title: United States Senate elections, 2008
text: Elections to the United States Senate were held on November 4, 2008 with 35 of the 100 seats in the Senate being contested.

title: United States Senate elections, 2008
text: Thirty-three seats were up for regular elections; the winners were eligible to serve six-year terms from January 3, 2009 to January 3, 2015, as members of Class 2.

title: United States Senate elections, 2008
text: There were also two special elections: one in Mississippi and another in Wyoming; as both seats were Class 1 Senate seats, the winners of both seats would serve the remainder of terms that ended on January 3, 2013.

title: Classes of United States Senators
text: The three classes of United States Senators are made up of 33 or 34 Senate seats each.

title: Classes of United States Senators
text: The purpose of the classes is to determine which Senate seats will be up for election in a given year.

title: Classes of United States Senators
text: The three groups are staggered so that one of them is up for election every two years, rather than having all 100 seats up for election at once.

title: Classes of United States Senators
text: For example, the 33 Senate seats of Class 1 were elected in 2012, the 33 seats of Class 2 were up for election in 2014, and the 34 seats of Class 3 were up for election in 2016.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: Nancy Elisabet Soderberg (born 1958) is an American foreign policy strategist.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She served President Bill Clinton as Deputy National Security Advisor and as an Ambassador at the United Nations.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She is currently President and CEO of Soderberg Global Solutions and Director of the Public Service Leadership Program at the University of North Florida in Jacksonville, FL.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She was appointed by President Obama to serve as Chair of the Public Interest Declassification Board (2011-2014).

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She has also previously served as President of Connect U.S. Fund, as Vice President of the International Crisis Group, and on the Board of the Jacksonville Port Authority.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She was a senior advisor to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and worked on four presidential campaigns.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She is a regular commentator on national and international television and radio, having appeared on NBC, ABC, CBS, CNN, BBC, Fox, National Public Radio, the Lehrer News Hour, CNN Crossfire, and The Daily Show.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She is the author of numerous articles on American foreign policy and two books: “The Prosperity Agends” (2008) written with Brian Katulis, and the Superpower Myth (2005).

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: In 1984, Soderberg received a Master of Science Degree from Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, concentrating on development economics and political risk analysis.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: She received her Bachelor of Arts in 1980 from Vanderbilt University.

title: Nancy Soderberg
text: It was reported on July 12th, 2017 that Soderberg had filed paperwork to run for Congress in the 2018 Midterm Elections in Florida's 6th Congressional District, as a Democrat .

title: 80th United States Congress
text: The Eightieth United States Congress was a meeting of the legislative branch of the United States federal government, composed of the United States Senate and the United States House of Representatives.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: It met in Washington, DC from January 3, 1947, to January 3, 1949, during the third and fourth years of Harry Truman's presidency.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: The apportionment of seats in this House of Representatives was based on the Sixteenth Census of the United States in 1940.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: Republicans gained a majority in both chambers for this Congress having gained thirteen Senate seats and fifty-seven House seats.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: Although the 80th Congress passed a total of 906 public bills, President Truman nicknamed it the "Do Nothing Congress" and, during the 1948 election, campaigned as much against it as against his formal opponent, Thomas Dewey.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: The 80th Congress passed several significant pro-business bills, most famously the Taft–Hartley Act, but it opposed most of Truman's Fair Deal bills.

title: 80th United States Congress
text: Truman's campaign strategy worked, and the Republicans lost nine Senate seats and seventy-three seats in the House, allowing the Democrats to begin the 81st Congress with twenty-one more seats than they had at the end of the 79th Congress.

title: Van Staphorst v. Maryland
text: Van Staphorst v. Maryland, 2 U.S. (2 Dall.)

title: Van Staphorst v. Maryland
text: 401 (1791), was the first case docketed with the United States Supreme Court.

title: Van Staphorst v. Maryland
text: Although the court agreed to hear and decide the case, the suit was settled before oral arguments. "

title: Van Staphorst v. Maryland
text: Collet v. Collet" was the first appellate case docketed with the court. "

title: Van Staphorst v. Maryland
text: West v. Barnes" was the first case decided by the court.

title: Berghuis v. Thompkins
text: Berghuis v. Thompkins, 560 U.S. 370 (2010) (docket 08-1470), is a decision by the United States Supreme Court in which the Court considered the position of a suspect who understands his or her right to remain silent under "Miranda v. Arizona" and is aware he or she has the right to remain silent, but does not explicitly invoke or waive the right.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: V.L. v. E.L., 577 U.S. ___ (2016) , is a case decided by the Supreme Court of the United States concerning the adoption rights of same-sex couples.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: In 2007, a Georgia Superior Court granted adoption rights to V.L., the partner of E.L., the woman who gave birth to their three children.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: However, after moving back to Alabama, the couple split up.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: E.L. tried to block V.L. from seeing the children, but V.L. filed a lawsuit seeking visitation and other parental rights.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: On September 18, 2015, the Supreme Court of Alabama ruled that the state did not have to recognize the adoption judgment, saying that the Georgia court misapplied its own state law.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: The court voided the recognition of the adoption judgment in Alabama.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: V.L. petitioned the United States Supreme Court to stay the ruling during her appeal and allow her to see her children.

title: V.L. v. E.L.
text: On December 14, 2015, the Supreme Court stayed the ruling pending their action on a petition for a writ of certiorari filed by V.L. On March 7, 2016, the Supreme Court of the United States reversed the decision of the Alabama Supreme Court by per curiam summary disposition.

title: Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt
text: Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, 579 U.S. ___ (2016) , is a landmark United States Supreme Court case decided on June 27, 2016.

title: Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt
text: The Court ruled 5-3 that Texas cannot place restrictions on the delivery of abortion services that create an undue burden for women seeking an abortion.

title: Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt
text: On June 28, the Supreme Court refused to hear challenges from Wisconsin and Mississippi where federal appeals courts had struck down similar laws.

title: Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt
text: Other states with similar laws may also be impacted.

title: Commissioner v. Banks
text: Commissioner v. Banks, 543 U.S. 426 (2005), together with Commissioner v. Banaitis, was a case decided before the Supreme Court of the United States, dealing with the issue of whether the portion of a money judgment or settlement paid to a taxpayer's attorney under a contingent-fee agreement is income to the taxpayer for federal income tax purposes.

title: Commissioner v. Banks
text: The Supreme Court held when a taxpayer's recovery constitutes income, the taxpayer's income includes the portion of the recovery paid to the attorney as a contingent fee.

title: Commissioner v. Banks
text: Employment cases are an exception to this Supreme Court ruling because of the Civil Rights Tax Relief in the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004.

title: Commissioner v. Banks
text: The Civil Rights Tax Relief amended Internal Revenue Service § 62(a) to permit taxpayers to subtract attorney’s fees from gross income in arriving at adjusted gross income.

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: Hirabayashi v. United States, 320 U.S. 81 (1943), was a case in which the United States Supreme Court held that the application of curfews against members of a minority group were constitutional when the nation was at war with the country from which that group originated.

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: The case arose out of the issuance of Executive Order 9066 following the December 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor and the U.S. entry into World War II.

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: President Franklin Roosevelt had authorized military commanders to secure areas from which "any or all persons may be excluded", and Japanese Americans were subject to a curfew and other restrictions before being removed to internment camps.

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: The plaintiff, Gordon Hirabayashi, was convicted of violating the curfew and had appealed to the Supreme Court. "

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: Yasui v. United States" was a companion case decided the same day.

title: Hirabayashi v. United States
text: Both convictions were overturned in "coram nobis" proceedings in the 1980s.

title: Hoffman v. Jones
text: Hoffman v. Jones, (Fla. 1973), was a case decided by the Supreme Court of Florida that was the first adoption of the comparative negligence rule in negligence law through judicial decision as opposed to adoption through statute.

title: Hoffman v. Jones
text: In the wrongful death case of Hoffman v. Jones, attorney Sammy Cacciatore Jr. was instrumental in causing the Florida Supreme Court to adopt for the first time the comparative negligence rule in negligence law.William Harrison Jones Jr. was killed by a Pav-A-Way Corporation truck driven by Philip Francis Hoffman Jr.

title: Hoffman v. Jones
text: It was the first case in the nation in which a state supreme court abandoned the almost-150-year-old doctrine of contributory negligence, which precluded an injured victim from recovery if the victim had contributed to the incident to any degree.

title: Hoffman v. Jones
text: The Florida Supreme Court adopted the concept of “pure” comparative negligence, which allows a victim to be compensated for the percentage of harm caused by the at-fault person.

title: Hoffman v. Jones
text: The decision of the court in Hoffman v. Jones has been cited in law school textbooks, and now the concept of comparative negligence is the prevailing doctrine.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: United States v. Quiver, 241 U.S. 602 (1916) is a case decided by the United States Supreme Court after first appearing in United States District Court for the District of South Dakota.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: The case argued on February 28, 1916 and decided on June 12, 1916 concerned adultery committed on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota between two enrolled members of the Oglala Sioux Tribe.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: The district court had held that adultery committed by an Indian with another Indian on an Indian reservation was not punishable under the act of March 3, 1887, c. 397, 24 Stat.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: 635, now § 316 of the Penal Code.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: This decision was made because the offense occurred on a Sioux Indian reservation which is not said to be under jurisdiction of the district court.

title: United States v. Quiver
text: The United States Supreme Court affirmed the judgment of the district court saying that the adultery was not punishable as it had occurred between two American Indians on an American Indian reservation.

title: Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan
text: Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan, 458 U.S. 718 (1982) was a case decided 5-4 by the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan
text: The court held that the single-sex admissions policy of the Mississippi University for Women violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Summers v. Earth Island Institute
text: Summers v. Earth Island Institute, 555 U.S. 488 (2009) , was a United States Supreme Court case decided 5–4 in which several environmental organizations brought suit against the United States Forest Service (USFS) to enjoin that federal agency from implementing rules that would allow the salvage sale of timber from 238 acres of fire-damaged federally owned land without conducting the notice, comment, and appeal process of the Forest Service Decision-making and Appeals Reform Act.

title: Boy Meets Girl (novel)
text: Boy Meets Girl is a 2004 chick lit novel by American author Meg Cabot.

title: Boy Meets Girl (novel)
text: The book was initially published under the name Meggin Cabot in January 2004 through HarperCollins Publishers, with subsequent reprintings of "Boy Meets Girl" using the "Meg Cabot" nom de plume.

title: Boy Meets Girl (novel)
text: "Boy Meets Girl" is the second book in the "Boy" series, but is only loosely connected to its predecessor "The Boy Next Door".

title: Making Every Moment Count
text: Making Every Moment Count is the eighth and final studio album by Australian singer-songwriter Peter Allen, released in 1990, two years before his death from an AIDS-related illness.

title: Making Every Moment Count
text: It was his first album of entirely new material since 1983's "Not the Boy Next Door".

title: Not the Boy Next Door
text: Not the Boy Next Door is a studio album released in 1983 by Australian singer and songwriter Peter Allen.

title: Not the Boy Next Door
text: This was his first release under Arista Records.

title: Fire! (manga)
text: Fire!

title: Fire! (manga)
text: (ファイヤー!

title: Fire! (manga)
text: , Faiyā! )

title: Fire! (manga)
text: is a shōjo manga series by Hideko Mizuno about the rise and fall of an American rock star named Aaron.

title: Fire! (manga)
text: It was serialised in "Seventeen" from 1969–1971 and won the 1970 Shogakukan Manga Award.

title: Fire! (manga)
text: The hedonistic Aaron is neither a 'boy next door' character, nor a 'shining prince', and Sandra Buckley states that it was his 'non-conventional, rebellious behavior' that was part of the attraction for the fans of "Fire!"

title: Fire! (manga)
text: It was innovative for shōjo manga by having the first sexually explicit scenes in post-World War II manga, and by having a male protagonist.

title: Fire! (manga)
text: The story has been read as a "conservative morality tale", but Buckley states that this ignores the two-year run of readers following Aaron's exploits avidly.

title: Fire! (manga)
text: There are accounts of teenage girls queueing for the next issue to come out.

title: Hold Me in Your Arms (album)
text: Hold Me in Your Arms is the second album by the British pop singer Rick Astley, released in November 1988 on RCA Records serving as the follow-up to his debut album "Whenever You Need Somebody".

title: Hold Me in Your Arms (album)
text: Like his previous albums, half the record was written and produced by Stock Aitken & Waterman, and the other half were Astley's own compositions produced by PWL associates Phil Harding, Ian Curnow and Daize Washbourn.

title: Hold Me in Your Arms (album)
text: The release of the album was delayed a few months due to a fire at PWL Studios destroying some of Astley's recorded material.

title: Hold Me in Your Arms (album)
text: This would be Astley's last record with Stock, Aitken & Waterman, due to Astley wanting to leave behind the dance-pop sound of the producers, of wanting to shed his boy next door image, and wanting to focus on his original compositions on his albums, reappearing in 1991 with the soul album "Free".

title: Superstar – The Hits
text: Superstar – The Hits is a best of collection by British R&B singer-songwriter Jamelia, released by Parlophone Records on 24 September 2007 (see 2007 in music).

title: Superstar – The Hits
text: The album contains ten out of eleven of Jamelia's UK Top 40 singles to date and omits her debut single, "So High", her first top forty hit "I Do", "Drama" single "Boy Next Door" and her collaboration with Tiziano Ferro, "Universal Prayer", which remains unreleased in the UK.

title: Superstar – The Hits
text: The album does contain, however, her version of "Stop" for the first time on a Jamelia album.

title: The Boy Next Door (album)
text: The Boy Next Door is a 2003 album by jazz singer Stacey Kent.

title: The Boy Next Door (album)
text: The songs were chosen to reflect male singers that Kent admires.

title: 'Tis Autumn
text: American jazz singer Stacey Kent covered it for her 2003 album "The Boy Next Door".

title: 'Tis Autumn
text: It has also been covered by Stan Getz, Bruce Eskovitz, Carmen McRae, Lee Konitz, Spike Robinson, Eddie Higgins and Bennie Wallace.

title: Boy next door
text: The boy next door is an archetype of storytelling.

title: Boy next door
text: He is often invoked in Western contexts to indicate wholesome, unassuming, or "average" masculinity.

title: Boy next door
text: A boy next door may serve as a love interest for a female protagonist who lives near by.

title: Boy Next Door (song)
text: "Boy Next Door" is the fifth single from British R&B artist Jamelia and the fourth and final single from her debut album "Drama".

title: Boy Next Door (song)
text: "Boy Next Door" is Jamelia's smallest hit, missing the UK Top 40, peaking at #42 and spending only two weeks inside the Top 75.

title: Boy Next Door (song)
text: The version released as a single was a slight remix to the version that appears on the album and is also slightly shorter in length.

title: Andy Umberger
text: Andy Umberger is an American actor who spent the early part of his career in New York City, where he was primarily a stage actor and appeared in three Broadway shows: "City Of Angels", "Passion" and "Company".

title: Andy Umberger
text: Since moving to Los Angeles in the late 90s, he has had supporting roles in over 15 films and has guest starred on over 60 television shows, with recurring roles on 10 different series, including: "Mad Men", "Weeds", "Boston Legal", "The West Wing", "Desperate Housewives", "ER", and as D'Hoffryn on "Buffy the Vampire Slayer".

title: Andy Umberger
text: He is one of only five actors to appear in three series created by Joss Whedon ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer", "Angel" and "Firefly").

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: Billy Sullivan (July 18, 1891 – May 23, 1946), also known as W. A. Sullivan, William A. Sullivan, and Arthur Sullivan, was an American character actor of the silent and early sound film eras.

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: Born on Long Island, New York in the village of Great Neck on August 18, 1891, Sullivan had his start in film shorts in the 1910s.

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: His first film production was a short which was part of a 23-part serial entitled, "The Million Dollar Mystery", in 1914.

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: The 23 episodes were edited into a feature-length film of the same name in 1918.

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: His first feature-length film was in the role of King Arthur in 1917's "Over the Hill".

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: During the early 1920s, he continued to work mainly in shorts, before moving into almost exclusively feature films in 1925.

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: From 1924 through 1927 he starred in about 20 films for Rayart Pictures, such as "The Slanderers" (1924), "Goat Getter" (1925), "The Winner" (1926), and "When Seconds Count" (1927).

title: Billy Sullivan (actor)
text: During his career he appeared in over 80 productions, including over 50 feature films.

title: Spencer Bell (actor)
text: Spencer Bell (September 25, 1887 – August 18, 1935) was an American stage and film actor, best known for playing opposite Larry Semon in many of his silent comedy shorts from the late 1910s to 1928.

title: Spencer Bell (actor)
text: Bell was one of the first African American comedic actors of the silent film era, and was the first to be signed to film contract.

title: Spencer Bell (actor)
text: Over the course of his fifteen year film career, Bell appeared in more than seventy comedy shorts.

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: Milton was a series of animated shorts created by Mike Judge in 1991.

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: They aired on "Saturday Night Live" in the mid 1990s, and like Mike Judge's other early shorts, appeared on MTV's Liquid Television in the early 1990s.

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: The 1999 film "Office Space" was based upon the cartoons, and featured actor Stephen Root in the role of Milton Waddams.

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: In the cartoon shorts all voices are by Mike Judge.

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: Although Milton was the title character from the shorts, the role was a supporting character in the "Office Space" movie, as was his boss, Bill Lumbergh (played by actor Gary Cole in "Office Space").

title: Milton (cartoon)
text: Milton traveled to different locations despite being consistently late for his taxis to take him there.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: Harry Bowen (October 4, 1888 – December 5, 1941) was an American character actor of the silent and sound film eras.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: Born on October 4, 1888 in Brooklyn, New York, he broke into the film industry doing film shorts during the silent era.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: His work on shorts continued into talking pictures, and it was in 1929 that he made his first appearance in a full-length feature, with a small role in "Red Hot Rhythm", directed by Leo McCarey.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: During his 20-year career, Bowen appeared in over 150 films, most of them film shorts.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: Other notable films in which he appeared include: the 1933 classic "King Kong"; "Flying Down to Rio" (1933), which was the first on-screen pairing of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers; John Ford's 1935 comedy, "The Whole Town's Talking", starring Edward G. Robinson; and "Next Time We Love" (1936), starring Margaret Sullavan, James Stewart, and Ray Milland.

title: Harry Bowen (actor)
text: His final screen performance, according to AFI, was the 1939 film, "The Day the Bookies Wept", starring Joe Penner and Betty Grable.

title: Charles Eldridge
text: Charles Eldridge (September 25, 1854 – October 29, 1922) was an American stage and screen actor of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: Charles Eldridge
text: In the film industry he appeared in over 100 films, although the majority of those were film shorts.

title: Charles Eldridge
text: He began on the stage during the 1870s, and appeared in at least one Broadway play, Charles Frohman's 1899 production of "Because She Loved Him So".

title: Charles Eldridge
text: His first appearance in film was in a 1910 short, "The Legacy", in which he starred.

title: Charles Eldridge
text: His first appearance in a feature film was in "The Strange Story of Sylvia Gray".

title: Charles Eldridge
text: In addition to the over 100 shorts he was in, Eldridge appeared in 27 feature films between 1914 and 1922.

title: Charles Eldridge
text: In his roles in full-length films, he would usually appear in a supporting role, although occasionally be given a lead, as in 1917's "Polly of the Circus", 1920's "Broken Hearts", and 1922's "Ashamed of Parents".

title: Charles Eldridge
text: "Polly of the Circus" was notable for being the first film released by Goldwyn Pictures, which was shot in Fort Lee, New Jersey, mostly at rented space at the studios owned by Universal Studios.

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: John Fleck (born May 7, 1951) is an American actor and performance artist.

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: He has performed in numerous TV shows, including "Babylon 5", "Carnivàle", "Murder One", and the "Star Trek" franchise.

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: He also appeared in "Howard The Duck", "Waterworld" and the ZZ Top music video Legs.

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: He made a minor appearance in the "Seinfeld" episode "The Heart Attack".

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: He plays a minor character during the sixth season of "Weeds".

title: John Fleck (actor)
text: He wrote and performed "Mad Women" at La MaMa E.T.C.

title: Gary Anthony Williams
text: Gary Anthony Williams (born March 14, 1966) is an American actor and comedian who provided the voice of Uncle Ruckus on "The Boondocks", Yancy Westridge in the video game "Alpha Protocol", and Horace Warfield in "".

title: Gary Anthony Williams
text: He appeared on the television series "Weeds", "Boston Legal", "Blue Collar TV", and as "Abe" Kenarban in "Malcolm in the Middle".

title: Gary Anthony Williams
text: Williams co-founded and is Artistic Director of the L.A. Comedy Shorts film festival in Hollywood, California.

title: Gary Anthony Williams
text: He also starred alongside Cedric the Entertainer on the hit TV Land sitcom "The Soul Man".

title: Gary Anthony Williams
text: Williams is currently a regular on "Whose Line is it Anyway?

title: A Story of Floating Weeds
text: A Story of Floating Weeds (浮草物語 , Ukikusa monogatari ) is a 1934 silent film directed by Yasujirō Ozu which he later remade as "Floating Weeds" in 1959 in color.

title: A Story of Floating Weeds
text: It won the Kinema Junpo Award for best film, the third consecutive year an Ozu film won, following "I Was Born, But..." and "Passing Fancy".

title: Andy Milder
text: Andy Milder (born August 16, 1969) is an American actor and voice actor.

title: Andy Milder
text: He has appeared in such films as "Apollo 13", "Armageddon", "Rumor Has It...", "Frost/Nixon", "Transformers" and "Domino".

title: Andy Milder
text: He was a series regular on "Fame L.A." and "Weeds", and appeared on such shows as "", "", "The West Wing", "Six Feet Under", "Ugly Betty", "Boston Legal", "Parks and Recreation", "Married... with Children", "The Wonder Years", "Private Practice" and "Criminal Minds".

title: Andy Milder
text: Milder provided narration for "Ballroom Bootcamp", "101 Most Starlicious Make-Overs", and "Wrecks to Riches".

title: Andy Milder
text: He provided the voice of Prince Sebastian LaCroix in the 2004 video game "" and Lightning Lad in the 2006 animated series "Legion of Super Heroes" and the film "".

title: Andy Milder
text: From 2005 to 2009, he was a recurring cast member and later series regular on "Weeds" as Dean Hodes.

title: Andy Milder
text: Starting in 2011, he is a recurring cast member on the Disney Channel sitcom "Austin & Ally" as Lester Dawson.

title: Andy Milder
text: He also had an appearance on the show "Royal Pains" on the USA Network.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: The 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante was the nineteenth and final round of the 2002 CART FedEx Champ Car World Series season, held on November 17, 2002 at the Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez in Mexico City, Mexico.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: It was the first Champ Car race at the track since the 1981 season.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: The race preceded a mass exodus of significant drivers and teams who all competed in their final Champ Car event, most of whom knew beforehand that they would not return.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: Most rued the fact that they were leaving for the rival Indy Racing League, wishing to continue in CART rather than endure a more stable future in the IRL.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: CART's winningest driver (42 wins), Michael Andretti, along with Kenny Brack, Scott Dixon, Dario Franchitti, Tony Kanaan, and Japan's most successful driver in U.S. open wheel racing Tora Takagi would all bid CART adieu in favor of the IRL.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: Other entities leaving CART included 1996-1999 champions Chip Ganassi Racing, 1995 champions Team KOOL Green, and Mo Nunn Racing permanently switched to the IRL, and Japanese automotive industry giants Honda and Toyota likewise left CART for the IRL.

title: 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante
text: Season champion Cristiano da Matta was set to leave CART for Formula One with his engine supplier's F1 team, and Christian Fittipaldi attempted a stock car career.

title: 2011 Honda Indy Toronto
