text: The 2011 Honda Indy Toronto was the ninth round of the 2011 IndyCar Series season and took place on July 10, 2011, at the 1.755 mi Exhibition Place temporary street circuit in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

title: 2011 Honda Indy Toronto
text: Dario Franchitti won the race, second was his teammate Scott Dixon, and Ryan Hunter-Reay came in third.

title: 2011 Honda Indy Toronto
text: Will Power took the 3 bonus points for winning pole and leading the most laps, but finished 24th after contact with championship rival Franchitti and Alex Tagliani.

title: 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton
text: The 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton was an IndyCar motor race held on July 25, 2010 at the Edmonton City Centre Airport, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada.

title: 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton
text: It was the eleventh round of the 2010 IndyCar Series season, the third annual edition of the Edmonton Indy in the IndyCar Series, and the sixth anniversary running of the race (including three years on the Champ Car World Series (CCWS) schedule).

title: 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton
text: The 95-lap race was won by Chip Ganassi Racing driver Scott Dixon, who started from the third position.

title: 2010 Honda Indy Edmonton
text: Will Power finished second for Team Penske and Dixon's teammate Dario Franchitti came in third.

title: 2007 Firestone Indy 400
text: The 2007 Firestone Indy 400 was a race in the 2007 IRL IndyCar Series, held at Michigan International Speedway.

title: 2007 Firestone Indy 400
text: It was held over the weekend of August 3–5, 2007, as the thirteenth round of the seventeen-race calendar.

title: 2007 Firestone Indy 400
text: It was the last race, for the time being, for the IndyCar Series at the track.

title: 2007 Firestone Indy 400
text: The race was also notable in that only seven cars were running at the finish, after a massive accident on lap 144 of the race which included Dario Franchitti flipping upside-down after hitting Dan Wheldon.

title: 2007 Firestone Indy 400
text: Franchitti would walk away unharmed.

title: Marino Franchitti
text: Marino Alessandro Cesare Franchitti (born 7 July 1978) is a British racing driver, and the younger brother of Dario Franchitti.

title: Marino Franchitti
text: He has spent the majority of his career racing in sports cars and grand tourers, with a career highlight of winning the 2014 12 Hours of Sebring.

title: 2009 Honda Indy Toronto
text: The 2009 Honda Indy Toronto was the tenth round of the 2009 IndyCar Series season and took place on July 12, 2009 at the 1.755 mi Exhibition Place temporary street circuit in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

title: 2009 Honda Indy Toronto
text: Dario Franchitti won the race, to join Chip Ganassi Racing teammate Scott Dixon as the only three-time winners in the 2009 season.

title: 2009 Honda Indy Toronto
text: Franchitti also regained the points lead from Dixon, leading the championship by two points as the championship heads to Edmonton.

title: 2009 Honda Indy Toronto
text: Ryan Briscoe finished second for the fifth time in the last six races, with Penske Racing teammate Will Power third on his return to the series.

title: 1998 Molson Indy Vancouver
text: The 1998 Molson Indy Vancouver was the fifteenth round of the 1998 CART FedEx Champ Car World Series season, held on September 6, 1998, at Concord Pacific Place in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

title: 1998 Molson Indy Vancouver
text: Dario Franchitti took his second consecutive win at this race, after passing Michael Andretti for the lead with seven laps left.

title: 1998 Molson Indy Vancouver
text: In doing so, Franchitti became the first driver to win a race from pole for over a year.

title: Dario Franchitti
text: George Dario Marino Franchitti, MBE (born 19 May 1973), known professionally as Dario Franchitti, is a retired Scottish racing driver.

title: Dario Franchitti
text: He is a four time IndyCar Series champion (2007, 2009, 2010, 2011), a three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500 (2007, 2010, 2012) as well as a winner of the 24 Hours of Daytona (2008).

title: Dario Franchitti
text: Franchitti started his career in his native United Kingdom in the early 1990s, competing in Formula Vauxhall and Formula Three and was also the winner of the McLaren Autosport BRDC Award in 1992.

title: Dario Franchitti
text: After Franchitti did not secure a single-seater drive in 1995, he was contracted by the AMG team to compete in touring cars in the DTM and its successor — the International Touring Car Championship.

title: Dario Franchitti
text: Despite 2 seasons with relative success, the series folded at the end of the 1996 season, again leaving Franchitti without a drive.

title: Dario Franchitti
text: Mercedes placed Franchitti in CART in 1997 with the Hogan Racing team.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: The 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma was the seventh running of the Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma and the fourteenth round of the 2011 IndyCar Series season.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: It took place on Sunday, August 28, 2011.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: The race contested over 75 laps at the 2.303 mi Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, California.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: Will Power led 71 of 75 laps, as Team Penske swept 1st–2nd–3rd on the podium.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: It was the first 1–2–3 finish in an Indycar race for Penske since Nazareth in 1994.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: Power closed to within 26 points of championship leader Dario Franchitti.

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: Power also closed within 7 points of Franchitti for the "Mario Andretti Road Course Trophy".

title: 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma
text: Simon Pagenaud substituted for Simona de Silvestro after she had complications renewing her visa, and U.S. Customs would not allow her into the country.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Johnny Mowlem (born 12 February 1969) is a professional British racing driver.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Mowlem is considered to be among the world's elite sports car drivers, having competed in every class of world championship sports car racing.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: He is the 2013 European Le Mans Series GT champion, having previously won the British Porsche Cup championship in 1996 and 1997.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: He has class victories in both the 24 Hours of Daytona and the 12 Hours of Sebring, and has earned podiums at virtually all of the world's major sports car races, including the Le Mans 24 hours and the 1000 km Nürburgring.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: He has also achieved overall podium finishes at the Daytona 24 hours as well as at the famous 10-hour Petit Le Mans race in the USA.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Mowlem began his career in single seaters racing up to Formula 3 level and got his big break when he was chosen personally by triple Formula One World Champion Jackie Stewart to join his "staircase of "talent" team in the junior single seater formula, alongside drivers of the calibre of Dario Franchitti, Allan McNish and Gil de Ferran.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: He switched to sportscars in 1996, winning the Class 1 championship of the British Porsche Cup and then gained international recognition the following year when he won all 17 races of the British Porsche Cup to become British champion.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: This launched his professional career in World Sportscars.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Later in his career he gained further international attention for his work as a driver of the hybrid-powered Ginetta Zytek prototype racer in the ALMS in 2008 and 2009.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: In 2010, Mowlem was a Lotus Racing factory driver, driving the American Le Mans Series (ALMS) and in the International GT Open Series for sports cars in Europe.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: His latest driving championship came in the European Le Mans Series in 2013.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Mowlem raced in the ALMS series every year that sanctioning body held races.

title: Johnny Mowlem
text: Mowlem also operates his own driving academy, working with both corporate clients and drivers wishing for a career in racing.

title: AFC North
text: The American Football Conference North Division, or AFC North, is a division of the National Football League's (NFL) American Football Conference (AFC).

title: AFC North
text: It was created as the AFC Central in 1970 following the completion of the AFL–NFL merger when two of the NFL teams—the Cleveland Browns and the Pittsburgh Steelers—moved from the "old" NFL to join the former American Football League teams in the AFC, in order to give the two conferences an equal number of teams.

title: AFC North
text: The division adopted its current name in 2002, when the league realigned divisions after expanding to 32 teams.

title: 2011 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Cleveland Browns season was the team's 63rd season as a professional sports franchise and its 59th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2011 Cleveland Browns season
text: The team had hoped to improve on its 2010 season, where it finished with a record of 5–11 and placed third in the AFC North, however, the team was eliminated from playoff contention in Week 14.

title: 2011 Cleveland Browns season
text: This season marked the second season under the leadership of team president Mike Holmgren and general manager Tom Heckert, as well as the first season under head coach Pat Shurmur.

title: 2011 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns played all of their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Cleveland Browns season was the team's 64th season as a professional sports franchise and its 60th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: Although the team improved on its record to 5–11 this 2012 season from its 4–12 finish in 2011, the team still placed fourth in the AFC North.

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: The team also failed to break its 9-year playoff drought, the longest in franchise history.

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: The 2012 season was the third season under the leadership of team president Mike Holmgren and general manager Tom Heckert and the second season under head coach Pat Shurmur.

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns also had Jimmy Haslam as their new owner, after buying the team from Randy Lerner.

title: 2012 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns played all of their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: 2007 Cleveland Browns season
text: The 2007 Cleveland Browns season was the team's 59th season as a professional sports franchise and its 55th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2007 Cleveland Browns season
text: The season began with the Browns attempting to improve upon their 4–12 record from the 2006 season, in which the team finished in fourth place in the AFC North.

title: 2007 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns also attempted to overcome the many injuries that plagued the team throughout the 2006 season.

title: 2007 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns remained under the supervision of head coach Romeo Crennel and they played all of their home games in Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: The 2008 Cleveland Browns season was the team's 60th season as a professional sports franchise and its 56th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns finished with a 4–12 record and failed to qualify for the playoffs.

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: The season marked Romeo Crennel's fourth (and what would be final) year as head coach of the Browns.

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: Cleveland played all of their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: In the 2008 season, the Browns failed to score a touchdown for 24 consecutive quarters.

title: 2008 Cleveland Browns season
text: Also from 2008 to present, the Browns have failed to obtain a winning record, thus they failed to make the playoffs for the seventh straight season.

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: The 2010 Cleveland Browns season was the team's 62nd season as a professional sports franchise and its 58th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: The team failed to break the longest playoff appearance drought in franchise history, a current streak of eight seasons without reaching the playoffs.

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: The team finished 5–11, matching its win total from the 2009 season and placed third in the AFC North.

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: This season marked the first season under the leadership of team president Mike Holmgren and general manager Tom Heckert.

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: It also marked the second season under head coach Eric Mangini.

title: 2010 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns played all of their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Lamar Chapman
text: Lamar A. Chapman (born November 6, 1976) is a former American football cornerback who played two seasons with the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League.

title: Lamar Chapman
text: He was drafted by the Cleveland Browns in the fifth round of the 2000 NFL Draft.

title: Lamar Chapman
text: He played college football at Kansas State University and attended Liberal High School in Liberal, Kansas.

title: Lamar Chapman
text: He was placed on the waived/injured list by the Browns on August 5, 2002.

title: 2009 Cleveland Browns season
text: The 2009 Cleveland Browns season was the team's 61st season as a professional sports franchise and its 57th season as a member of the National Football League (NFL).

title: 2009 Cleveland Browns season
text: The team placed fourth in the AFC North with a record of 5–11, improving upon its 2008 record of 4–12.

title: 2009 Cleveland Browns season
text: This season marked George Kokinis and Eric Mangini's first seasons as the team's general manager and head coach, respectively; however, Kokinis was fired on November 2 during the team's Week 9 bye week.

title: 2009 Cleveland Browns season
text: The Browns played all of their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Ron Snidow
text: Ronald Wayne Snidow (December 30, 1941 – May 17, 2009) was an American football defensive tackle in the National Football League for the Washington Redskins and the Cleveland Browns.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He attended San Rafael High School in California.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He played college football at the University of Oregon.

title: Ron Snidow
text: The Washington Redskins drafted Snidow in the third round of the 1963 NFL draft.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After five seasons with the Redskins, he was traded to the Cleveland Browns in exchange for a second round draft choice, just prior to the opening of the 1968 season.

title: Ron Snidow
text: Snidow was first-team All-Pro with the Browns in 1969.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He appeared in 126 career regular season games.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After suffering a broken leg while playing with the Browns, he retired at the end of the 1972 season, having played 10 years in the NFL.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After retiring from the NFL, Snidow worked as a commercial real estate broker in Southern California, until he retired.

title: Ron Snidow
text: In 2008, Snidow was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease, which he died from a year later on May 17, 2009, while on a vacation cruise off the coast of Italy on the island of Elba.

title: Freddie Summers
text: Freddie S. Summers (born February 16, 1947) is a former American football defensive back who played three seasons with the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League.

title: Freddie Summers
text: He was drafted by the Cleveland Browns in the fourth round of the 1969 NFL Draft.

title: Freddie Summers
text: He first enrolled at McCook Community College before transferring to Wake Forest University, where he played quarterback.

title: Freddie Summers
text: Summers attended Dorchester High School in Dorchester, Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Freddie Summers
text: On June 15, 1972, he was traded to the New York Giants in exchange for the Giants second pick in the 1973 NFL Draft.

title: Freddie Summers
text: He was placed on injured waivers on August 30, 1972.

title: Arcos Dorados Holdings
text: Arcos Dorados Holdings Inc. is McDonald’s largest franchisee in the world in terms of systemwide sales and number of restaurants.

title: Arcos Dorados Holdings
text: As of December 31, 2010, it represented 6.7% of McDonald’s franchised restaurants globally.

title: Arcos Dorados Holdings
text: As the largest operator of McDonald's restaurants in Latin America and the Caribbean, it has more than 94,000 employees, being one of the region's leading employers of young, first-time job holders.

title: Arcos Dorados Holdings
text: It serves more than 4.3 million customers daily and is the largest quick service restaurant (QSR) chain in Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: Shawarmer
text: Shawarmer is a Middle Eastern quick service restaurant chain specializing in Shawarma.

title: Shawarmer
text: Shawarmer opened its first branch in Riyadh in 1999 and currently is operating in 13 cities in Saudi with more than 70 Branches.

title: Shawarmer
text: Shawarmer concept revolves around innovating the traditional shawarma, and maintaining international quality standards to their offering, making Shawarmer one of the biggest food industry players in Saudi Arabia.

title: Hero Certified Burgers
text: Hero Certified Burgers is a Canadian restaurant chain franchise that sells hamburgers and other quick service restaurant fare.

title: Hero Certified Burgers
text: It is based in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and was founded in 2004.

title: Hero Certified Burgers
text: It had almost 60 locations as of March 2017, and opened its first store in the United States in 2015 in Elmwood Village, Buffalo, New York.

title: Hero Certified Burgers
text: The Buffalo location closed at the end of 2016.

title: Hero Certified Burgers
text: The company uses sustainably-sourced beef.

title: Noodle Box
text: Noodle Box Pty Ltd is an Australian stir fried noodle quick service restaurant chain headquartered in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia founded by Josh James and David Milne in 1996.

title: Lion's Choice
text: Lion's Choice is a Missouri-based quick service restaurant chain specializing in roast beef sandwiches.

title: Lion's Choice
text: The restaurant sells lean, top-round roast beef, slow-roasted daily on-site, shaved thin and served with a dash of secret seasoning on a toasted and steamed bun.

title: Toddle House
text: Toddle House was a national quick service restaurant chain in the United States, which specialized in breakfast but was open 24/7.

title: Toddle House
text: Much of their business was takeout.

title: Farmer Boys
text: Farmer Boys is a quick service restaurant chain based primarily in California, with headquarters in Riverside, California.

title: Tim Hortons
text: Tim Hortons Inc. (known internationally as Tim Hortons Cafe and Bake Shop, colloquially known as Timmy's or Tim's) is a Canadian multinational fast food restaurant known for its coffee and doughnuts.

title: Tim Hortons
text: It is also Canada's largest quick service restaurant chain; as of December 31, 2016, it had a total of 4,613 restaurants in nine countries.

title: Fast food restaurant
text: A fast food restaurant, also known as a quick service restaurant (QSR) within the industry, is a specific type of restaurant that serves fast food cuisine and has minimal table service.

title: Fast food restaurant
text: The food served in fast food restaurants is typically part of a "meat-sweet diet", offered from a limited menu, cooked in bulk in advance and kept hot, finished and packaged to order, and usually available for take away, though seating may be provided.

title: Fast food restaurant
text: Fast food restaurants are typically part of a restaurant chain or franchise operation that provisions standardized ingredients and/or partially prepared foods and supplies to each restaurant through controlled supply channels.

title: Fast food restaurant
text: The term "fast food" was recognized in a dictionary by Merriam–Webster in 1951.

title: Leeann Chin
text: Leeann Chin is a Bloomington, Minnesota-based Asian quick service restaurant chain, with over 50 locations throughout the Midwest, mostly in the Minneapolis-Saint Paul area.

title: Leeann Chin
text: The chain was founded by its namesake, Leeann Chin, funded by Carl Pohlad (banker and former owner of the Minnesota Twins) and actor Sean Connery.

title: Leeann Chin
text: The concept received Best Chinese Food and Best Takeout Food as well as being voted No. 80 in a list of the country’s top 100 by fast casual restaurant industry website FastCasual.com in 2011.

title: Leeann Chin
text: It is currently owned by Los Angeles-based financier and former investment banker Lorne Goldberg, who also owns the popular Asian chains Pick Up Stix and Mandarin Express.

title: Locust Lake State Park
text: Locust Lake State Park is a Pennsylvania state park on 1089 acre in Ryan Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania in the United States.

title: Locust Lake State Park
text: Locust Lake State Park is located approximately 7 mi north of Pottsville, 3 mi south of Mahanoy City, 8 mi west of Tamaqua and 6 mi west of Tuscarora State Park.

title: Locust Lake State Park
text: The lake is 52 acre .

title: Locust Lake State Park
text: The park offers hiking, camping, boating, fishing, swimming, biking, and a wide array of other seasonal activities.

title: Finchampstead
text: Finchampstead is a village and civil parish in the Wokingham Borough of Berkshire, England.

title: Finchampstead
text: Its northern extremity is 2 mi south of Wokingham, 5 mi west of Bracknell, 8 mi south-east of Reading, and 33 mi west of Central London.

title: Finchampstead
text: It is an affluent area, with the village ranking as Britain's 31st wealthiest.

title: Finchampstead
text: It has a high standard of living and is rated as one of the most desirable places to live in the UK.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: Canton is a charter township of Wayne County in the U.S. state of Michigan.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: It is located about 8 mi west of the city limits of Detroit and 8 mi east of the city limits of Ann Arbor.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: As of the 2010 census, the township had a population of 90,173, making it Michigan's second largest township and eleventh largest community.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: Canton is ranked as 96th highest-income place in the United States with a population of 50,000 or more.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: Canton Township is also consistently ranked as one of the safest cities in the United States, as well as in the state of Michigan.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: In 2015, the township was ranked as the 29th safest city in America.

title: Canton, Michigan
text: Canton is one of Michigan's fastest growing communities.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Jeff Horner (born August 1, 1983) is an American former basketball player and current assistant coach for the University of North Dakota.

title: Jeff Horner
text: He is best known as a point guard for the University of Iowa Hawkeyes basketball team.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Horner currently holds the University of Iowa career three point record at 232 shots made.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Horner was born in Mason City, Iowa.

title: Jeff Horner
text: His father Bob Horner was Mason City High School varsity basketball coach.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Horner made a verbal commitment to the University of Iowa while in the ninth grade.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Horner was the head varsity basketball coach at Valley High School in West Des Moines, Iowa from 2010-2014.

title: Jeff Horner
text: Horner's sister Kristin played basketball for Drake University.

title: Anthony Avent
text: Anthony Avent (born October 18, 1969) is a retired American professional basketball player who was selected by the Atlanta Hawks in the first round (15th pick overall) of the 1991 NBA Draft.

title: Anthony Avent
text: Born in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, Avent played for the Milwaukee Bucks, Orlando Magic, Vancouver Grizzlies, Utah Jazz and Los Angeles Clippers in six NBA seasons.

title: Anthony Avent
text: He played collegiately at Seton Hall University where he played in the 1989 NCAA championship game.

title: Anthony Avent
text: Prior to Seton Hall, Avent played at Malcolm X Shabazz High School in Newark, New Jersey.

title: James Blackmon Sr.
text: James Blackmon Sr. (born August 7, 1964) is an American basketball coach and former noted college and high school player.

title: James Blackmon Sr.
text: Blackmon has coached two teams to the class 2A high school basketball championship in Indiana, winning back-to-back titles in 2008 and 2009.

title: James Blackmon Sr.
text: Blackmon played basketball in college for the University of Kentucky Wildcats.

title: James Blackmon Sr.
text: As a senior at Marion High School, in Marion, Indiana, Blackmon was runner-up for the award of Indiana Mr. Basketball, won that year by Steve Alford.

title: James Blackmon Sr.
text: Blackmon was named to the McDonald's All-American and Parade All-American teams in recognition of his high school success.

title: Presley Askew
text: Presley Askew (November 17, 1909 – February 7, 1994) was an American basketball and baseball coach.

title: Presley Askew
text: Overall Askew won 169 games at New Mexico State and Arkansas and had an overall record of 509–312 in all high school and college coaching.

title: Presley Askew
text: Born in Red Oak, Oklahoma, Askew played basketball and graduated from Red Oak High School in 1926.

title: Presley Askew
text: He played for and graduated from Eastern Oklahoma State College, and eventually Oklahoma State University in 1930.

title: Presley Askew
text: He began coaching at Fanshawe Public School and became head varsity coach in 1932.

title: Presley Askew
text: In 1937 Askew moved to his hometown Red Oak High School to coach and was there until 1942 when he moved on to Van Buren High School in Arkansas.

title: Presley Askew
text: Askew's teams at Van Buren were very competitive and went to the state championship tournaments.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Weldon Drew (born April 22, 1935) was the head men's basketball coach at New Mexico State University from 1979 to 1985.

title: Weldon Drew
text: He was named to the position in 1979 as the successor to Ken Hayes who left to become head coach at Oral Roberts University.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew was previously an assistant coach for New Mexico State University from 1975 to 1979.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew came to NMSU after coaching high school basketball for Houston's Kashmere High School (485-135 record in 18 seasons), where he left with a 78-game winning streak after winning two consecutive Texas 4A state championships and the high school national championship.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew also won national coach of the year in 1975.

title: Weldon Drew
text: The NMSU job was Drew's first head coaching position at the college level.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew was the 20th person to hold the head coaching position in the Aggie basketball history.

title: Weldon Drew
text: After a dismal 1984-85 season, Drew was fired.

title: Weldon Drew
text: He then went to be an assistant coach at Oklahoma State for two seasons.

title: Weldon Drew
text: In 1987 Drew became the head coach at traditionally-black Langston University in Oklahoma.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew graduated from Fisk University in 1957 after a standout career playing basketball.

title: Weldon Drew
text: Drew graduated high school and played basketball at Wheatley High School in Houston.

title: Larry Friend
text: Larry Haskell Friend (April 14, 1935 – February 27, 1998) was an American National Basketball Association (NBA) player.

title: Larry Friend
text: Friend was born and raised in Chicago, Illinois and played basketball at Marshall High School in Chicago.

title: Larry Friend
text: However, he moved to Los Angeles, California before his senior year and played basketball at Fairfax High School.

title: Larry Friend
text: Friend first played college basketball at Los Angeles City College, where he was named an All-American Junior College.

title: Larry Friend
text: He then transferred to the University of California, where he was a three-year starter.

title: Larry Friend
text: He averaged 19.1 points per game his senior season and was also named to the AP All-American third team.

title: Larry Friend
text: Friend was drafted with the fifth pick in the second round of the 1957 NBA Draft by the New York Knicks.

title: Larry Friend
text: In his one season with the Knicks, Friend averaged 4.0 points, 2.4 rebounds, and 1.1 assists per game.

title: Larry Friend
text: In 1961-62 Friend returned to professional basketball to play for the Los Angeles Jets in the American Basketball League.

title: Larry Friend
text: He appeared in thirty-nine games for the Jets and averaged 11.0 points and 3.7 rebounds per game, while also leading the league in three-point shooting (58-163).

title: Larry Friend
text: Due to financial problems, the Jets folded midway through their first season.

title: Larry Friend
text: Following his playing career, Friend owned an investment business.

title: Larry Friend
text: He died on February 27, 1998 in Newport, California of prostate cancer.

title: Kelsall
text: Kelsall is a medium-sized agricultural/commuter village and civil parish in the unitary authority of Cheshire West and Chester and the ceremonial county of Cheshire, England.

title: Kelsall
text: It is located around 8 mi east of Chester, 8 mi west of Northwich and 4 mi north west of Tarporley.

title: Kelsall
text: The village is situated on Kelsall Hill, a part of the Mid-Cheshire Ridge, the broken line of sandstone hills that divide the west Cheshire Plain from its eastern counterpart.

title: Kelsall
text: The ridge includes other hills including Peckforton, Beeston, Frodsham and Helsby.

title: 2017 Winston-Salem Open
text: The 2017 Winston–Salem Open was a men's tennis tournament played on outdoor hard courts.

title: 2017 Winston-Salem Open
text: It was the 49th edition of the Winston-Salem Open (as successor to previous tournaments in New Haven and Long Island), and part of the ATP World Tour 250 Series of the 2017 ATP World Tour.

title: 2017 Winston-Salem Open
text: It took place at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, United States, from August 20 through August 26, 2017.

title: 2017 Winston-Salem Open
text: It was the last event on the 2017 US Open Series before the 2017 US Open.

title: 2017 Connecticut Open
text: The 2017 Connecticut Open (also known as the 2017 Connecticut Open presented by United Technologies for sponsorship reasons) was a tennis tournament played on outdoor hard courts.

title: 2017 Connecticut Open
text: It was the 49th edition of the Connecticut Open, and part of the Premier Series of the 2017 WTA Tour.

title: 2017 Connecticut Open
text: It took place at the Cullman-Heyman Tennis Center in New Haven, Connecticut, United States, from August 20 through August 26.

title: 2017 Connecticut Open
text: It was the last event of the 2017 US Open Series before the 2017 US Open.

title: Caroline Wozniacki career statistics
text: This is a list of the main career statistics of professional Danish tennis player Caroline Wozniacki.

title: Caroline Wozniacki career statistics
text: To date, Wozniacki has won twenty-six WTA singles titles including two WTA Premier Mandatory singles titles and three WTA Premier 5 singles titles.

title: Caroline Wozniacki career statistics
text: She was also the runner-up at the 2009 US Open, 2010 WTA Tour Championships, and 2014 US Open, a semi-finalist at the 2010 US Open, 2011 Australian Open and 2011 US Open and a quarterfinalist at the 2010 French Open and 2012 London Olympics.

title: Caroline Wozniacki career statistics
text: Wozniacki was first ranked World No. 1 by the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) on October 11, 2010.

title: 2017 BB&T Atlanta Open
text: The 2017 BB&T Atlanta Open was a professional tennis tournament played on hard courts.

title: 2017 BB&T Atlanta Open
text: It was the 30th edition of the tournament, and part of the 2017 ATP World Tour and the 2017 US Open Series.

title: 2017 BB&T Atlanta Open
text: It took place at Atlantic Station in Atlanta, United States between July 24 and 30, 2017.

title: 2017 BB&T Atlanta Open
text: It was the first men's event of the 2017 US Open Series.

title: 2013 US Open Series
text: In tennis, the 2013 US Open Series (known as Emirates Airline US Open Series for sponsorships reasons) was the tenth edition of the US Open Series, which included ten hard court tournaments that started on July 20, 2013 in Atlanta and concluded in Winston-Salem for the men and in New Haven for the women on August 24, 2013.

title: 2013 US Open Series
text: This edition consisted of four separate men's tournaments and four women's tournaments, with the Western & Southern Open hosting both a men's and women's event.

title: 2013 US Open Series
text: The series was headlined by two ATP World Tour Masters 1000 and two WTA Premier 5 events.

title: 2013 US Open Series
text: Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams were the US Open Series winners, making them eligible for a $1 million bonus if either also won the US Open, a feat which they both accomplished, hence receiving the largest paychecks to date for a single tennis tournament, totalling $3.6 million each.

title: Petra Kvitová career statistics
text: This is a list of the main career statistics of Czech professional tennis player Petra Kvitová.

title: Petra Kvitová career statistics
text: To date, Kvitová has won 20 singles titles including two Grand Slam singles titles at the Wimbledon Championships, one WTA Tour Championships singles title, two WTA Premier Mandatory singles titles and four WTA Premier 5 singles titles.

title: Petra Kvitová career statistics
text: She was also the bronze medallist at the 2016 Rio Olympics, a semifinalist at the 2010 Wimbledon Championships, 2012 Australian Open and 2012 French Open and a quarterfinalist at the 2011 Australian Open, 2012 Wimbledon Championships, 2013 Wimbledon Championships, 2015 US Open and 2017 US Open.

title: Petra Kvitová career statistics
text: Kvitová reached her career-high ranking of world no. 2 on 31 October 2011.

title: Jamie Murray career statistics
text: Jamie Murray is a professional tennis player who is the current British number one doubles player.

title: Jamie Murray career statistics
text: He has reached eight grand slam finals in total: (4 Doubles, 4 Mixed), he has won the mixed doubles at the 2007 Wimbledon Championships, 2017 Wimbledon Championships and 2017 US Open, and the men's doubles at the 2016 Australian Open and 2016 US Open, and has finished as runner-up in the men's doubles tournament at the 2015 Wimbledon Championships and 2015 US Open and in mixed doubles at the 2008 US Open.

title: Jamie Murray career statistics
text: Murray has been ranked as high as World No. 1 in the ATP doubles rankings, and was the first Britain to be ranked as world number one since the introduction of computerised world rankings in the 1970s.

title: Jamie Murray career statistics
text: He is currently ranked at world No. 5.

title: 2017 US Open Series
text: In tennis, the 2017 US Open Series was the fourteenth edition of the US Open Series, which comprised a group of hard court tournaments that started on July 24, 2017 in Atlanta and concluded in Connecticut for the women and in Winston-Salem for the men on August 26, 2017.

title: 2017 US Open Series
text: This edition consisted of three separate men's tournaments and three women's tournaments, with the Western & Southern Open hosting both a men's and women's event.

title: 2017 US Open Series
text: The series was headlined by two ATP World Tour Masters 1000 and two WTA Premier 5 events.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: In tennis, the 2014 US Open Series (known as Emirates Airline US Open Series for sponsorship reasons) was the eleventh edition of the US Open Series, which included nine hard court tournaments that started on July 21, 2014 in Atlanta and concluded in Winston-Salem for the men and in New Haven for the women on August 23, 2014.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: This edition consisted of four separate men's tournaments and three women's tournaments, with the Western & Southern Open hosting both a men's and women's event.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: The series was headlined by two ATP World Tour Masters 1000 and two WTA Premier 5 events.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: Milos Raonic and Serena Williams were the US Open Series champions in 2014.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: Serena Williams improved the biggest payout in professional tennis history record which she previously shared with Rafael Nadal.

title: 2014 US Open Series
text: The new record was then set at $4 million.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: The 2012 US Open Men's Singles final was the championship tennis match of the Men's Singles tournament at the 2012 US Open.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: In the final, Andy Murray defeated defending champion Novak Djokovic 7–6, 7–5, 2–6, 3–6, 6–2 to win the match.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: It was the equal-longest US Open men's final in history, lasting 4 hours and 54 minutes (equalling the 1988 US Open final played by Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander), and the equal second-longest men's final in the Open era, only behind the 2012 Australian Open final.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: By winning the 2012 US Open, Murray became the first British man since Fred Perry in 1936 to win a Grand Slam singles title, and the first British man in the Open Era to do so.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: The match is a significant part of the rivalry between the two players.

title: 2012 US Open – Men's singles final
text: This match also marked a milestone for Murray, as it was his 100th match win at a grand slam tournament.

title: Bernhard Vogel (politician)
text: Bernhard Vogel (born 19 December 1932) is a German politician (CDU).

title: Bernhard Vogel (politician)
text: He was the 4th Minister President of Rhineland-Palatinate from 1976 to 1988 and the 2nd Minister President of Thuringia from 1992 to 2003.

title: Bernhard Vogel (politician)
text: He is the only person to have been head of two different German federal states and is the longest governing Minister President of Germany.

title: Bernhard Vogel (politician)
text: He served as the 28th and 40th President of the Bundesrat in 1976/77 and 1987/88.

title: 2/40th Battalion (Australia)
text: The 2/40th Battalion was an infantry battalion of the Australian Army.

title: 2/40th Battalion (Australia)
text: Formed in mid-1940 from personnel recruited from Tasmania, the battalion was assigned to the 23rd Brigade, which formed part of the 8th Division.

title: 2/40th Battalion (Australia)
text: After completing basic training, the 2/40th was sent to Darwin to form part of the defensive garrison there as tensions with the Japanese grew throughout 1941.

title: 2/40th Battalion (Australia)
text: Following Japan's entry into the war, the battalion was deployed to Timor as part of Sparrow Force and in early 1942 they took part in the fighting on the island against the Japanese.

title: 2/40th Battalion (Australia)
text: Outnumbered and lacking supplies, the majority of the 2/40th's personnel were captured and spent the rest of the war as prisoners of war, although some were able to wage a guerrilla campaign across the island before being withdrawn by the end of year.

title: Gerald Ford
text: Gerald Rudolph Ford Jr. (born Leslie Lynch King Jr.; July 14, 1913 – December 26, 2006) was an American politician who served as the 38th President of the United States from August 1974 to January 1977, following the resignation of Richard Nixon.

title: Gerald Ford
text: Prior to this he served eight months as the 40th Vice President of the United States, following the resignation of Spiro Agnew.

title: Gerald Ford
text: He was the first person appointed to the vice presidency under the terms of the 25th Amendment, and consequently the only person to have served as both Vice President and President of the United States without being elected to executive office.

title: Gerald Ford
text: Before his appointment to the vice presidency, Ford served 25 years as U.S. Representative from Michigan's 5th congressional district, the final nine of them as the House Minority Leader.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: The community of Wyman Park is a border community that links Hampden to Roland Park.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: All of the Wyman Park area was annexed to Baltimore City in 1888.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: The general boundaries consist of the area from south to north between 33rd Street and 40th Streets and west to east from Keswick Road to Wyman Park.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: South of 40th Street, garden apartments, multi-story apartment buildings and single-family residences have been built.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: People here tend to relate to the north along 40th Street and University Parkway and The Johns Hopkins University.

title: Wyman Park, Baltimore
text: The Wyman Park also accommodates the Union Soldiers and Sailors Monument, located at 29th and Charles Street.

title: 40th Regiment
text: 40th Regiment, 40th Infantry Regiment or 40th Armoured Regiment may refer to:

title: Walt Zeboski
text: Walt Zeboski (died 12 November 2012), was an American photographer and photojournalist for the Associated Press for more than thirty years.

title: Walt Zeboski
text: Zeboski extensively photographed Ronald Reagan during his 1980 presidential campaign, snapping some of the most iconic pictures of Reagan's campaign.

title: Walt Zeboski
text: Zeboski, who often focused on California politics, covered the political terms of four consecutive Governors of California from the 1960s to the 1980s - Pat Brown, Ronald Reagan, Jerry Brown and George Deukmejian.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: The 40th Battalion was an infantry battalion of the Australian Army.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: Raised in 1916 as part of the Australian Imperial Force during the First World War, the battalion was recruited completely from Tasmania as part of the 10th Brigade, 3rd Division.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: During the war the battalion served in the trenches along the Western Front and had the distinction of having two of its members awarded the Victoria Cross.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: The battalion was disbanded in 1919, however was re-raised in 1921 as part of the Citizens Force, serving as a part-time unit in Tasmania throughout the inter-war years.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: During the Second World War, the 40th remained in Australia until it was amalgamated with the 12th Battalion.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: It was disbanded in 1946, but was later re-raised in the 1950s before being subsumed into the Royal Tasmania Regiment in 1960.

title: 40th Battalion (Australia)
text: In 1987, it was merged into the 12th/40th Battalion, Royal Tasmania Regiment.

title: José Mujica
text: José Alberto "Pepe" Mujica Cordano (] ; born 20 May 1936) is a Uruguayan politician who was the 40th President of Uruguay between 2010 and 2015.

title: José Mujica
text: A former urban guerrilla fighter with the Tupamaros, he was imprisoned for 13 years during the military dictatorship in the 1970s and 1980s.

title: José Mujica
text: A member of the Broad Front coalition of left-wing parties, Mujica was Minister of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries from 2005 to 2008 and a Senator afterwards.

title: José Mujica
text: As the candidate of the Broad Front, he won the 2009 presidential election and took office as President on 1 March 2010.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: The 1960 presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy, a United States Senator from Massachusetts, began on January 2, 1960, when Kennedy formally announced his candidacy for 35th President of the United States, replacing incumbent President of the United States Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: Kennedy was nominated by the Democratic Party at the Democratic National Convention of 1960, taking place between July 11 and July 15, 1960.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: On July 15, 1960, Kennedy named Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas as his official running mate.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: Kennedy and Johnson won the election on November 8, 1960, defeating incumbent Vice President and Republican nominee Richard Nixon, who would later go on to be the 37th President of the United States.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: Kennedy and Johnson were sworn in as 35th President and 37th Vice President of the United States on January 20, 1961 respectively.

title: John F. Kennedy presidential campaign, 1960
text: Kennedy would serve as President of the United States until his death in November 1963.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: The speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan comprise the seminal oratory of the 40th President of the United States.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: Reagan began his career in Iowa as a radio broadcaster.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: In 1937, he moved to Los Angeles where he started acting, first in films and later television.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: After delivering a stirring speech in support of Barry Goldwater's presidential candidacy in 1964, he was persuaded to seek the California governorship, winning two years later and again in 1970.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: In 1980 as the Republican candidate for president of the United States, he defeated incumbent Jimmy Carter.

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: He was reelected in a landslide in 1984, proclaiming that it was "Morning in America".

title: Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan
text: Reagan left office in 1989.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: Kyokusui-no-en (曲水の宴 ("Winding stream party" ) ) is a modern Japanese ceremony replicating a historical party game played by the nobility.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: Participants must compose a tanka poem beside a stream, within a time limit set by the passage of a lacquer cup of sake floating towards them on the water.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: When the cup reached the poet, they were expected to drink its contents, either as a celebration of the poem's completion or as a forfeit if they had not composed a suitable verse in time.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: The first "kyokusui-no-en" events were reportedly held in the Kofun period during the reign of Emperor Kenzō, making the ceremony around 1,500 years old.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: Other sources, however, suggest that the game originated in the Heian period, around 500 years later; it appears in scrolls from that period and is mentioned in "The Pillow Book" of Sei Shōnagon.

title: Kyokusui-no-en
text: There is also evidence of a Chinese version popularised by Wang Xizhi, which dates back as far as 353; poems composed at this event were recorded in Wang's famous work, the "Lantingji Xu".

title: Panela
text: Panela (] , Portuguese: "rapadura" ] ) is unrefined whole cane sugar, typical of Central and of Latin America in general, which is a solid form of sucrose derived from the boiling and evaporation of sugarcane juice.

title: Panela
text: Panela is known by other names in Latin America, such as piloncillo in Mexico (where "panela" refers to a type of cheese, "queso panela").

title: Panela
text: The name "piloncillo" means "little loaf", because of the traditional shape in which this smoky, caramelly and earthy sugar is produced.

title: Panela
text: It has far more flavor than brown sugar, which is generally just white sugar with a small amount of molasses added back to it.

title: Panela
text: Just like brown sugar, there are two varieties of piloncillo; one is lighter (blanco) and one darker (oscuro).

title: Panela
text: Unrefined, it is commonly used in Mexico, where it has been around for at least 500 years.

title: Panela
text: Made from crushed sugar cane, the juice is collected, boiled and poured into molds, where it hardens into blocks.

title: Panela
text: Panela is also known as rapadura in Portuguese.

title: Panela
text: In Australia the locals have aptly named it "Uluru Dust" due to its brown colour, dusty texture and dirt-like taste.

title: Panela
text: Elsewhere in the world, the word jaggery describes a similar foodstuff.

title: Panela
text: Both of them are considered non-centrifugal cane sugars.

title: Ruakuri Cave
text: Ruakuri Cave is the longest underground cave in the Waitomo area of New Zealand.

title: Ruakuri Cave
text: It was first discovered by local Māori between 400 and 500 years ago.

title: Ruakuri Cave
text: The name Ruakuri, or “den of dogs” was created when wild dogs were discovered making their home in the cave entrance some 300 years later.

title: 500 Years Later
text: 500 Years Later (፭፻ ዓመታት በኋላ "500 ʿamätatə bähwala ") is an independent documentary film directed by Owen 'Alik Shahadah, written by M. K. Asante, Jr. and released in 2005.

title: 500 Years Later
text: It has won five international film festival awards in the category of Best Documentary (including) UNESCO "Breaking the Chains Award").

title: 500 Years Later
text: Other awards it has won include "Best Documentary at the Pan African (Los Angeles) and Bridgetown (Barbados) Film Festivals; Best Film at the International Black Cinema (Berlin) Film Festival; and Best International Documentary at the Harlem (New York) International Film Festival".

title: Motherland (2010 film)
text: Motherland (እናት ሀገር "ˀənatə hägär ") is a 2010 independent documentary film directed and written by Owen 'Alik Shahadah.

title: Motherland (2010 film)
text: "Motherland" is the sequel to the 2005 documentary "500 Years Later".

title: Ife Piankhi
text: Ife Piankhi is a Ugandan poet, singer, creative facilitator and educator.

title: Ife Piankhi
text: She has collaborated with artists such as Keko, Nneka, Mamoud Guinea, Geoff Wilkinson, Michael Franti, Jonzi D, Wynton Marsalis, Floetry, among others.

title: Ife Piankhi
text: She has toured internationally for the past 22 years visiting Canada, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Zanzibar, Zambia, Romania, Italy, Holland, and USA.

title: Ife Piankhi
text: Whilst living in London she was a regular on Colourful Radio founded by Henry Bonsu.

title: Ife Piankhi
text: She has been featured in the documentaries 500 years later by Owen Shahadah and Nubian Spirit by Louis Buckley which highlight her knowledge of Nile Valley Civilisations.

title: Ife Piankhi
text: She is also resident poet and MC for Poetry in Session the longest running poetry event in Kampala to date.

title: Idiocracy
text: Idiocracy is a 2006 American satirical science fiction comedy film directed by Mike Judge and starring Luke Wilson, Maya Rudolph, and Dax Shepard.

title: Idiocracy
text: The film tells the story of two people who take part in a top-secret military human hibernation experiment, only to awaken 500 years later in a dystopian society where advertising, commercialism, and cultural anti-intellectualism have run rampant, and which is devoid of intellectual curiosity, social responsibility, and coherent notions of justice and human rights.

title: Tukufu Zuberi
text: Tukufu Zuberi (born April 26, 1959) is an American sociologist, filmmaker, social critic, educator, and writer.

title: Tukufu Zuberi
text: Zuberi has appeared in several documentaries on Africa and the African diaspora, including "" (2002), and "500 Years Later" (2005).

title: Tukufu Zuberi
text: He is one of the hosts of the long-running PBS program "History Detectives".

title: Tukufu Zuberi
text: As founder of his own production company, he produced the film "African Independence", which premiered at the San Diego Black Film Festival in January 2013.

title: Tukufu Zuberi
text: He is the Lasry Family Professor of Race Relations, Professor and Chair of the Sociology Department, and professor of Africana Studies at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Elizabeth Martínez
text: Elizabeth "Betita" Martínez (born December 12, 1925) is an American Chicana feminist and a long-time community organizer, activist, author, and educator.

title: Elizabeth Martínez
text: She has written numerous books and articles on different topics relating to social movements in the Americas.

title: Elizabeth Martínez
text: Her best-known work is the bilingual "500 years of Chicano History in Pictures", which later formed the basis for the educational video "¡Viva la Causa!

title: Elizabeth Martínez
text: 500 Years of Chicano History".

title: Elizabeth Martínez
text: Her work has been hailed by Angela Y. Davis as comprising "one of the most important living histories of progressive activism in the contemporary era ...  inimitable ... irrepressible ... indefatigable."

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako Mitchell is a British-American actor and filmmaker.

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako directed and co-wrote the short film "I'm in the corner with the bluebells" part of the international shorts competition at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako recently played “Klook” in “Klook’s Last Stand” at London’s Park Theatre where he received an Off West End Awards Best Actor nomination.

title: Ako Mitchell
text: He also recently played esteemed British actor Lenny Henry's brother in Fences in the West End.

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako has also worked at London’s Donmar Warehouse and played opposite Patina Miller in Sister Act at The London Palladium.

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako’s credits also include: Pilot in Nick Lloyd Webber’s The Little Prince (Savoy Theatre); Mitch in Spelling Bee (Donmar Warehouse); Mufasa in The Lion King (Lyceum Theatre-West End); Coalhouse Walker Jr. in Ragtime (Charing Cross Theatre) and Dennis in Lake Placid: The Final Chapter (Film).

title: Ako Mitchell
text: Ako also Co-produced the documentary film 500 Years Later, a winner at the Pan-African Film Festival, Black Berlin International Cinema and Harlem International Film Festival.
